title: A Morality Play Set to a Hip-Hop Beat
description: IT started as a gospel revue with no point of view, and it played the Toursky in Marseilles, France, and the Lyric in Baltimore as ''Golden Gate.'' Five years, three titles and 11 composers later, George Faison's brainchild has turned into a book musical with a message. It goes by the name ''Heaven and the Homeboy''; Theaterfest has it, and Mr. Faison, who won the 1975 Tony Award for best choreography for ''The Wiz,'' is now talking Broadway. Or not.

title: Mabel Brandon and Louis Cabot
description: Mabel Hobart Brandon, a former White House social secretary, was married yesterday to Louis Wellington Cabot, a former chairman of the Cabot Corporation, the Boston chemical company. The Rev. Carl Scovel performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Middleburg, Va.

title: Down at the Heel
description: When we landed in Rome in the Spring of 1994, after a Winter in Maine and Manhattan respectively, my friend Nancy Harmon Jenkins and I were each beginning to look as bad as our passport photos. Hoping that an adventure might fill in the lines that stress and tedium had etched on our middle-aged faces, we headed south toward the rocky heel of Italy, not knowing the extent to which Puglia -- or Apulia, as it's often called in English -- would warm and soften our souls.

title: In French Race, Economy Will Sour the Victor's Future
description: Francois Barbey, unemployed like 12.8 percent of the rest of the French working-age population, plans to vote for President Jacques Chirac's conservatives Sunday in the decisive round of the French parliamentary elections. But he says he fears that social and economic turbulence will lie ahead no matter who wins.

title: A Stay in the Country
description: WE arrived at Marlfield House, a gorgeous Irish country house hotel, in a highly bedraggled state. My husband, Robert, and I were exhausted from three months of new parenthood. We were tired out from hours of driving through intermittent rain on back roads, stuck behind ancient Irish farm vehicles piloted by ancient Irish farmers. And we were traumatized from our experience at a very expensive and spectacularly unpleasant hotel the night before.

description: French voters go to the polls today for the second time in a week to elect a new legislature, one that looks likely to give President Jacques Chirac a lot of trouble as he prepares France for a new common European currency starting in 1999.

description: DENNIS R. BERESFORD, who has been chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board for a turbulent decade, will step down at the end of this month. During his tenure, the board forced companies to begin recognizing the cost of post-retirement benefits while employees are still working. That angered many companies, but is now generally viewed as wise.

title: When Talk Radio Meant Listening
description: IT was five minutes to air time for the 11 A.M. Virginia Wren talk show on Danbury station WLAD-AM one day in the late 1970's. The host and the guest -- a touring European hypnotist of the day named Hans Poigar -- faced off across the microphone, waiting for the show to start. ''I can hypnotize you and stop you from speaking just by snapping my fingers,'' he boasted. ''Oh, no, you can't,'' scoffed the program host, Virginia Wren. ''Nobody has ever hypnotized me.''

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Dear Cousin Julius
description: I thank Michael Winerip for bringing the touching and tragic story of Max Schohl to the attention of your readers ('''Dear Cousin Julius, We Trust on Our God and on You,''' April 27). Kaethe Schohl, Max's daughter, was my childhood sweetheart. I left Germany and the Nazis behind in 1937 and came to the United States. I had lost track of Kaethe after she and her family escaped to Yugoslavia and thus had not seen or spoken to her in 60 years. It was your article that told me what had happened and where she was. After reading it, I obtained her phone number and called her. It was a most exciting, happy and long conversation after all these years. Afterward, I felt as if I were 15 again.

title: Cure for Party Blahs: A Little Light Magic
description: WHEN Food and Wine magazine chose a place for its annual ''Best New Chefs'' party, it went for an appropriately foodie site, a renovated Nabisco cookie factory at Chelsea Markets, the maze of food shops at 10th Avenue and 15th Street.

title: Lottery Numbers Came In, and So Did the Crowds
description: George Conroy, a 56-year-old Metro North Railroad police officer from Rye, N.Y., started wagering on Thursday, the morning that the lottery jackpot, still not won after five drawings, rocketed to $70 million.

title: The Amazon Celebrated At the Peabody
description: GROWING concern over the survival of the rain forest has focused new attention on the Amazonian people and their culture. At the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven, ''Rather than concentrate on the biological impact of deforestation, we're focusing on cultures whose traditional life ways depend on the tropical forest habitats,'' said Richard L. Burger, director of the museum.

title: The Horror: Updating the Heart of Darkness
description: THE END OF THE MILLENNIUM approaches, and not surprisingly, many observers detect a certain morbidity, something that might be called Gothic, in the cultural ether. Putting aside real-life events like the Heaven's Gate tragedy, there's Goth rock, Goth lit and Goth girls and guys in Goth fashions. There are horror and sci-fi films with ever more anxious-making special effects and intimations of apocalypse, variously natural and self-inflicted. In academic circles, theories concerning the grotesque, the uncanny and carnival are in vogue, perhaps partly as a backlash against the stricter, more politically correct, identity-oriented theory that dominated the early 90's. Now there's an exhibition at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston intent on ferreting out the Gothic in contemporary art.

description: HARDCOVER

title: In New Jersey, a Push To Impress the Voters
description: With three days to go before the primary in New Jersey, the three Democratic candidates seeking to challenge Gov. Christine Todd Whitman reached out to black and Hispanic voters. But if conversations with two dozen people in the working-class city of Linden are any indication, they are not the only ones whose thoughts on the Democratic candidates are muddled. Although most people interviewed said they would vote in the primary, fewer than half knew whom they would support.

title: Yonkers Jumps Ahead for an Opera Premiere
description: IT is not often that Yonkers is given the honor of an American operatic premiere, but that will happen next Sunday when -- in advance of its performance at Alice Tully Hall in Manhattan -- Opera Manhattan brings Massenet's ''Cleopatre'' to Sarah Lawrence College. The artistic director, Gabriel Guimaraes, will conduct a small chorus, a nine-instrument ensemble and several soloists, among them Keren Bernbaum, an alumna of Sarah Lawrence, and in the title role Marion Capriotti. The number to call for more details is 395-2411. .

Tristan Perich, 14, will be leaving his family in Katonah to attend the Andover School in Massachusetts. Justine Landegger, 14, of Ridgefield, will attend the Taft School in Waterbury. title: The Watergate Lock
description: The four-pound brass lock that once stood guard, ineffectually, at the Watergate complex in Washington as burglars broke into the Democratic National Committed headquaters drew a $13,000 bid at an auction last week. The lock's owner, Jim Herrald, a retired Watergate superintendent, has not accepted the bid. He is still waiting for a better offer.

title: Setting Past Aside, Russia and Ukraine Sign Friendship Treaty
description: After years of doubt and tensions, the Presidents of Russia and Ukraine today signed a friendship treaty designed to strengthen the weak bonds between the two Slavic states.

title: Demand Grows For Hourly Workers
description: IT is 8 A.M. on a weekday, and as a crush of highly paid executives heads for work along a strip of corporate office parks in Tarrytown, Linny Dung, 23, puts on a checkered apron at the Westchester Marriott Hotel and prepares for the long day ahead. A determined worker, Mr. Dung wants to save enough money to open a restaurant of his own someday. But for now the Vietnamese immigrant is content to be known as the waiter who tells jokes as he serves meals -- earning $3.64 an hour plus tips but honing the skills he will need for the future.

description: THE State Supreme Court ruling that overturned her school finance law was a major policy defeat for Governor Whitman. But that doesn't mean it will be a political setback. This isn't so much about politics as the disconnect between politics and policy. We tend not to debate the great issues in election campaigns; that would be risky.

title: A Rural Town Fights to Save Its Green
description: A BED of straw cushions the back of Donald S. Francis's pickup truck as he drives along the Town of Brooklyn's winding roads. He also has a harness called a cow halter handy. Mr. Francis says catching a stray farm animal wandering onto the road -- though not a typical responsibility of a First Selectman -- comes with the territory in his rural town.

title: Requiem For a Bookstore
description: HOW many writers does it take to bury a bookstore? If it is Books & Company -- the popular Upper East Side literary haunt that recently lost a real estate battle with its landlord, the Whitney Museum -- it takes a legion. There were writers on the street outside the small store and writers on the stairs, and then there were the writers on the walls -- photographs of all the authors who had read there over the last 20 years: Robertson Davies, Philip Roth, James Merrill, Susan Sontag, Cynthia Ozick.

title: The Dangerous Art of Walking
description: WALKING is the perfect exercise. It's good for the heart, gentle to the joints, needs no equipment and is easy on the pocketbook. The only problem -- it is against the law in Long Island. Or so it would seem, since walking is such a hazardous activity in the suburbs. The only time you see the word ''pedestrian'' in the newspaper, it's followed by ''was hit by a car crossing Jericho Turnpike'' (that, or it refers to a mediocre menu at an unhip Hamptons soiree). Thereare so many dangers and discouragements to walking, it's as if the streets were ruled by one big ''Don't Walk'' sign.

title: It's Time to Take the First Step in Pool Maintenance: the Filter
description: SWIMMING pools can make a hot summer more pleasant, but they do require maintenance to keep them safe and clean. Whether you choose to do these chores yourself or hire a professional, you should have some understanding of the swimming pool system. Knowledge of the basics can help you to solve simple problems and prevent costly service calls.

title: Art Exodus

More than $1 billion worth of ceramics, bronzes, furniture, paintings and porcelains have been flowing out of Hong Kong recently, because residents fear that China may restrict the export of art and antiques after it takes control from Britain on July 1. Chinese officials have said nothing to quell owners' anxieties.

title: Learning Poverty Firsthand
description: The majority of those who have had to depend upon welfare are not living in the lap of luxury. Nor are they having scores of children out of wedlock just to get a few extra bucks to buy liquor or to support a cocaine habit. Of course, there have been several high-profile cases in which individuals have been caught bilking the system. I think these are rare. Unfortunately, the actions of a few have unfairly skewed public opinion against the welfare system and its dependents.

title: BAAAD MOLE
description: Anthony Catania got suspicious when his floor started to shake. For weeks, sewer diggers had been tearing up the street in front of his restaurant-supply store in Seattle. Among the deployed tools was a tunnel-digging robot ''mole,'' a $475,000, 18-foot-long device that can chew through 70 feet of soil a day using programmed directional coordinates. The machine has been doing solid yeoman's work for years, but this time somebody programmed it incorrectly. Catania realized this when he saw 11 hard hats peering expectantly into a 30-foot-deep hole in the street, one muttering, ''Our mole is supposed to come out here but we haven't seen it.'' Eventually recovered without damaging Catania's property, the wayward mole left behind a 700-foot hole that will have to be filled with concrete. Cost: $600,000.

On my right, Bantry Bay stretched four slate-gray miles to the Beara Peninsula, framed by the Caha range; on my left, the road plunged to the lush-green valley of Kilcrohane; behind and in front of me were the purple-heathered hills and mountains that ridge the peninsula.

title: Parallel, Vertical and Serious

The superb fitting of a master tailor is needed to give the uniform its status and to insure its investment quality and longevity. Any deviation from the rules is perceived as subversive, but individual expression can be achieved through the fold of a pocket handkerchief, a flamboyant tie, a boutonniere or, on rare occasions, a rakish hat. Designers recently added shoulder epaulets to the classic pinstripe suit for fashionably progressive men and women, like the one at top far right.

title: Dear Cousin Julius

I was returning home as a 17-year-old, after having lived in Europe for more than 15 years. I remember the boat well, a 15,000-ton Liberty ship, full of refugees from war-torn Europe, remnants of P.O.W. camps (myself) and concentration camps, undernourished and still very hungry until we embarked. Once on the boat, the selection of quality food in unlimited quantities was unbelievable.

title: A Ferry Ride Away: Fire Island's Lure

In addition to its natural mainland wonders for year-round residents, renters and day trippers, Long Island also offers the unspoiled beaches of Fire Island, just a ferry ride away. Last Sunday, on the first warm day of the year, young people, many of whom left their Long Island nests to seek fortunes elsewhere, returned by ferry to enjoy the sea air, the pristine beaches and the absence of automobiles. The Fire Island experience is a mighty tug on those who want the sun, sand and the unparalleled social life. And the summer is just starting. STEWART KAMPEL

My mother, Martha Gomberg, received one -- a cable from a distant cousin in danger in Vienna. My mother gathered our family's available funds ($600, I believe) and went from Cleveland to Cuba. Somehow she managed to meet with the president-dictator, Fulgencio Batista, give him the money and ask him to issue visas for her cousin's family: a mother, father and 12-year-old son. I think she had never before been south of Ohio.

description: SILVERMAN-Harry T. Ten years have passed so quickly since you left us. Your loved ones still love, mourn and miss you.

description: City Hall's plan to turn Coney Island Hospital over to a private, for-profit company is threatening to unravel over several issues, including labor and court disputes, changes in tax regulations and possible financial problems facing the buyers.

title: Matthew Turner and Abby Sigal

title: Expansion of Whitman Visitors' Center Helps Honor Native Son
description: WALT WHITMAN would have turned 178 yesterday. But instead of merely blowing out candles on an enormous cake, Long Islanders were dedicating an impressive monument to their native son.

title: When Folkways Point the Way To Innovation
description: MEN AND WOMEN STOOD IN the aisle at Symphony Space early last month and talked intently of the merits of that night's program of sacred hula dancing from rural Hawaii. The conversation soon shifted to a program the same week by Shobana Jeyasingh, a choreographer from London who mixes modern dance and Indian traditional dance. ''And have you seen 'Flamenco' yet?'' one man suddenly exclaimed. ''The best dance film ever made!''

title: Cream and Sugar? Philosophical Discourse?
description: The subject on the table is destiny. And because the Heaven's Gate cult has recently committed suicide, flying saucers are on the agenda, too. So, for that matter, is the question of belief.

title: Elizabeth Curran, R. W. Stockton Jr.

title: Fifth Ave. Crime Now an Inside Job
description: As in much of the city, street crime has declined along Fifth Avenue in midtown, the tony arrondisement of Bergdorf Goodman, Tiffany & Company and Cartier, which was for years a lucrative home to a Dickensian crew of pickpockets, purse snatchers and con artists preying on tourists from around the world. In fact, such crime has dropped so sharply in recent years that the Fifth Avenue Business Improvement District and its 24-member security staff are moving along to a new and in some ways more challenging frontier: crimes inside buildings.

title: Dear Cousin Julius
description: I was a little girl, 7 years old, in Germany when my father began efforts to get us out. Until I read these letters, I never realized or appreciated how difficult it must have been for him to ask for help, and how wonderful were those who helped!

title: Dear Cousin Julius
description: Your article touched a nerve and reawakened feelings of bitterness I thought I had buried. I am referring to the excessively rigid and hostile attitudes of the United States consular authorities. Many, including my parents, had gathered the complicated documents necessary for an immigration visa and eventually went to their deaths in the extermination camps while the American authorities procrastinated. It is difficult to avoid suspicions of conspiracies and sabotage on orders from above when looking at the record.

title: Gebrselassie Breaks Record, But Not Bank, in 2-Mile Race
description: It was one of the stranger scenes in track and field history.

Mass of the Resurrection at St Mary's Church, 10 am, visitation Saturday and Sunday, 2:00-5:00 and 7:00 to 9:00 pm.

title: Two on the Aisle
description: Broadway's big night is bigger this year. It takes a network and public television to do it justice. The 1997 TONY AWARDS start at 8 P.M. on PBS and then move to CBS at 9. Rosie O'Donnell, who was in ''Grease!'' in 1994, plays host for both portions, at Radio City Music Hall. Nearly two dozen awards will be presented --from best direction and choreography to those for leading actor and actress, and best play and musical. Performers in the musicals ''Titanic,'' ''The Life'' and ''Steel Pier'' will strut their stuff, and segments from dramas and revivals are represented. Adding stardust to the gala are Julie Andrews, Christine Baranski, Glenn Close, Martin Short and Whoopi Goldberg.

title: Does It Pay to Shop At the Supermarket?
description: As more mutual fund shareholders consolidate their accounts in fund ''supermarkets'' like Charles Schwab's One Source and Fidelity Investments' Funds Network, they should know that these services do not come free.

title: In a Final Push, Gubernatorial Candidates Seek Black and Hispanic Support
description: With only three days left before Tuesday's primary, the three Democratic candidates seeking the nomination to challenge Gov. Christine Todd Whitman this fall reached out today to black and Hispanic voters from Newark to Camden.

title: Caroline M. Carey, James K. Langan
description: Caroline Mary Carey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Carey of East Dennis, Mass., was married yesterday to James Kennedy Langan, a son of the late Isabelle and Leo Langan. Thomas Byrne, the Mayor of Spring Lake, N.J., officiated at a residence there.

title: I Am More Than Hands
description: The response of readers (Letters, May 4) to Bendetson's account of caring for her sick husband suggests a new phenomenon: the care-giver as victim. We now have the predictable ''support groups'' and experts, and we can look forward to ''recovery movements,'' with the attendant psychobabble.

title: The Unorthodox Politics of an Ultra-Orthodox Rebel
description: Every morning at exactly 9 o'clock, Rabbi Aryeh Deri enters the downstairs room of a Jerusalem synagogue and sits at a small table, opposite a white wood Torah ark with gold-plated flames leaping from its facade. Unlighted pipe in hand, he begins swaying over a volume of the Talmud, instantly lost in rabbinic disputes. He remains seated until a lunch break four hours later. If fellow students at adjacent tables wander over to discuss worldly affairs, he waves them away: the morning hours are consecrated to study. In this room, surrounded by bearded men dressed as he is, in dark suits and black velvet yarmulkes, Aryeh Deri is a stalwart of the law -- the only law that matters to him. Here, in the closest Jewish equivalent to a monastic retreat, he is appreciated as what one fellow student admiringly calls ''a fierce pilpulist,'' exposing hidden loopholes in the Talmudic text.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRANDT, MAY
description: BRANDT-May. June 2, 1979. You are never far. The Family

title: Suzanne Shiles, Peter Fleming 3d
description: Suzanne Jane Shiles, an insurance consultant, and Peter Emmet Fleming 3d, a lawyer, were married yesterday in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Whitney H. Burr performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church.

title: Crash
description: What purpose is served by printing such juvenilia as J.S. Marcus's Lives column ''Crash'' (May 11)? Is it, perhaps, to serve as a sort of proof of Michiko Kakutani's essay ''Adolescence Rules!'' in the same issue? The death of a parent is, for most of us, a time of sorrow and introspection. Marcus seems, however, to have seized upon the event as an excuse to act as irresponsibly as a drunken teen-ager.

title: Rising Outcry in Argentina as Economic Reform Pinches
description: With violent protests over high unemployment and poverty spreading rapidly and congressional elections set for October, the Argentine Government has come under more pressure than ever before to loosen its economic policies, which have brought fiscal stability and tremendous growth but have failed to produce new jobs and better social conditions for many people.

title: Black Circus Seeks to Stir And Inspire
description: It was nearing 9:30 P.M. on Wednesday. The big-top tent of the Universoul Circus at 120th Street and Madison Avenue was bursting with energy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 29 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the opera ''Lilith'' carries an outdated reference to its premiere and performance schedule at the Dicapo Opera Theater in Manhattan. After the section went to press, the production was canceled because of a labor dispute.

title: In This Third-Grade Class, the Curriculum Includes Reading, Writing and Respect
description: Daniel Hessel thought he was being helpful when he urged a fellow third grader to put away his toys one afternoon in April.

title: Singer-Songwriters Of a New Generation Rewrite the Rules
description: AMONG THE KUDOS GREETING the singer-songwriter Ron Sex smith's 1995 debut album, ''Ron Sexsmith,'' was one critic's announcement that it contained ''some of the best new folk writing since Beck.'' Since Beck? Beck may be the hippest polyester-clad punk-rock soul man in pop, but few folk devotees would declare him a descendant of Woody Guthrie.

title: Carolyn Reed, Brad Arthur
description: Carolyn Walton Reed, the daughter of Mrs. James Hutton Sepull Jr. and the stepdaughter of Mr. Sepull of Edgewater, Md., was married yesterday to Lieut. (j.g.) Brad Lee Arthur of the Navy, a son of Adm. and Mrs. Stanley Roger Arthur of Vienna, Va. The Rev. Winslow Shaw officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Annapolis, Md.

title: Mine Labor In Congo Dims Luster In Diamonds
description: Slumped on the dirt floor, so exhausted that he ignored the huge tarantula crawling on the wall of the mud shack, Andre Onyumbe did not seem overwhelmed by the romance of diamonds.

title: Ciao, Charivari. Hello, Hair?
description: WHEN the ''Final Sale'' signs went up in the windows of Charivari at Columbus Avenue and 72d Street in March, many real-estate brokers and merchants saw its closing as the end of an era.

title: No Verdict in Denver
description: Deliberations continued for a second day today with no verdict in the trial of Timothy J. McVeigh, who is accused in the Oklahoma City bombing. The jury recessed at 5 P.M., and will reconvene this morning.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: DENVER
description: When the cameras zoom in on Denver, where a three-day economic summit of world leaders will be held this month, some residents may try to ward off the international exposure with an outdated protective mantra: ''Cow town, brown cloud; cow town, brown cloud.''

title: Settling A Feud In Only 15 Seconds
description: With $1 million on the line, the Olympic champions Michael Johnson and Donovan Bailey will sprint 150 meters on Sunday to decide the unofficial title of world's fastest man. The match race at the Skydome is expected to take less than 15 seconds, which is a good thing, because the sprinters apparently cannot stand each other's company for much longer than that.

title: When the Log Cabin Was Monticello
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Rights in the Americas
description: Human rights commissions appointed by governments are generally timid, but the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights is an admirable exception. Countries recently criticized by the commission, however, like Peru and Mexico, are now pressing to restrict its activities. Guatemala is trying to get a politician closely associated with past military repression appointed to the organization. The United States must campaign vigorously at this week's meeting of the Organization of American States in Lima, Peru, to defeat both efforts.

title: Segregation Anew
description: After dismantling affirmative-action programs, the public universities of Texas and California have witnessed ominous declines in black and Latino enrollment, raising fears that universities in these ethnically diverse states could one day become overwhelmingly white. Fearing rejection, many black and Latino students have decided not to apply at all. In addition, educators foresee a new minority ''brain drain,'' as outstanding students who do win acceptance opt for rival states, driven away by fears of racial isolation. The new segregation endangers the social coherence of both Texas and California. Educators and political leaders will need to work vigorously to reopen educational access and avoid long-term division.

title: Making Music And Turning Heads
description: YOU NEED AT LEAST $100,000 to have an art-case piano made these days; that is, a specially designed one. After all, you can't just plunk an ordinary black, shiny baby grand in your Montana lodge and expect to be taken seriously. What you need -- and the architect John Diebboll has designed -- is a log-cabin piano, something rustic in maple and birch, each piece taken from a log and left unfinished. As Mr. Diebboll describes it, ''When you see it, you can identify each tree.''

title: The Clinton Conundrum
description: As the first summer of Bill Clinton's second term approaches, that peculiar mixture of the admirable and degrading continues to distinguish his Presidency. How else to describe the twin spectacles of last week? There was Mr. Clinton, elder statesman baby boomer, confidently bantering with Prime Minister Tony Blair in London and rewriting the political map of Europe, even while becoming more enmeshed at home in what surely are the most lurid accusations ever directed against a sitting President. The American economic boom is helping to keep Mr. Clinton's approval ratings at an all-time high, yet a sense of personal scandal makes this a Presidency constantly on the edge.

title: On Reading Pope's Homer
description: In 1713, when he was only 25 years old, Alexander Pope assumed a momentous risk. Barred by his Roman Catholic religion from the normal apparatus of Government and private patronage, he took subscriptions for a large-scale project that filled his life for the next seven years and established his absolute pre-eminence among the poets of his time. The result was a version of Homer's ''Iliad'' that Samuel Johnson pronounced the greatest translation ever achieved in English or in any other language.

title: Fox Broadcasts Tape of Torre's Expletive
description: In its initial broadcast of the season yesterday, Fox Sports wired Yankee Manager Joe Torre for sound and came to regret it.

title: Fighting Words
description: Unlike my literary peers in the United States and the Rest of Canada - or the R.O.C., as it is now known here in Quebec - I can no longer scribble in English with impunity, which makes for a certain frisson. The Commission de Protection de la Langue Fran-->aise has dispersed 15 inspectors, each of them armed with a tape measure and color chart, to make sure that English lettering on outdoor commercial signs is half the size of the French, and that perfidious Anglophones haven't painted their half-pint messages in colors more alluring than the French. If Quebec's language laws tighten just one more notch, I may have to write my novels in words half the size of the French so as not to antagonize our linguistic vigilantes. I have already had to take down the billboard rooted in the field opposite our cottage on Lake Memphremagog:

But the book can also be read as a crypto-business story, full of object lessons about teamwork, strategy and the conflicts of work versus home.

description: WHILE location may be everything, as real estate agents say, there are those who contend that in many Westchester communities ''school district'' can be substituted for ''location.''

description: TWO cockney schemers in London, a French sailor in Marseilles and a destructive house guest in New England command attention in choice films on television this week.

title: In Kids' Pop Culture, Fear Rules
description: Her laugh turned to a moan at the first ripple in her bones. She tensed her thighs and abdomen to will the change on, and clutched the night air like a lover as her fingers lengthened and her nails sprouted. Her blood churned with heat like desire. The night, she thought, sweet night.

title: Betts Gabrielsen, Eldon C. Mayer Jr.
description: Betts Shanhouse Gabrielsen, a psychotherapist, and Eldon C. Mayer Jr., an investment manager, are to be married today in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Dr. R. Maurice Boyd, a nondenominational minister, is to perform the ceremony in the Prospect House at Princeton University.

title: Time to Play?
description: Vacation season is begining, and many bosses will take some extended time off within the next few months, trusting that the underlings will run the office efficiently. But is that what really happens when the boss is away? Or does everyone goof off until just before the boss returns? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. title: Learning Poverty Firsthand
description: I read with gratitude Jason DeParle's article on the sociologist Kathryn Edin, who so thoroughly debunks Charles Murray's cynical diatribes on welfare mothers (''Learning Poverty Firsthand,'' April 27). I grew up in Wisconsin, in a Scandinavian dairy community of 820 people, on tales of my ancestors' poverty in Norway and dreams fulfilled in the New World. I learned that the key to this good fortune was one of the biggest welfare programs in our history, the Homestead Act, whereby my great-grandfather was given our farm with the mere stipulation that he work the land. We still have the papers signed by Ulysses S. Grant. From those humble beginnings were produced, among others, our county's first female superintendent of schools (who held office for 30 years), a North Dakota Mother of the Year, two judges, a rural mail carrier who used a team of horses to complete his rounds in the winter, an uninterrupted stream of public-school teachers (the latest graduated in May) and me, a public-interest lawyer.

This new restaurant, at 495 Hempstead Turnpike (538-4425), like the other Brazilian and Portuguese churrascarias sweeping across the Island and city, is a place for hungry, really hungry people.

title: Deals and Discounts

Performers scheduled to appear include the Neville Brothers and Gato Barbieri. The Nice Festival '97 package includes five nights' accommodation, daily Continental breakfast and tickets to festival performances on three evenings. Prices start at $200 a person, double occupancy, and range up to $416; more than 90 hotels are participating. Air fare is additional. Information: (212) 719-5750 or (800) 847-4249.

title: Hingis Leads an Advance of Favorites at the French Open
description: Martina Hingis and Anna Kournikova, a Montague and a Capulet for their young generation, competed with the smiley civility of contestants at a Junior Miss pageant. But the Wimbledon champion, all 6 feet 5 inches of him, howled like a baby locked in a red dirt playpen today. Sometimes, Grand Slam tournaments can be hazardous to one's maturity.

title: A Cartoonist Sketches the Outline of Bosnia's Pain
description: In September 1995, as the war in Bosnia was winding to a close, an unassuming cartoonist from Malta with thick, round glasses and a worn charcoal-gray leather jacket climbed off a bus in the center of the devastated Bosnian capital.

description: A COMEDY troupe offering improvisation and music seems an unlikely beginning for the 68th summer season at Music Mountain, but Nicholas Gordon, president of the board, says it is to be a season of firsts.

description: There have been observations of Thomas Edison's 150th birthday all year, including Feb. 11, his actual birth date, but there is a concentration this summer. The anniversary is being celebrated as far away as Japan, where an international symposium is taking place this week. Closer to home, several events are coming up. For more information, call the Edison National Historic Site, (201) 736-0550, or contact the park service's Edison-related Web site at http://www.nps.gov/ edis/.

description: ALFRED RIDGEWAY is 88 and has owned Echo Farm in South Salem since 1959. For much of that time, Echo Farm was a dairy farm, producing a ton of milk a day.

title: Gardening
description: To pick and choose from the bouquet of garden books deposited on my doorstep at this time of year (''then, if ever, come perfect days'') has been a mixed pleasure. Their presence heightens the discrepancy between the ideal and the real in my own unkempt landscape. But how enjoyable it is, after a day's toil in my seven raised beds, to be an armchair gardener turning these lavishly illustrated pages.

title: A Megamall Cornerstone for a Waterbury Revival
description: UNTIL the 1950's Waterbury was the queen city of a prosperous Naugatuck Valley industrial corridor. But over the years its major factories moved away and its economy sagged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEER, HENRY I., M.D.
description: SCHNEER-Henry I., M.D. September 16, 1916 to May 29, 1997. We deeply mourn the passing of Henry I. Schneer. Dr. Schneer was Professor of Psychiatry at Downstate Medical Center and Nassau County Medical Center; President of the New York State Psychiatric Association; a lifetime member and Fellow of the American Psychoanalytic Association and the American Psychiatric Association; among other organizations. He was the author of two books, ''Adolescence,'' and ''The Asthmatic Child,'' in addition to numerous articles. Dr. Schneer was also the recipient of The Dudley Memorial Award for Surgery. He is survived by his son, Errol C. Schneer and daughter, Rose Betty Williams, as well as eight grandchildren. Services will take place on Monday, June 2nd at 11:45AM (family and friends at 11:00AM) at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York (516-764-9400). Dr. Schneer will be deeply missed by all the lives he touched.

title: Mexico Blooms in a 116th Street Barrio
description: When Guadalupe Ramirez came to East Harlem 10 years ago from Puebla, Mexico, the neighborhood offered both comfort and challenge. While the Spanish spoken by Puerto Ricans in the neighborhood diminished her alienation, Ms. Ramirez, 30, a sales assistant at Puebla Flowers on 116th Street between Second and Third Avenues, said she still had to struggle to learn Puerto Rican culture and tradition.

title: Tarzan, That Muscular Environmentalist

Visiting hours Sunday 2-5 and 7-10 PM.

title: If a Guy Is Bored With His Guy-Colored Nails
description: AS soon as Quentin Tarantino, Antonio Banderas, Lenny Kravitz and the Stone Temple Pilots started sporting Technicolor talons, it suddenly seemed more acceptable for cutting-edge guys to paint their nails.

title: NUPTIAL DETERRENTS
description: Citing the high American divorce rate, some legislators want potential newlyweds to slow down. A bill in California asks for a 90-day waiting period prior to marriage. Elaine Bloom, a state representative in Florida, is working on a similar bill that would encourage a driver's-education-style course for couples. On the just-do-it front, 100 Chicago-area couples were married last month during a mass ceremony at Six Flags Great America, aboard the Giant Drop. The Little White Chapel Drive-Up Wedding Window in Las Vegas defines haste -- couples can be married in 15 minutes, no car required. ''Roller skates are fine, too,'' says Joanie Richards, the chapel's manager. Would slowdown bills kill romance? Bloom counters, ''Does reading a driver's manual kill the romance of driving fast on a highway?''

title: Joan Paylo and William Goldschlag
description: Joan Marie Paylo and William Goldschlag were married yesterday in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, officiated at the home of Patricia Coate, a friend of the couple. Justice Louis B. York of State Supreme Court in Manhattan took part in the ceremony.

title: Top Student Has to Share Top Honors
description: FROM the beginning, Debra Polera has fought the Newburgh school district. When her daughter Santina, who is legally blind, was 5, the district was going to put her in a program for retarded children. ''I said how could this be? She's a brilliant little girl,'' Ms. Polera recalls. ''That started it all.''

title: The Father of Invention
description: THE simple version of the story of Thomas Alva Edison, the one most schoolchildren learn, is that he invented the phonograph, the incandescent light bulb and the motion picture camera.

title: Fred Allen's Other Jab
description: To the Editor:

title: From School to Church, Volunteers Help Out
description: AT the President's Summit for America's Future in Philadelphia in April, Gen. Colin L. Powell urged Americans at the volunteer conference to look into their hearts and communities and ''find someone who is in need.''

title: Big Tornado, Small Town
description: The Texas tornado that devastated the tiny hamlet of Jarrell on Tuesday was the most violent twister in the state in a decade: it killed 27 people and cleared the Double Creek Estates subdivision of almost all evidence that the neighborhood had ever existed.

title: Noelle Ellert, W. W. Sheehan 2d
description: Noelle Joy Ellert, a daughter of Barbara Ann and Roger Ellert of Cedar Grove, N.J., was married there yesterday to William Wallace Sheehan 2d, the son of the late Bernadette Sheehan and the late William Sheehan, who lived in Westport, Conn. The Rev. Kevin Schlott, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORING, MARILYN
description: LORING-Marilyn. On May 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Loving mother of Lisa and Robert. Adoring grandmother of Jacqueline and Nicolette. Service Monday, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Curtsies and Croquet
description: New York City Ballet benefits from the royal touch, a women's group gets help and Cooper-Hewitt Museum fans take to their mallets.

title: Abs-Fab Lumberjacks
description: Can a sport associated with wanton deforestation possibly capture a TV audience in these tree-hugging times? Fred and Robert Scheer think so. The brothers are the creators of the ''Ironjack Logger Sports Series,'' a new niche-market offering on cable's Outdoor Life Network. The key ingredient? A platoon of muscular, fearless lumberjacks, sensitized to the needs of the trees they whack and willing to show a little skin. ''Ironjack is where beach volleyball was 10 years ago, or rodeo,'' claims Fred. ''The all-American appeal is tremendous.'' Robert elaborates: ''There's blood, there's injuries, there's falling down, there's hard work, there's tools.'' Here's a look.

description: Correction Appended

description: GOSSIP

description: Weeks

title: Annoying the Wrong People
description: An anguished expression soon gives way to uncontrollable weeping as Ron Cole, 26, gropes to understand why he was arrested on weapons and conspiracy charges. ''I've done nothing but try to help the Government avoid bloodshed,'' says Cole (above), referring to his offers to assist the F.B.I. during past standoffs with far-right radicals. ''They're trying to make me look like a terrorist because I criticize them publicly.''

title: Lives Tangle in Park's Hidden World
description: When the two got to Carl Schurz Park around 4 P.M. that Thursday, May 22, they saw a familiar tableau of serenity and release: the sparkling East River, dogs cavorting, children scaling monkey bars and, of course, their teen-age friends, gathered along the chess tables and benches by the basketball courts, in the cool shadows of the trees.

title: Marilyn Tayler, Robert Prince
description: Dr. Marilyn Rosenbluth Tayler, the chairwoman of the legal studies department at Montclair State University in Upper Montclair, N.J., is to be married today to Robert Alexander Prince, a systems programmer at National Prescription Administrators in East Hanover, N.J. Rabbi Frederic Dworkin will officiate with the Rev. Albert Berner, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Manor, a restaurant in West Orange, N.J.

title: With Pride Rising, Chinese Count The Days to Hong Kong's Return
description: All over China, schoolchildren call out the number in unison before classes begin each morning.

title: Replacing Fixtures At a Co-op
description: Q. I live in a co-op that I own in Forest Hills, Queens. I was given a mandate by the management company to allow them to replace my toilet, shower head and faucet aerator to use less water. The new toilet left a large part of the old tile floor exposed. Since the old tile does not match the tile in the rest of the bathroom, I had to retile the entire bathroom. Since I did not ask for the new toilet and was told I had to allow it, I sent a bill to the board of directors and the managing agent asking to be reimbursed. They sent me a letter saying that since I was an owner, it was my responsibility. Do I have any recourse in this matter? . . . Selma S. Citrin, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOS, JULIE ANN
description: ROOS-Julie Ann. Beloved daughter of Roberta and Edwin, loving sister to Andrew and Peter, sisterin-law to Susan and Elisabeth, devoted aunt to Alexander, MacAlister Ethan, Kaile and Emma. Cherished friend of many around the world. Passed away from us to a better place on Tuesday, May 27, 1997. Her smile and courage touched all those who knew her, and will ease the pain of our loss. She will be dearly missed. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The National Marfan Foundation, 328 Main St, Port Washington, NY 11050. Arrangements for a memorial service are being finalized.

title: For Families, Trial Leaves Haunting Questions
description: As the trial of Timothy J. McVeigh drew to a close, leaving the jury to deliberate whether he set off the bomb that killed 168 people in Oklahoma City two years ago, many relatives of the victims watched the proceedings from 500 miles away, over closed-circuit televisions at the Mike Monroney Aeronautical Center in Oklahoma City.

title: Attracted by the Who As Well as the What
description: EVERY FIELD OF COLLECTING HAS ITS celebrities, the grand acquisitors well known within their worlds and sometimes outside them. In the realm of American Indian art of the Northwest Coast, for example, the name of James Hooper, a London sewer inspector, ranks alongside those of Capt. James Cook, the explorer, and George Gustav Heye, the museum founder. All had a taste for real or vicarious adventure and an eye for excellence in what they acquired. Their ownership considerably increases the value of an object.

title: Why Waste When Recycling Is So Savvy?
description: THE CITY OF NEW YORK HAS sent me a new booklet on recycling; and being of a civic-minded nature, I have established my green area (newspapers, threatening letters, press releases) and my blue area (empty beer cans, empty wine bottles, empty aspirin jars). According to the brochure, there is a dusty rose department, too, but I haven't figured out what goes in it yet. I read in the newspapers that my country is recycling faster and better, and that makes my bosom swell.

title: Clinton, at West Point, Says Bigger NATO Lessens Chance of War
description: President Clinton told graduating West Point cadets today that the mere prospect of NATO's expansion into the former Soviet bloc had increased stability in Europe and decreased the chances that they ''will ever be called to fight in another war across the Atlantic.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIVELSON, SHEILA F.
description: FEIVELSON-Sheila F. 6/1/90. My darling, you had a flair beyond compare and you lovingly spread joy to the many who love and miss you. Hugs and Kisses, Mom

description: Viking legend says Leif Ericsson sailed from Greenland in a sturdy wooden vessel, dodging icebergs and surviving treacherously cold waters, to discover North America about 1,000 years ago.

description: Diana Warner Kellogg, an architect, and Neil Norman Burger, an independent filmmaker and director, were married yesterday in Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Anne B. Kimball, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel.

title: A Not So Pretty Picture of History
description: ''CROSSING the Frontier'' won't make you wish you were there. It's a rather unpretty vision in photographs of the American West between 1849, the start of the California gold rush, and the present.

title: Julie Marigliano, Charles Callery 2d
description: Julie Ann Marigliano, the daughter of Nevella and James Marigliano of Astoria, Queens, was married there yesterday to Charles Peter Callery 2d, a son of Barbara and Brian Callery of Canton, Mass. The Rev. Donald Gleeson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Francis of Assisi Church.

title: Tara Brodkin, Michael Grauer
description: Dr. Tara Lisa Brodkin, a daughter of Sharon and Richard Brodkin of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Michael Trichter Grauer, a son of Dr. Theodora Grauer and Dr. Seymour Grauer of Syosset, N.Y. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, the senior rabbi at Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated there.

title: Indian Fare in Victorian House in Brewster
description: CONVENIENTLY situated to serve Westchester's northern population, Jaipore is just over the border in Putnam County. Since its auspicious opening four years ago, this kitchen has delivered uneven efforts ranging from engaging and competent to careless and inedible. Offerings have changed as well, and we miss the special regional menus Jaipore offered several years ago, although a few of the dishes have been incorporated into today's regular menu, albeit without comments on regional source.

title: F.Y.I.
description: What Takeout Comes In

title: Touring the Land of the Prancing Horse
description: YOU might think that if you spent $220,000 on a Ferrari, paid the $2,000 business-class air fare from New York to Milan, took the train to Modena, then a cab for the 14 miles to this small village, you could talk your way into a tour of the factory. Good luck.

title: Erin N. Rice, Craig M. Keanna
description: Dr. Erin Noel Rice, a pediatric resident, and Dr. Craig Michael Keanna, a pediatrician, were married yesterday in St. James, N.Y. Msgr. Charles W. Swiger Jr. performed the ceremony at SS. Philip and James Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Steak's on the Grill. Pass the Hot Peppers, Please.
description: It's getting harder and harder to find an authentic Philadelphia cheese steak these days, what with short-order cooks who leave big batches of meat sitting on grills, and the cheese too often an orangy sauce ladled from cans. Three cheers, then, for Rita's Cold Cuts in Wildwood Crest.

title: Black Erotica Challenges Black Tradition
description: TONI BRAXTON wears little more than an expression of defiance, her honey-hued skin set against a shock of white light, as she strategically holds a corner of a bed sheet inches beneath her navel, an arm concealing her chest.

title: 3 Democrats Who Would Be Governor: Where They Stand
description: On Tuesday, Democrats and unaffiliated voters who are willing to declare themselves as Democrats will go to the polls to select a Democratic candidate to challenge Governor Whitman in November.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Constructive Criticism

title: Congress Must Define Insider Trading
description: EVERYONE knows the hazards of insider trading. But what constitutes illegal insider trading is unclear. Congress has never adopted a definition and the courts have disagreed. Now, the Supreme Court is about to decide a case that could severely narrow the broad definition preferred by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Whatever the court rules, Congress should act to define the scope of unlawful conduct.

title: Elizabeth Dick, Christopher Rubin
description: Elizabeth Jane Dick, a daughter of Patricia and Arnold Dick of Boca Raton, Fla., is to be married today to Christopher Todd Rubin, a son of Brenda Rubin of Richmondtown, Staten Island. Cantor Kalman Fliegelman is to officiate at Club Getaway Resort in Kent, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUCAS, SALLY
description: LUCAS-Sally. Memorial service June 4, 1997 at the First Church of Religious Science, 14 East 48th Street, New York City, at 6 PM.

title: The Case of the Ever-Popular Detectives
description: THREE of the most beloved sleuths of all time -- Sherlock Holmes, Inspector Maigret and Hercule Poirot -- reign this summer on ''Mystery!'' (Two episodes remain in the Sherlock Holmes sequence that opened this series of repeat broadcasts: ''The Golden Pince-Nez'' on Thursday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13 and ''The Mazarin Stone'' on June 12, to be followed by eight Maigrets and eight Poirots.)

title: A Key Shift In Gold Funds
description: VICTOR FLORES, the manager of two precious metals mutual funds for U.S. Global Investors who simultaneously racked up the worst and one of the best performance records in his peer group, resigned unexpectedly last week.

title: A Visit to Gigi
description: To the Editor: I was surprised that in an excellent article about Colette and Burgundy, ''A Museum to Salute a National Treasure'' (April 13), the author failed to include a recommendation to stop at La Lucarne aux Chouettes (the Owls' Skylight) in Villeneuve-sur-Yonne. This small inn was designed, built, decorated and is run by that quintessential ''Gigi'' actress, Leslie Caron.

title: Ms. Berents, Mr. de Silva-Weeramuni
description: Anne Lindsey Berents, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles N. Berents Jr. of Boston, was married yesterday to Heshan Rashmi Udara de Silva-Weeramuni, a son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Namel Weeramuni of Los Angeles and Colombo, Sri Lanka. The Rev. E. Clifford Cutler performed the ceremony, which combined Episcopalian and Buddhist traditions, at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Cohasset, Mass.

title: Southeast Asia Bloc Admits Burmese and Two Others
description: Defying the wishes of the United States and brushing aside concerns over human rights abuses, the Southeast Asian political and economic bloc known as Asean announced today that it would embrace Myanmar as a member this year.

title: Iranian Moderate's Victory Portends Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Hartford Schools: A New Beginning
description: THE state takeover today of Hartford's public schools, which dissolved the city's elected Board of Education and replaces it with a seven-member state-appointed Board of Trustees, is a first for Connecticut -- the first time that a public school system is not under local control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, FRED
description: GLUCK-Fred. On May 30, 1997. Beloved husband of Susanne Doris and the late Iris Gluck. Dear father of Gary Gluck and Terry Frishman. Adored grandfather of Ivy and Rebecca. Cherished brother-in-law of Wilma Gluck and Mildred Jolna. Services today, June 1, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Bookshelf
description: SHAKER HEARTS. By Ann Turner. Illustrated by Wendell Minor. HarperCollins. $14.95. (All ages) An author's note gives a brief history of the utopian religious sect known as the Shakers. The spare poetic text and the dramatic, austere paintings -both full pages and isolated details - give a sense of the Shakers' fabled simplicity.

title: Golf, or 'Barney'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting It Fly
description: Seven years after I separated from my children's father and moved out of the house we'd shared, it was still hard going back there. This was a house I lived in for 18 years, a place I knew so well I could find my way around in the dark. After my marriage ended, my children and I moved to a small city, 30 miles from that house, and until our recent move to the West Coast, the kids continued to spend every other weekend with their father. Sundays were my time to pick them up, with their brown paper bags filled with clothes. I'd rather have driven a hundred miles in any other direction -- the memories that pickup conjured were still so painful.

title: COOKING
description: During one of the worst restaurant meals I've had in years, all I could do was fume about how deceptively pretty the presentation was. There were the usual bright squiggles of sauce (every chef in America, no matter how incompetent, knows how to use a squeeze bottle) surrounding bits of desiccated food erected like a sculpture so that patrons in the know could gush, ''Ooh, good height.'' Just pretentious and pointless.

title: 22-Story Rental Building Going Up on E. 86th St.
description: Demolition work is being completed to make way for a sleek, 22-story luxury rental building with a cantilever of upper floors over a smaller neighboring building on 86th Street between Second and Third Avenues. The $75 million project at 230 East 86th Street, which is to have 246 apartments, is being developed by the Related Companies. Construction is to be completed by the middle of next year.

title: Katherine Michels, Sanford Schwartz
description: Dr. Katherine Jo Michels, the daughter of Verena Michels and Dr. Robert Michels of Scarsdale, N.Y., is to be married today to Sanford Kevin Schwartz, the son of Carol S. Schwartz of Stamford, Conn., and the late Edward W. Schwartz. Rabbi Edward L. Schecter, the bridegroom's uncle, is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Anger in Workfare Ranks
description: It was her first job ever. Norma Delgado, who is 46 years old, had been on welfare for decades until this year, when she started at the Parks Department as part of the city's Work Experience Program. It requires that welfare recipients earn their benefits by working in city agencies.

title: U.S. Toughens Program On Unruly Air Travelers
description: With complaints by airlines about disruptive passengers on the rise, Government efforts to prosecute offenders are being expanded. A test program was begun at Honolulu and Los Angeles International Airports on Nov. 1, 1996, and the Department of Transportation plans to extend the program to the three major New York airports: Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark. In mid-May, Bill Mosley, spokesman for the department, said no date for the extension had been set. In the program, the Federal Aviation Administration, part of the transportation department, works with airlines, crew members, local law agencies, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and assistant United States attorneys to see that reports of passenger interference with crew members are investigated.

title: Let the Trial Begin!
description: Now that the Supreme Court has spoken, let Bill Clinton's trial begin! There are two vital reasons why it is in the national interest that Paula Jones have her day in court -- and that it be the longest day in court American jurisprudence can provide.

title: Breaking Out of the Box
description: Computers aren't merely pow-erful electronic gadgets. They are objects, too -- graceless, lumpy objects, electronic Model T's. They all look the same, and their sheer sameness ought to make us suspicious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTROVE, ANITA FAY
description: ASTROVE-Anita Fay, age 70, of Wellington, FL, died May 29, 1997. Originally from White Plains, NY. Survived by husband Bert, sons Dr. Andrew and Skip; sister Gertrude Levenson. Grandmother of six. Graveside services at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY. Times to be announced at a later date.

title: For New Jersey Voters, A Primary Confusion
description: Did Pauline Halas, a longtime resident of this working-class city and a dedicated Democrat, know which candidate for governor she would support in the Tuesday primary?

title: In a Season of Wild Cards, Actors Rule
description: ALL THOSE GORGEOUSLY COSTUMED corpses; all those vaunting hopes slaughtered; all that conniving ambition and competition lying like the wreckage on a bloody battlefield.

title: Mr. Harrington, Ms. Schnekenburger
description: Erica Marie Schnekenburger, a clinical social worker, and Christopher John Harrington, a mixed-media artist, were married yesterday in Cape May, N.J. Thomas M. Phelan, the Mayor of Cape May, officiated at the Washington Inn.

title: Choosing Whites From Bordeaux
description: BEST known for its reds, Bordeaux now produces a range of flavorful whites that marry perfectly with summertime fare. And, based on a recent sampling, some sensibly priced brands are available.

title: They're Off and Running, but With Whose Money?
description: GWEN BENNETT grew up around harness racing. Her father was a horseman, so were her customers at a local restaurant, and so was the man she married; they had their first date at the Vernon Downs race track, and watched his horse win.

title: Wrestling With 'Jeff'
description: ON a Saturday evening last month, Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn threw a coming-out party for 20 juniors and seniors. The school foyer was filled with gold and silver balloons and potted ficus trees strung with lights. At one end, where security guards usually inspect knapsacks for guns and knives, was a long table, covered with a white tablecloth and piled with elegant chocolate-dipped strawberries. Everyone was dressed to the nines.

title: One More Athlete's Wife Picks Up the Pieces of Her Life
description: Pie McKenzie's daughter felt ''special'' when other kids swarmed around her father, a scrappy right wing for the Boston Bruins. Years later, she had similar feelings of pride when fans swarmed around her husband, Brian Holloway, an all-pro offensive tackle for the Patriots and the Raiders. She should have known better, she says, than to allow her sense of herself to become so identified with her father's and her husband's celebrity.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: Susan Cooper, Jerald Rappaport
description: Susan A. Cooper, the daughter of Eli M. Cooper of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Alice L. Cooper, is to be married today to Jerald L. Rappaport, a son of Lois Radding and a stepson of Isadore Radding of Manchester, Conn. Rabbi David Greenburg is to perform the ceremony at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Bedford Corners, N.Y.

title: Democracies Love Peace, Don't They?
description: EVER since the American Revolution, Americans have believed that democracies are the most enlightened form of government and, by their nature, should be friends and allies. The nation's biggest wars have been fought in defense of democracies or under the slogan of making the world safe for them. Even when Washington has joined forces with dictators like Stalin or corrupt regimes like that of South Vietnam, it has felt compelled to recast their images to make them more acceptable partners.

title: Kenneth Starr, Trapped
description: Courtroom 2A, on the second floor of the U.S. Post Office and Courthouse in Little Rock, Ark., has been renovated in a giddy, ornate style; and on April 14, when Kenneth Starr strode through the gleaming oak doors at 1:20 P.M. for the sentencing of James McDougal, his mood seemed to mirror the exuberant entablature. He shook hands with the court stenographer. He shook hands with the marshal and the clerk. Working the room like a cherubic Rotarian, he shook hands with the journalists who had been ushered into the jury box. But Starr reserved his most enthusiastic salutations for the man he had successfully prosecuted for 18 counts of fraud and conspiracy arising from the Whitewater investigation.

title: While the Pugs Eat the Caviar, Owners Bond
description: Gregg Paraventi was walking down Beekman Place with his dog, Benito, when a young woman asked him if he was going to the hill. He recalls that he paused, smiled and had no idea what she was talking about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, DR. LESTER
description: WOLFSON-Dr. Lester. In Bridgeport, CT, on May 30, 1997. Husband of the late Sarah Ginsberg Wolfson, father of Alan and Linda Wolfson of Purchase, NY, and the late Joelle Wolfson Cormier, brother of William and Roz Wolfson of New York City and the late Cybil Wolfson Count. Grandfather of Wendy and Dr. Michael Doyle, Lawrence and Alissa Wolfson, and great-grandfather of Matthew, Emily and Kevin Doyle. Private services were held. A memorial period will be observed at the home of Alan and Linda Wolfson, 1 Cypress Point Dr., Purchase, NY, Sunday evening and Monday.

title: A Sermon Inspires A Town's Embrace
description: In January of last year, the Rev. Randy Bond gave a sermon at the Zion's United Church of Christ that unwittingly mimicked a century-old sermon by a Presbyterian minister in a small Pennsylvania town.

title: New Generation Shakes Up Voting for Orthodox Council
description: Few outsiders may have noticed it, but a quiet revolution took place among Crown Heights' Orthodox Jews last month. In elections for the board that oversees the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council and other activities, a slew of older incumbents were ousted and a new generation asserted its power.

title: Dead Men and Sperm
description: In recent years, doctors increasingly have had to decide whether to fulfill an unusual request -- to remove and store the sperm of men who have just died. The process, though rare, is simple. Within a day or so of a man's death, the doctor removes the sperm from the vas deferens and freezes it -- in perpetuity.

title: Persnickety Yes, but Everyone Loves a Rose
description: ROSES and June. What a combination. It is probably one of the most popular duos that the world has ever known.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Brassed Off

title: Ingenious Touches and a Faultless View
description: WITH its wide views of marshlands, reeds swaying in the late spring breeze, Jeffrey's in Milford makes a very pleasant place for lunch or an early dinner. We stress early because of the views. The food, of course, is just as appealing after dark.

title: Charles Baker and Katharine Wallace
description: Katharine Sanford Wallace and Charles Copeland Baker, investment bankers in San Francisco, were married yesterday in Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Barbara Merritt performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church.

title: My Gun
description: NEW JERSEY witnessed two horrible handgun tragedies this spring.

title: I.R.A. May Have Planted A Land Mine in Belfast
description: The Royal Ulster Constabulary police said this morning that the Irish Republican Army had apparently planned an attack on a police patrol using a land mine in West Belfast yesterday afternoon but abandoned it because there were civilians in the area.

title: Just Call Me Mr. President
description: THE morning after my election I shaved and put on a clean shirt even though my appointment calendar was blank. What if one of my new constituents needed some ''face time,'' or a city inspector showed up? Unshaven, in flip-flops and sweats, I had looked like a sitcom super who could be bought for a box of doughnuts. By the next day, when I actually went out on an official mission, I felt like a public man.

title: Summer Reading
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas Books issue of December 1996. It is meant to suggest some of the high points in this year's fiction, poetry, nonfiction, mysteries and science fiction. The books are arranged alphabetically under genre headings.

title: Court That Takes A Single Focus
description: TREVOR GEORGE and his girlfriend were dressed in matching outfits for Mr. George's appearance in court. Wearing black jeans and thinly striped shirts, they swung their clasped hands as they explained to the prosecutor that his girlfriend no longer wanted to press charges.

title: Alyssa Licht And Leon Rapko

title: Butterflies Take Flight at New Niagara Home
description: One of North America's largest glass-enclosed butterfly facilities -- housing some 2,000 butterflies from tropical countries -- is adding domestic species this summer in a new outdoor butterfly garden densely planted with perennials and flowering shrubs.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Top of the Topiary

title: Rockin' in the Stacks Draws Bands to the Chappaqua Library
description: THE dream of a high school rock band's cutting a demo tape and making it big reverberates in the frets and wails of dozens of young musicians.

title: Grisham, Yes, but a Far Cry From 'The Firm'
description: AS DUSK DESCENDS ON AN INLET overlooking the harbor here, it's hard to remember that tourists are now the city's greatest industry. Film-making equipment and the still air have combined to make this the insect capital of the South. With the movie lights slated to be switched on at any minute, crew members light cigars and apply bug spray. No one rushes.

title: Tracing Tragedy in Ireland
description: MOST visitors to Ireland first come upon evidence of the Great Potato Famine of 1845-50 where I did -- in the graveyards. Prowling around the north transept of St. Mary's Collegiate Church in Youghal, County Cork, one afternoon, I was surprised to find a large, rounded-off pyramid of earth surrounded by an iron railing marking a famine grave. Sir Walter Raleigh is said to have introduced the potato to Ireland next door in the garden of his mansion, Myrtle Grove. In Kilmallock, County Tipperary, a huge expanse of prime real estate stands empty in the middle of a housing development, and in lush pastures above the town of Callan in County Kilkenny, one field of green has been landscaped as a memorial to the dead buried there. Many famine burial grounds bear no markers. In Dunfanaghy on the north coast of Donegal, townspeople directed me to a triangular yard of grassy mounds on a hill overlooking the bay. The swollen earth, untouched after all these years, tells an eloquent if silent story.

title: Miss Libby, Mr. Osborne
description: Virginia Kindel Libby, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Libby of New York, was married yesterday to Stanley de Jongh Osborne 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard de Jongh Osborne of New York. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hocus Focus
description: ''I want to take you back, back . . .back to the last time you bought sandwich-spread-type products.'' That's Hal Goldberg, a consumer researcher in Irvine, Calif., gently coaxing four hypnotized women. He asks one to ''visualize'' eating a tuna-salad sandwich. ''What's on it besides tuna? What do you mean, 'Onions help'?'' She means tuna salad is ''bland.'' To Goldberg, this fairly bland insight suggests the need for a new product: onion-flavored mayonnaise.

title: Vibrant Downtown With an Artistic Flair
description: THERE are places on Long Island where traditional downtown shopping districts have faded and decayed, their vitality siphoned off by malls and strip shopping centers.

title: Adolescence Rules!
description: Kakutani's great piece ''Adolescence Rules!'' proves that our society sees itself as ever young and ever hip, but dumbed down into the drabbest mediocrity. Testimony to this can be seen in the models in advertisements who show the vacuity of their existence with their mouths open and a look in the eyes that says, ''Ain't nobody home.''

title: 8 Million Facts In the Naked City
description: TOURISM in New York is booming: 30.3 million visitors in 1996, up from 28.8 million in just two years; in both cases, slightly more than half were overnight visitors, not day-trippers. This year, 30.6 million are expected, and some days, it seems as they are all here right now.

title: Protecting Buyers Of New York Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: Balancing Act
description: ALISON WELD wears two very different hats in New Jersey's art world, but she finds they both fit her well. She is an active painter, with a show of recent work on view through June 13 at Aljira: A Center for Contemporary Art, a nonprofit gallery here. At the same time, she is the assistant curator for New Jersey art at the State Museum in Trenton. In that role, she has exhibited the work of more than 200 other artists from the state over the last nine years.

title: Police Pay Talks Will Weigh Productivity
description: An arbitration panel scheduled to hear New York City's dispute with its main police union has decided to consider the union's arguments that its members deserve a larger wage increase because of increased police productivity.

title: Out of the Mouth of Babes, The Wisdom of 'Goo-Goo'
description: ''PLEASE WATCH YOUR language! Children present!'' the sign warns crew members on the set of ''Baby Geniuses,'' a Sony Pictures fantasy comedy that was being filmed on a sound stage here.

title: Refining Hearing With Digital Aids
description: WHAT computers have done for seemingly everything else in life -- revolutionizing the way things are done -- they are now doing for the hearing aid. Sandra Solomon, a White Plains audiologist, said that newfangled, digital hearing aids are flexible, reprogrammable to meet changing needs and are far quieter than traditional analog hearing aids.

title: Andrea van Beuren, Roger E. Kass
description: Andrea van Beuren, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. van Beuren of Middletown, R.I., was married there yesterday to Roger Evan Kass, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kass of Bedford Corners, N.Y. The Rev. Alan Neale, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Berkeley Memorial Chapel. Rabbi Edward Schlaeger took part in the service.

title: Pam McGreevy and Dan Newman
description: THE Rev. Molly Paine McGreevy is not at all a stereotypical minister or mother of the bride. She has worn almost every imaginable hat. She has been a stay-at-home mom, a Pop Art collector, a regular on the soap opera ''Ryan's Hope'' and most recently, an Episcopal priest.

title: With 25 in Hand, I Began An Affair, With My Sax
description: AT 7 years old, out of a clear blue Jewish sky, I began taking piano lessons. What is a Jewish sky? It is two Eastern European shack dwellers, my parents, in their 20's, in the early 30's in New York, thinking they are doing the culturally correct middle-class thing for their children -- or at least that's the conclusion I've recently come to. With a $1-a-lesson piano teacher seated on the bench next to me I fingered some C scales and struggled over that particular Bach piece that has become the all-time beginner's favorite.

title: Fighting Words
description: Unlike my literary peers in the United States and the Rest of Canada - or the R.O.C., as it is now known here in Quebec - I can no longer scribble in English with impunity, which makes for a certain frisson. The Commission de Protection de la Langue Franaise has dispersed 15 inspectors, each of them armed with a tape measure and color chart, to make sure that English lettering on outdoor commercial signs is half the size of the French, and that perfidious Anglophones haven't painted their half-pint messages in colors more alluring than the French. If Quebec's language laws tighten just one more notch, I may have to write my novels in words half the size of the French so as not to antagonize our linguistic vigilantes. I have already had to take down the billboard rooted in the field opposite our cottage on Lake Memphremagog:

title: SoHo Artists Work to Rescue Rare Day Care Center
description: The last five years have been precarious ones for Doris Dillems's New Friends Place nursery school and day care center at 130 Greene Street. Rent increases and legal fees racked up in her struggle to hold on to her ground-floor space have helped to drain her resources. This month, she must leave the space where for the last 18 years she has operated one of the few day care centers in SoHo. The landlord wants to sell it, and she says she cannot afford to stay in the area. ''I'm going under unless I get some help,'' she said.

title: Pope Gives a Blessing to Poland's Turn West
description: In unseasonable cold and wet, Pope John Paul II returned to Poland today and expressed pleasure at being back ''under the roof of the parental home'' where he said the tiniest details and objects recalled what was most precious to him. Even the weather, he noted in a smiling, unscripted aside, was familiar.

title: Moscow on the Make
description: Monday Dawn, with its shafts of light and hints of redemption, doesn't really happen in Moscow. At some point the black of night dissolves into the gray of day. Long trucks full of beets, cabbage and the first spring melons start rumbling across the broken pavement to their destinations at scores of city markets. People rouse themselves, drink tea, then shuffle across the snowy ground to 500 trolley stops and subway stations.

title: Montana Landowners Fight Public on Acess to Trout Streams
description: As wealthy out-of-staters buy ranches along prime trout streams in Montana, a battle is erupting over access to publicly owned rivers that flow through private land.

title: I Am More Than Hands
description: I believe that articles like Jane Bendetson's ''I Am More Than Hands'' (Lives, April 13) raise awareness to the reality, not the Hollywood version, of the care-giving experience. As the leader of a support group for care-givers whose spouses or parents have Alzheimer's disease, I see both the love and the frustration of the members. The people in my group, many of whom are in their 70's and 80's and dealing with their own fragile health, spend 24 hours a day caring for their relatives.

description: FROM NINEVEH TO NEW YORK

Practicing attorney for 45 years and vice president of Kravet Fabrics Inc. Youngest and last of six brothers, sons of Max and Mary Mishkin. Services Monday, 1:00 PM, ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel'', 76th Road and Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: Old-Time Radio Casts Its Spell All Over Again
description: THE LONE RANGER RIDES again. So do Vic and Sade, the Bickersons, the Shadow, Captain Midnight and hundreds of other characters who are making comebacks in rebroadcasts and sales of recordings from the golden age of radio, when it was a home for drama and comedy as well as music and news. Long sustained by nostalgia buffs and hobbyists operating with collegiality and an avid sense of mission, old-time radio is increasingly turning up on AM and FM dials around the country, as well as in the books, newsletters and catalogues that accompany a lively traffic in reissued and bootleg tapes.

title: Chai Kulsakdinun and Julie Wang
description: Julie Wang, an investment banker, and Dr. Chai Kulsakdinun, a resident in orthopedic surgery, were married yesterday at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park in New York. The Rev. Darrell Berger, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: You've Earned a Free Ticket. Just Try Getting It.
description: LISA ZIPFEL had big plans to take a 12-day European vacation with her boyfriend this summer. Even better, she had enough frequent-flier miles on Trans World Airlines to take care of the tickets. So in January, she called to make her reservations for July. She preferred to fly into Rome, but if seats were not available, Paris would be fine.

Eugene Prior, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

description: When Richard Nicotra encountered opposition to an office building he planned to build within protected wetlands in the Bloomfield section of Staten Island he hired Richard Lynch, the botanist who led the fight, as landscape adviser.

title: Curbs Backed on Sale of Hospitals
description: In an effort to fend off problems involving for-profit hospitals, the General Assembly has passed a measure that would strictly regulate the sale of nonprofit hospitals to profit-making companies.

title: Chicago Museum Adds Modern Art Galleries
description: The Art Institute of Chicago has opened five galleries of contemporary art that include recent acquisitions and gifts and many works not seen at the institute for more than five years. The new galleries, on the first floor of the renovated Morton Wing, display American and European painting, sculpture and mixed-media works from the post-World War II period to the early 1990's, including important works by Mark Rothko, Frank Stella and Donald Judd.

description: Major industry groups are protesting, senior members of Congress are complaining and the White House economic advisers are balking. But Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, continues to doggedly defend the agency's proposal to toughen air-quality standards.

title: Mimi Cotsen, Mark B. Saker
