title: A Desire to Communicate
description: Here's what Chatter correspondents thought about Americans studying a foreign language and immigrants learning English.

title: A Stylish Berlin Hotel Rises From the Ashes
description: Almost 90 years ago the Adlon hotel, one of the most beautiful and glamorous hotels in the world, opened in Berlin. Kings, diplomats, artists and politicians praised its architecture, its luxurious design, and its view of the Brandenburg Gate and Pariser Platz, an architectural ensemble of palaces and embassies. All these buildings, including the hotel, were consumed in the flames of World War II and demolished soon thereafter. Until 1989 the former site of the Adlon adjoined the ''death strip'' that divided East and West Berlin.

title: Neutrality, Swiss Style
description: Switzerland is losing its reputation for neutrality at a dizzying rate these days. On the heels of charges that Switzerland bought its survival during World War II by giving the Third Reich a solid financial base and trading in the gold the Nazis looted, there were new accusations last week that Switzerland had favored the Nazis in its arms deals.

title: A Nursing Home's Forward Leap
description: ONE day soon -- possibly as soon as a week from tomorrow -- Helen Phillips, who is 97, will be moving. But not very far.

title: Ally in War, Burden in Peace
description: DURING the war in the former Yugoslavia, the United States developed a close alliance with Croatia in the battle to push back the Serbs in Bosnia. Now Croatia finds itself in a bitter dispute with its old patron.

description: STRONG-James. In loving memory of my sweetheart, gifts to the American Brain Tumor Association, 2720 River Road, Des Plaines, IL. 60018-4110, would be deeply appreciated. Age B. Diedrick

description: THE buttery scent of exploding popcorn, gossamer clouds of cotton candy and children's ear-popping shrieks of glee. What other evidence do you need to know the Shrine Circus has come to town?

title: They're Calling It Canadian Cuisine
description: Canoe was installed about a year and a half ago in one of the 30-year-old Toronto Dominion buildings designed by the studio of Mies van der Rohe. The name was inspired by the view of the Toronto Islands, an archipelago just offshore in Lake Ontario, once reached only by canoe. The restaurant, a large multilevel space with some private dining areas, is done in pleasing, neutral tones, and was designed around an outdoorsy theme. A large glass screen near the entrance is embedded with autumn leaves, carpeting has been patterned to resemble birch bark, and the rustic dinner plates have a leaf motif. The result is a mood of sophisticated informality. Tables are arranged to take advantage of the view.

title: Illicit Camel
description: The Government moved this week against Joe Camel, the smooth cartoon dromedary that hawks Camel cigarettes. In an administrative complaint, the Federal Trade Commission charged that R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company created the character in the mid-1980's to lure underage smokers.

title: Of All That He Sells, He Sells Himself Best
description: ON a recent blustery Saturday, a scruffy-looking Englishman and a small group of guests climbed aboard two giant hot-air balloons in the southern English countryside. As the winds pushed the balloons above fields of muted green, the host waved from the gondola to throngs of spectators below.

title: A Poster Is . . . More Than a Poster

'' posters from the School of Visual Arts that were painted, photographed or sketched by faculty members including the graphic designers Milton Glaser and Tony Palladino. The 29 1/2-by-45-inch posters are being sold for $35, plus $3 for shipping and handling, by the school, at 209 East 23d Street, New York 10010-3994.

title: No, No, Nouvelle
description: MY friend Nikki makes people who are passionate about food seem indifferent to the subject. When she explains how she escapes the rigors of medical school over a quiet dinner at Marcello's of Suffern, it makes me want to follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBURG, SARA
description: GINSBURG-Sara. Died at home in New York City on May 24, 1997. Retired Assistant Professor in the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Served there from 1954 until 1985 in the Departments of Biochemistry and Neurology. Born in St. Petersburg, Russia in 1908. Sister of the late Victoria Front. Received her Ph.D. in organic chemistry from the Univertsity of Berlin. At Columbia, was instrumental in designing numerous drugs, including one still used in overcoming poisoning caused by war gases and insecticides. Her body was given to Columbia for anatomical study. No funeral or memorial service. Any gifts in her memory may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Inc., 710 West 168th Street, Box F, New York, New York 10032. For further information, contact Dr. Lucien Cote at (212) 305-9173.

title: Defense of Crown Wears on Jordan
description: Seven years after Magic Johnson first challenged him for a championship, Michael Jordan equates defending a title with playing King of the Hill. He still wants to stay on the mound until the bell rings and recess is over, but the competition is relentless, someone always rushing forward.

description: Russell Kucinski, the Rutgers College student who created a fake bomb for his art class and literally stopped traffic in New Brunswick in March, got an A on the project but came out of the experience disgusted with the justice system.

title: Money, Partnerships, Planning at UConn
description: ON April 17, Dr. Philip E. Austin was inaugurated as the 13th president of the University of Connecticut. Dr. Austin, 55, raised in North Dakota and a graduate of North Dakota State University, began his career as provost at Bernard Baruch College in New York in 1978, after service in Vietnam.

description: Harvard defeated Yale in their annual crew race today and redeemed a previously dismal season, sweeping all three races in the 132d rowing of America's oldest intercollegiate sporting event.

description: PEARLMAN-Celia. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Devoted mother of Jack. Cherished grandmother of Sheri and Ted. Loving greatgrandmother of Meryl, Lindsay, Kara, Sophie, Alex and Jason.

description: Karl Malone caught the basketball as it swished through. The very same ball he could not get to go in from the foul line moments earlier, the one Michael Jordan ended the game with so suddenly.

description: Three months after the Energy Department announced an interim plan to clean up a radioactive underground plume of water at the Brookhaven National Laboratory and calm public health fears, the operation is coming under increasing criticism from environmentalists, scientists and Brookhaven administrators.

description: A partial list for this week.

description: GRAY-Mildred (nee Bell). Beloved wife of the late Hamilton, Jr. Mother of Barbara Barry and H. Kenneth Gray. Also survived by three grandchildren and seven great - grandchildren. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

description: Kostya Tszyu had a big name on his mind before defending his International Boxing Federation junior welterweight title here Saturday night. But it was not his opponent, Vince Phillips.

title: A Knight of Academe Braves the New-York Historical Society's Checkered Past
description: Like a spurned bride who decides that cohabitation is better than solitude, the financially troubled New-York Historical Society, after six years of failed attempts to join permanently with several New York City cultural institutions, last month quietly signed an agreement to affiliate its library with New York University.

description: If last week's premature disclosure of merger talks between the AT&T Corporation and SBC Communications Inc. was an attempt to float a trial balloon, it is fair to say the balloon got shot out of the sky.

description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a 14-day cash management bill.

description: President Jacques Chirac, who called the elections that have produced a parliamentary majority for his Socialist opponents, knows well what life can be like when the President and Prime Minister are from different parties.

title: Widow of Malcolm X Is Burned, Badly, in Fire at Yonkers Home
description: Dr. Betty Shabazz, the widow of Malcolm X, was in critical condition at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx last night, with burns over 80 percent of her body, after a fire at her Yonkers apartment that law enforcement officials said was deliberately set by her 12-year-old grandson.

title: Rosset and Corretja Make Brisk Exits in Paris
description: The big, bad wind blew into town today, and several hotshots who considered themselves big, bad threats for the French Open title found themselves complaining about every gust and being blown right out of the running at this Grand Slam event.

title: New Area Codes Introduced
description: The owners of about eight million New Jersey phone numbers began trying out their new area codes yesterday. Because the 201 and 908 area codes are nearly out of numbers, a large part of the 201 area is now covered by the 973 area code, and much of the 908 area is covered by 732. Callers can use either the new or the old code until Dec. 6, when the new ones become mandatory.

title: Jordan Is the Greatest With Ali in the Crowd
description: THE life-and-death playoffs did not begin for the Bulls until 9.2 seconds remained in the fourth quarter last night, with the score tied at 82-82; until Karl Malone stepped to the free throw line with a chance to do what most valuable players are supposed to. That was when you could finally feel the electricity at the United Center and, yes, smell the fear, the way it often is for a heavyweight championship fight.

title: A Contender at Shea? Mets Are Giving Fans a Reason to Believe
description: Let the countdown begin. In only two weeks, two weeks from tonight, the Mets and the Yankees will play each other for the first time during the regular season. Yes, Mets vs. Yankees, as in the 31-23 Mets vs. the 30-25 Yankees. Put those numbers in standings form:

title: Can Maker of B-1 Find a New Life as a Technology Star?
description: It's been a better year than Rockwell had a right to expect. Its older modem technologies sold well, a technological glitch with its newer ones was easily solved, and robust economies in Europe and North America translated into great sales for its factory automation systems. The barrage of small, sweet surprises pushed second-quarter earnings way above predictions.

title: Hey, Das Blinkenlights, Want to Get Spammed?
description: Whenever technology has flowered, it has put man's language-developing skills into overdrive. From the wheel with its axle to the spinning wheel with its bobbins, to the compact disk and its jewelbox, inventions have trailed new words in their wakes.

title: $5,000 Reward Offered For Girl's Prosthetic Arm

title: Lockheed Martin Planning Russia Venture
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation plans to announce today that it is forming a joint venture with a Russian organization, Intersputnik, to offer satellite communications services, according to people familiar with the company's plans.

title: Bridge
description: The famous Goldman Pairs, first played in 1929, is probably the second-oldest continuously played event in bridge. (The Vanderbilt Knockout Teams is one year older.) A week ago, in Stamford, Conn., the Goldman title went to Carleton Lett and David Gurvich, both of Manhattan. They also won in 1994, and Lett owns an earlier title with another partner. Only one player, the great Alvin Roth, has won more than three Goldmans: he has had four victories.

But the Triarc Companies, which acquired Snapple from the Quaker Oats Company, said Foote, Cone had been dismissed.

title: Supreme Court to Rule on Pipe Fitters, Long Bathed in Railroad's Asbestos
description: It was Danny Nelson's second day on the job as a pipe fitter for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and he was deep in the catacombs beneath Grand Central Terminal, repairing an expansion joint on a steam pipe as wide as a barrel and sheathed with asbestos.

title: Democrats Head Into Primary
description: Taking their final campaign swings through the state and their final oratorical shots at one another across the broadcast airwaves, the Democratic candidates for governor -- Robert E. Andrews, James E. McGreevey and Michael Murphy -- appeared to to be locked in a tight race leading up to tomorrow's primary election. And with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's armor showing signs of cracking, each candidate promised to give the Governor a close contest in the fall. $(Page A1.$)

description: FATAL PLANE CRASH A father and son from Long Island and two visitors from Israel died when their plane crashed near an airport. B2.

title: A Performer Who Rests, And Other Surprises
description: The Diamond Project, a festival of new works that the New York City Ballet does not call a festival, continues apace, and the third entry, ''Circle of Fifths,'' is a winner.

title: Turkish Leader, His Coalition Crumbling, Will Call Elections
description: After 11 months in office as modern Turkey's first Islamist leader, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan acknowledged today that his coalition Government was crumbling and said he would call for new elections.

title: If salmon are going to be turned into low-fat 'bacon,' can salmon belly futures be far behind?
description: IF a bacon cheeseburger sounds tasty but unhealthy, how about a burger garnished with fish-based food product that resembles fried bacon pieces? It should taste like bacon, too, under a patent awarded to a Juneau, Alaska, inventor, Duff W. Mitchell.

title: Drug Rights Sold to L'Oreal Unit
description: Praecis Pharmaceuticals Inc., a biotechnology company in Cambridge, Mass., has sold the European rights to its new prostate cancer drug for as much as $68 million.

description: The only black officer in the 81-member North Brunswick Police Department filed a Federal lawsuit against the town on Thursday, asserting that he was denied a promotion because of racial discrimination.

title: Finding success in television has become a nightmare for Dreamworks.
description: THOUGH the Dreamworks studio has yet to release its first movie, you could have found an especially scary title playing at the studio's headquarters in recent weeks. It was called ''A Nightmare on Television Row.''

title: What Is A Hit Film? Moviefone May Know
description: The record-breaking Memorial Day opening weekend of ''The Lost World: Jurassic Park'' has brought renewed attention to the importance of not just the first few days of a Hollywood film, but also to the business of predicting a movie's box-office prospects.

title: Church Service Reflects Hope in Tornado-Ravaged Community in Texas
description: Survivors of a deadly tornado that ravaged this central Texas farming community gathered at the First Baptist Church here today to share their grief in a folksy service accompanied by tears, hugs and hymns.

title: A Job for the Supreme Court
description: Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson had it exactly right in April when he declared unconstitutional the line-item veto authority granted the President a year ago by Congress. The new law, which permits the President to cancel individual spending and tax items in appropriations bills he has already signed into law, plainly violates the constitutional separation of powers.

title: The Baltic Curse
description: As the Baltic nations of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania ponder the prospect of NATO expansion, they fear they will once again become the orphans of Europe. They were last abandoned in 1940, when the Soviet Union forcibly annexed the three countries a year after Stalin and Hitler secretly agreed to place them under Moscow's dominion.

description: At one point during a nationally televised debate last month, Prime Minister Jean Chretien made an apology that seemed surprisingly frank for a politician in the thick of his 11th election campaign.

title: As Predicted, Fedorov Is Getting to the Flyers
description: From the category of ''life imitates commercial'' comes the television advertisement featuring the star status of Detroit's Sergei Fedorov and the erratic behavior of an unnamed goalie for the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about two consultants to the Russian Government from the Harvard Institute for International Development, who were dismissed by Harvard, misstated the surname of one of the consultants. He is Jonathan Hay, not Hays.

title: In a Modest Nod to Peace, Croats Reopen Bosnia Bridge
description: As Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright presided, the Government of Croatia reopened a bridge linking its territory to the northern Bosnian town of Brcko today, an important, if largely symbolic, step to comply with the 1995 Dayton peace accords.

title: Flyers Are Pointing Fingers, But Are Not Naming Names
description: There is a palpable sense of discomfort between the Philadelphia Flyers and their coach, Terry Murray, and it came to the fore today, one day after the Flyers lost Game 1 of the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup final by 4-2 to the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Bozell Explains Rejection of Offer
description: A bid by Omnicom Group to buy Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt was spurned, employees are being told, because it would have served to ''undo'' that agency company.

title: States Divided in Sensitive Tobacco Talks
description: As talks with the tobacco industry enter a crucial week, conflicts are growing among negotiators representing states over the critical issue of liability, with at least one of them vowing to propose a settlement plan even if others balk.

title: With all the sound and fury over push technology, it must signify something.
description: IN the silicon world, as in many others, being contrary is almost as fashionable as being rich. So one of the best ways to gauge the value of a new technology is by the extent of the backlash it inspires.

title: 4 Killed as a Small Plane Crashes Near Republic Airport
description: A father and son from Long Island and two friends visiting from Israel died late Saturday when their single-engine plane, preparing to land at Republic Airport in Farmingdale, crashed in a nearby deserted parking lot, Federal officials said today.

title: It's Unclear
description: Now that President Clinton has forced Boris Yeltsin to say ''uncle'' to NATO expansion, there is really only one relevant question left: Will NATO expansion be remembered for what it is -- a quaint farce, driven by domestic American politics and bad imitations of Dean Acheson -- or will it actually be dangerous? Are we just present at a bad joke, or present at the disaster? That will now be determined by one issue: Will Russia still go ahead with its nuclear arms control agreements with the U.S., despite NATO expansion?

title: New Parts Of Town For Spoleto Festival
description: The Rev. Julius Barnes, pastor of St. Luke's Reformed Episcopal Church, wasn't all that sure what to think when officials from the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. approached him about building a sculpture garden on the 110-year-old church's side lawn.

title: Whiten's 15th-inning Blast Is the Right Tonic for Yanks
description: The changing emotions and queasy feelings permeated both dugouts and bullpens today because the Red Sox and Yankees played extra innings and kept on playing and playing. There were wild shifts of emotion and weak stomachs each time one team threatened to score, because the longer the game lasted, the more arduous it would be for the weary players to experience a loss. No one wanted to lose this game.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in the Metro Business column last Tuesday about a survey on working women and technology misidentified the polling firm and misstated the number of people surveyed. The firm is Penn, Schoen & Berland Associates, not Penn & Schoen Associates; the survey covered 423 respondents, not 100.

title: Still Hearing That Tennessee Waltz
description: All is calm, bright and reasonable in the music of Patti Page, who celebrated her 50th year as a performer on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. The concert was a testimonial to a bygone pop era, when the biggest hits smoothed over emotions instead of indulging them. Her voice is still rich and steady, and only a little less sweet than it was in her 1950's heyday, when her even-tempered singing was just what America wanted.

title: Motorola Sidelines Device Providing Live N.B.A. Scores
description: Four months after winning a groundbreaking lawsuit establishing its right to broadcast second-by-second National Basketball Association game scores over its pager network, Motorola Inc. is showing little interest in the electronic device at the heart of the legal debate.

title: Armstead Steps Up To Podium For Giants
description: The Giants have had four productive minicamps, an off-season workout program that has had well over 90 percent participation. And just when it seems things could not get any better, something else happens to raise the level of optimism for next season even higher.

title: Look Who's Stealing Nebuchadnezzar's Thunder
description: Across southern Iraq, but especially in the rubbled remains of this city with its magical name, some mud bricks unearthed from the distant past still carry the mark of Nebuchadnezzar, the fabled Babylonian king. It was Nebuchadnezzar who wrested the ancient capital back from the Assyrians, repelled Persian intruders and captured Jerusalem, establishing Babylon in the sixth century B.C. as the largest and most glorious city in the world.

description: Serious crime reported to the police declined 3 percent in 1996 -- the fifth annual decrease in a row -- led by an impressive 11 percent drop in homicides, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Israeli Accuses Palestinian Aide in Killing of Land-Selling Arabs
description: The head of a Palestinian security agency and his men were directly involved in two recent killings of Arabs suspected of selling land to Jews, the Jerusalem police chief said today.

title: Singer From New York Feared Dead in Memphis
description: Jeff Buckley, an up-and-coming singer and songwriter from New York, is listed as a missing person and is unofficially presumed dead, said Lieut. Brenda Maples of the Memphis Police Department. He disappeared on Thursday while swimming in a marina near the Mississippi River in Memphis.

Deer Park Dr., Gaithersburg, MD, on Monday, June 2, from 6-8 PM. Graveside services and interment on Tuesday, June 3, at 10 AM, at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, VA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, MORTON, M.D.
description: NATHANSON-Morton, M.D. With profound sorrow we mark the death of Morton Nathanson, M.D., Chairman Emeritus of our hospital's Department of Neurology from 1984 to the present and its Chairman from 1972 to 1984. He was the founder of the Neurology Service at LIJ and through his dedicated efforts an accredited residency program was established that produced scores of welltrained neurologists. Dr. Nathanson was a brilliant teacher and highly respected researcher with over 70 published papers. He was an avid collector of antiquarian and landmark books, particularly those relating to the history of neurology. An extremely energetic man with strong opinions and a great sense of humor, his was truly a robust personality. Our heartfelt condolences go to his wife Margret and his children David, Madlyn and Laura. Gedale Horowitz Chairman of the Board David R. Dantzker, M.D. President and CEO Long Island Jewish Medical Center

title: Video Primer: Smuggling Drugs for Fun and Profit
description: Despite some tabloid touches, ''Drug Run'' provides a seemingly authentic close-up of one way that heroin travels from the fields of Colombia to the streets of Western Europe. With a concealed camera and the claimed cooperation of the Cali cartel, tonight's ''Cinemax Reel Life'' documentary focuses on a ''mule,'' a young man who is seen swallowing what are described as packets of heroin that he has been commissioned to transport to Heathrow Airport in London. The report was previewed on ''60 Minutes'' last night.

title: A Far Cry From Mack the Knife
description: Habitats affect how listeners listen and how musicians play, and in terms of tone and mood, the New York Chamber Symphony, at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night, sounded fuller, warmer and at moments more relaxed than it ever did in its old home at the 92d Street Y. Given the unusual size, Tully Hall is a queer space, not at all suited to many activities that call themselves chamber music. A group of 40-odd players, however, fits nicely.

title: Man Leaps to His Death From Statue of Liberty
description: A 30-year-old man who jumped 80 feet to his death at the Statue of Liberty on Saturday evening acted erratically beforehand, a National Parks Service officer said yesterday.

title: Hostos Students Hear an Unusual Sound: Praise
description: After a week of being criticized by politicians and university trustees, students at Hostos Community College of the City University of New York were praised yesterday at a commencement ceremony that at times resembled a political rally.

title: Arson Bill to Become Law
description: As the authorities continued to investigate an arson fire that destroyed a church in Glassboro on Friday, Governor Whitman planned to sign a bill today that imposes a mandatory 15-year prison term for setting fire to a church, mosque, synagogue or other house of worship. Other kinds of arson carry a maximum sentence of 10 years.

title: Malone and Stockton Together Take the Blame
description: It was not the neon vision of Dennis Rodman that flashed like a cheap hotel sign in Karl Malone's head after this game. It was the two missed free throws blinking in his mind.

title: Jenny Bramley, 87, Physicist and Inventor
description: Dr. Jenny R. Bramley, the first woman to receive a doctorate in physics in the United States, died on May 26 at the Manor Care Health Facility in Lancaster, Pa., where she was a resident. She was 87.

title: Village Supports 6 Indicted Hasidim
description: Scattered throughout this Hasidic village are study halls where young men spend much of the day immersed in tall, yellowed volumes of Talmud, swaying and fidgeting to an ardent singsong. Many women study as well, though in more private fashion.

title: Austerity Sells Better To Voters in Canada
description: The social safety net that Canadians have long cherished was badly frayed by the budget cuts of Prime Minister Jean Chretien, who inherited a huge budget deficit. But every opinion poll before parliamentary elections today indicates that voters are ready to return him to power.

title: President's Accuser May Be Questioned On Her Sexual Past
description: President Clinton's personal lawyer today threatened to make an issue of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual history if she goes ahead with her plan to take Mr. Clinton to trial on charges of sexual harassment and damaging her reputation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When ELINOR and RANDOLPH GUGGENHEIMER began thinking about how best to celebrate their 65th wedding anniversary, Mrs. Guggenheimer, 85, suggested that perhaps a trip to Paris or London or a weekend in Vermont might be nice.

title: Robert Serber, 88, Physicist Who Aided Birth of A-Bomb
description: Robert Serber, a theoretical physicist who was the intellectual midwife at the birth of the atomic bomb and helped shape particle physics research for decades, died on Sunday at his home on the Upper West Side in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Trading 80's-Style Earnestness For Glitz and a 40-Foot Lemon
description: Though the stadium concert, with some 50,000 fans worked up over the pyrotechnics of a group the size of ants, is one of modern rock-and-roll's iconic images, there hasn't actually been a stadium rock show in the New York region since the Grateful Dead last performed at Giants Stadium nearly two years ago. On Saturday night at the same stadium, U2 rectified the situation. In front of a sold-out crowd, the band offered images guaranteed to reach the back rows: a 170-foot long video screen, a giant olive on an immense swizzle stick and a 40-foot lemon that (like the finale of Pink Floyd's last tour) turned into a giant disco ball, sending beads of light spinning over the faces of everyone in the audience.

title: Silenced Majority
description: Gov. George Pataki has yet to weigh in on the proposal by Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, for a citywide referendum on rent regulations. One might think he would embrace it: In his inaugural address he advocated new laws allowing New Yorkers the kind of voter initiative and referendum enjoyed in 23 other states.

title: As New York Homicides Fall, Rate of Solved Cases Goes Up
description: A hidden benefit of New York City's decreasing crime rate is emerging now in the Police Department's growing ability to solve homicides, at a time when officials are celebrating yet another announcement of encouraging statistics.

title: Not Forlorn, But Feeling Forgotten
description: WITH one of the best views in the city and in the summertime at least a gratifying breeze, a ride on the Staten Island ferry has long been a legendary bargain. It was cheap at 5 cents, cheap at 50 cents, and now it is about to be free. Come next month, riders will be able to travel back and forth between St. George and South Ferry for nothing at all, thanks to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Mets Gain a Sweep of Phils, But Lose Ordonez to Injury
description: The angry scream pierced the euphoric Mets clubhouse, sounding so strange in the wake of yesterday's 8-5 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies, the completion of a weekend sweep, the latest lesson in how fundamental baseball is paying off.

title: CHRONICLE
description: More than 20 years ago, GEORGE PLIMPTON, the writer and Paris Review editor, performed a piano composition he had written, ''Opus 1,'' at an amateur night contest at the Apollo Theater. He came in second, he said, to a 10-year-old girl who tap-danced and sang.

title: Reed Hundt's Legacy
description: Reed Hundt, who announced last week his resignation as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, brought a focused agenda and energetic leadership to the commission. He has fought successfully to create competitive telephone and other telecommunications markets where none now exist. He has also fought to impose public responsibilities on broadcasters and other powerful interests in exchange for their access to public resources. He will leave the commission with communications policy headed in the right direction, and leave for his successor the difficult task of fighting off forces that are no doubt salivating at the prospect of undoing Mr. Hundt's good deeds.

title: Norman Gains Ground At Drenched Memorial
description: Rain was the only thing that stopped Greg Norman today. And before showers drove him into the clubhouse, he showered the golf course with birdies.

title: INSIDE
description: Finding Profits in Schools

title: Expanding From Parts to Piecing Them Together
description: There is a muffled buzz here on the factory floor, where hundreds of employees are assembling computer innards. At one long table, for example, a line of workers solder multicolored wires onto connectors to fit the precise dimensions of the Compaq personal computers into which they will soon be installed.

title: Matters of Life and Death for Mummies
description: The Tai-Gu Tales Dance Theater evoked the miracle of creation with wonders of its own on Saturday night at the Taipei Theater. The company from Taiwan, in its American debut, made vast universes appear to form and dissolve in ''The Back of Beyond.'' Yet this production choreographed by Lin Hsiu-Wei had a cast of only seven dancers and lasted only 75 minutes. The action, to a taped score by Shih Chieh-Yun, skillfully blended traditional Chinese dance with Western modern dance.

title: A $1 Gamble on Wall Street Yields a Share of Millions
description: Through hard work, shrewd investing, good timing and a little luck, it's possible to make millions in an instant on Wall Street. Or you can buy a lottery ticket there.

description: Theodore Dreier, an engineer and educator who was a founder of the legendary Black Mountain College, died on May 7 at Jefferson County Hospital in Fairfield, Iowa. He was 94 and lived in Fairfield.

title: Pippen, Hurt, Finds Footing

title: In a Duel of the Fastest, Bailey Runs All Alone
description: The race for the title of world's fastest man, which nearly became a fiasco because of financial problems and a threatened withdrawal by Donovan Bailey, turned out to be no race at all. Bailey won in 14.99 seconds today at 150 meters as Michael Johnson pulled up with a limp, an apt metaphor for the hobbled state of track and field in North America.

title: Famed Riveter In War Effort, Rose Monroe Dies at 77
description: Rose Will Monroe, an employee of an aircraft factory who, through a chance meeting with a Hollywood star, became the celebrated ''Rosie the Riveter'' in World War II, died on Saturday in Clarksville, Ind. She was 77, and a resident of Clarksville.

title: 'Chicago' and 'Titanic' Rake In the Tony Awards
description: In a season teeming with new musicals, ''Titanic'' drew away from the pack last night, winning the Tony Award for best musical as well as four other awards. It was a moment of sweet vindication for the $10 million musical, whose budget, technical problems and improbable subject earned it more than its share of taunts and labored jokes. In the end, the ship floated.

title: Bickering Until the Bitter End (and Even After)
description: There is an enormous repertory of American operas written since the Second World War. But you wouldn't know it from the offerings of most American opera houses.

title: 3 Democrats Are Optimistic In Primary to Face Whitman
description: In a campaign that started several months ago in New Jersey as a collection of hopefuls dreaming an implausible dream of defeating an impossibly popular Republican Governor, the Democratic candidates were brimming with confidence this weekend about their chances to win tomorrow's primary. And with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's armor of invincibility having shown signs of cracking in recent weeks, each candidate promised to give her a close contest in the fall.

title: Digital Hints at Antitrust Suit Against Intel
description: As a legal battle between the Intel Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation escalates over what Digital contends is a violation of its patents, the next phase could be an antitrust suit filed against Intel by Digital.

title: Nerds Inc. Turns Typos Into On-Line Advertising
description: ''Tommy if you don't learn how to spell you are not going to get anywhere. . . .''

title: Renewed Violence Strikes Ulster As Talks Are About to Resume
description: The police said today that the Irish Republican Army threatened new violence this weekend in the Roman Catholic area of Poleglass in West Belfast.

title: LEFT WINS STRONG MANDATE AS VOTERS IN FRANCE REJECT AUSTERITY IN FAVOR OF JOBS
description: In a stunning rejection of President Jacques Chirac's economic austerity policies, French voters on Sunday gave the Socialist Party and its Communist allies a mandate to form a Government that would make jobs its absolute priority for the next five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALMUS, LENORE (FLORY)
description: KALMUS-Lenore (Flory) Born NY October 24, 1936, died June 2, 1997 after a valiant fight with cancer. Lenore received her B.A. from Wellesley in 1957, and her LL.B career from New York University in 1962. She began her law career in government, and entered private practice in 1966 with the late Norman Roy Grutman. A creative and tireless litigator, she joined the firm of Bower & Gardner in 1976, and began her concentration in medical-legal matters. She achieved partnership in 1980, in recognition of her incisiveness and intellect. Lenore specialized in representing physicians and hospitals in complex medical litigation, and was acknowledged by many physicians as having a vast medical knowledge. Most importantly, she brought to her clients both passion and insight, which earned her the reputation as an effective and loyal advocate. In 1994 she became a partner in McAloon & Friedman, where she continued to practice until illness prematurely ended a distinguished career. Lenore was a mentor to many young lawyers, and she taught them her love of both law and medicine. Her legaacy will be that she loved her profession, served it with distinction and shared her knowledge with a new generation. She will be deeply missed by her family, friends, colleagues and clients. Contributions to Crow Canyon Archelogical Center; for information call 1-800-422-8975. Memorial service Friday, June 6, 10:30 am at U.N. Chapel, 777 First Avenue at 44th Street.

description: Wary Bonn Holding Firm To Europe Currency Plan

title: Adult Trial for a Teen-Ager
description: Jayson Vreeland, the younger of the two teen-agers charged in the April murders of two pizza deliverymen, will be tried as an adult, a Superior Court judge ruled yesterday. To keep the matter in juvenile court, Mr. Vreeland's lawyer, Paul Selitto, needed to convince Judge N. Peter Conforti that a public trial would cause a specific harm to his client and that Mr. Vreeland, 17, could be rehabilitated before he turns 19. The lawyer did not succeed, The Associated Press reported.

title: Chang Is the Latest Loss in a Lackluster Men's Field in Paris
description: The French Open today lost a former champion, Michael Chang, and a potential one, seventh-seeded Marcelo Rios of Chile, while Brazil's patriotic Gustavo Kuerten, hounded by the tournament's fashion police for wearing a blue-and-yellow get-up that had the color scheme of his country's flag, has threatened to show up for his quarterfinal match in his underwear.

title: ENERGY CONSULTANTS ANNOUNCE $65 MILLION MERGER DEAL
description: The Metzler Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Resource Management International Inc., a privately owned consulting company, for about $65 million in stock. Metzler, a consulting company for the energy industry, said it expected the deal to be completed within 90 days. Last year, Metzler, based in Deerfield, Ill., had earnings of $4 million on revenue of $22 million. Resource Management, based in Sacramento, Calif., had $35 million in sales in 1996. Metzler shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $24.25, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: At 50, a Rock-and-Roll President Acts His Age in a Cable Special
description: There comes a moment in a forthcoming music-television special on President Clinton -- a sepia-tinted, reverential account of the ''rockin'est'' President's taste in 60's and 70's music -- when a slow smile drifts over Mr. Clinton's face and his gaze slips into the distance beyond the interviewer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: Doc Cheatham, Jazz Journeyman Who Blossomed Into a Star, Dies at 91
description: Doc Cheatham, a lyrical, elegant trumpet player whose career blossomed when he was in his 70's and who then became one of the jazz's best known stars, died yesterday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. Mr. Cheatham, who would have turned 92 on June 13, lived in Manhattan.

title: Commander at Aberdeen To Retire Over an Affair
description: In a demonstration of the military's heightened sensitivity to sexual misconduct, the commanding general of the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground has decided to retire after admitting that he committed adultery while separated from his wife more than five years ago, Pentagon officials said today.

description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day on Friday about a proposed purchase of a unit of Burlington Industries by the Sequa Corporation described Sequa incorrectly. It is a diversified company with interests including aerospace, machinery, metal coatings and detergent additives; it is Burlington that is a maker of fabrics, clothing and interior furnishings.

title: Justices Agree to Take Up Liability in Police Chases
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to set the legal standard for determining whether a police officer is liable for injuries resulting from a high-speed chase.

title: Bias in Scholarships Charged at 25 Colleges
description: A leading women's organization filed legal complaints today against 25 universities, charging that sexual discrimination has caused vast disparities between men and women in the awarding of athletic scholarship money.

title: Pearle Vision Names New Agency
description: Pearle Vision Inc. in Dallas, a unit of the Cole National Corporation that operates the Pearle Vision Centers retail chain, has named McCann-Erickson New York to handle its advertising and marketing account, with billings estimated at $25 million. The account had been handled by GSD& M in Austin, Tex., a unit of GGT Group, until that agency declined to participate in a review.

title: Now, Charges in Chaotic Life Of Malcolm X's Grandson, 12
description: When Malcolm Shabazz flew to San Antonio to rejoin his mother a few months ago, he and his family hoped it would be a new beginning for the boy, who had endured years of nomadic wanderings through cheap rooming houses, then a two-year separation from his troubled mother.

title: All, or Almost All, About a Father
description: Each season of ''P.O.V.'' (''Point of View''), the public-television ''showcase for independent nonfiction film'' that begins its summer run tonight, brings evidence of the tendency of young, experimenting documentarians to turn their cameras on their own lives. The mix of up-to-the-minute photographic display and old-fashioned family tribute or exposure can be effective; it can also be wearing. Often the works are sensitive; often they are self-indulgent. Alan Berliner's new offering, ''Nobody's Business,'' is all of the above.

title: Iconoclastic Genius of Cloning
description: THERE is a persistent rumor about Dr. Steen Malte Willadsen that rings so true to those who know him that it has taken on a life of its own. The story is that several years ago, without bothering to tell anyone, without troubling to write it up for publication, Dr. Willadsen cloned an adult cow.

title: Commander to Retire At Troubled Base
description: The two-star general who commands the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground, the troubled base in Maryland where drill sergeants have been court-martialed for sexual encounters with female recruits, has decided to retire at a lower rank. His decision follows an anonymous tip about an affair he had with a civilian while separated from his wife more than five years ago.

title: News Reporters in Family Court: Permissible but Rare
description: For years, firsthand news accounts of Family Court proceedings were rare. It was almost a given that judges would bar reporters from covering trials, and would often close their courtrooms to all but the parties involved. The prohibitions became so stringent that many people assumed that the public was legally barred from Family Court.

title: SMARTALK TELESERVICES PAYS $70 MILLION FOR GTI TELECOM
description: Smartalk Teleservices Inc. has acquired GTI Telecom Inc. for $70 million in a combination of two makers of prepaid phone cards. Smartalk, based in Los Angeles, said GTI would continue to operate out of its headquarters in Winter Park, Fla. Under the deal, which was announced Sunday, Smartalk will issue about 2.5 million common shares and $26 million in notes, and will assume about $10 million in GTI debt. Smartalk's stock slipped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $13.125, in Nasdaq trading. Smartalk said the privately held GTI had 1996 revenue of about $21 million. Last year, Smartalk reported a loss of $3.1 million on revenue of $15 million.

title: Chretien's Liberals, Pressing Austerity, Keep Slim Majority
description: Canadian voters returned Prime Minister Jean Chretien to power on Monday, giving him a slim Parliamentary majority and a weak mandate to continue with the fiscal austerity that has practically eliminated the country's federal deficit while cutting deeply into Canada's revered social programs.

description: Mitsui Toatsu Chemicals Inc. and the Sumitomo Chemical Company will merge their polystyrene businesses by October, the Japanese chemicals makers said yesterday at a news conference.

title: Insurer Asks for Reform
description: Dissatisfied with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's latest attempt at automotive insurance reform, one insurer is advancing a plan of its own. Yesterday, the Allstate Insurance Company began running ads on radio and cable television calling for lower mandatory coverage limits, more policy options for motorists and a crackdown on insurance fraud. In April, to help her plan's chances in the Legislature, the Governor dropped a proposal to offer motorists the option of less coverage for lower rates, a move that has drawn criticism from the insurance industry.

title: Hospital In Greenwich Is to Join Yale System
description: Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut, which had been among the nation's dwindling number of community hospitals striving to remain independent, announced yesterday that it was affiliating with the Yale-New Haven Health System.

title: Campbell Soup May Move
description: With negotiations with state officials at an impasse, the Campbell Soup Company is considering moving out of Camden, the only headquarters the 128-year-old soup maker has ever known. The state and the company have been discussing a deal in which the state would offer tax benefits and land purchases in return for Campbell's agreeing to stay in the state for at least six years. But the company is balking at making any commitment and says it will consider offers to move out of state, Bloomberg Business News reported yesterday. Campbell employs about 1,800 people at its Camden headquarters.

title: F.D.A. Plans to Control Herbal Stimulant Tied to Deaths
description: The Food and Drug Administration announced plans today to regulate the use of ephedrine, a herbal stimulant used for body building and weight loss that has been blamed for 20 to 30 deaths and more than 800 adverse reactions since 1993.

title: Development Talk Tonight
description: The Great Watershed Controversy will return to Emerson's center stage tonight. For years, advocates have urged the borough to buy 20 wooded acres near the Oradell reservoir to keep the property's owner, an offshoot of United Water Resources, from putting up 137 homes on Emerson's last developable land. About 150 acres surrounding the disputed parcel are protected as wetlands.

title: State Buying More Farms
description: Lee and Penny Hendrickson's 92-acre farm in Lawrence Township is one of 42 farms that will be bought and preserved forever under legislation signed by Governor Whitman yesterday. The measure provides $22 million to buy 6,500 acres of farms for the state's Farmland Preservation program (the Hendrickson's farm cost the state $625,000). Since the program began in 1983, the state has saved more than 38,000 acres of farmland from development, the director of the program said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMANN, DR. MANFRED R.
description: LEHMANN-Dr. Manfred R. BarIlan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn the passing of its honorary alumnus and distinguished member of our Global Board of Trustees, Dr. Manfred R. Lehmann, and extend its most profound condolences to his beloved wife Sara Anne and the entire family. In modern times, Dr. Lehmann personnified the man who was at one and at the same time a great scholar and successful merchant. However, he was also a distinguished champion of the cause of Israel. He wrote brilliantly on the subject and initiated many enterprises to achieve justice for the Jewish people-in almost every area where these claims were not being fulfilled. At Bar-Ilan University, he and his wife established a Chair in loving memory of their son Jamie, committed to the study and publication of Ancient and Medieval Jewish Liturgy, ''rightfully called archaeology of the Jewish soul.'' The more than one thousand articles he published were on subjects which ranged from the most scholarly to the most timely to the most fascinating. His loss is irreparable. We pray that his family will continue to play a vital role in Bar-Ilan University's development as already demonstrated by his daughter Karen and her husband David who were our inaugural Young Presidential Founders. We join with the family in deriving solace from inspiring memories. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor, Bar-Ilan University Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President, Bar-Ilan University Jane Stern Lebell, President, American Friends Brig. Gen. (RES) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUNDAGE, HOWARD DENTON
description: BRUNDAGE-Howard Denton, an investment advisor and Senior Vice President with Smith Barney Capital Management in Old Lyme, died at his home in Lyme, CT on May 31. He was 73 years old. Mr. Brundage was born in Newark, New Jersey on November 9, 1923 to Salome Louise Denton and Edgar Ray Brundage. He was a 1944 summa cum laude graduate of Dartmouth College and earned Phi Beta Kappa honors his Junior Year. He also graduated with distinction from Midshipmen Officers' School at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration. Mr. Brundage married Nancy Williams in 1945. They resided for a number of years in Montclair, New Jersey and Nantucket, Massachusetts prior to moving to Lyme, CT in 1977. Mr. Brundage's career spanned investment banking, commercial banking, venture capital and corporate finance. He worked with Morgan Stanley & Co., Hanover Bank, was a partner of J.H. Whitney & Co., and from 1962 to 1974 was Chief Financial Officer of J. Walter Thompson & Company. Mr. Brundage was a Director of London Guarantee and Accident Company, Phoenix Assurance Company, Smith Barney Equity Fund and Smith Barney Income Growth Fund. He served on the boards of Minute Maid Corporation, Morton Packing Company and Parade Magazine and was President and Director of the Herald Tribune newspaper. Mr. Brundage took an active interest in civic and charitable affairs. While living in Montclair, New Jersey he served as Parks Commissioner and Director of Revenue and Finance. He also served on the boards of the Montclair Art Museum, Mountainside Hospital, the Mountclair Public Library and was a trustee and VicePresident for Finance of the John and Florence Schumann Foundation. Mr. Brundage is survived by his wife of more than fifty years, Nancy Williams Brundage; a son, Peter Brundage, of Ft. Lauderdale, FL; three daughters: Louise Brundage Lynch, of Old Lyme, CT, Joanne Brundage Wilcox, of Madison, CT, and Geraldine Elizabeth Brundage, of Chester, CT; and six grandchildren. A memorial service is planned for 11 am Thursday, June 5 at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme. Fulton-Theroux Funeral Services at Old Lyme is in charge of arrangements. Contributions in Mr. Brundage's memory may be made to the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme (Ferry Road) or the Lyme Historical Society/ Florence Griswold Museum (Lyme Street) in Old Lyme, CT 06371.

title: Wells Keeps Yanks Rolling on the Road
description: Forget that David Wells looked overpowering while striking out four of the first six Red Sox tonight, because this was a night when he desperately searched for pitches in his repertory and found absolutely nothing. Zero. Wells had no curveball and his fastball shrank after its early display of life, so he had to improvise. He had to pitch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KULAK, BARNETT
description: KULAK-Barnett. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Anne Kulak on the loss of her husband, Barnett Kulak. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Falls 41.64, But Smaller Stocks Climb

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILIS, ISIDOR
description: BAILIS-Isidor. 95. On 6/1. Loving husband of the late Sonia, father of Ruth Potel and Seymour, brother of Shelly. Survived by six grandchildren and eighteen great grandchildren.

title: A New Hotel for Times Sq.
description: The booming hotel market around Times Square is growing by another 122 rooms. CDL Hotels International, the majority owner of the Millennium Broadway at 145 West 44th Street, formerly the Macklowe, has completed its $3.4 million purchase of the Newspaper Guild's headquarters two doors down and will soon begin construction of a 22-story hotel tower there.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions yesterday about the Tony Awards misstated the title of the winner for best play. It is ''The Last Night of Ballyhoo,'' not ''at Ballyhoo.''

title: Money for Women's Sites
description: CMP Media of Manhasset, N.Y., one of the nation's largest high-tech publishers, has bought a minority stake in Cybergrrl, a Manhattan company that develops on-line networks.

title: New Assignments For Bates Officials
description: Three executives of the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C. are changing jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAWITS, RUTH MILLER
description: SAWITS-Ruth Miller on May 31, 1997. One of the original ''Rosie the riveters'', she was a shipfitter of U.S. battleships during World War II and Shop Steward of Women's Shipfitters at Todd Shipyards in Hoboken, N.J. She died of mesothelioma, a cancer associated with asbestos exposure in the shipyards. She gave her life in the fight against Hitler. After World War II, she earner her M.A. in Education and was for many years a teacher and junior high school counselor in New York and Ohio. An early feminist and social activist, she fought throughout her life for justice in a variety of causes. She was a descendent of many noted rabbis including Reb Isaiah Shor, Chief Rabbi of Jasi. She leaves her husband of sixty years, Murray, two children, Peter and Ellie, her son-in-law, David Gasner and her two grandchildren, Max and Alex Gasner. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEUBERGER, MARIE SALANT
description: NEUBERGER-Marie Salant. A Memorial Service for Marie Salant Neuberger will be held Thursday, June 19, 1997 at 5 PM at The New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 St, New York, NY.

title: What is hip? Warner-Lambert wants youth appeal for Schick and Wilkinson Sword products.
description: MANY advertisers strive to infuse brands with contemporary attitudes that are oh-so-edgy. But what do you do when your products are already edgy or even double-edgy?

title: On Broadway, The Line With No End
description: NOW that the Tonys have been doled out to winners like the shows about that toddlin' town and that totterin' ship, maybe Broadway should think about creating a new award that gets to the bottom of the theater-going experience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, GOLDIE (NEE GRONENBERG)
description: LEVINE-Goldie (nee Gronenberg). On May 30, 1997. Beloved wife of Louis H., loving mother of Honey and Leonard Slavit, Morton and Susan Levine. Grandmother of Ira and Diana, David and Robin, Gail, Richard and Patti, and Gary. Great-grandmother of Gillian, Michael, Danielle, Evan, Roni, Meredith, Taylor and Mallorie.

title: Pippen Is Quietly Essential
description: This is not to imply Scottie Pippen is a square, because he is as cool and smooth as the blues, but he has also become the Muzak for the Chicago Bulls.

title: Smith Barney Dismisses Official Linked to Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: Smith Barney Inc. has dismissed Robert B. Maloney, its New England regional director, whose role in raising campaign contributions for his brother, Representative James H. Maloney, Democrat of Connecticut, is under investigation by Federal authorities, the firm said yesterday.

title: Past as Prologue: Blair Faults Britain in Irish Potato Blight
description: In Ireland, even distant history is never very far away. So when Tony Blair, the British Prime Minister, expressed regret over the weekend about Britain's role in the potato famine that devastated Ireland in the mid-19th century, he inserted himself into a debate that seems almost as fresh as if the famine took place in the 1940's instead of the 1840's.

title: Millennium Partners Raises $300 Million
description: Millennium Partners, the company that built Lincoln Square, a 1.7 million-square-foot mixed-use complex at 68th Street and Broadway, and is seeking to replicate it in several cities across the country, has raised $300 million in capital for new projects from Goldman Sachs & Company's Whitehall Fund, George Soros, the financier, and a group of German insurance companies.

title: The 1997 Tony Award Winners
description: These are the winners of the 1997 Antoinette Perry Awards, presented by the the League of American Theaters and Producers with the American Theater Wing on Sunday night at Radio City Music Hall:

title: From the Inside Out, an Artist in His Element
description: While so many of Fernand Leger's contemporaries were looking at the world through prisms of intimacy, introspection or abstraction, the Normandy-born artist was drawn by the colors and shapes of urban and industrial life in the first half of the 20th century. His choice was not accidental. Before becoming a painter in his 20's, Leger studied architecture, and the resulting concern with form influenced his entire approach to painting.

title: A New Shooting Star of the Left: Lionel Robert Jospin
description: Four years ago, Lionel Jospin, stunned by the crushing defeat of his Socialist Party in the 1993 parliamentary elections, was pondering whether to give up politics and return to his original career as a diplomat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOS, JULIE ANN
description: ROOS-Julie Ann. Beloved daughter of Roberta and Edwin, loving sister to Andrew and Peter, sisterin law to Susan and Elizabeth, devoted aunt to Alexander, MacAlister, Ethan, Kaile and Emma. Cherished friend of many around the world. Passed away from us to a better place on Tuesday, May 27, 1997. Her smile and courage touched all those who knew her, and will ease the pain of our loss. She will be deerly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The National Marfan Foundation, 328 Main Street, Port Washington, NY 11050. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, June 5, 1997 at 1:30 p.m. at the Central Synogogue, 123 East 55th Street, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LINFIELD, DEBORAH
description: LINFIELD-Deborah. What happened? I love you. I miss you. Mom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORLOWSKY, IRENE HENRY
description: ORLOWSKY-Irene Henry, of Garrison, NY, on May 25. Beloved wife of Eli; loving mother of Douglas and Philip, and adoring grandmother of four. Cremated May 27. Donations in her memory may be made to the Fresh Air Fund.

title: In Banned Testimony, Father Says Kelly Denied Raping Girl
description: Over loud objections from the prosecution and in defiance of a judge's warning, Alex Kelly's father testified today that his son denied raping a 16-year-old girl after he had driven her home from a party in Darien more than a decade ago.

title: From Ripken's Shadow to the Mets' Lineup
description: Manny Alexander, the replacement for the injured Mets shortstop Rey Ordonez, waited years in Baltimore for this chance: to play every day. But as he watched from the Orioles' bench, as the supposed heir apparent to Cal Ripken, Alexander came to believe he never would replace the future Hall of Famer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERCE, PAULINE (POLLY)
description: PIERCE-Pauline (Polly). Died at her home on June 1, 1997. Wellknown social worker in New York City, loved and will be missed by many. No services will be held.

title: Taking Stereotyping to a New Level in Fashion
description: Stereotypes are the shorthand of sitcoms and stylists.

title: Finding the Animal In Ibsen's Airhead
description: It may have taken Nora Helmer, the trapped, unhappy heroine of ''A Doll's House,'' half a lifetime to acquire the insight and courage to slam the door on Torvald, her self-consumed, suffocating husband. But never for an instant did Janet McTeer, the strapping English actress who plays her in the acclaimed Broadway revival of Ibsen's masterwork, have a doubt as to what kind of ''Doll's House'' she wanted to build.

title: Bond Prices End Mixed on Rate Concerns
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, after a strong manufacturing report raised the specter that the Federal Reserve might again increase interest rates. The report offset good demand from European investors who were looking for a safe haven after a Socialist-led coalition won French elections.

title: Overloaded Water Slide Falls; 1 Is Killed and 32 Are Injured
description: A section of a water slide at an amusement park near here snapped today after it was overloaded by dozens of teen-agers, killing one of them and injuring 32 others.

title: Drug Laws Help Foster Juror Rebellions
description: To the Editor:

title: Melodrama as Structure for Subtlety
description: THE GOD OF SMALL THINGS

title: A New Market For First Union
description: The First Union Corporation said today that its investment banking unit had received approval from the Federal Reserve to begin equity underwriting.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: Dollar Gains as Traders Bet Euro Will Be Weakened
description: Faced with a Socialist victory in France and an unusual domestic spat between the German Government and the central bank, currency traders headed for safe harbors today. They quickly bought up American dollars and British pounds while pushing down the value of both the French franc and the German mark.

title: A Ruined Church Laments Stones Left Unturned
description: It was pure luck that no one was in the Noto cathedral the night more than a year ago when the roof fell in. But that was the only fortunate aspect of an otherwise sorry tale that is still unfolding, as workers pick through the rubble and local officials quarrel over who was to blame.

title: Man Who Stole 3 Purses Dies After a Struggle, Police Say
description: A man who had snatched purses from three women in Brooklyn yesterday morning died after being injured in a confrontation with relatives of one victim, the police said.

title: Plans for Insanity Defense
description: A 31-year-old computer programmer charged with murdering his parents in their home in Englewood last September will enter an insanity defense at trial, his lawyer said yesterday. The suspect, De Witt L. Crandell 2d, is manic depressive and suffers periodic psychotic episodes, the lawyer, Brian J. Neary, said at Mr. Crandell's arraignment. Mr. Neary said his client stabbed his 66-year-old father, De Witt, 50 times. His mother, Miriam, 63, was stabbed four times. No date has been set for the trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REMY, JEAN, CLAUDE MD.
description: REMY-Jean-Claude MD. The attending and resident staff of the department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at New York Methodist Hospital sadly note the sudden passing of Dr. Jean-Claude Remy, a distinguished Gynecologist-Oncologist and a beloved member of our attending staff. Richard Schwarz MD, Chairman

title: Hong Kong Retailer Fined $12 Million
description: Giordano International Ltd., a retailer based in Hong Kong, was fined 93 million Hong Kong dollars ($12 million) by Chinese authorities for violating customs and commerce rules, the company said yesterday. The company, whose expansion in China has met repeated obstacles since its former chairman, Jimmy Lai, criticized Chinese leaders, said it was appealing the fines and so had not yet recorded any losses to cover the cost of the penalty.

title: McVEIGH GUILTY ON ALL COUNTS IN THE OKLAHOMA CITY BOMBING; JURY TO WEIGH DEATH PENALTY
description: As silent tears streamed down the faces of victims and their families in the packed courtroom, a Federal jury today found Timothy J. McVeigh, an angry drifter, guilty of the Oklahoma City bombing, which killed 168 people, injured hundreds more and shook the nation's sense of security within its borders.

title: Broadway Theater Plan Faces Big Hurdles
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Arson Is Cited in Fire That Kills Brooklyn Man
description: Moments after a Brooklyn mother ushered her three young children into the hallway outside their 10th-floor apartment yesterday morning and went back inside alone, a suspicious fire tore through the apartment, killing her husband and seriously injuring the woman, the police said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When YO-YO MA, the cellist, and TAN DUN, the composer and conductor, were at Tanglewood together last summer, they began discussing how they might collaborate. They had little idea that they would make music for Hong Kong's passage from British to Chinese rule next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, FAE (NEE KAUFMAN)
description: COHEN-Fae (nee Kaufman). On June 2, 1997. Beloved mother of Paul and Natalie Forbes, and Robert and Liane Feuer. Cherished sister of Jerry and William Strulowitz and Rita and Martin Bachner. Adored grandmother of Amy and Miguel Carmona, Marilyn Feuer, Helen Feuer and Neal Epstein, and Beth Gilbert. Great grandmother of Matthew Nathan Epstein. Dearest friend and companion of Nathan Kardonsky. Services, Boulevard Riverside, 1450 B'way, Hewlett, NY, Tues, June 3, 12:30pm.

description: Helmut Lang's Men's Shows

description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Won't Fret Over a Lost Chance
description: It was a shot that has shattered the psyches of many teams -- a game-winning jumper at the buzzer. On Sunday, the Utah Jazz witnessed the majesty of Michael Jordan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRINDELL, HAROLD. HAZZAN
description: BRINDELL-Harold. Hazzan. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of the Hazzan of West Surburban Temple Har Zion of River Forest, IL for more than four decades. He served the spiritual needs of his congregants with great dignity, warmth and care. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Florence, his children, grandchildren and all his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Abraham Lubin, Pres. Henry Rosenblum, Pres. Elect Abraham B. Shapiro, Exec Admin

title: Lab's Task: Assuring Bombs' Quality Without Pulling Nuclear Trigger
description: Nearly 1,000 feet beneath the desert floor, in an area pockmarked by years of nuclear explosions, the Department of Energy is showing off a new laboratory in which it wants to conduct plutonium experiments of a new and controversial kind: to assure that aging nuclear weapons will still perform, without actually detonating them.

title: Threatening Paula Jones
description: All may be fair in love, war and lawsuits, but not all tactics are Presidential. Even in litigation, dignity has a place. President Clinton should warn his personal lawyer, Robert Bennett, that there are some tactics he cannot use when publicly defending the President in a civil suit brought by Paula Jones. One is threatening on national television to ruin Ms. Jones's reputation by bringing up her sexual history.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an agreement between Russia and Ukraine misspelled the surname of Ukraine's top military official. He is Volodimyr Horbulin, not Korbulin.

title: Stevens Seeks Triple Crown on Silver Charm
description: It has been 19 years since a horse won the Triple Crown, 19 years since Gary Stevens sat in front of the television set at his parents' home in Boise, Idaho, a 15-year-old boy rooting for Affirmed and a rider not even three years older than himself.

title: The Big Barbecue
description: The great story is prosperity. It is here, and with a vengeance. There is so much money washing around the country that people have to get out of bed at dawn on Saturdays to get it all spent before the week is out.

title: Steel With Soft Surface
description: In the last few years, multiple sclerosis has slowly stolen the strength in Joseph H. Hartzler's legs, forcing him to use a motorized scooter to get around the Little League baseball field where he coaches his son's team, and the aisles of the Federal courtroom in Denver where he was the lead prosecutor in the trial of Timothy J. McVeigh.

title: While It's Merger Season on Wall St., Some Question the Firm's Intentions
description: Lehman Brothers was all smiles and chuckles on May 7. The company's stock price surged 11 percent that day as rumors circulated that a big financial institution would shortly acquire the vaunted investment bank.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about independent bookstores in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the husband-and-wife team who own the Corner Bookstore, on Madison Avenue at 93d Street, and the Lenox Hill Bookstore, at 1018 Lexington Avenue, near 72d Street. She is Lenny Golay; he is Ray Sherman, not Golay.

title: Accounts
description: * Hampel/Stefanides, New York, has resigned the account of the New York Restaurant Group, which the agency had handled since August 1995. The agency cited creative and philosophical differences. Billings on the account were estimated at $1 million to $1.5 million. The restaurants owned by the company include Smith & Wollensky and the Post House.
