description: To the Editor:

title: France Rebels Against Austerity
description: French voters did more on Sunday than force President Jacques Chirac into an unwanted and unwieldy governing partnership with the Socialist opposition. They also sent a warning likely to resound through Europe, especially in other high-unemployment countries of the European Union like Germany, Italy, Spain and Greece. Governments that demand cuts in the welfare state to meet the eligibility conditions of a single European currency do so at considerable political risk.

title: Missing Tables
description: Tables listing foreign stocks, active bond issues and Government agency and Treasury zero-coupon bonds were unavailable yesterday.

title: Messinger Picks Sides In Heated Race For Her Post
description: Ruth W. Messinger endorsed a black City Councilwoman, C. Virginia Fields, over a lesbian in the contest for Manhattan borough president yesterday, picking sides in a politically vexing clash that had pitted two of her main constituencies against one another for most of the year.

title: Gay Couples' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPILLANE, LAURA ELIZABETH CARMODY
description: SPILLANE-Laura Elizabeth Carmody, of Charlotte, North Carolina, formerly of Freeport and Cold Spring Hills, Long Island, on May 27, 1997. Mrs. Spillane is survived by her children, Claire Wilfert and Vivian McCarthy, both of Charlotte, Linda Steinmetz of Abbeville, SC, and John Spillane of Wilmington, NC; a sister, Barbara Hall of Lancaster, PA; 2 brothers, Charles Carmody of Freeport, L.I. and George Carmody of Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. She is also survived by five grandchildren and 4 great-grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York, Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Wednesday at the funeral home. Interment in Cedar Grove Cemetery.

title: Unicef Says U.N. Reforms Could Harm the World's Children
description: As the United Nations prepares for the broadest restructuring in its history, the executive director of Unicef took the unusual step today of warning publicly that, under the proposed changes, the agency is in danger of losing its independent voice for children around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYNES, MARY C.
description: HAYNES-Mary C. On June 1st 1997 age 77 of Port Jefferson Station, NY formerly of St. James, NY and Hartsdale, NY. Former Director of Nursing for I.B.M. Medical Division, White Plains, NY. Beloved and cherished sister of Francis C. Haynes, Patricia Ciancarelli and sisters-in-law Rose and Mary Haynes. Adored aunt of many nieces, nephews and great nieces and nephews. Daughter of the late Ernest J. and Carolyn Haynes. Loved sister of the late Catherine Hiebler, Michael, Ernest, George and John Haynes and late nephews Ernest and James Haynes. Reposing at The Branch Funeral Home, INC. 190 E. Main St., Smithtown. Funeral Mass St. Philip & James R C Church 10am Thursday. Interment St. John of God Cemetery. Visiting 2-4 & 7-9:30pm.

title: Voters Could Enhance Or Eclipse County Bosses
description: The Robert Treat Hotel is hardly Tammany Hall. But located in a small suite on the 16th floor of the historic downtown hotel is the headquarters of the closest thing that Essex County has to a political machine.

title: The Albright Idiom
description: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright promised a new level of candor when she took charge of American foreign policy. She delivered during a weekend visit to the Balkan region. In a series of remarkably blunt conversations with the leaders of Croatia and Serbia, Ms. Albright made plain that they had failed to carry out many of the provisions of the Dayton peace agreement.

title: McVEIGH GUILTY ON ALL COUNTS IN THE OKLAHOMA CITY BOMBING; JURY TO WEIGH DEATH PENALTY: HEALING MUST WAIT
description: After the explosion, people learned to write left-handed, to tie just one shoe. They learned to endure the pieces of metal and glass embedded in their flesh, to smile with faces that made them want to cry, to cry with glass eyes. They learned, in homes where children had played, to stand the quiet. They learned to sleep with pills, to sleep alone.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: VICTORY FOR ARTISTS -- The Supreme Court has affirmed the First Amendment rights of artists to sell their wares on city sidewalks. B3.

title: PHYSICIAN CORPORATION DISCLOSES NEW MERGER TALKS
description: The Physician Corporation of America said yesterday that it was in talks with an unnamed partner to be bought for $7 a share, or $266 million, two months after a previous suitor abandoned an agreement to buy the managed-care company. The Miami-based company said in February that it would take an $80 million charge to cover claims from workers' compensation insurance policies. In March, Sierra Health Services Inc. ended an agreement to buy Physician, citing widening losses at the division. That agreement was valued at $11.81 a share. Shares of Physician, which also operates health maintenance organizations, fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $6.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Making a Classic Gentler and Warmer
description: American Ballet Theater has come up with a glowing gem in Frederic Franklin's new production of ''Coppelia,'' performed for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday and with a different cast on Saturday afternoon.

title: Nigerians Fire on Rebels Who Seized Sierra Leone
description: A West African force led by Nigeria went on the offensive today to put down an eight-day-old military coup in Sierra Leone, sending ships, planes and troops into action against rebel targets in Freetown, the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, SELMA
description: SUSSMAN-Selma. Beloved wife of Alfred Sussman, dear mother of Jean (Ed Lyons) Sussman, Paul (Linda Dallin) and Harold (Shekoofeh) Sussman. Grandmother of Maya and Leo Sussman, Sabrina and Cyrus Sussman. Sister of Stanley (Joyce) Feinman and Beatrice (Harry) Kirsch and Rosalyn (Morty) Rudin. Services 10am Wednesday at Congregation Beth Israel in Ann Arbor, MI. For information: The Ira Kaufman Chapel, 248-569-0020

title: Chess
description: Three foreign grandmasters and one American shared first place in the 1997 National Open Tournament in Las Vegas, Nev. Dmitry Gurevich of Chicago, Alexander Baburin of Ireland, formerly of Russia, Julian Hodgson of England and Ilya Smirin of Israel scored 5 1/2-2 1/2 in the six-round Swiss system event and each was awarded a $2,937.50 prize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, KURT A. M.D. PH.D
description: ADLER-Kurt A. M.D. Ph.D The Department of Psychiatry expresses its profound sadness on the death of its esteemed member, Kurt A. Adler, MD, Ph.D. Dr. Adler was Emeritius Associate Psychiatrist on the voluntary medical staff of Lenox Hill Hospital and ably served this institution since 1947. A wise and vital man up to the time of his death, Dr. Adler was a Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and President of the Board of Directors of the Advanced Institute for Analytic Psychotherapy. Dr. Adler was mentor to several Chiefs of Service and to the Director of this Department, and could always be relied upon to provide incisive and wise counsel. All of us in the Department shall very much miss Kurt. He was one of a kind. Allen H. Collins, MD, MPH Director Joseph P. Merlino, MD, MPA Associate Director Lenox Hill Hospital New York, New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, JUDITH
description: BLOCK-Judith. Wife of Hilbert Block. Mother of Arthur, Richard, Richard and Marcy. Mother-in-law of Helen and grandmother of Michael and Karen. Eulogy and gathering at the Block residence on June 7 beginning at 1PM.

title: A Drama That Was Hardly Made for Television Struck Deeply All the Same
description: The verdict on the trial was delivered days before the verdicts on the defendant. On Friday night, as the jury in the Oklahoma City bombing case was still sorting itself out, trial watchers on Jim Lehrer's ''NewsHour'' agreed that the judge had tolerated no nonsense and that the lawyers had behaved themselves.

title: BOSTON CHICKEN TO CUT HEADQUARTERS STAFF BY 25%
description: Boston Chicken Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss 115 employees, or one-fourth of its headquarters staff, and have franchisees combine their administrative duties to cut annual costs by as much as $40 million. The company is also reviewing, and may scale back, plans to add 300 franchised restaurants this year. The layoffs will result in a second-quarter pretax charge of as much as $4 million. With sales at its Boston Market restaurants stagnating, the fast-food chain is struggling to cut costs. Its problems have pushed the company's stock down from a record $41.50, reached Dec. 6. Boston Chicken's shares fell $1.875, to $16.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOST MARRIOTT CORP., Bethesda, Md., which owns hotels that operate under the names Marriott and Ritz-Carlton, paid $32.5 million for a 90 percent stake in the Norfolk Waterside Marriott hotel in Norfolk, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, INGRID
description: BERNSTEIN-Ingrid The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of Ingrid Bernstein, beloved mother Sherry and Bruce Cohen, founders of our synagogue. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: At City University, 120 Receive B.A.'s In Special Program
description: Florence Klein started college 58 years ago. Yesterday, at the City University of New York baccalaureate commencement, she finished.

title: Dressed In Black And Angst
description: The first time around, as Luigi Pirandello presented it 70-some years ago, the exchange took place in the drawing room of an ''ancient palace'' in Italy. Ancient palaces (and even drawing rooms) are hard to come by in contemporary Manhattan, however. So the young playwright and director Jeremy Dobrish has set virtually the same conversation between two desperately trendy young things in a downtown art gallery.

title: Free House in Easy Workout
description: Free House, who has chased Silver Charm through two legs of the Triple Crown and who will try to catch him one more time in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday, worked five furlongs in 1:01 3/5 yesterday morning in his final formal rehearsal for the return match.

title: Republican Is Chosen To Seek Molinari Seat
description: Vito J. Fossella Jr., a three-year City Councilman, was selected by the executive committee of the Staten Island Republican Party as its candidate to run for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Susan Molinari.

title: The McVeigh Jury Speaks
description: In finding Timothy McVeigh guilty yesterday in the 1995 terrorist bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal building, the jury in the case rendered a verdict that was amply supported by the evidence. The outcome has provided a restorative measure of justice and closure for the blast's survivors and for victims' relatives, many of whom hugged and wept when they heard the jury's finding. It has also provided a reassuring example of the nation's jury system at work.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AUFHAUSER, ALFRED
description: AUFHAUSER-Alfred. It is with fondest remembrance of Alfred that I salute his lifelong friendship, humor and personality. Walter C. Klein

title: F.D.A. Can't Meet Youth-Smoking Goals
description: To the Editor:

title: Rush Is On For Cloning Of Animals
description: AT a branch of PPL Therapeutics in Blacksburg, Va., Dr. Willard Eyestone said he had about a half-dozen cows that were pregnant with clones made from the skin cells of fetal calves. At the University of Wisconsin, Dr. Neal First has several sheep pregnant with clones made from adult skin cells. But the two cautioned that the animals were still early in pregnancy and there was no guarantee that they would carry the clones to term.

title: After Jordan, New Script For N.B.A.?
description: THE buzzer-beating, Game 1-winning jump shot straight out of a million schoolyard dreams was made after many others had clanged off the rim, which made Michael Jordan want to say, as he does in his latest state-of-the-art television spot, that repeated failure is what primes him to succeed.

title: LAZARD TO BUY 38% STAKE IN ALEXANDER HAAGEN
description: A unit of Lazard Freres will purchase $235 million in newly issued common shares of Alexander Haagen Properties Inc. The purchase, over two years, will give Lazard Freres Real Estate Investors a 38 percent stake in Alexander Haagen, a real estate investment trust that owns and operates retail shopping centers, chiefly in Southern California. Shares of Alexander Haagen Properties rose $1.0625, to $15.0625, on the American Stock Exchange. The investment will give Lazard the right to name four representatives to a revamped 10-member board at Alexander Haagen.

title: Industry Index In Unexpected May Rebound
description: A survey of the nation's corporate buyers the officials who purchase everything from paper clips to trucks -- showed unexpected strength in manufacturing during May even as consumer spending began to slow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, HON
description: BROWN-Hon. Lawrence Vroom, 82, of Middletown, NJ, formerly of Staten Island, on May 31, 1997. Husband of Winifred R. Father of Pamela B. Diamond. Grandfather of three. Great-grandfather of one. Graveside services at Moravian Cemetery, Staten Island, on Wednesday, June 4, at 11 AM. Visitation Tuesday, 7-9 PM, at the Worden-Hoidal Funeral Home, 60 East Front St., Red Bank, NJ.

title: Judge Sets Award Limits For Suffering
description: In what is believed to be the first effort to place definable limits on ''pain and suffering'' damage awards in civil cases, a Federal judge yesterday issued statistical guidelines intended to help juries accomplish that task.

title: Nice Guys Finish First With $17.5 Million Lottery Win
description: The snatch of conversation from the women leaving the elevator at 28 West 23d Street in Manhattan at closing time yesterday afternoon went this way:

title: U.S. Case Against 2d Defendant May Not Go as Smoothly
description: The guilty verdict against Timothy J. McVeigh yesterday does not necessarily mean the Government's case against his co-defendant, Terry L. Nichols, will proceed as smoothly.

title: Top Soft-Drink Makers Raise Stakes in Brand War
description: The beverage wars among the nation's top three soft-drink producers intensified yesterday as Pepsico Inc. said that it would create a new division for its $6.14 billion company-owned bottling operations to increase its competitiveness.

title: Giuliani Says Pataki Must Do More to Resolve Rent Impasse
description: With two weeks left until state rent controls expire, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani traveled here today and called on Gov. George E. Pataki to become more involved in resolving the impasse, while the Governor went to New York City to begin a public relations campaign in favor of his proposal to phase out rent regulations.

title: Johnson May Miss Nationals
description: A day after Michael Johnson pulled up with a thigh injury in a match race against Donovan Bailey of Canada, questions arose yesterday about whether he would be able to participate in the national track and field championships next week.

title: The Gathering Storm
description: Now in one document, available with a phone call, are two revealing exposures of the failure of President Clinton's policy of putting trade above all other U.S. interests in China.

title: U.S. Steel Sells Stake in Plants
description: USX-U.S. Steel Group Inc. said today that it had sold an interest in three Clairton Works coke processing plants to two unnamed limited partners for about $360 million before taxes.

title: Slain Girl Is Mourned in Chinatown
description: The smoke of burning incense curled to the ceiling of a funeral home in Chinatown yesterday, an ephemeral sign that those who loved her wished Wu Quin-Rong all the peace and happiness in her next life that she was denied in this one.

title: Zurich Insurance Sells $1 Billion in Debt
description: Zurich Insurance Group, a Swiss insurer that is negotiating to buy Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc., a big United States money manager, has sold $1 billion in debt to finance the expansion of the company. Zurich shares rose as much as 4.2 percent yesterday after the company said it had sold $1 billion in so-called capital securities to institutions. Investors were apparently confident that the unexpected debt sale would be used to help finance a bid for Scudder.

title: Puncturing Czech Economic Miracle
description: No longer is Vaclav Klaus the infallible economic miracle maker of Eastern Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, DAVID
description: SCHWARTZ-David. You left us a legacy of wonderful memories. Thanks for the memories. We love you. Your family

title: Severity of Shabazz's Burns Hurt Her Chances to Survive
description: The director of the medical team treating Dr. Betty Shabazz, who remains in critical condition with severe burns on 80 percent of her skin, said yesterday that surgery would put her at great risk but that her doctors had no choice.

title: Essence of Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Family Ever on the Verge of Emotion
description: It cannot be easy to sing lines from ''Blues in the Night'' and ''Off to See the Wizard'' while completely different music plays in the background, as Gregory Prather does in Ed Bullins's ''Boy X Man,'' but Mr. Bullins seems to love demanding the near-impossible of actors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, MORTON DR.
description: NATHANSON-Morton Dr. Died early June 1 after a brief illness at age 79. Dr. Nathanson was the founder and Chairman of the Department of Neurology at LIJ/ HMC . He was a mentor, teacher and guiding force of neurologists throughout the United States. Surviving are his wife, Margret, his children, David, Madlyn Nathanson Flavell and Laura Nathanson Kroehling, 5 grandchildren, and his sister Roslyn Klarish. There will be no memorial service.

title: TV Ratings for Tony Show Rise 35 Percent
description: With Rosie O'Donnell as host of the Tony Awards, and as a relentless promoter of the ceremony on her daily talk show, the Nielsen rating for the CBS portion of the awards broadcast Sunday night jumped about 35 percent from last year.

title: Jewel Lafontant-Mankarious, Lawyer and U.S. Official, Dies
description: Jewel Lafontant-Mankarious, a Chicago lawyer who held high posts in the Nixon and Bush Administrations, was active in the civil rights movement and was on the boards of major corporations, died on Saturday at her home in Chicago. She was 75.

title: Faster Surfing, Some of the Time
description: THE latest modems may help reduce the World Wide Wait, but they are guaranteed to increase confusion. They have become known as ''56K'' modems even though they can neither receive data faster than 53 kilobits a second nor transmit it faster than current 33.6-kilobit models. They come in two types, X2 and K56flex, distinguishable largely by their incompatible high-speed standards. You will probably want one sooner or later, but since partisans have recently turned up the volume in a standards shouting match, clarifications are in order.

title: Beyond Fleetwood Mac and the Sax
description: Here is a Presidential opinion that actually transcends politics. ''I still think 'Eleanor Rigby' is one of the most powerful songs I ever heard,'' Bill Clinton says about the haunting but, let's face it, mawkish Beatles song. That is the most daring, debatable opinion he offers in a gushy VH-1 interview about what music has meant to him. Of course, you wouldn't expect him to be grilled about the Federal budget on something called ''Bill Clinton: Rock 'n' Roll President.'' But you might hope that the special would be as lively and as much fun as its quasi-irreverent title promises.

title: Scottish Media in Talks For Grampian Television
description: The shares of Grampian Television P.L.C. surged yesterday after Scottish Media Group P.L.C. confirmed that it was in talks to buy the northern Scotland broadcaster for about $:105.6 million ($173 million). The bid for Grampian, at 320 pence a share, would broaden the reach of Scottish Media, which owns Scottish TV in central Scotland and The Herald newspaper in Glasgow.

title: Blair Scolds British 'Workless Class' in Outline of Welfare Plan
description: Appearing at a notoriously neglected housing project in South London, Prime Minister Tony Blair today denounced the culture of dependency on government that he said had created a ''workless class'' of people who live off the state and have no motivation to find jobs.

title: Executive Changes
description: FILENE'S BASEMENT CORP., Wellesley, Mass., named W. Jay Carothers president, chief operating officer and director. Mr. Carothers previously was president of the Federated Merchandising Group. He succeeds Mone Anathan 3d, who is seeking early retirement. The appointment takes effect on June 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALB, ZELDA
description: KALB-Zelda. on June 2, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis Kalb, loving mother of Toby ( Howard), Robert ( JoAnn), Paul (Terry) and the late David. Grandmother of Jesse, Jennifer, Allison (David), Joanna, Ben, Jonathan and Jamie. Services today, 10:30am at Riverside Chapel, Hewlett.

title: New Accusation In Investigations Of Bear Stearns
description: An employee of the Bear Stearns Companies has said that an executive of the firm told him to destroy documents that were sought by investigators examining the relationship between Bear and A. R. Baron & Company, a defunct brokerage firm which cleared trades through Bear, according to correspondence between lawyers in the case.

title: Tougher on Emissions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, WALLY
description: SCHUSTER-Wally. Of New York and Las Vegas. Retired music publisher. Beloved and worshipped husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Peter, Jason and Michael. Loving grandfather of Maisie. Adored brother of Phoebe & Leonard Lewin. Cherished uncle of John & Lynn and Jamie and Lee Lewin. Dear brother-in-law of Jackie & Gary Barnett. Fond cousin and friend of many. Services were held in California. You will never be forgotten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTULLI, THOMAS V.
description: SANTULLI-Thomas V., Pediatric Surgeon and former Chief, Pediatric Surgical Service, Babies and Children's Hospital of New York, born March 16, 1915, died June 2, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife, Patricia Anne, (nee Rita); two sons, Dr. Thomas V. Santulli, Jr. and Dr. Robert B. Santulli, a brother, Vincent Santulli, and five grandchildren. Predeceased by his first wife, Dorothy (nee Beverley). Reposing Wednesday, 3-7 PM, Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. (W. 261st St., Bronx). Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, 11 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment st. Mary's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Santulli Lectureship, Columbia University or the Pediatric Surgical Research Fund, the Babies and Children's Hospital of New York.

title: Trying Again, Gigante Team Offers Case for Incompetency
description: A Mafia murder case became a medical school seminar yesterday as lawyers for Vincent Gigante began a last-ditch attempt to convince a judge that the suspected mob boss is mentally unfit to stand trial.

title: Chrysler Says May Sales Fell As Strike Crimped Output
description: The Chrysler Corporation became the first in the auto industry to fulfill Wall Street's prophesy that May sales results by the Big Three American auto makers would be weak, compared with the strong monthly sales levels of a year ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CINNAMON, ANNE
description: CINNAMON-Anne of Hallandale Fl. formerly of Asbury Park, New Jersey passed away June 1, 1997. She was predeceased by her loving husband Morris Cinnamon Graveside Services Thursday, June 5 11 A.M. at Beth El Cemetery Glendale, NY.

title: SoHo Street Artists Triumph As High Court Rebuffs City
description: Ending a case that pitted the First Amendment rights of street artists against New York City's efforts to control sidewalk congestion, the United States Supreme Court yesterday refused to hear the city's appeal of an earlier ruling that barred it from requiring the artists to be licensed.

title: The Mets Play Through the Rain, but It's Still a Washout
description: The Mets would have been justified had they called off last night's game with Montreal at Shea Stadium. Rain fell all day and into the evening, creating small marshes where outfielders would roam.

title: Bus-Truck Collision Injures 24 in Brooklyn
description: A bus returning to Chinatown in Manhattan from a trip to Atlantic City collided with a tractor-trailer truck yesterday morning on the rain-swept Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn, pinning the truck driver in his cab and causing minor injuries to the bus driver and his 23 passengers, the police said.

title: One of Medicine's Best-Kept Secrets: Methadone Works
description: BACK when a subway ride cost 15 cents, Dr. Vincent Dole, a metabolic specialist, and Dr. Marie Nyswander, a psychiatrist, joined forces to try to reverse a worrisome rise in heroin addiction in New York City.

description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Ends Appeals In Drug-Pricing Suit
description: A Federal appeals judge cleared the way today for a $352 million price-fixing settlement involving 11 major drug companies to take effect in September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, ROBERTSON D.
description: WARD-Robertson D. Age 91, May 30, 1997. Meadow Lakes, NJ., formerly of Short Hills, NJ. Husband of Margaret Elizabeth Wright Clark, father of Mike Ward, Ted Ward & Toni Carr, grandfather of eight, great grandfather of four. graduate of Princeton University 1926, former partner of J.H. Whitney & Co., former Director of Crum & Forster and Marine Colloids. Served as Chairman & Trustee of the Overlook Hospital, Summitt, NJ and St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, NJ Memorial service to be held in the Main Chapel of Princeton University, Thursday, June 12 at 2:30 PM.

title: Enron to Pay $440 Million to Settle Gas Dispute
description: The Enron Corporation said today that it would pay $440 million in cash to settle litigation with the Phillips Petroleum Company over an agreement to buy high-priced natural gas from a North Sea field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, ELEANOR C.
description: CLARKE-Eleanor C. on June 2, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late James T. and Eleanor N. (nee Ryan). Loving sister of James A., Margaret M. Sullivan, William T. and the late Joseph P., sister-inlaw of Mary. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St., NY, NY Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10 AM, St. Bernard's R.C. Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Study Ranks Software as No. 3 Industry
description: The computer software business has risen rapidly to become America's third-largest manufacturing industry, paying wages twice the national average, according to a new study.

title: 16 Palestinians Marked for Death for Selling Land, Israelis Say
description: Israeli security forces have information that 16 Palestinian dealers involved in selling land to Jews have been marked for death, including three land dealers already killed during the last month, an Israeli newspaper reported today.

title: ANTHEM OFFERS $7 A SHARE FOR ACORDIA STAKE
description: Anthem Inc., an Indianapolis insurance brokerage company, said yesterday that it would pay $40 a share, or about $170 million, to acquire the shares of Acordia Inc. it did not already own, adding to its health insurance business. Shares of Acordia surged $4, or 11 percent, to $39.50, after a delayed New York Stock Exchange opening. Anthem, a closely held health care manager based in Indianapolis, already owned 66.8 percent of Acordia. Anthem said it would buy the Acordia shares in a tender offer expected to begin by June 6.

title: G & K TO ADD NATIONAL SERVICE PROCESSING PLANTS
description: G & K Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy uniform and linen rental assets from National Service Industries for $287 million. National Service, based in Atlanta, is a distributor of textiles and lighting equipment, with annual revenue of $2 billion. G & K Services, based in Minneapolis, is an industrial launderer and supplier of work uniforms, with annual sales of $305 million. Under the agreement, G & K will acquire 29 uniform and linen processing sites, with total annual revenue of $205 million. Shares of G & K Services fell $2, to $30.75, on the Nasdaq stock market. Shares of National Services Industries fell 62.5 cents, to $43.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: With a Summery, Delicate Air
description: Dressing up on a summer evening may mean nothing more than a wisp of a slip dress or a bare top over a skirt covered with delicate embroidery. If that sounds too feminine, how about a silk bag with a whimsical embroidered design?

title: Anatomy of a Tickle Is Serious Business at the Research Lab
description: IT is an enduring mystery pondered over the ages by such luminaries as Socrates, Galileo and Darwin, as well as by many a preschooler: why do people laugh when they are tickled? Yet tickling has remained little more than a cackle-filled curiosity far from the purview of modern science.

title: Six Weeks, One Theory
description: When everything was said and done, Timothy J. McVeigh, the loner who liked to travel fast and light, was still alone. No friend, no family member, no stranger came forward to give him an alibi for the Oklahoma City bombing, and he did not take the stand in his own defense.

title: 2 Building Companies In Spain Consider Merger
description: Securities regulators in Spain suspended trading yesterday in the shares of the builders OCP Construcciones S.A. and Gines Navarro S.A., because of the possibility the companies will merge. A spokesman for Corporacion Financiera Alba S.A., which controls a 52.5 percent stake in Gines Navarro, said the two companies ''had reached agreement to study their possible merger.

title: No Headline
description: ''I cried, and I cheered.''

title: Storm Warning: Bigger Hurricanes and More of Them
description: THE East and Gulf Coasts of the United States may be entering a long-anticipated, prolonged siege of more frequent and more destructive hurricanes, forecasters say.

title: Slip of the Tape Leaves Torre and Fox Red-Faced
description: Funny how a single cuss word on Fox Sports -- one of the nasty seven that George Carlin said can't be uttered on television -- can cause such a big hullabaloo.

title: Lilco Plan Is Favored in a Poll
description: Supporters of Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to cut electric rates through a partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company who sponsored a poll of Long Island voters said today that the poll had found a majority favoring the plan.

title: Houston Undergoes Surgery For a Nagging Wrist Injury
description: Allan Houston, the shooting guard whom the Knicks signed to a $56 million contract last season to become one of their primary offensive options, underwent successful surgery today to repair partly torn ligaments in his right wrist.

title: Horseshoe-Crab Ban Holds
description: The state's recent ban on horseshoe crabbing is apparently being respected, environmental officials said yesterday. In five days of exhaustive patrols along the mucky shores of the Delaware Bay, enforcement agents from the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife have not found any violators, said Steve Herb, the division's assistant director for operations.

title: Wal-Mart Investing in Mexican Partner
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said today that it planned to buy a controlling stake in Cifra S.A., Mexico's largest retailer, for $1.2 billion.

title: At the Nation's Table: Longboat Key, Fla.; The Stuff Dreams Are Made On
description: In its previous life, the Haye Loft, a flight above the Euphemia Haye restaurant in Longboat Key, Fla., was a bedroom. This is entirely fitting, because the pies here are the essence of sweet dreams: the pillowy lemon meringue, the dense-as-night black walnut, the smooth-as-satin-sheets banana cream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWNE, ROBERT P.
description: BROWNE-Robert P., of Atlanta died June 2,1997. Mr. Browne retired as President of Stewart R. Browne Manufacturing Company. He was also a member of the Atlanta Country Club. Survivors include his wife Jean M. Browne, Langhorne, PA., daughter, Carolyn M. Browne, Langhorne, PA., sons, James S. Browne, Atlanta, Alan R. Browne and Christopher P. Browne both of Marietta, sisters, Phyllis Anderson, Millbrook, NY., Helen Peters, Seattle, WA., Judy Haydon, Florence, OR, and seven grandchildren. Memorial services will be held Wednesday June 4 at 2:30PM in the Arlington Chapel. In lieu of flowers make contributions to the American Heart Association. The family will receive friends one hour prior to the service. For information call H.M. Patterson & Son Arlington Chapel 404-851-9900.

title: Corrections
description: The credits with a television review yesterday about ''Bill Clinton: Rock 'n' Roll President'' on VH1 misstated the given name of the program's Washington producer. She is Joy Roller, not Jay.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the re-enactment of a Viking voyage referred incorrectly in some editions to the publisher that plans a book by the project's organizer. The company is Ballantine, not Simon & Schuster.

title: GAYLORD ENTERTAINMENT SELLS SEATTLE TV STATION
description: The Gaylord Entertainment Company said yesterday that it had sold its Seattle television station, KSTW-TV, to Cox Broadcasting Inc. for $160 million. Cox, a unit of Cox Enterprises of Atlanta, swapped the station with Paramount Stations Group Inc. for KIRO-TV in Seattle. Paramount, a unit of Viacom Inc., acquired KIRO-TV from the A. H. Belo Corporation in exchange for KMOV-TV in St. Louis. Belo was required by Federal regulations to sell KIRO-TV after it acquired Seattle's KING-TV as part the company's recent acquisition of the Providence Journal Company. Gaylord, based in Nashville, owns the Grand Ole Opry, Opryland and television and radio stations.

title: More Good News for Tonys
description: The good news for the Tony Awards exceeded all expectations as the national rating for Sunday's telecast arrived yesterday and gave the show its biggest audience in a decade.

title: Amstrad to Become Part of Viglen Unit
description: Amstrad P.L.C., a British maker of consumer electronics and computers, said yesterday that it would fold itself into Viglen, its personal computer unit, and return at least $:200 million ($327 million) to shareholders.

title: Team Begins Investigating Park Accident
description: While the stunned survivors of an ill-fated senior trip struggled to make sense of their loss, investigators here began studying events that led to the collapse of a water slide at a local amusement park on Monday.

title: Mexico Accused of Diverting U.S. Anti-Drug Aid to Fight Rebels
description: A sharp dispute erupted here today over charges by a leftist senator that Mexico's military had misused helicopters supplied by the United States for anti-drug missions.

title: Chicago Exchanges Seek to Loosen Yoke of Regulation
description: It takes sharp elbows and a strong constitution to survive a day in the Eurodollar pit at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Contracts representing millions of dollars in short-term interest rate futures turn over every second in a cacophonous blur of hand signals and shouted orders. Moments of relative quiet are punctuated by frenzy as the electronic boards ringing the pit record tiny movements in the Eurodollar's value.

title: Yankees Foiled By Palmeiro's Homer in 10th
description: This pulsating night was supposed to about David Cone versus Jimmy Key, about two former teammates who are among the elite pitchers in the American League and about both trying to keep the scoreboard barren. It did not turn out that way.

title: Kafelnikov And Graf Lose Their Titles
description: There was a double dethroning this drizzly afternoon at the French Open, the Grand Slam where it's not only lonely at the top, it's empty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, JONATHAN
description: LEVIN-Jonathan. The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York, Inc. deeply mourns the death of Jonathan Levin, the son of Gerald M. Levin, Chairman and CEO of Time Warner, Board Treasurer of the Philharmonic, and a long-time friend and loyal supporter of the Orchestra. A popular faculty member at Taft High School in The Bronx, Jonathan was admired by his students, colleagues and neighbors. He was a devoted teacher, ever willing to assume new responsibilities for the welfare of his students. His untimely death at age thirty-one is a shock to us. We feel that the Philharmonic family has lost a beloved member. We extend our sincere condolences to Jerry and Barbara Levin, Carol Levin, and the children, Laura, Lee, Michael and Anna. Kurt Masur, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Deborah Borda, Exec Director Directors of the Society

title: People
description: * Martin F. Reidy, chief operating officer at R/GA Digital Studios, New York, part of True North Communications, was named to the additional new position of president.

title: Clinton Tactic In Jones Case Worries NOW
description: The National Organization for Women today criticized President Clinton and his lawyers for threatening to make an issue of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual history if she proceeds with her lawsuit against him for sexual harassment.

description: LURAY-Marty. 5/5/29-6/4/93. Thinking of you with love always -in our hearts and minds forever. Edith, Jennifer and John

title: ENRON FORMING VENTURE WITH ENEL OF ITALY
description: The Enron Corporation and Enel S.p.A., Italy's state electricity utility, said yesterday that they would form a 5 trillion lire ($2.9 billion) power-generating venture to take advantage of opportunities in Europe's electricity market. As part of the agreement, Enel would contribute about 10 power plants and Enron, the Houston-based energy company, would pay to upgrade and expand them. The new company would be able to generate as much as 5,000 megawatts of power. Shares of Enron rose 50 cents yesterday, to $40.50.

title: TITAN HOLDINGS HIRES ADVISER TO EVALUATE OFFERS
description: Titan Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had retained Furman Selz Inc., the New York investment firm, to help evaluate ''expressions of interest'' it had received about the potential sale of some or all of its business. Titan, an insurance company based in San Antonio, said there was no assurance that any sale would be agreed on. The company, which has divisions for auto insurance, public entity insurance and commercial properties, did not say who had expressed interest or which divisions might be acquired. Its shares rose $1.75 yesterday, to $21.125, giving the company a market value of more than $200 million.

title: Digital Hearing Aids Hold New Promise
description: DURING the last 20 years, Russell Frahm, a 79-year-old retired businessman in Tucson, Ariz., has gone through at least six pairs of hearing aids. The electronic components have varied, and so have the styles, from behind the ear to in the ear to the tiniest versions, hidden inside the ear canal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTER, WALLY
description: SCHUSTER-Wally. Of New York and Las Vegas. Retired music publisher. Dearest son of the late songwriter Ira Schuster and Minnie Schuster. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Peter, Jason and Michael. Loving grandfather of Maisie. Adored brother of Phoebe & Leonard Lewin. Cherished uncle of John & Lynn and Jamie and Lee Lewin. Dear brother-in-law of Jackie & Gary Barnett. Fond cousin and friend of many. At the time of his death, he was a member of ASCAP Songwriters Guild of America and the Academy of Popular Music. Services were held in California on June 3,1997. You will never be forgotten.

description: REITELMAN-Paula (nee Frankenstein) on June 3, 1997. Devoted mother of Jason, Sarah and RuthAnne. Dear daughter of Rebecca Betty (nee Erman) and the late Boris Frankenstein. Beloved sister of Marsha and Sherman. Cherished niece of Regina Landesman, Eli Frankenstein and Ben Frankston. After a valiant battle with cancer. Graveside services Beth David Memorial Park, Kennilworth, NJ, June 4 at 11:00 A.M.

title: Chefs Are Finding That the Pen Is as Mighty as the Ladle
description: CHEFS these days all want to write cookbooks, said Alfred Portale, whose own ''Alfred Portale's Gotham Bar and Grill Cookbook'' is scheduled for fall publication by Doubleday.

title: Executive Changes
description: B. F. GOODRICH CO., Akron, Ohio, named David Burner, president and chief executive, to the additional position of chairman, succeeding John Ong, who will retire on July 1.

title: 2 Killed in Collision With Newspaper Truck
description: A father and his 6-year-old daughter died early yesterday in Newark when their car collided with a New York Times delivery truck, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWER, CLAUDIA
description: BREWER-Claudia. On June 3, 1997, of Pelham Manor, NY. Beloved wife of William Brewer, devoted mother of Samantha and Christopher Brewer, daughter of Patricia and the late Francis Welsh, sister of Greg, Paul, Jim, Tim and Mary Beth Welsh. Reposing Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Ave, Pelham, NY. Mass Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church on Friday, 10 am. Visiting hours on Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm.

title: With Debuts, Classic Becomes Fresh
description: Martha Butler and Ethan Stiefel made their debuts as Swanilda and Franz in American Ballet Theater's new production of ''Coppelia'' on Monday night and sparkled with downright conviction, making an old ballet seem young.

title: At Last
description: Suddenly the field grasses are knee-high, and in the woods of western Massachusetts the ferns have completely uncoiled. On some small farms in Rensselaer County, New York, the first hay has already been cut. A light afternoon breeze now carries the tentative bleating of crickets and the hush of leaves in the trees, sounds that seem to advance the season a month or two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHBERG, MURIEL
description: HIRSHBERG - Muriel. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Students Show Off Designs In Motion
description: This year's annual Graduation Dance Concert of the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts became a display of choreographic traffic patterns. Every work on Sunday night at the school's La Guardia Concert Hall featured intricate designs in space for groups of dancers.

title: She Puts One Of the Great Vineyards On Parade
description: MAY-ELIANE DE LENCQUESAING was striding through her new barrel cellar and found the lights weren't working. ''They said they'd be here tomorrow,'' an assistant said.

title: Smoked Out
description: The problem with the settlement talks between the tobacco industry and the states which are suing it is that the focus is on the wrong subjects: money and immunity. The money is for victims, lawyers and the states; immunity from lawsuits is for the tobacco industry, which is seeking long-term financial security. That's not what should be driving our national policy.

title: Whitewater Counsel Is Accused of 'Leaks'
description: President Clinton's personal lawyer today accused the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, and his office of violating federal rules that bar prosecutors from disclosing confidential grand jury matters.

title: In a First-Round First, Brothers Are Drafted
description: The town of Hahira, Ga., population 367, has one traffic light, one gas station and two first-round picks in baseball's annual draft of amateur players. The Philadelphia Phillies and the Cleveland Indians made draft history yesterday by selecting brothers in the first round. The Phillies chose J. D. Drew, an outfielder and junior at Florida State University, as the second player drafted, and the Indians made Tim, a pitcher and high school senior, the 28th player taken.

title: Vietnamese Men Lead in Smoking
description: Nearly 73 percent of Vietnamese men smoke, the highest rate in the world, according to research to be published on Wednesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: As Fear Spreads, Palestinian Land Broker Tells of Abduction
description: At 1 A.M. last Sunday, Asad al-Rajabi and his family were awakened by a knock on the door of their stone house in a dusty hillside neighborhood in East Jerusalem.

title: FAULDING GETS MERGER PROPOSAL FROM MAJORITY OWNER
description: Faulding Inc. said yesterday that it had received a proposal from its majority owner, F. H. Faulding & Company, to acquire the 38 percent of Faulding common shares it does not already own for $12 a share in cash, or about $68.4 million. Faulding, an Elizabeth, N.J., maker of injectable drugs and dispensing devices, said its board would discuss forming a special panel of outside directors to review the proposal. title: Canada's Restive West

As before, Mr. Chretien has to cope with a still formidable separatist party in French-speaking Quebec, where the Prime Minister almost lost his own constituency. Yet the most interesting result was the revolt that swept the Western provinces, giving the right-wing Reform Party 60 seats, thus making Preston Manning the official opposition leader in Parliament.

title: CABLETRON SHARES PLUMMET ON WARNING OF WEAK PROFIT
description: The stock of Cabletron Systems Inc. fell by a third yesterday after the company, a network equipment maker in Rochester, N.H., said slowing sales of older products and the company's failure to make enough new ones to fill orders would hurt profit for at least two quarters. Cabletron shares plunged $15.50, to $30.25, as 25.8 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange. The company said late on Monday that it expected its revenue for the three months ended May 30 to be $360 million to $370 million, down from the fourth quarter's $380.6 million. At best, earnings will be slightly higher than the $57.1 million in the first quarter a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REMY, JEAN, CLAUDE, M.D.
description: REMY-Jean-Claude, M.D. The Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at State University of New York-Health Science Center at Brooklyn and Kings County Hospital Center wishes to express its deepest sympathy of the death of its faculty member, Dr. JeanClaude Remy. Dr. Remy expired on May 29, 1997. Dr. Remy completed his residency in OBS/GYN at Long Island College Hospital in 1976. Dr. Remy completed a Fellowship in Gynecologic Oncology at this institution in 1978. Dr. Remy was a Clinical Associate Professor in the Dept. of OBS/GYN at State Univ. of N.Y.-Health Science Center at Brooklyn. He was the Director of the Gynecology Ambulatory Care Service at State Univ. of N.Y. - Health Science Center at Brooklyn, an Attending Physician at Kings County Hospital Center and at Lutheran Medical Center. He was appointed President of the Brooklyn Gynecological Society in 1996. He was a Board Certified Obstetrician and Gynecologist and a Board Certified Gynecologic Oncologist who was dedicated to patient care. Dr. Remy was a Fellow of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, a member of the Society of Gynecologic Oncologists, the American Medical Association, Kings County Medical Society, Brooklyn Gynecological Society, New York Obstetrical Society and the Association Des Medecins Haitiens a L'etranger. Dr. Remy was an exceptional gynecologic oncologist, teacher and lecturer. His superior clinical and surgical skills were acknowledged by the faculty, medical students and residents. He was the recipient of many teaching and service awards at State Univ. of N.Y.-Health Science Center at Brooklyn. Dr. Remy will be missed by the Department and the faculty at this institution.

description: ROSSMAN-Isadore, M.D. Montefiore Medical Center notes with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. Isadore Rossman, a respected member of the medical center for half a century. An internationally and nationally recognized clinician and scholar, Dr. Rossman played an instrumental role in developing innovative programs in the fields of social and geriatric medicine. He participated in the establishment, in 1947, of Montefiore's Home Health Agency, the country's first hospitalbased home care agency and, since 1955, served as its medical director. He was president of the American Geriatrics Association, and was author and editor of numerous professional papers, chapters and books. A compassionate and devoted physician and gentleman, he will be missed by his patients, colleagues and all who knew him. Our condolences are extended to his wife, Sylvia; son, Dr. Paul Rossman; grandson, Jonathan, and entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., President Jay B. title: To the Good Times, With a Twang

His guitar twang and his unmistakable voice -- part back-country wail, part alley-cat yowl -- carry rock's heritage of juke joints and honky-tonks, of illicit good times and joyful miscegenation, of electricity coursing through the rural Southland and changing some things forever.

title: ECHLIN TO BUY AUTO PARTS DIVISION FROM ITT INDUSTRIES

The division, part of the ITT Automotive unit of Auburn Hills, Mich., has annual sales of about $140 million, a fraction of ITT Industries' total sales of $8.72 billion. Echlin, an auto parts maker based in Branford, Conn., has annual sales of $3.13 billion. The sale includes manufacturing and distribution centers in the United States and Canada that provide brake drums, shoes and rotors. Echlin said the division would be renamed Aimco Products Inc. ITT Industries, based in White Plains and spun off by the ITT Corporation in 1995, said the sale would allow it to focus on providing products for car makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOY, JOHN C.W.
description: FOY-John C.W., British World War II veteran and retired Head of English Proofreading in the United Nations Publishing Division, died last Saturday (May 31, 1997) at the age of 78 after a long struggle with lung cancer. He lived in Englewood, New Jersey. Mr Foy served in World War II with the Royal Expeditionary Forces-First Division (Territorial Army). A member of the 53rd Medium Regiment, Royal Artillery, he landed in France in October 1939 and was wounded in 1940 during a German air attack near Lille. He was captured by German forces and held as a POW in Bleicherode, a salt-mining town near Nordhausen in the central region of Thuringen. He was liberated in 1945 by General Patton's Third Army. After the war he returned to his native London, where he worked for the London Times and Odhams Press Ltd. He came to the United States in 1953 to join the United Nations, from which he retired in 1979. A longtime resident of Englewood, Mr. Foy was an avid gardener, a military-history enthusiast, and a soccer aficionado. He is survived by his wife of 40 years, Geraldine F. Foy; his son, John F. Foy of Manhattan; his two daughters, Penelope B. Foy of Merrick, NY, and Jennifer F. Schalhoub of Little Ferry, NJ; a brother, Ronald Foy of London; two sisters, Gladys Jackson and Florence Cook, also of London, and his grandchild, Catherine F. Foy. Mr. Foy often stated that without aid from the British Red Cross Society he would not have survived the long years as a POW. For that reason, and in lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to: National Headquarters of the Red Cross, 17th & E. Street, NW, Washington, D.C. 20006. Goodbye, mate. We'll miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTULLI, THOMAS V.
description: SANTULLI-Thomas V., MD, renowned pediatric surgeon died on June 2, 1997, from cancer of the lung, at the age of 82. He was a pioneer in the development of the speciality of Pediatric Surgery, initiating one of the first seven training programs in the U.S. Dr. Santulli received a B.S. degree from Columbia University in 1935 and his M.D. degree from Georgetown University in 1939. He taught at Columbia University for over 40 years where, as Director of Pediatric Surgery at Babies & Children's Hospital for 25 years, he trained many future leaders in the field. Nine of his former trainees became directors of Pediatric Surgery at major academic medical centers. At his retirement in 1983 as Professor of Surgery Emeritus in Columbia University, the pediatric Surgery Library and Conference Room at Babies & Children's Hospital were named in his honor. Dr. Santulli was president of the American Pediatric Surgical Association, the first president of the New York Pediatric Surgical Society, and a member of numerous other medical organizations, including the American Surgical Association, the New York Surgical Society, the British Association of Pediatric Surgeons, and the American College of Surgeons. He was an honorary member of many foreign surgical societies. He was recipient of the Babies & Children's Hospital Centennial Medal as the ''Father of Pediatric Surgery'' at Columbia University in New York City. The Santulli Society, which convenes at national meetings, was formed by his former trainees, and the Santulli lectureship in Pediatric Surgery was established in Columbia University. Dr. Santulli was the author of over 130 scientific publications and book chapters and was integral to the creation of many media publications and national exhibits. He is survived by his beloved wife, Patricia Anne (nee Rita); two sons, Dr. Thomas V. Santulli, Jr. and Dr. Robert B. Santulli; a brother, Vincent Santulli; and five grandchildren. He was predeceased by his first wife Dorothy (nee Beverly). William T. Speck, MD President and Chief Exec. Officer The Presbyterian Hospital Herbert Pardes, MD V.P. for Health Sciences and Dean Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University

title: A Singer Who Does Horn
description: The singer Kurt Elling didn't have a drummer when he played on Tuesday night at the small Dark Star Lounge on the Upper West Side, but it didn't matter. Starting up ''My Foolish Heart,'' his pianist, Laurence Hobgood, reached inside the piano to dampen the string of the tonic chord's root note, and started clicking the key, then fashioned shifting chords around it. The bassist Ugonna Okegwo redoubled some of those clicking patterns in his bass lines. And Mr. Elling himself applied rhythm to everything he did. Most of his singing is an imitation of a horn, and in some instances memorizations of specific solos by very rhythmic horn players like Dexter Gordon and Wayne Shorter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLESINGER, EDWARD B.
description: SCHLESINGER-Edward B., MD. Died on June 1, 1997 at 83. Dr. Schlesinger was the first Byron Stookey Professor of Neurological Surgery, Chairman of the Department of Neurological Surgery, and Director of Neurological Surgery Service of Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in NYC. Dr. Schlesinger received his BA from the University of Pennsylvania and his MD from the University's Medical School. His research experience began in his college years when he became a voluntary assistant in neurophysiology at the Johnson Foundation of the University of Pennsylvania. He began his internship at Hartford Hospital after which he was an Assistant Resident, then Resident, in Neurosurgery at the Neurological Institute of Columbia-Presbyterian. Dr. Schlesinger's hard work earned him a fellowship to the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota in 1941. He joined the military where he served until 1945. Dr. Schlesinger's appointments at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons began in 1946 when he became Research Assistant in the Department of Neurology. He also served as Research Associate of the Department of Neurological Surgery, and as Assistant and Associate Professor of Clinical Neurological Surgery. During the years 1949-1963, Dr. Schlesinger was in charge of cancer research projects at the College of Physicians and Surgeons. During his tenure, he established the Isotope Laboratory with support from the John A. Hartford Foundation. This period brought the development of the multi-collimated scanning device for extra-cranial localization of brain tumors using gamma emitting radioisotopes. Dr. Schlesinger published over 70 articles on the topics of neurological surgery, neuropharmacology, and nuclear medicine. Many will remember Dr. Schlesinger as a person who brought to Columbia-Presbyterian a wealth of experience in terms of teaching, practice, professional writings, organizational participation, and research. Dr. Schlesinger is survived by his wife, Mary (formerly Mary Eddy), four children, Jane, Mary, Ralph and Prudence, and seven grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Scoville Memorial Library, Salisbury, CT or Augustus C. Long Medical Library, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. A funeral service will be held on Sat., June 7th, 1:30 at the Mt. Riga Cemetery, Salisbury, CT. William T. Speck, MD, President and Chief Executive Officer The Presbyterian Hospital Herbert Pardes, MD V.P. for Health and Sciences and Dean, Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University
