title: A Grateful Trainer Puts His Faith in Free House
description: After Free House's victory in the Santa Anita Derby on April 5, his trainer, Paco Gonzalez, could barely speak because he was so overcome with the emotion of winning the biggest race of his career. A similar torrent of feelings could be unleashed Saturday if Free House can capture the Belmont Stakes and stop Silver Charm from sweeping the Triple Crown.

title: Investigators Are Exploring Basic Questions of Motive in Levin Slaying
description: As the search for the killer of Jonathan M. Levin completed its second day yesterday, detectives were still exploring the most fundamental questions of any homicide investigation: Did the victim know his attacker? Was there a possible motive in Mr. Levin's personal life -- a romance gone bad, a love triangle? Or was his shooting perhaps the violent end to a robbery attempt?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, DENNIS
description: JAMES-Dennis. United Cerebral Palsy sadly acknowledges the sudden, untimely passing of Dennis James-friend and benefactor of and spokesman for the thousands of Americans with cerebral palsy. A pioneer in television in his own professional right, Dennis articulated the aspirations of people with cerebral palsy by hosting the UCP telethon since the inception of this television event in 1950. He traveled the country, establishing the telethon as an effective vehicle for the telling of the cerebral palsy story. His warm sense of commitment encouraged hundreds of American communities to organize and support the necessary program services vital to those with cerebral palsy. We extend to Micki, Dennis' three sons: Dennis Jr., Bradley and Randy our deepest loving condolences. Dennis distributed his caring heart abundantly and selflessly and will be forever missed. Jack Hausman, Founder Leo Hausman, President UCP/NYC

title: CHRONICLE
description: Hollywood may have its Academy Awards in March, but New York City has its Crystal Apple Awards in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, LEONARD E.
description: LEVY-Leonard E. Beloved husband of Roslyn; devoted father of Judy Benkov (Keith) and Joan Danzig (Jeffrey); cherished grandfather of Carly, Jordan, Lloyd and Blake. Services Thursday, 1:30pm, Riverside Memorial Chapels, 21 West Broad St, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Senator Regrets Role in Book on Aliens
description: A new book contending that the nation's military and industrial power largely derive from a crashed alien spaceship is being disparaged by Senator Strom Thurmond, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, who wrote the book's foreword.

title: Not Enough Is Done to Ease End of Life, Panel Says
description: Too many Americans are denied a chance to die well because of inadequate care and lack of understanding of their needs, an expert panel from the Institute of Medicine said today.

title: White House Stands By Weld Despite Opposition of Helms
description: The White House insisted today that President Clinton would not back down from his choice of Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts to be ambassador to Mexico, despite the objections of Senator Jesse Helms.

title: Investors Get a G.M. Windfall, And G.M. Does All Right, Too
description: The General Motors Corporation has a deal for investors who own the more than $363 million in two issues of its preferred stock. It wants to pay them a higher rate of interest.

title: Boardwalk Repairs Approved
description: Community groups have successfully defeated a plan to tear down a crumbling portion of the Atlantic City Boardwalk that city officials consider unsafe. Yesterday, the City Council voted to repair the Boardwalk in its present location, directly over the ocean and its sometimes damaging waves.

title: Harper Hobbling Jazz With Steady Defense
description: If the Chicago Bulls had an Achilles' heel, it was supposed to be the starting guard with the wobbly knees.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Ford Motor Company's plans to build cars, mini-vans and pickup trucks that can burn ethanol, gasoline or a combination of the fuels misstated the scale of production. Ford plans to build 250,000 of the vehicles by 2001, not 250,000 in 2001.

title: Fabege Shares Soar On Takeover Offer
description: Fabege A.B.'s shares soared yesterday after it received a cash takeover offer of 2.2 billion kronor ($286 million) from Naeckebro A.B., another Swedish real estate company. Naeckebro's bid topped a stock-swap offer from Hufvudstaden A.B. Fabege's shares jumped 10 kronor each, to 84 kronor.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The marriages of their children Prince Charles and Prince Andrew may have been relatively short lived, but QUEEN ELIZABETH II and PRINCE PHILIP are coming up on their 50th wedding anniversary.

title: Wait a Minute: Duncan Isn't Going So Quickly
description: There was bitterness and sadness in Mariano Duncan's voice today as he told reporters that he wanted to be traded from the Yankees. As soon as possible, he wants to leave the team on which he has been considered a leader, the team he helped to win a pennant and a World Series last year.

title: Bruguera Saves Face For Seeded Field in Paris
description: He's not exactly a household name, but he's the only card-carrying clay-court magician among the men's semifinalists who will fight on Friday for the right to become a French Open champion on Sunday. The final four that was completed today includes an ecstatic Brazilian surf bum, the well-read son of a Belgian pharmacist, an Australian serve-and-volleyer who practiced his clay-court moves on crushed ant beds, and the genuine article, the two-time French Open champion Sergi Bruguera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREFETZ, JACQUELINE. (NEE FISCHER)
description: KREFETZ-Jacqueline. (nee Fischer) Died on June 3, 1997, in New York. Born on October 7, 1928 in Antwerp, Belgium. Beloved wife of the late Burton Krefetz. Loving mother of Claudia and Scott and grandmother of Ariel. Also survived by her sister Renee Holden and nephews Stuart and Paul. Funeral service today, Riverside, 76 St. & Amsterdam 1:15 P.M.

title: France's New Jacket
description: There was a delightful photo the other day showing President Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain laughing together in London. Here's a secret: I know what they were laughing about. They were laughing about France.

title: Rush to Closure
description: Closure, the national buzzword of the week, is the panacea for all our ills. No sooner was Timothy McVeigh found guilty than it was universally declared that closure would arrive soon for the loved ones of his 168 victims. The verdict brings instant closure to some troubled American institutions, too: The F.B.I. proved that it could still get its man (even if it did bungle evidence), and the legal system proved that it could still work (R.I.P., Judge Ito). There's even closure for the press, which is already racing on to Paula Jones.

title: Mini-Planet at Solar System's Edge Might Be Part of Rubble Belt
description: An icy, 300-mile-wide mini-planet has been found beyond Neptune on the dark fringes of the solar system, and scientists believe it may be part of a hidden belt of millions of bits of speeding rubble left over from the creation of the solar system, pieces of which occasionally crash into Jupiter.

title: 'Barrymore' didn't win a Tony, though its leading man did. Can the box office still cash in?
description: THE theory in theater advertising is that Tony Awards sell seats. Inevitably, then, the winners in the musical, play and revival categories at the 1997 Antoinette Perry Awards -- ''Titanic,'' ''The Last Night of Ballyhoo,'' ''Chicago'' and ''A Doll's House'' -- are all trumpeting their victories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOS, JULIE ANN
description: ROOS-Julie Ann. We mourn the passing of Julie Ann Roos. We extend our sincerest sympathy to her beloved father, Edwin G. Roos, and her cherished brothers, Andrew H. Roos and Peter Roos. She will be dearly missed, but will live forever in our hearts. Memorial services will be held Thursday, June 5, Central Synagogue, 1:30pm Williams Real Estate Co. Inc.

title: Displacing Ignorance
description: To the Editor:

title: As Queens Changes, The Gardens Remain
description: DANIEL KARATZAS does not sound like your usual tour guide. ''Just tell me when to shut up, if I'm telling you too much,'' he said, leading the way down shady streets in Jackson Heights, Queens, where griffins guard the entryways to apartment house courtyards full of old elms and dogwoods and soft green grass.

title: Hextall's Return Could Be a Big Lift for Flyers
description: Everyone, including Bob Clarke, knew the Philadelphia Flyers had a goalie problem at the beginning of the season. But only Clarke, general manager of the Flyers, had the power to do something about it.

title: Jordan Shows Jazz Exactly Who Owns the Finals
description: He started by dribbling past Shandon Anderson on the right wing and beating Adam Keefe along the baseline. By the time Michael Jordan took flight in the third quarter of tonight's game against Utah, he had only two obstacles left: Karl Malone and gravity.

title: Decision Time on Clean Air
description: The most contentious and complex environmental issue to face the Clinton Administration this year is coming to a head. Carol Browner, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, will shortly propose to the White House tough and costly new limits on two kinds of air pollution -- ground-level ozone, or smog, and dust-like particles known as particulates. She says the new standards will improve the lives of millions who suffer respiratory diseases and prevent 15,000 premature deaths every year. The White House, beset by heavy lobbying from industry, must decide whether to accept her argument that the new standards are vital to public health or ask for weaker rules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARLAND, ROSE
description: GARLAND-Rose. The Board of Directors, Trustees and staff of Beth Abraham Health Services join in extending our deepest sympathy to Thomas J. Hayes, our good friend and colleague at Beth Israel Medical Center, upon the loss of his beloved mother, Rose Garland. To the entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Michael R. Potack, Chairman Beth Abraham Health Services William H. Frohlich, President Beth Abraham Health Services

title: Biker Club House Blasted in Norway
description: A meeting house for the Norwegian Bandidos motorcycle club was obliterated here late Wednesday night by an explosion that the police said could signal an intensification of the Scandinavian biker war. At least one person, probably a passing motorist, was killed in the blast and several others were injured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMANN, DR. MANFRED R.
description: LEHMANN-Dr. Manfred R. The concert you worked so hard on and looked forward to with such excitement was every bit the success you so desired. You were the rarest of human beings. Not a day in your life went by without your working on behalf of Klal Yisroel. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Joseph Frager, President Jerusalem Reclamation Project

title: Computer Stocks Extend Slump; Dow Falls by 42.49
description: Stocks fell yesterday, as computer issues extended a weeklong slump and financial stocks dropped on concern over higher interest rates.

title: Hand in Small Hand Around the Internet
description: WITH all the reports lately about trouble on the World Wide Web -- not the technical kind, but the kind that involves pornographers, pedophiles and lewd material -- it is all too easy for parents to believe that cyberspace has become a hazardous playground for youngsters.

title: Algeria Vote Nears, With Democracy in Ruins
description: The first multi-party elections in Algeria since 1992 are to be held on Thursday, but the Islamic party whose surge led the military to annul that vote has been banished and the extent of real parliamentary democracy appears strictly circumscribed.

title: Church Garage Is Set on Fire
description: Less than a week after arson destroyed the First Baptist Church, which has a predominantly black congregation, a garage owned by another nearby black church was set on fire yesterday. The garage, which was destroyed, was situated next to the Church of God's Deliverance and was ''a long country block'' from the First Baptist Church, said Andrew N. Yurick, the Gloucester County Prosecutor.

title: The Shipwreck Story No One Survived to Tell
description: THE PERFECT STORM

title: Whitman Bus Rolls Into South Jersey
description: On the morning after Democrats chose State Senator James E. McGreevey as their party's nominee, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman wasted no time today taking her case for a second term directly to the voters.

title: Asian Sculptures
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.S. Criticized Harshly in Judge's Ruling
description: A Federal judge in Denver has awarded $250,000 in punitive damages to a woman whose family business was raided by armed Internal Revenue Service agents four weeks after the woman insulted an I.R.S. agent.

title: Bruno Unveils New Rent-Law Compromise
description: In a show of Republican unity intended to pressure Democrats to compromise on a rent agreement, the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, unveiled his plan today to end state rent regulations within two generations by eliminating protections for apartments that become vacant and for tenants who earn more than $125,000 a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIELE, NORMA
description: MIELE-Norma. Dearest friend, you will be greatly missed. Norma & Murray

title: Vietnamese Who Fought for C.I.A. Are Still Awaiting Back Pay
description: Nearly one year after Congress promised them $20 million in back pay, the ''lost commandos'' of the Vietnam War -- Vietnamese soldiers dropped behind enemy lines and then abandoned by the United States -- have not received a penny.

title: McGreevey Assails Pension Bond Plan
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey said today that his first priority as the Democratic challenger to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman would be fighting Mrs. Whitman's $2.75 billion pension bond borrowing plan, which is scheduled for a vote in the State Senate on Thursday.

title: A Father With Power in the Media World and Pride in His Son
description: Few of Jonathan M. Levin's students may have known who his father was.

title: Bridge
description: Before reaching for an indignant pen, the reader is urged to read on. All is not quite what it seems.

title: An Apology to Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Shade of Indigo
description: In the past, part of the beauty of a concert by the folk-rock duo the Indigo Girls was the synchronicity between its members, Amy Ray and Emily Saliers, who could delve into winning harmonies and energetically pick their guitars in counterpoint as if connected by an invisible bond. But on their current tour, which came to Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, what distinguished the concert was the growing differences between the pair.

title: Yankees Now Facing A Test of Character
description: When the primary topics of conversation in a post-game clubhouse of a defending champion are character and wild-card berths, there can be little doubt that the title defense is in deep trouble.

title: Before Considering Her Rival, Voters Will Assess Her
description: If State Senator James E. McGreevey is going to unseat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman this fall, he first needs voters to answer yes to this question: Are they so unhappy with Mrs. Whitman that they want to toss her from office?

title: Budget Deal Allows Rowland To Eliminate Up to 5,000 Jobs
description: Ending a bitter standoff over the state budget, Gov. John G. Rowland and Democratic legislative leaders reached a compromise tonight that limited Mr. Rowland's power to privatize the state's computer operations while allowing him to eliminate 5,000 positions from the state work force.

title: Mets Haunted By a Ghost From the Past
description: Around these parts, he will always be Bobby Boo.

title: DRAWING 'A LINE,' COHEN TO FORGIVE GENERAL'S AFFAIR
description: After months of upheaval in the military over sexual relationships, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen today drew ''a line'' and decided to forgive a top Air Force general's adulterous affair in the mid-1980's, saying it did not disqualify him as a leading candidate for Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL

title: Guatemalan Isn't Hostile to Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Orders Placed At Factories Gained 1.2% During April
description: Orders placed with factories rose 1.2 percent in April, more than expected, a sign the manufacturing economy remained in high gear after a strong start to the year.

title: Dollar Rises Against Pound And Gains a Bit on the Yen
description: The dollar rose against the British pound yesterday after Britain's top central banker said the pound had risen too quickly against the mark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCVEIGH, WALTER B. (FATHER M. BERNARD)
description: McVEIGH-Walter B. (Father M. Bernard), died Tuesday, June 3 at the age of 78 peacefully in his home, The Trappist Abbey of Our Lady of Guadalupe Lafayette, OR, of which order he was the Abbot for over twenty years. He attended Saint Paul's School, Concord, NH and Harvard University and served in the U.S. Navy for five years. Survived by his brother, Charles S. McVeigh, Jr., a niece Evelyn B. McVeigh, two nephews, Charles S. McVeigh, III and Johnson B. McVeigh, seven grandnieces, one great-nephew. Memorial service to be held on Thursday, June 12 at 12:00 noon at The Church of The Resurrection, 119 E. 74 St., New York City.

title: Lift Education Standards, and Wages Will Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: More Color for The News
description: The Daily News will bring out its first full color front page today, if only on a limited run for delivery outside the city. Other New York City papers are expected to follow. The New York Times expects to begin printing color in its daily sections, starting with the sports section, in the fall, while The Post is still looking for a place to build a color plant.

title: Brazilians Sell $3 Billion Of Unsecured 30-Year Debt
description: Brazil, seeking to reorganize its foreign debt and reduce its future liabilities for interest by at least $160 million, sold $3 billion of unsecured 30-year bonds yesterday, most of which are being exchanged for Brady bonds.

title: Prosecutor Faults Diplomats in Clash With City Police
description: The Manhattan District Attorney provided more ammunition for the United Nations parking ticket wrangle yesterday, saying that were it not for diplomatic immunity, he would prosecute two diplomats for fighting with the police over a ticket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURTZBERG, LAWRENCE
description: KURTZBERG-Lawrence. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Lawrence Kurtzberg. To his family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn his passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: When Money Counts
description: ANYTHING that makes travel lighter, simpler and safer is always welcome. Several new products can help.

title: Calendar: Graphics And Roses
description: Graphic Design, Soviet Style

title: E. B. Schlesinger, 83, Neurosurgeon and Teacher
description: Edward Bruce Schlesinger, a former chief of neurosurgery at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, died on Sunday in Fort Lee, N.J., at his apartment there. He was 83 and also lived in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Few Schools Affected
description: To the Editor:

title: Met Museum Carves New Space From the Air
description: IN two years, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will be 60,000 square feet larger, but much of the new space will be hidden above the grand staircase in what is now air space.

title: Ahmanson Ends Hostile Bid for S.&L.
description: Ending a bitter four-month hostile takeover contest, H. F. Ahmanson & Company yesterday withdrew a $6.7 billion offer to buy its Los Angeles neighbor, the Great Western Financial Corporation. That clears the way for Great Western to proceed with its agreed sale to Washington Mutual Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, WILLIAM EDWIN III
description: STANLEY-William Edwin III, of Red Bank, NJ on June 3,1997. Husband of Betsy Elsas Stanley. Father of Edwin James Cooper Stanley, Lindsay Baird Stanley, Alexander Morse Friedrich, Amanda Claire Friedrich, and Elizabeth Elsas Friedrich. Son of Edith Behr Blackwell. Brother of Peter Stanley, Aileen Blackwell, and Edith Cummings. No visitation. Funeral service Friday 11 AM from St. Georges-by-the-River Episcopalian Church, Lincoln Ave., Rumson, New Jersey. Memorial donations to Family & Childrens Service, 1900 Hwy #

title: Ang Lee Film at Festival
description: Ang Lee's new film, ''The Ice Storm,'' based on Rick Moody's novel about mate swapping and family trauma in suburbia, will open the 35th annual New York Film Festival on Sept. 26 at Lincoln Center. Mr. Lee, the Taiwan-born director of ''Sense and Sensibility,'' ''Eat Drink Man Woman'' and ''The Wedding Banquet,'' will make his New York Film Festival debut.

title: Bernard G. Segal Dies at 89; Lawyer for Rich and Poor
description: Bernard G. Segal, a Philadelphia lawyer who elevated his horizons to help spread the principles of law and justice throughout the segregated South and to every mean street in America, died on Sunday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 89 and had been president of the American Bar Association at the height of the struggle for civil rights in 1969-70.

title: Injecting Aggression Into the Dreamscapes
description: Promises, promises. ''What you see is real,'' the rapper Maxim Reality intoned during the Prodigy's set on Monday night at Irving Plaza. Later he insisted, ''This is dangerous.'' Actually, the only thing endangered by the performance was the Prodigy's reputation.

title: Texas Allowing Suits Against H.M.O.'s
description: In one of the sharpest moves yet in the nationwide backlash against the power of health maintenance organizations, Texas will soon become the first state where consumers will be explicitly allowed to sue their H.M.O.'s for medical malpractice.

title: Diplomas in Doubt at 3 More CUNY Schools
description: The furor over City University standards spread to three more community colleges yesterday, as university trustees threatened to withhold diplomas from hundreds of graduating students who had not passed a newly required English test.

title: Ford Sales Off as Industry Endures a Dismal Spring
description: For the auto industry, the spring selling season was as damp and cold as the weather across most of the country.

title: Plant to Remain in Bronx
description: The Dodgers may never come back to Brooklyn, but at least the Bronx is getting to keep its Melba toast. Two New York investment firms announced yesterday that not only would they buy CPC Specialty Foods, the unit of food giant CPC International that is the nation's leading manufacturer of Melba toast, but that they would leave the plant in the Bronx. When CPC International announced recently that it was seeking a buyer for the unit, there were concerns in the Bronx that the sale would result in the plant, and its approximately 200 jobs, leaving town. But the new owners, Dubilier & Company and Cramer Rosenthal McGlynn Inc., say not to worry.

title: Trainer Says Holyfield Is Ready for Tyson
description: DONALD TURNER, the trainer for EVANDER HOLYFIELD, said the heavyweight champion was much stronger for his June 28 rematch against MIKE TYSON in Las Vegas, Nev., than he was in their first fight. Because of that, Turner believes Holyfield will have a much easier time than he did in knocking Tyson out in the 11th round last Nov. 9.

title: VF PLANS TO ACQUIRE BRITTANIA BRAND FROM LEVI STRAUSS
description: The VF Corporation signed a letter of intent yesterday to buy the trademarks and existing inventory of Brittania Sportswear Ltd. from Levi Strauss & Company. Specific terms were not disclosed. As part of the transaction, VF will offer Brittania's existing licensees agreements similar to those already in place. VF, based in Wyomissing, Pa., owns the Lee, Wrangler, Rustler and Riders brands. Levi Strauss, based in San Francisco, manufactures a broad line of clothing.

title: M.T.A. Turns Deal Maker In Promoting Metrocards
description: When the Mets play the Yankees later this month in New York's first regular-season interleague baseball games, Yankee Stadium will be the scene of another first: advertisements on the back of Metrocards.

title: Wind-Swept Words For a War Memorial
description: MOST war memorials have stirring inscriptions from Presidents or generals. The new Armed Forces Memorial in Norfolk, Va., will have inscriptions from ordinary soldiers, sailors and nurses taken from letters they sent home. The excerpts, which span the two centuries from the Revolutionary War to the Persian Gulf war, have been engraved on thin sheets of bronze and will be scattered across a field as if blown there by the wind. One letter was written by Sarah Rosetta Wakeman, who masqueraded as a Union soldier in the Civil War.

title: A Work of Constant Change, Every Part of It Inevitable
description: The Parsons Dance Company gave itself a glittering 10th-anniversary benefit party on Tuesday night at the opening of its two-week season at the Joyce Theater, establishing a note of playful celebration from the start in the first of three programs. There was live music from the Turtle Island String Quartet, high-energy dancing from David Parsons's handsome, skillful company and, best of all, a premiere that is one of Mr. Parsons's most accomplished dances.

title: Ammirati Puris Gets Global Compaq Account
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it would consolidate its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $200 million, at Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York.

title: New York Bartender to Ireland's Kingmaker
description: The most notable public event on a warm recent afternoon in this hamlet in rural southwest Ireland was the arrival of a huge white bus carrying Dick Spring, the local County Kerry boy who made good in Dublin.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a nominee to run the Internal Revenue Service misidentified the current head of the agency in some editions. Michael P. Dolan is acting commissioner; the previous commissioner, Margaret Milner Richardson, stepped down last month.

title: Retail Grows At the Modern
description: IN choosing a new director for its retail operations, the Museum of Modern Art has gone straight into the heart of the fast-track retail world it hopes to enter: it has hired James D. Gundell, a senior vice president and general merchandising manager at Bloomingdale's.

title: When Time Flies In a Light Show
description: TO look at the Virtual Image Clock -- and at $2,995, looking is all you may be able to do -- is to watch time pass in a dazzling flurry of color and patterns. The hour and minute hands can appear or disappear, widen or narrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITTLEMAN, ARNOLD
description: HITTLEMAN - Arnold. Beloved husband of Sandra. Loving father of Gerry, Bruce and Laura. Devoted father-in-law of Becky and Jude. Adoring grandfather of Jessica and Tina. Dear son of Eva and the late Charles. Adored brother of Warren. Forever in our thoughts and hearts. Funeral service Friday 12 noon at Temple Emanuel, 455 Neptune Blvd., Long Beach, New York.

title: Daniel Lehner, 49, Head of Inflight Papers
description: Daniel A. Lehner, the flamboyant president of Inflight Newspapers, a multimillion-dollar corporation that distributes newspapers and magazines to airlines and hotels around the world, died of a heart attack on Tuesday while attending a concert at Radio City Music Hall. He was 49 and lived in Cedarhurst, N.Y.

title: Texas Execution Delays
description: To the Editor:

title: CHS ELECTRONICS TO BUY COMPUTER PRODUCTS COMPANIES
description: CHS Electronics Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four closely held companies that are expected to add $120 million to its revenue this year. The acquisitions of Ameritech Argentina S.A. and Compexpress Informatica Ltda. are expected to make CHS Electronics the leading computer products distributor in Argentina and Brazil. CHS Electronics of Miami, which distributes computers, floppy drives, modems and software, also agreed to buy Ameritech Exports Inc., a concern in Miami that distributes Compaq Computer products throughout South America, and Atlantis Skupina, which distributes computer products in Slovenia. CHS did not disclose financial terms except to say that the purchases are being made with a combination of stock and cash.

title: An Agreeable City Council
description: In the partisan hallways of Albany or Washington, the swiftness and hearty handshakes with which the City Council endorsed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's election-year budget last night would have been unimaginable.

title: Judge Orders Runoff Election
description: Mayor Bret D. Schundler, seeking a second full term, suffered a setback yesterday in his battle to avoid a runoff election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOFFMAN, ALAN
description: GOFFMAN-Alan. The Officers and members of the Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member Alan Goffman. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Flyers' Coffey Is Questionable
description: Paul Coffey, the Flyer defenseman, remained in Philadelphia today for a medical examination while his teammates traveled here for Game 3 of the Stanley Cup finals.

title: American Topics
description: Fast-Thinking Victim Dept.: When a man drove up next to Myko Kona not long ago in Redondo Beach, California, and exposed himself, she kept her cool. She snapped his picture. He tried to grab her, but she ran behind his van to photograph the license plate. There was none. He tried to back over her. She ran to the front, and snapped a shot of that license plate before diving into bushes and escaping. The police developed the film and within hours arrested Jimmy Jewell, 33. He pleaded guilty.

title: Parcells Adds Free Agent To Linebacker Collection
description: His teams have always been defined by their linebackers, and Bill Parcells is trying to create the same solid corps on the Jets that he established with the Giants and the New England Patriots.

title: Clinton Aide Says Tobacco Talks Still Face Snags
description: A top White House official said yesterday in an interview that it appeared that negotiators in the tobacco talks still faced hurdles in trying to reach a plan to settle legal and regulatory issues involving smoking.

title: Army Unsure As Soldier In Sex Case Asks to Retire
description: The Army's top enlisted soldier, who had been charged with sexual misconduct and indecent assault involving four servicewomen over nearly three years, has quietly requested retirement, Army officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITCHER, WALTER
description: PITCHER-Walter, of Orangeburg, NY, on June 3, 1997. A master plumber in New York City. Husband of Betty (nee Heffner). Father of Beth O'Grady, Sue Kramer, Marge Millay. Grandfather of Elizabeth, Eddie, Justin, Sean and Katie. Mass Friday, 10:30 AM, St. Anastasia Church, Harriman, NY. Visiting Thursday 2-4 and 7-9, Assumma-Shankey Funeral Home, Pearl River, New York.

title: New Cabinet Is Announced In France
description: France's new Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, today announced a new Cabinet whose 14 ministers include 2 Communists and a member of the environmentalist Greens party.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday offering consumer information about buying a refrigerator misstated the telephone number of a manufacturer, Traulsen & Company. It is (800) 825-8220.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, ELLEN DENISE
description: DOHERTY-Ellen Denise of Manhattan, formerly of Hyde Park, Mass. On June 3. Age 40, suddenly. She is survived by nine brothers and sisters. She was a graduate of Barnard College, Class of '79 and was a Senior Welfare Adviser at the Office of the Manhattan Borough President. Visiting hours will be held in the Carroll-Thomas Funeral Home, 22 Oak St, Hyde Park, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Monday, June 9 at 9 AM in St. Pius X Church, Milton, Mass. For further info please contact 617-361-3216

description: To the Editor;

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CUFFE, EDWARD W.
description: CUFFE-Edward W. Feb. 16, 1936, Fall River, MA-June 5, 1996, NYC. Rage on, wherever you are. The Ding Ansich Dynasty

title: Shabazz Has First Operation to Repair Burns
description: After four hours of delicate surgery on her charred body, Dr. Betty Shabazz remained in critical but stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center last night, with her surgeon declaring that ''this was a very good day for her.''

title: Unisource and Partners Move to Cut Costs
description: Unisource N.V. said yesterday that its three European partners would merge their international telecommunications operations, to cut costs and ease the loss of Spain's Telefonica de Espana as a partner. Unisource consists of the dominant Dutch, Swedish and Swiss telephone companies. They have operated their networks as separate units until now. It said it could cut 20 percent off its costs by merging them.

title: Try Opening the Doors In This Show House
description: DESIGNER show houses, like Mother's Day, are a symbol of the American spring: hokey, artificial, a marketing ploy that is curiously beloved all the same. But their pleasures are fleeting: here today, gone two weeks later. The Kips Bay show house, the Koh-i-noor of the interior design industry's charity-benefit show-house circuit, closed its double doors just a few weeks ago. However, a late-spring offering is in full bloom, the Hudson River Designer Show House in South Nyack, N.Y., open until June 15.

title: Taylor Pleads Guilty to Tax Charge
description: LAWRENCE TAYLOR, the Giants' former All-Pro linebacker, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in Camden, N.J., yesterday to filing a false income tax return in 1990 and was released after posting $10,000 bond.

title: School Violence Drops
description: For the first time in six years, violence in New Jersey schools is decreasing, according to a report released yesterday by the State Commissioner of Education, Leo F. Klagholz.

title: U.N. Extends Plan for Iraq to Sell Oil to Buy Food
description: The Security Council extended a plan today to allow Iraq to sell $2 billion in oil for a second six-month period to pay for food, medicine and other essential items for civilians.

title: Megan's Killer to Give Up Right To Seek Parole if Life Is Spared
description: Jesse K. Timmendequas will agree to serve the rest of his life in prison to try to avoid the death penalty for the murder of Megan Kanka, his lawyer said today.

title: Dedicated To the Jazz From Day 1
description: TO better understand the anomaly of the pro basketball franchise that is the Utah Jazz, go beyond the inimitable pick-and-roll veterans John Stockton and Karl Malone and past the hard-nosed Jerry Sloan. Go down the row of assistant coaches and stop at the 44-year-old David Fredman, who is 5 feet 6 inches when his posture is perfect and who failed to make his high school team in the petite southern Illinois town of Marion more than a quarter of a century ago.

title: Contraceptive to Control Deer
description: For the first time in New Jersey, a contraceptive vaccine will be used to control the population of deer, the Morris County Parks Commission said yesterday. Ten to 15 female deer that now roam the grounds of the Frelinghuysen Arboretum in Morristown will be injected with the vaccine during a two-week period in August.

title: Continental Rift
description: The first two lessons from the Socialist victory in France's elections on Sunday are obvious, and mostly of interest to the French. One is that President Jacques Chirac and the Gaullist movement are in trouble, revealing a dangerous sinkhole on the right wing of French politics. The second is that any serious attempt to reduce France's generous social and welfare provisions will be overwhelmingly rebuffed by the French public.

In the latest twisted use of the country's libel laws, they have obtained a $5.7 million damage ruling against an opposition politician who had the temerity to deny accusations that he was bent on producing racial discord.

title: Clinton Lawyer Retreats on Threat Over Accuser's Sexual Past

title: WESTERN MICRO AGREES TO BUY COMPUTER DISTRIBUTOR
description: Western Micro Technology Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Star Management Services Inc. for $52 million in cash and stock. Western Micro, based in Campbell, Calif., said Star Management owned several companies that distribute midrange computer-server systems manufactured by I.B.M. Western Micro, also a computer distributor, said it would pay $45 million in cash and issue 510,714 common shares in the deal. Shares of Western Micro closed up 62.5 cents, to $13.375, in Nasdaq trading. Western Micro also agreed to pay shareholders of Star Management $5 million based on reaching performance goals.

title: Man Pleads Not Guilty in Fraud
description: An Irvington man pleaded not guilty yesterday in Superior Court to what prosecutors said was a scheme to swindle people who had hired him to settle their unpaid utility bills. Last year the man, James Williams, tracked down several people who had large outstanding balances at Bell Atlantic and Public Service Electric and Gas and persuaded them that he could help them them pay off their bills in exchange for substantial amounts of cash, said Ray Weiss, the prosecutor's spokesman.

Mr. Henderson, 57, who turned over creative duties in 1993 to Denzil Strickland, president and creative director, said he planned to work on a freelance basis. A chairman will not be named.

title: $25 and Under

His affection for the little katzenjammers, whose primordial cowlicks look like models for Bart Simpson's, stayed with him through his years as a pastry chef and later as chef at Bistro Jules in the East Village. So when he opened his own restaurant in Park Slope last December, he decided to call it Max & Moritz, perhaps out of sheer childish delight in finally owning his own place. He even used their silhouettes as his logo.

Since these are also essential aspects of Mr. Greenaway's own work, the match is phenomenally apt. ''The Pillow Book'' finds the filmmaker at his most atypically seductive, creating a spellbinding web of cruel elegance and intricate gamesmanship, exploring the exotic, haunting beauty of the bizarre.

The judge, Helen Balick of United States Bankruptcy Court, agreed to let Marvel suspend the payments to banks until mid-July in hopes that talks involving the company, its bankers and boldholders result in a workable reorganization plan. The company, which is based in New York, publishes Spider-Man and Incredible Hulk comic books. It filed for Chapter 11 protection in December amid slowing sales of its comic book and trading card lines. Marvel's lawyers told Judge Balick yesterday that continued losses forced the company to seek suspension of the payments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCHNER, RABBI ALEXANDER S.
description: LINCHNER-Rabbi Alexander S. Nofloh Ateres Roshaynu, the crown of our head has fallen. Oy lonu ki shokoh shimshosaynu, woe to us for our sun has set. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of its esteemed, revered and beloved Rabbi Alexander Sender Linchner, zecher tzadik livrocho. Rabbi Linchner was a visionary who devoted his every thought, action and moment to Toras Yisroel, Am Yisroel and Eretz Yisroel. Inspired and guided by his legendary father-in-law, Reb Shraga Feivel Mendlowitz, zt''l, founder of Torah U'Mesorah, and spiritual force behind virtually every major institution of Torah, Rabbi Linchner set out with a passionate commitment to teach and inspire Jewish youth, both here and in Israel. As a young American yeshiva student, he went to pre-war Europe to study with the sainted Chofetz Chaim, whose love for the Jewish People would continue to inspire Rabbi Linchner throughout his life. He returned to the U.S. only to be devastated at the loss of six million Jews, particularly one and a half million innocent children. He was permanently affected by the Nazis carefully orchestrated plan to bring about the spiritual demise of the Jewish People by systematically murdering the Roshei Yeshiva, rabbis and Torah scholars and destroying of all of Europe's Torah centers, cities, towns and shtetlach. He viewed himself as a Holocaust survivor, committing his life to restore the Jewish People to their glory-primarily through its youth-return Torah learning to its primacy and build the Land of Israel. Profoundly influenced by Rabbi Shamshon Raphael Hirsch's philosophy of Torah im Derech Eretz, he founded Boys Town Jerusalem where he would teach students that they stood in the place of that lost generation of Jewish children and would inspire them to carry on with our timeless Torah heritage. Rabbi Linchner nurtured Boys Town not just as a school, but as a movement. Its 5,000 graduates have taken the value system imbued in them to virtually every Israeli city, town and village which now bears indelible imprint of the sterling character and values of Rabbi Linchner and his revered and sainted mentors, the G'doley Yisroel. Most important, he touched the lives of countless Israeli youth, giving them hope, opportunity and the means to lead a self-respecting life as they collectively build the Land of Israel while molding its spiritual fibre. The Jewish People have suffered an irreplaceable loss. Our ultimate tribute to Rabbi Linchner-who never compromised principle by remaining steadfast to the Torah-will be through our rededication to the tangible expression of his lifelong mission of perpetuating the timeless values of Torah im Eretz Yisroel, Boys Town Jerusalem. Boruch attoh b'voecho, u'voruch attoh b'tzaysecho. We express our heartfelt sympathy to Rebbetzin Linchner, Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Mrs. Naomi Rothstein, his children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and his cherished extended family, the Boys Town Jerusalem mishpocho. Hamakom yinachem eschem besoch shaar a'velay Tzion v'Yerushalayim. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P.
