description: Our campaign finance system is in total meltdown. There are many villains, but one overshadows all others: soft money. That is why my fellow Republicans should stop opposing President Clinton's decision to ask the Federal Election Commission to ban soft money.

title: Messinger Faults Filming by Giuliani Camp
description: A professional camera operator working for Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election campaign -- accompanied by a city worker -- shot film in the municipal offices of Ruth W. Messinger for possible use in the Mayor's campaign advertisements, Mr. Giuliani's aides said yesterday.

title: Art in Review
description: John Zinsser

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: I'm Not Rappaport

title: His So-Called Life: Days of Whine and Neuroses
description: The title of the new sitcom ''Life . . . and Stuff'' is meant to be cute. You know, it's about school fund-raisers, how sex disappears from marriage and other everyday events that define being middle-aged in suburbia. But if the show's creators can't bother to come up with something less generic than ''stuff,'' what can they expect from us?

title: Art in Review
description: Augustina von Nagel

title: INTERMEDIA SAYS IT WILL BUY DIGEX FOR $150 MILLION
description: Intermedia Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Digex Inc. for $13 a share in cash, or $150 million, as it moves to expand its phone offerings to include data services. Digex shares rose $2 yesterday, or 18 percent, to $12.875, while Intermedia rose $1.375, to $28.50. Digex, based in Beltsville, Md., links companies to the Internet and helps them set up and manage sites on the World Wide Web. It has more than 2,000 customers and 450 employees. Intermedia, based in Tampa, Fla., provides local and long-distance phone services.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOBLOVE, STEVEN
description: JOBLOVE-Steven, 7/21/55-6/6/94. In our hearts and thoughts everyday. Love, Mom, Dad and Vicki

title: Rent Regulations Fuel Housing Court Chaos
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: John Livanos began his American career as a dishwasher in 1957. Today he and his family own a string of restaurants that includes casual places in Westchester County and the elegant Oceana in Manhattan.

title: Then And Now
description: From the steps where George C. Marshall stood 50 years ago, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright spoke to Harvard and the country about America's continuing responsibility in the world. It was a brave speech and a compelling one. But it had an effect that Ms. Albright surely did not intend: to underline the difference between our political leaders then and now, the difference between strength and weakness.

title: Albright Sees an Ambitious World Mission for U.S.
description: On the 50th anniversary of George C. Marshall's quiet offer here at Harvard University to rebuild Europe with American aid, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright laid out an activist agenda for American responsibility and leadership in a less coherent, post-Soviet world.

title: Dennis James, 79, TV Game Show Host and Announcer, Dies
description: Dennis James, the perpetual television personality whose career as a ubiquitous game show host, announcer, actor and commercial spokesman extended from the primeval days of television to the present, died on Tuesday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 79 and had worked almost continuously since 1938.

title: It's Not All Popcorn and Car Chases
description: Just when you thought the summer blitz of popcorn action-adventure films would preclude serious moviegoing until the fall, three film festivals are opening almost simultaneously in New York City this weekend. Anthology Film Archives, the East Village institution that had until recently been languishing, is flexing its muscles with a major new film series, Springfest '97, which, if successful, could rival the New York Film Festival and the New Directors/New Films series as a major international showcase.

title: Johnson, Out of Nationals, Unlikely to Get Into Worlds
description: Michael Johnson has withdrawn from next week's national track and field championships with a thigh injury, and he now seems to have only a remote chance of competing at the world championships in August in Athens.

title: Nigeria's Game in Sierra Leone
description: The recent military overthrow of Sierra Leone's elected Government drew swift and justified condemnation across Africa. It defied the continental trend toward democracy and threatened to re-ignite a civil war in which at least 10,000 people died before the now deposed President, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, achieved a negotiated peace six months ago.

title: Fugazy Admits Perjury
description: William D. Fugazy, a prominent New York transportation executive, pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of committing perjury during a bankruptcy proceeding.

title: Tribute to a Teacher
description: To the Editor:

title: Administration Backs Off White Teacher's Dismissal
description: The Clinton Administration urged the Supreme Court today to let stand an appellate ruling that a New Jersey school board should not have dismissed a white teacher to preserve the job of a black teacher with equal seniority.

title: INSURER TO PAY FOR 1995 FIRE DAMAGE AT MALDEN MILLS
description: American International Group Inc. has agreed to pay for fire damage at the privately owned fabric maker Malden Mills Industries. Although American would not disclose the amount of the payment, Malden's general counsel, Ernst Weglein, said it was about $300 million. The payment was made by the Commerce and Industry Insurance Company, a unit of American International that is no longer writing policies. A fire on Dec. 11, 1995, destroyed three buildings at Malden's plant in Lawrence, Mass., where the company is based, and in the neighboring town of Methuen. Malden said it spent $72 million to build a new plant to produce its Polartec and Polarfleece fabrics.

title: It's the Physical Flyers Who Are Being Bullied
description: The hit of the series occurred late in the second period.

title: President Stays on Sidelines in Debate Over Nominee to Head the Joint Chiefs
description: The White House today expressed confidence in the judgment of Defense Secretary William S. Cohen but refused to say whether the President would support a recommendation that an Air Force general who admitted to a long-ago adulterous affair be made Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHMANN, DR. MANFRED R.
description: LEHMANN-Dr. Manfred R. Last Friday, Dr. Manfred Lehmann was taken from us. The loss to his family is unimaginable. The loss to Eretz Israel is irreparable, and to his admirers and friends his passing has caused deepest sorrow. Freddy was the personification of the Universal Man, a leader and mentor to all who had the honor of meeting and knowing him. In his philosphies, he represented all that is rare and admirable. His enthusiasm and devotion to causes close to his heart were expressed in his writings, in his conversations, in his Being. His charity knew no bounds. He gave to all in need. He was such a brilliant man. The languages, his knowledge of history, archeology, politics, there was no area he was not interested in and conversant with and shared those ideas and feelings generously. All my compassion goes out to you my dearest friend Anne, to Barbie, Karrie and their families. I am mourning your loss with you. Betty Retter

title: Co-op Market in Queens Shows Signs of Strength
description: The Queens co-op market has strengthened in recent months, prompted both by the general firming of New York City's real estate market and by the return to financial health of many buildings in the borough, with sales increasing and some landlords bringing apartments they had been renting back to the for-sale market.

title: Norman and Price Share Lead in Kemper on 66's
description: Nick Price and Greg Norman already share a friendship. Today, they also shared the lead at the Kemper Open.

title: Leader Quits Business Group In Parade Flap
description: The president of the Madison Avenue Business Improvement District resigned yesterday, a day after distributing a flier that urged stores on the Upper East Side to remove valuables from window displays or stay closed during the Puerto Rican Day parade this Sunday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When BESS MYERSON was a competitor in the 1945 Miss America pageant, a concentration-camp survivor approached her in Atlantic City with a request in Yiddish.

title: Home Video
description: All told, it was a clever way to put together an estimable if none-too-major motion picture for not a whole lot of money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVANOS, GEORGE P.
description: LIVANOS-George P. The trustees and staff of the Seamen's Church Institute note with deep sorrow the death of George P. Livanos following a long illness. Mr. Livanos was an esteemed member of the board of trustees for twelve years. He served on the executive committee, the finance committee, and the Center for Seafarers Rights advisory committee with distinction. Mr. Livanos received the prestigious Silver Bell Award in 1987 in recognition of his contributions to the international maritime community. He was a true friend to seafarers.

title: The Island of Dreams
description: Come with me to the island of dreams fulfilled, to the oasis of idealism in the sands of the city.

title: Art in Review
description: Steve McQueen

title: CHRONICLE
description: Ten years ago, JIM KELLY, the Buffalo Bills quarterback, who retired in February, set up a charity to help children with disabilities. Now, he must come to the aid of another disabled child, his own son, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Trinity I Fund Makes Offer To Acquire Fisher Scientific
description: Fisher Scientific International Inc., a manufacturer of scientific instruments and supplies, said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited takeover proposal from Trinity I Fund L.P., a group affiliated with members of the Bass family, the Texas investors.

title: WHITEWATER FILES SPLIT U.S. LAWYERS
description: After heavy lobbying from both the White House and the Whitewater independent counsel, the Justice Department is deeply divided over whether to back the President or the prosecutor in the Supreme Court case involving Government lawyers' notes of conversations with Hillary Rodham Clinton, department officials said today.

title: Crew to Investigate Rehiring of Teacher
description: The day after a junior high school teacher in Brooklyn was accused of punching two students, a spokeswoman for Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said he was investigating why the teacher had not been barred from working in the schools after striking a third student last year.

title: Lawyer for Shabazz Grandson Denies Youth Confessed to Fire
description: A conflict developed yesterday between the lawyer representing 12-year-old Malcolm Shabazz and Yonkers detectives over whether the boy admitted to the police that he purposely set the fire that nearly killed his grandmother.

title: Bank Moving Offices To One Liberty Plaza
description: Royal Bank of Canada is expanding and moving its New York offices to four floors at One Liberty Plaza, at Church and Cortlandt streets in lower Manhattan, under a 15-year lease worth $170 million. The bank will occupy 160,000 square feet at One Liberty, which is owned by World Financial Properties.

title: Police Called In After Thousands Gather In Brooklyn in a Car-Towing Argument
description: A rowdy crowd of several thousand Orthodox Jews gathered last night in Borough Park, Brooklyn, and some members of the crowd scuffled with police officers after a dispute between an Orthodox Jewish man and two New York City deputy sheriffs who had sought to tow the man's car, the police and witnesses said.

title: At Einstein, Quadriplegic Gets a Medical Degree
description: When Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, addressed 193 graduates yesterday at the commencement ceremony of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University in the Bronx, she singled one graduate out for special praise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEADER, SIDNEY D., M.D.
description: LEADER-Sidney D., M.D. On June 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruby Felt Leader, loving father of Isobel Aviva Kirsch and Steven Leader and father-in-law of Barbara, cherished grandfather of Beth and Gabrielle Kirsch and Jaclyn and Allison Leader. Services Friday 12pm at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 W. 83 St, NYC.

title: Marriott Trying to Buy a Site For Another Times Sq. Hotel
description: Marriott International, the largest hotelier in the city, is in negotiations with the Prudential Insurance Company to purchase a development site in Times Square for a 700-room Courtyard hotel, according to real estate sources.

title: How the Very New Can Be Old at Heart
description: Wednesday's concert at Christ and St. Stephen's Church by the Friends and Enemies of New Music was presumably in the hands of the former party, since most of the music was not only new but very new: five of the seven works were written this year. But dates can deceive. Very little on this program was concerned with newness of substance, style, construction or expression. The accent, if that is not too strong a word, was rather on old-fashioned mildness.

title: 48 Indicted In Drug Ring In Manhattan
description: Jesse Vega must have known what was coming when two masked men burst into the One Stop barber shop in the East Village and shoved him back into the chair. Three months earlier, he had used a straight razor to slash the leader of the Champion Crew heroin gang. The time had come for a reckoning.

title: Bulls Also Do a Number On Jazz Players' Minds
description: It seems the Bulls have got away with a hand-check on the Jazz players' heads, bumping and shoving the soft stereotype of the Western Conference to the forefront again.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALAN and MARILYN BERGMAN have won three Oscars, two Grammy Awards and three Emmy Awards. But the Johnny Mercer Award they are to receive on Tuesday at the Sheraton New York Hotel from the Songwriters Hall of Fame has special meaning, particularly for Mr. Bergman. Mercer, the songwriter, who died in 1976 at 66, was Mr. Bergman's mentor.

title: People
description: * Beverly Beaudoin was named to the new post of general manager at Bozell Direct, New York, part of Bozell Worldwide. She had been managing director at Dimac Direct, New York, a division of the Heritage Media Corp., which is being acquired by the News Corporation. Bozell Worldwide is a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Michael

title: Judge Eases Workfare Rules For Recipients Taking Classes
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ordered the Giuliani administration to stop requiring welfare recipients who are in college to participate in workfare programs if such work unduly interferes with their studies.

title: PUTNAM INVESTMENTS FORMS ALLIANCE WITH NIPPON LIFE
description: Putnam Investments said yesterday that it had formed an alliance with Nippon Life Insurance in Osaka, Japan, for the management of Japanese pension fund assets. Putnam said it also formed an alliance with Nissay Asset Management Company, a unit of Nippon Life, to jointly market and manage international products to Japanese pension fund sponsors. Putnam, a subsidiary of Marsh & McLennan Companies, manages more than $190 billion in assets for 575 institutional clients and more than eight million individual shareholders. Nippon Life has about 17.5 million policyholders and $355 billion in assets.

title: Doll Is a Model
description: To the Editor:

title: George Fenneman, 77, Dies; Courtly Foil for Groucho
description: George Fenneman, who earned an enduring place in television history as the good-natured, courtly foil to the tart-tongued mischief of Groucho Marx on the long-running quiz show ''You Bet Your Life,'' died on May 29 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77.

title: Bringing Up Bonzo
description: The young Katharine Hepburn in her ''Bringing Up Baby'' days could have provided what ''Buddy'' needs: the certainty that it is perfectly sensible to treat chimpanzees as children and dress them in tailor-made Bergdorf Goodman baby clothes.

title: German Insurer Is Reviewing Nazi-Era Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Are Already Talking Wild Card
description: Close your eyes and reflect upon the magical memories of the 1996 Yankees. So many inspirational stories. So many victories pulsated with emotion. It was a special season, fraught with execution and excellence and eventually a World Series title.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the On Baseball column yesterday about the Yankees-Orioles game referred incorrectly in some editions to the Baltimore pitcher who gave up a grand slam to New York's Charlie Hayes. He was Jesse Orosco, not Mike Mussina.

title: CUNY Says 541 Failed Required English Test
description: Officials at the City University of New York yesterday raised to 541 their count of the prospective graduates at the university's six community colleges who have not passed a English proficiency test that is now required for graduation.

title: Albright's Words: Global Task for U.S.
description: Following are excerpts from Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's commencement address yesterday at Harvard University . Her remarks were transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription agency.

title: New Findings Cast Doubts On Possibility Of Lunar Ice
description: The Moon shows no signs of concealed water, a new study says, disputing an earlier finding. The new evidence dims the vision of people someday living in lunar colonies or stopping there to get fuel for long voyages to the planets.

title: Feiffer Sojourn at Columbia
description: The cartoonist Jules Feiffer, who quit The Village Voice last week after a salary dispute, will become a senior fellow in the National Arts Journalism Program at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism. Mr. Feiffer, 68, said he would use the fellowship to ''extend the form I'm known for, the cartoon, into a more narrative form.''

title: S.& P. Cuts Rating On Yamaichi Debt
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation cut some of the Yamaichi Securities Company's long-term debt yesterday to a notch above junk-bond status, citing the big Japanese brokerage house's inability to reduce costs as competition heightens. S.& P. reduced Yamaichi's long-term counterparty debt ratings -- which measure default risk in interest-rate swaps and foreign exchange trades -- to ''BBB'' from ''BBB+.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HITTLEMAN, ARNOLD
description: HITTLEMAN - Arnold. Beloved husband of Sandra. Loving father of Gerry, Bruce and Laura. Devoted father-in-law of Becky and Jude. Adoring grandfather of Jessica and Tina. Dear son of Eva and the late Charles. Adored brother of Warren. Forever in our thoughts and hearts. Funeral service Friday 12 noon at Temple Emanuel, 455 Neptune Blvd., Long Beach, New York.

title: C.I.A. Traitor, Saying He Wanted Cash for Family, Gets 23 Years
description: The highest-ranking C.I.A. officer ever convicted of espionage told the judge at his sentencing today that he had become a spy for Russia for the benefit of his three children.

title: German G.D.P. Posts 0.4% Rise
description: The German economy expanded more than expected in the first quarter as rising exports and corporate investment made up for weak consumer demand and a decline in construction activity.

title: Largest Gift Ever Endows a New College
description: Frustrated by the state of engineering education, a New York City foundation is committing $200 million to build a college from scratch. The gift is the largest in history to an American institution of higher education.

title: Drug Evidence Admitted in Alex Kelly Case
description: The judge in the Alex Kelly rape trial decided today to admit evidence that Mr. Kelly's accuser may have used marijuana on the night she says Mr. Kelly raped her after driving her home from a Darien party more than a decade ago.

title: Society's Failure
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Bill Heads to Senate
description: A committee sent a measure to the full State Senate yesterday that would ban the procedure that abortion opponents describe as partial-birth abortion. But the lawmakers did not accept an amendment that Governor Whitman had said she would insist upon before signing such a bill.

title: In New 'Coppelia,' a Chance For Talent to Display Itself
description: American Ballet Theater is showing off many of its talented dancers in Frederic Franklin's genial new staging of ''Coppelia.'' The production is like a burst of warm summer sunshine. Tony Straiges's scenery and Patricia Zipprodt's costumes may emphasize pastel hues, but the choreography can take on many interpretative colorations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief sports article yesterday about the New Jersey High School track and field championships misstated the winning 800-meter time in some editions. Fred Sharpe won the race in 1 minute 53.50 seconds.

title: Unlike EU, It Moves Slowly on Integration : ASEAN:Less Is More
description: SINGAPORE  When asked recently what he had found unique about ASEAN, Vu Khoan, the deputy foreign minister of Vietnam, thought for a moment then replied with a smile: "Having to try to play golf and sing karaoke, because it leads to quiet diplomacy."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Average Rises 35.63, As Market Gains Broadly

title: A. R. Baron's Top Salesman Admits Guilt and Will Assist Inquiry
description: The star salesman at A. R. Baron & Company, a brokerage house that cleared its trades through the Bear Stearns Companies before collapsing amid customer and regulatory complaints last summer, entered a guilty plea yesterday and agreed to cooperate with a continuing criminal investigation of Baron.

title: Swiss, Irked by Critics, Ask 'Why Single Us Out?'
description: After months of being told that their history books were wrong and that Switzerland's war was not a good war, a truculent mood is building here that may turn the nation against making amends for what the Clinton Administration and others depict as complicity with Nazi Germany.

title: Merrill Lynch to Hire 2,000 for Cash and Tax Incentives
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, one of New York City's largest employers, has promised to add 2,000 jobs in exchange for more than $28 million in cash and tax incentives from the city and New York State, people familiar with the agreement said yesterday.

title: Foster's Shares Being Bought Back and Sold
description: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. of Australia said yesterday that it would pay $468 million to buy back 13 percent of its shares held by Asahi Breweries Ltd. of Japan. At the same time, Foster's major shareholder, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia, said it was selling its 36.5 percent stake.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Retailers' Usual Suspect Is the Weather
description: Just how big a part do cumulus clouds, high- pressure systems and warm fronts really play in the strength of retail sales? It depends greatly. Not on the actual weather, it seems, but rather on the sales. If they are bad, the weather can be culpable. If they are stellar, cool air is rendered oddly irrelevant.

title: E-Z Pass Is Coming
description: Electronic toll collection will be available in New Jersey for the first time next month, when the E-Z Pass payment system will make its debut at the Bayonne Bridge, the Port Authority said yesterday.

title: Burnett Assigned Two Accounts
description: The Leo Burnett Company has been awarded two assignments for which billings were not disclosed.

title: So Long, Fractions, but Maybe Not Till 2000
description: They were trading stocks in New York in quarters and halves, rather than dollars and cents, as early as the 18th century. But that practice will die before the 21st century arrives.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Clinton's Pentagon Blues Seem to Be Back Again
description: Right from the start, Bill Clinton has had trouble with the Pentagon.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: DAMAGES TO ATTICA INMATE -- Twenty-six years after he was beaten and tortured by guards who had crushed the Attica prison uprising, a former inmate, Frank Smith, left, was awarded $4 million in damages by a Federal jury. B5.

title: Hingis Dismisses Seles on the Way to Final
description: When Martina Hingis was a pigtailed girl of 9 shagging balls in Switzerland in 1990, Monica Seles was one of her idols. Back then, Seles was the 16-year-old terror of the women's tennis tour, and she was beating up on the opposition here and capturing the first of three consecutive French Open titles.

title: The Doomsayers Are Wrong
description: With 11 of 15 European governments now led by Socialists or other social democrats, European voters seem to be united in resisting tough economic medicine a la Margaret Thatcher. The trend toward privatization, vital to Europe's ability to wean itself from dependence on the public sector, appears to have hit a wall, at least in France.

title: An Uneasy First Encounter in France's Political 'Cohabitation'
description: With a fixed smile of resignation, France's conservative President, Jacques Chirac, presided today over the first session of the new Socialist-led Government, which voters elected against his wishes on Sunday. He said he hoped that power-sharing would be rooted in mutual respect.

title: Ronnie Lane, 51, the Founder Of Small Faces, a British Band
description: Ronnie Lane, an English rock guitarist who founded the band Small Faces, died on Wednesday at his home in Colorado. He was 51.

title: Clinton Supports Plan to Ban 'Soft Money' in Campaigns
description: President Clinton today threw his support behind efforts to have the Federal Election Commission ban the unregulated ''soft money'' donations to political parties that are at the center of inquiries into Democratic finances.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEBBINS, CAMERON DUKE
description: STEBBINS-Cameron Duke. Aged 20, suddenly in an auto accident in Ithaca, NY on June 4 1997. Beloved son of Rowland Stebbins III of Corning, N.Y. and A. Morgan Henning Stebbins of Providence, R.I. Adored brother of Rowland Stebbins IV of Brooklyn, N.Y. Also survived by his grandmothers, Mrs. Basil Duke Henning of New Haven, CT. and Mrs. Rowland Stebbins, Jr. of N.Y.C. A memorial service will be held on Sat., June 7, 11 AM. at Christ Episcopal Church, 39 East First St., Corning. Interment at Greenlawn Cemetery, Brooklyn, private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Pomfret School, Pomfret, CT. 06258

title: It's Not Funny, the Target Says; Lighten Up, Radio Host Says
description: There is some question about exactly what was said. Don Imus, the radio personality, says he would never call anyone ''a drunk,'' as is alleged by a certain angry Manhattan judge.

title: PEROT SYSTEMS AGREES TO ACQUIRE ASSETS OF NETS INC.
description: Perot Systems has agreed to acquire most of the assets and employees of Nets Inc. for $9 million, the companies said yesterday. Nets Inc., which specializes in linking buyers and sellers of industrial goods on the Internet, filed for bankruptcy protection last month. The agreement, which is still subject to the approval of creditors, would allow the company to pay off most of its $10.2 million debt, including $1.7 million in loans made by its chairman, Jim P. Manzi, the former chairman and chief executive of Lotus Development Corporation. Perot Systems, a computer services company, said it would use Nets Inc.'s 60-member engineering team and the software it created to expand its business helping companies streamline their operations using the Internet.

title: The Spoken Word
description: PETE HAMILL, Richmondtown Branch, New York Public Library, 200 Clarke Avenue, between Amboy and Arthur Kill Roads, Richmondtown, Staten Island. The writer and editor-in-chief of The Daily News will read from his book ''Snow In August.'' Tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. Free. Information: (718) 668-0413.

title: Tuning Out, Turning Off, Dropping Out
description: When the Moody Blues sang ''Timothy Leary's dead'' on an early album, they intended a 60's-style compliment: that the acid guru had attained a better vantage point and was ''outside looking in.'' But three decades later, dead really means dead. Or at least it might for someone without Leary's love of self-promotion and gift for gamesmanship from beyond the grave.

title: Council, As Expected, Approves $33.4 Billion Budget Deal
description: The City Council approved a $33.4 billion election-year budget early this morning that is among the least austere of the city's spending plans in a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, SHIRLEY
description: SHAPIRO-Shirley. on June 3, 1997. Beloved mother of Paul and Carol, Elaine and Murray. Grandmother of Sari and Alan, Leslie and Joel, Mitchell and Karen, the late Howard. Great grandmother of David, Adam, Robbie, Brian, Andrew and Sam. We will always treasure the wonderful memories her name evokes. Funeral 12 Noon Sunday at Riverside Nassau, Great Neck.

title: For Hutu Refugees, Safety and Heartbreak
description: The diminutive peasant woman stands, hunched over, with the aid of a stick that is as thin and as tall as she is. Asked her age, she says, ''I don't know.'' Then, after talking to her granddaughter, she says she is 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, PETER J.
description: GALLAGHER-Peter J. On June 4, 1997. Retired Fireman, NYCFD. Beloved husband of Ann (Nancy), nee Porter. Brother-in-law of Ida and Mary Gallagher. Also survived by five nieces and eight grand nieces and grand nephews. Reposing 2-5 and 7-9PM at Henry McCaddin & Son Funeral Home, 24 7th Ave, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Church of Saint Augustine, Saturday, 9:45AM. Interment Saint John's Cemetery.

title: No Headline
description: ''We can accept atrocities as inevitable, or we can strive for a higher standard. We can presume to forget what only God and the victims have standing to forgive, or we can heed the most searing lesson of this century, which is that evil -- when unopposed -- will spawn more evil.''

title: The Next City Budget Debate
description: ''Mellow'' is not a word that normally springs to mind in connection with New York City's Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. But the budget negotiations between the Mayor and the City Council were concluded this week with remarkable ease and serenity. A big pile of money does wonders to improve the political temperament.

title: Its Arms Twisted, Legislature Passes Whitman's Bond Plan
description: After hours of debate and political arm-twisting, the New Jersey Legislature gave final approval tonight to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to borrow $2.75 billion to close a deficit in the state pension system and a gap in her new state budget.

title: TOTES TO BUY A MAJORITY INTEREST IN ARIS ISOTONER
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a majority interest in its Aris Isotoner division to the rainwear maker Totes Inc. for an undisclosed sum. Sara Lee, based in Chicago, makes a wide range of products, from baked goods and coffee to Ball Park franks and L'eggs hosiery. Totes, the nation's largest umbrella company, is controlled by the Boston investment firm Bain Capital Inc. Aris Isotoner sells gloves, slippers and cold weather accessories. Sara Lee will retain an interest in the combined company, to be known as Totes Isotoner.

title: Russian U.N. Delegate Rejects Police Charges
description: Russia's representative to the United Nations rejected charges today by the Manhattan District Attorney's office that, were it not for diplomatic immunity, a Russian diplomat and a colleague from Belarus would face charges of harassment, resisting arrest and disorderly conduct after scuffling with police last Dec. 29.

title: Gripping the Oar Means Risking the Shirt
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPMAN, ROBERTA
description: LIPMAN-Roberta. Missed, loved and remembered by us all. You are always in our hearts. Sandy, Larry, Beth, Donna and Glenn

title: Bank Camera Shows a Man Used Levin's Card to Withdraw Cash
description: The investigation into the slaying of Jonathan M. Levin focused last night on a handful of possible suspects, including students or former students, as detectives searched for an assailant who shot Mr. Levin and then apparently used the beloved high school teacher's bank card to steal $800.

title: Detroit Closes In On Stanley Cup Celebration
description: The Stanley Cup has not yet been clinched by the Red Wings, but residents are celebrating -- and the team is playing -- as if it is a sure thing. You can see it in the thousands of red team flags flying from the cars of fans.

title: Overweight Packages, Contents: Handcuffs
description: There is an old saying that curiosity killed the cat. Curiosity did not do much, either, for 363 people who turned up in response to an official-looking notice about an overweight package that was supposedly waiting for them at a place called the Bronx Regional Package Center.

title: Georgia Candidate for Governor Admits Adultery and Resigns Commission in Guard
description: Former Georgia Attorney General Michael J. Bowers, who earned nationwide attention for aggressively defending his state's anti-sodomy law, announced today that he had carried on an adulterous affair for more than a decade with a woman who once worked in his office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANET, FREDA
description: SANET-Freda, age 86, on June 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Sanet. Devoted mother of Elaine and Herman Schkolnick and Dr. Robert and Linda Sanet. Cherished grandmother of Caroline and Barry Schkolnick, Joseph Schkolnick, Richard and Lori Schkolnick and Wendy and Randy Solganik. Loving great-grandmother of Jonathan and Emily. Her journey is an inspiration. Contributions may be made to ''The Hospice,'' Visiting Nurse Association of Northern New Jersey. Services private.

title: Guam Is the Pace-Setter In Driver Seat-Belt Use
description: Government statistics indicate that there is one clear way to improve drivers' safety habits: move them to Guam.

title: U.S. Airline Executives Are Hot in a Deregulated Europe
description: It's not that Frederick W. Reid isn't used to working abroad. After all, Mr. Reid, a California native, has worked for a hotel concern in India and spent 14 years overseas with Pan American World Airways and American Airlines. There have been stints in the Middle East, in Paris and twice in London.

title: Signs and Symbols on a Thrill Ride
description: The thrill ride genre is a study in shorthand. ''Con Air'': convicts on an airplane. (''Do the math,'' as one character inevitably says about something nonmathematical, using the season's best-loved cliche.) Cameron Poe: he's our hero. Here's what we know about Cameron (Nicolas Cage, looking fabulous): he loves his family. He protects women. He sounds like Elvis. There are Christ-like overtones to his hair weave. He makes origami birds in his jail cell. He must be a really nice guy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, ELLEN DENISE
description: DOHERTY-Ellen Denise. Her colleagues on the staff of Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger are deeply saddened by the passing of a good and loyal friend. As the Borough President's senior advisor on social services, Ellen was a creative organizer and powerful and accomplished writer. We will remember her always for her kindness, passion, fierce independence and incomparable wit. Our hearfelt condolences go to her partner, Sandy Lowe, and to her surviving family members.

title: Officials Trying to Link Olympic Bomb to Other Atlanta Blasts
description: Investigators think two bombings last winter in Atlanta were carried out by the same person or group and are weighing evidence that the same person might be responsible for the explosion at the Olympics last July, a law-enforcement official said today.

title: Brouillard Gets Supermarket Work
description: The Penn Traffic Company in Syracuse, which operates 265 supermarkets in four states, has named Brouillard Communications in New York, owned by WPP Group, to handle broadcast, outdoor and direct response advertising as well as promotional planning. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Sentencing Bill to Be Signed
description: The State Legislature approved a bill yesterday that would require anyone convicted of a serious, violent crime to serve at least 85 percent of his or her prison sentence before being eligible for parole. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman plans to sign the bill on Monday, a spokesman said.

title: Finding Fresh Images for an Evergreen Subject
description: Imagine a show where a Robert Mapplethorpe is far less interesting than a work by a Regina DeLuise, where a Joel Meyerowitz or an Eliot Porter is eclipsed by a Richard Warren.

Cohen was confronted today with rising criticism for his decision to support the general and with new questions about the officer's past.

description: GUTENBURG-Larry, March 5, 1949-June 6, 1995. Always remembered and honored. Bernie Durham and Jose Anselmi

description: So maybe it is still a little early to start printing those Armandomania T-shirts. But with an economical effort, helped by a Mets record-tying five double plays, Armando Reynoso reached an important personal milepost yesterday.

description: With her mohawk haircut and her activism in the successor to East Germany's old Communist Party, Angela Marquardt has never worried about provoking controversy.

title: Fritz Leutwiler, 72, Banker; Revamped Currency System
description: Fritz Leutwiler, a Swiss central banker who played an important role as the system of floating currency rates was put into place, died May 29 in Zumikon, Switzerland, where he lived. He was 72.

title: Laws Require Cameras and Other Security at A.T.M.'s
description: The surveillance camera picture that the police believe may show Jonathan M. Levin's killer at a Chase Manhattan automated teller machine is extremely blurry, investigators and bank officials said yesterday, in part because of the location of the camera.

title: An Accord With Total News Is Reached
description: In a legal settlement expected to bring changes in the way content is viewed on the Internet, a Web site has agreed to stop displaying the content of six news providers with its own ads.

title: Under Threat, Disaster Bill Is Approved By Congress
description: Congress passed an $8.6 billion disaster relief bill tonight, but the vote totals gave Republicans no hope of overriding a promised Presidential veto over provisions intended to prevent Government shutdowns and ban sampling methods from the census.

title: ELDORADO GOLD TO BUY TWO AFRICAN MINES FROM GENCOR
description: The Eldorado Gold Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two gold mines and nine exploration properties in Ghana and South Africa from Gencor Ltd. for $193.6 million. Eldorado, in which Gencor has a 40 percent voting interest, would see its output rise by 18 percent, to 230,000 ounces of gold this year and 375,000 ounces next year. Eldorado, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, said it would have a 90 percent stake in the Bogosu mine in Ghana, which produces 100,000 ounces of gold a year, and 45 percent of the Fairview-ETC mine in South Africa, a proposed merger of two mines that would produce 150,000 ounces of gold a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, RICHARD
description: KARP-Richard. On June 5, 1997. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle, friend. Educator, supporter of Jewish causes, lover of life. Loving, generous and kind. Mourned by wife Lita, children Miriam and Steven, Judi and Sidney, Molly and Marc, Charles, and grandchildren Sam, Anna, Seth, Adam, Elana and Jonah, nieces Susan and Rachel, nephew Gary. Service today, 12:30 PM, ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva observed until Tuesday afternoon. Donations to Educational Alliance, Bialystoker Synagogue, or UJA-Federation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHNER, DANIEL A.
description: LEHNER-Daniel A. The Dowling College family was profoundly saddened by the passing of Daniel A. Lehner, our friend, colleague, and fellow trustee. Mr. Lehner's commitment to higher education and his dedication as a member of a number of Board of Trustees Committees and recipient of the 1994 Presidential Tribute Award will long be remembered. His keen insight and first-hand experience in the field of transportation enriched the growth and reputation of The National Aviation and Transportation Center. Mr Lehner's dedication, support for numerous initiatives, scholarships, and his active involvement in volunteer programs will serve as a continuing legacy for us all. Our deepest condolences to his wife, Remy, and family. Scott Rudolph Chairman of the Board Victor P. Meskill, Ph.D. President Dowling College Long Island, New York

title: Ex-Attica Inmate Wins $4 Million for Reprisals After '71 Uprising
description: Twenty-six years after he was beaten and tortured in an orgy of reprisals by guards who had crushed the deadliest prison uprising in the country's history, a former Attica inmate was awarded $4 million in damages yesterday by a Federal court jury in Buffalo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETTLER, JOSEPH
description: GETTLER-Joseph, 78, formerly of Roslyn, Mineola, and Garden City, N.Y., on May 28, 1997, in Boca Raton, FL. Husband of Mildred, father of John, Caryn McDermott, Jan Fields, grandfather of three, and brother of Caryl Mann, and John. Graveside service 2:00PM, Mon June 16, Greenfield Cemetery, Uniondale, N.Y. Kraeer Funeral Home, Boca Raton, FL.

title: After 15 Years, Dow Jones Lets Futures Trade On Its Average
description: Fifteen years after scorning the infant stock index futures market and going to court to keep anyone from trading derivatives based on the Dow Jones industrial average, Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it had licensed three exchanges to begin trading such contracts.

description: Buying Biennial Works

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, MORRIS
description: BENSON-Morris. Beloved husband of Betty, father of Sam, Jack, Irving and Donna. Cherished grandfather of ten and great grandfather of six. Died peacefully at home in Miami Beach Wednesday, June 4, with his current wife, Ligia, and newly adopted daughter Yani beside him. Born in 1903 in Istanbul, he immigrated to Brooklyn, NY at age 17. He was instrumental in the development of contemporary sportswear with his company Benson Modes and passed on his expertise to his sons in their respective businesses. He lived a rich full life and his passing leaves an enormous chasm in the lives of the many who loved him. Memorial service Friday, June 6, at 1 p.m. at the Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, corner of Ave M, Brooklyn. 718-377-2700. In remembrance contributions to the Sephardic Home for the Aged, 2266 Cropsey Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11214 would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a new security being offered by the General Motors Corporation misstated the history of such securities. This is not the first such issue to have a maturity of less than 15 years, which allows it to escape a proposed change in the tax laws. A subsidiary of the First American Financial Corporation sold a similar security in April, in a deal underwritten by Chase Securities.

title: National Semiconductor Posts Loss for 4th Quarter
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation today reported a loss for its fourth fiscal quarter, reflecting various one-time charges associated with the sale of its Fairchild Semiconductor unit. But on an operating basis, National's earnings exceeded even the most optimistic Wall Street estimates.

title: Frederic W. West, 78, Salesman And Bethlehem Steel Executive
description: Frederic W. West Jr., who rose through the sales ranks of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation to become president and, later, a vice chairman, died last Saturday at the H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center and Research Institute Inc. in Tampa, Fla. He was 78 years old and had been living in retirement in Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, JONATHAN
description: LEVIN-Jonathan. The Greater New York Chapter of the March of Dimes expresses heartfelt condolences to our friend and benefactor Gerald Levin and to his family on the tragic death of Jonathan Levin. His death is a great loss to our city's education system and to the untold students who would have benefitted from his dedication and devotion to the teaching profession. The Board of Directors

title: Stoically, a Rival Tilts at Croatia's Leader
description: In the middle of a political rally, President Franjo Tudjman's chief rival in the presidential elections was punched and whipped with a belt by a man in an army uniform and toppled forward unconscious into his microphone on Thursday night.

title: Fire at Hotel Building Site
description: A fire broke out on the roof of a 502-room hotel under construction in Atlantic City on Thursday night, hours after work had ceased and while the electricity was turned off, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, ELI
description: COOPER-Eli. We note with sorrow the passing of a great leader, a visionary whose Cooper Fellows program created a living legacy for present and future generations of Russian-speaking Jewish youth. May his memory be for a blessing. May his wife Harriet, his sons Douglas and Neil, and the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Albert Reichmann, Chairman American Friends of Shvut Ami Rabbi Eliezer Kugel, Dean Shimon Grilius, Founder

title: Italian Police Arrest Suspected Mafia Boss
description: The police in Sicily today arrested a top crime boss who had been on the run since 1989.

title: Excel Agrees To Buy Telco For $1 Billion
description: Excel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $1 billion in cash and stock to acquire Telco Communications Group Inc., solidifying Excel's position as one of the largest long-distance telephone companies in the nation.

title: Saved by a Sadist: Not Good
description: Carmen Rivera, who made a strong debut as a playwright last year with the comedy ''La Gringa,'' has followed up with a very dark play, ''To Catch the Lightning,'' which teases and baffles throughout. In the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's production, an accomplished cast under Max Ferra's direction makes the work's four tormented characters vivid, moving and sometimes threatening, but at best one can only guess what the play is about.

title: In TV Interview, Teen-Ager Denies Killing Her Newborn
description: The New Jersey teen-ager who is accused with her boyfriend of murdering their newborn son in a Delaware motel last November denied in a nationally televised interview last night that she had killed the infant.

title: Bridge
description: Two world-class teams continued their rivalry here today in the final of the International Team Trials, which will select the American representatives in the world championships in Tunisia in October.

title: Bonds Stage Biggest Rally In a Month
description: Treasury prices rebounded sharply yesterday in the strongest one-day rally for bonds in a month.

title: Last Dance: Kuerten Pairs With Bruguera
description: One danced, the other didn't.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COFFEY, BURTON L.
description: COFFEY-Burton L., 81, Rockport, Maine, former Caltex Petroleum executive, died unexpectedly here, June 3, 1997. He formerly resided in Riverside, CT. Predeceased by his wife, Esther Nancy Coffey in 1995. Mr. Coffey is survived by one son, Burton T., Sr. of Rockport; a daughter, Emily Jean Coffey of New York City; one sister and three grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at 11:00 am Saturday, June 7, 1997 at St. Peters Episcopal Church, Rockland. For information contact Burpee-Strong Funeral Home, Rockland, ME.

title: McVeigh's Lawyers Cite Waco In Urging Jury to Spare His Life
description: Lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh today asked Federal Court jurors to see him not as a ''monster or a demon,'' but as someone who could be their brother, their son, their grandson, and to spare his life in the Oklahoma City bombing case.

title: U.S. Envoy in Congo Offers Aid but Wants Progress on Rights
description: President Clinton's special envoy to the Congo, Bill Richardson, arrived here this afternoon with a team of United States officials who could pave the way for the investment and economic assistance desperately needed by this country, which was reduced to financial ruin during 30 years of Mobutuism.

title: Germany Will Place Scientology Under Nationwide Surveillance
description: The German authorities decided today to place the Scientology movement under nationwide surveillance for one year, their sharpest action yet in a long battle against a group they say is bent on undermining their democratic society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVEN, IRVING
description: KOVEN-Irving. On June 5, 1997. Beloved husband of Esther, revered father of Cory, Jay and his wife Juliet, adoring grandfather of Belle, Robbie, Willie and Rose, loving brother of Eleanor Magid and devoted uncle to Ken, Karen and Sabrina Magid. We will cherish his memory always. Services will be held Monday 11:15am at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam and West 76 St, New York. Burial will take place at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. In lieu of baskets the family has requested that donations may be made in Irving's memory to the JCC Capital Development Fund, 371 South Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591 for the building of their new family community center.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 4.8%, LOWEST SINCE 1973
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell further in May to 4.8 percent, its lowest level since 1973, as Americans enjoyed an economy that has lately produced a remarkable combination of low joblessness and low inflation.

title: Notes Protected by Privilege, Justice Dept. Brief Asserts
description: The Justice Department said today that Hillary Rodham Clinton's conversations with White House lawyers about Whitewater-related matters were protected by the attorney-client privilege, contrary to the position of the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: No Rollover: Jazz Ends Bulls' Hope for Sweep
description: From that manual of old-fashioned plays, they dusted off the give-and-go. On one possession at the end of the first half, John Stockton passed to Karl Malone inside, immediately cut toward the basket and received the ball back from Malone for a layup.

title: Clintons Supported, But With an Asterisk
description: The Justice Department says notes of lawyers' conversations with Hillary Rodham Clinton on Whitewater should be protected, but it says the privilege is not ironclad. It wants the Supreme Court to order a lower court to reconsider the case.

title: Another Rise In British Rates
description: Britain's newly independent central bank raised the base lending rate yesterday, to 6.5 percent from 6.25 percent. The increase was aimed at fighting inflation; even though the main measure of inflation grew at a 2.5 percent rate in April, meeting the bank's target, the bank is worried that price growth will accelerate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, STANLEY S.
description: LEVENSON-Stanley S. Of Brooklyn, NY. Died suddenly on June 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Ruth. Adored father of Amy. Funeral service Sunday 2pm at Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn, 718-633-0400. Contributions in remembrance to the Brooklyn Heights Syangogue, 131 Remsen St, Brooklyn, NY 11201, would be appreciated.

title: City Strips Montefiore Of a Contract
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation has terminated Montefiore Medical Center's contract to run Jacobi Medical Center, saying Montefiore jeopardized care by, among other things, cutting back on staffing and failing to expand some outpatient services.

title: Painting His Way Out Of a Corner
description: EIGHT years after he last held a brush and confronted the emptiness of an untouched canvas, James Jenkins rediscovered his muse. His studio is in a modern-day garret, a windowless basement room hidden beneath the maze of lower Manhattan's narrow streets. With improbable luck, his atelier is next door to DaVinci's. Inspiring neighbor, even if it's only a pizzeria whose masterpieces are rendered in red sauce.

title: Coach Sees Flyer Team On Brink Of Collapse
description: Choke is not a pretty word in the idiom of professional sports. The word is rarely employed -- out loud, at least -- when a coach is referring to his own team. In the Stanley Cup finals, such a description, with all its pejorative connotations, is almost unheard of from the man behind the bench.

description: SILLS-Goldie. Beloved mother of Sandra Ginsberg and Franklyn. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Joseph Robert Sills. Beloved companion of Mr. Al Gelbtuck. Services Sunday 1PM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel,'' 21 W. Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Over There, Different Rules on Sex
description: Maj. Bruno Mignot says he has a lot of time for Americans. They gave the French a hand in World War I; they helped out again in World War II. They built up what he concedes is a ''very big power'' in what he views as ''a very short time.'' But the recent upheavals over sex in the American military have left him deeply perplexed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARONSTEIN, HENRY
description: ARONSTEIN-Henry. Think of you always. Miss you. Happy birthday. Love, Margie, Susan & Jesse

title: Criticism Over Dispute That Drew Thousands
description: As calm returned to Borough Park, Brooklyn, after a car-towing dispute on Thursday night drew an angry crowd of thousands into the streets, some residents and a City Councilman said yesterday that the confrontation was just the latest conflict between residents and city deputy sheriffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLSRUD, EDMOND
description: KARLSRUD-Edmond. On June 6, 1997 at New York Hospital. Artist, colleague, friend, irreplaceable in all categories. Our prayers are with his wife Carolyn, his daughters Katherine, Karen, Kirsten and their families. Judy and Alan Olsen

title: Shot in Hand, Rookie Officer Kills Gunman
description: A rookie police officer on his first night of official duty was shot in the hand last night as he struggled over a gun with a robbery suspect in the Bronx, the police said. With his other hand, the officer, still entangled in the struggle, pulled out his own gun and shot and killed the suspect.

title: Drug Testimony Is Challenged In Retrial of Kelly Rape Case
description: The prosecution in the Alex Kelly rape trial today aggressively challenged an expert witness who testified that the young woman who accused Mr. Kelly of raping her when she was 16 had smoked marijuana on the night Mr. Kelly gave her a ride home.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DIGIOVANNI, CONSTANCE
description: DIGIOVANNI-Constance. 6/7/6012/3/94. Dear Connie, happy birthday in heaven to my beautiful little sister. ''They that love beyond the world cannot be seperated by it. Death is but crossing the world, as friends do the seas; they live in one another still.''

title: Taking a Fresh Look at Sacred Texts
description: New translations of Scripture and new editions of prayerbooks tend to be group efforts, the work of official bodies appointed by some larger organization or higher authority. King James I, to cite a famous example, rounded up 47 scholars who spent nearly a decade translating the Bible from Hebrew and Greek into what has become its most enduring English version.

title: SHARES OF CHILDREN'S BROADCASTING CLIMB SHARPLY
description: Shares of the Children's Broadcasting Corporation soared yesterday after the company said it had agreed to sell all of its AM radio stations to the Global Broadcasting Company for a combined $72.5 million. Shares of the company, a radio programmer, rose $2.25, or 65 percent, to $5.875, in Nasdaq trading. Children's Broadcasting, based in Minneapolis, said the sale of the 13 stations would allow it to cut costs to compete against a new children's network from the Walt Disney Company's ABC Radio Networks. The sale comes about nine months after Children's Broadcasting sued the Disney unit, charging it with trying to drive the company out of the children's radio market. ABC Radio plans to start Radio Disney in four markets in November.

title: Lawmakers to Push Futures Investigation
description: The United States Department of Justice will be asked next week by a group of Federal lawmakers to investigate the possible anti-competitive effects of a Chicago Board of Trade proposal to drop two cities that serve as delivery points for the exchange's corn and soybean futures contracts.

description: The 12-year-old grandson of Betty Shabazz was described today by his lawyer as inconsolable, crying constantly, even as his family tried to lift his spirits with a set of new clothes for a hearing in Family Court.

title: Police Seeking Ex-Student, 19, In Levin Killing
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday identified a troubled former student of Jonathan M. Levin as the primary suspect in the slaying of the idealistic teacher, as the police scoured three New York City boroughs for a young man they thought was trying to elude them.

title: Guilty Plea in Beating At Long Island Nightclub
description: A Queens man has pleaded guilty to attempted criminal mischief in connection with the beating of a young man outside a Long Island nightclub last year, prosecutors said yesterday.

description: Furthering the Chinese Government's grasp on Hong Kong's basic industries, China Telecom said today that it would buy 5.5 percent of Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd. from Cable and Wireless P.L.C. for $1.2 billion.

title: Military Tightens Grip in Algeria Election
description: Parties representing Algeria's military-backed authorities swept to victory in parliamentary elections on Thursday, but a low turnout and accusations of fraud undermined the Government's assertion that the vote represented a big step toward democracy and peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STULBAUM, ARTHUR, D.D.S.
description: STULBAUM-Arthur, D.D.S. Our condolences to his family. Clem Weinstein, M.D., Vice Pres. Wendy Perron, Exec Director

title: After 19 Years, Racing World Hopes for a Coronation at Belmont
description: Patrice Jacobs Wolfson remembers it well. It was 19 years ago, and her colt Affirmed stood on the brink of completing his sweep of the Triple Crown. Now Wolfson, the daughter of the great trainer Hirsch Jacobs and a partner with her husband, the prominent owner Louis Wolfson, is openly rooting for Silver Charm to end the long dry spell for the good of racing.

title: Killing Casts a Shadow Over School
description: When she arrived at William H. Taft High School yesterday morning, Stephanie Santino knew that the police were eagerly seeking to question a former student about the killing of Jonathan M. Levin, an exuberant English teacher.

title: Law May Endanger Legitimate Refugees
description: A Federal advisory panel sharply criticized a new immigration law today, saying it did not provide adequate protection for refugees seeking asylum in the United States.

title: For Some Infertility Experts, Human Cloning Is a Dream
description: Dr. Mark Sauer, an infertility expert at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, dreams of offering his patients a type of cloning some day. He would like to take a human embryo, at the stage when it is two or three days old and has only about eight cells, and use these cells to grow identical embryos where once there was only one.

title: Choreographer Wins $25,000 Festival Award
description: Anna Halprin, a pioneering avant-garde choreographer, will receive the 1997 Samuel H. Scripps/American Dance Festival Award in a ceremony on June 23 at the summer festival, in Durham, N.C. The sculptor George Segal will present the award, which carries a $25,000 prize and is given for lifetime achievement in modern dance.

title: Kenyans Head Mini Marathon Field
description: The Kenyan runners Tegla Loroupe and Delillah Asiago will lead a field of almost 10,000 women today in the 26th running of the 10-kilometer Advil Mini Marathon through Central Park.

Their generosity and commitment to the college will benefit Hunter students for years to come. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Mrs. Leader and her family. David A. Caputo, President, Hunter College Floria V. Lasky, Chair, The Hunter College Foundation

description: At the height of this country's long civil war, travelers dreaded the military checkpoint on the road just south of here.

title: A Nasdaq Firm Settles Price Suit For $30 Million
description: In the largest settlement to date in a price-fixing case that encompasses much of Wall Street, Herzog, Heine & Geduld Inc., one of the Nasdaq's most prominent market makers, agreed yesterday to pay $30.6 million to investors.

title: Fairness in Special Education
description: Over the last two decades New York City's Board of Education has found itself almost constantly in court, defending a special-education system that spends enormous amounts of money on disabled students while educating and graduating few of them. Among other complaints, children's advocates have charged that black and Latino children are assigned to special-education classes in excessive numbers, based on racial stereotypes. The Federal Government now warns that the city could lose Federal funds if it does not reduce the number of black and Latino students assigned to special-education classes.

title: Torpid Bulls Forced to Face the Music
description: Scottie Pippen pried open a sleepy eye in the early morning light. What was that noise? There was clanging and banging. But this was not an alley cat tipping over a garbage can. This sounded like cymbals and bass drums and bugles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEBBINS, CAMERON DUKE
description: STEBBINS-Cameron Duke. Aged 20, suddenly in an auto accident in Ithaca, NY on June 4 1997. Beloved son of Rowland Stebbins III of Corning, N.Y. and A. Morgan Henning Stebbins of Providence, R.I. Adored brother of Rowland Stebbins IV of Brooklyn, N.Y. Also survived by his grandmothers, Mrs. Basil Duke Henning of New Haven, CT. and Mrs. Rowland Stebbins, Jr. of N.Y.C. A memorial service will be held on Sat., June 7, 11 AM. at Christ Episcopal Church, 39 East First St., Corning. Interment at Greenlawn Cemetery, Brooklyn, private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Pomfret School, Pomfret, CT. 06258

title: China's Trade Status Remains 'Open Question' as Vote Nears
description: With animosity toward China growing on the right and left in Congress, President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said yesterday that it remained ''an open question'' whether Congress would vote to revoke China's normal trading status.

title: NOVELL PRESIDENT TO LEAVE AT END OF JUNE
description: Novell Inc., the troubled maker of computer networking software, said yesterday that Joseph A. Marengi had resigned as president and chief operating officer, effective at the end of June. Analysts said the departure of Mr. Marengi, 43, had been expected since May 28, when Novell surprised investors with a net loss for its second quarter and said it would cut its work force by about 1,000 employees, or 18 percent. Mr. Marengi had been considered a candidate to be chief executive of the company, but the board gave the top job to Eric Schmidt, chief technology officer at Sun Microsystems Inc., in March. Mr. Schmidt will temporarily assume the responsibilities of president.

title: Tenants Fear Rent and Welfare Changes Spell Eviction
description: Maria Maldonado and Rosemarie Soto -- mothers, welfare recipients, next-door neighbors -- have watched with apprehension as, one after another, Hasidic families have replaced Latino households in their rent-regulated Brooklyn apartment building at 193 South Ninth Street in the heart of Southside.

title: A Generous Strike Zone Works Against the Mets
description: There may be larger strike zones than the parameters used by Umpire Mark Hirschbeck tonight, but they would have to involve picket lines.

description: TOLBERT-John P., died on June 5, 1997. Loving husband of Elinor, devoted father of Jennifer and Page, beloved brother of Arch and Stokes, adoring and adored grandfather of Christopher. The memory of his intelligence, charm, and wit shall sustain us. Our lives are greater for his, and he will be known to all who know us through our words and deeds. A memorial service will be held Thursday, June 12, at 5 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Avenue, P.O. Box 548, Mongomery, AL. 36101-0548.

title: Algeria's Sham Election
description: This week's parliamentary elections in Algeria were not a serious exercise in democratic governance. Rules restricting the legislature's role assured that real power would remain with President Liamine Zeroual and his backers in the army high command. As a result, no end is in sight to Algeria's civil war, which has killed at least 60,000 people in the five years since the army canceled previous elections in order to prevent victory by a fundamentalist party, the Islamic Salvation Front.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESENDANGER, MARIA NUSSBAUMER BOLSEY
description: WIESENDANGER-Maria Nussbaumer Bolsey, of Galesville, MD on May 27, 1997. Beloved mother of Carole Bolsey and her husband, Dr. Twig W.I. Johnson, of Galesville, MD. Also survived by her extended family: Margo and Emil Bolsey, of White Plains, NY.; the Walter Nussbaumers, of Zoug, Switzerland; the Bolsey/Williams family, of Jamaica Plain, MASS; the Bolsey/Adarker family of Portland, Oregon; the Bolsey's of Los Angeles, CA; the Wiesendanger's of Zoug, Switzerland, Paris, France; and Milan, Italy; the Meilland and Bogopolsky families, of Crassier; Vevey and Prevenges, Switzerland. Memorial Services and Interment of the Cremains will be held on June 19, 1997 at 3 p.m. in the Zoug Cemetary, Zoug Switzerland. A 90th Birthday Commemoration Ceremony and Reception will be held on July 5, 1997 at 4 p.m. at the home of her daughter and son-in-law in Galesville, MD. For more information contact the Hardesty Funeral Home, P.A. 905 Galesville Road, Galesville, MD.

title: Pondering 2 Trials, Judges Lean to One Conclusion
description: In tone and pace, the murder trials of O. J. Simpson and Timothy J. McVeigh could not have been more different. And it is the contrast between the two -- one characterized by celebrity, daily telecasts, endless testimony and general messiness, the other by neat, decorous efficiency -- that could very well lead many judges to conclude that high-profile cases must be more tightly controlled, legal experts say.

Helmsley, over a real estate empire that stretches from modest garment-district buildings to the Empire State Building, is close to selling the family's real estate company and ending a long-standing feud.

title: Williams Criticizes Calipari
description: The tension between Coach John Calipari and forward Jayson Williams that was apparent throughout the Nets' season has come to the surface even more in a basketball diary Williams wrote for this month's GQ magazine.

title: Officer Shot in Bronx Dies of His Injury
description: A police officer who was shot last month while driving his car in the Bronx died yesterday morning at Jacobi Medical Center. Investigators announced yesterday that the officer, who was off duty at the time of the shooting, had been the victim of a robbery.

title: Fireworks Explosion Saddens a Tennessee Town
description: The plain little mountain town was deeply proud of its fireworks king, the local boy whose dazzling shows had gone all the way to the nation's capital, and even overseas.

title: Edythe Meserand, 88, Pioneer As an Executive in Radio News
description: Edythe Meserand, who was one of the first women to become a radio news executive, died on Monday at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y.. She was 88.

title: HAYES WHEELS IN TAKEOVER OF LEMMERZ OF GERMANY
description: Hayes Wheels International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 100 percent of Germany's Lemmerz Holding G.m.b.H. for $200 million cash and $110 million in Hayes preferred stock, which will be convertible into five million shares of Hayes common stock. Hayes will also refinance about $80 million of Lemmerz's existing debt. The transaction will more than triple Hayes's automotive parts business in Europe. Hayes, based in Romulus, Mich., said in December that it was buying a 76.63 percent interest in Lemmerz, which makes steel and aluminum wheels for cars and heavy-duty trucks, for $295 million in cash, stock and debt.

title: Making It to Dartmouth With That Old Moxie
description: ''Whatever happened to 'class'?'' the inveigling prison matron, Mama Morton, and the self-justifying manslayer, Velma Kelly, lament in the hit musical ''Chicago.'' The same question could apply to ''moxie,'' that peculiarly American character trait embodied by those indefatigable 1940's movie types like Mickey Rooney and Thelma Ritter.

title: Jones Case Puts a Human Face on Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweet Memories of That First Murder
description: If the gamblers, bagmen and other lowlife heroes of Elmore Leonard's novels are likable, it's only in part because they are not bloodthirsty; they always have some offbeat, amusing quirk, too. Harry Arno, the Miami bookie who is at the center of ''Pronto,'' has a soft spot for Ezra Pound. Poetry has nothing to do with it. In 1945, both Harry and Pound were in Rapallo, Italy, where Harry first killed a man, imbuing the place with sentiment and glamour forever.

title: Stuart Troup, 63, a Jazz Critic and Editor
description: Stuart Troup, a jazz writer, critic and editor who worked for newspapers in the United States and Europe, died on Wednesday at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 63 and lived in Manhattan.

title: RAYTHEON SEES $573 MILLION IN PLANT CLOSING COSTS
description: The Raytheon Company has estimated that it will spend $573 million to close plants, sell equipment and cut jobs after completing two huge acquisitions, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In January, Raytheon announced that it would buy the military electronics operations of General Motors' Hughes Electronics and of Texas Instruments for a total of more than $8 billion. The $573 million, to pay for severance and plant closings, will be spent over two and a half years following the closing of the deals, a Raytheon spokesman said. Raytheon will also pay $165 million in fees to investment bankers, lawyers and accountants for their work on the purchases, the S.E.C. filing said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, DENNIS
description: JAMES-Dennis. United Cerebral Palsy, its staff, volunteers and 150 affiliates nationwide mourn the loss of Dennis James. For more than 40 years, Dennis generously contributed his time, talent, energy and love to UCP. He was the ''Father'' of UCP's telethon, hosting the event since its inception in the 1950's. His efforts have raised more than $700 million to advance the independence of people with cerebral palsy and other disabilities. We will greatly miss Dennis, his dedication and generous spirit and give our sincere condolences to his wife, Micki, his sons, Dennis, Jr., Randy, and Brad and the entire family. Leonard H. Goldenson, Chairman of the Board Jack Hausman, Vice Chairman Of the Board Michael H. Simonson, Esq., President UCPA John W. Kluge, President UCP Research & Educational Foundation Michael W. Morris, Exec. Director UCPA Murray Goldstein, D.O., M.P.H. Medical Director, UCP Research & Educational Foundation

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, MINNIE
description: HANDLER-Minnie. On June 6, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Herbert; loving mother of Arthur, Howard and Mark; adoring grandmother of Karen, Jennifer and Hayley. Contributions in her memory to: Make A Wish Foundation.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Trip To Rivera Is Easy for Yanks
description: The bridge was the way to go. That has not always been true this season at Yankee Stadium, where the bridge -- the means of getting from the starting pitcher to the closer -- has often been an unpleasant route. Last night there was no backup, no toll. The Yankees, for a change, could enjoy an E-Z Pass.

title: Government Charges 4 in Theft of F.B.I. Van
description: Criminal complaints were filed against four suspects today in the theft of an F.B.I. van and the weapons, ammunition and assault gear inside.

title: Whitman's Borrowing Plan: Criticism May Not Go Away
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman unveiled her multibillion-dollar borrowing plan for the state pension system in January, her top aides were stunned by the harsh criticism, even from members of her own party.

title: A Picasso and a Monet Turn Up in Storage
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents in Cleveland have recovered two paintings -- one by Picasso and one by Monet -- that were reported missing five years ago by Dr. Steven G. Cooperman, an ophthalmologist in Brentwood, Calif.

title: With No Big Rival, It Calls the Shots in Athletic Shoes
description: Slouched in their chairs, eyes fixed on a table littered with shoes, they give their grim assessments. A sneaker by Fila? Overpriced. A pair of new Reeboks? The group is more charitable, though one person says the bubbled soles look like ''something for NASA.'' A pair of skateboard shoes? Booed off the table.

title: Role of C.I.A. In Guatemala Told in Files Of Publisher
description: In June 1954, the publisher of The New York Times privately agreed with the Director of Central Intelligence to keep a foreign correspondent of The Times out of Guatemala, according to the publisher's personal files, just as the Central Intelligence Agency was secretly mounting a coup there.

title: Young Ailey Dancers Show Off Their Skills
description: The rock-concert roars that welled up from the audience on Thursday night at the John Jay Theater were for student dancers from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center and young members of the Ailey junior and senior troupes. The cheers were merited. Strong technique was a hallmark of this annual spring program, but also superb performing skills, from the smallest roly-poly dynamo first out onstage to the three senior dancers who ate up that stage in ''Sinner Man'' from Ailey's ''Revelations.''

title: Blair Urges New Way for Europe's Left
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, on his third European excursion in two weeks, brashly counseled a gathering of the continent's Socialist leaders in Sweden today to discard dogma ''or die'' and told Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Bonn that the European Union was out of touch with its own people.

title: One Way to Redeem the Tax Package
description: The tax package that the White House negotiated with Congressional leaders offers few redeeming features. It would do little to spur investment. It would tilt the tax code in favor of high-income families. It would create huge deficits after several years that will force Congress to squeeze hard on Federal programs. But there is an imaginative way to amend it to produce at least one useful outcome -- medical insurance for children.

title: They're Hors D'Oeuvres Of the City Budget Meal
description: It was late Thursday night, the hours wilting away, and in an antechamber on the second floor of City Hall, the New York City Council was performing one of the final rituals in the process of birthing a municipal budget. Bills, already endorsed by Council leaders and soon to be formally passed, were being debated with a lackadaisical decorum.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM PLANS TO HIRE 5,000 WORKERS
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said yesterday that it would hire 5,000 workers in the Ottawa region in the next four years to meet increased global demand for telecommunications products. Northern Telecom, based in Brampton, Ontario, said it would also invest $181.5 million to upgrade and expand research and product development. The company's Ottawa work force currently exceeds 10,000.

Leggett and Company. He was President of the Huguenot Society of America. Mr Whitmarsh is survived by his wife Mary Louise Ward Whitmarsh, their daughters Linda Whitmarsh, Carol Bennett, Dorothy Sprague, five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. There will be a memorial service on Monday June 9, at 11 a.m. at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Huguenot Society of America, 122 E. 58 St, NYC 10022 would be appreciated.

Lehner. Chairman of the hospital's Ben Franklin Club and generous Franklin Hospital benefactor, his never-failing contributions to the quality of life in our community will be sorely missed. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Remy, a Franklin Trustee, and to his children and the entire Lehner and ''In Flight'' families. Justice Howard E. Levitt, Chairman, Board of Trustees Franklin Hospital Medical Center

description: In percent

title: Irabu Dazzles Steinbrenner
description: After getting his first look at the pitching of Hideki Irabu in Florida yesterday, George Steinbrenner said he expected the Japanese right-hander to reach the Yankees after the All-Star break, July 7-9.

title: An Artist Who Seeks Revenge Through His Art
description: An artist is meant to create, a critic is meant to criticize and no one expects them to be happy bedfellows. But occasionally conflicts between artists and critics come to dominate the art and the criticism. And that is more or less where things now stand in the war between the American painter R. B. Kitaj and British art critics. The war has become the event.

title: Xerox Is Buying Out a Partner
description: The Xerox Corporation is finally taking full ownership of Rank Xerox, the London marketing and manufacturing operation it created in 1956 with the Rank Organization.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the New Jersey section last Sunday about the redevelopment of the 300 block of George Street in New Brunswick misstated the date by which tenants must move from buildings scheduled for demolition. The New Brunswick Development Corporation expected the buildings to be empty by the end of the month, not by June 1.

title: G.O.P. Delays A Relief Bill In Bid to Curb A Veto Threat
description: Hoping to build a ground swell of public opposition to President Clinton's plan to veto an emergency relief bill, Congressional Republicans said today that they would not send the legislation to the White House until Monday.
