description: NATHANSON-Edward T. (Ted). Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member Edward Nathanson. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Martin I. Klein, President

title: UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES TO ADD HIGHLANDS GAS
description: Union Pacific Resources Group Inc. announced yesterday that it had an agreement to acquire the Highlands Gas Corporation of Englewood, Colo. Including debt and other obligations to be assumed by Union Pacific, the total value of the transaction is about $180 million. Highlands is engaged in natural gas gathering, processing, marketing and transportation as well as natural gas liquids transportation and marketing. Highlands' assets include three gas processing plants with a total capacity of 117 million cubic feet a day, five gas gathering systems with more than 700 miles of pipe and about 400 miles of transportation pipeline. Union Pacific is the United States' largest independent oil and gas exploration and production company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEIWEISS, ENRIQUE
description: BLEIWEISS-Enrique, died June 5th, 1997 in Miami Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Elsy. Deeply mourned by her and by daughters, Monica Plotsky and Jacqueline Terpins, by son-in-law, David Plotsky, and by four grandchildren.

title: Irish Go to the Polls To Choose Legislators
description: The Irish voted for a new Parliament today, but they will probably not know until Sunday, if then, which parties will form a new government.

title: The Plum Of Your Lips
description: Shall I ask the rain to dance

title: George Livanos, 70, a Giant In Greek Shipping Business
description: George P. Livanos, who helped build postwar Greece into a formidable merchant shipping power and as owner and operator of vast tanker fleets vigorously promoted efforts to protect the marine environment, died last Sunday at a hospital in Athens. He was 70 years old and in recent years had suffered from a rare blood disorder complicated by heart trouble.

title: HFS PLANS TO SELL 75% OF ITS STAKE IN AVIS
description: HFS Inc. plans to sell 75 percent of a stripped-down Avis Rent-A-Car Inc. to the public in a first-time stock sale that may raise as much as $250 million. After the offering, which was expected, Avis will be the world's largest Avis franchisee, with about 540 sites. HFS will continue to own the Avis brand name and reservation system, which it acquired with Avis in October for $793 million. The Avis offering comes six weeks after the Ford Motor Company sold 19 percent of its Hertz rental unit. Hertz shares have risen about 35 percent since the company sold shares to the public in April. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Avis did not say how many shares it plans to sell.

title: Ted Nathanson, 72, Director Of NBC Sports and News Shows
description: Ted Nathanson, whose career as a television director ranged from game shows and political conventions to 13 Super Bowls and 21 Wimbledon tennis championships, died yesterday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 72.

title: Corrections
description: A chart last Saturday with an article about the United States' deployment of a hydrogen bomb that detonates underground misstated its explosive power in some editions. The bomb, the B-61, can yield the equivalent of 350,000 tons of TNT; it is not as powerful as an older bomb, the B-53, which can yield the equivalent of nine million tons of TNT.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 15 about the translator Robert Fagles included an incorrect reference by Mr. Fagles to the author of ''The Authoress of the Odyssey.'' A letter from Mr. Fagles dated June 1 says the work is by Samuel Butler, not Robert Graves.

title: Administration Refines Proposal for Tax Credits and I.R.A.'s
description: The Clinton Administration is proposing to combine two main elements of its tax-cutting plan, a credit for families with children and an expansion of the Individual Retirement Account, Administration officials said today.

title: Teamster Vote Under a Cloud In a Fraud Case
description: The Federal Government announced yesterday that it was charging a campaign fund-raiser working for Ronald Carey, the teamsters' president, with mail fraud, asserting that the fund-raiser masterminded a scheme in which embezzled union money was contributed to Mr. Carey's re-election campaign in 1996.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review last Saturday about ''As You Like It,'' by the Acting Company at St. Clement's Church, misstated the given name of the author of ''Rosalynde,'' the novel that inspired Shakespeare's play. He was Thomas Lodge, not Henry. The review also misstated the title of a play by Ben Jonson. It is ''Every Man in His Humor,'' not ''and His Humor.''

title: Water Restrictions Lifted
description: Water restrictions that had been imposed on 85,000 customers of United Water Toms River on April 5 were lifted yesterday after the State Department of Environmental Protection said the company could reopen six wells that had been closed since November.

title: Man Jailed Over Water Use
description: A Stafford man has been in jail since Monday, when he was convicted of repeatedly refusing to allow utilities officials to connect his house to the local water supply.

title: Chairman Helms
description: Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's assiduous courtship of Senator Jesse Helms may have gained his cooperation on several foreign policy fronts, but it has obviously not vanquished his despotic streak. Mr. Helms, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has now arbitrarily determined that Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts is unfit to be Ambassador to Mexico, and the Senate shall not even have the chance to review his qualifications.

title: Dow Adds 130, Putting 1997 Gain Near 1,000 Points
description: In yet another display of the market's seemingly bottomless store of euphoria, stock prices surged again yesterday, lifting most of the major indexes to new records.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate Falls to 4.8%; Payrolls Rise Moderately

title: A Reunion for 'R' Generation
description: A letter came in the mail a few weeks ago informing me that it was time to make a pilgrimage back to my college for my 10th reunion. The envelope sat on my desk for quite a while, sometimes under a pile, sometimes, after a vigorous purge of junk, all by itself, unabashedly requesting my attention. There were several attachments explaining activities and costs and housing arrangements, but for a long time I wasn't able to consider them because I got so worked up whenever I looked at the cover note.

description: To the Editor:

title: Toxic Spill at Laboratory
description: Three employees of a Merck & Company research complex in Linden were hospitalized yesterday after a toxic chemical spilled in a laboratory, company officials said.

title: Live, From Ramallah
description: When I received a call from the Ramallah police to come to the station for a cup of coffee, I didn't expect to be detained by the Palestinian Authority for an entire week without being questioned or charged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOHERTY, ELLEN DENISE
description: DOHERTY-Ellen Denise. The Crime Victims Treatment Center of St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital mourns the sudden death of its first Co-ordinator. Her energy, humor and passion will be greatly missed. Her spirit lives on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, HAROLD
description: GROSSMAN-Harold. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Harold Grossman, associated with The Times from April 1, 1963, until retiring in August 1, 1978.

title: Sporting Trifecta In One Day
description: TALK about your Triple Crown. Martina Hingis loves horses and is a refugee from the former Soviet bloc. That gives her something in common with both Silver Charm and the Detroit Red Wings on this extraordinary Saturday.

title: J. Anthony Lukas, 64, an Author, Is Dead
description: J. Anthony Lukas, a driven, tenacious author and reporter who won two Pulitzer Prizes while exploring the social and racial fault lines of 20th-century America, committed suicide on Thursday in his apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 64.

title: INSIDE
description: In Washington, Debate; In France, Astonishment

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, IRA
description: WOLFE-Ira, 85, of Tamarac, FL. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, died June 4, 1997. Predeceased by wife Ida, survived by wife Roslyn, daughter Susan (Tony) Girese, stepchildren Diane Hunter and David Holden; grandchildren Adam, Cheryl, Mark and Steven. Services held by Star of David Memorial Chapels, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, MORRIS
description: BENSON-Morris. Beloved husband of Betty, father of Sam, Jack, Irving and Donna. Cherished grandfather of ten and great grandfather of six. Died peacefully at home in Miami Beach Wednesday, June 4, with his current wife, Ligia, and newly adopted daughter Yani beside him. Born in 1903 in Istanbul, he immigrated to Brooklyn, NY at age 17. He was instrumental in the development of contemporary sportswear with his company Benson Modes and passed on his expertise to his sons in their respective businesses. He lived a rich full life and his passing leaves an enormous chasm in the lives of the many who loved him. Memorial service Friday, June 6, at 1 p.m. at the Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, corner of Ave M, Brooklyn. 718-377-2700. In remembrance contributions to the Sephardic Home for the Aged, 2266 Cropsey Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11214 would be appreciated.

title: Pianist of Delicacy as Well as Muscle
description: Carlo Grante's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night, the fifth in a series of six by the young Italian pianist, systematically demonstrated technical ability, but it was a prowess that went beyond sheer muscle and speed. Interestingly, Mr. Grante's pianistic skills were clearest in the least showy of his music: pieces by Debussy that included the second book of ''Images'' and six of the Book I ''Preludes.''

title: Senators Expressing Doubts On Joints Chiefs Candidate
description: The candidacy of an Air Force general to become the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff seemed increasingly imperiled today as a growing number of senators said the officer's adulterous affair in the mid-1980's could disqualify him.

title: From Chelsea Clinton's Dad, Pithy Advice for Graduates
description: Besides wishing them courage and warning them against cynicism, President Clinton urged the students in his daughter's graduating high school class today to guard against self-pity. But he sounded a bit sorry for himself as he contemplated sending his only child, Chelsea Victoria Clinton, off to college.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWRE, E. STEWART, M.D.
description: OWRE-E. Stewart, M.D. Formerly of Brookville, L.I. on June 5, 1997. Age 76. Beloved husband of Carolyn. Father of Mary Ellen, Elliot, Claude, Granville and Gabrielle. Brother of Adrienne Lynch, grandfather of Alexandra, Katherine, Elizabeth and Carolyn. Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, Sunday 2:00 pm. In lieu of flowers, donations to DeBakey Medical Foundation, Rm A-954, 1 Baylor Plaza, Houston, TX 77030

title: English Is an Art, Not a Science
description: City University trustees are determined to hold back diplomas for hundreds of community college students because they have failed a newly mandated English test. But this test does not test much at all.

title: Fall Schedules: Scientific Proof That Chaos Is Not Just Theory
description: EVERY FALL, NETWORK programmers swear that they'll be kinder and gentler to viewers, that they won't toss their prime-time schedules into a blender again, hoping for some new, more potent concoction. And every spring, they fall off the wagon.

title: A Federal Tax Program Helps Build Housing
description: ON Fulton Street in Farmingdale, the 28-unit Woodbridge at Farmingdale rental complex for people 62 and older stands on what once was a used-car lot. title: Bloated
description: The skyscraper, the Cadillac fin, the flag, the cowboy boot under the jutting cuff of jeans, the cigarette, the steel-mill chimney all share a geometry, a sharp clarity of outline; they demonstrate power and energy rising, they take off. When I first started coming to America, the country would rise in my mind's eye, delineated with this cut and thrust. But if such symbols haven't become by now simply dated emblems of another time, they're actively denounced and repressed. The visual lexicon of American identity has changed emphasis; bigness still defines it, but a bigness grown pillowy and flaccid and fluffy and fat like baby flesh -- the esthetic of the animated cartoon writ large over aspects of the culture far beyond the world of entertainment where it began. The new esthetic seems to me part of a generalized cult of childishness, fake infantilism. Its meanings run much deeper than the old cult of pioneer innocence or liberal hedonism; its roots lie in something far more important than the perennial anxiety about obesity. American gigantism was assertive; now it has turned escapist.

He gets a little tired of public attention, finds that autograph signing can get a famous person into trouble and, in his introduction to life in the clubhouse, explains in extralarge type, ''I just don't like people touching my stuff.'' And while he is unfailingly polite, his compliments tend to the backhanded. Tsk-tsking that his teammate Alex Rodriguez does not get as much attention as he should, Mr. Griffey says: ''From Day 1, they labeled me the 'Savior of Baseball' in Seattle. With Alex, you heard about how he was a great shortstop that could come in and help Ken Griffey.'' ''Junior'' does show a moving gratitude for the huge presence of Ken Griffey Sr., who never minded a 2 A.M. phone call (even about non-baseball stuff) from his son and who to this day will give his son a call in the dugout. It would be surprising if an amazing athlete, having been raised rich and talented and special and scooped into the majors at the age of 19, did emerge with much wit and grace. What is odd is that Mr. Griffey shows more of both in real life than he does in the book. Apparently he is not getting the ghostwriting he deserves. Laura Mansnerus

After last Sunday's elections, ''French paradox'' could refer to French theories of economics. The new Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, promises to address the future by retaining the indulgent social policies of the ''past,'' and to reduce the deficit by shortening the workweek to 35 hours and raising the minimum wage.

Finishing a tournament in which they displayed technical brilliance and overall cohesiveness, the Wings completed a four-game sweep of the final series tonight with a 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers amid the jubilation in Joe Louis Arena.

That is, Americans think about it an awful lot -- mostly worrying that they're not doing it right or not doing it enough -- before appearing on talk shows and sharing their deepest, darkest inhibitions and fantasies with millions of people. But do they actually do it anymore behind closed doors? The jury's out on this one.

Yes, some mice are still playing, but others seem to have discovered that the real fun of the boss's vacation is finding out what it's like to be the cat.

title: Where the Elite Meet to Meet

Every group in the tristate area, from grocery wholesalers to nuclear physicists, must hold an annual conference between May and September. Those who can't afford to go to northern Italy, or even to San Francisco, come to the wide open spaces of Long Island. At this time of year, you can't enter a hotel, a resort or a popular restaurant anywhere near the ocean without encountering a boistrous group of insurance salesmen or science teachers, over-excited at being away from home and wearing big labels saying things like, ''Hi I'm Randy -- vice president for Revolving Door Maintenance.''

title: Fumbling After Grace: Fishing and Writing
description: WHEN Dame Juliana Berners's ''Treatise of Fishing With an Angle'' was published in England in 1496, literature and fishing fused as securely as a Velveeta-swathed treble hook embeds in a hungry trout's lip. The English language boasts more than 5,000 books on fishing. Fishing, particularly fly-fishing, is without doubt our most literary sport.

title: A Place for Pasta and More in Armonk
description: FROM its premier site on this hamlet's busiest thoroughfare, La Scala issues an inviting roadside call, its attractive public face promising much. Once inside, one may wonder at the relative spareness of the place, appointed, it would seem, without much imagination. But be assured: artistry is practiced in the kitchen. Spend an evening at table here and most of what is promised will be fulfilled.

title: Vain
description: ''American women are always obsessed with the dieting and the plastic surgery, but the more they try to go backward and look younger the more the result is the opposite: they end up looking ridiculous. Not to be obsessed by that is the most natural and clever way to be. And to be yourself is better than being ridiculous. American women want to copy the models in the magazines.

title: That Aura of Masculinity, And Foliage
description: FOR years, I was only dimly aware of the explosion of colognes and after-shave products pitched to men: Polo Sport, Egoiste, CK One and the like. Even Michael Jordan, whose olfactory image would seem to conjure up sweat socks, has his own cologne. Personally, I let only one nonnatural scent touch my body -- eau de Mennen. I imagined that most buyers of those expensive little designer bottles were young men seeking extra ammunition for a date.

title: Hellbent
description: Inherent in the first Thanksgiving is the idea that God signifies His approval through the dissemination of earthly goods. Through industry and faith, the founding Dissenters believed, America -- and ultimately the world -- could be ordered and made a model of heaven. In the Calvinism of Massachusetts lay the seeds of American energy, of the faith to do all things -- to make steel, build railways and take land from Mexico. What the Dissenters started in the 17th century found its full expression a century later, in the American Revolutionary War. To be the first people to invoke the pursuit of happiness as a goal merely increased the settlers' sense of predestination. Once the life of the republic was assured, the United States could become the secular missionary to the world -- a role that, despite Vietnam, it still feels bound to fulfill. Its leaders seem compelled to pursue the Jeffersonian quest for happiness in Bosnia and Northern Ireland. In the end, it's this quest, not isolationism, that wins American voters.

title: Controversy Diminishes Italy's Clout In Albania
description: Two embarrassing episodes have given Italian diplomacy in Albania a black eye, self-inflicted at a critical moment in the sensitive relationship between the countries that face each other across a narrow stretch of the Adriatic Sea.

title: A Lifetime of Experimentation With Style
description: IT'S not only the most famous artists who make history. Sometimes, almost unknown figures are pioneers in their way. One such artist is Hananiah Harari, an American modernist who at 84 is having his first retrospective, at the Montclair Art Museum, organized by Gail Stavitsky, the museum's curator of collections and exhibitions.

Mr. Solti was then 54, and this landmark project, the first complete studio recording of the four-opera cycle, had taken more than a decade.

title: Edward Bikales and Ellen Butler

He ran inn-to-inn bicycle tours, while she wrote personal essays for the local paper and halfheartedly filled out medical-school applications.

title: An Expert At Becoming The Swan Princes Go Wild Over
description: IT WAS THE EVENING OF THE first ''Swan Lake'' of American Ballet Theater's spring season this year at the Metropolitan Opera House. Susan Jaffe was priming herself to dance Odette-Odile, personations she initially saw at the age of 8, when they kindled in her a longing to dance. Since joining Ballet Theater in 1980, Ms. Jaffe had been coached in these roles, which Dame Margot Fonteyn regarded as the most taxing in any ballerina's repertory.

In its exhibition ''Technology, Jobs and an American City'' on view through Nov. 9, the Stamford Historical Society charts the city's evolution from past to present and into the future.

title: LIPA Asks What More Can It Do to Be Fair?
description: ''What Exactly Is LIPA Hiding?'' $(May 25$) can be answered quite simply -- nothing. In fact, the Long Island Power Authority process to review and receive public input on its plan has been thorough, comprehensive and open to all members of the public.

title: Powerful
description: The British are terrible military snobs. The oldest regiments, the smartest drill, the most glamorous uniforms, the most exotic battle honors -- we have them, others don't. That has always been the British outlook. Recently the British have taken to congratulating themselves on the remarkable efficiency of their armed forces as well. Since they won a startling long-range victory in the Falklands in 1982, the British forces have been turning up on the winning side in all sorts of places -- the Persian Gulf war in 1991, Bosnia in 1995. If not the winning side, then the politically correct place, as deemed to be by the United Nations Secretary General. The British have become successful peacekeepers as well.

title: Paper Fights To Stay Alive
description: ELEVEN years ago, three reporters combined their ambition with an American Express card and opened a newspaper on South Street here. They did not want to write about grand national plans or state policies. The Peekskill Herald would be a local paper -- as local as news gets -- with coverage of high school sports, mom-and-pop stores and plain folks living around the corner. But weekly coverage of this small, struggling city has buried the paper in debt.

title: Wounded
description: One of Milan Kundera's saddest and funniest stories recounts the troubles of Edward, a teacher courting a pious girl in a little town in Communist Czechoslovakia. When the girl refuses his overtures in the name of God, he makes a big show of his spirituality. Spotted by a colleague as he is crossing himself ostentatiously before a roadside crucifix, he is called in to the directress's office and required to explain himself. In order to hold onto his job, he confesses his error. I know, he says in essence, that God doesn't exist, but I can't help believing in Him. The directress takes pity on him and proposes re-education classes. But the amorous adventure is cut short, and Edward, who takes nothing and no one seriously, ''occasionally sits in church and looks thoughtfully at the cupola.''

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column in the Real Estate section today, about a house on East 65th Street in Manhattan once occupied by Franklin D. Roosevelt and his family, misstates the office to which he was appointed in 1913. He was named Assistant Secretary of the Navy, not Secretary. The article also misidentifies the vacation place where he was stricken with polio. It was in Canada, not Maine.

title: Rolling And Tucking Wraps, The Sandwich of the Moment
description: THE sandwich of the moment is the wrap. The idea, which originated in California and has taken root in the East, is to spread a combination of ingredients, moistened with dressing, on some kind of pliable flatbread like a Mexican flour tortilla, Middle Eastern peasant bread, Indian nan or even the rice-flour wrappers used for Vietnamese summer rolls. Tuck in the ends, roll it up and you have a wrap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURI, CHARLES S.
description: TURI-Charles S., Born in 1916 in Szolnok, Hungary. Son of Kalman and Francesca Turi. Graduate of Pasman University with a Doctorate in Law. He left Hungary in 1939 with his brother George to avoid the Holocaust. During World War II, he served in the American Army. Upon his return to Hungary in 1945, he met his wife Ava and was married in 1946. In 1947 he formed the Charles Turi Jewelry Company, a manufacturer of fine jewelry that supplied the premier American retailers with European fashion and quality throughout his tenure. His company continues to operate successfully to this date. He is survived by his sons, George and Andrew, their wives, Susan and Judith, and grandchildren: Beth, Michael, Karen, Nicholas and Caitlin. His humanity, grace and spirit enriched all of his family and many dear friends. He will be missed by all. Service Sunday 11:00 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Tyrolean Razzle-Dazzle
description: OSWALD von WOLKENSTEIN, knight errant, adventurer and troubadour, rode these trails countless times 500 years ago, and now, like some vision from the past, a cavalcade of horses emerges from the dawn mists, wending its way up the steep mountainside above Trostburg, the medieval castle where the South Tyrol's most celebrated native poet was born in 1377. title: Borderless

This is a dose of the new -- virtual -- American dream. For us, the promised land is no longer America; cyberspace is the promised land, and America beckons as the gateway. The United States, as the maestro of cyberspace and its attendant multimedia and computer businesses, has rejuvenated its image of opening up the great frontier: a place where everyone has a shot at freedom and success. For many Japanese, especially the young, this marks quite a turnaround, since the image of a pioneering, confident America collapsed in the 1980's.

Barnspace Productions can be reached after many a left and right turn off Route 684, but it is a destination for which many dancers, musicians and actors are grateful. Iris Salomon said she founded Barnspace in 1985 after dancing for many years in Europe and Manhattan and then moving to Westchester to raise a family. The name derives from a large barn on the property which she and her husband, Ralph, own here. The nonprofit organization allows professional performers to collaborate and develop new works under a sky-lighted roof with ample space for experimentation. No one single art form is favored in the group's mission statement, but its most thriving product is modern dance.

While finding Ms. Tracy's essay very entertaining, I caught myself wondering if we walk on the same planet. I have mapped out various two-and-a-half to three-mile routes, and none require more than my cursory attentiveness in order to avoid tree roots, petunias (prize or otherwise), bicycles etc. Although I often prefer to walk on the side of the roadway to avoid curbs and uneven sidewalks, walking on the sidewalks is not a major obstacle, since every street on my ''routes'' has them.

title: Oporto
description: Oporto, Portugal's second-largest city and the capital of its port wine industry, is in the middle of a major restoration of its historic heart. The 1755 earthquake that heavily damaged Lisbon spared Oporto (known as Porto by the Portuguese). With many streets unchanged since the Middle Ages and an endless variety of tiles (azulejos) and wrought-iron balconies decorating its buildings, this city along the Douro River has a remarkably unspoiled assortment of architecture.

title: Off-Road Vehicle Ban Angers Enthusiasts
description: A BAN on off-road vehicles on public land is upsetting enthusiasts in East Hampton. The town says it is mirroring a state law that bans the vehicles from all state land.

title: Testing Quality of Pool Water
description: LAST week this column featured an introduction to the circulation and filtration system in swimming pools. These systems are designed to recycle the pool water so it can be filter out the dirt and debris and make the water clearer. Water that is clear and transparent can be deceptive, however. Even though it looks clean, it may still harbor germs and algae. To remove these contaminants you need to treat the water with disinfectants.

But for all the apparent sprawl of 115 paintings and sculptures chosen by this year's judge, Cora Rosevear, a curator at the Museum of Modern Art, the show maintains a certain coherence. And despite the relatively conservative bent of most of the artists, it never gets routine.

title: What You Never Knew You Needed
description: WHEN I took Economics 101, a test question asked, ''What makes for a successful business?'' If you said giving customers what they want, you might scrape by with a B. But for an A, you had to add: offering things people they never knew they needed. Think Barbie and Big Macs, rap music and all-terrain vehicles. In New York, this precept guides enterprises opened by immigrants, who have an instinct for filling wants longtime residents didn't realize they had.

The 20-year-old Kuerten is the lowest-ranked finalist in French Open history and could become the event's first unseeded champion since Sweden's Mats Wilander, then just 17, won in 1982.

title: Zaire's Fall Jolts Neighboring Angola's Frail Peace
description: In an important spillover effect of the war in Zaire, Government troops in neighboring Angola have attacked territory controlled by their longtime rebel enemies, who lost their most important backer when Mobutu Sese Seko, the Zairian dictator, was defeated.

title: The Irish Famine and the English
description: The role of the English Government in the potato famine that ravaged Ireland in the 1840's is still a raw and divisive issue in Ireland, where many people hold England directly responsible for the tragedy. Last weekend, at a ceremony commemorating the 150th anniversary of the famine, the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, went as far as any English leader ever has in expressing his regret at his country's role.

title: Dynasties Just Aren't What They Used to Be
description: Dynasties in sports, unlike political dynasties, end when they go bad. This is the reason we feel so free to boost them early. We never get stuck with an athletic Marcos or a Mobutu after they've stopped entertaining us. It's risk-free to say that Tiger Woods will be the champion of his sport forever, as we once predicted for Mike Tyson. If we're wrong, they'll be gone, and their replacements won't execute us.

title: Hoboken Proposes A Ballfield On a Pier
description: Little Leaguers who hit the ball out of the park being proposed for Hoboken, N.J., would have the satisfaction of having their home run splash into the Hudson River. Hoboken officials have proposed building a 2,400-seat stadium and a baseball museum on a pier owned by the city, which was the site of the first organized game of baseball under formal rules, in 1846.

title: Human
description: Reading an obituary for the British cricket star Denis Compton in an American newspaper this spring, I felt my excitement growing. Compton's obit took me back to my own childhood in Japan at the end of World War II. Growing up in a valley surrounded by a forest on one of the Japanese islands, I had never heard of cricket. Even now, half a century later, hockey is not a sport the Japanese have taken to, though perhaps it is not as unfamiliar as sumo in the West. But as I read about this hero in a sport I hardly knew anything about, I felt as though an emaciated Japanese youth were also there, sitting in the stands.

title: Just Another Meal in Paradise
description: The author called it a journey ''without a hint of redeeming purpose.'' A few years ago, in a 1965 Mustang convertible, Mr. Stevens, accompanied by an ex-model, his weight-lifting pal Rachel (Rat) Kelly, embarked on a simple quest: eat in all 29 Michelin three-star restaurants in Europe at the time on consecutive days. One was the Louis XV in Monte Carlo, which chef Alain Ducasse had rapidly steered to three stars. This spring, however, after giving three stars to Mr. Ducasse's new restaurant in Paris, Alain Ducasse, Michelin dropped Louis XV to two stars, meaning no chef has yet to be honored with six stars at once.

title: Unembarrassable
description: ''I'm as puzzled as everyone else over here about the American habit of seeking advice on every aspect of one's private life. In England, we thrive on our own inhibitions; they're all we can truly call our own. Among the English, it's considered self-pitying to air difficulties, but Americans are unembarrassable. They'll invite a camera crew into their toilet out of a general feeling of openness. Everyone in America is a prima donna -- it's like Kafka's Great Nature Theater of Oklahoma, where everyone can be an artist. In America, everyone can be a celebrity.

What happened to us and why had we been rejected by the most selective college of all? As Billy Smith, writer and rugby player, pointed out, the Electoral College had admitted George Bush, Yale '48, and then Bill Clinton, Georgetown, '68. Wasn't a generation missing?

title: Push Has Come to Shove

Ernest Hemingway's coinage in his 1932 book ''Death in the Afternoon'' was ''The whole end of the bullfight was the final sword thrust, the actual encounter between the man and the animal, what the Spanish call the moment of truth.'' In truth, the Spanish call it la hora de la verdad, ''the hour of truth,'' but Hemingway's translation was an improvement on the Spanish phrase. (Although his famously spare prose could have spared the ''whole'' in ''the whole end.'')

title: A Garden Shows Why 'Iris' Means Rainbow
description: The bearded irises are about at their peak at the Presby Memorial Iris Gardens in Upper Montclair, N.J., and so are the Siberian irises, which stand behind their fancier cousins in a gorgeous sea of deep, deep blue violet. So maybe you missed Iris tectorum, which started blooming in mid-May, spreading out its violet petals like the spokes of a wheel. Don't worry, there are more to come. The beardless Louisianas are just beginning to open their wide, flat petals, which droop at the end. Then come the two- to six-foot spurias, narrow-petaled types that make terrific cut flowers. Then the Japanese irises, as flat as plates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOTLAND, CONSTANCE HEDDEN
description: SCHOTLAND-Constance Hedden. Age 91. A retired teacher, died June 6, at her home in Chester, NJ. The widow of Dr. Joseph H. Schotland and the daughter of the late Charles Stuart and Amelia Schaeffer Hedden, was born in Newark, NJ. She was graduated from Barringer High School, Dennison University, and received her M.A. in English from Montclair State Teachers College. Her teaching included English in West Side High School and adult classes in Barringer Evening High, North Newark Adult School, YWCA Adult and West Side Adult School. She retired in 1947. After resigning from teaching, she contiuned her community activities, serving on the boards of the Essex County College Woman's Club, the Vailsburg Community Council, the New Jersey League of Nursing and the Public Health Division of the National League of Nursing. She was President of the Newark Visiting Nurse Association Board and was appointed to the Newark Board of Education. After moving to Chester in 1959, she was active on the Board of V.N.A. of Morristown, the Welkind Auxiliary of Chester, and the Long Valley Woman's Club. She is survived by her sister-inlaw, Mrs. Stuart (Mabel) Hedden of Walnut Creek, CA; three grandnephews and a grandniece; and eleven great-grandnieces and great-grandnephews. Also surviving are her stepchildren, Mrs. Seymour (Joan) Schenkel of West Caldwell, NJ, Dr. Richard Schotland of Tucson, AZ, and Dr. Donald Schotland of Wynnewood, PA, and their children and families including ten great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband, Joseph H. Schotland, her brothers Edgar and Stuart Hedden, and a niece, Dr. Margot H. Woodard. At Mrs. Schotland's request, there will be no formal funeral services.

title: How The World Sees Us
description: Nations, like movie stars, have their moments. The crumbling of the Berlin wall in 1989 marked the beginning of America's ascendancy to a new level of world domination. No traveler can miss the evidence abroad. In music, television and movies, America's influence is approaching what advertising people call ''market saturation.'' The emblems of American mass culture have infiltrated the remotest outposts: the Coca-Cola logo is on street corners from Kazakhstan to Bora-Bora; CNN emanates from television sets in more than 200 countries; there are more 7-Eleven stores in Japan than in the United States. Our technology -- computerized weapons systems, medical scanners, the Internet -- sets the standard to which developing countries aspire. Even our teeth, gleaming, beveled, orthodontized into orderly white rows, are the envy of the world.

One woman displayed her elaborate tattoos through the veiled back of her 1950's cocktail dress. Another woman had her feet painted in henna, using a design that is traditional in India and that fades in about a month. Some people recalled the flower children of the 60's, while others paired African hairstyles with street-smart designer T-shirts. And some people championed experimental styles and hair in a rainbow of colors, far removed from the sanitized world of minimalism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAZZERO, ROBERT W.
description: DeLAZZERO-Robert W. Chairman of the Board of Port Morris Tile & Marble Corp, New York has passed away on May 29, 1997 in his home at the age of 81. Mr. DeLazzero was past President of the National Terrazzo and Mosaic Association of America. In 1991 he won the Charles G. Witt Memorial Award which is the most prestigious honor in the Terrazzo Industry. Servicing the Greater New York Area for over 90 years, Port Morris is one of the oldest and largest tile, marble and terrazzo contractors. Mr. DeLazzero led the firm for over 30 years, and his legacy is that Port Morris continues to install many of the major projects in New York. Mr. DeLazzero built the largest terrazzo map of its kind for the New York State Pavilion of the 1964-65 World's Fair. During the construction of the World Trade Center, Mr. DeLazzero together with the Commissioners and Director of the WTC, went on a fact-finding mission to the Far East, as a consultant for future trade centers. It was at this time that he named the famous restaurant ''Windows on the World'' as stated in the May 31, 1976 issue of New York Magazine. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Sime DeLazzero; his son, Vincent Paul DeLazzero, II, currently President of the firm; daughters Margery Arnheim and Steffany Belcher; a brother Giacomo DeLazzero; two sisters Norma Fraser and Dora Fox and grandchildren and great grandchildren. Contributions can be made to the Muscular Dystrophy Association, in memory of his two beloved grandsons Christopher and Jason Haumann.

Every so often, using a small used wagon, she and a few friends would clear the rubbish from around the front of their building near 29th Street. But the flotsam would fetch up again.

title: Pope's Visit Underlines New Church In Poland
description: Last Sunday, Magda Gorska, 28, went, as is her custom, with her husband and two young children to one of the eight Masses at St. Ladislaus, her local Roman Catholic church in one of this city's middle-class suburbs. The regular congregation, which filled the church to overflowing, included many young families like the Gorskas, as well as the middle aged and elderly.

title: howdydoody.com
description: Howdy Doody and Buffalo Bob were the first guys to invade my living room and sell me products back in the 1950's, when I shared my childhood with television's. But they kept their distance. However hard they pushed their sponsor -- Buster Brown shoes? Bosco? Cream of Wheat? -- they never sought out their young fans off camera for a follow-up sales chat. Had Howdy been as intrusive as the Fuller Brush man, he would have been collared on a morals charge, puppet or not.

title: Pentagon Shifts Its Caribbean Command to Aid in Drug Fight
description: In an effort to enhance drug interdiction efforts along the smuggling routes increasingly favored by traffickers, the Pentagon has transferred jurisdiction over the Caribbean Sea and the island nations and territories in it from the Atlantic Command to the military authority currently responsible for South and Central America.

title: Living in the Shadow of a Famous Song
description: LORI LIEBERMAN HAS recorded the song ''Killing Me Softly'' twice, and each time she has seen it become a big hit -- for somebody else.

title: State Art Grants Return After a Year's Hibernation
description: New Jersey artists weren't happy last year when the state Council of the Arts put on hold a program that had provided fellowship money for more than 20 years.

title: Assignment: Times Square
description: Your Times Square issue was terrific. I have seen the area go through a lot of change recently -- ''for the better,'' most people would say, I guess. But I do miss some of the ''character'' that is disappearing as it is being redeveloped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISINGER, ESTHER (NEE SILVERMAN)
description: WEISINGER-Esther (nee Silverman) of Boynton Beach, FL, on June 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Arthur S. Weisinger. Devoted mother of Dr. Martin and Roberta Weisinger and Dr. Barbara Weisinger. Loving grandmother of Dr. Andrew, Barbara and Lynn Weisinger. Funeral services were held on Friday June 6, 1997, in the Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. For further information contact Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, NJ.

title: Brooklyn Birthdays Merit a Coronation
description: THIS year the Brooklyn Museum of Art turns 175 years old and its present building turns 100. The Cyclone roller coaster turns 70 and the Welcome Back to Brooklyn Festival turns 15.

title: Hellzapoppin', Daddy-o: Mythic Men Behaving Badly
description: IS the high life back or what? You bet your cruise-missile cigar and jet-fuel martini it is. But though skinny ties and lounge music may yet endure, some things have surely changed -- including the ways men will be boys.

title: American Crafts, Cause and Effect
description: SOMETIMES AN ART EXHIBITION CAN make less look like more without leaving the viewer feeling shortchanged. This is the unusual achievement of ''Inspiring Reform: Boston's Arts and Crafts Movement,'' a deftly presented, thought-provoking show at the Davis Museum and Cultural Center at Wellesley College.

title: Isadore Rossman, 84; Doctor Stressed Home Care
description: Dr. Isadore Rossman, a physician who specialized in geriatrics and pressed the idea in the 1940's that home care was more effective than hospital care for many patients, died on Tuesday at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Sports Books in Brief
description: THE BILL JAMES GUIDE

title: Heather Smith, John Carino
description: Heather Cherrington Smith, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Hiram Smith Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Karsten Carino, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John M. Carino, also of Greenwich. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena in Riverside, Conn.

title: Best Pitchers in the A.L. Could Miss All This Interleague Excitement
description: Anticipation and excitement could be generated by interleague play, which begins Thursday. But something is lost when a team is confronted with a decision to bypass its best pitcher in one of the games, simply because of the baseball leagues' differences in the rules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURAND, CELESTIN A. III
description: DURAND-Celestin A. III. Passed away peacefully June 3, 1997 at home with his usual faith, courage, tenacity and sense of humor. Celestin touched the lives of everyone he met. He was greatly loved and admired and his great joy and love of life will be sorely missed. A member of the New York Stock Exchange since 1963. He founded and managed Durand & Cullen a specialist firm in 1966. In 1972 they merged with Beachamp & Co. In 1989 while managing partner, the firm was sold to Merrill Lynch. He remained with Merrill Lynch as Vice President of their newly formed Specialist Division for three years until his retirement in 1992. A lifetime resident of Garden City, NY, he retired to Miami, Florida. There, he enjoyed the things in life which gave him his greatest pleasures, his dog Clancy, golf, travel and horses. He bred and raced Thoroughbred horses as a partner in Royal Lines Stable. He was a member of the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Assoc and the California Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Assoc. Since 1993 he served on the Board of Directors of World Fuel Services, a listed Company based in Miami since 1994. He also served on the Board of Directors of The Jockey Club Condominium Assoc, Phase I. He was the beloved husband and best friend of Lin, the loving father of C.A., Michael and Christopher, doting grandfather of eight, the big brother of John, DeeDee and Joanne. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City, 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. Monday. Interment Tuesday, Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Family suggests donations to St. Rose of Lima Parish, 415 E. 105th St, Miami Shores, FL 33138 or St. Jude's Children's Research, P.O. Box 50, Memphis, TN 38101. His generosity of spirit and willingness to be kind to everyone, will be remembered by all who knew him. ''Time flies, suns rise and shadows fall let it pass by love regins forever overall.''

title: Fighting Over an 1850 Carriage House With an Ugly Face
description: Nicholas Guzzone, a developer, and the Cobble Hill Association agree on one thing; the facade of 193 Congress Street is ugly.

title: Pricing the Convenience of A.T.M.'s
description: ''Is Your A.T.M. Ripping You Off?'' by David J. Morrow (May 4) discussed the fees assessed to withdraw cash from the nation's automated teller machines. The article drew varied responses from readers.

title: Turning the Tables on the Generals
description: Nothing exposed the yawning generation gap in today's military better than Defense Secretary's William Cohen's pardon last week of Gen. Joseph Ralston for his adulterous affair with a civilian woman 13 years ago.

title: Adultery Is Just One Land Mine for Pentagon Chief
description: The call was to Kazakstan, and Defense Secretary William S. Cohen picked up the telephone with what aides recalled was a remarkable sense of calm, given the embarrassing question he was being compelled to ask.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, ROBERT L.
description: COOPER - Robert L. Having shared years of glorious yesterdays, I only wish we could share in all of tomorrow's promises. Miss you still; love you always. Jordan

title: Balanchine vs. Ashton
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitened
description: One of the great unsolved mysteries of American culture is the devotion Americans have for their teeth. Any European who can suppress a twinge of envy will admit to the blinding beauty of the teeth he encounters in the New World. Nowhere else on the face of the earth will he find so many enchantingly white and straight teeth. Looking at a smiling set of such teeth is like looking at a freshly whitewashed picket fence.

title: Both Horses Validate Triple Crown
description: IT is 19 years, and counting, since any thoroughbred won the Triple Crown. We are once again reminded why it has been this long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICA, MARISSA ANN
description: PICA-Marissa Ann, Assistant Director of Critical Care Nursing at The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died of breast cancer on June 5, 1997. Born in Waterbury, CT., she was 36 years old. Marissa graduated from Mount St. Mary's College, Newburgh, NY, in May 1983, cum laude, with a B.S. in Nursing and received her Masters of Science in Nursing from Hunter Bellevue Graduate School with a 4.0 GPA. She began her elite nursing career in June, 1983 at The NY HospitalCornell Medical Center and in 1992 she was promoted to Assistant Director of Critical Care Nursing. Marissa chaired the Major Modernization Critical Care Multi-Disciplinary Task Force for the move into the newly constructed pavilion at The New York Hospital. She was President of the NYC Chapter of AACN from 1995 to 1996, during which time she presented ''The Role of Patient Care Technician'' at The National Teaching Institute Critical Care Conference. As a recognized leader in the field of critical care nuring, Marissa was a guest speaker at various conferences and hospitals. She was named in Who's Who in American Nursing, 1996-1997. As a member of Mensa, Marissa typified the Society's own description of a member as ''someone with a good sense of humor who likes to talk!'' The tremendous respect, admiration and love of her peers, colleagues and especially family, will always be one of Marissa's greatest legacies. She is survived by her mother Jennie Pica of Waterbury, CT. and father Vincent Pica of Southbury, CT. and sisters Barbara Gervase-Claffey of NYC and Pattie Pica-Fitzgerald of Santa Monica, CA, as well as many beloved and close friends. Friends may call at Maiorano Funeral Home at 95 Willow St, Waterbury, CT, Sunday, June 8, 3-8PM. A mass will be celebrated at Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Monday, June 9th. at 9:00AM.

title: Anxiety And Hope Precedes Letdown
description: They had stood abreast throughout the Triple Crown, from Louisville to Baltimore and then to New York. And as the horses charged down the stretch in yesterday's Belmont Stakes, the men behind the scenes with Silver Charm -- his exercise rider, groom and hot walker -- watched the race together, rooting for their colt.

title: Horns and Strings From Earlier Times
description: THE 15th annual Connecticut Early Music Festival is a moveable feast, the 10 concert events (as well as 3 free public lectures) taking place at sites in New London, Niantic, Noank, Mystic and Waterford. The unifying element is the use of antique instruments or their replicas in performance.

title: The Longest Hitter Meets the Longest Course
description: As the longest course in United States Open history at 7,213 yards, Congressional is a brute that, theoretically, should favor golf's longest hitter, Tiger Woods.

title: Earth to Clarence: It's a Different Life
description: EVERY time a bell rings in Bedford Falls, or anywhere, another soul is saved; another angel is winged, according to Frank Capra's dubiously titled ''It's a Wonderful Life.'' If that film still flourishes after 51 years, it's because the movie has everything to do with the way of whimsy and nothing to do with the way of the world.

title: Deep in the Russian Soul, a Lethal Darkness
description: THERE are few more shocking trips one can take in Russia than to the general wards of a major hospital. Despite the well-publicized problems of the Russian health care system, it is not the hospitals themselves, or their staffs, that give alarm: it is almost always the age of the patients and their condition.

title: Riding a Different Trail To the Winners' Circle
description: Touch Gold's victory in yesterday's Belmont Stakes spoiled the Triple Crown bid of Silver Charm, but it announced the arrival of a special colt who has overcome adversity, injury and inexperience to stand atop the racing world.

title: Gangsta vs. Metal in Cairo
description: At an underground club in the heart of the city, Arab and black African kids in impeccable gangsta gear gyrate to the sound of The Notorious B.I.G. and Tupac Shakur. Boys with boxer shorts riding up over their camouflage pants eye the few women on the dance floor. They favor Chicago Bulls jerseys and have a problem with heavy metal, which is in heated competition with rap for the hearts and wallets of Egyptian club kids. ''Lots of Cairo kids listen to metal and thrash,'' one 19-year-old says dismissively, after greeting a visitor with a complicated handshake. ''They have long hair and wear tight pants and cowboy boots. They hate anyone from the hip-hop scene.'' both factions want their MTV, but they are skeptical about the United States. ''America is a dreamland for youth, but you have too many criminals,'' says a 23-year-old Metallica fan. ''I feel safer in Egypt.'' Richard McGill Murphy

title: In Honor Of the Fund That Loves New York
description: Ford, Carnegie, Mellon and Rockefeller are respectable enough names in the realm of foundations, but in the minds of most people concerned with historic preservation, city planning and the quality of life in New York City, they don't hold a candle to Kaplan. The J. M. Kaplan Fund, with assets of roughly $120 million -- an amount that the Ford Foundation would consider a rounding error -- has for years been the first stop for those seeking grants to save buildings, support cultural institutions, restore landmarks and finding innovative ways of creating housing in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARRENO, FREDERICA (BUCHER)
description: PARRENO-Frederica (Bucher). In Watch Hill, RI, June 6, 1997. Wife of the late Albert J. Parreno of Watch Hill, RI and Del Ray Beach, FL. Sister of Mrs. Roger Berger of Portsmouth, RI. Aunt of Frederick W. Bucher and Barbara B. Gallagher and sister-in-law of Elizabeth Bucher. Funeral service will be held at the convenience of the family. There are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Watch Hill Improvement Society, P.O. Box 1451, Westerly, RI 02891. For information, Buckler-Johnston Funeral Home, 121 Main Street, Westerly.

title: That Widow Proves Again That She Is Truly Merry
description: Just to prove that it is not suffering from hardening of the toe shoes, American Ballet Theater has come up with an exuberant sleeper in ''The Merry Widow.'' Ronald Hynd's choreographed version of Franz Lehar's operetta is a goulash of a ballet, filled with painted-on mustaches, enough fake folk dances to cause a war in the Balkans and more astute choreography than greets the eye under all the glittering sets and costumes.

title: A Cemetery In Queens Hit By Vandals
description: Vandals broke into two mausoleums at a Jewish cemetery in Queens early yesterday, setting fire to the remains of a body, in what the authorities described as possibly an anti-Semitic incident.

title: For Taiwan Immigrant, Success Brings Trouble on Political Donations
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATTNER, DAVID SAMUEL
description: RATTNER-David Samuel. On June 6, 1997. Graduate of Juilliard School of Music and Columbia University. He devoted his professional life to teaching and music education throughout the NYC public school system and conducted The All City Orchestra and The Teachers' Orchestra. His knowledge, warmth, thoughtfulness and integrity will be remembered with great affection by all who knew him. Dear and beloved husband of Henriette. Loving father of Nina Gelbart and father-in-law of Bill Gelbart. Cherished grandfather of Matthew and Eva. Devoted brother of Nat and brother-in-law of Miriam. Adored uncle and great uncle. Services Monday, 12 noon at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: David Johnston, 76, Commodities Trader
description: David T. Johnston, a commodities trader and executive who served two terms as chairman of the Commodity Exchange in New York, died May 26 at the Courtland Gardens Health Center in Stamford, Conn.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CANDIDATES LOVE A PARADE -- With an important segment of the electorate lining Fifth Avenue, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger marched in the Puerto Rican Day parade. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMELTZ, RABBI BENJAMIN
description: SCHMELTZ-Rabbi Benjamin. Israel has lost a Torah Crown. Friends and members of the Murray Hill Synagogue have suffered a wound to all our hearts. We have lost our beloved Rabbi. More than a friend, he was like a brother, a son, or a favorite uncle to all of us. The Jewish people have lost one of its potentially greatest leaders. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his entire family. May we all be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Murray Hill Synagogue

description: For Justin Leonard, it was a great way to prepare for this week's United States Open.

title: Treasury's Schedule of Auctions Is Limited to Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: G.O.P. LAWMAKERS WANT $16 BILLION FOR HEALTH PLAN
description: House Republicans offered a $16 billion plan to provide health care for uninsured children today, but they said they could not completely fulfill their promise to set aside $1.5 billion to help low-income elderly people pay health insurance premiums.

title: Cultural Clashes, Abroad or at Home
description: EXILES

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about placing advertisements on New York transit Metrocards misidentified a sporting event that is under consideration for such a promotion. It is the United States Open tennis tournament, not a golf tournament.

title: A Great Wall, Alas, of T-Shirts and Baseball Caps
description: At the foot of the Great Wall of China stands a statue of a man whose image is known around the world. It is Colonel Sanders, impeccable in white suit and goatee, holding a jumbo tub of Kentucky Fried Chicken.

title: That Hot Day 33 Years Ago, When Ken Venturi's Life Opened
description: TO most people, he's a television face and voice now, the CBS golf analyst, but when Ken Venturi returns to Congressional near Washington for the festivities surrounding this week's United States Open, he'll suddenly be Ken Venturi the golfer again, the golfer who won the 1964 United States Open there.

title: Glimpses on the Web At the Fall TV Season
description: Television fans who just cannot wait for the fall prime-time programs can put away their remote control and pick up their mouse to find out what what each of the networks hopes will be must-see TV. Each broadcast network -- CBS, ABC, NBC, Fox, UPN and WB -- have set up shop on the World Wide Web to promote the returning shows and the 37 new ones coming in the next television season.

title: Thomas B. Adams Dies at 86; Descendant of Two Presidents
description: Thomas Boylston Adams, a descendant of Presidents John Adams and John Quincy Adams who was a corporate executive, a writer and administrator in the field of history and an opponent of the Vietnam War, died on Wednesday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 86.

title: D. H. Fender, 78; Studied Sight and Brain
description: Dr. Derek Henry Fender of the California Institute of Technology, a biologist who studied eyesight and the functioning of the brain, died on May 28 at his home in Altadena, Calif. He was 78.

title: Texaco Picks BBDO For Product Work
description: Texaco Inc. has shifted the responsibilities for product and retail advertising in the United States, with billings estimated at $30 million to $40 million, to BBDO Worldwide in New York from Bates USA in New York and Houston. The decision was described on Friday by executives familiar with Texaco's plans who spoke on condition of anonymity.

title: Barclay G. Jones, 72, an Expert On Earthquakes' Consequences
description: Barclay G. Jones, an expert on the social and economic consequences of earthquakes, died on May 26 at Cayuga Medical Center in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 72 and lived in Ithaca.

title: Judge to Decide on Runoff
description: The burden will be on lawyers for Mayor Bret Schundler to persuade Judge Maurice J. Gallipoli of Superior Court today not to order a runoff election. Last week, another Superior Court judge, Arthur D'Italia, struck seven votes from Mr. Schundler's total in the May 13 election, erasing the 5.5-vote majority he needed to win on the first ballot. But he stopped short of ordering a runoff against the runner-up, Jerramiah T. Healy.

title: Joseph Kennedy Puts List Of His Regrets on Display
description: After hours of chatter and complaints that the state Democratic Party's issues convention was dragging on too long, silence enveloped the crowded hall. Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, the charismatic inheritor of the state's most famous political name, the man who everyone had thought would have a lock on his party's nomination for governor in 1998, was at the lectern. And his voice was breaking.

title: The First Stone
description: By forgiving a top Air Force general his past adultery, Secretary of Defense William Cohen raised a storm about unequal treatment of officers who have sinned. But the important question is a different one: whether the sin, without more, should be treated as a crime at all.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GREGG, DR. DOROTHY (MRS. PAUL SCOTT)
description: GREGG-Dr. Dorothy (Mrs. Paul Scott). Wednesday, June 11, 1997, 6 PM. In lieu of flowers, you may wish to make a contribution in memory of Dorothy to one of the following non-profit institutions: New York Art Ensemble, Inc.; Women In Research & Education Institute; NYC Radio; Burned Churches Project, National Council of Churches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMENY, RAE
description: KAMENY-Rae. Died peacefully in her 101st year. Survived by her daughter Edna and son Franklin; her son-in-law Ira Lavey and many nieces and nephews.

title: Banning Cigarette Billboards
description: Cigarette advertising on billboards would be banned under a bill scheduled for a hearing today before the Assembly Transportation and Communications Committee. The billboard industry already has voluntary standards against cigarette advertising near schools and churches, but one of the bill's sponsors, Carol J. Murphy, Republican of Morris Plains, said that was not enough. ''These ads are aimed at young people, and they drive,'' she said.

title: Of Body And Soul
description: I used to believe that there were two Islamic fundamentalist countries that could resist the tug and pull of globalization: One was Iran, because it had oil, and the other was Sudan, because it had nothing. Iran seemed to have the resources to make itself an exception to the rules and Sudan was so utterly devoid of resources, it didn't seem to matter if it was in the game or not.

title: Farewell to a Railroad Tower
description: Early in this century, New Jersey had more than 100 railroad towers where crews would control train traffic by looking out over the tracks. These days, switching is mainly done by central computers, and only a half-dozen towers remain. ''You don't see the results of your work go by the window anymore,'' Bill Chaplik, an operations manager for Amtrak, said. ''Now we watch little lights blink on a screen.''

title: On Adultery Issue, Many Aren't Ready To Cast First Stone
description: Faye Black, a secretary in Orange, Tex., who has been married four times, knows firsthand the outrage of the scorned wife. Husbands 2 and 3 both cheated on her, the former with so many women, she said, it was as if he was working his way down the alphabet.

title: Machine Tool Orders Up 7.7% in April
description: Orders for machine tools rose 7.7 percent in April from the month before, posting the fourth monthly increase in a five-month period, according to an industry survey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROSE
description: SCHWARTZ-Rose, 96. Beloved wife of the late Harry; devoted mother of Janet; cherished Nana of Lisa and Julie. Died June 7, 1997. Also survived by loving sonin-law Myron Fine and children Jeri, Marti, and Leslie; also grandchild Gregory. She will be greatly missed. The family will observe shiva through Friday, June 13.

title: People
description: * Megan Kent was named managing partner and planning director at TBWA Chiat/Day, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group. She assumes duties from Lorraine Ketch and Steve Le Neveu, who had been managing partners and executive directors for account planning; they left to join Leap Partnership/Los Angeles, Santa Monica, Calif., a unit of Leap Group, as creative partners. Ms. Kent had been account planning group head at Fallon McElligott, Minneapolis.

title: Stockton Flings Jazz Into Tie With the Bulls
description: There are very few moments when Utah's private John Stockton lets anyone see what is churning inside of him. And yet, for once, he was as transparent as an aquarium. You could see the excitement swimming inside him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANTROW, JOSEPH
description: KANTROW-Joseph. On June 7, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Esta and the late Julia. Adored father of Deborah Miller and Ellen Kantrow; cherished grandfather of Marc, Ronna and Diane; greatgrandfather of Jesse. Services Monday, 12 noon, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer M.C., Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the United Nations decolonization committee referred to the British colony of Gibraltar incorrectly. It is a peninsula, not an island.

title: Jones Starts at Top, And Aims to Stay
description: For Steve Jones, the memory of his greatest moment in golf remains vivid.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: Morris Stahl had tried for years to get his wife, Phyllis, to stop smoking. Hiding her cigarettes did no good. Nicotine patches couldn't help her overcome a three-pack-a-day habit. But Mr. Stahl was worried about her health. So he bought space on a billboard near their Pittsburgh home. The message: "Phyllis J. Stahl  Stop Your Smoking! We love you. From your family and friends." When the couple drove by the billboard, Mr. Stahl pointed it out to his wife. "She said, 'God, are you crazy?' She was upset, but that was the reaction I wanted." Did it work? "A lot of my friends asked me where I slept last night," Mr. Stahl said. His reply, "Well, under the billboard."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, IRVING R.
description: STONE-Irving R. Retired Executive Vice President and Treasurer of Knott Hotels Corp. Died 6/7/97, one week before his 87th birthday. Vinnie survived his wife of 55 years, Elsie, who died in Easton, MD, on 1/24/97. The Stones lived in Forest Hills and Shelter Island, NY. Survived by his stepson Warren J. McCarron. Service is private.

title: Hold That Curtain!
description: To the Editor:

title: Owner's Faith Is Rewarded
description: Mormons everywhere will probably forgive Larry Miller, owner of the Utah Jazz, for fudging the rules. Miller did not attend Game 1 of the National Basketball Association finals a week ago in Chicago because, in following his religion, he does not watch sports on Sunday.

title: Belmont Draws Strong Ratings
description: Silver Charm's quest for the Triple Crown not only drew more than 70,000 people to Belmont Park on Saturday, but also motivated a lot more people than usual to watch the outcome on television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUFRIN, HELEN
description: SUFRIN-Helen. Beloved wife of Oscar; dear mother of Dr. Gerald and Dr. Janice Sufrin and Leslie and Roberta Sufrin; loving grandmother of Lisa, Peter, Carolyn, Michelle and Douglas. Services today, 2:30 PM, at Mt. Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Moving to Invest $1 Billion in Comcast

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOLBERT, JOHN P.
description: TOLBERT-John P., died on June 5, 1997. Loving husband of Elinor, devoted father of Jennifer and Page, beloved brother of Arch and Stokes, adoring and adored grandfather of Christopher. The memory of his intelligence, charm, and wit shall sustain us. Our lives are greater for his, and he will be known to all who know us through our words and deeds. A memorial service will be held Thursday, June 12, at 5 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Avenue, P.O. Box 548, Mongomery, AL. 36101-0548.

title: G.M. and U.A.W. Preparing for Strike At Three Factories
description: After months of skirmishes, the United Automobile Workers union and General Motors are bracing for another showdown over the company's effort to continue shrinking its work force through attrition.

title: Bridge
description: The top-seeded team led by Seymon Deutsch of Laredo, Tex., won an unexpectedly easy victory in the final of the international team trials here on Saturday. He and his teammates, Zia Mahmood of Manhattan, Michael Rosenberg of Tuckahoe, N.Y., Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., and Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Calif., will be one of two teams representing the United States at the world championships in October in Tunisia.

title: Homecoming Is Sentimental For Poland And the Pope
description: When Pope John Paul made his historic trip to this ancient city in 1979, Poland was Communist and Arkadivisz Forgiel was a boy of 8. Now 26 with a child of his own, Mr. Forgiel joined more than a million other Poles today on a vast green meadow for another papal Mass, a now-familiar event that seemed almost like a miracle a generation ago.

title: The Last Word in Celebrity Books
description: Summer beach reading it is not: 40 pages of boilerplate legalese touching on the somber issues of trusts and pro rating of annuities, copyrights and the future owner of a Greek alabaster head of a woman.

title: Internet Changing How Research Centers Work
description: The year is 2050. The place: Earth. The possibilities: a chaotic world at the mercy of warring factions; a world in which sustainable development is mediated by governmental action; a world in which technology has eliminated the threats posed by global warming, population growth and diminished natural resources. Which future is in store and what, if anything, can or should be done about it?

title: Tradition on Trial As New Yorker Rethinks Cartoons
description: Last week, The New Yorker named a cartoon editor for the first time since 1973. The anointed, Robert Mankoff, was chosen because in addition to possessing an edgy, contemporary kind of humor, ''he's a passionate curator of and defender of and promoter of the art of cartooning,'' said the magazine's editor, Tina Brown.

title: Newspaper owners proselytize business sense to their reporters and editors.
description: WHEN it comes to their marketing strategies, newspaper publishers are trying any number of ways to appeal to their readers. But on internal matters, publishers are showing a growing unanimity about marketing of a different kind -- campaigns aimed at getting their reporters and editors to accept the realities of the newspaper business these days.

title: Pristine Russian Far East Sees Its Fate in Gold
description: The basic view from this mountain village hasn't changed for 7,000 years, since a giant reservoir of molten lava crested over to form the mighty peak of Asia's largest and most active volcano. Eagles and falcons dance through the crisp air. Not far away, the world's biggest population of grizzly bears -- shaking off their winter slumber -- forage for salmon as big as dogs.

title: Veteran Troupe Celebrates 'This Is the Army'
description: The soldierly physiques had faded. Furtive glances at name tags brought recognition to time-worn faces thought unforgettable. But for the 45 remaining cast members of Irving Berlin's ''This Is the Army,'' reunited at Sardi's on Friday evening, the musical's acclaimed Broadway opening on on the Fourth of July in 1942 could have been yesterday.

In World War II, he was a Lieutenant Commander in the U.S. Navy in the Atlantic and Pacific. Joining the Foreign Service in 1947, he served in Berlin, Madrid, Dar es Salaam, New Delhi, Kampala and Lagos, where he met and married his wife of 24 years, Janice J. Lyon, also a Foreign Service Officer. He later founded a residential realty firm, MGMB, Inc., in Washington, DC. He is survived by four children, six grandchildren, and a sister, Mildred Millar-Graff of Brooklyn, an authority on Central Park. A memorial service will be held June 12 at 11 AM at the Navy Chapel, 3801 Nebraska Ave. NW, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Colorado Springs Symphony Orchestra, Box 1692, Colorado Springs, CO 80901.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UIHLEIN, HENRY II
description: UIHLEIN-Henry II. Of Lake Placid, NY. Died June 8, 1997, at his winter home in Indian Wells, CA, at the age of 101. He is survived by his wife, Suzanne M. Uihlein, and by his nephews, Robert and August Rohe. Mr. Uihlein was preceded in death by his first wife, Mildred Anthony Uihlein, who died on July 9, 1990. He was a grandson of Henry Uihlein who was a longtime president of the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company early in this century, and was himself a director of the company for several decades until its sale in 1982 to the Stroh Brewing Company. Mr. Uihlein was born in New York City on February 3, 1896, and attended public and private schools there. A promising collegiate career was cut short by tuberculosis and resulted in his spending several years in Lake Placid, NY, where he was restored to health by the altitude and climate. He married Mildred Anthony of South Orange, NJ, on June 10, 1927, and after an extended European honeymoon, they settled in Montclair, NJ, where he founded a real estate corporation. Summers were spent in Lake Placid. In 1933, the Uihleins moved to New York City where Mr. Uihlein attended to his father's affairs until he died in 1939. In 1941, the Uihleins made Lake Placid their permanent residence, purchasing farm land from the Lake Placid Club which became known as Heaven Hill Farm. Over the succeeding decades, Mr. Uihlein developed a blue ribbon pure-breed Jersey cattle herd, a prize maple syrup operation, and a first class seed potato farm. Stock from his Jersey herd consistently took top prizes at American Jersey Club Shows. Several years ago, the Jersey herd was donated to the Miner Institute of Chazy, NY, where they continue breeding under the Heaven Hill name. Also several years ago, the maple syrup and potato operations were donated to the College of Agriculture of Cornell University under which auspices they continue to be operated as demonstration and research facilities (and in the case of the potato operation, as a disease-free source of seed potatos.) In addition to his interests in fishing, hunting, stamp collecting, and skeet shooting, Mr. Uihlein supported the sport of speed skating in Lake Placid by sponsoring a number of contestants and events, thus contributing to to Lake Placid's reputation as a winter sports resort. He was an official timer at the 1932 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid and an active supporter of the 1980 Winter Olympics for which he was made an honorary member. In 1983, he was named to the Lake Placid Hall of Fame. Henry Uihlein also liked classic automobiles and undertook the restoration of 2 1939 DeLage automobiles. These automobiles, one a coupe and the other a convertible, are one of a kind and were the stars of the French Pavillion at the 1939 World's Fair. More recently, they have taken top honors at the Concourse D'Legance at Pebble Beach, CA, and other national competitions. Mr. Uihlein has also been actively involved in philanthropy. In addition to funding the Cornell College of Agriculture gifts noted above, he played a major role in the creation of the Uihlein Mercy Center, a geriatric hospital and home located not far from Heaven Hill Farm in Lake Placid. He also has an administration building named after him at the Eisenhower Medical Center in Palm Desert and has served as an honorary Trustee of the Center. He has also actively supported the work of the Mayo Clinic. He will be missed by his many relatives, friends and all those whose lives he touched during his many years. Services will be held on Saturday, June 14th at 11:00 a.m. at the Uihlein Mercy Center Chapel in Lake Placid, interment to follow at North Elba Cemetery, Lake Placid, NY. Memorials may be made to Cornell University College of Agriculture, Uihlein Mercy Center, Lake Placid, NY, Eisenhower Medical Center, Palm Desert, CA, and the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN. For information, call the Clark Funeral Home in Lake Placid, NY.

description: During Betty Adams's childhood in Memphis, her parents portrayed Jackie Robinson as the paradigm of the qualities she was expected to emulate. Marian Anderson, Ralph Bunche, relatives and neighbors were also employed to teach life lessons, but Robinson always remained special.

title: Hingis in Chase Field
description: Although she lost in the final of the French Open last weekend, MARTINA HINGIS has accumulated enough points to clinch the first berth in the season-ending Chase Championships. The tournament, to be held at Madison Square Garden in November, features the top 16 singles players and top eight doubles teams from the Corel WTA Tour. Hingis made her first appearance there last year, losing to STEFFI GRAF in the final.

title: Oregon Moves Nearer to New Vote on Allowing Assisted Suicide
description: When Oregon enacted the nation's first law permitting doctors to help their terminally ill patients commit suicide, the state was expected to become a national laboratory for a new way of dying.

title: The Next Act for Microsoft
description: For the Microsoft Corporation, money is not a problem, but finding a way to continue its remarkable trajectory of growth certainly is.
