description: World Cup Qualifying

title: Granada May Buy Rest Of Yorkshire Broadcaster
description: Granada Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the shares in Yorkshire-Tyne Tees Holdings Group P.L.C. it does not already own for $:476 million ($779 million). Granada bought 27 percent of Yorkshire-Tyne, a British television broadcaster, last September.

title: Woman Is Arrested In Student's 1996 Death
description: A 20-year-old woman was arrested yesterday in the slaying last year of Curtisha Morning, a student at Riverhead High School, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKBINDER, BLANCHE ROSTOW
description: BOOKBINDER-Blanche Rostow. Died May 11 in Hallandale, FL. She was born in New York and lived in the Oranges before moving to Forida. She was a member of Temples Sharey Tefilo and Israel for 25 years. She taught at Peshine Avenue School in Newark for over 35 years before retiring. Mrs. Bookbinder was Head Counselor for YWHA Camps in PA, a charter member and president of Women's American ORT, East Orange Chapter, a member of the National Council of Jewish Women and ORT in Florida, and was a Co-Chairman of UJA campaign in Florida. She received a citation from the Library of Congress for her work in recording talking books for the blind. Her husband Isidor Jan Bookbinder predeacesed her in 1981. She is survived by her son Kenneth, her daughter-in-law Mary, grandson Noah and her sister Hilda Meyerson, all of whom miss her greatly.

title: Poll: Messinger Has Failed To Get Voters' Attention
description: Nearly two-thirds of New Yorkers do not know enough about Ruth W. Messinger to express an opinion about her, in the latest indication that her bid for Mayor has yet to capture the attention of the public, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: The Counterculture World of the A.B.A.
description: Fiction could not have accounted for the bizarre, amusing, very 1960's nine seasons of the American Basketball Association. In the A.B.A., Freddie Lewis, the most valuable player of the 1975 All-Star Game, won a quarter horse named Tough Julie who dropped dead within three weeks. The Miami Floridians distracted free-throw shooters with bikini-clad ball girls. One team had Morton Downey Jr. as general manager, another had Pat Boone as owner. And Darnell Hillman taught Julius Erving how to groom an Afro for maximum size and aerodynamics.

title: New University Is Suggested
description: New Jersey should consider building a new state university to stem its chronic undergraduate brain drain, a higher education advocate said yesterday.

title: Compelled by Shabazz's Situation, Hundreds Give Blood
description: Half a block from the Harlem boulevard named for her slain husband, Malcolm X, Dr. Betty Shabazz was honored yesterday with something more vital than a street sign: the blood of hundreds of New Yorkers, who gave of themselves for a woman who few of them knew but all admired.

title: Forced Bankruptcy Sought for U S One
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. filed a petition yesterday against the U S One Communications Corporation for involuntary bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the Bankruptcy Code.

title: Judge Faults Leading Law Firm For Not Disclosing Ties to Client
description: A Federal judge has found that a prestigious New York law firm violated procedural rules by failing to disclose properly its representation of both a company in bankruptcy and, in a separate matter, one of the company's largest creditors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, DONALD F.
description: O'ROURKE-Donald F., on June 8, 1997. Beloved son of Helen and the late Joseph. Loving brother of Robert B., Maureen Johnson and the late Linda and Joseph. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Funeral on Wednesday, 8:30AM, from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn. Mass 9:30 AM at St. Brendan's RC Church. Interment in Calverton National Cemetery. Visiting hours are on Tuesday, from 2-5 P.M. and 7-10 P.M.

title: DIGITAL TO SELL PC'S BASED ON ADVANCED MICRO'S CHIPS
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it would start selling personal computers using Advanced Micro Devices Inc.'s K6 microprocessor, at prices about 14 percent less than those of machines based on chips from the Intel Corporation. Sales are to begin later this month. Digital, of Maynard, Mass., is the first major computer maker to commit to using the AMD-K6. The move comes a month after Digital sued Intel, saying the company designed its Pentium processor with technology Digital developed for its flagship Alpha chip. Digital also sells PC's based on Intel chips.

title: Softball's New Cachet Spawns a League of Pros
description: There is no powerful men's league providing support, and no extensive television contract. There are no high-profile collegiate stars to add luster to lineups and no wealthy individuals eager to own franchises.

title: RAYTHEON AGREES TO DELAY OVER TEXAS INSTRUMENTS UNIT
description: The Raytheon Company agreed yesterday to delay its $2.95 billion purchase of Texas Instruments Inc.'s military business until June 30 while the companies resolve Federal antitrust concerns. The two-week extension is intended to give the Justice Department and the company more time to work out details of a settlement over computer chips used in radar systems, people familiar with the talks said. The issue could force a delay in closing the merger until after the target date of June 30, but the companies say they are close to resolving the remaining issues. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., is also planning a larger acquisition of the General Motors Corporation's Hughes Electronics business.

title: Developer Plans Sports Center For $1 Billion In Rockaways
description: A company connected to one of the world's best known development groups, the Reichmann family of Toronto, has proposed building a vast $1 billion entertainment and sports complex, including a hotel and convention center, on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, GLENN STUART
description: BERMAN-Glenn Stuart. Of Manhattan, 44, died June 7, 1997. Beloved companion of Paul Murphy; son of Norma and Larry Berman of Merion, PA; brother of June and Peter Olster, Cary, Suzie and Eddie Weiss; uncle of seven nieces and nephews. Family burial Monday, June 9; reception for family and friends at Glenn's Manhattan home, Friday evening, June 13.

title: Bid to Freeze Property Taxes
description: Property taxes for an estimated 240,000 low-income elderly and disabled homeowners would be frozen at 1996 levels under a proposal that is on the legislative fast track. The measure, introduced by Assembly Speaker Jack Collins on Thursday, passed yesterday in the Assembly's Senior Issues, Tourism and Gaming Committee.

title: A 90's Family: Mom, Dad And Baby Makes Money
description: In the opening scene of ''Baby Anger,'' Peter Hedges's bristling black comedy about golden children and the parents who use them, a Russian cabby recounts for a childless yuppie couple an oft-told apocryphal story of a mother who, spying her child trapped under a school bus, finds the strength to lift the vehicle.

title: The Elite Waiting List for an Elusive Championship
description: It is the empty space in their trophy cases, the missing line on their resumes.

title: Accounts
description: * Crane & Co., Dalton, Mass., to Grey Advertising, New York, to handle advertising for the paper company, which had been handled by Sacks & Rosen, New York. Billings were not disclosed.

title: FELCOR ACQUIRING CONTROL OF UP TO 12 EMBASSY SUITES
description: Felcor Suite Hotels Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay about $146.7 million to buy control of as many as 12 Embassy Suites hotels from the Promus Hotel Corporation. Felcor, a hotel real estate investment trust based in Irving, Tex., said it would buy two of the hotels, in Syracuse and Dallas, for $46.7 million. In addition, Felcor will invest about $100 million to buy majority stakes in as many as 10 new Embassy Suites hotels that Promus plans to build and in which Promus will retain a 10 percent interest. Promus, a Memphis-based hotel manager and franchisor, will run all the hotels for Felcor.

title: Bacteria Make Common Pollutants Harmless
description: IT might seem like an impossible dream -- a strain of bacteria that can break down some of the most common and long-lived toxic chemicals in polluted ground water. But scientists at Cornell University have found just such a bacterium in sewage sludge. They have given it the unassuming name of strain 195, and say that it is the first ever found to make certain toxic solvents harmless, including one commonly used in dry cleaning.

title: Officials Link Atlanta Bombings and Ask for Help
description: Leaders of a task force investigating a series of bombings in Atlanta said today that they were ''all but positive'' that the same person or people planted bombs at a lesbian nightclub and at a building housing an abortion clinic, and expressed ''increasing confidence'' that those incidents were linked to last summer's explosion at Centennial Olympic Park.

title: Future of Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ball Park for Atlantic City
description: Atlantic City officials are hoping that the crack of the bat has the same power to draw tourists as the roll of the dice. Yesterday, the city cleared a final hurdle in its plans to build a minor league baseball stadium.

title: Pope's Less Confrontational Tone Pleases Friends in Cracow
description: Many of the 600 or so guests who gathered on Sunday night to celebrate the 600th anniversary of the Theological Faculty of Jagiellonian University are old friends and former colleagues of Karol Wojtyla, the onetime Archbishop of Cracow who left in 1978 to become Pope John Paul II.

title: Yanks Trade Weathers to Indians for Curtis
description: David Weathers flopped in the Yankee bullpen during April and then found himself in Columbus after being singled out for criticism by George Steinbrenner. Yesterday, he was sent to the Cleveland Indians for Chad Curtis, an outfielder now in the minors who is recovering from an injury sustained in a scuffle with a teammate.

title: Gerry Adams Runs Out of Excuses
description: Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, cannot complain about recent political developments in Britain and Ireland. His own party, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, did well in the recent Irish and British parliamentary elections. More significantly, the new British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, and the probable new Irish Prime Minister, Bertie Ahern, are likely to push for a Northern Ireland peace settlement.

title: Hometown Witnesses Paint McVeigh Likable as a Child
description: In their bid to spare their client's life, lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh today called his childhood friends, his godmother and soldiers who served with him in the Army to tell a Federal Court jury that he was a lively, affectionate child who grew up to be a perfect soldier.

title: The Ghosts of Octobers Past
description: Baseball, more than any other sport, invites, maybe demands, historical perspective. But then baseball has a richer history than other sports, both in the years it has been played and the individual achievements it has produced.

title: Cablevision Moves to Acquire 10 More Local Cable Systems
description: Promising 100 television channels, high-speed Internet access and telephone service, the Cablevision Systems Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 10 cable television systems in the metropolitan area covering more than 820,000 customers from Tele-Communications Inc.

title: The Front of the Pack Is Kennedy's Place
description: It is the considered opinion of Frank Shorter, the 1972 Olympic marathon champion, that the abundance of African distance runners has produced more troubling consequences for Americans in the head than in the legs.

title: Charles Jones, a Composer, 86
description: Charles Jones, a composer who taught at the Juilliard School and the Mannes College of Music, died on Friday at New York Hospital. He was 86.

title: Louisiana Vote Inquiry Focuses on Gambling and New Orleans Politics
description: Given that this is Louisiana, where politics and corruption blend like red beans and rice, few doubt that last year's narrow election of Mary L. Landrieu to the United States Senate may have been something shy of stainless.

title: Small-Cap Stocks Are At It Again
description: Left behind by the bull market in the first quarter, stocks of smaller companies have raced forward in recent weeks, easily outpacing giant stocks. Market Place, page 10.

title: A Self-Styled Hollywood Star
description: A few people have been able to title themselves successfully: Napoleon for instance. But control of the military might just be required to make monikers like emperor stick. The music industry, for example, has rejected Michael Jackson's King of Pop. And the entertainment world hasn't taken Howard Stern's King of All Media very seriously.

title: PARMALAT TO BUY AULT, WITH OFFER THAT BEAT SAPUTO'S
description: Ault Foods Ltd., the Toronto-based dairy concern, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Italian food and dairy company Parmalat Finanziaria S.p.A. for $415 million (Canadian), or around $300 million (United States). Under the agreement, Parmalat will pay $34 (Canadian) for each of Ault's 11 million shares outstanding. Parmalat's offer topped a bid by Saputo Group Inc., a Montreal-based cheese and dairy concern, which offered last month to acquire Ault for $28 (Canadian) a share, or $308 million, in a bid that expires on Thursday. Saputo owns 16.4 percent of Ault's shares.

title: Head of House Panel Offers Plan to Help Revive Capital
description: To stem the steady flow of people leaving the District of Columbia for the cleaner, safer environs of the suburbs, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee proposed a $325 million tax relief plan today for residents and businesses in some parts of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODLIN, SYLVIA
description: MODLIN-Sylvia. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Joseph Modlin on the loss of his wife Sylvia. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Army Fights Rebel Force To Control Brazzaville
description: In a fifth day of fighting between the national army and a militia loyal to a former head of state, mortar fire rained down today on the center of Brazzaville, capital of the Congo Republic, as France and the United States struggled to evacuate their citizens from the city.

title: Cliburn Prize Opens Door To Struggle
description: There is something slightly sadistic about the awards ceremony at the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition here, something beyond the waiting and teasing inherent in all such events. Before the three medalists were announced on Sunday night, the finalists and about 3,000 listeners patiently endured an hour of speeches brimming with acknowledgments and platitudes, relieved only by a 16-minute film retrospective of Cliburn competitions past.

title: At French Open, Two Breaths of Fresh Air
description: Maybe next year he will book himself a room at the Ritz with the rest of the big shots. But Sunday night the new French Open champion, Gustavo Kuerten, partied and sambaed until dawn and then, just as his coach, Larri Passos, had predicted, fell asleep on the floor in his hotel room like an overgrown dog. A breath of fresh air in a sport whose stars need little more than a hangnail to motivate them to call in sick, Kuerten was as unpretentious as the joint that housed him.

title: Thai Man Extradited In 1991 Heroin Shipment
description: A man said to have been one of the masterminds of the largest heroin shipment ever seized in the United States has been extradited from Thailand and is seeking to negotiate a plea deal with Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn, it was revealed in court yesterday.

title: Continental Set to Begin Exclusive Pact With Boeing
description: Continental Airlines is expected to announce today that it will buy 35 wide-body jets in an exclusive arrangement with the Boeing Company, according to people familiar with the airline's plans.

title: Playing, Swaying and Praying
description: The Tibetan Freedom Concerts, the only rock festival with an on-site temple, took over Downing Stadium on Randalls Island for the weekend. Two dozen rock and hip-hop groups donated their performances, including million-dollar-selling acts like the Beastie Boys, U2, Alanis Morissette, a Tribe Called Quest, the Foo Fighters and members of Pearl Jam, R.E.M. and Oasis, more star power than the summer's commercial package tours. Saturday's attendance was 19,500; Sunday, headlined by the Beastie Boys, drew 27,500.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: INQUIRY INTO BABY'S DEATH -- A baby born in a bathroom at a high school prom in New Jersey on Friday was alive during birth, officials said. But a decision whether to charge the mother awaits more tests. B2.

description: Like a casino novice who can't choose between the allure of the slots and of the roulette table, ''Easy Money'' spends some time gawking before settling down to its real business, the unwholesome relationship between gambling and government.

description: A Federal judge urged the National Transportation Safety Board yesterday to give lawyers representing the families of victims of the Trans World Airlines Flight 800 disaster at least as much access to the plane's wreckage as was given to the news media.

title: Giuliani Uses Conference To Rally Immigrant Cause
description: Nearly a year after Congress voted to slash benefits to legal immigrants, a group of Republican and Democratic local elected officials from around the nation, organized by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, rallied yesterday in New York City to call on Congress to restore the aid.

title: Vacancy Issue Becomes Focus Of Rent Debate
description: With just six days to go before state rent laws are due to expire, the battle over the future of those laws is focused almost entirely on one exceptionally thorny issue: whether landlords should be allowed to raise rents as much as they want on regulated apartments that become vacant.

title: Dr. Thomas Vincent Santulli, 82, A Pioneer of Pediatric Surgery
description: Dr. Thomas Vincent Santulli, professor emeritus of surgery at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and former director of surgery at Babies and Children's Hospital of New York, died last Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 82 and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

description: With opposition leaders threatening more violent protests like the one that rocked this capital recently, a protracted battle over constitutional reform is looming in Kenya, threatening to overshadow or even derail presidential elections later this year.

description: Richard S. Aldrich, a cousin of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller who was elected to a two-year term as a Republican councilman at large from Manhattan in 1963, died on Friday in Massachusetts. He was 73 and lived in Providence, R.I., his birthplace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMELTZ, RABBI BENJAMIN
description: SCHMELTZ - Rabbi Benjamin. There is now a deep void in my life due to the loss of my revered Rabbi and my dear friend. I will never forget your smile, your wit, your words of wisdom and, above all, your goodness, which encompased all humanity. My heartfelt sympathy goes out to the Schmeltz family. I will truly miss you. Janet Zinner

title: Deregulation in Boston: Disruption, but Also Construction
description: In the two years since Massachusetts voters ended most rent controls for the cities of Boston, Cambridge and Brookline, two distinct interpretations of the results are beginning to emerge: While tenant advocates and landlords agree that noticeable disruptions and turnover have occurred in some neighborhoods, landlords say there are also signs that eliminating the rules has encouraged new housing construction and repairs.

title: IBJ Schroder Moving Within Manhattan
description: IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company, the United States investment banking arm of the Industrial Bank of Japan, will receive $3.1 million in public subsidies for moving its headquarters from One State Street Plaza to 180 Maiden Lane, both in lower Manhattan, under an agreement with city and state economic development officials.

description: FRANK-Minna (Rabhun). Died on June 6, 1997. Mother of Judith. Devoted grandmother of Jonathan, Blake and Mara Faye. Community activist, loyal neighbor and friend.

The Funeral Service will be held at The Bay Head Chapel, Bay Head, NJ, Wednesday at 11:00 A.M. Interment will follow in Greenwood, Brielle, NJ. An intrepid Zionist, he was by word and deed a model of devotion to G-d and humanity. Our prayers of condolence go out to his beloved wife Naomi, their children, and grandchildren. We include as well his loving brothers Leon Landes and Rabbi Aaron Landes, the esteemed chairman of our Cabinet. State of Israel Bonds Gideon Patt, President Burton Resnick, National Chairman Rabbi Haskell M. Bernat, National Director Synagogue and Rabbinic Activities

Beloved wife of the late George, devoted mother of the late George, Jr. and the late Marilyn Wescott-Smith. Loving grandmother of Michael Smith of Pomona, CA., and Andrea Smith of Hacienda Heights, CA. Devoted mother-inlaw of Fritz and Nancy Smith of Hacienda Heights, CA. Cherished sister of Dorothy Ryan of Rockville Centre, N.Y., Mary Gunther of Manchester, VT. and the late Alexander, George, Gordon, Allan and Lester Cummings. Visiting Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, Tuesday, June 10, 2-4 & 7-9pm. Service Wednesday, June 11, 10am, Church of Atonement, Engle Street, Tenafly, N.J.

title: Nations and Cultures Meet In a Spectacle Full of Masks

The production, commissioned by the Japan Society, was undeniably elaborate. But as performed on Thursday night at the society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium, it seemed simultaneously ponderous and insubstantial.

Now a new analysis of 30 years of data from the North American Breeding Bird Survey has found that on the whole, continent-wide numbers of the birds have remained surprisingly stable.

title: Indiana Girl Who Killed 2 Is Transferred From Prison for Adults
description: Donna Ratliff, a 16-year-old Indiana girl who has become a national symbol of the plight of juveniles incarcerated in adult prisons, was transferred yesterday from Indiana's maximum-security women's prison to a private treatment center for young people.

title: Protest in Baby Slaying Case
description: Prosecutors in the Amy Grossberg murder case filed a complaint yesterday, claiming that Ms. Grossberg's interview on television last week violated a gag order, The Associated Press reported. Prosecutors would not comment on or supply a copy of the complaint filed with Judge Henry duPont Ridgely of Superior Court.

title: Are Digital Cameras Good Enough Yet? That All Depends
description: THINK of images from digital cameras as peanut butter sandwiches without enough peanut butter. Just as there is only so far you can spread a teaspoon of Jif before the taste disappears, the square dots that make up a digital image can go only so far before the chunky pixels fail to cohere into a seamless picture. Digital cameras have their uses, but today's consumer-oriented models do not yet deliver enough dots to approach the quality that film has delivered routinely for years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, ABBOTT
description: LEWIS-Abbott, 83. Beloved husband of Mary, died June 9, 1997. He was loved by everyone who knew him. He was always there for his family, community and friends. We will miss him, Graveside service at Mt. Ararat, Farmingdale, NY today at 2:30 PM.

title: House Panel Votes Changes to Try to Keep Medicare Solvent
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved legislation tonight to make sweeping changes in Medicare that would keep it solvent for a decade and offer new health insurance options to 33 million elderly Americans.

title: Family of Man Slain by Police Wins $6.7 Million in Damages
description: A Brooklyn jury awarded $6.7 million yesterday to the family of an emotionally disturbed man who was fatally shot in 1992 by two police officers who said he had lunged at them with a knife.

title: In the Name of St. Nicholas, The Russian Faithful Walk
description: A seven-day pilgrimage whose origins date from 1383, when an icon was discovered depicting St. Nicholas the Miracle Worker, is still observed in the village of Velikoretskoye, Russia. In czarist times the journey from the church in Vyatka, now Kirov, where a copy of the icon is kept, attracted more than 20,000 believers. Restricted under the Communists and banned in 1961, it was revived in 1989.

title: U.S. to Cut Auctions and Increase Issues
description: The Treasury said yesterday that it was changing its auction schedule to include a new five-year inflation-indexed note this year and to reduce the number of auctions of conventional 10-year notes to four a year from six. It also said it planned to add a 30-year inflation-indexed security in the future.

title: Times Sells Former Plant
description: Security Capital Industrial Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Aurora, Colo., has paid $11.5 million for a vacant warehouse in Carlstadt, N.J., used until two years ago as a printing plant for The New York Times.

title: Potshots From All Sides Offer Tax-Fight Preview
description: Offering a preview of the rancorous debate that lies ahead, interest groups pounced on the tax package proposed today by the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, with some calling the tax cuts too limited and others calling them too generous to the wealthy.

title: Reid Shelton, Actor, 72, Dies; Original Broadway Warbucks
description: Reid Shelton, a veteran actor and singer who created the role of Daddy Warbucks in the original Broadway production of ''Annie,'' died on Sunday in Portland, Ore. He was 72 and lived in Waldport, Ore.

title: As Promised, President Vetoes Bill On Flood Aid
description: In an escalating war of political wills, President Clinton made good today on his threat to veto an $8.6 billion emergency flood relief bill because of unrelated provisions, volleying it back to the Republican-led Congress almost the moment he received it.

title: Hutu Exiles Fear Return To Burundi
description: Difficult as it has been to get thousands of Hutu refugees back to their homes in Rwanda, there are others who present a greater problem: the refugees from Burundi, which is in the middle of a civil war.

title: Frogs' Unusual Diet for Longer Life: A Medley of Toxins
description: TO an unknowing predator, the poisonous, fingerprint-size frogs of the American tropics may look as tasty as their fruity strawberry and banana coloring suggest. But in fact, these frogs are so unappetizing at first bite -- some are potentially deadly if swallowed -- that most animals spit them out like Brussels sprouts and avoid all future contact.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about the founding chairman of the neurology department at Long Island Jewish Medical Center misstated his given name. He was Morton Nathanson, not Robert.

title: A Convert Spreads the Word for Haitian Art
description: Jonathan Demme, the movie director, was walking around the West Side back in 1987 when music from the Haitian Corner, an art gallery, caught his ear. Going inside, he browsed but didn't buy any paintings. ''They were a couple of hundred dollars each,'' Mr. Demme recalled recently, ''and I was a flea market-junk store person. I'd buy art for $25 or $30.''

title: Chrysler Plans More Dual-Fuel Mini-Vans
description: The Chrysler Corporation plans to announce on Tuesday that by this autumn, all of its mini-vans with 3.3-liter engines will be outfitted for the 1998 model year with the equipment to burn either gasoline or ethanol, the National Ethanol Vehicle Coalition said today.

title: U.S.-Latin War on Drugs Replacing Blame With Cooperation
description: When officials from all over the Western Hemisphere assembled here this week, they wasted no words on empty predictions of quick victory in the war on drugs. Instead, they focused on a less ambitious goal: working together, rather than at odds with one another, on drug policy.

title: Court to Decide Whether Harassment Law Applies to People of Same Sex
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal law that prohibits sex discrimination and sexual harassment on the job applies to behavior between people of the same sex.

description: It won't be difficult to spot Hideki Irabu on Tuesday night. He'll be the guy wearing the size 50 pinstripes.

title: PERKINS FAMILY RESTAURANTS' STOCK SLIDES 15 PERCENT
description: Shares of Perkins Family Restaurants L.P. skidded more than 15 percent yesterday after Perkins, the restaurant chain, said it might eliminate its cash distributions because of a Federal law requiring it to be taxed as a corporation starting next year. Perkins, based in Memphis, is now taxed as a partnership. If it receives the new tax status, it will pay taxes at the higher corporate rate. Any cash distributions will be included in investors' taxable income and taxed at each investor's individual tax rate. The company said the corporate tax rate would leave it too short of money to pay shareholders. It would most likely reduce its cash distributions, but might eliminate them entirely. Shares of Perkins fell $2.125, to $11.50.

title: CISCO TO ADD SKYSTONE SYSTEMS FOR STOCK AND CASH
description: Cisco Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Skystone Systems Corporation for $89.1 million in cash and stock. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., said it would pay one million shares of its stock and $22.6 million in cash for all of Skystone. It expects to take an after-tax charge of 8 cents to 13 cents a share in its fourth quarter, which ends next month. Skystone, based in Ottawa, has been an innovator in synchronous optical networking, which will be used for moving voice, video and data over the same network. Skystone was founded in 1994 and has about 40 employees. Shares in Cisco, the largest maker of networking equipment, rose $1.5625 yesterday, to $66.50.

He was a member of the Ashokan American Legion Post#

title: Chemical Traces of Blood Found In Bones of Tyrannosaurus Rex
description: SCIENTISTS say they have recovered elements of blood from the bones of a dinosaur that died some 65 million years ago. This is the first time that blood components have been recovered from dinosaur bones, and the nearest that science has come to the science fiction fantasy of recreating the creatures from the genetic information in their blood cells.

title: Despite Slight Rise, Reading Scores Fall Far Short of Goal
description: Eighteen months after Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew set a goal that every third grader be able to read at grade level by now, New York City school officials acknowledged yesterday that this year's scores fell far short: while the test results were slightly higher than a year ago, more than half still could not read at the third-grade mark.

title: ASCEND SHARES SLIDE ON A DELAY IN PRODUCT SHIPMENTS
description: Ascend Communications stock tumbled yesterday in heavy trading on concern that a software problem might cause it to miss second-quarter revenue targets. Ascend's shares fell $6.25, to $41.375, as 27.8 million shares changed hands. Shares of the Cascade Communications Corporation of Westford, Mass., which Ascend is acquiring, fell $4.3125, to $28.5625. Because a software flaw in a chip in its Max networking products line forced it to delay shipments, Ascend, based in Alameda, Calif., may turn in less than the $225 million in second-quarter revenue forecast by one analyst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHEIDKER, RICHARD L.
description: SCHEIDKER-Richard L., Sarasota, Fl. Former senior vice president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, died here on June 9, 1997 at the age of 81. During World War II he was naval aide to the Director of the Office of Stragetic Services, Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, and assisted him at the Nuremberg Trials. Mr. Scheidker joined the advertising agency association in 1946 and headed its public relations activities until his retirement in 1971. He helped to establish the National Advertising Review Board, also the Advertising Educational Foundation, and organized a program to train minority people for advertising jobs. He was born in Hannibal, Missouri, and was graduated from the School of Journalism of the University of Missouri in 1936. He was a radio writer before entering the advertising agency business. During World War II, after action in the Battle of Leyte Gulf, he was awarded the Bronze Star Medal. He is survived by a sister, Mrs. H. Norman Schnitzlein of Tampa, Florida. For more information, contact Toale Brothers Funeral Home, Gulf Gate Chapel.

description: Steffi Graf's problematic year took another unfortunate turn yesterday when the former No. 1 player underwent knee surgery that will force her to miss Wimbledon and the United States Open championships.

title: WHOLE FOODS IN $146 MILLION DEAL TO ACQUIRE AMRION INC.
description: Whole Foods Market Inc. of Austin, Tex., has agreed to acquire Amrion Inc., a nutritional-supplements maker and seller, for $146 million in stock. Under the agreement, Whole Foods, the nation's leading organic grocer, will pay 4.6 million shares, or 0.87 of a share for each of Amrion's 5.3 million shares outstanding. Whole Foods shares fell $1.75, to $30, while shares of Amrion, of Boulder, Colo., slipped 50 cents, to $24.875. Costs related to the acquisition will reduce Whole Foods' profits by $3 million to $5 million for the quarter ending Sept. 28.

title: AMERICA ONLINE AND CUC SHOPPING SERVICE FORM VENTURE
description: America Online Inc. and the discount-shopping service CUC International Inc. are joining forces. Under a three-year agreement, America Online, the Internet access provider, will receive $50 million in fees plus potential other payments from a revenue-sharing arrangement. CUC is expected to generate more than a million annual memberships for America Online, which is based in Dulles, Va. America Online will promote CUC services on line and by direct mail to America Online subscribers. CUC, based in Stamford, Conn., is best known for restaurant coupon books often sold by churches and other nonprofit groups. Much of its $1 billion-plus annual revenue derives from fees it charges its millions of customers, typically $49 a year.

description: Now and then, in his job as medical director of a San Francisco hospice agency, Dr. Robert V. Brody discovers that a patient has killed himself with help from a doctor. The news rarely surprises him; in San Francisco, a city scarred deeply by the AIDS epidemic, doctor-assisted suicide has become a familiar thread in the complex tapestry of health care at the end of life.

title: The Not-So-Gentle Art Of Getting a Table
description: WHEN a Manhattan couple, Carol Peligian, an artist, and her husband, Robert Baghosian, a lawyer, dine out, they make reservations in Mr. Baghosian's name. ''Inevitably, the person taking the reservation will ask, 'Eric?' And we say, 'Uh-huh,' '' Ms. Peligian said. ''They usually give us a table.''

description: To the Editor:

title: A Favor-the-Rich Tax Plan
description: After studying the tax system carefully, chairman Bill Archer of the House tax-writing committee has come up with a proposal that barely eases the strain on middle-class families while showering the rich with benefits. To finance cuts in capital gains and inheritance taxes, Mr. Archer has held tax benefits for others to a minimal level.

title: Cutting Taxes a Luxury Now With Consequences Deferred
description: For all the anguish they say they went through to get an agreement to balance the budget within five years, what members of Congress are really doing now is what they enjoy most: cutting taxes and increasing spending.

title: Sidney C. Sufrin, 87, Professor At Syracuse and Massachusetts
description: Sidney C. Sufrin, an economics professor and public policy specialist who headed a Government-sponsored economic mission to Spain after World War II, died on June 6 in Amherst, Mass., Phillip Shatz, the family's attorney, said. He was 87 and had been ill for some time with renal failure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFSON, BETTY
description: WOLFSON-Betty. Died suddenly on June 9, 1997. Beloved wife of Harvey. Loving mother of JoAnn Novak and her husband Frank. Cherished grandmother of Samantha Novak. Dear sister of Andrew Tompkins. Private memorial will be held. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to The American Diabetes Association.

title: Pension Bonds Pass a Test
description: A new law allowing the state to sell $2.75 billion in pension bonds cleared a judicial hurdle yesterday when a Superior Court judge ruled that it was constitutional.

title: BDM'S STOCK DECLINES 24% ON LOWER EARNINGS FORECAST
description: Shares of BDM International Inc. fell 24 percent yesterday after the concern, an information technology company, warned that second-quarter earnings would fall below expectations. BDM, based in McLean, Va., said late on Monday that it expected earnings of 14 cents to 16 cents a share on revenue of $275 million, below analysts' consensus estimate of 25 cents a share. BDM reported earnings of $6.7 million, or 45 cents a share, on revenues of $251.9 million for the second quarter ended June 30, 1996. BDM blamed a hardware delivery delay, foreign exchange rates and issues involving a state government contract. BDM's shares were down $6.75 at $20.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, DONALD
description: O'ROURKE-Donald. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Donald O'Rourke, associated with The Times from 1952, until retiring in 1993.

title: To Mend Broken Minds: Herbs, Faith and Chains
description: It is Sunday morning and the service with its drum beating and rhythmic wailing -- can be heard all along the rutted street here on the outskirts of this city, where garbage, the rusting carcasses of abandoned cars and barefoot children vie for space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MYRA KAYE
description: KAUFMAN-Myra Kaye. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Devoted mother of Ira and Jeffrey. Dear sister of Rosalyn Fox. Loving grandmother of Laura Jill Kaufman. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, New Jersey, Thursday, 10 AM.

title: JONES INTERCABLE SELLS CABLE AND WIRELESS STAKE
description: Jones Intercable Inc. said yesterday that it had sold its more than 25 million shares of Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C. to reduce debt of $329 million. Terms were not disclosed, but the deal may be worth as much as 72.7 million pounds, or $119 million, based on the 291-pence closing price yesterday of Cable and Wireless Communications shares in London. Jones Intercable, of Englewood, Colo., is one of the largest cable television operators in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGLEY, STEPHEN
description: LANGLEY-Stephen. The staff of the Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM) mourns the death of Stephen Langley, who established the world class Arts Administration Program at Brooklyn College. Many of our staff have been students in the program and now serve as faculty. He will be missed.

title: Independents Have a Weapon Against the 'Big Boxes'
description: In 1948, Clarence Buikema opened a 3,000-square-foot hardware store in this town 30 miles west of Chicago and made a home for his family in the upstairs apartment. Competitors in the area, which was then mainly rural, were few and far between.

title: Act Honorably, Worried Owners Urge Their Peers
description: Saying they believed there was a strong chance that state rent controls would expire on Sunday, the city's largest landlord groups called on their members yesterday to act responsibly and continue to honor and renew leases on rent-regulated apartments while Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders negotiate the terms of a new law.

title: Alphabet Soup
description: Contrary to reports that he is easing away from the battle over revising the television ratings system, Jack Valenti was back at work in Washington yesterday, sleeves rolled up -- because of surgery to mend a tendon he hurt playing golf -- as he tried to forge another compromise.

title: House Panel Backs Benefits For Immigrants
description: The House Ways and Means Committee tonight approved legislation that would guarantee cash benefits for hundreds of thousands of impoverished legal immigrants who would otherwise lose such aid this summer as a result of the 1996 welfare law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOS, JULIE ANN

description: The Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, announced yesterday that he would seek the death penalty for James Allen Gordon, who the police said murdered three women last July after raping one and tormenting the others.

description: Summing up the defense of Alex Kelly, his lawyer said today that the 16-year-old girl who accused him of rape 11 years ago fabricated the story because she felt guilty about having sex in the back of a Jeep with a boy she just met, a boy with whom she had no future because he had a girlfriend.

title: Despite Missed Goal, Crew Defends Reading Scores
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew vigorously defended the results of this year's reading tests yesterday, saying that New York City's 80,000 third graders should be applauded for notching a measurable improvement over last year's class, even if tens of thousands of them missed his goal that all should be reading at their grade level by now.

description: Five days before the laws limiting rent increases on 1.2 million apartments are to expire, Governor Pataki and legislative leaders met but reported no progress on an accord.

description: An expected flood of new corporate debt weighed on Treasury prices yesterday, erasing early gains on increased buying from foreign investors and on a regional report that showed moderate economic growth.

title: OIL DRILLER'S STOCK RISES AFTER $997 MILLION DEBUT
description: The shares of the Santa Fe International Corporation rose more than 10 percent above the offering price in their first day of trading. The company's $997.5 million initial public offering was the largest offering so far this year. The stock of the Dallas-based oil-drilling company, a unit of Kuwait's state oil company, the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, closed at $32 as almost 14.3 million shares were traded. Santa Fe sold 35 million shares at $28.50 each. Santa Fe owns 26 offshore rigs and 25 land rigs operating in 16 countries. Daily rental rates for drilling rigs have more than doubled in the last year, analysts said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a Democratic Party convention in Massachusetts omitted a word in some editions in a reference to the position of Senator Jesse Helms toward the nomination of Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts as Ambassador to Mexico. Mr. Helms, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has said he will not schedule a hearing because he believes that Governor Weld is not qualified.

description: For the third consecutive year, George Washington High School dominated its opponents, outscoring them by an average of 11 runs. But, unlike the 1995 and 1996 teams, there was a happy ending to this year's storybook season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, JOSEPH A.
description: KELLY-Joseph A., CPIM, CPM, CIRM, director of materials management for Bristol-Myers Squibb company of Princeton, N.J., died Tuesday, May 27, 1997 at Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick, NJ. He was 46. Joseph graduated with honors from Rutgers University in 1973 with a BS degree in Industrial Engineering and a BA in Economics. In 1976 Joseph received his MBA from Syracuse University in Operations Management. The son of the late Joseph P. Kelly. Joseph is survived by his mother, Rose Kelly; his fiancee, Deborah Parker; her children Elizabeth, Laura, and Katie Parker; and four sibblings, Nancy K. Weimer; Thomas Kelly; Janet Payne; Mark Kelly; and grandfather Edward Klaus.

description: Faced with the start of formal audits of their wartime accounts next week, Switzerland's banks have quietly told investigators that they recently discovered hundreds of accounts that may have belonged to Holocaust victims and thousands more that they cannot account for.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATHANSON, MORTON, M.D.
description: NATHANSON-Morton, M.D. The Department of Neurology of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine is saddened to note the death of Morton Nathanson, M.D. Dr. Nathanson was a Clinical Professor and a member of the Department for over 20 years, before moving to found the Department of Neurology at the Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was a man of great energy and wit. He was an exceptional teacher, a world-renowned diagnostician, and a man of erudition. He helped train a generation of neurologists. Particularly important was his ability to counter prevailing opinion when he believed he was right. We will miss his warmth and kindness. We extend our deep sympathy to his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUSE, CAROLINE (NEE BEAR)
description: MARCUSE-Caroline (Nee Bear). Died on June 10, 1997. 92 years old. Wife of the late John Marcuse. Beloved mother of Ann Raymond and Lee Marcuse. Adored grandmother of Jennifer Farrell and Pamela Raymond. Dear sister of Annette Hofbauer. She leaves two great-grandchildren. In memory please send donations to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTROVE, KATHY ADLER
description: ASTROVE-Kathy Adler, June 9beloved wife of Edgar, loving mother of Jane Graver and Jim Astrove, cherished grandmother of Melissa, Ben and Grace, sister of Dotsy Potter and John Adler. Mt. Holyoke College '54, Columbia University Teachers College '55. Dedicated teacher in Larchmont and Scarsdale, volunteer at the New Rochelle Senior Employment Service, member of Toughlove, a director of The Adler Foundation, and founder of endowed educational funds. Remembrance for Kathy will be on Sunday, June 22, 11:00 A.M., at the house. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Katherine Adler Astrove Youth Education Fund, Joslin Diabetes Center, One Joslin Place, Boston, MA. 02215, or to Katherine Adler Astrove '54, Fund for Summer Internships, Mount Holyoke College, South Hadley, MA. 01075.

title: 17 in Motorcycle Gang Charged in Indictment
description: A Federal indictment unsealed today charged 17 Midwestern members of a motorcycle gang with racketeering and accused them of attacking a rival gang in crimes that included drug dealing, attempted arson, bombings and murders.

title: Fourth Graders Successful, Study Shows
description: American fourth graders scored above the international average on standardized tests in math and science, according to a study released today that also pointed to a mysterious sag in students' relative skills by eighth grade.

title: RENT REGULATIONS FIRMLY SUPPORTED IN NEW YORK CITY
description: With the tenacity of a New Yorker refusing to surrender a hard-won parking spot, city residents by an overwhelming margin support regulations that keep rents below what the market will bear, and therefore do not want state rent ceilings to expire on Sunday, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: Mishandling Russian Uranium
description: There is no more urgent international need than providing for the safe and secure disposal of bomb-grade nuclear materials from dismantled Russian warheads. That difficult job is now threatened by a misguided privatization plan that could undermine one of the central mechanisms for safeguarding highly enriched Russian uranium.

title: '94 Candidate In Maryland Is Held in Plot To Hire Killer
description: Maryland has had its fair share of politicians running afoul of the law over the years. But little compares with the troubles now facing Ruthann Aron, a once rising star in the state Republican Party.

title: Pesky Jeter And Boggs Ignite Rout Of Chicago
description: If Jaime Navarro had had a can of bug spray, he would have targeted Derek Jeter and Wade Boggs. If he had had a fly swatter, he would have flailed at them. If he had had a no-pest strip, he would have wrapped it around their legs. Navarro, the Chicago White Sox starter, would have tried anything to squelch Jeter and Boggs as last night progressed, because the two hitters on top of the Yankee lineup continually harassed him. No one, meanwhile, was harassing the Yankee starter, Andy Pettitte.

description: Community Care Services of Mount Vernon, N.Y., said yesterday that it was the target of a Federal investigation into allegations of improper payments involving Medicare.

description: The airline industry, which only a few years ago was in dire financial straits, now has the reverse problem: Many people seem to think it makes too much money.

title: When Quotes Can't Be Trusted
description: ''It's a memoir. It's not investigative journalism. I'm not a journalist.'' Thus Robert Reich, the former Labor Secretary, reacted after a reporter, Jonathan Rauch, revealed that he had played fast and loose with several quotations in his memoir of life in the Clinton Administration, ''Locked in the Cabinet.''

title: Nicotine Control Issue Said to Delay Tobacco Talks
description: The tobacco talks recessed yesterday after B.A.T. Industries P.L.C, the parent company of Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, objected to a settlement proposal that would have given the Federal Government regulatory control over nicotine, people close to the talks said.

title: Conseco Selects An Image Agency
description: Conseco Inc., a insurance and financial services company in Carmel, Ind., said yesterday that it had named Fallon McElligott Berlin in New York as the first agency to handle corporate image and brand-building advertising. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Fallon McElligott Berlin was selected after a review that had been narrowed to that agency and one other finalist, McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown in Chicago. Fallon McElligott Berlin is an affiliate of Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis.

title: A Pot for Every Chicken, at Sale Prices
description: TWO cookware dealers are trying to clean house by offering deep discounts. At Lamalle Kitchenware, on the sixth floor at 36 West 25th Street, everything has been reduced 30 percent to 50 percent. Fish grills are now $14.95 (were $29.95); stainless-steel ice cream scoops are $8.95 (were $17.95), and 10-quart copper casseroles are $269.95 (were $384.95). Cookbooks are 40 percent off. The sale will continue until everything is sold. In August the store plans to move to a ground-floor space nearby, but no lease has yet been signed. Information: (212) 242-0750.

title: Steinbrenner Is Irked By Players' Criticism
description: Most of the Yankee pitchers may not think that Hideki Irabu deserves a guaranteed slot in the team's rotation when he finally makes his way to New York, which will probably happen in another month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKMAN, CHARLOTTE
description: MARKMAN-Charlotte. June 9, 1997. Charlotte was beloved on the Lower East Side and was a life long fighter for justice. Services Thursday, June 12, 1997, at 10 AM, at St. Augustine's Church, 290 Henry Street, NYC.

title: Ugly Life Warrants Leniency, 'Megan' Defense Says
description: In 1996, while Jesse K. Timmendequas was awaiting trial for the rape and murder of 7-year-old Megan Kanka, his mother wrote him a letter. Several of her children, she said, faulted her for failing to protect them when they were sexually assaulted as children by men in her life. She wrote, ''They all blame me for what happened, and I guess they are right.''

title: Romario and Ronaldo: Brazil's Thrilling Strikers
description: ''Ronaldo, Romario.'' ''Romario, Ronaldo.'' Either way, it rolls off the tongue, and either way, it has become a mantra from Porto Alegre in the south of Brazil to Rio De Janeiro and Belem further north.

title: Wyse to Acquire Blasko, Sipos
description: Wyse Advertising in Cleveland said yesterday that it would acquire Blasko, Sipos & Courtney in Cleveland, effective on July 1. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Li Shuxian, 73, Widow of Last China Emperor
description: Li Shuxian, the widow of China's last Emperor, has died, breaking one of the final links to the 267-year Qing dynasty, which ended when the boy Emperor Pu Yi was deposed in 1911.

title: No Indictment in Slaying
description: A Union County grand jury declined yesterday to indict four Federal agents and a Newark police officer who shot an unarmed man 38 times and killed him. The jury found that the members of the Federal Bureau of Investigation Violent Crimes Task Force who opened fire on Michael Byrd, 21, in an Elizabeth apartment on Jan. 30 were in fear of their lives, said Edward M. Neafsey, the Acting County Prosecutor. They had gone to the apartment to arrest Mr. Byrd after he failed to show up at his trial for the 1995 murder of an East Orange woman, Mr. Neafsey said.

title: States Prodded To Ban Youths In Front Seats
description: The National Transportation Safety Board asked the 50 states today to make it illegal for a child under the age of 13 to ride in the front seat of a car.

title: First Production for an Early Williams Play
description: ''Not About Nightingales,'' an early unproduced Tennessee Williams play, is scheduled to have its world premiere at the Royal National Theater on March 5, 1998. The play, found by Vanessa Redgrave, will be directed by Trevor Nunn, the incoming artistic director of the National Company.

title: $360 MILLION SWAP TO SEND NUMAR TO HALLIBURTON
description: The Halliburton Company agreed yesterday to buy the Numar Corporation, a maker of a device used to evaluate rock formations that contain oil and natural gas wells, in a stock swap valued at $360 million. Halliburton, a Dallas-based oilfield service company, will exchange 0.4832 of a share for each outstanding share of Numar, which is based in Malvern, Pa. The agreement values Numar at $39.62 a share, based on Halliburton's closing on Monday. Halliburton will exchange 0.9664 of a share if the acquisition closes after a 2-for-1 stock split, which the company also announced yesterday. The deal was announced after Halliburton shares had closed at $80.875, down $1.125. Numar's shares were unchanged at $20.75.

title: A Law Firm Takes Years To Find the Right Space
description: When the 112-year-old Atlanta-based law firm of King & Spalding recently signed a lease to move its New York offices to 1185 Avenue of the Americas, a small news article appeared. But behind that report were two years of planning and six months of negotiations, a combination of decision- and deal-making that provides a glimpse into the complex strategies and economic considerations of commercial real estate.

Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at 12th street, Garden City, Wednesday 7-9 pm and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 pm. title: WACHOVIA TO BUY VIRGINIA BANK FOR $542 MILLION
description: The Wachovia Corporation, making its long-awaited expansion into Virginia, agreed yesterday to acquire Jefferson Bankshares Inc. for $542 million in stock. The planned combination is the latest in a wave of mergers that is sweeping the industry. Wachovia, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., plans to exchange 0.625 share for each share of Jefferson, which is based in Charlottesville, Va. Based on Monday's closing stock prices, that values Jefferson at $38.83 a share. Yesterday, Jefferson stock jumped $7.75, or 25 percent, to $37.75, and Wachovia gained 12.5 cents, to $62.25. Wachovia has 473 branches in North Carolina, South Carolina and Georgia.

It steadied their grip on their adopted culture, with stories and advice on such varied things as baseball and schooling for girls. It strengthened their resolve, covering the struggles of the nascent labor movement. It gave them an unvarnished vision of the Golden Land.

description: JONES-Charles. The Juilliard School notes with sadness the passing of Charles Jones, distinguished member of the Juilliard faculty since 1954. description: Continuing a run of technology announcements by the cable television industry, Home Box Office said yesterday that it planned to begin offering digital high-definition programming in the summer of 1998.

title: Big Movies
description: After Fox's decision to spend a reported $80 million for one movie, Steven Spielberg's ''Lost World: Jurassic Park,'' CBS has made a more complicated but far less costly business arrangement with Warner Brothers to bring several big-budget movies to that network, including the forthcoming ''Batman and Robin''; ''Contact,'' with Jodie Foster, and ''Conspiracy Theory,'' with Mel Gibson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPERCQ, KATHLEEN D.
description: LEPERCQ-Kathleen D. Died June 7, 1997, of a heart attack. She is survived by a brother, Thomas Draper, of NYC. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Fund for Animals, Inc, 355 West 52nd Street, N.Y., New York 10019.

title: Yeltsin to Oust a Foe as Governor in Russia's Far East
description: Setting the stage for a sharp political and constitutional battle, a spokesman for President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that the President planned to remove from office the rebellious -- but extremely powerful and independently elected -- Governor of one of Russia's largest regions.

title: A British magazine stirs up a fuss over medical emergencies on United States airlines.
description: LONDON'S New Scientist magazine has kicked up a a stir in its current issue with an article declaring that on United States carriers, ''More airline passengers are dying from heart attacks and other medical emergencies than in plane crashes.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about criticism of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's borrowing plan for New Jersey's pension system misstated the amount she says the state would save. It is $45 billion, not $45 million.

title: As Rent Laws' Expiration Approaches, Pataki and Lawmakers See No Progress
description: Five days before the state laws limiting rent increases on 1.2 million apartments are to expire, Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Legislature met today for several hours -- their longest face-to-face discussions of the year -- but said they had made no progress toward a compromise on the rent issue.

title: Nickell's Bridge Team Wins
description: A star-studded bridge team led by Nick Nickell of Manhattan will represent the United States in world championship play in Tunisia in October.

title: Hayes Offers Apology
description: Charlie Hayes, who initially denied that he had been verbally abusive toward a Yankee fan in a Baltimore hotel last week, apologized to the fan during a 20-minute meeting yesterday in General Manager Bob Watson's office at Yankee Stadium. Besides the apology, the fan, Gary Perone of Staten Island, received three tickets to last night's game, dinner at the Stadium Club and an autographed bat and ball.

title: 1998 Season May Bring Four Mets-Yanks Games
description: The Mets and the Yankees would play each other four times, two games at each stadium, under a schedule being considered for the 1998 season, a baseball official familiar with discussions about interleague play said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MENOWITZ, SOPHIE
description: MENOWITZ-Sophie. (1914-1979). Gone but not forgotton these many years. We think of you always. Love from your family who meant so much to you.

title: Hearing Set on Interview
description: A judge said yesterday in Dover, Del., that he would hear arguments July 3 on whether an order barring public comment was violated last week when a television crew interviewed Amy Grossberg, the Wyckoff teen-ager accused, with her boyfriend, of killing her newborn baby in November.

title: Personal Health
description: A BRIGHT, fresh-looking Vanna White smile can often compensate for less attractive features and take years off a person's face. With dental decay now less troublesome, more people are turning their attention to improving the appearance of their teeth. For some, orthodontics to change the positioning of the teeth is the prime concern. But for ever-increasing numbers of patients, the issue is whitening of discolored teeth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITES, FRANK
description: LEVITES-Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Levites, associated with The Times from Oct. 1, 1965 until retiring in Dec. 1 1981.

title: Sport Utility Vehicles Pose Growing Danger to Car Occupants
description: The rising number of sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks on the nation's roads, combined with their increasing weight, poses a growing danger to car occupants and pedestrians, the Transportation Department concluded today in its first study of the issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITMARSH, THEODORE F.
description: WHITMARSH-Theodore F. The Huguenot Society of America records with great sorrow the death of Theodore F. Whitmarsh, a Life Member since 1967 and former President of the Society. William W. Reese, President

title: Christian Coalition Looking To Ex-Lawmaker as Leader
description: Former Representative Randy Tate, who was elected to Congress in the Republican wave of 1994 and ousted just two years later, will succeed Ralph Reed as executive director of the Christian Coalition, people close to the selection process said today.

title: Having What It Takes To Perform a Perfect 10
description: As a kid growing up in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, Chris Huffins wanted to be Julius Erving, not Bruce Jenner. His interest was basketball, not the decathlon. If he was to toss anything, it was to be a jump shot, not a javelin.

title: End the Stalemate on Rent Laws
description: The standoff over rent regulation in Albany is embarrassing the State Legislature and needlessly frightening more than a million families who live in apartments in the New York metropolitan area. Critical state business on matters like welfare reform, Medicaid and the ever-tardy state budget is so backed up that there is dwindling hope any will get the attention they require.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, JONATHAN
description: LEVIN-Jonathan. MUSIC * ENTERTAINMENT * MEDIA division of B'nai B'rith mourns the tragic and untimely death of Jonathan Levin. Our hearts ache for Jerry Levin and the entire Levin family to whom we extend our profound condolences. Louise E. Dembeck, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUEDERS, DUANE B.
description: LUEDERS-Duane B. Died June 6, 1997, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Hermine, father of Stephanie, Cynthia, Alison, and Duane, grandfather of Daniel, Alison, Warren, Tyler, Duane, and Mark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWSTADT, MRS. MILICENT (PENNY) BROWN
description: NEWSTADT-Mrs. Milicent (Penny) Brown, daughter of Judge Arthur and Helen Brown, now deceased, died on Sunday, June 8, on her 67th birthday following a short illness. Her husband David, children Tod and Tracy, and her best friend Peggy, were embracing her as she died peacefully. Penny lived in Danville, California at the time of her death. Many friends and neighbors tendered her loving care during her illness. Penny grew up in Woodbridge, NJ, and spend most of her life there, before moving to California with her husband in 1986. She graduated from Woodbridge High School, earned a BA degree from Syracuse University and an MA from Rutgers University. She then taught in Connecticut and Woodbridge Township schools. She was a good friend to many, but above all she was a self-effacing wife, mother, and grandmother, whose children and grandchild are her proud legacies. Services will be held on June 12 at the GreinerCostello Funeral Home, 44 Green Street, Woodbridge, NJ. Internment will follow at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, JOAN HOOPER
description: FISHER-Joan Hooper. On May 17, 1997. Wife of Samuel H. Mother of Samuel III and Jonathan. Grandmother of 4. Sister of Sarah, Debbie and Frederick. Interment at West Point, June 13, at 10 A.M.

title: Placenta and Dress Tested for Signs of Live Birth at Prom
description: Law enforcement officials said yesterday that they had obtained a search warrant that allowed them to seize the placenta and the blood-soaked dress of a young woman whose baby was born and died in a bathroom at her high school prom. They said that tests on these items along with an autopsy on the baby would help them determine whether criminal charges were warranted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALITA, MARMOUR, DEBBIE
description: SHALITA - MARMOUR - Debbie Temple Shaaray Tefila is filled with sorrow over her untimely death. She grew up in and was married in our synagogue. She shared her smile and laughter with all who knew her. We will sorely miss her. We extend our hearts and loving sympathy to her husband David, her parents Alan and Simone, to her twin sister Judy and all her family and friends. We will always remember her and pray for the comfort of those who loved her. Our sanctuary will embrace her one last time on Friday, June 13, at 11am. Harvey M. Tattelbaum, Rabbi Dr. Ellen R. Saxl, President

title: Shameless Gimmick: Bring It On
description: GET out your construction helmets; the Red Sox are coming to Shea Stadium Friday night. In journalistic language, this is big news: the man is biting the dog.

description: MICHEL-Mary G. 11 June 1986. Sweetest one, every family event, every celebration is so muted by your absence. Every day a heartache without your tender loving presence. We adore you always and everywhere.

title: Exhilaration Over a Wave Of Normality (Finally)
description: So what if yesterday did not turn out exactly the way the early-morning weather forecasters had said it would -- something about a high of 90 degrees in Manhattan, a first for the year, a sure footnote in the appropriate annals. The fact that the thermometer stopped climbing at 89 did not keep Jeff Herzog from stripping off his shirt. Finally.

title: Romantic Rival Is Arrested in 1996 Death of a Teen-Ager
description: When 17-year-old Curtisha Morning, a promising and popular senior at Riverhead High School, disappeared a year and a half ago, her parents repeatedly told the police that she was not the type of girl to run away from home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWER, HILDA
description: BERKOWER-Hilda. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Services on Thursday, at 11:30 A.M., Gramercy Chapels, 152 2nd Avenue, New York City.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Burundian refugees in Congo misstated the recent national name change. The country was Zaire and is now Congo, not the reverse.

title: French Cuisine Makes Way for Women
description: THE role of women in the French professional kitchen has changed significantly. Until recently, they couldn't get jobs and attained the title of chef only when they opened their own restaurants -- often modest extensions of home-style kitchens.

title: Of an Amerasian Youth In a Vietnamese Camp
description: The 13-year-old Amerasian hero of Rachid Bouchareb's engrossing adventure film ''Dust of Life'' is one of those rare children whose canny, expressive eyes convey a preternaturally advanced intelligence and wisdom. The child of a black American serviceman and a Vietnamese woman, the boy, named Son (Daniel Guyant), suddenly finds himself an outcast in 1975 when American troops, including his father, hastily evacuate Saigon.

title: Ordered to Ban Slaney, U.S. Reviews Its Options
description: Track and field's world governing body ordered Mary Slaney's entry withdrawn from the national championships today, but American officials did not immediately comply. Her status for the 1,500 meters remained uncertain as preliminary rounds approach on Friday.

title: France Signals Its Flexibility To Avoid a Crisis on the Euro
description: France's new Socialist Government signaled today that it was willing to be flexible to avoid a major crisis at a European summit meeting scheduled for Amsterdam next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTENSTREICH, ROSE TENE BAUM
description: ROTENSTREICH - Rose Tene baum. Died June 10, Birmingham, Alabama. Adored wife of the late Nathan Rotenstreich. Loving mother of Jon and Susan Rotenstreich, James and Judy Rotenstreich, Ferne Siegel. Cherished grandmother to 9 grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren. Her sense of fun, humor and wisdom touched everyone she met. She was a model of courage and strength for us all. Family request memorials sent to Grasman Endowment Fund, Temple Emanuel, Birmingham, Alabama.

title: How to Turn Horses Into Little Lambs
description: Forget about the bronco-busting you learned from all those Hollywood westerns. ''Taming the Wild Horses'' tells of a kinder, gentler approach that gets results faster.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFER, ROSE LIEBMAN
description: HOFFER-Rose Liebman. Died on June 10th. Pre-law NYU, LLB Brooklyn Law School, Doctor of Humane Letters, Honoris Causa, International University College at Aix En Provence, where she had been a Trustee. She was a retired NYC Administrative Law Judge, and in the 1970s she served as the U.N. Representative of the International Federation of Women Lawyers. She was a president of the Brooklyn Law School Alumni Association. The Law School honored her in appreciation for her generosity and dedication with a distinguished alumni award. A seminar room bears her name. She was also a past president of both the Bronx and Metropolitan Womens Bar Associations and on the Board of the Hias Womens Division. As an active member of the firm of Hoffer and Hoffer she participated in many landmark cases and appeared before the New York Court of Appeals and the US Supreme Court. She was also a past co-counsel and director of the Empire and Allcity Ins. Cos. Recently a lab for medical research was named in her honor at Yale. She is survived by her husband and law partner, Philip Hoffer and son Dr. Mark Hoffer of L.A. and his wife Margo and son Dr. Paul Hoffer of New Haven, sister Pauline and brother Bernard, eight grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Private family graveside services arranged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEB, JOSEPH
description: LIEB-Joseph, on June 10, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lillian, devoted father of Carolyn and the late Phyllis. Loving grandfather to Jennifer, Ellen, Elizabeth, Tom and Bill.

title: Former Black Panthers Leader Is Freed on Bail
description: To the cheers of now-graying colleagues from the tumultuous 1960's, Elmer Pratt, a former Black Panther leader, was released on bail today after serving 27 years in prison on a murder conviction he says was concocted by Federal officials bent on destroying the Panther organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONS, MELODY
description: ARONS-Melody. The faculty and staff of the Columbia University School of Public Health mourn the tragic loss of Melody Arons, daughter of our colleague and friend, Dr. Ray Arons. Ms. Arons died June 5 at the age of 29. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the family. Surviving are her father Ray, mother Marilyn, and son Jonathan. Donations may be made to the Parent Information Center of New Jersey, Inc., 210 Carlton Terrace, Teaneck, New Jersey 07666.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALITA, MARMOUR, DEBORAH
description: SHALITA - MARMOUR - Deborah, on June 10, 1997. Beloved wife of David Marmour; mother of Daniel; daughter of Simone and Alan Shalita; sister of Judith Shalita. Services Friday, 11am, at Congregation Shaaray Tefila, 79th Street and 2nd Avenue, NYC.

title: Slain Teacher's Kindness Is Recalled
description: The student sat on the high school's front stoop, his legs dangling and his body slouched. He looked like nothing so much as a human question mark, which was an apt posture for a teen-ager who could not decide whether to go up the steps to yesterday's memorial service for his murdered English teacher.

title: A New Look for British Air: Tail Fins in 50 Designs
description: British Airways sought yesterday to break from the copycat pattern of the airline industry, introducing a new look for its aircraft that includes about 50 different tail-fin designs from artists around the world.

title: Hunger in North Korea: A Relief Aide's Stark Report
description: An American relief expert who has just returned from a weeklong visit to North Korea said today that he had seen kindergarten classes where malnourished children were too weak to stand, and that he had driven along provincial city streets devoid of old people.

title: From Sinead O'Connor, Songs to Answer Her Own Prayers
description: Last month, Sinead O'Connor gave one of her friends a copy of her new mini-album, ''Gospel Oak.'' The friend decided to listen to it on her car stereo on the way to the park with her dog, who was overexcited and rambunctious, making driving difficult. But as soon as the music began, Ms. O'Connor said, ''the dog just totally fell asleep, passed over on the seat like a human.''

title: Motorola Kuwaiti Pact
description: Motorola Inc. has signed a contract worth $24 million to expand a digital cellular network in Kuwait. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., said the expansion would allow the Kuwaiti network operated by the Mobile Telecommunications Company to service more than 155,000 subscribers nationwide. Motorola developed the Kuwaiti network in 1994 for 50,000 subscribers.

title: New Chief Executive For New York Bank
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that its president, Thomas A. Renyi, will become chief executive on July 1, putting him closer to taking the helm of the bank's board when the chairman retires next year.

title: A Longtime Champion of Culture Turns 90
description: Today is the 90th birthday of Paul Mellon, who in one domain after another has done as much as anyone now living to improve the quality of American life. He has done it in museums and libraries, in schools and colleges, in landscapes saved from the developer, in riding and hiking trails open forever to nature lovers and, not least, in the thousands of acres acquired in 1952 in the Cape Hatteras National Seashore.

title: For Poorest Indians, Casinos Aren't Enough
description: The image of the Indian gambling casino as money machine evaporates among the destitute Oglala Sioux of the Pine Ridge Reservation. The casino here consists of three double-wide trailers stuck together on cinder blocks in a rutted lot with two rusty oil drums outside for trash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAAS, RAYMOND, J.
description: WAAS-Raymond, J. On June 3, 1997, of Harrisburg, Pa. Beloved son of the late Frank and Senja Waas. He is survived by his three nephews, Peter, David, Chris Waas, and a host of other relatives and friends. Services and internment will be held graveside June 14, 11 a.m. at Fairfield Memorial Park, Stamford, Ct.

title: Officer Kills Ex-Girlfriend And Himself On a Sidewalk
description: An off-duty police officer shot and killed his former girlfriend as she spoke on a pay telephone on a crowded Queens street corner yesterday evening, then killed himself with a shot to the head, the police said.

title: If Jordan Explodes, The Jazz Is Ready
description: The serious, almost baritone voice emanating from Michael Jordan sounded like something simmering today. And Utah's Bryon Russell could hear it.
