description: RICH-Harriet (nee Oser), of Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved wife of Maxwell. Devoted mother of Kenneth Rich and Richard Rich. Mother-in-law of Sylvia Rich. Loving grandmother of Karen Rich, Leslie Smith, Chris Rich, Debbie Rich, Nina Rich, Michael Rich, Beckie Rich, and Bonnie Rich. Great grandmother of Madeline Rich. Services New Montefiore Cemetery Farmingdale, N.Y., Thursday 1 PM. For information contact ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 1-800-522-0588.

title: Political Ideas Of McVeigh Are Subject At Bomb Trial
description: In their effort to save his life, lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh today showed a Federal jury the magazine articles and videotapes about the Federal raid near Waco, Tex., that they said convinced Mr. McVeigh that the Government had declared war on the American people.

title: New Jersey Blue Cross Takeover By For-Profit Insurer Is Canceled
description: Facing legal and regulatory challenges by New Jersey officials and consumer groups, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey called off plans yesterday to merge with a big for-profit Midwest insurance company, Anthem Inc. The merger, which did not involve a payment, would have created one of the nation's biggest health insurers.

title: Discrepancy in Cataract Surgery
description: MEDICARE patients who are in conventional fee-for-service health plans are twice as likely to have eye surgery for cataracts as those in a large Western health maintenance organization, a California study has found. The study suggests either that many people in fee-for-service plans are being operated on unnecessarily or that many in the H.M.O. are being denied needed surgery, the researchers said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Metro Business column yesterday about the sale of a former printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J., misstated the surname of a real estate broker for Insignia/Edward S. Gordon Company who represented the seller, The New York Times Company. The broker was Ben Katz, not Fox.

title: Clinton Rejects G.O.P. Tax Cuts as Unfair to Middle Class
description: President Clinton today rejected the Republican blueprint for apportioning proposed Federal tax cuts, saying it would shortchange the middle class and violate the terms of the balanced budget package agreed to by both parties last month.

title: Three Cheers For Jesse
description: Jesse Helms, bete noire of knee-jerk liberals, scourge of U.N. boondoggling, darling of rock-ribbed reactionaries -- is turning out to be the most effectively bipartisan chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee since Arthur Vandenberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIL, ARTHUR G.
description: HEIL-Arthur G. Of Stamford, Connecticut, on June 9, 1997. Graduate of Manhattan College, class of 1932. Father of Marie Hawe of Stamford. Also survived by three grandchildren and predeceased by his wife Mary Heil. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, 10:30 A.M., at Saint Leo's Church, Stamford.

title: Cordiant executives are setting goals for life after 'demerger.'
description: AS Cordiant P.L.C. proceeds with plans to divide its worldwide agencies into stand-alone companies, some top executives who will direct the destinies of the separated units are sharing their plans for life after the ''demerger.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODWIN, DONALD C.
description: GOODWIN-Donald C. The Board of Directors and Shareholders of 775 Park Avenue Corporation mourn the loss of Donald C. Goodwin. For many years his expert guidance and caring personality have been invaluable in managing the affairs of our building. With great gratitude, we extend our condolences to his son, Scott Goodwin. 765/775 Park Avenue John W. Espy, M.D., President

title: Partisans of the Old Sound Move On to Wagner and Bruckner
description: Things used to be simple. The early music movement was about playing early music, music that had been forgotten and therefore needed to be brought back to life. So it was necessary to learn how to play obsolete instruments, how to read kinds of musical notation that had been superseded, how to sing as people had sung before. Early music was early. It was performed by early music ensembles at early music festivals, including most naturally in this country the biennial Boston Early Music Festival, whose 1997 program opened yesterday.

title: Woods Fears Neither Course Nor Crowds
description: He is a celebrity, a role model, a groundbreaker, a multimillion dollar endorser of products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBI, JOHN MARTIN
description: JACOBI-John Martin, age 91, died on June 9, 1997 after a long illness. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy Jacobi, and beloved uncle of Evelyn Cousins, Patricia Hammond, and Ernest L. Bial. Services are private.

title: In Rockaways, a Plan Draws Mixed Reviews
description: George Williams was washing his 1985 Oldsmobile yesterday morning on an abandoned road in the Arverne area of the Rockaways, Queens, his back to the Atlantic Ocean, surrounded by blown-out tires and jettisoned car parts. Mr. Williams, 53, a letter carrier, moved to the area 30 years ago and remembered Arverne before the bulldozers cleared it of 4,000 bungalows in the late 1960's, leaving only rubble and the distinction of being one of the nation's most notorious examples of failed urban renewal.

title: G.O.P. EASES STAND IN RENT-LAW FIGHT
description: After a week of public relations miscues and falling poll numbers for Gov. George E. Pataki, Senate Republicans today gave ground on several crucial elements in the rent control battle, potentially giving the Republican Governor greater latitude to negotiate a compromise with Democrats who want the rent laws extended.

title: New Party Chief Expected
description: Thomas P. Giblin, who as chairman of the Essex County Democratic Party helped bring about Mr. McGreevey's victory in the June 3 primary, will be named state chairman of the party later this week, a member of Mr. McGreevy's campaign staff said yesterday. Mr. Giblin will replace B. Thomas Byrne Jr., who did not seek reappointment to the post. Senator McGreevey got 32,442 votes in Essex County out of a statewide total of 145,859.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, BRUCE J.
description: LEVY-Bruce J., 40, mathematician and manager, Research and Development at National Software Testing Laboratories in Wynnewood, Pa., Monday, June 9, 1997, of cancer. He is survived by his companion, Leslie Ann Bowman of Ardmore, Pa.; his parents, Dr. Sidney J. and Bobette Adler Levy of Chicago; his sister and brother-in-law, Joyce A. Levy and Christopher Egan also of Chicago; and many friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Bruce J. Levy Memorial Prize in Mathematics, C/O Anita Moore, Pomona College, 550-North College Avenue, Claremont, CA 91711 or your local Salvation Army.

title: Incentive to Sell Half Of Asea Brown Stake
description: Incentive A.B. agreed yesterday to sell half its stake in the Swedish-Swiss engineering company ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. for 12.4 billion kronor ($1.65 billion) to Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and Investor A.B. The move would keep a quarter of ABB's Stockholm-listed shares within Sweden's Wallenberg family, which controls both Incentive and Investor.

title: This Fight Night Could Feature a Fight
description: It's billed as Oscar Night at the Dome, a chance for the Golden Boy himself, Oscar De La Hoya, to dazzle an unranked challenger before a partisan Hispanic-American crowd. No pay-per-view, just an HBO telecast. No mythical pound-for-pound title on the line, just his World Boxing Council welterweight crown.

title: Contractors' Vans Seized
description: When Vincent Cama's mother went on vacation last summer, Mr. Cama figured he would surprise her by hiring a contractor to renovate the kitchen in their home in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.

title: Prices for Crude Oil Tumble On Report of Rise in Inventory
description: Crude oil prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a report showed that inventories in the United States were rising even as refiners operated at close to maximum rates.

title: Retreat by G.O.P. Brightens Prospects for Disaster Relief Bill
description: Faced with signs of growing public anger over delay in enactment of a disaster relief bill, and with desertions by the Republican rank and file, the Senate majority leader tonight signaled retreat from two provisions that led President Clinton to veto the legislation earlier this week.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, MICHAEL HARRISON
description: COHEN-Michael Harrison. It is 7 years since we lost you, that void will never be filled. Love Forever, Mom, Dad and Charles

title: Energizing Schools in a Burst of Color
description: THE Paint Lady swoops up the stairs to Intermediate School 57, an imposing 43-year-old yellow-brick building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Inside the front door are exuberant lime-yellow and yellow-orange walls.

title: Interleague Baseball: Let the Rivalries Begin
description: For the first time in major league baseball, teams from the American League will play teams from the National in regular-season games, beginning with four games tonight.

title: Norman Cleaveland, U.S. Rugby Olympian, 96
description: Norman Cleaveland, who won an Olympic gold medal as a member of the 1924 United States rugby team that beat a heavily favored French squad in Paris, died Sunday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 96.

title: A Highlight In a Career Of Highlights
description: WHEN he is old and tired and rocking by the fire, Michael Jordan should remember last night as one of the sweeter nights of his storybook career. He should remember the wild Delta Center crowd and the scary thought of going home to face the end of his championship dream, and possibly the 1990's, dynastic Chicago Bulls.

title: So Many Passions, All Right at Home
description: FOR anyone convinced that modern houses are antiseptic tanks inhospitable to passionate lives and human eccentricities, the late Dorothy Norman's residence at 124 East 70th Street offers eye-opening reproof.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFER, ROSE LIEBMAN
description: HOFFER-Rose Liebman. The Brooklyn Law School community notes with profound sadness the passing of Rose L. Hoffer, a member of the Class of 1954, and a distinguished and cherished alumnus. Her devotion to the Law School was reflected in her tireless service as President of the Law School Alumni Association, her generous scholarship aid to students, and support of the Capital Endowment Campaign. A woman of intellect, grace and good will, she will be deeply missed by all. We extend our deepest condolences to her beloved husband Philip, her children and grandchildren, and the entire family. Paul Windels, Jr. Chairman, Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean Hon. William C. Thompson Alumni Association President

title: Stock Prices Set Records For 4th Straight Session
description: Stocks set records yesterday for a fourth consecutive session as investors continued to be encouraged by meager inflation and stable interest rates.

description: Eleven of the 12 players who will represent the United States in the Bermuda Bowl World Team Championship in Tunisia in October are now known, and all of them have had successes at world level.

description: PARKING GARAGE COLLAPSES -- The first floor of a parking garage at a Queens shopping center collapsed, snarling traffic and disrupting subway service. B3.

description: Playing in his 41st United States Open, Jack Nicklaus will have the special treat of competing against his son Gary, who qualified for his first. The elder Nicklaus will tee off Thursday at 7:40 A.M., while the son tees off at 11:50 A.M.

title: INCO TO SELL UNIT FOR CASH TO DEVELOP NICKEL DEPOSIT
description: Inco Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Alloys International unit to the Blackstone Group L.P. for $410 million, raising money to develop its Voisey's Bay nickel deposit on the eastern coast of Canada. Inco said it expected the sale to give it a gain of $85 million. The final price paid by Blackstone, based in New York, could be adjusted before the sale is completed in a few months. Inco, based in Toronto and one of the world's largest suppliers of nickel, said it would use the money to repay debt, buy back shares and finance Voisey's Bay, which will cost $1.4 billion to develop and is expected to be one of the world's richest and lowest-cost nickel deposits.

title: Ameritech Plan Wins Approval
description: The Ameritech Corporation said Tuesday that Michigan regulators had approved its application to provide long-distance phone services, moving the local phone company one step closer to being the first Baby Bell to enter the long-distance market.

title: Europe Ruling Assured On British Air-American
description: The European Commission will rule on the planned trans-Atlantic alliance between British Airways P.L.C. and American Airlines well before November, a commission official said yesterday. The official, who asked not to be named, in accordance with European Union attribution rules, was responding to the British carrier's threat to abandon the alliance with American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, if it does not receive regulatory approval by November.

title: Sidney Silverstein, 70, Expert In Refurbishing Old Buildings
description: Sidney Silverstein, a New York carpenter who started at the bottom and became a nationally known expert in housing rehabilitation and a builder of affordable dwellings, died on Saturday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 70 and lived in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: Flashes of Energy and Funk
description: In every piece but one during Marc Cary's late set on Tuesday night at Sweet Basil, lightning struck his band. There was one flashing moment when the music couldn't get any hotter. The young pianist, who has undergone three of the few remaining old-school apprenticeships available to jazz players, with Arthur Taylor, Betty Carter and now Abbey Lincoln, likes to hit hard and fast. But he isn't simply a hammerer or a demon, and neither is anyone else in his band. He plays with a jumping energy informed by funk but not defined by it, and his septet was tenaciously present in the music.

title: Nose Up, Chin Up, In a Room of His Own
description: ''IF you live in squalor, you have to have order,'' Quentin Crisp says, squeezing past the piles that block his front door. ''I live in America in exactly the same way I lived in England. A room in a rooming house.''

title: Among the Not So Well Heeled of Gucci Gulch
description: The first benefits of the proposed 1997 tax cut began trickling down through the economy early this morning when the $10-an-hour professional standees arrived to hold places for the $300-an-hour lobbyists who would not show up until hours later for their seats in the big tax-pie hearing room.

title: Congo Under Laurent Kabila
description: The course taken by the new Government of Congo under Laurent Kabila will have important consequences for much of Africa. Nine other countries border on the vast, mineral-rich and strategically located land formerly known as Zaire, and the political and military dynamics in several of them have already begun to shift. So have regional perceptions of France and the United States. Paris lost prestige for sticking too long with the dictator of Zaire, Mobutu Sese Seko. Washington, though also a longtime Mobutu supporter, is now identified with the new Kabila Government.

title: Boy Drowns in Closed Pool
description: A 15-year-old Englewood boy who did not know how to swim drowned after he and a friend broke into a closed municipal pool Tuesday night, the police said.

title: Shabazz Undergoes A Fifth Operation
description: Dr. Betty Shabazz underwent her fifth operation in seven days yesterday to remove burned tissue from her body, a hospital spokeswoman said. She remained in extremely critical condition.

title: People
description: * Gil Bashe, executive managing director at Hill & Knowlton, New York, and worldwide director for health and pharmaceutical accounts, was named to the additional new position of vice chairman for strategic planning at Common Health, a health care communications agency that like Hill & Knowlton is owned by WPP Group.

description: * Nora McAniff, publisher of People magazine, a unit of the Time Inc. division of Time Warner Inc., was named president of Advertising Women of New York, succeeding Linda Urben, U. S. corporate advertising director at the AT&T Corp., New York.

title: Interleague Play Marks Its Place in Baseball History Books
description: On the eve of baseball's historic entry into interleague play, Don Zimmer, who has worn a baseball uniform so long that some people swear he was born in it, was recalling what made the sport in New York so unique four decades ago.

title: F.A.A. Caught in an Urban Policy Battle
description: A Federal Aviation Administration plan for a suburban-style office building near Kennedy International Airport is emerging as the center of a dispute over a little-known Presidential order that says Federal agencies should consider downtown areas when moving employees.

title: Coverage for Experimental Medicines Sought
description: Seeking to restrict the power of medical insurers to deny treatment, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed legislation today that would make it easier for terminally ill people to receive coverage for experimental procedures.

title: Test Troubles at CUNY
description: The City University of New York's board of trustees is well within its rights to insist that prospective graduates of the community college system pass a test that proves competency in English. But the trustees should make sure that the test they choose has been validated by credible research and taps the skills that the colleges want to measure. Meanwhile, the trustees erred when they issued a decree only days before graduation that would withhold diplomas from students who do not pass the exams.

title: Pacificorp Is Said to Reach Deal to Buy British Utility
description: Pacificorp has reached an oral agreement to acquire Energy Group P.L.C. of Britain for $6 billion in cash and is selling its big telecommunications subsidiary to help pay for the acquisition, a person familiar with the transaction said yesterday.

title: Ex-Manager at Theater Is Charged in Scalping
description: Complaints from a popular rock band that the best seats to its shows on Long Island had been siphoned off to scalpers and ticket brokers led to the indictment yesterday of the former box office manager of the Jones Beach Marine Theater.

title: Whitman Plans to Aid Youth
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will propose legislation today that is intended to improve the effectiveness of the beleaguered Division of Youth and Family Services, but Democrats are accusing her of belatedly trying to cash in on an issue that they have been trying to address for more than a year. The measure would increase the number of caseworkers and loosen the agency's strict confidentiality rules. Relatives of children under the division's supervision have complained that the rules often prevent them from getting urgent information.

description: Because of the second day of Shabuoth, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: INVESTORS SELL 6% STAKE IN MCKESSON FOR $216 MILLION
description: The McKesson Corporation said yesterday that an affiliate of Kelso & Company and other investors had sold the 6 percent stake of McKesson they acquired as a result of the company's acquisition of General Medical Inc. in February. The investors' sale of their 2.8 million shares, for $216 million, comes at a time when McKesson stock is trading at a record high. McKesson, based in San Francisco, is the largest United States supplier and distributor of drugs and health care supplies. Kelso Investment Partners IV L.L.P., an affiliate of the private investment firm in New York, held 1.77 million of the 2.8 million shares sold. Shares of McKesson fell 50 cents, to $76.75. They reached a record $78.625 on Monday.

title: Flights Delayed in the East
description: Air traffic around the eastern United States was slowed for nearly eight hours today because the main system for talking to airplanes in flight broke down at National Airport here.

title: Buckling Up -- Adults and Kids
description: The peak driving season has begun, but many who travel by car fail to take the simplest safety precautions. Surveys estimate that only about two-thirds of all adult drivers and passengers wear seat belts, and belt use for children is even lower. The National Transportation Safety Board, a Federal agency, estimates that auto fatalities could be reduced by 10,000 a year, from the current level of 40,000, if all adults wore their seat belts and children were properly restrained in the back seat.

title: Immunity Suggested in Campaign Inquiry, but Prospect Is Dim
description: Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, the Republican who heads the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses, has told associates that he wants to grant immunity from prosecution to at least 18 potential witnesses to obtain their testimony, but Democrats on the committee are expected to block the plan.

title: Gingrich Picks Republicans to Find Ways to Press China on Rights
description: Newt Gingrich, the House Speaker, has put together a group of prominent Republican legislators, some of whom favor continuing normal trading status for China and some of whom oppose it, and has asked them to come up with another approach to pushing the Chinese on human rights, their legal system and the general promotion of democracy, Congressional aides said today.

title: Pharmacia Moves 2 New Brands
description: The accounts of two pharmaceutical brands being acquired by Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. from units of Johnson & Johnson have been awarded to W. B. Doner & Company in Southfield, Mich., a roster agency of Pharmacia & Upjohn.

title: Robert Jones, 84, Ex-Alabama Congressman
description: Robert Emmett Jones Jr., an Alabama Democrat who served 30 years in the House of Representatives, where he helped speed passage of legislation creating the Interstate System of highways, died on June 4 at a hospital in Florence, Ala. He was 84, and a resident of Scottsboro, Ala.

title: Foster Care System Is So Strained, Children Sleep in Agency Offices
description: Hundreds of New York City's most troubled children are stranded in city offices, psychiatric hospitals and private homes because the child welfare system is virtually filled to capacity.

title: PART-OWNER OF PRICE COMMUNICATIONS QUESTIONS DEAL
description: Franklin Resources Inc. said yesterday that it thought the Price Communications Corporation's purchase of Palmer Wireless Inc. might not be in the shareholders' best interests. Price Communications, a television and radio station company based in New York, offered in May to acquire Palmer Wireless for $880 million, including several hundred million in debt. Franklin, which has a 31.5 percent stake in Price, said the deal's $17.50-a-share purchase price might not maximize shareholder value. The stock of Palmer Wireless, based in Fort Myers, Fla., closed yesterday at $15.25 a share, down 75 cents in Nasdaq trading. Franklin, a financial services company in San Mateo, Calif., said it thought Price Communications should re-examine the deal and explore other avenues.

title: Microsoft Joins Netscape on Software Privacy
description: The Microsoft Corporation announced yesterday that it would take the unusual step of agreeing with its archrival in the Internet market, Netscape, on a standard for privacy software.

title: Dell Computer Switches Agencies
description: The Dell Computer Corporation in Austin, Tex., has shifted its direct marketing account, for campaigns aimed at individuals and small businesses, to the Irving, Tex., office of Rapp Collins Worldwide, owned by Omnicom Group, from Lieber, Levett, Koenig, Farese, Babcock in New York. Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $10 million to $12 million.

title: Asian-American Is Named To Top Civil Rights Position
description: President Clinton will name Bill Lann Lee, an Asian-American lawyer from Los Angeles, to be Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights, the first person other than a white or African-American to hold the Government's top civil rights post, Administration officials said today.

title: An Ailing Jordan Is Just the Cure
description: They were supposed to be the ones providing the bedside manner, the ones who could make the flu-ridden Michael Jordan as comfortable as possible by taking the load off his slumped shoulders. But many of the Bulls simply watched in amazement tonight as Jordan (38 points) all but beat the Utah Jazz by himself in Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals.

title: Fraud Found In Registration Of Voters In Bosnia
description: Revealing a serious threat to the credibility of Bosnia's coming local elections, international monitors said today that voter registration fraud was so pervasive in the important city of Brcko that all registration centers would be closed, the local staff dismissed and registration started over again.

title: Kohl Finds His Pet Project May Prove His Undoing
description: For much of his 14 years in office as Europe's longest-serving leader and most enduring political colossus, Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl has behaved as if no crisis is so great that it cannot be postponed a day or two while tempers cool and back-room deals are brokered.

title: BANKBOSTON SELLS GANIS CREDIT TO UNIT OF DEUTSCHE BANK

Ganis Credit, based in Newport Beach, Calif., provides financing to recreational vehicle and marine boat consumers. The acquiring unit, Deutsche Financial Services, based in St. Louis, agreed to buy the personnel, systems and origination capabilities of Ganis.

title: Gooden Blasts Brass And Returns to Rotation
description: Ninety minutes before last night's game with the White Sox, a puzzled and perturbed Dwight Gooden criticized the Yankees for delaying an announcement about whether he would be activated to pitch on Sunday against the Florida Marlins. He said angrily that he would not have agreed to have hernia surgery last April if he had realized his return to the team would become so complicated.

title: Vaulting Toward Acceptance (After 15 Feet)
description: Having equaled the indoor world record of 14 feet 5 1/4 inches in the women's pole vault last March, Stacy Dragila and others in her sport are now seeking to raise the bar to Olympic acceptance. The good news is that the 2000 Summer Games will be held in Sydney, Australia, and the outdoor world record-holder, Emma George, just happens to be Australian.

description: FOR anyone looking for reasons why the mayor who won her first term here as an underdog in 1991 with 55 percent of the vote was returned to office in 1995 with 76 percent of the vote, the fountain is a good place to start.

The Maine Trading Company is at 36 West 25th Street; (212) 627-7195.

description: State Education Commissioner Richard Mills will announce today the removal of the administrators of two New York City schools where students continue to perform dismally despite the intervention of Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew over the last year, an official familiar with the situation said early this morning.

title: Mother's Neglect Arrest Called No Surprise
description: Blond and cute, but a little small for his age, Dennis Glotov, 7, is a familiar face in his neighborhood, a cluster of single- and two-family homes in a working-class area in Paterson, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODES, PAULINE
description: HODES-Pauline, 73, of Long Beach, NY and Ft. Lauderdale, FL on June 10, 1997. Devoted wife of Louis. Beloved mother of Laura Drexler and Arlene Raskin. Loving mother-in-law of Alan and Bruce. Cherished grandmother of Seth, Erica, Risa, Evan and Ian. Dear sister-in-law of Selma and Benjamin Schwaid. Pauline received her B.A. from Hunter College, MBA from NYU and Juris Doctor from Brooklyn Law School. She spent 22 years as a teacher at Island Trees H.S. She was a lifetime member of Hadassah and an active member of Temple Israel of Long Beach. First Commander of the Jewish War Veterans Auxiliary of Long Beach. Please omit flowers. For further information, please call Gutterman's at 516-764-9400.

title: G.O.P. in House Moves to Bar Minimum Wage for Workfare
description: Republicans in Congress moved today to make sure that tens of thousands of welfare recipients would not be covered by the minimum wage.

title: Seriously Goofy Awards From MTV
description: Putting aside comedy for a moment, Mike Myers announces a Lifetime Achievement Award to the actor who inspired him to go into show business. In one of those familiar taped montages, we range over the career of the honoree: Chewbacca, the Wookie from ''Star Wars.'' It's a short career. Highlights include an interview with Larry King, who asks that typical Hollywood question, ''Why do you think there are so few interesting roles for Wookies?'' For anyone who has dozed, squirmed or groused through the staid old Academy Awards show, the perfect antidote is ''The 1997 MTV Movie Awards.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMMONS, BENSON E.L. III
description: TIMMONS-Benson E.L. III, Ambassador, retired on June 11, 1997 at Southampton, N.Y. Survived by his devoted wife Sanya and his loving sons, Peter of Washington, D.C. and Nicholas of Richmond, VA. Services will be private.

title: Surprise Favorite Emerges in Race to Be the Tories' Next Leader
description: William Hague, the youngest and least experienced member of former Prime Minister John Major's Cabinet, emerged today in an increasingly divisive selection process as the surprise favorite in the race to be the Conservative Party's new leader.

title: Treasuries End Session Mostly Flat
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended mostly flat yesterday, as investors waited for what they hope will be favorable economic data for the bond market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRUGER, NICHOLAS ADAMS
description: CRUGER-Nicholas Adams. 5/20/ 22-6/9/97. Scion of the great, protector of the small. ''And if God wills, I'll love thee better still after death.'' Semper fidelis. Beatrice

title: Rights Group Urges Kenya to Widen Freedoms Before Election
description: The human rights organization Amnesty International said today that Kenya's general elections this year would not be fair unless constitutional reforms were carried out and repressive public-order laws were repealed.

title: 4 From a Deflated High-Flier Settle With U.S. for $456,000
description: Four former executives of T2 Medical Inc., a high-flying stock in the early 90's that later plunged, agreed to pay a total of more than $456,000 yesterday to settle regulatory charges that they had fraudulently inflated company earnings.

title: Congo's Dire Need for Help Will Test Mettle of Its New Leaders
description: The garbage has not been collected in most neighborhoods here in the capital in seven years. It has been that long since schoolteachers, police officers, firefighters, soldiers, nurses -- indeed, Government workers of any kind -- have been paid on a regular basis. And when they are paid now, a month's salary is just about enough to buy a loaf of bread.

title: French Socialists Say They'll Ease Up on Immigrant Crackdown
description: Moving quickly to carry out a campaign pledge to relax this country's tough immigration policies, France's new Socialist Government has promised to review requests for residence papers by tens of thousands of illegal immigrants who were threatened with deportation.

title: Heat Wilts Bus Service
description: As temperatures increased earlier this week, so did the number of New Jersey Transit buses suffering from engine failure. Of 1,600 buses in service on Tuesday, 47 broke down on the road or in garages, said Steven Coleman, a spokesman for the company. On average, he said, 20 buses malfunction each day.

title: American Topics
description: It's a real-life dilemma in toyland: Barbie's disabled friend, Share a Smile Becky, cannot fit into the elevator of the $100, two-story Barbie Dream House. Kjersti Johnson, 17, a high school student in Tacoma, Washington, who has cerebral palsy, complained about the Dream House's lack of access. "How ironic and true," she wrote. "Housing for people with disabilities that is not accessible!" Mattel said all future doll accessories will be wheelchair-accessibile. Thousands of Becky dolls have been sold since they were introduced in May.

title: Clean Up the Flood Aid
description: It was a huge flood, an epochal event, but the response of Congressional Republicans has been militantly petty. After imploring the nation to give them control of the chamber, their leaders seemed determined to show that they would rather use that power to play political games than pass a disaster relief bill to help the flooded towns and farms of the Upper Midwest. Now the restive rank-and-file seems to be forcing them to take the proper course.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK TO BUY SIGNET'S CORPORATE-TRUST UNIT
description: The Signet Banking Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its corporate-trust business to the Bank of New York Company. Terms were not disclosed. Bank of New York will acquire 700 bond trustee and agency relationships in the transaction, primarily for municipalities in Virginia and Maryland. Bank of New York said the acquisition would add to earnings immediately after completion of the transaction, expected in the third quarter. Signet, based in Richmond, said in March that rapid consolidation of corporate trust operations was giving the big companies advantages in pricing and service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEEHAN, MARY JANE (NEE FLEMING)
description: SHEEHAN-Mary Jane (nee Fleming). The twelve Sheehan children mourn the passing of their mother who died peacefully at home Tuesday in Ocean Grove, NJ. Wife of the late Dr. George Sheehan. Visitation Thursday and Friday, 24 and 7-9 PM, John E. Day Funeral Home, Red Bank, NJ. Funeral Mass 10 AM, Saturday, Holy Cross R.C. Church, Rumson, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to Madonna House, 1139 Corlies Avenue, Neptune, NJ 07753.

title: Mother Said to Leave Baby
description: A 19-year-old girl was arrested yesterday, accused of leaving her newborn baby overnight in the garage of her home, wrapped only in a blanket, the Jersey City police said. The girl, Claudette Felix, told the police that she tried to hide the baby from her parents until she could put it up for adoption, said Beverly Frazier, a police spokeswoman. The baby was taken to Jersey City Medical Center, where it was listed in stable condition, a nursing supervisor said.

title: U.S. Proposal Underwhelms U.N. Members
description: Diplomats and United Nations officials were less than enthusiastic today about a deal worked out between the Clinton Administration and the Senate that would allow payment of a large part of the American debt to the organization, but with substantial strings attached.

title: Poor Pain Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Delivering a Big Blow to the Death Tax
description: Daisy Crowder says she is not a rich person, but she is angry that the Federal Government might treat her like one when she dies, by levying a hefty inheritance tax on the small stoneworking and construction company that she and her husband have built from scratch in Newport, Tenn.

title: No Headline
description: ''Yes, I am pleading for my son. But he is a human being, just as we all are.''

title: FIRST UNITED BANCSHARES TO BUY RIVAL BANK COMPANY
description: First United Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it planned to acquire Citizens National Bancshares of Hope, Ark., for 1.6 million common shares, or $61.6 million. First United's stock closed yesterday at $39.25, down 25 cents in Nasdaq trading. The deal was announced after the market closed. First United, based in El Dorado, Ark., expects to close the deal in the fourth quarter. Citizens is the parent company of Citizens National Bank, which has branches in Hope and Texarkana, Ark. As of March 31, Citizens had assets of $263 million and net income of $918,000. First United has $1.56 billion in assets.

title: Strategist Helps Owners Lobby for Their Concerns
description: In the cacophonous battle over the future of rent controls, New York's largest landlord group, the Rent Stabilization Association, has long complained that its voice gets drowned out in a city of renters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, ELEANORE GRACE LOURIA
description: BLUM-Eleanore Grace Louria. Peacefully, at home, just a few days after her 104th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Richard Leon Blum, loving mother of Howard and the late Richard Jr., adoring grandmother of Howard Jr., Thomas, William, Eleanore, Richard III, Cornelius, and her six greatgrandchildren, Tripp, Ross, Mathew, Eric, Daniel, and Sarah. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Recreation Rooms and Settlement.

title: After Four Centuries, Shakespeare Comes to Life in His Natural Habitat
description: So finally, almost four centuries later, the prologue to ''Henry V'' seemed to make sense as Mark Rylance, the actor playing King Harry of England, stood at the front of the stage in the replica of Shakespeare's Globe Theater and asked: ''Can this cockpit hold the vasty fields of France? Or may we cram within this wooden O the very casques that did affright the air at Agincourt?''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICATIONS INC., San Antonio, a broadcasting concern, agreed to acquire 30 percent of American Tower Corp., of Webster, Tex., an owner of domestic wireless communications towers, for $32.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, EVALYN
description: STEIN-Evalyn. Wife of Arthur for 56 years. Mother, sister and grandmother. Services will be held at Union Field Cemetery, Ridgewood, NY, 11 AM, Friday, June 13.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Joins Netscape In On-Line Privacy Plan

title: Stars-to-Be Get Their Chance to Shine
description: There is always an extra buzz of anticipation to the annual Workshop performances presented by the School of American Ballet. And the ballets by George Balanchine -- presented on Monday night as well as on Saturday at the Juilliard Theater by the school, an affiliate of the New York City Ballet -- were even more exciting than usual. In part this was because of the inspired selection of repertory, but most of all it was because of the dancing.

title: Top Officer Needn't Be Flawless, Cohen Says
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said tonight that he would not insist that the officer selected as the next Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff have a ''blemish-free'' sexual history, even though an admission of adultery doomed the candidacy of the Air Force general originally in line for the job.

title: Murdoch Set To Buy Family Cable Concern
description: At first glance, it would appear to be a merger of the sacred and profane.

title: Novartis is latest rival to accuse Schering-Plough of unfairly attacking its product.
description: FOR the second time this year, the Schering-Plough Corporation has angered a competitor over advertising that the rival says promotes Schering products by taking unfair shots at other brands.

title: Fears of the Powerless
description: To the Editor:

title: USA Track Suspends Slaney, Too
description: Mary Slaney, America's greatest female distance runner, was prohibited today from competing in the national track and field championships after being suspended for a disputed drug test taken nearly a year ago at the Olympic trials.

title: The Ultimate Test of Good, Bad and Ugly
description: The course will be challenging. The bogeys will be plentiful. The competition will be intense. And the drama could be memorable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODLE, JESSICA SLOCUM
description: WOODLE-Jessica Slocum. Of NYC and Nantucket, MA. On June 10, 1997. She was the daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. C. Jonathan Slocum, widow of Joseph Cass Woodle, mother of Peter Cass Woodle, who predeceased her, and Joanne Slocum Woodle, MD. Grandmother of Gage and Alexandra Fairey. She is also survived by her brother Jonathan Slocum, MD. She was a member of The National Society of Colonial Dames, The Cosmopolitan Club, The City Garden Club of NYC, The Nantucket Garden Club, and The Nantucket Yacht Club. At her request there will be no memorial service. Contributions in her memory to The Nantucket Conservation Foundation would be appreciated in lieu of flowers.

title: INSIDE
description: Memo About a Lunch

title: Domestic Affairs
description: As we all have heard, ad nauseam, the motto of the '92 Clinton campaign was ''It's the economy, stupid.'' And as we all know, President Clinton's various personal problems with the likes of Paula Jones are not hurting him the least in the polls, because the economy is soaring. The logical conclusion is that the President's private life doesn't matter for the country.

title: Jordan Propels Bulls
description: Michael Jordan, overcoming a stomach ailment, hit a 3-pointer with 25 seconds left in the game and scored 38 points last night as the Chicago Bulls beat the Utah Jazz, 90-88, in Salt Lake City to take a 3-2 lead in the N.B.A. championship series.

title: Injuries Take Toll On Mets In Loss
description: Though injuries have decimated the Mets this season, they've won anyway, and that is part of their charm. But they are being stretched to the breaking point on the eve of interleague play.

title: From Cabinet To Leadership Of Coalition
description: Reaching back to the Reagan years, the Christian Coalition announced today that the group's new president would be Donald P. Hodel, a former Secretary of Interior and Secretary of Energy, who will work alongside former Representative Randy Tate, the new executive director.

title: Not Even Mostly Mozart, but Clearly Some
description: To the satisfaction of leading scholars, an Iowa musicologist has amassed strong evidence that portions of two little-known Viennese operas were written by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart in the prolific and unsettled year before his death.

title: Ex-Convict, 70, Says Reports of Child Rape Are Just Lies Concocted by a Spiteful Son
description: Even out here in the Southern California desert, half an hour on a dusty road from the nearest town and 3,000 miles from New Jersey, Edward James Howard has heard the stories about the days he was known as Charles W. Timmendequas of Plainfield, N.J. He knows he is all over the news as a sexual sadist who preyed on his children, turning one of them, Jesse K. Timmendequas, into a pedophile and killer. ''But it's all lies,'' he said. ''All of it.''

title: With a Sale, Murdoch Will End Direct-Broadcast Bid
description: As if making a deal to acquire Pat Robertson's Family Channel was not enough, Rupert Murdoch also struck a $1.1 billion agreement yesterday with a consortium of big cable television operators that would remove Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation from an active role in America's direct-broadcast satellite market.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corruption Investigation Widens to Include School
description: A Federal corruption investigation involving a Brooklyn social services group has widened as prosecutors try to determine what happened to hundreds of thousands of dollars in government funds that the group paid to a computer training school, according to court documents.

title: McVEIGH'S PARENTS ASK JURY TO SPARE LIFE OF THEIR SON
description: Mildred Frazer flashed her son, Timothy J. McVeigh, a mother's smile and a silent greeting as she entered the Federal courtroom today. Then she took the stand to ask the jury in the Oklahoma City bombing case to spare his life.

title: Rogers Gets An Earful, And Yanks Stage Rally
description: Kenny Rogers heard assorted boos in the first inning last night, heard the noise increase by the third inning, heard the howling escalate by the fourth and then needed earplugs by the fifth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELELLA, CARMELLA. (NEE CHIAVARO)
description: VELELLA-Carmella. (Nee Chiavaro). Beloved wife of Vincent. Dearest mother of Connie Tudisco, Maria Collura and Senator Guy Velella. Also survived by ten grandchildren and eleven greatgrandchildren. Reposing at Ralph Giordano Funeral Home, 1727 Crosby Avenue, Bronx, Thursday and Friday, from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass Our Lady of Mount Carmel, 116th Street, Manhattan, Saturday, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, all donations to: St. Jude Shrine, 512 West Saratoga Street, Baltimore, Maryland 21201.

title: Part of a Parking Garage Collapses in Queens
description: The first floor of a four-level parking garage behind the Sears shopping center in Rego Park, Queens, collapsed yesterday after a support beam buckled, Fire Department investigators said.

title: Bluma L. Trell, 94, Professor And Expert on Greece, Dies
description: Bluma L. Trell, whose unbridled enthusiasm brought ancient Greece alive to a generation of New York University students even as her meticulous research into ancient coins had given scholars their first definitive view of the Temple of Artemis at Ephesus, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Englewood, N.J. She was 94 and had lived until last year on Bleecker Street in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMANT, FRED J.
description: DIAMANT-Fred J. Beloved husband of Ena. Devoted father of Vivian Goldberg, Gregory Diamant, and stepfather of Diana Forino. Loving grandfather of Raphael and Caroline Cabasso, Deanne, Andrea, Allison Forino, and Cass Vanini. Services on Thursday, 10:45 AM, ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, IRNIE
description: SIMON-Irnie. With great sadness and sorrow the entire staff of Edmar mourns the untimely passing of its president Irnie Simon, a leader always striving towards excellence in the business world, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Jeanne, mother Henrietta, brother David, and children, Dana, Brian, Richard and Adam. Edmar Family

title: Personal Files Via Computer Offer Money and Pose Threat
description: It was past midnight when Beverly Dennis came home, weary from her second-shift factory job, and found a letter with a Texas postmark among the bills and circulars in the day's mail. As she read it in her small house in Massillon, Ohio, alone in the dark stare of the sliding glass doors, her curiosity turned to fear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALBERTIS, SARA B. (SALLY)
description: ALBERTIS-Sara B. (Sally) 3/17/056/8/97. Farewell to our dear beloved friend. She was a great lady, a woman ahead of the times. An artist, inventor, young at heart, and a lover of life. She will be missed by all of her friends. With love Debbie, Steve, Todd, and Liza Garrin

title: Prudential Names Insurance Unit Chief
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America has named John V. Scicutella to head its insurance unit, replacing an executive who quit after less than two years on the job.

title: Pressured, House Chairman Modifies Tax Plan
description: Under pressure from various interest groups, the Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee modified his tax-cutting plan slightly today, even before he dealt with demands for wholesale changes from the Clinton Administration and the committee's Democrats.

title: Transforming Botanical Cinderellas
description: THE last time revolution swept the kid-glove world of flower arranging was back in the 1920's, when Constance Spry, a London flower designer with an eccentric eye, ornamented Mayfair drawing rooms with weeds and greengrocer produce.

title: New Format Offers Market Opportunities
description: When fans enter Shea Stadium tomorrow night for the Red Sox-Mets series, 20,000 will get water filters to celebrate the start of interleague play. On Saturday, kids will receive Mets shorts. What, no commemorative coins to honor Pumpsie Green, who played for both teams, or Bill Buckner inaction figures?

title: After Foxwoods, Pequots Turn to Building Ferries
description: The Mashantucket Pequot Indians of Connecticut do not do things halfway. The tribe has made millions as owners of Foxwoods Casino, building and rebuilding their resort in the eastern Connecticut woods until today Foxwoods is considered one of the most profitable gambling halls in the world.

title: Legislature Is in Session, All 2 of Them
description: JAMES F. BRENNAN, a Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn, pondered the idea for a split second, then dismissed it as too profoundly wacky to merit further consideration.

title: Cable Deal Creates Not-So-Odd Couple
description: At first glance, a deal between Rupert Murdoch and Pat Robertson may appear to be a marriage of the sacred and the profane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFER, ROSE
description: HOFFER-Rose. We extend our deepest sympathies to our colleauge and friend, Philip Hoffer and his entire family, on the loss of his beloved wife Rose. Dinkes & Morelli

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the early music movement misidentified one of the American schools at which musicians are trained in period-performance styles. It is the Mannes School of Music, not the Manhattan School of Music.

title: After a Workshop, 8 Chamber Groups Brave Carnegie Hall
description: The people who run Carnegie Hall could get by well enough just putting on concerts. But happily for us they share the noble view that music is less a commercial enterprise than a cultural adventure and one that gives them responsibilities to the future as well as to the present: hence their commitment to training programs like the Isaac Stern Chamber Music Workshop.

title: Sallie Mae Head to Resign; Hopes to Break Stalemate
description: Seeking to break what has been a bitter, protracted fight for control of the Student Loan Marketing Association, Lawrence A. Hough, the chief executive, said yesterday that he would resign from the company as soon as a successor could be found.

title: Make A.T.M.'s Safer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARGIULO, HELEN A.
description: GARGIULO-Helen A., 79, died June 10 in Monterey, CA. Born February 4, 1918 in New York, NY, she was a legal secretary for the State of New York for 37 years. A graduate of Hunter College, she moved to Pacific Grove, CA. a year ago after living in New York all her life. Survived by son, Ted Gargiulo, Jr., Pacific Grove, CA; brother, Victor Grande, Long Island, NY; sister, Italia Mainland, Monterey, CA; 2 grandchildren. No services will be held. Contributions to Hospice of the Central Coast, P O Box 1798, Monterey, CA. 93942.

title: Kodak Plans a Purchase
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it would buy the digital photography services company Applied Network Solutions Inc. for an undisclosed amount, increasing its products for the entertainment market. The closely held Applied Network Solutions, of Rancho Cucamonga, Calif., would be dissolved and its top officials would become members of Kodak's themed entertainment unit, which provides digital-based images at theme parks, sporting events and other sites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIETSCHE, ALPHONSUS A.
description: DIETSCHE-Alphonsus A., on June 9, 1997. Retired employee of U.S. Catholic Conference. Beloved husband of the late Clare. Loving father of Christine Pfeifer, Clare Murphy, Kathleen Dietsche and Rosanne Carroll. Dear grandfather of 7. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street. Funeral Mass today, Holy Family R.C. Church, 9:15 A.M. Interment in Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARCOFF, SYLVIA
description: SHARCOFF-Sylvia, on June 10, 1997, in Pompano Beach. Lovingly remembered by children, grandchildren, great grandchildren and dear friends. Graveside service at 2:30 on Friday at Cedar Park, Westwood, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, MICHEL
description: BRODSKY - Michel. Beloved brother of the late Viva Chagall, devoted friend and supporter of the arts by family and friends. Died June 5 in Paris, France. Funeral Friday June 13, 3:30 P.M., at Cemetery of St. Paul de Vence. In sadness. Piet, Meret and Bella Meyer

title: Long Live A Truly Good Scare
description: Few films survive in theaters beyond a month. Far fewer linger after two or three months.

title: Sporting Goods Retailers Start to Consider New Lineups
description: For months Wall Street has speculated that sporting goods retailers would begin to merge or acquire one another, simply because there are too many of them. But the retailers seemed to resist, apparently convinced that they could make it on their own, even though Sports Authority Inc. was beating all the others over the head.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODWIN, DONALD C.
description: GOODWIN-Donald C. The Board of Directors and shareholders of 960 5th Avenue mourn the loss of Donald C. Goodwin. His invaluable guidance will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his son Scott Goodwin.

title: Decontrol Threat Brings Renters' Advocate to Fore
description: Michael McKee was directing traffic at a protest outside Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's Manhattan office a few days ago, writing names and phone numbers, talking with several reporters and listening patiently to an elderly woman's woes, when someone grabbed his arm and muttered a few words.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Dr. Katz is holding a reunion of his patients tonight at Catch a Rising Star, a club on West 28th Street. Sounds like a Freudian slip?

title: Officer Subject Of a Complaint Before Shooting
description: A police officer who killed his former girlfriend and himself in Queens on Tuesday had been the subject of a harassment complaint she filed two weeks ago, and the Police Department's Internal Affairs Bureau had been planning to question him about it, police officials said yesterday.

title: Police Say Mother Left Newborn Baby in Garage
description: A 19-year-old woman was arrested yesterday, accused of leaving her newborn baby overnight in the garage of her home, wrapped only in a blanket, the Jersey City police said.

title: Bill Gates Goes Vertical
description: The announcement this week that the Microsoft Corporation, the 800-pound gorilla of computer software, is buying an 11.5 percent interest in Comcast, the nation's fourth-largest cable television operator, may be one of those signal moments that realign the entire entertainment-information industry.

title: Time Warner Stock Price Reaches $50
description: There were no speeches or toasts, but Time Warner hit a milestone freighted with symbolism yesterday. The company's stock closed at $50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. That is an all-time high for a company that has gasped and wheezed on the stock market ever since it was formed by the 1989 merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALITA, MARMOUR, DEBORAH
description: SHALITA - MARMOUR - Deborah, on June 10, 1997. Beloved wife of David Marmour; mother of Daniel; daughter of Simone and Alan Shalita; sister of Judith Shalita. Services Friday, 11am, at Congregation Shaaray Tefila, 79th Street and 2nd Avenue, NYC.

title: Italy and France Wrap Up Tournament in a Deadlock
description: The 2-2 tie between France and Italy in the final game of the Tournoi de France tonight might lead casual American observers to believe that little has changed in international soccer since 1994, when Brazil and Italy played a scoreless tie in the World Cup final and had to decide it all rather unsatisfactorily with penalty kicks.

title: U.S. Sues to Block Merger Plan of 2 Long Island Hospitals
description: The Justice Department filed suit yesterday to block the merger of two of Long Island's largest hospital networks, Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems. The lawsuit contends that the merger would violate antitrust laws, lead to higher hospital rates and inhibit the development of competing hospital systems.

title: Tricky Footwork by a Trio
description: It wasn't the proverbial indisposition that made Janet Orenstein, the violinist of the Guild Trio, miss the group's concert on Sunday afternoon at Kaye Playhouse.

title: How Bosnia Policy Set Stage For Albright-Cohen Conflict
description: At a White House meeting on May 16, the long-simmering policy debate between Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Defense Secretary William S. Cohen over how to revive America's stagnant Bosnia policy finally came to a boil.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Dow Jones in some editions of the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about an alliance between America Online Inc. and CUC International Inc. understated CUC's annual revenue and misidentified the company whose membership is expected to surge because of the alliance. CUC's revenue exceeded $2 billion in its most recent fiscal year; it was not merely $1 billion-plus. In addition, it is CUC, not America Online, that expects to gain a million annual memberships.

title: Capitalism doesn't always take. Location, it seems, is destiny.
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom these days says that economic development is largely a matter of getting political and economic institutions right, then letting private enterprise flourish. And in recent years this sanguine view of free enterprise has proved prophetic: most economies that have opened their borders and deregulated markets are growing rapidly. So when Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Institute for International Development at Harvard and definitely of the glass-is-half-full school, admits to gloomy thoughts, the world takes notice.

title: A Republican for Rent Regulation
description: When my wife and I married more than 30 years ago, we moved into an apartment in Glen Oaks, a sprawling complex on the eastern edge of Queens providing affordable housing for young families.

title: Pulling the Strings (and Catching Malaria) for the Met's Most Complex Show
description: When Mahrukh Tarapor, the Metropolitan Museum of Art's associate director for exhibitions, innocently accepted the task of assembling more than 350 precious objects from 24 countries nearly four years ago for the museum's ''Glory of Byzantium'' exhibition, she knew that her mission impossible would require persistence as well as diplomatic ingenuity. After all, many of the objects were sacred and they were held in 117 collections.

title: When Money Counts
description: IF it's true that everything tastes better by candlelight, think of lanterns as condiments. Lanterns are everywhere this summer -- which means you can even put those tired old Christmas lights to new uses.

title: Amasa S. Bishop, 76, Scientist Who Worked in Fusion Physics
description: Amasa Stone Bishop, an American nuclear scientist specializing in fusion physics who took up environmental causes under United Nations auspices, died on May 21 at Clinique de Genolier, near Geneva, Switzerland. A resident of Genolier, he was 76.

title: U.S. Racing Hitting Bumpy Roads
description: The consensus among the sport's professionals is that bicycle road racing is now in a trough in the United States, after having ridden the crest of a wave for more than a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURCH, PETER J.
description: BURCH-Peter J., 71, of Hendersonville, NC, on June 11 at Pardee Hospital. Thomas Shepherd & Son Funeral Home: 704-693-3435.

title: Ex-Gov. Hunt of Alabama Cleared by Pardon Board
description: Guy Hunt, the former Governor whose criminal conviction while in office in 1993 stood out even in the rough-and-tumble world of Alabama politics, was exonerated today by the state pardon board he largely appointed.

title: Trump Wins a Slot Room
description: Donald Trump scored a victory yesterday when the State Casino Control Commission gave him permission to set up a room containing 172 slot machines on the Boardwalk side of his Taj Mahal Casino. The commission balked at the proposal when it first came up for a vote last week because the original plan called for the room to include a series of folding doors that could be left open, providing easy access from the Boardwalk for children or vagrants, said Gloria Ford, a spokeswoman for the commission.

title: Gene Atkins Hill, 69, Columnist For Field & Stream Magazine
description: Gene Atkins Hill, the writer who created the cozy, sun-dappled place called ''Hill Country'' in Field & Stream magazine, died in Tucson, Ariz., on May 31. Mr. Hill, who lived in the New York area for most of his life, was 69.

title: F.A.A. Excoriated on Failure To Hire More Air Controllers
description: A parade of witnesses, including several members of Congress, gave descriptions of the Federal Aviation Administration today that were even less flattering than usual at a Senate subcommittee hearing on staff shortages at control towers and air traffic control centers in the New York area.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a proposed acquisition of International Family Entertainment Inc., which owns the Family Channel, misattributed a quotation. It was Tim Robertson, the chief executive of International Family, not his father, Pat Robertson, who said of the action, by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, ''We felt it was time for the Family Channel to join the consolidation that was going on in the industry.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEEDS, MORTON
description: LEEDS-Morton. 6/13/84... ''To reach the port of heaven, we must sail sometimes with the wind and sometimes against it, but we must sail and not drift nor lie at anchor''.

title: R. R. Bahadur, 73; Created Statistical Concept
description: Raghu Raj Bahadur, a professor emeritus at the University of Chicago who was considered one of the architects of the modern theory of mathematical statistics, died on Saturday in Chicago. He was 73.

title: Better Tool to Judge
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSCRYPT TO PAY $34 MILLION FOR E F JOHNSON
description: Transcrypt International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the E F Johnson Company, a closely held wireless communications company, for $34 million. Transcrypt, based in Lincoln, Neb., makes information security and wireless communications products. Transcrypt will pay for the purchase in cash or debt assumed at closing. Transcrypt, which went public in January, had 1996 revenue of $13.8 million. E F Johnson, which is based in Waseca, Minn., had full-year revenue of $79.3 million. Shares of Transcrypt rose 75 cents yesterday, to $11, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Orthodox Israelis Assault Jews Praying at Western Wall
description: Conservative Jewish men and women who tried to pray together at the Western Wall during the Shavuot holiday early Wednesday morning said today that they had been assaulted by hundreds of rigorously Orthodox men evidently incensed by the sight of women praying with men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPOPORT, GENIA
description: RAPOPORT-Genia. Dear Kalia, our hearts go out to you & Lenny & the entire Rapoport family. All our love, Jane & Joseph Pontarelli

title: When It Comes to Stock Funds, Investors Can't Seem to Say No
description: Six and a half years into a record-breaking bull market, American investors have crossed a threshold, committing more than half of their mutual fund assets to stocks, double the level at the beginning of the decade.

title: Miler Misses Out on a Family Affair
description: This was the worst day so far for Paul McMullen, America's top miler, since he severed parts of two toes in a lawn-mowing accident last week.

title: USA WASTE SERVICES IN $312 MILLION EXPANSION
description: USA Waste Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire certain assets from Browning-Ferris Industries of Houston and Allied Waste Industries of Scottsdale, Ariz., as well as the assets of two closely held waste companies for $312 million in stock and cash. USA Waste, which is also based in Houston, is the nation's third-largest trash hauler and owns landfills, recycling centers and transfer stations. The Browning-Ferris assets it acquired, which have annual revenue of $125 million, include 12 collection and hauling operations, two landfills, one transfer station and one materials recovery facility. The Allied Waste assets have annual revenue of $34 million. The assets acquired from the two private solid waste companies were worth $70 million. USA Waste Services shares closed unchanged at $36.875.

title: A Moody Thriller to Check Against History Soon
description: KOWLOON TONG

title: Hong Kong When It Was Young
description: STAIDLY English and exotically Chinese, Hong Kong became a photographer's mecca after the British took it over in 1841. As the crown colony on the South China Sea developed from a barren rock into a bustling metropolis, Westerners and Asians -- among them Felice Beato, John Thomson, Lai Afong, Pun Lun, William Pryor Floyd and the American Milton M. Miller -- recorded its scenes and events, selling images of prospering Hong Kong to itself and the rest of the world.

description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: The first thing you notice about the Park is the chandeliers. They are breathtaking Baccarat. Then you gradually begin to pay attention to the rest of the dining room. It's a grand space, so elegantly and expensively refurbished that people all around can be heard exclaiming, ''I'm bringing my decorator to see this!''

title: LESLIE'S POOLMART TAKEN PRIVATE IN $140 MILLION DEAL
description: Leslie's Poolmart Inc., a swimming pool supply retailer based in Chatsworth, Calif., said yesterday that it had been acquired by management in a private transaction valued at $140 million. In November, a bid was submitted by Hancock Park Associates II, a partnership involving Leslie's Poolmart's chairman, Michael J. Fourticq; the chief executive, Brian P. McDermott, and Leonard Green & Partners L.P., a Los Angeles investment firm. They offered $14.50 a share for the company's common shares. The stock was delisted from the Nasdaq stock market on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, RABBI ARTHUR
description: DAVID-Rabbi Arthur, on June 11, 1997. Beloved husband of Mildred. Devoted father of Miriam and Jonathan, and father-in-law of Kenneth and Heli. Cherished grandfather of Hannah, Emily and Nora Gray, and of Samuel David. Loving brother of Morton. Senior Chaplain, Nassau County Police Dept. He will be remembered always for his devotion to Judaism, love of learning, and respect for his fellow man. Services Friday 1:30 PM, Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 516-295-3100. Contributions in his memory to The Jewish Theological Seminary of America will be appreciated.

title: Sexual Morality Has Long Baffled U.S. Military
description: To the Editor:

title: Disney Parade About to Turn Midtown Goofy
description: The Irish get one; so do the Puerto Ricans and the Germans and the Jews and the Turks. And really, there is no better way to accent one's unique contribution to New York City's cultural stew than with a parade up Fifth Avenue. So why not Disney, whose arrival in Manhattan passes for a cultural revolution? After all, what's Disney -- chopped mouse ears?

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: 'Self-Acceptance' Won't Help the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Producers' Group Presents Awards
description: Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., and @radical.media in New York won the most awards in their classes at the sixth annual Association of Independent Commercial Producers Show in New York.

title: Electrolux to Cut 12,000 Workers and Shut Plants
description: Electrolux A.B., the Swedish maker of Frigidaire appliances, said yesterday that it would lay off about 10 percent of its work force, or about 12,000 workers, and would close 24 factories and 50 warehouses in two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERDON, BLISS
description: VERDON-Bliss. Her friends and colleagues at New York University are deeply saddened by her tragic and senseless death. We extend our hearts and loving sympathy to her family and to all her friends. ''There is not room for Death, Nor atom that his might could render void; Since thou art Being and Breath And what thou art may never be destroyed.'' Emily Bronte.

title: Judge Orders Disclosure In Union Race
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that a court-appointed monitor who oversaw the re-election of Ron Carey as the teamsters' president last year may obtain information that Mr. Carey's former campaign manager had contended was protected by lawyer-client privilege.

title: Realism With a Vengeance
description: REALISM is never very far out of style, but it has certainly been on the upswing in the last decade or so. Its re-emergence might be traced back to the early 1980's when artists like Jack Goldstein, Troy Brauntuch and Robert Longo made enigmatic paintings and drawings based on photographic images, and Eric Fischl painted tales of suburban dysfunction in a more traditional style. In the late 1980's came the meticulously real figures and objects, often cast, by Robert Gober, Jeff Koons and Kiki Smith. Now it's painting's turn again, as a number of younger artists try to add new wrinkles to realism's long history.

title: $25 and Under
description: The outlandish structure at the end of a long driveway in a neighborhood of warehouses and auto supply shops looks like anything but a restaurant. With its brightly striped turrets, it could be a carnival, a circus or a factory outlet for lumber and aluminum siding. In fact, it is Master Grill, the biggest and possibly most elaborate Brazilian rodizio in the New York City area.

title: Sights Set on 4-Minute Mile For 3 High School Runners
description: Gabe Jennings is an 18-year-old runner from Wisconsin who doesn't own a television set, writes poetry and credits yoga for his success this season. Tomorrow, he will lead a three-man assault on the four-minute mile at the national high school outdoor track and field championships in Raleigh, N.C.

title: Holding Our Breath
description: The Clinton Administration will soon make one of the most important environmental decisions of this decade: whether to support the Environmental Protection Agency's proposal for tough new rules on air pollution.

title: 4 Groups See Urgency for Accord on Tobacco
description: Four major public health organizations today offered their strongest support yet for a legal settlement with the nation's cigarette manufacturers, creating further divisions in the already discordant body of anti-smoking advocates.

title: Bounced Commissioner Practices Her Rebound
description: Cardboard boxes clutter the floor of Dr. Mary Hibberd's office here, some filled with files to discard and others bulging with mementos to keep. Her desk is strewn with folders and a hammer and a screwdriver for removing photos from the wood-paneled wall.

title: Dow Jones Unit in Move
description: Dow Jones & Company has leased 71,000 square feet of office space at Two World Trade Center, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: 15 Suspended In Broker Inquiry
description: N.A.S.D. Regulation, the regulatory arm of the National Association of Securities Dealers, said today that it had suspended and fined 15 current or former brokers at H. J. Meyers & Company for charging retail customers unfair prices or for failing to prevent overcharges.

title: 2 FAILING SCHOOLS TO BE REINVENTED
description: Frustrated with the pace of change at two New York City junior high schools, state and city school officials said yesterday that they would clean house at the troubled schools later this month, restocking the buildings with new students, administrators and teachers.

title: Parties Raised $15 Million in 'Soft Money' in '97, Data Show
description: Despite calls from Democrats and Republicans to reform campaign financing, both parties have raised a total of $15 million this year in ''soft money'' donations, the type of donation most heavily criticized.

title: Lagging on Land Mines
description: It is not every day that the Republican-controlled Senate finds the Clinton Administration too timid in pressing for an arms control agreement, but that is what happened this week on land mines. In a reversal of roles, a majority of senators, including some of the most ardent Republican supporters of the military, declared their support for a nearly total ban on future American use of anti-personnel land mines.

title: Turkish Generals Raise Pressure on Premier
description: Turkey's military leadership has sharply stepped up its pressure on the country's Islamist-led Government, and an important secular member of the governing coalition said today that a change of leadership ''is expected in the coming days.''

title: Baseball Crosses Great Divide: A.L. 3, N.L. 1
description: The Texas Rangers and the San Francisco Giants played major league baseball's first interleague game tonight in an American League park but in National League time.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZALEFSKY, S.R., RN.
description: ZALEFSKY-S.R., RN. 10/10/1893-6/13/1973. Dear Mother, two miracles are your legacy: your great-grandchildren, Allegra and Jeremy. Love, Lois

title: Camden Finances Scrutinized
description: A bill that would create a state-appointed financial review board to oversee operations in the troubled city of Camden was introduced in the Assembly yesterday. The measure would give the board final say on municipal spending, hiring and purchasing decisions. Some Camden politicians are not happy with the bill. State Senator Wayne R. Bryant, a Democrat, said the bill usurps the authority of the city's elected Mayor and City Council. The proposed legislation also fails to address Camden's need to increase its tax base, Milton Milan, the Mayor-elect, said.

title: Tracks Make Pitch to the 3-Year-Olds
description: Although the second half of the racing season does not begin until midsummer, track officials have already begun wooing the connections of Touch Gold, Silver Charm and Free House to try to capitalize on the appeal that drew 70,682 fans to Belmont Park last Saturday.

title: In the Hunt for Husbands, Mr. Right Need Not Apply
description: The best to be said for ''Wedding Bell Blues'' is that it's on a par with leafing through dusty back issues of Cosmopolitan on a lonely night. As three unhappily single women (played by Illeana Douglas, Paulina Porizkova and Julie Warner) strike out in search of quickie nuptials, the film manages to use face cream, leg shaving, talk of masturbation and words like ''colonic'' to draw would-be laughs. The opening credits are accompanied by a pregnancy test montage.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Citizen Ruth

title: Poor Landlords
description: The city's landlords are not making enough money. They want longer limousines and larger portions of caviar. They want bigger spreads in the Hamptons. They want their millions converted into tens of millions, their tens of millions into hundreds of millions, and so on. In short, they want everybody's rents raised.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Giddings & Lewis Accepts $675 Million Merger Bid From Thyssen
description: Escaping a hostile takeover bid, Giddings & Lewis Inc., a Wisconsin maker of machine tools and assembly line equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by Thyssen A.G. for $675 million.

title: TEXAS PLANNED COMMUNITY TO BE SOLD FOR $543 MILLION
description: The Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Woodlands property unit, which owns and operates a 27,000-acre office and residential development north of Houston, for $543 million in cash. A partnership formed by an affiliate of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company and the Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, one of the country's largest real estate investment trusts, is buying the Woodlands. Mitchell Energy, a natural gas producer based in Woodlands, Tex., said it expected to record a second-quarter charge of $55 million to $60 million after taxes on the sale. The Woodlands, begun in 1974, is a planned community with about 48,000 residents and 740 companies and institutions.

title: Pol Pot Is Said to Leave Last Base in Cambodia
description: Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader, executed another guerrilla leader and fled his last remaining base, Cambodia's First Prime Minister Prince Norodom Ranariddh said this morning.

title: An Affront To the Dead, And the Living
description: JOSEPH GEISMAR never made headlines, not as far as can be told. He was one man among many. He was born, and he made a living in the women's hat business, and after he died in 1921 his remains were put in a mausoleum in Bayside Cemetery in South Ozone Park, Queens. There, he was supposed to rest in peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE SILVA, GILBERT, JAMES
description: De SILVA-Gilbert-James. On June 11, 1997. Of Long Beach, New York. Beloved son of Gilbert and Lorraine De Silva. Dear friend of Peter Farmer. Brother of Linda. Uncle of Nicholas and Victoria Tommasulo. Beloved nephew of Alita Hunt and cousin of Barbara Mangialardi. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxvile, June 14th, at 10 AM.
