description: Tina Modotti

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Mars Attacks!

title: U.N. Chief Picks Irish President to Be Top Aide on Human Rights
description: In a move that is expected to bolster the role of the United Nations in promoting civil rights worldwide, Secretary General Kofi Annan named President Mary Robinson of Ireland today as his new High Commissioner for Human Rights.

title: As Company Gives Up Dishes, Its Hometown Grows Anxious
description: It is hard to miss the buzz at Corning Inc.'s Sullivan Park research labs. Never mind that they are smack in the middle of a sleepy rural town. The air virtually crackles with excitement.

title: Madison Ave. In Newsroom Once Again
description: The line between editorial and advertising content in the news media, which seems to become blurrier every 60 minutes, is being fuzzed further by the coming appearance of a correspondent for the Cable News Network in an advertisement for Visa credit cards.

title: Art in Review
description: John McCracken

title: Lawmaker Says Huang Passed Secret Data
description: A Republican Congressman said today that intelligence information showed that while working at the Commerce Department, John Huang, who has become a central figure in the Democratic fund-raising scandal, passed classified Government data to his former employer, the Lippo Group of Indonesia.

title: Democrats Bar Immunity in Finance Inquiry
description: Democrats on the Senate committee investigating campaign finance abuses tonight blocked a Republican plan to grant limited immunity from prosecution to 18 witnesses who gave the Democratic Party money that may not have been their own.

title: FAHNESTOCK BIDS $37.5 MILLION FOR FIRST OF MICHIGAN
description: Fahnestock Viner Holdings Inc., a Toronto-based securities brokerage concern, said yesterday that it would offer $37.5 million in cash for the First of Michigan Capital Corporation. Fahnestock, which has 525 brokers and 49 offices in the United States, offered to pay $15 a share for First of Michigan, a Detroit-based brokerage firm with about 280 brokers and 34 offices, 33 of them in Michigan. Holders of 57 percent of First of Michigan's shares have agreed to sell at that price and the firm's board has approved the sale. First of Michigan's shares soared $5.375, to $14.125, on the Chicago Stock Exchange. Fahnestock rose 75 cents, to $18.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: For Children
description: A 'Hop on Pop' Father's Day

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Pre-Broadway Runs in London

title: Congressional Rough Doesn't Play Favorites
description: Everybody was talking about it, and no one could do anything about it. But, unlike the weather, Congressional Country Club's brutally thick rough will not change, so all the best golfers in the world can hope to do is stay away from it.

title: Flag Measure Stirs Lawmakers' Blood
description: When all else fails the professional politicians, when the campaign financing scandal drags and disaster relief backfires, there is always the flag for them to rally 'round.

title: Dow Rises 135.64 Points for Fifth Straight Closing High
description: It's the best of all possible worlds on Wall Street, or at least it sure seems that way these days.

title: 'Caveman' Is Closing
description: ''Defending the Caveman,'' the one-man comedy about the battle of the sexes written by Rob Becker, will close after its evening performance at the Booth Theater on June 21. The show was originally performed by Mr. Rob Becker, who was replaced by Michael Chiklis. The production had 26 previews and 671 regular performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISK, ELIZABETH BARRY
description: SISK-Elizabeth Barry, on June 11, 1997. Beloved daughter of Margaret and John, cherished sister of Ann Bulgrin and Patricia Gribbon, loving aunt of John, Meghan, Daniel, Brian and Kathleen. Niece of Sr. Ann Sisk O.S.U., and Patricia Lange. Sister-in-law of Arthur and Stephan. Visiting will be Thursday and Friday, Lloyd Home, 214-43 39th Ave, Bayside. Mass Saturday, 9:45 AM, Sacred Heart Church, 21535 38th Ave., Bayside. Interment Mount Saint Mary's Cemetery.

title: E-Z Pass Contract Is Upheld
description: A state appeals court yesterday upheld the New Jersey Turnpike Authority's decision to award a $488 million contract to MFS Transtech to implement the state's E-Z Pass electronic toll collection system.

title: G.O.P., IN TURMOIL, YIELDS AND PASSES FLOOD RELIEF BILL
description: Capitulating under political pressure, Congressional Republicans passed a long-awaited $8.6 billion disaster relief bill today, but not before the process revealed sharp divisions within the party's leadership and became a public relations fiasco reminiscent of the Government shutdown 18 months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, SAMUEL S.
description: HELLER-Samuel S. Oct 6, 1902 June 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Rose, devoted father of Franny Heller Zorn, cherished grandfather of Danny and Katie Zorn, loving brother of Phillip, Aaron and Martin. He was a founder of Art Gifts Products Inc. and a fellow of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. Services are private.

title: Home Video
description: Fat Ladies in Film

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNHAUSER, ERWIN
description: TANNHAUSER-Erwin. On June 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Jutta. Dear uncle, cousin and friend. Services Sunday at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Please call 212-362-6600 for time of service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALITA, MARMOUR, DEBORAH
description: SHALITA - MARMOUR - Deborah. The administration, faculty, staff and students of the State University of New York Health Science Center at Brooklyn mourn with great sadness the untimely passing of Deborah Shalita-Marmour, daughter of Dr. Alan Shalita, Chairman of the Department of Dermatology, and Simone Shalita. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to Deborah's husband, to her parents and sister, and to all family members and friends. Eugene B. Feigelson, MD, Interim President

title: Art in Review
description: 172d Annual Exhibition

title: A Generational Rent Gap
description: Joseph Bruno, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, has removed one barrier to settling the dispute over rent control that has paralyzed state government this year. Mr. Bruno dropped his fight to eliminate a section of the rent regulations that protects domestic partners of leaseholding tenants in the same way as spouses.

title: Another Delay in Store for French Abortion Pill on U.S. Market
description: In the latest twist in a long battle to bring the French abortion pill RU-486 to the United States market, distributors now say a manufacturing problem will delay the designated December target date, perhaps as long as three to five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEPERCQ, KATHLEEN D.
description: LEPERCQ-Kathleen D. Died June 7, 1997, of a heart attack. She is survived by a brother, Thomas Draper, of NYC. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Fund for Animals, Inc, 355 West 52nd Street, N.Y., New York 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GIBNEY, WILSON J.
description: GIBNEY-Wilson J. 06/13/17-03/04/87 Happy Birthday, Wilson. Love, Helen.

title: Tyson, Turning Up Anger, Says He's Set for Holyfield
description: If being ill-tempered is a sign of being prepared to fight, then Mike Tyson is ready for his rematch on June 28 against Evander Holyfield.

title: Makes A Bus Seem Safe
description: America's bus-driving sweetheart has a new boyfriend, the kind of guy who can pull a ticket for the Love Boat out of his pocket and suggest an impromptu getaway. That's how Annie (Sandra Bullock) finds herself out to sea with Alex (Jason Patric) in ''Speed 2: Cruise Control,'' the latest demolition derby from Jan (''Twister'') De Bont. Just in time for Father's Day, the film also supplies a demented terrorist (Willem Dafoe) who uses high-tech golf clubs as deadly weapons.

title: In Retrial, Alex Kelly Is Convicted Of Rape Committed 11 Years Ago
description: Alex Kelly, the former Darien High School wrestling star who spent eight years as a fugitive traveling from one European resort to another, was convicted today of raping a 16-year-old girl he had driven home from a party 11 years ago.

title: After Floods, Billions in Balm
description: The emergency relief bill passed by the Republican-led Congress today provides $5.6 billion for victims of floods and other disasters.

title: Indicting The Feds For the Siege At Waco
description: An atmosphere of stomach-clenching dread suffuses William Gazecki's grim documentary film, ''Waco: The Rules of Engagement.'' This methodical indictment of the United States Government's siege of the Branch Davidian compound near Waco, Tex., four years ago has awful lessons to teach about governmental hubris and how a deliberate failure to communicate can have catastrophic consequences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSH, MATILDE
description: HIRSH-Matilde. Beloved mother of William A. and Helenjane Hirsh Julian, dear sister of Stephen B. Freedman, adored grandmother of Laurel, Philip, and Andrew. Services Tuesday, 10 AM, ''The Boulevard Riverside Chapels'', Brooklyn Ocean Parkway at Prospect Park.

title: Swiss EconomyExpands Slightly
description: Switzerland's economy expanded two-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, its first quarterly gain in two years, offering more proof that Europe's slowest-growing economy is emerging from its longest recession since World War II.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNTING, GEORGE ROBERT
description: BUNTING-George Robert. Age 79, formerly of Riverdale, Bronx and Lavallette, NJ. Loving husband of Nancy Bunting. Beloved father of Nancy Foulk, George Bunting Jr., Anthony Bunting, Claudia Cannataro, Laura Carroll and Kristin Devlin. Devoted grandfather of 12 grandchildren. Family will receive friends Saturday 7-9 p.m. and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232nd Street, Bronx. Religious service Sunday, June 15 at Williams Funeral Home, at 8 P.M.

title: Montgomerie Keeps It Straight To Snare the First-Round Lead
description: Colin Montgomerie used his 3-wood today like a carpenter using a favorite hammer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNALLY, KEVIN T.
description: McNALLY-Kevin T., on June 11, 1997, of Garden City. Loving husband of Helen. Devoted father of Moira Trageser, Kevin R., Brian C., Monica Mandel and Jennifer Belton. Cherished grandfather of 7. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th St. Garden City, Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Memorial Mass St. Joseph's Church Garden City, Saturday 1pm. Donations may be made to the American Diabetes Assoc.

title: U.S. Faces 'Real Challenge' in Selling U.N. Plan, Annan Says
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that Clinton Administration officials had told him that their agreement with Senate leaders to attach conditions to the payment of overdue debts to the United Nations ''was the best deal they could get under the circumstances.''

title: INSIDE METRO
description: REBIRTH OF HIGHBRIDGE -- Archbishop John Cardinal O'Connor led a procession in the Bronx to highlight the rebirth of the Highbridge section, where 29 buildings have been renovated with the help of the New York Archdiocese. B3.

title: Political Money, On Line
description: California is now moving to use the Internet to bring a little sunlight to the murky corners of political fund-raising. In a bipartisan vote, the California State Senate has approved a bill that will require prompt on-line filing of campaign contributions to statewide candidates like governor and ballot-measure committees by 1998. All state legislative offices will be covered by 2000. California, whose State Assembly passed a similar bill last year, may thus provide an incentive for other states that have yet to go on line.

title: Army to Name 2 to Fill In for Top Enlisted Man
description: The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. Dennis J. Reimer, will appoint two Acting Sergeants Major of the Army pending the outcome of an investigation of Sgt. Maj. Gene C. McKinney on sexual harassment and other charges, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of Jewel Lafontant-Mankarious on June 3 referred incorrectly to a distinction she attained when she became Deputy Solicitor General of the United States in 1973. While she was the first woman to hold so high a position in the Solicitor General's office, she was not the highest-ranking black staff member. That was Thurgood Marshall, who became Solicitor General in 1965.

title: Xaverian Pitcher Dominates Molloy
description: When Ruddy Lugo, the hard-throwing freshman from Xaverian High School, took the mound yesterday, everyone in Yankee Stadium knew exactly what pitch he was going to throw. Unfortunately for the opposing players from Archbishop Molloy, even with that knowledge, there was little they could do about it.

title: Schering-Plough and Lilly Sign Liver Drug Deals
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation and Eli Lilly & Company each signed deals yesterday with small biotechnology companies to co-develop drugs for the treatment of hepatitis C, a liver infection with sometimes-deadly consequences.

title: Kolbenschmidt Merger Is Postponed
description: Kolbenschmidt A.G., a maker of automobile pistons, said yesterday that it was postponing its merger with a Rheinmetall A.G. auto parts unit because the original schedule was too short. ''I don't know how long the delay will be, but the merger is still going ahead,'' said Jakob Lux, a Kolbenschmidt spokesman.

title: Youths With Attitude: Hopeless, Cynical
description: Two years ago, ''Kids'' got so far inside urban adolescents' lives that it looked like a documentary. The year before, ''Fresh'' made that world look like another planet, but one easily reachable by subway. ''Squeeze'' has a lot in common with those films, but its real soul mate is ''The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter,'' Carson McCullers's 1940 novel. It noted that there is a moment in many lives at which things go right or wrong, up or down, and that moment may come unfairly early, when young humans are unprepared, even with adult mentors at their side, to fight their best fights.

title: Where They Stand
description: CURRENT LAW

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDENBAUM, JOHN, M.D.
description: LINDENBAUM-John, M.D., on June 11, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley. Dear brother of Peter and sister-in-law Sheila. Service private. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to the CPMC Fund for the Lindenbaum Lectures.

title: Honoring Famous and Infamous at the Hall of Fame
description: Phil Spector, one of pop's least public figures, emerged to accept an award from the Songwriters' Hall of Fame on Tuesday night. This producer, who created the Wall of Sound as a teen-ager and who went on to work with the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, the Ramones and Celine Dion, is also renowned for erratic behavior, like waving a gun in the studio.

title: Cone, the Super Fan, Looking for a Playoff Atmosphere
description: Appropriately and perhaps adeptly, David Cone will be the first Yankee to pitch in an interleague skirmish when New York opposes the Florida Marlins in Miami tonight. But if you listen to Cone discuss the event, he sounds more like a public relations director for the virtues of the American League against the National League than a pitcher in a historic game.

title: BAXTER TO BACK VIMRX DEVELOPMENTAL VENTURE

Vimrx will issue to Baxter 11 million common shares plus preferred stock together worth about $90 million, giving Baxter a 23 percent to 26 percent stake in Vimrx. Vimrx will invest $10 million in the venture, to be based in Irvine, Calif., and have an 80 percent stake. Baxter will invest $20 million in the as-yet unnamed venture. Vimrx shares were unchanged at $3.50, while shares of Baxter, based in Deerfield, Ill., fell 37.5 cents, to $54.125.

Waltner, Professor Emeritus of Columbia University College of Physician & Surgeons and Consultant Emeritus in Otolaryngology of The Presbyterian Hospital. A national leader in his specialty, Dr. Waltner pioneered the study of fluid circulation in the inner ear and helped develop many techniques used in the reconstruction of hearing mechanisms. He was also instrumental in the establishment of ultrasound as an early treatment for Meniere's disease. Having developed numerous techniques that continue to be used today, he will also be remembered for many other professional and philanthropic contributions. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. William T. title: Private Vouchers Proposed

A publicly financed voucher program was approved by the local Board of Education in February, but was withdrawn last month after opponents gained a majority on the board. Now, a nonprofit group has been formed to raise money and administer an entirely private voucher program, Patricia Gray, the president of the Lincoln Park Education Foundation, said yesterday.

description: U S West Media Group Inc. said yesterday that it had sold about 4.4 million Time Warner Inc. shares for $220 million. U S West Media said the sale was part of a plan to sell $1 billion of assets the company did not consider strategic and was unrelated to its partnerships with Time Warner involving cable systems, Warner Brothers and Home Box Office. U S West Media, which is based in Englewood, Colo., acquired the stock in Time Warner of New York, when it bought Continental Cablevision Inc. The stock was sold for about $50 a share to Salomon Inc., which then resold it. Time Warner shares slipped 37.5 cents, to $49.625.

title: A Master's Touch Like Midas's
description: ALFRED HITCHCOCK was the first great movie director who knew what to do with television: he used it to make himself rich and famous. If today his name instantly brings to mind his substantial profile, morbid humor and English accent, it is thanks to the on-camera appearances that framed every episode of ''Alfred Hitchcock Presents,'' the anthology series than ran from 1955 to 1962 and endlessly in reruns. Through television, Hitchcock's personality became more famous than his movies, and he proved himself a master of public relations as well as of suspense.

A few years ago, Mr. Parker left to pursue his own career, bringing an end to the particular excitement they generated.

Lionized nearly 30 years ago as the epitome of hip complacency, then dormant for a long while, he emerges here as a figure of unexpected stature. This film calls for deep reserves of backbone from its terse hero, and Mr. Fonda supplies them with supreme dignity and grace.

title: Black Comedy in a Terrorist Bombing

title: What Would Kochel Say?
description: A remark heard among some jaded classical musicians is that the only thing better than discovering a new work by Mozart is to lose an old one by Bruckner. It appears that the first half of that feat has been achieved by David Buch, a professor of music history at the University of Northern Iowa. Rummaging in a university library in Hamburg, Germany, Dr. Buch found Mozart's name written on a collaborative score for a 1790 opera titled ''The Philosopher's Stone.'' It seems likely that Mozart also had a hand in another score, for ''The Beneficent Dervish,'' an obscure Viennese opera in the fairy-tale manner of ''The Magic Flute,'' composed during his prolific final years. The discoveries further illuminate his desperation in those years, when he took what work he could get.

title: TRANSITIONAL HOSPITALS WITHDRAWS FROM DEAL
description: The Transitional Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that it had withdrawn from a $565 million agreement to be bought by the Select Medical Corporation in favor of a higher bid from Vencor Inc. Transitional Hospitals agreed in May to be acquired by Select Medical, based in Mechanicsburg, Pa., for $14.55 a share, which Vencor topped. Vencor has since raised its bid to $16 a share, or $639 million. Transitional has the option of terminating the Select Medical agreement with the understanding that Select Medical will have five days to top the Vencor bid. Vencor operates a network of hospitals, nursing centers and contract services in 46 states. Transitional, formerly known as Community Psychiatric Centers, operates 16 acute-care hospitals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLODA, LIVIU
description: FLODA-Liviu. August 16, 1913 June 3, 1997. This Romanian native left his homeland in 1963 and began a career with Radio Free Europe in 1964. His creative, engaging journalism included interviews with Eugene Ionesco, Nobel laureate George Palade, Jean Negulesco, Isamu Noguchi, Andrei Codrescu, Andrei Serban, Radu Lupu, Viorica Cortez, and many others. He provided a welcome support to many Romanian refugees and exiles, especially in their broadcast appeals for family reunification. When the New York office of RFE/RL closed in 1993, the Voice of America recruited him. He left to assemble his archives for the Hoover Institution of War, Revolution, and Peace. This extraordinary collection of tapes, scripts, personal letters, and photos provides a unique portrait of the experience of Romanians in America. To his wife Martha and children Sylvia and Eugen, friends extend their deepest sympathies.

title: Goddesses Are Photographed, Not Born
description: Using lights, innovative film techniques and a painter's eye for composition, George Hurrell transformed mere celebrities into the gods of film, creating many of the most enduring pictures that Hollywood studios ever used to sell movies to America. ''A Hurrell portrait is to the ordinary publicity still what a Rolls-Royce is to a roller skate,'' Esquire wrote in 1936. In HURRELL'S HOLLYWOOD PORTRAITS: The Chapman Collection (Abrams, $39.95), Mark A. Vieira presents 275 of the studio shots Hurrell made from 1929 to 1943, during the beginning of his nearly 70-year career. Mr. Vieira attempts to define Hurrell's technique, but too often he merely describes, in condescending detail, simple technical terms like f-stops, while skimming over more unusual procedures like Hurrell's retouching process. The photographs include Hurrell's first Hollywood portrait (of Ramon Novarro) and the notorious haystack picture of Jane Russell used for Howard Hughes's film ''The Outlaw.'' The shots include not only well-known portraits of legendary stars, finely reproduced, but many lesser known images and almost forgotten personalities, as well as a few surprises, from a partly undraped Jean Harlow to an unretouched Joan Crawford. Cecil B. DeMille compared Hurrell to Rembrandt, and no wonder; under Hurrell's guidance, movie stars became burnished, unreal images. Hurrell described his work simply: ''Bring out the best, conceal the worst, and leave something to the imagination.'' By following this creed, he made the publicity photo into art. Patricia Eliot Tobias

title: In Venezuela, A Refuge On a Ranch
description: THESE days the environmentally friendly style of travel called eco-tourism is all the rage, especially in Venezuela. But long before it was fashionable it was the stock in trade of Hato Pinero, a ranch and wildlife refuge in northern Venezuela.

title: A Show for the Stage Struck
description: CHITA RIVERA SENT HER ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' costume in a shoe box. Mrs. Vincente Minnelli opened an old crate in her basement and shipped the model for the fountain scene in ''An American in Paris.'' And Jo Sullivan Loesser took Frank Loesser's self-portrait off her wall and packed it up for the National Portrait Gallery, where it joined Ms. Rivera's black Spandex, Lee Minnelli's fountain and some 400 other artifacts from American musical-theater history in the current exhibition ''Red, Hot and Blue: A Salute to American Musicals.''

title: Chalking Up Fifth Ave. for Museum Festivities

At 6 P.M. on Tuesday on the front terrace of the museum, at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, Roy Nathanson's Klezmer Band will play music heard at New York City weddings. The concert is part of the continuing exhibition ''New York Gets Married,'' on display through Sept. 21.

title: Taking Tea
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed the delightful account of visiting Concord, Mass. (''Great Minds Live Alike,'' May 4). However, despite many written discussions of the subject, Americans persist in referring to English afternoon tea as ''high tea.'' The young woman in the picture of the Colonial Inn is obviously partaking of afternoon tea. High tea is a much more hearty meal, with thicker-sliced bread and a slab of not-so-fancy cake; it is a meal served to the working man around 6 P.M., when he returns home.

Seeman of Toledo, Ohio, and the late Harry A. Seeman. The Rev. Brinton Webb Woodward Jr., an Episcopal priest and the headmaster of the Holderness School in Plymouth, N.H., performed the nondenominational ceremony.

Rock of Bay Shore, NY, Jean Luz of Bedminster, NJ and Helen Murdock of Dennisport, MA, and the late Edward A. Osmun, Sr. of Morristown, NJ; Grandmother of eleven, greatgrandmother of fourteen. Burial will be in Island Pond Cemetery, Harwich. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Cape Cod Hospital Foundation, 4 Bayview St., Hyannis, MA 02601 or Pilgrim Congregational Church, Main St., Harwichport, MA 02646 in her memory. Beloved husband of Rhoda and devoted father to Alan and Jackie Goldberg of New York City and Jacqui and Matt O'Connell of Pensacola, FL. Loving grandfather to Jason, Ryan and Emily, and brother of the late Marilyn Ellen Goldberg. He was our daddy and will be dearly missed. Services Monday, June 16, at 1 PM, at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, LI. Donations can be made in his memory to Temple Beth-El or Huntington Hospital. Sorrel, which grows like a weed in my garden, has a sharp lemony taste and makes a refreshing hot or cold soup. (As a sauce, it makes a good foil for fatty fish like salmon or mackerel, or lamb chops).

title: Yes, a Big Seller Can Have Footnotes
description: I have no illusions about the relative unpopularity of university press books. The notion of a university press ''best seller'' is, in the minds of many, an oxymoron. Of the $20 billion that was spent in this country on books last year, only a feeble $350 million, or 1.7 percent, was spent on those published by the hundred or so university presses; that's about a third of what Americans spent on religious books.

description: DR. STAIN has gone to California to seek his fortune. One day he was behind the counter of Young's dry cleaner on East 17th Street, chattering, bustling, dismissing rumors that he planned to sell the store. The next day he was gone, almost magically, like the ink blotches he periodically removed from my shirts.

title: Mr. Thompson's Stalled Inquiry
description: Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee is in an unenviable position as he attempts to conduct an impartial investigation of campaign fund-raising abuses in the election last year. Many senators in both the Republican and Democratic Parties are rooting -- and in some cases maneuvering -- for him to fail. The partisan anger has all but destroyed the cooperation of the Government Affairs Committee, whose work is vital to the cause of cleaning up the corrupt system of fund-raising in American politics. If the committee's work is to be saved, Democratic leaders will have to abandon their delaying tactics, and the Republican side will have to make some concessions to Democratic concerns.

Here, in the popular wedding month of June, four makers of wedding cakes in the state talk about their creations. CARL SOMMERS

He has lived in Southampton, Amagansett, Sagaponack and on a barge in a bay. A beguiling mixture of intellect, adventure and wit, he has tried his hand -- and sometimes his feet -- at dozens of endeavors and written about them in what he calls participatory journalism.

title: Opera's Most Popular Myth Keeps Finding New Life
description: THERE ARE COUNTLESS VERSIONS of the myth of Orpheus and Eurydice in the literature of the world, from the classical Greeks to Jean Cocteau. The appeal of a story about a mortal's being brought back from death is obvious. But this myth puts an enthralling twist on the fantasy. When the young Eurydice is bitten by a poisonous snake, her husband, Orpheus, an Arcadian poet and singer, dares to travel to the underworld to reclaim her. Facing death, he demands her release, and death gives in.

Trained as classical dancers, some had tasted modern dance through Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor and others. Yet they had known nothing quite like this.

The latest news is that some doctors are administering medication immediately after a possible exposure to H.I.V. as a so-called morning-after treatment to prevent AIDS infection. If those doctors are correct, some lives will be saved. This, of course, is reason to celebrate. Yet the history of the AIDS crisis suggests that there may also be reason for concern.

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. gave heartfelt voice to his dream of a world where children are judged by the content of their character rather than the color of their skin. A few months later, in May 1964, President Lyndon Johnson told the graduating class of the University of Michigan, ''The Great Society is a place where every child can find knowledge to enrich his mind and to enlarge his talents.''

title: Smoking Is a Drag, Ads Tell Young People
description: Move over, Joe Camel. This week the state began an advertising campaign to discourage those aged 11 to 17 from smoking. ''Smoking. Don't Get Sucked In.'' will be the tagline on billboards through September and in ads on cable television (Nickelodeon and MTV, among other channels) and radio through October. The messages will also be shown in movie theaters in July and August. The campaign is being run by the state Department of Health and Senior Services, financed with a $1 million Federal grant for smoking prevention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, NOMINA TWINING
description: DAVIS-Nomina Twining, 100 years, of Sun City Center, Florida, formerly of NYC, on June 9th, 1997. Born 1897 in Lansingburg, NY to Frank Barton Twining and Nomina Bucklin Twining, educated at Emma Willard School, graduated from Miss Porter's School and attended classes at RPI. She moved to Florida in 1980. Beloved wife of the late James W. Cox and J. Stanley Davis, both of Albany, NY and NYC. Loving mother of Nomina Cox Horton of Sun City Center, FL., and the late Gilbert Riggs Cox of NYC, stepmother of Marion Davis Delgado of Center Sandwich, NH. Also grandmother of Nomina Twining Fay of Bradenton, FL., Susan Darcy Cox Hecker and the late Gilbert Riggs Cox Hecker, both of St. Louis, MO. Mrs. Davis was a former member of the Society of Mayflower Descendants, Colonial Dames of America, the DAR and the St. Petersburg Yacht Club, and one of the first members of the Junior League of NYC. A private service and burial will be held at Oakwood Cemetery, Troy, NY, officiated by Father Leach. In lieu of flowers, contributions to St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Fifth Ave, NYC.

This says a lot about economics (the relatively low costs of pasta and pizza) and also about contemporary taste preferences.

title: Drawing Lessons From His Own 'Prehistory'
description: UNTIL ABOUT 15 YEARS AGO, GYORGY LIGETI'S career as a composer seemed quite straightforward. We knew that as a young man in Budapest, in the decade after World War II, Mr. Ligeti had written a great deal of music, but little of it was published or played. He himself was inclined to speak disparagingly of the ''prehistoric Ligeti,'' emphasizing, as he still does, his problems at the time: the lack of information in Hungary about what was happening in the West, the moratorium in his country on modernism (even Bartok's modernism), the compulsion to be upbeat and nationalist.

title: It's Not Too Hot To Stay Cool
description: The suave look of these men seen on Fifth Avenue last week was not disturbed by the above-90-degree heat. The men simply changed their suit fabrics to lightweight cotton, linen or tropical-weight fabrics and, in most cases, their colors to white, ivory or beige. They did not succumb to the trend of dressing down to fend off the heat. Instead, their style was all about crisp elegance. A standout was the man (center) who switched his pin-stripes to navy on white. Even the dark suits were cut from linen or lightweight worsteds. The occasional boutonniere, two-tone shoes, solid-color necktie, straw hat and walking stick added to the swagger of this smooth and courtly look.

And though you secretly hanker after a copy of the soundtrack to ''Valley of the Dolls'' or a lock of Richard Harris's hair and a copy of his hit, ''MacArthur Park,'' you don't know where to look.

title: It's, You Know, About Opinions and Stuff
description: If you want to blazon a name as a young television pundit, you can learn from Laura Ingraham. The ubiquitous 33-year-old conservative plies her trade at, among other places, the MSNBC cable network, the cradle of the new commentary, where 19 all-purpose pundits called contributors stand by to kick around the hot topic in the news. In a recent MSNBC colloquy about whether Sports Illustrated's swimsuit issue was sexist, Jef Pollock, a Democratic pollster, argued that the images of women were an ''objectification.'' Instantly Ingraham barked: ''What does that mean? What does that mean?'' Pollock opened his mouth. ''What does that mean?'' she repeated -- five times in all before declaring, ''No one wants to see fat people on the cover of magazines in swimsuits.''

title: Crime
description: James W. Hall does something brave in RED SKY AT NIGHT (Delacorte, $23.95), and if it doesn't entirely work, well, at least he got it out of his system. The brave thing Mr. Hall has done in his eighth thriller is to disable his series hero, a philosophical beach bum named Thorn, who lives in a shack on Key Largo and normally spends his time making bonefish flies. ''I believe in austerity, simplicity, the unembellished life,'' he says, oblivious of how insufferable that sounds to less noble life-forms. Although he's a first-class brooder, Thorn can't fathom the criminal mind that would break into a medical research facility to torture, mutilate and kill 11 dolphins. Only after Thorn is crippled by a spinal cord injury and treated by a sinister scientist at a pain clinic for combat veterans does he come to understand -- and learn how to fight -- that kind of evil.

title: Guess What City Looks Like America
description: NEW YORK CITY often seems like some outrider to the American experience. By its scale and its reputation for excess, the nation's largest city has long cultivated an aura of prickly difference that residents and nonresidents alike have relished. New Yorkers gaze across the Hudson with arrogance and contempt, and the rest of the country gapes back with awe, loathing and relief.

title: Melissa Biren, Scott Singer
description: Melissa Ann Biren, a daughter of Phyllis and Steven Biren of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married last evening to Scott Andrew Singer, the son of Harriet and Andrew Singer, also of Chappaqua. Rabbi Chaim Stern performed the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: DIARY
description: TAX CUTThe House Aims at Capital GainsFew ideas warm the hearts of either Republicans or Wall Street as much as the notion of cutting capital gains taxes. Little wonder, then, that a proposal to slice the top rate on long-term gains to 20 percent from the present 28 percent was at the center of a multifaceted plan voted by the House Ways and Means Committee to slice tax liabilities by $85 billion over the next five years -- the first big Federal tax cut proposal since 1981. But that amount was still down from an initial $135 billion. Under pressure from the airline industry, which saw itself unduly burdened by taxes on tickets, and small-business groups, which demanded a bigger reduction in inheritance taxes, Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who heads the committee, quickly modified the plan. Democrats complained that the package favored the rich.

title: Playing Like a Veteran, Cink Stalks the Leaders
description: When Stewart Cink was a collegiate golfer at Georgia Tech, he competed against Tiger Woods six times.

title: Warning: Beware of Outer-League Experiences
description: After his first taste of the New Age of Baseball, Paul Molitor, the highly respected veteran of the Minnesota Twins, remarked, ''You had to keep reminding yourself that this was a real game.''

title: Julie Levinson, Scott Werner
description: Julie Dawn Levinson, a daughter of Linda and Barry Levinson of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married there today to Scott Matthew Werner, a son of Irene and Charles Werner of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Elizabeth Rolle is to officiate at Farrington Manor, a catering business.

title: Tell It to the Jury: The Killer Is Not a Demon
description: IN a courtroom in Denver last week, defense attorneys portrayed Timothy J. McVeigh as a carefree youngster and dutiful soldier whose patriotism was transformed into something unpredictably dark by the billowing fires of Waco.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE-Frances. Grandma, It's been four years and not a day goes by when I don't think of you. Love, Michael

title: John Ashbrook and Mona Jha
description: Mona Jha, a daughter of Pramila Jha Gupta and a stepdaughter of Dr. Ramesh Gupta of Depew, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Watson Ashbrook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Ashbrook of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Grant Harrity, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at Sweetwater Farm in Glen Mills, Pa.

title: The Chair: Not Only a Seat but Also a Sculptural Piece
description: THE newly enlarged Lynn Tendler Bignell Gallery of the Brookfield Craft Center, housed in an old grist mill on the banks of the Still River, is the site of an exhibition on view through July 6 that zeroes into ''The Craftsman's Chair.'' It's to the point, catchy and probing.

title: Wedding Bells
description: If the booming state of the bridal industry is any indication, many women are still inclined to view their wedding day as the most important day of their lives. I wonder how many men would say the same. Certainly, there is disparity at work in the clothes: the bride takes the stage in a one-of-a-kind, once-in-a-lifetime dress, while the groom, more often than not, is outfitted in a mere suit or a rented tuxedo.

title: My Father the Geezer
description: May father was 65 when I was born. Even to myself, the statement sits funny, like one of those how-so brain teasers with the hidden loophole - the boy's mother is the doctor. But there is no loophole. He was my biological father, 20 years older than my mother. He had children late because he married late. I came in under the wire.

title: Rescued From Oblivion
description: TRUE STORIES

title: Conviction in Kelly Rape Case Ends Prosecutor's 11-Year Trial
description: On Feb. 13, 1986, members of the Darien police force went to a little-known state prosecutor with a rape case involving a 16-year-old girl and an 18-year-old man, both from Darien, a wealthy town better known for its gentle manners and expansive lawns than for lurid crime. The man charged with the rape was Alex Kelly. The prosecutor was Bruce P. Hudock.

title: Finding a Guide
description: To the Editor: My husband and I travel abroad once a year, in Europe or Asia. Here are some suggestions from our experiences:

description: THE MAN MADE OF WORDS

title: Patricia Hutchinson, Robert Perkins
description: Patricia Anne Hutchinson and Robert Mark Perkins, medical students at the University of Pittsburgh, were married yesterday at the First Parish Church in Brewster, Mass. The Rev. Lisa Morton, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

description: To the Editor:

description: Buddy

description: Lisa Whitehill Griffin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Griffin of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Francis McGill Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. McGill of Fort Washington, Pa. Msgr. Michael J. Bransfield performed the ceremony at the Watch Hill Chapel in Watch Hill, R.I.

title: Small Owners Say They Are Overlooked
description: While the rent debate in Albany has focused on letting prices rise once tenants move, thousands of small landlords around the city are complaining loudly that such a solution leaves them out in the cold.

title: Mary D. Keyserling, 87, Dies; Senior Government Economist
description: Mary D. Keyserling, an economist who made women and children the focus of her work in and out of government, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in McLean, Va. She was 87 and had been director of the Labor Department's Women's Bureau during the era of feminist ferment in the 1960's.

title: Jessica Gordon, Donald Ryan Jr.
description: Jessica Moseley Gordon, the daughter of Mayor David S. Gordon and Mrs. Gordon of Newport, R.I., was married last evening at her parents' house to Donald Christopher Ryan Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryan of Chappaqua, N.Y. Mayor Gordon officiated.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on May 25 with an article about stickball misstated the surname of one student who spoke about the game. He is James Colby Chamberlain, not Cameron.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Cyclospora Returns

title: New Releases
description: LEE KONITZ: 'STRINGS FOR HOLIDAY'

title: Atlantic Salmon Stocking Program Runs Into Opposition
description: Standing alongside a concrete tank under a fluorescent light in the Salmon River fish hatchery, it was hard to imagine that the shallow tray built into the tank might hold an important key to the future of the complex and currently troubled Lake Ontario cold-water fishery.

title: Making a Nature Trail More Inviting to Everyone
description: ON the rocks along Poorhouse Creek in Stamford, a chipmunk has left bright yellow pawprints for all to follow. Along the trail, there's evidence the chipmunk has stopped for a bite of nuts to eat, visited with a squirrel and managed to sneak past a predator's habitat. Its adventure is fun to follow whether or not one can see because there are flowers to smell, turtle shells to touch and woodpeckers to listen for.

title: One Aim, 2 Methods, Scores Rise
description: At Public School 205, one third-grade teacher, Barbara Collins, stood unmoving before the upturned faces of her 25 students. The soft intonations of her voice floated toward them as they recited their reading lesson. She nodded slightly as she coaxed them phonetically over words like ''intelligent'' and ''difficult.''

title: Guilty at Last
description: Some people in wealthy Darien, Conn., supported Alex Kelly when two teen-age girls accused the high-school senior of raping them in 1986. He was a star athlete, good-looking, daring, popular. Why would Alex Kelly need to rape anyone?

title: Dear Cousin Julius
description: Alan Dershowitz should know better than to heap unwarranted criticism on F.D.R. for this nation's immigration policy on Jews in the late 1930's (Letters, May 18). As war clouds gathered over Europe, this country's mood grew increasingly isolationist and xenophobic. Immigration quotas were reduced on all groups, not only Jews. Simply because Roosevelt presided at this point of our history does not automatically mean he controlled immigration by executive fiat.

title: Two Festivals in Full Swing, More on the Way
description: WHILE the Norfolk Festival waits in the wings (the first event is scheduled for June 26), Music Mountain and the Connecticut Early Music Festival are already in full swing, and the Silvermine Guild is preparing to begin its 39th annual summer chamber series this Friday. The 8 P.M. program at the Guild Arts Center of New Canaan features the flute-harp duo of David Fedele and Victoria Drake in works of Bach, Debussy, Faure, de Falla and more.

title: Don Quixote and Sancho Ride (and Sing) Again
description: TO discover a new take on an old show must be every director's possible dream, and the quest goes on. But only a ''Man of La Mancha'' fanatic could discern the newness to which the current Paper Mill Playhouse production, under two directors, lays claim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, EVELYN
description: MILLER-Evelyn. We mourn the passing of our beloved Evelyn on June 13, 1997. She remains with us forever. Funeral service today, 11 AM, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC. Contributions in her memory to cancer research would be appreciated. William, Laura, Judy, Bob, Natalia, Kira, Mildred, Susan

title: Stephen Langley, 58, A Theater Manager
description: Stephen Langley, an educator, author and theater manager, died on June 7 at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 58 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: A Thriller on the Hudson Draws on Local Legends
description: THE transformation of North Tarrytown into Sleepy Hollow has seized the collective imagination here, stirring municipal dreams of an Athens-by-the-Hudson. A new waterside park with an amphitheater will be completed by fall, Mayor Sean Treacy said, and the Hudson Valley Writers' Center, blossoming in its new address at the restored Philipse Manor Railroad Station, has announced a variety of new programs in literature, songwriting and public readings.

title: Squaring A Military Past With A Future Job
description: THE Ford Motor Company does not even ask. Nor does Nationsbank, the country's fourth-largest bank. And even if a company does ask questions about military experience and discharge on employee application forms, executives nationwide say a less-than-honorable military discharge is not an automatic blemish on a career or a reason not to hire someone -- despite the debate over the case of Kelly Flinn, the former First Lieutenant who left the Air Force with a general discharge.

title: Back on the Course For a Blind Golfer
description: WITH 20/20 vision that was able to spot a flagstick from 500 yards away on a golf course, Bill McMahon seemingly would not have had to be concerned about his eyesight at the age of 24. But he was, because of the diabetes that ran on his father's side of the family, and had necessitated several laser eye treatments after he graduated from Holy Cross College in 1980.

title: Doing Battle Against Unwanted Plants
description: GOOD gardeners should not need this cautionary note because they know better. Or should. But here goes anyway: Be very careful when using herbicides.

title: Cohen, On Tour, Is 'Skeptical but Hopeful' on Iran
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today that the United States was ''skeptical but hopeful'' about the prospect of improved relations with Iran as a result of last month's landslide election of a relatively moderate cleric as Iran's President.

title: A Trade With the Cubs Could Fill Some Gaps
description: Spurred by their sudden need for an infielder, the Mets are discussing a multiplayer deal with the Cubs, a highly ranked National League official confirmed yesterday. But while the Mets are interested in infielder Rey Sanchez, they are also asking the Cubs about pitchers to bolster their thin middle relief corps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLLY, ALBERT J., JR.
description: GOLLY-Albert J., Jr. Of Elmont, NY, on June 12, 1997. Beloved son of the late Albert Sr. and Aune Golly. Fond cousin of Dorothea Zuerker. Reposing at the Elmont Funeral Home Inc., 1529 Hempstead Tpke, Elmont. Visiting Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30 AM, St. Vincent De Paul Church, Elmont. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx.

title: The Brothers Emanuel
description: The best Rahm Emanuel story is not the one about the decomposing two-and-a-half-foot fish he sent to a pollster who displeased him. It is not about the time - the many times - that he hung up on political contributors in a Chicago mayor's race, saying he was embarrassed to accept their $5,000 checks because they were $25,000 kind of guys. No, the definitive Rahm Emanuel story takes place in Little Rock, Ark., in the heady days after Bill Clinton was first elected President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNHAUSER, ERWIN
description: TANNHAUSER-Erwin. On June 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Jutta. Dear uncle, cousin and friend. Services 9:30, Sunday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: For Tribes, a Call to Action To Get Tax Plan Defeated
description: S. Timothy Wapato remembers precisely the first time the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Bill Archer, ambushed the Indian nation, at least in his view.

title: Joshua Redman, Gabrielle Armand
description: Gabrielle Armand is to to be married today to Joshua Redman Shedroff, who is the jazz musician known as Joshua Redman. Rabbi Roger Ross is to perform the ceremony at Tarrytown House in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOLLEY, FRED G.
description: JOLLEY-Fred G., June 12, 1997, at home. Survived by his wife, Mary Lois Jolley, and his loving family, Margaret, Kenneth, Elizabeth and John Petrocelli, Dr. Irene Willis, Daves Rossell and Grant Willis, six grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Mr. Jolley was most recently employed by Jordan McGrath Case & Taylor, Inc., in New York. Viewing will be on Sunday, June 15, from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M.; service at 8:00 P.M., at Moorehead, McKim and Gallaher Funeral Home at 424 West 51 Street in Manhattan.

title: Amid the Wild Grandeur Of a Spanish Sanctuary
description: MY first glimpse of the Coto Donana came shortly after dawn as I traversed a narrow street in the loftiest quarter of the once-shimmering, now-crumbling Spanish city of Sanlucar de Barrameda. Gazing north over red-tiled roofs speckled with moss, I saw the soaring stone church of Santo Domingo and in the distance, barely visible in the gap in the skyline left by two modern and charmless apartment buildings, a low, horizontal stretch of solid green. They were pine trees, clumped together in the dunes as tightly as broccoli in an Andalusian market stall.

title: Endless 'Summer Place'
description: WHO better to usher in the first steamy day of June than those icons of another era, Troy Donahue and Sandra Dee? The pair, still blond and tan, were in town on Tuesday to kick off the American Movie Classics network's summer season -- and to see the restored version of their 1959 classic, ''A Summer Place.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMM, HAROLD
description: HAMM - Harold. Congregation Ohab Zedek of Belle Harbor mourns the passing of the beloved husband of Etta and beloved father of Audrey Weinstock. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Mendy Bauman, Stanley Liker, Presidium

description: FREE CHOICES

description: Hemingway

title: SKI FLORIDA
description: ''Just say 'ski mountain' and people blast you like you're some sort of wild nut!'' says Murray Mantell, a University of Miami civil engineer. Actually, Mantell is only trying to help. In an attempt to stamp out a nonnative shrub from a 22,000-acre addition to Everglades National Park, the Federal Government plans to scrape off 17 million cubic yards of topsoil. What to do with it? Mantell has proposed building a 700-foot mountain, covering it with plastic snow and opening the world's most humid ski area. He's submitting his final proposal to the Park Service later this year. ''This could be a great way for people to see the Everglades and appreciate what it's all about,'' he argues. Atop a plasticized mountain? ''Well, I was thinking more about the nature trails that we'd put in with it.''

title: THE WRITER IS DEAD. BUT HIS GHOST IS THRIVING.
description: Colin Powell may have run the military, Lee Iacocca may have sold the Mustang, Sydney Biddle Barrows may have sold ... well, never mind. But when were they trained to write a book?

title: Does God Play Hardball?
description: Earthquakes in Iran, record floods in the Dakotas, killer tornados in Texas. Throughout the 90's, many people have shared an eerie sense that the number and severity of natural disasters is increasing. This may be nothing more than popular panic, but you wonder: Is someone trying to tell us something? Here, four very different religious thinkers share their thoughts.

title: Katonah Is Again Host to the Caramoor Music Festival
description: THE elegance, charm and variety that is the Caramoor International Music Festival returns next Saturday when the 100-acre Caramoor estate in Katonah opens its gates for a summer party through Aug. 10. Many friends will return, including the pianists Misha Dichter, John Browning, Wu Han and Garrick Ohlsson, the Tokyo String Quartet and two first ladies of American song, Barbara Cook and Andrea Marcovicci, and a series called ''Introductions'' on Thursday afternoons will present more than a dozen emerging artists.

title: Cable TV Finds A Stamford Home
description: THE year was 1982 and along the Stamford oceanfront complaints were springing up about the tall building on Harbor Drive that glowed brightly through the night. The tenant, the broadcasting arm of Westinghouse known as Group W, was launching its all-news cable network, Satellite News Channel.

title: Don't Alter Bankruptcy Laws
description: THE United States economy is in its best shape in 30 years, but a record number of Americans are filing for bankruptcy. Last year, more than 1.1 million people filed -- more than 1 percent of all households and double the number in 1988.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: THE FARMHOUSE IN THE DELL
description: An old farmhouse is guaranteed to be both charming and problematic, and this 18th-century house in upstate New York was no exception. Porches and bedrooms were added to the original structure by the mid-1800's, but the tiny rooms had low ceilings and rather small windows. And the fact that the house sat in a heavily wooded glen didn't make the interiors seem any ligther.

title: For Jordan, Four Mates, Five Rings
description: The play was designed for him, which was elementary to everyone. But in their haste to not let Michael Jordan end their season, John Stockton and the Utah Jazz discounted one vitally important quality in his arsenal: trust and belief in his teammates.

title: Konstantinov Clings to Life After Wreck
description: Vladimir Konstantinov and two of his Detroit Red Wings colleagues were following the team's advice when they took a limousine home Friday evening after one final celebration of their Stanley Cup triumph.

title: A Brooklyn Industrial Area Draws on Loyalties
description: A MERGER of two bakery companies has brought David Dew and his brother, Stephen, to the East Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. And it has made them, unknowingly, neighbors of Buddy and Jack Teich, Joe Piela, and Martin Greenfield. In the urban industrial milieu, anonymity usually prevails.

title: Timing the Market, and Proud of the Results
description: GERALD APPEL is a longtime practitioner of an out-of-favor art: market timing. Using mathematical models, Mr. Appel, 64, zips in and out of the market with the more than $300 million he manages, hoping to catch the rising waves and skirt the plunges. In a world where ''buy and hold'' is investment gospel, such short-term moves are seen as a heretical strategy that does not improve returns and incurs high commissions.

title: Alysia Reiner and David Basche
description: Alysia Michelle Davis Reiner, a daughter of Gail Reiner Davis and Dr. Charles A. Reiner, both of Manhattan, is to be married today to David Alan Basche, a son of Joyce O. Basche of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Malcolm Basche. Rabbi Sherre Zwelling is to perform the ceremony at the Westhampton (N.Y.) Bath and Tennis Club.

title: The Subversive
description: The theme of Lewis's article is honor. Throughout, he documents McCain's stubborn obsession with ''honor and integrity'' that extended and intensified his long ordeal as a P.O.W. in the Vietnam War, commenting that ''to accept early release would have dishonored not only himself but his family.'' Yet Lewis also points out that McCain is quick to talk about his adultery. What about honor and integrity here? Doesn't adultery dishonor one's family?

title: Fill 'er Up? We Do.
description: IT'S just before 9 on a dazzling morning and the largest refinery on the East Coast is running full tilt, as it always is these days. The world's biggest catalytic cracker is cracking, crude and gas and diesel are surging through 675 miles of blue and gray pipe, the intermittent ''psssht'' of venting steam rises above the hum of compressor motors. And as Michael Karlovich, Bayway Refinery's head of community relations, stands on the deck of company headquarters admiring a surreal 300-foot-high skyline that looks like gargantuan thermos bottles and mixing bowls and flame-topped rocket-launching platforms, he is reminded of a recent conversation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARMEL, ROBERT
description: CARMEL-Robert. Seems like just yesterday that we lost such a great person. I truly miss you and think of you always. Your friend, Kathie M

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDDEN, CHARLES E.
description: FEDDEN-Charles E., on June 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Joyce, devoted father of Joy and Stephen, brother of Jane Hammarstrom. For many years, a practicing attorney in New York City. Memorial service Wednesday, June 18, 11:30AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSHINE, SYLVIA SHARIS
description: ROSENSHINE-Sylvia Sharis. On June 13, 1997. Beloved wife of Marvin, loving mother of Benjamin and mother-in-law of Dawn. Adored sister of Jack Weksler, cherished daughter of the late Benjamin and Ethel Weksler. Services 1:15 PM, Sunday at ''The Riverside,'' West 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., New York City. Interment Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawn, New York. Donations may be made to Shaara Zedek Hospital, Jerusalem, Israel.

title: Uganda Leader Stands Tall in New African Order
description: These are heady days for the former guerrilla who runs Uganda. He moves with the measured gait and sure gestures of a leader secure in his power and in his vision.

title: A Three-Sided Assault, but the Four-Minute Mile Stands Unshakeable
description: What was called the best field of high school runners in 20 years attacked the four-minute-mile barrier tonight at North Carolina State University. They should have brought reinforcements.

title: Merchants vs. Drivers on Atlantic Avenue
description: Charlene Heyliger is moving her clothes shop, Gourd-Chips Boutique, from its present location on Atlantic Avenue. She is going to try her luck on Court Street, which does not have all the traffic problems.

title: Loyalty, at a Price
description: Re ''You've Earned a Free Ticket. Just Try Getting It,'' (Spending It, June 1), which discussed frequent fliers' difficulties in redeeming free-travel awards from the airlines:

title: Living Amid Change
description: AFTER apartheid, Veronica, 17, dreams of a different life, of adventure and romance. She doesn't want to scrub white men's floors ''and be useless.'' In a word, she's bored. She wants to sing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIT, HAROLD (HAPPY)
description: MAIT-Harold (Happy). Our dear, kind, loving son; adoring, wonderful husband; tender, affectionate father. Loved by his family, friends and many nieces and nephews. You will forever be in our hearts and minds. Always with a smile and kindness to all. We were blessed to have you even for so short a time. Dar and Poppa Mait

title: Suddenly, the New Politics of Morality
description: WANT to see a politician really hem and haw? Show up at his or her next town meeting and ask about the issues now dominating American public discourse: Should adultery be tolerated in the military? Should cloning be banned or encouraged? Should doctors be allowed to help terminally ill patients commit suicide?

title: Paulomi Shah, Daniel Katzive
description: Paulomi Shah, a daughter of Divya and Harshad Shah of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Daniel Lewis Katzive, the son of Marion and Richard Katzive of Scarsdale, N.Y. Justice Sondra M. Miller of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated at Tarrytown House.

title: A Filmmaker Peers Past Kissing Lovers To See the Real Paris
description: FOR THE FRENCH DIRECTOR Cedric Klapisch, there is no such thing as a story without dissonance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, CAROL D.
description: WOLFF-Carol D., whose engagement to Gordon was announced in this paper fifty-eight years ago. She was greatly loved and admired by her husband Gordon, two daughters, three grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. May she rest in peace.

title: Rogers Is Sent to the Bullpen And Quickly Brought Back
description: Kenny Rogers, the $20 million question mark, ambled into Joe Torre's office Saturday after being summoned by the manager. Mel Stottlemyre, the pitching coach, closed the door behind Rogers and, as the meeting stretched on for 15 minutes, it became more obvious that Rogers, the Yankees' slumping starter, was being moved to the bullpen. Sort of.

title: Cover Boys
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Korman And Mark Tabs
description: Lisa Korman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Korman of Wayne, N.J., was married last evening to Mark Alan Tabs, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Tabs of New York. Cantor Charles D. Romalis officiated at the Park Savoy, a catering business in Florham Park, N.J.

title: Splendor In the Lemongrass
description: The grass is not always greener on the other side, but sometimes it is more aromatic. Take lemongrass. As common in Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam as front lawns are in America, lemongrass smells like citrus tinged with ginger. But unlike, say, Kentucky bluegrass, lemongrass is edible, occupying a hallowed place in the cooking of Southeast Asia.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-12

title: Pizzeria Had Illicit Menu, Police Say
description: Nestled on a busy retail block of First Avenue between 68th and 69th Streets, the Alto pizzeria probably would not arouse much attention except among the hungry. On Thursday the modest lunch crowd eating slices and calzones was largely oblivious to one fact that distinguishes this pizzeria from others: the manager, Albert Ferado, 47, was recently arrested on charges that he was selling more than just Italian food. ''He was moving a lot of cocaine,'' said Capt. Kevin Hickey, the commanding officer of Manhattan North Narcotics District. ''We caught him red-handed.''

title: Developing a Plan for a Changing County
description: OLD habits take a long time to die -- and one of Dr. William N. Cassella Jr.'s old habits is to say ''we'' when he talks about the County Planning Board. It is not surprising. From 1962 until last March, Dr. Cassella, a resident of Dobbs Ferry, was a member of the voluntary citizens board, serving as its chairman since 1973.

title: Furniture a Gun Moll Would Have Found Just Swell
description: FROM STEVEN SPIELBERG'S Jurassic redux to the velvet-suited, dentally challenged international man of mystery from the 60's, the superspy hero Austin Powers, reanimation is in the air. So it seems appropriate that James Mont, one of the dinosaurs of American style, is making a comeback. As revivals go, it is a modest one, but well deserved.

title: Katrina Burger, Kim Brooker Jr.
description: Katrina Iran Burger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Van Vechten Burger Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to T. Kimball Brooker Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brooker of Chicago. The Rev. Dr. Earle W. Pratt performed the ceremony at Trinity St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, N.Y.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TALL SHIP FESTIVAL

title: Like Old Times: Steel Plant Coming to New Haven
description: IN capturing the first newly built large-scale industrial plant in Connecticut in more than 20 years, and the first basic manufacturing company to enter the state in 50 years, New Haven has negotiated a reversal of industrial emigration, what Mayor John DeStefano Jr. calls ''a contrarian occurrence.''

title: It's Maggert, Lehman and a Committee of Others
description: There are so many contenders, and so many possibilities.

title: Miss Neumann And Mr. Keane
description: Margaret Elizabeth Grace Neumann, a daughter of Kathleen and Gerard Neumann of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Terence Vincent Keane, the son of Joan and Matthew Keane of Larchmont, N.Y. Msgr. John J. Rowan, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Ostrabrama Roman Catholic Church in Cutchogue, N.Y.

title: Beware Web 'Cookies'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rounds Caps Comeback By Winning 800 Title
description: After the 1988 Olympic trials, Kathi Rounds shelved her running career, disgusted with the state of track and field. After an absence of six years, and the birth of a daughter, she returned to training, only to miss a spot on the 1996 Olympic team because of a competitor's late charge. Today, her comeback reached a more satisfying conclusion with a national title in the women's 800-meter race.

title: Two Children at Library Find Baby in the Trash
description: Alerted by a baby's cries, two children found a newborn girl yesterday morning in a trash can outside a public library in Edison, N.J., the police said. The baby appeared to be healthy, and investigators were searching for her mother. It was the fourth time in less than a month that a newborn appeared to have been abandoned at birth in New Jersey.

title: 80 Candles for Andrew Wyeth
description: When the American artist Andrew Wyeth turns 80 on July 12, there will be celebrations and exhibitions in Maine and Pennsylvania, the two places between which he divides his time.

title: A 50's Fable Whose Edge Doesn't Dull
description: ''COME ON, COME ON.''

title: April K. Mellody, James C. Gillespie
description: April Kathleen Mellody, an assistant press secretary at the White House, and James Christopher Gillespie, a senior research analyst in the office of the White House chief of staff, were married yesterday. The Rev. James McGee performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Scranton, Pa.

title: Flea Market Confidential
description: IN Dover, a pleasant old factory town at the end of the train line in northwest New Jersey, the bells of Sacred Heart Church echoed over the hills last Sunday morning. No Bach chorales waft from the campaniles of Dover, however. title: ANDRE THE ICON

Plus, he's dead.'' Whatever the reason, Andre iconographers are at work from New York to Los Angeles, slapping posters and stickers of the brooding hulk's face on public walls, apparently as an absurdist swipe at society's worship of corporate logos. Fairey, who started the craze, has caught flak for his efforts - he has been jailed in five cities for vandalism - but says the work must go on. Meanwhile, he is about to enjoy a burst of fame: as the subject of a short film, ''Andre the Giant Has a Posse,'' which will be screened later this month at MOMA.

title: Pounding and Protests for Hong Kong's Big Day

A slew of carpenters' hammers echoed through the two main halls this week: the hall where at midnight on June 30 Beijing's resumption of sovereignty will be made formal, and a second hall where soon after midnight its appointed government will be sworn in.

title: A Nice Place for Extinction
description: In 1992, in the mountains of Haiti, an American herpetologist named Victor Grigg and his local guide, Thierry Adrien, are searching for a specimen of Eleutherodactylus sanguineus, the ''blood frog,'' which is believed to be on the verge of extinction. As they proceed on their journey, Victor, who is escaping from an unacknowledged loss, listens to Thierry's fabulous tales of his life and family, of growing up and growing old in Haiti, a country that has been transformed from a place of lush abundance to a sere, mutilated, inhospitable land. But while the two men hunt for the secrets of nature, the macoutes, the deadly thugs who have had so much to do with Haiti's downfall, close in on their own human prey. IN THE PALM OF DARKNESS (HarperCollins, $21), the first of the Cuban-born writer Mayra Montero's four novels to appear in English, is a resplendent piece of writing that brings a mysterious and murderous country throbbingly to life. In a pitch-perfect translation by Edith Grossman, Ms. Montero evokes a world in which science and technology have barely intruded, the magical and the occult flourish, and the gritty reality of ordinary life can also achieve a glorious sensuality. Ms. Montero's novel pinpoints the tragedy of the human species as it threatens inexplicably to devour itself, while at the same time exalting the impulses that lead people to live so hungrily, to feel so voraciously. Zofia Smardz

title: FATHER'S DAY
description: The History of Contraception Museum in Toronto contains 600 artifacts from humankind's endless quest for effective birth control. *''Gathering these things was never easy,'' notes Percy Skuy, the museum's founder, ''because there's really no need for people to keep an old contraceptive item.'' *The first mention of contraception appears in Genesis 38:9, in which Onan ''spilled it on the ground lest that he should give seed.'' *Shifting the burden, Casanova is said to have persuaded his partners to use half a lemon as a disphragm. *Don't try this at home: Six years ago in Australia, teen-age boys used the wrappers from Crunchie and Violet Crumble chocolate bars as condoms. *What's the lesson in it all? Human ingenuity. ''Look how creative people were!'' Skuy marvels. ''One day, people will also look at the methods we use today with curiosity and awe.''

The National Society For Hebrew Day Schools mourns the loss of Mrs. Irma Horwitz who for more than four decades headed the National Associations of Hebrew Day Schools PTAs an affiliate of Torah Umesorah. Irma's father the late lamented Mr. Samuel C. Feuerstein z''l, together with Rabbi Shraga Feivel Mendlowitz, founded Torah Umesorah in 1944. The Day School movement as envisioned by its illustrious founders is today universally recognized as the most indespensible tool in the effort to stem the tide of assimilation in our time. Irma lead a cadre of like minded volunteers who traveled the length and breadth of this country to help establish and strengthen Hebrew Day Schools. This movement today numbers 567 schools and more than 160,000 students. Irma's brillant mind, untiring dedication and inspiring spirit will continue to bear fruits for many years to come. May her memory be a blessing. Torah Umesorah Mr. David Singer, Chairman of the Board Rabbi Joshua Fishman, Executive Vice President Dr. Shmuel Zentman, Treasurer

title: It Happened One Night. O.K., One Morning.
description: IN his memoirs, Benjamin Franklin wrote that he would gladly live life over again, if only he could act like an author preparing a second edition of his book: he should not only be able to fix errors but also modify events, and presumably alter endings. The next best thing to reliving life, Franklin continued, might be recollecting it which, judging from the liberties he took, involved the same sorts of revisions.

title: Angry Congressional Panel Retaliates Against Pentagon Official
description: When the Pentagon last fall raised the price of discounted cigarettes sold in military supermarkets in an effort to cut consumption and improve the troops' health, medical experts cheered.

title: Hate Where We Live? Just Another New York Myth.
description: The stereotype of New Yorkers unhappily imprisoned in tiny, cramped apartments may be mostly myth. Almost half of city residents say they are satisfied with where they live now, and two-thirds say they have enough space, including apartment dwellers. In fact, 40 percent of people in rent-regulated apartments are so content with where they live they'd be willing to pay more to stay put.

title: Dec. 23, 1989
description: Last summer, my wife of eight years found out she was pregnant. A few months later, Emil Constantinescu, a geologist, was elected President of Romania. Mentioning these two apparently unrelated events in the same breath might seem like a non sequitur, but since Christmastime 1989, my fate and Romania's have been inextricably linked, united in a bond of blood and pain. And now, finally, recent developments hold out the possibility of a new beginning for both of us.

These days, though, Mr. Nunez, 32, usually finds himself beside the piano, surrounded by 44 children ages 12 to 18 who run the gamut: rich and poor, parochial and public, white and black, Jewish and Muslim.

title: Suburban and Urban Plights
description: BORN of the railroad and sustained by the automobile, suburbia began as an outlet for city dwellers escaping the hordes of European immigrants. Since those days, it has become a territory with a character all its own, one that seems to offer the advantages of both town and country and the disadvantages of neither. Yet it has been less than successful as a prescription for happiness, the term having acquired pejorative connotations and the place, wherever it may be, having become the butt of derogatory jokes, not all of them made by outsiders.

To others, it is an unending aural nightmare, a clanging, haranguing sleep killer, no better than the shriek of a car alarm. Just about everyone who lives within earshot of Old Jeff, it seems, has strong feelings about the six-ton bronze bell atop Jefferson Market Library, which began ringing last December after a century of slumber.

title: Strangers at Home
description: While Israeli-Palestinian talks remained stalled last week, Israel's policy of revoking the residence permits of Jerusalem Arabs added to the mistrust. More than 1,000 Arabs have lost residency since January 1996 on the grounds that they lived outside Jerusalem for several years or accepted foreign citizenship. Ordered to leave Jerusalem within 15 days, most have remained as illegal aliens in their native city.

title: The Outsider as Hollywood Favorite
description: ON THE OPENING NIGHT of the exhibition ''The Lost World'' at the Museum of Natural History in May, Jeff Goldblum, the hero of Steven Spielberg's latest blockbuster, ''The Lost World,'' seemed to be everywhere, as if he, like his dinosaur co-stars, had been cloned.

Yesterday, in a change most welcome on the Met side, those supposed Achilles' heels became strengths. The kind the Mets used to build a fabulous 18-9 record last month.

A $1.9 billion flood tunnel from Wayne to Newark Bay remains the corps's own preferred option, said Paul Tumminello, its project manager for the Passaic River Basin.

This season, Merrill Ashley, one of the last ballerinas to inspire George Balanchine, observed two estimable milestones: 30 years with the company and 20 of those as a principal dancer. To celebrate, the company skipped the fanfare but quietly presented her with one of her busiest seasons in recent years.

title: 75th St. Congregation Visits Its History

Among them was the 1907 neoclassical Temple Israel, at 201 Malcolm X Boulevard, formerly Lenox Avenue, and 120th Street. For 72 years it has been Mount Olivet Baptist Church. Last Sunday a dozen members of Temple Israel, now at Park Avenue and East 75th Street, toured historic sites around Mount Morris Park, including their temple's former home.

In fact many of these products will be on display this week at the PC Expo industry bazaar in Manhattan. But many analysts say that at $500 or more, the Microsoft-based gadgets so far pose no serious challenge to the popular Palm Pilot by U.S. Robotics.

''

Royalties from offshore oil and gas leases would provide the money, giving the program an interesting symmetry. Dollars raised from depleting one natural resource would be used to protect another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAGER, MAYOR YITZHACK I.
description: RAGER-Mayor Yitzhack I. The officers, directors and friends of the American Committee for the Beer-Sheva Foundation mourn the passing of our founder, our leader, the heart and soul of our organization-our neshama. His distinguished career as a military leader, journalist, radio commentator, businessman, diplomat, International President of State of Israel Bonds, in the Soviet Jewry Movement and Mayor of Beer-Sheva are well documented. The crowned jewel in his extraordinary life of achievement has been his mayoralty of Beer-Sheva. In eight years he led the sleepy desert town of Beer-Sheva to unbelieveable growth and development. His dynamic leadership, foresight, vision and energy have helped Beer-Sheva to become a major city in Israel. Today, Beer-Sheva is truly the capital of the Negev and is helping fulfill the Ben-Gurion dream of the development of the Negev. ''Ijo,'' your legacy will live on forever. Sidney Cooperman Chairman of the Board Elie Wiesel Honorary Chairman of the Board Ronald Slevin, President
