description: President Clinton was in the Oval Office meeting with his new advisory panel on race on Friday when a journalist asked him about widespread skepticism among civil rights leaders that his initiative would go beyond talk.

title: The Respect Divide
description: Corey Arthur made virtually no effort to conceal his role in the murder of Jonathan Levin, investigators said.

title: 2 Men Shot in Robbery At a Grocery in Queens
description: The owner and an employee of a Key Food supermarket in Queens were shot yesterday during a robbery in which the gunman and two accomplices escaped with $23,000, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERG, PETER NEIL
description: BERG-Peter Neil. Age 49, on June 14, 1997. ''His art moved the universe.'' Beloved husband of Jo. Devoted father of Bram. Cherished son of Janet and the late Vernon. Loving brother of Richard and sister-in-law Mindy. Services Tuesday, 1:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: All Eyes On Three Men And a Clock
description: WITH the state's rent laws under revision and the fate of 2.7 million tenants hanging in the balance, events in Albany yesterday seemed the sort New Yorkers would look back on decades from now as a defining experience in their own lives, not to mention the life of the city, a legislative version of the blackout of 1965, or the blizzard of 1969.

title: Novice Newscasters Get Voice Therapy
description: Several nights a week she is beamed into millions of living rooms, her voice authoritative and confident as she deconstructs the trial of Timothy McVeigh for a prime-time television audience. But last week, stripped of her pancake foundation, the newscaster looked more like a nervous schoolgirl awaiting the results of a final exam.

title: Long-Jump Title Caps Jones's Double
description: Having already become the world's fastest woman of the season, Marion Jones today threatened to become the next Carl Lewis.

title: 3 Agencies Acquired In Public Relations
description: Three public relations agencies have been acquired for undisclosed terms.

title: An optical fiber composite to monitor the structural integrity of an airplane body.
description: AIRPLANE accidents often result from a chain of unpredictable events. Sometimes human error is to blame. Occasionally, people aboard planes make mistakes simply because they do not speak up.

title: For Women, 25 Years of Title IX Has Not Leveled the Playing Field
description: Twenty-five years have passed since the Federal Government mandated that women's athletic programs in schools be equitable with men's. President Clinton and female sports pioneers will be commemorating the anniversary in Washington tomorrow.

title: Yanks Edge Mets in Game of Hearts
description: As the Yankees and the Mets get ready for their first regular-season game, which team are New Yorkers rooting for?

title: Pulsipher Progressing, Pitch by Pitch
description: It is a quarter past nine on a sleepy Thursday evening on the western coast of Florida, and Bill Pulsipher is dying to get into a ball game.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: WHITE HOUSE IS SET TO EASE ITS STANCE ON INTERNET SMUT
description: With a groundbreaking Supreme Court decision imminent on a new law restricting children's access to indecent material on the Internet, senior Clinton Administration officials are preparing a policy that undercuts the Administration's strong support of the law until now.

title: Interleague Starts Off Out of Sync in Florida
description: David Wells was in the wrong place at the wrong time; in fact, he was somewhere he was never meant to be -- at least not for the last 25 seasons. Kenny Rogers was in the place he was supposed to be, though he wasn't supposed to be there now, but it always seems to be the wrong time for him. Lots of fans were in the wrong place at the wrong time, too.

title: They'll Still Cheat
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Cuts Aid Growth
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: New York, New York, It's a Competitive Town

title: Seagate Plans Irish Plant
description: Seagate Technology Inc. plans to invest more than 148 million Irish pounds ($223 million) to establish a manufacturing plant in Ringskiddy, in southwest Ireland, creating more than 1,000 jobs in the next three years. The plant will make data storage magnetic disks, which it will supply to the Seagate hard disk drive manufacturing operation in Clonmel, County Tipperary, set up in 1995. Seagate is based in Scotts Valley, Calif.

title: New England Crime Bosses Could Appeal
description: James J. (Whitey) Bulger has a reputation as the organized crime boss who always gets away.

title: Drive a Range Rover? Time to Pay Up
description: To the Editor:

title: Internet Song Use Spurs Recording Industry Suits
description: The recording industry, which has been plagued by piracy of its own in the analog form -- illegal tape recordings -- acknowledged its growing new digital problem quite loudly last week, filing three lawsuits against the operators of Web sites reportedly pirating and distributing copyrighted songs free over the Internet.

title: Disclosures on Travel
description: Representative Donald M. Payne of Newark took more trips that were paid for by nongovernmental groups than anyone else in New Jersey's Congressional delegation last year, financial disclosure reports released last week show.

title: After 40 Years, It's New York At New York
description: Joe Torre does not expect to roll a ball to Bobby Valentine -- or have Valentine roll one to him -- that says, ''Who's going to squeeze, you or me?'' Not this week, not during any of the three games the Yankees will play against the Mets at Yankee Stadium.

title: High Court Backs Netanyahu in Influence-Peddling Case
description: The Israeli Supreme Court today upheld the decision of the Attorney General not to prosecute Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu or his Justice Minister in an influence-peddling case, thus lifting one burden from the embattled Government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOTZ, JACK (JACOB)
description: LOTZ-Jack (Jacob). On June 13, 1997. Beloved husband of Doris. Devoted father of Janet Robinson. Well known and respected in the men's clothing industry for over 50 years and served as office manager for Joseph H. Cohen and Sons. After he retired he became a volunteer teacher of English to foreign-speaking students. Services Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBARD, BRUCE
description: GELBARD-Bruce. Age 45, of Annadale, Staten Island, a retired corporate secretary and a Board of Education official, died Saturday, Staten Island Hospital. Surviving are his wife, the former Lila Schaefer and daugher, Debra Reinish, his parents David and Jean Gelbard, a brother Dr. Mark Gelbard and a sister Trudy Markowitz. The funeral is today with a service at noon in Menorah Chapels, New Springville, Staten Island, 2145 Richmond Avenue. Rabbi Norman Strizower will officiate. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. 51 years ago, we waltzed to the same drummer and remained joined at the hip 'til you left. Love you always, Audrey

title: In a further push into Latin America, DDB Needham is buying a stake in a Brazilian agency.
description: MADISON AVENUE giant is singing along to the Carmen Miranda tune ''South American Way'' -- and just like her, with a Brazilian accent.

title: Methodically, McVeigh Jury Weighed Facts
description: The small jury room was plastered in big white sheets of paper, each one scrawled in colored ink with parts of the case against Timothy J. McVeigh: the bomb, the false names, the credit cards.

title: Bridge
description: Preliminary results in the World Bridge Federation's Worldwide Pairs contest played earlier this month indicate that two Chinese pairs finished first and second. First with 79.4 percent were Zhang Jie and Zhao Jinlung, playing East-West in the game on Friday. Second with 79.1 percent were Zhu Ping and Qi Shengya, playing North-South in the Friday game.

title: Lightening Utility Bills
description: A utility tax that now adds 13.5 percent to consumers' energy bills would be phased out as part of the deregulation of the electric and natural gas industries under a bill to be considered by a State Senate panel today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOK, HENRY
description: HOOK-Henry. Israel and Fenie Feit Family Circle mourn the loss of its member Henry Hook, husband of Beatrice, father of Simeon and Judy Kaplan.

title: E Pluribus Unum?
description: Imagine that the Constitutional Convention of 1787 never happened, that the American states went their separate ways. Then, years later, they set out to create a common currency, good in all 13 states, with a central bank to manage it -- while 13 independent governments continued to make the political decisions.

title: Accounts
description: * Levitz Furniture, Boca Raton, Fla., to Bozell Retail, New York, a division of the Bozell Worldwide unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, as agency of record, succeeding David Cravit & Associates, Chicago, which closed. Bozell Retail will focus on creative, production and media duties for the broadcast portion of Levitz's account, with billings estimated at $25 million.

title: Honors for Work In Public Relations
description: Fleishman-Hillard Inc. won the most top awards, called Silver Anvils, at the 1997 awards presentation sponsored by the Public Relations Society of America in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, GEORGE S., C.P.A.
description: GOLDBERG-George S., C.P.A., of Dix Hills, LI, on June 13, 1997, after a long struggle. Beloved husband of Rhoda and devoted father to Alan and Jackie Goldberg of New York City and Jacqui and Matt O'Connell of Pensacola, FL. Loving grandfather to Jason, Ryan and Emily, and brother of the late Marilyn Ellen Goldberg. He was our daddy and will be dearly missed. Services Monday, June 16, at 1 PM, at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, LI. Donations can be made in his memory to Temple Beth-El or Huntington Hospital. Daddy was on a transplant list at the time of his death. He firmly believed in this cause. Find it in your hearts to be an organ donor.

title: Opening a Conversation on Race
description: In proposing a year-long national ''conversation'' about race, President Clinton put the nation's most important social problem where it belongs, at the top of the national agenda. His speech on Saturday at commencement exercises of the University of California at San Diego was a sermon with little sanctimonious preaching. He went beyond the obvious need for racial justice to the practical and even economic reasons why the United States must nurture its increasingly diverse society.

title: The Khmer Rouge Implosion
description: The violent self-destruction of the Khmer Rouge leadership reported in the last few days appears to mark the end of a civil war that has riven Cambodia in one form or another for 30 years.

title: Lehman, Sinking Again, Would Give Anything for a Mulligan
description: TOM Lehman's life has been an Open book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OKON, SAUL
description: OKON-Saul, on June 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Ann and Ira. Loving brother and brother-in-law of Shirley and Robert Bloom. Uncle of Wendy and Carlos and Paul and Michele. WW II veteran, lover of classical music, world traveler and ceramicist. Services today, 11 AM at the Reform Temple of Suffern, Suffern, NY. Shiva will be observed at the family's home through Thursday evening.

title: View From a Teacher's Desk: The Students Aren't Studying
description: To the Editor:

title: A Slippery U.N. Deal
description: Given Senator Jesse Helms's longstanding antipathy to the United Nations, the budgetary deal he has struck with Senate Democrats and the Clinton Administration constitutes progress. Mr. Helms would authorize payment of $819 million over three years to the world organization, less than the $1.3 billion the U.N. says the United States owes. This at least acknowledges that back dues are owed. But the catch is that this reduced payment comes with a variety of conditions, including a Congressional intention to shave the American contribution to U.N. operations from 25 to 20 percent, whether or not other U.N. members agree.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARDWELL, LELIA M.
description: WARDWELL-Lelia M., 90, June 11, 1997, peacefully at home. Wife of the late Edward R. Wardwell, mother of Lelia W. Seidner, Allen Wardwell, Helen W. DuBois. Also survived by her sister-in-law Clarissa Wardwell Pell, 9 grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Memorial service Wednesday, June 18, 11am, Church of the Epiphany, E. 74 St & York Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Church of the Epiphany or the the New York Philharmonic.

title: Day of Ups And Downs For Yanks And Kelly
description: The afternoon began with Kenny Rogers stumbling, continued with Don Zimmer grumbling and changed dramatically once the Yankees started rumbling toward the end of the first game. The evening should have ended triumphantly for the Yankees after Dwight Gooden forced enough Florida Marlin hitters into mumbling in the second game, but Pat Kelly rose and fell in the ninth inning, so the Yankees succumbed.

title: 11 PC Makers To Introduce Stripped-Down Office Model
description: In its infancy, the personal computer industry made a major selling point of saying that PC's offered freedom from the arbitrary dictates of the corporate data center with its bureaucratic caretakers in white lab coats. Now, as the maturing PC industry approaches the end of its second decade, central authority is in.

title: So Far, U.S. the Winner in Asia 'Open Skies' Pacts
description: SINGAPORE  A spreading patchwork quilt of "open skies" agreements finalized between the United States and Asia-Pacific countries since April is offering passengers the prospect of more services at lower prices in the world's fastest growing aviation market.

title: Colombian Rebels Release 70 Soldiers and Marines
description: With the flags of a clandestine rebel movement held high and its anthem playing in the town square, the rebels freed some 70 Colombian soldiers and marines today after the Government agreed to cede temporary control of a swath of territory to the insurgents.

title: Muzzled in Singapore
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Dies After Jumping In Front of Subway Train
description: A man who jumped to the tracks in front of an oncoming No. 7 train was struck and killed last night in Woodside, Queens, the police said.

title: Airbus to Make Bigger Versions Of Large Jet
description: Airbus Industrie, which is in an increasing competition with the Boeing Company for the world's commercial aircraft market, said today that it would build two larger versions of its biggest jet, the four-engine A340.

title: Dutch Take 'Third Way' to Prosperity
description: The Dutch are used to living with a potent mix of neighbors often seen here as more pushy or flamboyant than themselves. They watch the mighty Germans, the elitist French and the insular British and sometimes get a little sour about being ignored while others drive European affairs.

title: For Tenants, Anger At Albany May Linger
description: Even though the tentative agreement reached early this morning would extend rent protections for most tenants, politicians in Albany could face lingering anger over the time and tempers involved in arriving at the deal.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Another Venice Biennale Shuffles to Life
description: When it comes to big, international art exhibitions, the Venice Biennale has something none of the others can match: the brilliant, seductive artwork that is the city itself. The city's ancient sights and pleasures, as much as the promise of any insight into contemporary art, draw art-world professionals from around the globe to this fabled archipelago in just-happy-to-be-here droves.

title: Abortion Ban to Be Weighed
description: The State Senate will consider a bill today to ban a late-term abortion procedure.

title: Lott Calls Clinton 'Spoiled Brat' For Stand on Tax Cuts in Accord
description: Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, today called President Clinton a ''spoiled brat'' for wanting his own way in divvying up proposed tax cuts.

title: Montgomerie Covets Title He Just Can't Win
description: It made for good viewing. Colin Montgomerie acknowledged that much. Four players in the hunt over the final few dramatic holes. A match-play atmosphere between him and his playing partner, Ernie Els. The United States Open on the line.

title: Men Behaving Badly, Or at Least Not Too Well
description: WOMEN WITH MEN

title: When Going Public With Pain Can Be Healing
description: Judith Helfand was 14, watching Phil Donohue's talk show, when she first heard about diethylstilbestrol, or DES, the drug once commonly given to pregnant women to prevent miscarriages and later found to cause cervical cancer in their daughters. ''You didn't take that drug did you?'' Ms. Helfand asked her mother.

description: ''Beset with invisible boomerangs.''

description: A letter from the Embassy of Saudi Arabia in Washington:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, LEONARD
description: FELDMAN - Leonard. You're missed, loved and remembered. Gail, Robert and William

title: 2 Brewers in Talks On Molson Stake
description: The Molson Companies and Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. are in negotiations to repurchase the Miller Brewing Company's 20 percent stake in Molson Breweries, a Molson spokesman said today.

title: Croatian Chief Re-elected by Wide Margin
description: After a campaign that outside monitors condemned as ''fundamentally flawed,'' Franjo Tudjman trounced his beleaguered opposition to win another five-year term as Croatia's President, according to official election results announced tonight.

title: Before the Golf Drama, An NBC Melodrama
description: Golf, we are told, is mystical and magical, more than whacking a dimpled ball into a hole. Aficionados of other sports often go bobbing for deep meaning; witness the many precious tomes proclaiming baseball's significance.

title: Former Pilot Signs Deal To Write About Sex Case
description: Four weeks after resigning her position as the Air Force's first female B-52 pilot, Kelly Flinn has signed a deal with Random House to write a book about the national controversy over her affair with a married civilian.

title: Another Rally In Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong stocks rose today for a second day in an across-the-board rally as a new index of China shares gave investors a fresh reason to buy the market's hottest companies.

title: Contemporary Music Drawing Crowds on the West Coast
description: Something is happening with the West Coast's two most prominent orchestras, the San Francisco Symphony and the Los Angeles Philharmonic, and classical music executives are taking note. Contemporary music, which is supposed to be anathema -- all those works audiences sit through as a penance for the sin of preferring Tchaikovsky -- is becoming more prevalent and popular. This is partly because the styles of new music are becoming more accessible, but also because of the interest generated when musicians who are truly excited by new music reflect that in their playing.

title: Chess
description: In the 12th running of the Aegon Human-vs.-Computer Tournament, 50 of the world's best computers competed against 50 human players, with a time control of 90 minutes for all moves plus a bonus of 30 seconds for each move.

title: A Molehill of Rent Reform
description: Gov. George Pataki and legislative leaders have reached an agreement on rent regulation that does nothing to dismantle the cumbersome bureaucracy that has crippled the housing market in New York State since World War II. But the agreement does at least make some good changes in the existing rules. That is fortunate, since the State Legislature is unlikely to have the stomach for another rent regulation fight for a very long time.

title: White House Shows A Willingness to Aid In Tobacco Dispute
description: A top Clinton Administration official said yesterday in an interview that the White House would be willing to review a tobacco settlement proposal even if negotiators in the talks were unable to resolve the contentious issue of punitive damages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIT, HAROLD
description: MAIT-Harold. Our hearts go out to Janet, Josh, Jenny and David. Our Parents Group has been tragically diminished. Loving friends, The Fraidstern, Lehrman and Small Families

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIGRO, GIOVANNA
description: NIGRO-Giovanna. The Board of Directors and Staff of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City mourn the passing of Giovanna Nigro, a program director at UCP for 28 years. Miss Nigro's level of achievement in her work and commitment to the disabled was unparalleled. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family.

title: Start Expanding That Garage For Detroit's Next Generation
description: Big is getting bigger on the American road.

title: A Once-Mighty Radiotelescope Moves Back to the Cutting Edge
description: Even the mightiest telescopes grow old, and unless rejuvenated by new technology, they may end up as mothballed museum pieces. That fate has been averted for the largest radiotelescope in the world, now 34 years old, which has just completed a radical and costly face lift.

description: BRIGHT ANGEL TIME

title: 2 Appointees Ousted From Animal Group
description: Two mayoral appointees on the board of a nonprofit agency that runs the city's animal control system were dismissed yesterday after publicly criticizing the Giuliani administration's handling of the agency.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Saturday about the formation of a partnership by the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company to buy and own office buildings misstated the history of the 19 properties held by the partnership. Mass Mutual bought all of the properties in the last year to finance the partnership; it did not transfer real estate already on its books.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD TO BE SOLD FOR $52.8 MILLION
description: The lingerie retailer Frederick's of Hollywood Inc. will be sold to a group led by the closely held Knightsbridge Capital Corporation, an investment bank. Frederick's said on Sunday that the Knightsbridge group would pay $6.14 in cash for all of Frederick's 8.6 million class A and class B common shares outstanding, giving the transaction a value of $52.8 million. The class A shares were up 62.5 cents, at $5.875, yesterday, while the class B shares were up $1.1875, at $5.9375. After the purchase, Frederick's would be privately held and continue to operate its catalogue business and about 200 retail stores in 39 states, a spokesman said. Knightsbridge is based in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, MARY
description: ROTHMAN-Mary, age 97. Loving wife of the late Marty Rothman. Her friends and family will long cherish her lively spirit, intelligence and love. She enriched our lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLAN, SAMUEL C., MD.
description: KARLAN-Samuel C., MD. On June 15, 1997, of Whitestone, Queens, at the age of 89. Graduate of NYU Medical School, he practiced neurology and psychiatry in Queens for over 40 years. Beloved husband for 62 years of the late Florence Greenfield Karlan and father of Robert D. Karlan and Naomi Freedman. Loving grandfather of Diane Karlan, Susan Karlan, Wendy Kramer, Michael Karlan, Deborah Freedman Ledbetter, Jane Freedman Iafrati and Richard Freedman, and great-grandfather of Jennifer and Allison Kramer, Emma and Lucie Ledbetter, Rebecca, David and Hannah Iafrati and Emily and Jessica Freedman. He had a long, rich and fulfilled life and leaves a legacy of love and inspiration for his children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Services 1:00 PM, Tuesday, June 17, at Schwartz Bros. Funeral Home, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Gay, and Patriotic, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Rabbis Listed Among Suspects In Laundering Of Drug Profits
description: A dozen men, including two identified as Orthodox Jewish rabbis, were charged by Federal authorities yesterday with conspiring to launder and hide $1.75 million in drug profits for Colombian narcotics dealers by routing the cash through the bank accounts of a synagogue and a yeshiva in Borough Park, Brooklyn.

title: He Lit Nuclear Fire; Now He Would Douse It
description: FOR the things I do, it's accurate enough,'' Dr. Hans A. Bethe said as he rummaged though his briefcase and pulled out a slide rule, a relic from the days before computers took over tedious number-crunching for most scientists. Its battered case told of considerable use.

title: Two Death Penalty Cases, One Dilemma
description: The simultaneous death penalty trials of Jesse Timmendequas, who raped and murdered 7-year-old Megan Kanka, and Timothy McVeigh perfectly illustrate what Americans think about the death penalty: We think it is a just and valid punishment, even though it is not all that clear when it should be applied.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, SARAH LYNN
description: MOSS-Sarah Lynn, 36, died on Monday after a short illness. She is survived by her parents, four sisters, a nephew, two nieces. Moss, a graduate of L.S.U. and The Natural Gourmet Cooking School was chef at The Botany Restaurant. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, June 18 at the John Krtil Funeral Home at 1297 First Avenue. Visitation 5:00 P.M., Service 5:30 P.M. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, the American Lung Association or the Fresh Air Fund.

title: Toll Workers Union Signs Tentative Pact
description: The union representing 650 bridge and tunnel workers announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority that calls for a 10.4 percent wage increase over 39 months.

title: McLeodUSA and Consolidated To Merge in $400 Million Deal
description: McLeodUSA Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Consolidated Communications Inc. for $400 million in cash and stock, eliminating a rival in the Midwestern telephone market.

title: Cost-Cutting Plan Limits Choices for Revolving-Door Addicts
description: The numbers were so out of line that even experienced bureaucrats could not believe them when they got their first look two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GETTMAN, SHEILA
description: GETTMAN-Sheila passed away in her home at Westbury on June 13,1997. Beloved wife, mom, mother-in-law, grandma, sister and neice. She is survived by her husband Jules, her children Lonnie, Laurie, and Steven, son-in-law Eric, grandchildren Gina, Arielle and Mark, her sister Gloria and her Aunt Sarah. She will be remembered most for her generous and self sacrificing spirit. She will ALWAYS be treasured for her everlasting love and caring nature.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES SAYS IT IS TALKING TO A POSSIBLE BUYER
description: Responding to questions about a recent rise in its stock price, Core Industries said yesterday that it was in discussions with a possible buyer of the company. Core's shares rose $3.50 yesterday, to $23.25, giving the company a market capitalization of almost $250 million. The shares were as low as $12.75 as recently as April 15. The company, based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., makes electronic and hydraulic controls for farm and construction equipment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLAYSON, STUART LATHROP
description: FINLAYSON-Stuart Lathrop, last sighted in New Zealand on March 12, 1997. A service will be held on Saturday, June 21 at 4 P.M., First Church of Round Hill, 464 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, you may wish to make contributions to the following: Greenwich Library, 101 West Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. 06830; Choate Rosemary Hall, 333 Christian St., Wallingford, CT. 06492; Brown University, Box 1893, Providence, Rhode Island 02912.

title: Auto Insurance Plan Diluted
description: A State Assembly committee voted yesterday to weaken a key part of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to lower auto insurance rates by aggressively fighting insurance fraud. The bill's sponsor, Assemblyman E. Scott Garrett, said he believed that New Jersey drivers would see no reduction in their premiums if the amended bill became law.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Dark Passion Pushing Against Cool Distance
description: The accent was on smoldering drama in three premieres presented by Buglisi/Foreman Dance on Saturday night at the Clark Studio Theater at Lincoln Center. That is not surprising, given that the company's four founders (Jacqulyn Buglisi, Terese Capucilli, Christine Dakin and Donlin Foreman) have all performed with Martha Graham. What was unusual -- and heartening -- was the program's balance between dark theatricality and cooler abstraction.

title: Stocks Mixed, With the Dow Falling 9.95
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with many investors taking a breather from last week's buying spree, which sent all the major indexes to record after record.

title: Ernst & Young Gets Space at 55 Broad
description: Ernst & Young L.L.P. has leased two floors at 55 Broad Street, at Beaver Street, where about 140 new employees will provide software development for the accounting and consulting firm's clients.

title: In Ashes of Gutted Bronx Church, Community Sees Rebirth
description: A five-alarm fire devastated a nearly 100-year-old Roman Catholic church on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx on Sunday night. But yesterday, as the bright sunlight of a flawless late spring day streamed through the charred roof of the church, St. Philip Neri, its clergy and parishioners saw in its ruins a vision of the future.

title: Schools Should Tackle Gay Issue Directly
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams Can't Run, And Will Miss Series
description: The monumental matchup between the Yankees and the Mets was only two hours away and the excitement was spreading throughout Yankee Stadium. But Bernie Williams, the best player on the Yankees, was snoozing on a trainer's table. A strained left hamstring was expected to keep him from playing in the three-game series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, SYLVIA
description: FELDMAN-Sylvia. Age 79. On Jun 16, 1997, peacefully in her sleep. Beloved wife of Joseph Feldman and Herman Flink. Mother of Claire Press and Lawrence and Susan Feldman. Grandmother of Julie and Jeremy Feldman, Carey Press and Jody and Michael Strong. Services will be held at Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave., Tuesday 12 noon. Interment Mount Zion, Maspeth.

title: Pettitte Fizzles Early And Yanks Strand 11
description: Andy Pettitte was especially casual before last night's memorable encounter with the Mets, playful enough to inform an inquisitive and gullible bat boy that Joe Torre had eliminated him from starting the historic game and frisky enough to tease reporters who were staking out Bernie Williams's locker.

title: Bruce K. Gelbard, 45, Official At Center of School Board Fight
description: Bruce K. Gelbard, the powerful secretary to the New York City Board of Education who was ousted last summer, died Saturday at Staten Island Hospital. He was 45.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: French Concerns Rebuffed As Currency Plan Proceeds

title: Bill Voted in Trenton to Ban Disputed Abortion Method
description: The State Senate passed a bill today that would ban what abortion opponents call ''partial-birth abortion,'' although the vote fell just short of the number needed to override a promised veto from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOOK, HENRY
description: HOOK-Henry, on June 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Loving father of Simeon (Sheila) Hook and Judy (Joel) Kaplan. Devoted brother of Lillian Borts and Mathilda Hook. Adored grandfather of Chani (Shmuel), Naomi (Haim), Avi and Ira. Proud great-grandfather of Rikki, Yael and Talia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBARD, BRUCE
description: GELBARD-Bruce. Friends and colleagues at the Board of Education mourn the sad and premature passing of Bruce, former Secretary of the Board, and Chief Administrator of the Impartial Hearing Office. Eash of us has very special memories of a very special person. Deepest sympathy to his wife Leila, his step-daughter Debra, his parnets, David and Jean, his sister Trudy and brother Mark.

title: Federal Prosecutors Seek Death Penalty In Manhattan Case
description: For the first time in more than 40 years, Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have decided to seek the death penalty, asking permission from Attorney General Janet Reno to pursue a capital case against a man they accuse of nine murders in his role as head of a violent drug gang.

title: Candidates to Square Off
description: Governor Whitman and the man who wants her job, State Senator James E. McGreevey, will meet face to face at a dinner tonight for the first time in their campaign. Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, and Mr. McGreevey, a Democrat from Woodbridge, will address business lobbyists at the Employer Legislative Committees of New Jersey's dinner at the Princeton Hyatt Regency. Both sides promised to keep things clean. ''She's going to talk about her record,'' said Jenny Rider, a Whitman spokeswoman. ''He's not going to get down and dirty,'' said Nicole Tedeschi, a spokeswoman for Mr. McGreevey.

title: Who's Afraid of Markus Wolf?
description: Markus Wolf, for nearly 34 years the head of East Germany's Ministry of State Security, or Stasi, and perhaps the greatest spymaster of modern times, wants to visit the United States to promote his just-published autobiography. But if he shows up, American officials vow that he will be sent back to Germany on the next plane.

title: Turkey's Prime Minister, About to Step Down, Defends Record
description: At what seemed to be a farewell news conference, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan said today that he would soon resign but predicted that after new elections he would be returned to office with a stronger mandate.

title: An Un-Washington Sort of Guy Longs for Home
description: Some White House chiefs of staff practically have to be dynamited out of office. Some resign discreetly for the good of the President. But Erskine B. Bowles, President Clinton's current chief of staff, has been advertising his departure for months.

title: The First Brag Belongs to Mlicki and the Mets
description: Forget the Mayor's Trophy game, forget Fort Lauderdale, forget St. Petersburg. This was New York, and this was for real.

title: Japan, Adept at Imitating, Starts to Invest in Innovation
description: TOKYO  "Knowledge shall be sought for all over the world, and thus shall be strengthened the foundation of the imperial polity."

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Eating Well column on June 4, about testing calcium supplements for lead, referred incorrectly to the president of the Leiner Health Products Corporation, which makes supplements that comply with California's standard for levels of lead. The president, Gale Bensussen, is a man.

title: Only 3 Nations Qualify Now, He Says : Top General Defends U.S. Choices for NATO
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General John Shalikashvili, on Monday strongly defended the U.S. preference to admit only three new members to NATO at this time, but said the alliance should draw other applicants steadily closer, enhancing the Partnership for Peace and "bringing them inside the fence" at NATO headquarters.

title: Investor Seeks Bidding Edge For Landmark On 42d St.
description: A New York real estate investor has bought a piece of the $250 million mortgage on the Chrysler Building, possibly gaining an early advantage in bidding for the 77-story Art Deco tower, which is expected to be put up for sale within a few months.

title: CAPITOL IN DISCORD OVER PLAN TO AID UNINSURED YOUTHS
description: Even though President Clinton and Congress have agreed to spend $16 billion on health care for uninsured children in the next five years, a major dispute has broken out over whether the states or the Federal Government should decide how to use the money.

title: British Bank Weighs Bid For Finance Operation
description: The British bank Abbey National P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire Cater Allen Holdings P.L.C., which is an intermediary between the Bank of England and big commercial banks. According to a report in The Financial Times, the London newspaper, Abbey National could pay as much as $:200 million ($327 million) for Cater Allen,

title: Bonds Advance Modestly as Investors Await Price Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly in light trading yesterday, as market participants waited for today's Government's report on consumer prices for last month.

title: Tales for Head and Heart On Randalls Emerald Isle
description: Step-dancing replaced slam-dancing for one stadium show this summer, when the Guinness Fleadh arrived on Randalls Island last weekend. The London Fleadh (pronounced flah), named after a traditional Irish festival, has been an annual event in England for the last seven years, bringing together Irish performers and others who share a touch of Celtic sensibility.

title: PRICE COMMUNICATIONS IN $168 MILLION DEAL ON PHONE LIST
description: The Price Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell part of the Fort Myers, Fla., customer list it would soon acquire from Palmer Wireless Inc. to Wireless Network L.P. for $168 million. Price Communications, based in New York, agreed last month to acquire Palmer, a cellular telephone concern, for about $506 million plus $380 million in assumed debt. Palmer and Wireless Network are both based in the Fort Myers area, which has about 382,000 potential customers, or about 10 percent of Palmer's 3.9 million potential customers to be acquired by Price. Price said the Palmer acquisition was an attempt to enter into the wireless communications business. Palmer owns and operates 18 cellular telephone systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUYLER, BEN H.
description: KUYLER-Ben H. Husband of Pauline, father of Laury and Ray, brother of Julius and Leonard, wonderful grandpa to Phoebe and Luke. For shiva information contact Sinai Chapels, 718-445-0300.

title: No Grant for Mayor's School
description: Mayor Bret Schundler of Jersey City is one of the architects of the state's charter school law, under which 16 publicly funded, independently run schools will open starting this fall. But yesterday, when the State Department of Education named 14 charter schools that will get start-up grants, a school that the mayor himself helped found was not among them.

description: To the Editor:

title: After Ad Barrage, Target Unveils Some of Its Plans
description: For several weeks now, Target, the giant discount chain from the Midwest, has bombarded the New York market with advertisements that are clever riffs on life in the city, sprinkled with images of yellow cabs and Central Park. But with only one new store in the metropolitan area, in Menlo Park, N.J., Target has prompted some puzzlement with its advertising blitz.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKEL, ANITA
description: FINKEL-Anita. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, June 18, at 5PM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Officially, Sicily Is Desperately Short of Jobs, but Sub Rosa, Things Are Rosier
description: On paper, this town on the slopes of Mount Etna should be on the verge of a social revolt. Unemployment now stands officially at 30 percent. Bankruptcies are up, credit is tight, and as the hot Sicilian summer approaches, people like Antonio DiStefano wonder how they are going to feed their families.

title: U.S. SURGICAL LOWERS ITS BID FOR CIRCON TO $14.50 A SHARE
description: The U.S. Surgical Corporation of Norwalk, Conn., said yesterday that it had lowered its offer to acquire 973,174 shares of a rival surgical-equipment maker, the Circon Corporation of Santa Barbara, Calif., to $14.50 each, from $17. U.S. Surgical said the purchase would bring its ownership of Circon to 14.9 percent, the biggest stake it could obtain without setting off Circon's shareholder-rights plan, commonly known as a poison pill. It said it had lowered the offer to reflect Circon's recent performance. Circon shares closed yesterday at $13.391, up 64.1 cents. Circon's board has repeatedly rejected U.S. Surgical's offers. After the current offer expires on July 14, U.S. Surgical plans to begin a new offer for all of Circon's outstanding shares at $16.50 each.

title: Milton Blatt, 87, Track Coach and Teacher
description: Milton Blatt, an inspiring teacher and coach at Andrew Jackson High School in Queens who guided its track and cross-country teams to national prominence, died last Thursday at his home in Glen Cove, N.Y. He was 87.

title: RALLY'S AND CHECKERS CALL OFF HAMBURGER CHAIN MERGER
description: Rally's Hamburgers Inc. and Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc. said yesterday that they had halted their $174 million merger because of regulatory problems. The two hamburger chains said they were unable to obtain approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a certain accounting treatment. In March, Checkers agreed to buy Rally's in a stock transaction that would have given the combined company about 950 restaurants, primarily in the Southeast and the Midwest. Both companies have struggled in recent years because of increased competition from other fast-food chains. Checkers is based in Clearwater, Fla., and Rally's, in Louisville, Ky.

title: Seeding Seesaw at Wimbledon
description: Showing a marked predilection for able-bodied young servers and the not-so-young Boris Becker, and showing a marked lack of interest in the former French Open champions Thomas Muster and Michael Chang, the ever-subjective seeding committee at the All England Lawn and Tennis Club yesterday released the men's seedings for Wimbledon, which begins next Monday.

title: Troupe's Anniversary, an Occasion for Fun
description: The New York Baroque Dance Company celebrated its 20th anniversary on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall with a goofy new work, a charming children's suite and a retrospective that suggested why the troupe is so esteemed.

title: Digital Cameras Do New Tricks
description: JUST as camcorders have turned home movie cameras into charming antiques, digital still cameras will one day take the place of film models. But that day remains a long way off, even though manufacturers are releasing so many new models it is hard to keep track. Two relatively pricey recent models from Sony Electronics Inc. show how much better these cameras are getting and how much better they could be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOS, PETER
description: BLOS-Peter. The staff and Board of Trustees of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services are deeply saddened by the death of Peter Blos, Ph.D. Dr. Blos served as clinical consultant and teacher to generations of professionals at JBFCS. He was an extraordinary teacher and theoretician on the psychological development of adolescents and on the clinical treatment of troubled children, youth, and families. For the last twenty-six years, the Martha K. Selig Educational Institute of JBFCS has sponsored the Peter Blos Biennial Lecture, which JBFCS looks forward to continuing in lasting memory of Dr. Blos. A graduate of Carnegie Mellon University and The Art Students League she was a mural artist of distinction. She was associated with art interests throughout her life. title: Political Rivals Maneuver On Reports of Pol Pot Flight
description: First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh said today that he expected Pol Pot, the fugitive Khmer Rouge leader, to be killed or captured in the next few days and that he hoped to hand him over alive to an international tribunal.

title: Corrections

It was 84 years, ended on Saturday, not the 146 years since The Times's founding.

title: BT INDUSTRIES TO BUY RAYMOND FOR $353 MILLION
description: BT Industries A.B. of Sweden will acquire the Raymond Corporation of Greene, N.Y., for $33 a share, or about $353 million, as BT expands its global materials-handling equipment business, the companies said yesterday. The share price in the deal, which was unanimously approved by Raymond's board, is lower than the closing price on Friday of $35.125, a record. Shares fell $2.375 yesterday, to $32.75. An investment group including Metropolitan Capital Advisers Inc. has pushed for a sale of Raymond for months. The company makes narrow-aisle lift trucks used in factories and warehouse stores like Office Depot. Raymond had 1996 revenue of about $305 million.

title: Sunless Tanning at a Spa
description: If you crave a suntan without exposure to the sun, you can use a self-tanning product that gives the skin a golden glow. But achieving a natural-looking result is tricky. Day spas offer self-tanning by professionals who apply the product even in hard-to-reach spots, for an even ''tan.''

description: In the top of the seventh inning at Yankee Stadium last night, with the bases full of Mets and John Olerud at the plate, the capacity crowd was screaming its split personality for all it was worth, with cries of ''Let's Go Mets'' and ''Let's Go Yankees'' competing on the airwaves, their different rhythms creating a different kind of cacophony than had ever been heard before in the Bronx ball park.

title: Court Upholds Findings In Ex-Comptroller's Case
description: A state appeals court has upheld an investigative panel's findings that Elizabeth Holtzman, the former New York City Comptroller, had violated conflict-of-interest laws in securing a campaign loan from a bank trying to win city business.

description: ''Nothing happens that God doesn't know about,'' says the 10-year-old boy, obviously wise beyond his years, to the 30-year-old priest who is his confessor. That's the cue for Father and child to kiss, lingeringly and on the mouth.

They also adopted a nonbinding blueprint to guide countries in protecting a deteriorating global environment while at the same time promoting economic well-being.

Yesterday two employees of the pizza parlor, Stefano's Pizzeria and Ristorante, pleaded guilty to drug conspiracy charges in Federal court.

Contributions in his memory to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Japanese Bank Discusses Forming Ties to Barclays
description: Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd., one of the weakest of Japan's big banks, is discussing linking with Barclays Bank P.L.C. in a broad range of areas, including asset securitization. description: Gabelli & Company, the asset management firm, has lost its effort to overturn an $850,000 arbitration award won by a former employee, Elizabeth R. Bramwell.

title: Korean Folk Tunes Vying With Grand Orchestral Colors
description: The Pusan Philharmonic Orchestra from South Korea is celebrating its 35th anniversary this year as well as its first full season with a new music director, Sung Kwak. Mr. Kwak took up the ensemble's reins after holding the directorship of the Austin Symphony and assistant conducting posts at the Cleveland Orchestra and the Atlanta Symphony.

For more information contact Platt's Funeral Home, 337 North Belar Road, Evans, GA.

description: Rock-and-roll would be nowhere near as exciting and compelling without the help of people who don't understand it. Ozzfest '97 at Giants Stadium on Sunday was a perfect example of an ordinary rock show turned into a mass display of rebellion and defiance solely because of the uninformed hostility of authority figures.

title: Sports Is Catching Up To the Wicked 'Arliss'
description: The world of Arliss Michaels, the self-proclaimed sports superagent, is so mercenary, double-dealing and generally unheroic that it makes ''Jerry Maguire'' seem like Sunday school. That is the secret of the series' charm. Now that sports has become big-time show business, and the myth of the All-American hero has given way to questions about drugs, gambling and multimillion-dollar contracts, the wicked satire of ''Arliss'' is just a few shades away from reality.

title: Calpers Draws A Blueprint for Its Concept of An Ideal Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NILES, DAVID
description: NILES-David. The suave voice that brought sophistication to the airwaves passed away on June 12, 1997. A broadcast pioneer, a founding member of AFRA, (later AFTRA) and WEVD chief announcer for 37 years. Started on WMCA in 1933 after a career in the stage and silent movies. He held WEVD together allmost until the time it ceased to be known as ''the station that speaks your language,'' the memorable slogan that David Niles originated. For American Thymele Theatre and all your friends, Stephen Diacrussi and family.

title: Tracking Swiss Deals With the Devil
description: ''Nazi Gold'' will do nothing to shine up Switzerland's image, much tarnished in the past year by allegations that money deposited in its banks in the 1930's by Europe's threatened Jews has vanished. A lawyer who is suing the Swiss Government on behalf of Jewish survivors and the families of those who did not survive says drily, ''It was the only safe place to put money.''

title: Mixed Results in Return Of Huskey and Johnson
description: Two hours before the Mets boarded buses to the Bronx yesterday, Manager Bobby Valentine stepped out of the home dugout at desolate Shea Stadium and into the bright afternoon sun wearing orange shorts and a white T-shirt. Already a half-dozen of his injured players were testing their various strains and pains.

title: It's a Small World
description: If you grew up within a 30-mile radius of Disneyland in the past 25 years, the Main Street Electrical Parade is a recurring childhood memory, somewhere along the lines of Kool-Aid and Big Wheels. But unlike the latter two, you never quite outgrow the parade. The zippy theme music is a wedding reception staple -- my friends have used it to introduce their attendants -- and when Disney announced several years ago that the parade would be retired, music stores sold out of the Electrical Parade CD. After a fruitless search, I tried the last resort of a Christmas list to get it, but my mother refused. ''You're too old,'' she said.

The deal would continue the rapid consolidation of the nursing home industry, creating one of the biggest chains of homes and outpatient services for the elderly in northern New Jersey, the Boston area, Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

There won't be another plane until tomorrow. And if you want to go from Kishinev, the capital of Moldova, to Prague, you might be better off connecting through Moscow, a 1,600-kilometer detour.

title: The Last Days of Pol Pot
description: Reports from Cambodia, though unconfirmed, suggest that the chief architect of that country's misery is in final retreat. After more than 30 years of fighting and killing, the hated Khmer Rouge is reportedly in complete disarray and its supreme leader, Pol Pot, is said to be fleeing for his life. That is surely welcome news for a country where more than a million people died under Khmer Rouge rule two decades ago and where ordinary Cambodians have endured the group's guerrilla attacks ever since.

title: Protests Persist Over Shooting

Nearly 300 people marched in front of City Hall to demand the arrest of Robert Leaks Jr., the officer who killed 31-year-old Danette Daniels. An organizer of the rally, Terrence Dent, said the protests will continue every Monday until Officer Leaks, a 10-year veteran who was suspended without pay after the shooting, is indicted on murder charges.

title: EARNINGS REPORT LIFTS MICRON TECHNOLOGY STOCK
description: Shares of Micron Technology Inc. and Micron Electronics Inc., which is majority-owned by Micron Technology, rose yesterday after the two companies reported quarterly earnings that were stronger than expected. Micron Technology, a semiconductor company based in Boise, Idaho, earned $96.8 million, or 45 cents a share, in its third quarter, up 66 percent from a year earlier and sharply higher than the 38 cents a share that analysts had expected. Micron Electronics, which produces computing systems and products, reported earnings of $19.7 million, or 20 cents a share, up 40 percent from a year earlier. The results were announced after the stock market closed. In after-hours trading, Micron Technology shares rose to $42.875, up from its close of $41.75. Micron Electronics rose to $18.125 from its close of $17.875.

description: The Army is far better than society on issues of race, Sgt. Darrius Rochester said on a drizzly afternoon, and he did not have to look far for proof: He was one man in a crowd more mixed racially than most places, watching as 30 or so aging soldiers stood at attention at a retirement ceremony here at the Fort Campbell Army base. Half the retirees were black.

title: KRAFT TO SELL CHEESE DISTRIBUTOR TO SCHRATTER FOODS
description: Kraft Foods agreed yesterday to sell its Anco Foods cheese distribution business to Schratter Foods of Montvale, N.J., a unit of the French cheesemaker Bongrain Group and one of the first United States importers of French cheese. Terms of the sale, which the companies expect to complete by June 30, were not disclosed. Anco, based in Fairfield, N.J., imports and distributes specialty cheeses, including brands like Boursin and Chaumes. Kraft, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, said it was selling Anco as part of its effort to focus on making and marketing its own brands of food. It said Anco, which it bought in 1990, had more than $70 million in sales in 1996.

description: KAPLAN-Harry, in his 100th year passed away on June 14, 1997 in North Broward Medical Center, Pompano Beach, Florida. He was the beloved husband of Belle (Jacoby) for 28 years and of the late Betty (Rosen) for 45 years. He is survived by his daughter Mimi (Aaron) Klein of Margate, FL.; his son David of Federal Way, WA.; grandson Ross Klein of Long Island, granddaughter Pamela (David) Levine and great-grandsons Daniel and Michael Levine. He is also survived by his sister Deborah Meyer and niece Susan of Los Angeles, sister-in-law Doris Rosen (Charles) Margett, step-daughter Irene (Leonard) Klaver and stepgrandchildren Ellen Klaver, James and Sharon Klaver and son Max Brown, Dr. Marjorie (John) Warden and daughter Emma Maxinne. He practiced accounting from 1924 to 1987, receiving his CPA certificate in 1928. He also graduated from New York Law School in 1929 and was admitted to the New York Bar in 1930. The family will see visitors and friends at the ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, on Wednesday, June 18 from 7:30 to 9:30 PM. Private graveside services will be held on Thursday, June 19 at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, New York.

description: With Congress still dawdling over legislation to clean up campaign financing, leadership on changing Washington's corrupt money game is emerging from a surprising direction. title: In Chicago, North and South Conduct a More Civil War
description: Madison Street in Chicago is known to local baseball fans as the DMZ, a dividing line not just for the city's street-numbering system but for Cub fans and White Sox fans, with loyalties split between Wrigley Field on the North Side and Comiskey Park on the South Side. It is the closest thing to trench warfare the city has known. And emotions remain heated whether the teams are winning -- which they have done infrequently over the last half century -- or are in last place (as the Cubs are) and fourth place (as the Sox are).

title: INFORMIX TO WHITTLE GLOBAL WORK FORCE BY 10 PERCENT
description: The chairman of the Informix Corporation, Phillip E. White, said yesterday that Informix, the data base software company, planned to cut 10 percent of its 4,600 worldwide work force, including 200 jobs in Europe, to help it return to profitability. The cuts, mostly to sales and technical support positions, would leave the company with about 1,000 employees in Europe. Analysts had been expecting job cuts since Informix reported a bigger-than-expected first-quarter loss in May of $140.1 million, or 93 cents a share, compared with net income of $15.9 million, or 10 cents, in the similar period a year earlier. Shares of Informix rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $9.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, DANIEL
description: JAMES-Daniel, retired senior partner of Cahill Gordon & Reindel in New York City, residing in Ivoryton, CT, died, Tuesday, June 10, 1997 at Yale New Haven Hospital. Mr. James was born in Logansport, IN. May 19, 1905, the son of William C. and Mary Faber James. He received an A.B. in 1927 and a J.D. in 1929 from Indiana University, Bloomington, IN. as a Research Fellow he received an LL.M. from Harvard Law School in 1931. He was a member of The Anglers' Club of NY, The Graduate Club (New Haven), The University Club of New York, Hammonassett Fishing Association; a former Trustee of The Spence School, the Legal Aid Society of New York, Peabody Museum Associates; past chairman of the Committee on Atomic Energy of the Bar Association of the City of New York and of Harvard Law School Scholarship Committee; Director of Indiana University Foundation; recipient of the Indiana University Distinguished Alumni Service Award; Alumni Fellow, and member of the Board of Visitors of Indiana University School of Law. He married Margaret Banks Greathouse in 1929. She died in 1988. In 1989 he married Margaret Fisher Marshall, who survives him. He was predeceased by his brother, William C. James of Carmel, CA. He is survived by his three daughters: Mary Katherine Staehelin of Brugg, Switzerland, Margaret Rapp of Doylestown, PA, Lila Banks Staples of Pacific Grove, CA; eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. He is also survived by three stepchildren: John Knox Marshall of Addison, ME, James Curtiss Marshall of Durham, ME, and Anne Marshall Henry of Lawrenceville, NJ; and five step-grandchildren. A Memorial Servivce will be 3:30PM on Saturday, June 21, at St. John's Episcopal Church, Main St. Essex, CT. In iieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Indiana University Foundation. PO Box 500, Bloomington, IN 47402.

title: Right Back at You: Yanks and Mets Are Even
description: The scenes and sounds that filled Yankee Stadium for most of last night were the sort that the Yankees are familiar with. They were Yankee scenes and Yankee sounds that drowned the Mets and drowned out their fans. The scenes are why the Yankees prevailed, 6-3, and the sounds are what they heard for their exploits.

title: Melting Pot Of Music, Traditions And Youth
description: With the advent of world music programs that demonstrate the extraordinary variety with which far-flung cultures have expressed themselves, the long-cherished notion that music is a universal language has been taking a beating. But wherever trends exist, there are also people willing to buck them, and the belief in music as a common bond has taken its most concrete form in the growing number of multinational youth orchestras.

title: Police Scour Westchester For '96 Murder Suspect
description: Dozens of police officers from New York City and Westchester County scoured a hospital in Bronxville and combed the surrounding streets by foot, car and helicopter last night in search of a fugitive charged with murdering two men at a topless nightclub on the Upper East Side a year ago.

title: Senate Panel Rebuffs Clinton on Child Health Plan
description: Conservative Republicans scored a big victory tonight as the Senate Finance Committee rejected a bipartisan proposal to expand Medicaid to cover millions of uninsured children.

title: Old Plots and New Profits: Watergate at 25
description: On the 25th anniversary of Watergate, G. Gordon Liddy, a felonious conspirator in that historic scandal, took a commercial break on his radio talk show today and was immediately enveloped in audience applause and cheers, demonstrating once more that there is little dishonor without profit in this city.

title: Airline to Pay $1.4 Billion For 67 Jets
description: American Eagle, the regional carrier affiliated with American Airlines, said today that it would buy 42 regional jets from Embraer of Brazil and 25 more from Bombardier Inc. of Canada in contracts valued at $1.4 billion.

description: BESIDES Jean-Georges Vongerichten, other Manhattan chefs are discovering the power of wild greens, and in California, foraging is a veritable profession.

title: Panel Urges Deep Cuts in U.S. and Russian Nuclear Arsenals
description: The United States and Russia should reduce their nuclear arsenals to a few hundred weapons to lower the risk of war and keep other nations from producing huge stockpiles, the National Academy of Sciences said today.

title: Cautious Yankees Put Williams on Disabled List
description: A grimacing Bernie Williams struggled to get his injured left leg into his blue jeans last night, and then he had to sit in a chair to gently fit his left foot in a black boot. The picture of pain made it obvious why the Yankees had put their durable center fielder on the 15-day disabled list because of a strained hamstring.

title: The Overlooked Story
description: Of course the President had to mention the 1968 Kerner Commission report in his commencement address at the University of California at San Diego last Saturday. Its central finding -- two societies, one black, one white, increasingly separate and unequal -- has become a civil rights mantra. Now, Mr. Clinton said, America faces the possibility of becoming not two nations but several: black, white, Asian and Hispanic.

title: HECHINGER IN DISCUSSIONS OVER SALE OF COMPANY
description: The Hechinger Company said yesterday that it was in talks to be bought for $3 a share, or more than $127 million. Hechinger, the struggling chain of home improvement stores, did not name the prospective buyer and said there was no assurance that any deal would result. The company's shares rose from their record low of $1 on May 30 to $2.25 yesterday, before trading was halted in anticipation of the announcement. The shares reached a high of $27.25 in 1987 and were trading as high as $16 three years ago before beginning a steady decline. Hechinger, of Largo, Md., has 117 stores.

title: EMI Plans Return Of Capital to Holders
description: The EMI Group, the British music publisher and retailer, said yesterday that it planned to return up to $:499.1 million ($815.7 million) of capital to shareholders. This is equal to 114.5 pence for each existing ordinary share. EMI shares gained ground on the news, rising 19 pence, to 1,126 pence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, FRIEDA G.
description: GOLDBERG-Frieda G. Lifelong Tarrytown, New York resident. Passed away June 17, 1997, at her home in Tarrytown. Survived by daughters, Myra Gordon & Susan Alpert and her son-in-law, Stanley Alpert, her grandchildren, Harold and Carrie Gordon, Alissa and Robert Lipkin and Leslie Gordon. She is also survived by her great grandchildren, Arielle Gordon and Elana Lipkin, & Margaret Sellers, a dear family friend. Funeral services to be held on Wednesday morning, June 18th, at 10:00 A.M., Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, New York. Family requests any donations be made to any organization researching Alzheimer's disease.

title: Poll Says Half Like Governor
description: About half the state's registered voters are pleased with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's performance, according to a new poll released by The Star-Ledger of Newark and the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: A Rivalry Beyond The City
description: DAVID CONE pitches this afternoon against Rick Reed, another of the million Yankees-Mets stories in the naked city and a subtle reminder that while inter league baseball may be a hit, the advancement of Major League Baseball as one harmonious enterprise may be as long a stretch as Randy Johnson's.

title: Gonzalo Fonseca, 74; Carved Enigmas in Stone
description: Gonzalo Fonseca, a Uruguayan-born artist best known for his stone carvings of enigmatic architectural forms, died on June 11 at his studio in Seravezza, Italy, near the city of Lucca. He was 74.

title: Arriving in Newark, Changes
description: The 32,500 bus and rail passengers who use Pennsylvania Station in Newark every day will be getting some new amenities, New Jersey Transit officials said yesterday. The agency said it was seeking bids for a new concourse to improve access to trains, and other enhancements like new lighting and drainage.

title: Neo-Nazi Leader Gets Jail Term in South Africa
description: The leader of South Africa's neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement was sentenced today to six years in prison for the 1996 beating of one of his black workers who was caught eating on the job.

title: No Headline
description: ''We were really expecting an increase in homelessness, but there hasn't been the influx we were waiting for-at least not yet. I think it's kind of a sink-or-swim thing here, and people are paddling away. What we don't know is how long they'll stay afloat.''

title: Tampax Account To Leo Burnett
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would move the worldwide Tampax tampons account to a longtime roster agency, the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, from the Foote, Cone & Belding unit of True North Communications in New York, when it completed the acquisition of the Tampax parent, Tambrands. Billings were estimated at $65 million.

Father and step-mother Gerald and Catherine Davidson. Mother and stepfather Dorothy and Rennie Pennock. His fiance Anne O'Driscoll. description: The Mets have won with saturation preparation. Information overload. Hitters and pitchers are given videotape, photographs, scouting reports and verbal histories, to augment their instincts.

description: ''If you're a writer,'' the scraggly-bearded scholar said, glowering at a reporter trying to enter his yeshiva, ''look elsewhere for a story.''

title: A.T.M. Camera Leads the Police Astray
description: The Police Department said yesterday that it had erred on Monday when it said that the search for a missing Queens man was focusing on a woman who was photographed withdrawing $400 from the man's bank account the day after he reportedly disappeared. The police released a picture of the woman, who was not identified, to news organizations.

description: When he was 5, Earl Moffat climbed onto the stool next to his father and carefully helped pour vanilla extract into little brown bottles lined up on the counter.

title: 'Steel Pier' Is Closing
description: ''Steel Pier,'' a musical with book by David Thompson and music and lyrics by John Kander and Fred Ebb, is to close after the evening performance on Saturday, June 28, at the Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, Manhattan. The show, directed by Scott Ellis and starring Karen Ziemba, Daniel McDonald and Gregory Harrison, will have run for 76 regular performance and 33 previews.

title: State's Stiffer Standards for Graduation Are Embraced by Many in Class of 2000
description: When the State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, proposed an ambitious new rule last year that would require all high school students to pass a battery of college-preparatory Regents tests, few imagined that Victoria Strong, a teen-ager from East New York in Brooklyn, and her fellow ninth graders at Fashion Industries High School would embrace the stiffer standards with a zeal rivaling the Commissioner's.

title: Host Marriott Services will test tabletop computers at eight restaurants it operates.
description: MOST MARRIOTT SERVICES, which operates 1,800 restaurants in 73 airports in the United States and overseas, is giving new meaning to the term ''power lunch.''

title: As Holyfield Trains for a Rematch With Tyson, His Camp Inspires Ordinary People
description: A computer analyst held hands in a prayer circle with two boxing trainers. The champion, of course, was the circle's anchor. It was still dark outside the Main Boxing Gym, but the thick, soggy air haloed everyone with sweat in the pre-dawn blackness.

He paid $8,000 for a day with Mr. Woods at one of the clinics his organization operates in different cities around the country to teach golf to children who would not normally have access to learning the game.

title: Pointing to 4 Power Plants
description: An advocacy group called on Governor Whitman yesterday to crack down on four coal-burning power plants. The ''dirty four'' -- in Jersey City, Deepwater, Upper Township and Hamilton Township in Mercer County -- account for more than 90 percent of the nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and mercury emissions from coal or oil burning plants in the state, but generate just 26 percent of the total electrical output of such plants, Gerald Flanagan, an organizer for New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, said.

title: A Convicted Killer Is Found After 16 Years, to Rejoicing
description: It was more than two years after her disappearance that the police detective found Holly Maddux's mummified body stuffed in a trunk in her boyfriend's closet. It has taken more than 16 years to find her boyfriend, a former peace activist convicted of her murder.

title: CCL INDUSTRIES AGREES TO ADD SEDA SPECIALTY PACKAGING
description: CCL Industries of Willowdale, Ontario, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Seda Specialty Packaging Corporation for $255 million (Canadian), or $184 million (United States), in cash, combining two makers of packaging for cosmetics and household products. The offer of $29 (United States) a share by CCL represents a 32 percent premium over Monday's closing price of $22 for Seda. Seda's stock rose $6.50 yesterday, to $28.50. Seda, based in Los Angeles, is expected to have about $100 million (Canadian) in sales this year. CCL has annual revenue of more than $1 billion (Canadian).

title: One Floor Up, the Caviar Awaits
description: CAVIAR RUSSE, a second-floor caviar bar, retail shop and restaurant at 538 Madison Avenue (54th Street), opens tomorrow, giving the service of caviar a suitably precious setting, with velvet banquettes, crystal chandeliers and rich trim. The simple but luxurious menu offers caviars, some by the tiny spoonful, along with other appetizers, main dishes and desserts.

title: Overuse of Antibiotics
description: ''Do as I say, not as I do,'' sums up parents' and pediatricians' attitude toward antibiotics, a Boston University School of Medicine survey shows. They know that overusing antibiotics can be dangerous, but they overuse them anyway when children are sick, the survey found.

title: Class Notes
description: With memoirs dominating best-seller lists, it was perhaps inevitable that college English departments, keen to attract students, would begin offering courses on how to write them.

description: Japan's trade surplus more than tripled in May, the Finance Ministry said today in a report that fed concerns that trade tensions with its major partners could escalate.

title: In Sink-or-Swim Welfare, Pensacola Staying Afloat
description: As welfare programs across the country enter a new era of time limits, this sunbaked city of sailors and tourists has become the first place where limits have already expired and poor families are being dropped from the rolls.

title: Corrections

title: The Witness Isn't Dead
description: When Forrest Sawyer and his producers at ''Turning Point'' on ABC set out to examine why the family of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. believed that James Earl Ray should be given a trial to reassess his role in King's murder, they had to examine the conspiracy theories of William F. Pepper, one of Mr. Ray's lawyers. They did -- and found a witness thought to be dead who confounds Mr. Pepper's theories.

title: Tests on Beagles Are Delayed
description: Bowing to pressure from animal-rights advocates, a pharmaceutical company said Monday that it would put off tests in which the legs of 36 beagles would have been broken. But members of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals said yesterday that they want the company, Yamanouchi Pharmaceuticals, to cancel the tests altogether. Huntingdon Life Sciences in Franklin Township is conducting the experiments for Yamanouchi to test a drug intended to prevent bone brittleness.

title: Morningstar Publisher to Join John Nuveen
description: The John Nuveen Company said today that John Rekenthaler, publisher of Morningstar Inc., would become its vice president and manager of its investment strategies group in mid-July.

title: Forces of Rival Cambodian Chiefs Fight in Capital
description: A burst of heavy fighting erupted in the streets of the capital on Tuesday night between bodyguard units loyal to the country's two feuding Prime Ministers, revealing a further deterioration in Cambodia's stability.

title: The Talent-Stocked Devils Are Thinking Long Term
description: With plenty of young players developing in their minor league system and juniors program, the Devils are not looking for someone to step in immediately at Saturday's draft, especially since their first selection is only 24th over all.

title: Nabobs Lite
description: On the 25th anniversary of the Watergate break-in, let's imagine how today's very different media might cover the scandal.

title: Comfort in Steak and Potatoes
description: Sometimes all you want is comfort food. No fancy vinegars or salsas; no exotic cheeses or herbs. To me, steak and potatoes are comfort food.

title: Rising Cost of College Imperils Nation, Report Says
description: The nation's colleges and universities need to cut costs dramatically or face a shortfall of funds that will increasingly shut out the poor from higher education and from economic opportunity as well, according to a blunt and far-ranging assessment of American higher education that was made public yesterday.

title: U.S. Seizes the Lone Suspect In Killing of 2 C.I.A. Officers
description: United States officials working with Afghan tribal leaders and Pakistani intelligence officers have seized the lone suspect in the killing of two C.I.A. officers outside the agency's headquarters in Virginia, Government officials said today.

title: His Passions: Fast Trains and Burgundy
description: COMING down to Burgundy from Paris on the sleek, high-speed train, it occurred to me that the 90-minute trip would not have been possible were it not for Faiveley Industries, the Paris-based company that makes doors, brakes and other vital rail parts, not just for the T.G.V., but for trains all over the world.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 2 about the New-York Historical Society misstated its record of support from New York State. Apart from emergency appropriations during its recent crisis, the society has indeed received state funds, in the form of frequent grants from the State Council on the Arts.

description: HERTZ-Lore. On June 15, 1997. Lore Hertz, wife of the late Herbert Hertz. Mother of Peter K. Hertz of Maryland. Mother-in-law of Vicki Hertz. title: For Hong Kong, a Lot of High-Priced Land Hangs in the Balance
description: HONG KONG  The incoming government of Tung Chee-hwa, which will take control of Hong Kong at the end of this month, has spent the last six months battling critics of its controversial new Bill of Rights and electoral law. But now it faces its first tough economic decision: what to do about the territory's runaway real-estate market.

title: Rep. Armey to Offer Bill Aimed At Cutting Auto Insurance Costs
description: Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, says he will introduce legislation today aimed at sharply reducing the cost of auto insurance by giving motorists the option to drop coverage for pain and suffering that results from accidents.

title: New Swede in Sampras's Path
description: Perish the thought that top-seeded Pete Sampras, three times a Wimbledon champion, has developed a phobia about playing Swedish underdogs, because next week he will play Mikael Tillstrom, the Swedish spoiler who ended Stefan Edberg's stellar Wimbledon career last year in the second round.

title: Family Recipes, Lovingly Recreated
description: The simple white stucco exterior of Bellissimo Restaurant and Tavern, a converted diner in Waterbury, Conn., offers no hint of what's inside. But as soon as the waiter brings out bulbs of roasted garlic and baskets of fresh rosemary-and-onion focaccia, it becomes clear that this is no ordinary roadside restaurant.

title: Runner, Heal Thyself
description: On a sun-splashed morning recently at the wooded Valley Green recreation trail, Kim Gallagher, the only woman to win two Olympic medals in the 800 meters, tossed aside her walking cane and steadied herself to run. Gallagher's 7-year-old daughter, Jessica, clutched a stuffed animal and waited impatiently for her mother to stride down the path.
