description: To the Editor:

title: Selling Condos to Nations: a Matter of Diplomacy
description: When Mitchell B. Rutter bought 2 Dag Hammarskjold Plaza a year ago, he entered a strange new world where sovereign immunity, geopolitical alliances and hints of corruption counted for as much as the usual factors that make a real estate investment succeed or fail.

title: MONTEREY RESOURCES TO ACQUIRE MCFARLAND ENERGY
description: Monterey Resources Inc. said yesterday that it would buy McFarland Energy Inc., another California oil and gas company, for about $106 million in cash. Monterey, based in Bakersfield, will begin a tender offer to buy all of McFarland's shares outstanding for $18.55 each. McFarland, based in Santa Fe Springs, produces about 3,700 barrels of oil and five million cubic feet of gas a day. Its proven reserves are equivalent to about 20 million barrels of oil. Monterey produces about 50,000 barrels of oil a day and has proven reserves of about 218 million barrels. Shares of McFarland rose $1.75 yesterday, to $18.375; Monterey fell $12.5 cents, to $15.125.

title: CHEVRON ENTERS JOINT VENTURE FOR THAI PLANT
description: The Chevron Chemical Company said yesterday that it had entered into a joint-venture agreement with the Petroleum Authority of Thailand to proceed with engineering for an aromatics plant in Map Ta Phut, Thailand. Chevron said it expected to invest about $1 billion in the plant, which would begin production in 2000. The Thai Cabinet approved 40 percent participation in the project by the Petroleum Authority. Chevron said the plant would produce 675,000 tons of paraxylene, a petrochemical feedstock, and 600,000 tons of benzene annually. The Petroleum Authority said the project would provide more than 200 long-term jobs and several thousand jobs during construction.

title: When the Reaper Is About as Grim as Santa
description: At one point during the not-very-black comedy ''For Roseanna,'' two characters use hair dryers and space heaters to thaw a frozen corpse. The film tries no less desperately to warm hearts. Nominally about the approaching death of a healthy-looking coronary patient named Roseanna (Mercedes Ruehl), this gallows farce actually cares more about the cute scheming of her husband. Marcello (Jean Reno) is the gravedigger in a small Italian village. To guarantee his beloved a space in the crowded local cemetery, he must work overtime to keep all the other townspeople alive.

She was 88 and lived in Marion, Mass.

description: A suspect implicated by Canadian officials in the bombing that killed 19 Americans in Saudi Arabia last year was deported to the United States today after agreeing to cooperate with the Justice Department's investigation of the attack.

title: Europe Focuses on Future and the Impact of New Members
description: Having set aside their differences about how to achieve a common currency, the leaders of the European Union tangled today over another problem they will have to solve in the next few years: how to continue sharing power once they open up their club to new members from Central Europe.

title: Panel Cites Banned Lenses in Jet Accident
description: The Delta Air Lines captain who flew his plane too low approaching La Guardia Airport and ripped the landing gear off when it hit the pier supporting the runway on Oct. 19 was wearing contact lenses that are forbidden by the Federal Aviation Administration because they reduce depth perception, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

Pataki went into the fight over New York rent regulations with the hope of emerging as a statesman and conciliator, defending the free market while bringing warring Democrats and Republicans together. Instead, his performance in the dispute was marked by a cascade of political miscues, producing a legislative result that bore little resemblance to what he proposed as a compromise.

title: An Exhibition Shows How Blacks Set Free by the Civil War Asserted Their Rights and Helped Set New National Aims
description: In September 1865, during the Reconstruction period, John Dennett, a correspondent for The Nation, encountered a black man, newly freed from slavery in the town of Concord, N.C. Exhausted, his body hurting, the man said he had walked 600 miles from a plantation in Georgia searching for his wife and children, who had been taken from him when they were sold. Of all the social forces unleashed by Reconstruction, nothing was more powerful than the former slaves' desperate efforts to find their lost families, and their rush to marry the partners they had been forbidden to marry under slavery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWANER, HENRY W.
description: SCHWANER-Henry W. of White Plains, NY. He is survived by two first cousins, Walter Schwaner and Freida Willms and five nieces and one nephew. His wife Mary S. Schwaner died in 1983. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALL, JAMES H. M.D.
description: WALL-James H. M.D., 94. Medical Director, NY HospitalCornell Medical Center, Westchester Division. James Hardin Wall, M.D., former Medical Director of the NY Hospital, Westchester Division in White Plains, NY, Professor of Clinical Psychiatry, Emeritus at Cornell Medical College, Founder and Chairman of the Westchester Community Mental Health Board and Consultant to the Silver Hill Foundation in New Cannan, CT, died in his sleep on June 13 in Freeport, ME. Born in Lancaster, South Carolina and raised in Chester, SC, he was the seventh child in a family of ten and the first member of his family to attend college. Dr. Wall was graduated from the University of North Carolina and Chapel Hill in 1925; Thomas Jefferson Medical College in 1927, where he finished second in his class; and interned in the U.S. Navy in Philadelphia in 1927-28, before joining the staff of the NY Hospital, Westchester Division (then Bloomingdale Hospital), in 1928. In 1936 he became Assistant Medical Director; in 1946, he became Medical Director, a post that he held until his retirement in 1965. Dr. Wall's wife, the former Louise Holt Baker, died suddenly in 1990. His daughter, Georgia Hardin Wall, was killed in an automobile accident in 1965. He is survived by a son, Edward Wall, Brunswick, ME; two elder sisters, Mary W. Peterson, 98 of Charlotte, NC, and Ethel W. Stanford, 95 of Atlanta, GA; seven grandchildren and three great grandsons. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM Saturday, June 21 at the White Plains (NY) Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you make a donation to the White Plains Presbyterian Church or to the charity of your choice.

title: INTEL REQUESTS SUMMARY JUDGMENT IN SUIT AGAINST DIGITAL

The request is the latest in the legal wrangling that started on May 13, when Digital sued Intel, saying it had violated 10 patents owned by Digital in the development of the Intel Pentium chips. Intel then asked Digital to return all information and prototypes about future chips that Intel had given Digital, which Digital has refused to do.

title: Marching Season in Northern Ireland

Every summer, Protestant groups hold marches commemorating a 1690 Protestant victory over Catholics. The marches, which peak in early July, are often routed through Catholic neighborhoods, setting off a spiral of injury, looting, property damage and sometimes deaths. The I.R.A. murders this week took place very near the site of last summer's worst riots, and seem designed to provoke retaliatory violence from the largely Protestant groups loyal to London. All sides must scramble to prevent violence this year.

Reynoso, the Mets' starting pitcher, feared the worst: perhaps a broken kneecap or some other kind of serious damage.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OMNICARE INC., Cincinnati, a provider of pharmacy services to long-term- care institutions, agreed to acquire EBA Pharmacy Inc., Chicago, and Sun Health Inc., Hartford, both privately owned institutional pharmacy providers. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times yesterday about the Arecibo Observatory radiotelescope misstated the situation in which one of its reflectors acts like a microwave oven. That occurs when the telescope is sending radar signals to distant objects, not when it is receiving radio waves from them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITZ, JACOB
description: LEVITZ-Jacob. Educator and Writer. Died on June 17, 1997, nine days short of his 85th birthday, after a long illness. Son of Rabbi Meir Perets and Bella Genendl, was born in Kolno, Poland in 1912. He received a traditional Jewish education in his hometown and in various Yeshivot. He came to the United States in 1929 and graduated from the Jewish Teachers Seminary, New York City. He received a B.A. in 1944 and an M.A. in 1947 from Wayne University, Detroit, Michigan. (Thesis: ''The Acculturation of the East European Jews in Mexico 1920-1946''); Ph.D from Dropsie College, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in 1954 (Dissertation: ''The Jewish Community in Mexico 1900-1954''). He worked over half a century in the field of Jewish education as a Teacher, Principal, Consultant and as Professor of Yiddish Language and Literature in The Jewish Teachers Seminary-Herzliah and its graduate school, The New School and Touro College, New York City. Contributed poetry and essays to various Yiddish, Hebrew and Anglo-Jewish publications: ''Zukunft'', ''Literarishe Bleter'' (Warsaw), ''Getseltn'', ''YIVOBleter'', ''Yidishe Shprakh'', ''Niv'', ''Hadoar'', ''Shviley Hakhinukh'', ''Jewish Education'', ''American Jewish Yearbook'' and others. His poems were put to music and included in the Anthologies: ''Gezang Un Kamf'' (New York), ''Yiddish Poets In Song'' (New York), ''Cradle Songs In Yiddish'' (TelAviv), ''Yiddish Cradle Songs In Hebrew'' (Tel-Aviv). He translated into English Sholem Ansky's ''The Dybbuk'', produced for television by Sidney Lumet. He is included in ''Leksikon Fun Der Nayer Yidisher Literatur'' (''Biographic Dictionary of Modern Yiddish Literature'', Congress for Jewish Culture, New York); ''Who Is Who In World Jewry'' (Tel-Aviv, 1978), ''Who Is Who In American Jewry'' (Los Angeles, 1980), and others. Survived by loving partner of seventeen years, Erica Erdberg; beloved daughter and son-in-law Beverly and Stephen Vosko; cherished granddaughters: Jennifer and Michelle; dear sister Norma Friedman; devoted nephews, Dr. Philip (Ellen) Friedman and Jack (Sandy) Friedman and their families; caring-in-laws Claudia and Jim Warberg; adored nieces Emily and Anya Warberg and many special friends, colleagues and generations of students. A man of rare intellect and wisdom, his distinguished life enriched us all. Services are on Thursday, June 19, 1997, at 9:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment is at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: New Member Joins Nasdaq Committee
description: The Nasdaq stock market said today that it had named Joseph Ciechanover, who is chairman of El Al Israel Airlines and president of the Challenge Fund-Etgar L.P., to its International Markets Advisory Board.

title: CHRONICLE
description: While rushing to Georgetown University Medical Center early Tuesday morning with his wife, ELLEN HART PENA, Energy Secretary FEDERICO PENA had no time to argue with her. She was about to give birth.

title: Muster and Capriati to Skip Wimbledon With Injuries
description: The former French Open champion Thomas Muster, ranked fourth in the world but demoted to sixth in the Wimbledon seedings because of his 0-4 track record there, has withdrawn from Wimbledon at the last minute for the second year in a row. Unseeded Jennifer Capriati also informed officials yesterday of an injury-related withdrawal.

title: ALLIED SIGNAL AGREES TO BUY AIRCRAFT LIGHTING SUPPLIER
description: Allied Signal Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Grimes Aerospace, a supplier of aircraft lighting systems, from an affiliate of Forstmann Little & Company. Terms were not disclosed. Grimes, which has annual sales of $230 million, makes exterior and interior lighting systems. It has 1,400 employees worldwide. Allied Signal, based in Morris Township, N.J., is a technology and manufacturing company. Forstmann Little is an investment firm based in New York.

title: Nets Push Williams In Trade Discussions
description: Nets Coach John Calipari could sever his dysfunctional relationship with Jayson Williams if he decides to pursue any one of several trade scenarios, including a deal that would send his power forward and another player to the Boston Celtics for forward Dino Radja.

title: Airlines Are Cracking Down on Delayed Departures
description: Three Milwaukee-bound passengers on a stopover in Phoenix got an unpleasant surprise recently after slaking their thirst in the terminal cocktail lounge. Returning to the gate, they could only watch forlornly through the window as their plane taxied to the runway, having unceremoniously dumped their luggage in a baggage cart on the tarmac.

title: Childless and Fulfilled
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Not 'Elitist Guilt'
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Is Shot Dead in Queens After Honking Horn at a Van
description: A man was shot and killed in Queens yesterday after he honked his horn at a van in front of him, the police said. Witnesses said that a passenger in the van, apparently angered by the honking, calmly stepped out of the van and fired several shots at the other driver.

title: The Endangered Bookshop
description: The demise at month's end of the Doubleday Book Shop on Fifth Avenue and 56th Street will leave more than a physical void. For upward of a century, midtown Fifth Avenue was the premier showcase of Publishers' Row. Generations of authors strove to appear nonchalant as they looked for their new progeny in the gleaming windows at Scribner's and Brentano's. No more. Soaring rents years ago doomed both bookstores, and B. Dalton as well. The corridor's sole survivor will soon be the giant Barnes & Noble outlet at 48th Street.

title: Lane Timmons, 81, Former Envoy to Haiti
description: Benson Ellison Lane Timmons 3d, who was United States Ambassador to Haiti as the Duvalier regime tightened its reign of terror in the 1960's, died on June 11 at Southampton Hospital on Long Island. He was 81 and had been living in Southampton in retirement.

title: WEYERHAEUSER TO CLOSE PLANT IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that it planned to close a plywood plant in Plymouth, N.C., resulting in the loss of 200 jobs, and take a second-quarter charge to pay for the move. Weyerhaeuser, based in Tacoma, Wash., did not specify the amount of the charge but said it would be offset by a gain from the sale of the company's mortgage company unit. Weyerhaeuser is closing the plant because it would cost too much to upgrade it, said Bruce Amundson, a company spokesman. Weyerhaeuser makes wood and packaging products. Its shares rose $1.25 yesterday, to $53.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEILLER, HELEN
description: KEILLER-Helen, on June 16, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late George and Mary Keiller. Survived by her nephews, Gary Keiller and Edgar Edman. Funeral services at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Madison Avenue at 71 Street, Friday 11:30 AM.

title: Ill Will Prevails as House Finance Inquiry Adopts Set of Rules
description: The House committee investigating the way campaigns were financed in last year's election engaged today in the same partisan bickering that has characterized investigations on both sides of the Capitol all year.

title: No Budget Drama Expected
description: Little drama is expected today as State Senate and Assembly committees consider a new budget, thanks to unanticipated tax revenue and $590 million foreseen from the sale of pension bonds.

title: KPMG Partner a Contender For Top Accounting Post
description: Robert K. Elliott, a partner at KPMG Peat Marwick known for outspoken views on the future of the accounting profession, has emerged as the leading contender to become chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, according to people familiar with the search. But another candidate, whose name could not be learned, has emerged in recent days and could be the choice, those people said.

title: Keeping the Beauty and the Audience Wide Awake
description: Julio Bocca and Nina Ananiashvili have only to step onto the stage, it seems, for audiences to explode with tumultuous applause. That was the case when American Ballet Theater presented the first ''Sleeping Beauty'' of its season on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. But even Mr. Bocca and Ms. Ananiashvili looked understated at times in a performance that was dedicated to Rudolf Nureyev but had too little of his larger-than-life engagement.

title: Opposition to Abortion Ban
description: The Medical Society of New Jersey announced its opposition yesterday to a bill that would ban a procedure that abortion opponents describe as partial-birth abortion.

title: Baptist Leaders Urge A Boycott of Disney
description: The Southern Baptist Convention has called upon its 15.7 million members to boycott the Walt Disney Company, saying that Disney has moved away from wholesome entertainment and toward themes of sex, violence and homosexuality.

title: Two Festivals Compete For What's Hot in Jazz
description: On the eve of what looks like the finest schedule of improvised music New York has ever had -- the combined offerings of the JVC Jazz Festival and the Knitting Factory's Texaco New York Jazz Festival -- the heads of the two organizations are effectively at war. George Wein, the producer of JVC and the patriarch of festivals around the world, is in the unaccustomed position of having to compete for talent with the upstart owner of the Knitting Factory, Michael Dorf. In private, they are maneuvering like opposing armies. In public, the two are trading fighting words.

title: British Aerospace Joins Lockheed in Plane Project
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that it had joined the Lockheed Martin Corporation in its competition with the Boeing Company to build the United States military's next-generation fighter aircraft.

title: Hong Kong's Queen
description: To the Editor:

description: A day after the state's highest court upheld Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to banish sidewalk food vendors from parts of midtown Manhattan, confusion reigned on busy streets as police officers struggled to determine which streets were off-limits to them and vendors sought to re-establish themselves in places that had long been closed to them.

title: Reading the Tea Leaves for a Fresh Season of Life
description: Pang Hon Ming's black-slippered feet whispered across the floor as he moved toward the round table, a white plate piled with fried noodles floating on the edge of his fingers. Carefully, with chopsticks and a ladle, he filled five small bowls with noodles before setting them in front of each of the diners, regular customers.

description: After six days of deliberations, a Federal jury acquitted the owner of a defunct valet-parking business Tuesday of charges that he cheated investors of more than $1 million.

description: The Mets wore strange blank stares in the minutes after Tino Martinez beat them with a 10th-inning single yesterday, like two dozen grooms at one huge Bronx wedding. They all knew they had participated in some great event in their lives, something they will remember forever, but they were not quite sure what to make of it.

description: Speaker Newt Gingrich, in a speech to the Orphan Foundation of America, outlined 10 steps tonight to improve race relations in the United States. They are excerpted from his prepared text.

description: It sounds like a scene for pulp fiction: A week after a jury in Denver hands down a death sentence for the deadliest act of political terrorism on American soil, the same city is host to the leaders of eight of the world's most powerful nations.

description: KIPPERMAN-Anne (Sherman) Friedland, 91, in Columbus, OH on May 19, 1997. Mother of Nina Helene, Stewart Bronfeld, Jack Bronfeld, the late Ronald Friedland. For information call (614) 459-3636.

description: CAROLEE-Ernest. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ernest Carolee, associated with The Times from October 15, 1977, until retiring on January 4, 1997.

title: Parties in Tobacco Talks Say Accord May Be Near
description: State attorneys general said yesterday that they were narrowing their differences with cigarette producers in the tobacco talks, and some predicted that a settlement proposal could emerge as early as today. But others expressed caution, saying important issues remain unresolved.

title: Shareholders Discuss Challenges Facing Digital
description: Shareholders of the Digital Equipment Corporation had a rump session in Manhattan yesterday to examine the prospects of the troubled computer maker, but it was unclear what action, if any, the group would take.

title: Sounds of Summer: W.N.B.A. to Take Center Court
description: The behemoth is racing Gary Cavalli's way, dribbling a two-toned basketball. The co-founder and chief executive of the American Basketball League awaits Saturday afternoon's start of the Women's National Basketball Association, which insists that it has come to coexist with the A.B.L., not to bury it.

title: Gencor to Shed Base Metals, Buy Nickel
description: The big South African mining company Gencor Ltd. said today that it would spin off its base metals, minerals and coal businesses and acquire control of an Australian nickel refiner as it moves from gold mining into faster-growing industrial raw materials.

title: Writer Jailed for Assisting Wife's Suicide Reveals That He Suffocated Her
description: George Delury, the writer and editor who served four months in prison for helping his ailing wife commit suicide in their Upper West Side apartment in July 1995, has disclosed in a new book that he suffocated her with plastic bags because he did not believe the drug she had taken would kill her fast enough.

title: Sale Reported for Hip Magazine
description: The young and the restless of the design magazine world can now settle down. Time Inc. is expected to announce shortly that it is buying Wallpaper, the London magazine of design, fashion, travel and entertaining aimed at globally hip urban dwellers (aged 25 to 40).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERBERG, HANNELORE
description: SILBERBERG-Hannelore on June 17, 1997. Beloved wife of Wolfgang, loving mother of Steven and Deborah, cherished grandmother of David and sister of Guy, after a long illness which she bore with the great courage and selflessness that characterized her whole life. Services Thursday, 12:30, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

description: ELLIS-Esta B. Formerly of Mt Vernon, NY, on June 16, 1997 at 94. She served on the National Board of Hadassah and for 16 years represented Hadassah at the United Nations. She was also active in her community. She is survived by her daughter Patricia Stone, grandchildren Susan and Robert and great-grandson Jeffrey. In accordance with her wishes she was cremated after a small family service and her ashes scattered at sea. Contributions in her name can be sent to Hadassah.

title: Technology Stocks Slide, Raising Fears
description: Technology stocks, the perennial bad boys of summer, were beaten down yesterday, raising some fresh concerns that another seasonal swoon could be on the way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, FRANCES
description: FINKELSTEIN-Frances. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations expresses sincerest condolences to our distinguished colleague, Alan Finkelstein, on the untimely loss of his beloved mother. We pray that he and his family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Melvin Salberg, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Leona Helmsley Puts an Empire Worth Billions On the Market
description: After a turbulent decade at the head of New York City's largest real estate empire, Leona Helmsley said yesterday that she intended to sell most or perhaps all of the properties, valued at close to $5 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANDI, ROBERT ANDREW (BOBBY)
description: LANDI-Robert Andrew (Bobby). Remembered with love. United with Creator forever through Christ Jesus. Jerome Landi

description: ROMINE-Christopher. Died at age 40, June 16, 1997. He will be missed forever by his wife, Silvia, family and many friends. Service will be at Church of St. Thomas, Friday June 20, 10:30 am, 5 Ave-53 St.

title: Clinging to the Old Standards In a World With New Rulers
description: ''My father had four wives,'' began Regina Wong. ''My mother is the No. 1 wife. My family had a big, big complex in Canton'' -- the southern Chinese city also known as Guangzhou. ''But my father moved to Hong Kong and then to Macao. He stayed in Macao and my mother stayed here. Now she owns a herb shop.''

description: IGNATOW-Archie. Happy Birthday, sweetheart. Wish you were here. Remembered with love. Gene, Children and Grandchildren

description: Just before 4 A.M. on Sunday, five F.B.I. agents sneaked into a hostel in Afghanistan, where Afghan informants had told them they would find Mir Amal Kansi, one of the world's most wanted men, the suspect in a deadly 1993 rampage outside C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va..

title: Hormone Use Helps Women, A Study Finds
description: Hormone replacement after menopause can significantly reduce a woman's risk of death as long as she continues it, a large study has found.

description: CUTLER-Arthur J. passed away on June 18, 1997-died suddenly in his sleep. Alice, Jody and Danielle mourn the loss of their father, husband and friend. Arthur J. Cutler, a man of extreme intellect, compassion and devotion to his family and friends, will be sorely missed by all those who he touched in his time. May his soul rest in peace. Alice, Jody and Danielle

title: CHRONICLE
description: STEPHEN BOGART, the son of Humphrey Bogart and Lauren Bacall, filed suit on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan against three entities in Ted Turner's broadcast empire, charging that they had falsely promoted and marketed a documentary on his father as having been based on a book he wrote.

title: BOSTON PROPERTIES STOCK RISES 7% AFTER INITIAL OFFERING
description: Shares of Boston Properties Inc. rose 7 percent yesterday in their first day of trading after a $785 million initial public offering of the office holdings of the publishing magnate Mortimer Zuckerman. Boston Properties stock rose $1.75, to $26.75, on the New York Stock Exchange; 7.92 million shares were traded. The stock traded as high as $26.875. Boston Properties sold 31.4 million shares at $25 each on Tuesday in one of the biggest initial offerings for a real estate investment trust. The company said it would earn $730 million from the offering. The proceeds will mostly go to repay debt. Boston Properties owns 63 office properties and nine warehouse buildings.

Robert G. Newman, M.D. President Ronald Holland Director of Security

title: Who Owns New York? Martinez and Yanks
description: The overlapping chants for the Yankees and the Mets were impossible to ignore when they reverberated throughout Yankee Stadium on a gray afternoon. Bouncing back and forth, the cheers made an epic baseball game seem like a rock concert where the audience insisted on providing backup vocals. Lots of backup vocals for lots of crisp baseball.

title: Study Says Pataki's Welfare Plan Will Increase Deep Poverty
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's proposal to overhaul the state's welfare system, combined with stricter Federal welfare rules, would double the number of families living far below the poverty line, according to a study by Columbia University's School of Social Work.

title: No Headline
description: ''People forget, but it was an original and daring musical. Putting poems by T. S. Eliot to music was odd. You have to give credit to the composer for creating 25 songs about different kinds of cats. Not many people would be up to that.''

title: S.E.C. Orders Offshore Fund To Halt U.S. Stock Resale
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, seeking to halt abuses of a rule that has allowed companies to sell stock overseas without registering the shares in this country, obtained a cease-and-desist order yesterday against an offshore mutual fund that had made a practice of buying such stock at a discount and then reselling it in the United States.

title: Blue-Ribbon Panel Urges Clinton to Act on F.E.C.
description: A high-profile committee appointed by President Clinton to promote campaign finance reform recommended today that the President ''take immediate action'' to fill four vacancies at the Federal Election Commission.

title: After the Bomb, the Boom: A City Mends Its Heart
description: Like the shoots that poke up from the blackened floor of a forest in the months after a fire, people are swarming into downtown Manchester one year after it was turned into a fury of sundered concrete, broken timbers and shattered glass by a huge Irish Republican Army bomb.

title: In the 'Megan' Case, a Statement of Loss vs. a Plea for Mercy
description: Megan had tea parties with her dolls and played in the mud with toy trucks. Her favorite flavor was mint chocolate chip. Her brother, who was 18 months older and thought of himself as her protector, has been found screaming in his closet in the middle of the night in the three years since she was raped and strangled by a man who lived across the street.

title: Hollywood's Tryst With Dorothy Dandridge Inspires Real Love at Last
description: When Dorothy Dandridge played a 1953 engagement at the glamorous Mocambo nightclub in Los Angeles, cigarette girls sold copies of Charles Alfred Kinsey's ''Sexual Behavior of the Human Female'' as a publicity stunt. That was one small measure of Dandridge's phenomenal sultriness, thanks to her rare mix of poised elegance and voluptuous beauty. Reviewing her great triumph on the movie screen, The Hollywood Reporter put it succinctly: ''Dorothy Dandridge in 'Carmen Jones' -- Wow!'' Describing another of her nightclub appearances, Time said aptly that she ''came wriggling out of the wings like a caterpillar on a hot rock.''

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING TO SELL AUTO PARTS NETWORK
description: Automatic Data Processing Inc. agreed yesterday to sell the assets of Auto Info to settle Federal charges that it illegally acquired the company to create a monopoly in the auto salvage industry, the Federal Trade Commission said. To resolve a lawsuit filed by the F.T.C. last November, Automatic Data agreed to shed the auto parts trading network that it acquired from Auto Info. Shares of Automatic Data, based in Roseland, N.J., fell $1.125 yesterday, to $48.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOVITZ, BENJAMIN
description: LEBOVITZ - Benjamin. Beloved husband of Sonia. Devoted father of Lucille and Linda. Loving grandfather of six. Services Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, Thursday 2:45pm. For info ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Peter Blos, a Psychoanalyst Of Children, Is Dead at 93
description: Peter Blos, one of the first child psychoanalysts and a leading authority on adolescence, died last Thursday in Holderness, N.H., where he had a country home. He was 93 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Gesture of Good Will: Taking the U.N. Out to the Ballgame
description: There are circles in New York where the focus of debate this week was not the Yankees-Mets subway series, and certainly the United Nations Security Council is among them. But that did not preclude 13 foreign delegates, members of the Council, from lending a multinational flavor to the capacity crowd at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Just after noon, they called a halt to discussions about Iraqi violations of nuclear inspection policy to attend the rubber match of the series.

title: Saudi Bombing Suspect Agrees to Plead Guilty in an Earlier Plot
description: A Saudi dissident who says he will cooperate in the investigation of the bombing that killed 19 Americans in Dhahran last year will plead guilty to an indictment unsealed today in an earlier plot to kill Americans. The first plot was never carried out.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Night on the Town (Bring the Stroller)
description: SOME snapshots of New York City night life, circa right now:

title: Subway Series A Ratings Hit
description: The Yankees-Mets series has juiced up local television ratings. Tuesday's game on Channel 11 posted an 11.9 Nielsen rating, the highest for the station since a 14.5 for a Yankees-Red Sox game in September 1988. On SportsChannel, the game produced a 2.1 rating, a shade below the 2.2 for one of the Mets-Red Sox interleague games, but well above the season average.

title: 'Honey, They Stole the Birdbath'
description: I HAVE to admit the thieves had good taste,'' said Jim Shaughnessy of St. Louis, whose ornate marble birdbath, carved with the faces of such unlikely bath-time companions as Plato, Aristotle and Socrates and worth $10,000, was one of 61 garden ornaments discovered by the police in a U-Haul trailer near Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Title IX Helps Female Scullers Thrive
description: For college athletic directors like Bob Marcum at the University of Massachusetts, the matter at first was simply one of numbers. If UMass elevated its women's rowing program from a club sport to varsity status, perhaps a couple of dozen female athletes could be added to improve the school's proportion of female-to-male athletes, one of the tests for compliance to Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972.

title: East German Spymaster Is No Yasir Arafat
description: To the Editor:

title: Central bankers and options traders weigh down gold's price.
description: THE world economy is set to grow at its fastest pace in almost a decade and currency markets are jittery over whether European fiscal discipline is about to be relaxed in the struggle to introduce the euro, the long awaited single currency. So gold, that age-old hedge against inflation and uncertainty, must be rising, right?

title: Laid-Off Workers Demand Back Pay
description: Thirty workers recently laid off by the Global Shopping Network, a cable shopping channel, were angry. Not only were they laid off on June 6 without notice, but they also have not been paid for their last two weeks of work. The company also failed to pay thousands of dollars into their 401(k) accounts.

title: Gains Posted By Treasuries As Fed Buys
description: Treasury prices gained yesterday, as the Federal Reserve Bank entered the market as an active buyer while a survey of business conditions showed pockets of weakness. Investors saw the survey as further reducing the chances that Fed policy makers will raise interest rates when they meet in two weeks.

title: PANCANADIAN PETROLEUM TO BUY CS RESOURCES
description: PanCanadian Petroleum Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire CS Resources Ltd., a Canadian heavy-oil producer, for $521 million (Canadian), or $376 million (United States). Last week, Gulf Canada Resources Ltd. said it would buy CS Resources for $413 million (Canadian), or $297.9 million (United States), in cash and stock, but CS Resources said it was in talks with an unidentified third company. Under the deal with PanCanadian, CS Resources shareholders will receive $16 (Canadian), or $11.50 (United States), for each of their shares. PanCanadian will also assume $56 million (Canadian), or $40.4 million (United States), in debt. PanCanadian said it planned to mail its offer to CS Resources shareholders tomorrow. The offer will expire 24 days later. The offer is contingent on two-thirds of CS Resources' shares being tendered. PanCanadian, CS Resources and Gulf Canada are based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Police Anger Unsettles City Already Edgy

''What's this about?'' Imelda Rivera Santos, a passer-by, asked an officer helping to put up parade barricades. ''Respect,'' he told her. ''It's about respect.''

title: Good Early Returns for Interleague Play
description: The weather was not World Series weather, the championship of baseball was not at issue and all the New York Yankees really got for winning two of three games from the New York Mets was a temporary purchase on interborough bragging rights. But for a moment it seemed as if the World Series had descended upon the Bronx in June. Yankee Stadium was packed to the rafters, the play was inspired, the fans were pumped up and those old enough to have attended games between the Giants and the Dodgers could say to their grandchildren, ''See, that's the way it used to be when New York teams played each other.''

title: Six Guilty in Granting Of Extra Prison Privileges
description: Three Federal prison guards have pleaded guilty to accepting bribes in exchange for granting special privileges to top mobsters at a Brooklyn jail, the Justice Department announced yesterday. Three civilians also pleaded guilty to bribery and smuggling charges in connection with the case, officials said.

title: A LaFosse Premiere Dares Its Viewers, and They Respond

title: Basking in Glow of Victory, Els Strives to Focus
description: Ernie Els was asleep at his Orlando, Fla., home when the phone call came from South Africa on Tuesday morning. So when he arose, he placed a return call to Nelson Mandela. This time, Mandela was asleep.

title: The Real G-7's
description: Tomorrow in Denver the Group of Seven major industrial democracies, along with Russia, will gather to discuss the global economy and any other issue they can rustle up to make their tired annual summit meeting seem relevant. The G-7 has to really scrounge for a role today because as a group it no longer represents the most important powers shaping the world economy. I mean, would you look to Canada for economic advice? Hockey yes, but not money. With that in mind, I offer my biennial listings of whom you'd invite to the G-7 if you weren't stuck with the U.S., Germany, Japan, Italy, France, Canada and Britain.

title: Robert C. McEwen, 77, Veteran Lawmaker

Barton Hepburn Hospital in his hometown of Ogdensburg. He was 77.

title: From Garry And Larry, Their Show Of Shows
description: If Johnny Carson hadn't retired, ''The Larry Sanders Show'' might not exist. While Johnny was there the rules of the game were set, and we had too much fun with him not to take his mystique seriously. Johnny was a world-class entertainer, impeccable, unflappable, inviolable and infinitely watchable. And like all world-class entertainers and deities, Johnny made each viewer feel that he (or she, but especially he) was attuned to some special pitch of Carson wit, some subtle reaction no one else was noticing.

title: Bridge
description: A bidding idea that has grown steadily in popularity in the last decade is the fit-showing jump. In certain competitive auctions, which need to be carefully defined, a player simultaneously shows length in the suit he is bidding and some fit in his partner's suit. The common situations arise when an overcall or a takeout double follows an opening suit bid.

title: Mr. Clinton's F.E.C. Fold
description: President Clinton was on the right track earlier this month when he petitioned the Federal Election Commission to ban ''soft money,'' the unlimited contributions to political parties that have made a mockery of the existing limits on donations to Federal campaigns. After all, it was misguided F.E.C. rulings that opened the soft money loophole, which both Mr. Clinton and the Republicans scandalously exploited in 1996. The agency has the authority to undo its mistakes without waiting for Congress to pass reform legislation.

title: Grains of Salt for a Theory
description: If it is possible to blow up a conspiracy theory with facts, ''Who Shot Martin Luther King Jr.?'' should explode the argument that King was killed in 1968 on orders of the United States Government. That claim, promoted by William F. Pepper, the lawyer for James Earl Ray, who is serving a life sentence for the murder, has recently been subscribed to by King's wife and children.

title: Outlawing Islam
description: Yesterday's resignation of Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan of Turkey stems from a conflict, now bedeviling much of the Muslim world, over how much freedom to grant Islamic expression and Islamic political parties. In Turkey, the secular military pressured Mr. Erbakan, who heads an Islamist party, to crack down on displays of Islam, and has now forced his resignation. Many other nations, including Algeria, Tunisia and Egypt, ban some Islamic parties outright. Muslim nations are right to be wary of groups that might impose dictatorships if they reached power. But such bans can end up creating repressive police states in the name of preventing them. They can also help radicalize Islamic movements that might otherwise play by democratic rules.

title: With 6,138 Lives, 'Cats' Sets Broadway Mark
description: Like Grizabella rising to the Heaviside Layer, ''Cats'' ascends to Broadway heaven tonight, when it overtakes ''A Chorus Line'' to become the longest-running show in Broadway history, with 6,138 performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, OSGOOD MARSH (NEE JIM)
description: NICHOLS-Osgood Marsh (nee Jim). On June 14, 1997. Husband of Eleanor, brother of Gouverneur Nichols and Polly van der Does of New York. Jim lived for over 50 years in Wilton, CT. He was a writer, editor, and head of his own public relations firm. His memberships include the Century Club, Harvard Club and Wilton Riding Club. Memorial services will be held Monday, June 23, at 11:00 AM at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Wilton, CT. Contributions to the Wilton Library, 137 Old Ridgefield Road, Wilton, Connecticut 06897.

title: Gingrich Outlines Plan on Race Relations
description: In the Republicans' first major response to President Clinton's recent speech on race relations, Speaker Newt Gingrich tonight sketched out a 10-point program to promote racial healing and black achievement that he said relied more on specific steps and less on theory, talk and affirmative action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELFAND, KATE
description: GELFAND-Kate, June 17, 1997, age 87. Wife of the late Joseph, mother of Elson, Philip and Bellinda, mother-in-law of Phyllis and Lynn and Clive. Services Thurs., June 19, 1:45PM, I.J. Morris, 21 E. Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, N.Y.

title: Men Once Led By Pol Pot Say They Have Him
description: One of the most reviled figures of the century, the fugitive Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot, surrendered to his former comrades today, a clandestine rebel broadcast said.

title: Teen-Agers and Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: George Strugar, N.F.L. Lineman, 63
description: George Strugar, a former defensive lineman with the Jets and Los Angeles Rams who had a standout career at the University of Washington, died last week in Anza, Calif. He was 63 years old. The cause of death was lung cancer.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a speech by President Clinton on race relations misstated the timing and events leading to creation of the National Commission on Civil Disorders, known as the Kerner Commission. The commission investigated the causes of the urban riots of the summer of 1967 and issued its report on March 1, 1968. The assassinations of Robert F. Kennedy and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. occurred after the report was completed.

title: Beyond Goofy, the Tricks Are Just for Laughs
description: Somewhere, Ed Sullivan is smiling. Just when it seemed that the vaudeville legacy of his show -- all those plate spinners, jugglers and ventriloquists -- had been banished from television forever, two new comic series have brought them back. ''Oddville, MTV,'' a nightly show that began on Monday, creates a parodic framework for corny performers who take themselves seriously. These escape artists, singers of wacky songs and contortionists are what vaudeville would have called novelty acts and David Letterman would call stupid human tricks. ''Oddville, MTV'' is set up to appreciate both the serious and the satiric aspects of the routines.

title: Bar to Government Bond Work for Dai-Ichi
description: The Japanese Government said today that it would bar Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. from underwriting and bidding to buy Government bonds at auction. The move was the latest blow to the bank, which has been caught up in a scandal over racketeer payoffs.

title: MEDICARE REVAMP ADVANCES IN VOTE BY SENATE PANEL
description: The Senate Finance Committee unanimously approved sweeping legislation today that would redesign Medicare and increase charges for affluent elderly people under the program, provide new money for health coverage of uninsured children and restore welfare benefits for more than a half-million legal immigrants.

title: Seasons Come and Go, but N.H.L. Grows
description: Amid the expansions and realignments of the 1990's, the National Hockey League has replaced its esoteric conference and division designations with prosaic and geographical names. The Prince of Wales Conference became the Eastern Conference and the Conn Smythe Division became the Pacific Division.

title: Wyman-Gordon Fined
description: The Wyman-Gordon Company has agreed to pay $1.8 million in penalties for safety deficiencies at a southeast Texas forging plant where an explosion killed eight workers and injured two, Federal safety officials said today. The company, based in North Grafton, Mass., also agreed to make safety improvements at the plant and at four others to prevent similar accidents, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration said. The company admitted no wrongdoing in the settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMAN, MILTON J.
description: LIPPMAN-Milton J., on June 17, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude, adored father, father-inlaw, grandfather, and brother. Funeral will be held Friday, 10 AM, at I.J. Morris of Dix Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESSLER, HATTIE
description: KESSLER-Hattie. On June 17, 1997. Beloved mother, grandmother and devoted wife to her late husband Ben. She is survived by her loving daughter Adrienne and son-in-law Steve Grossman, and grandchildren Kenneth and Lauren. She will be sorely missed by family, friends and all who knew her.

title: Another Hit In New York: Interleague
description: FOR nearly half a season, Mets and Yankees fans, often as subtle as a car alarm, bellowed long and hard about how a newfangled kind of format known as interleague play would be a wonderful throwback. A throwback, New Yorkers figured, to an era when the only baseball that counted was in their own five boroughs, played by players in Yankees, Dodgers and Giants uniforms.

title: OLYMPIC CASCADE BUYS WESTAMERICA INVESTMENT GROUP
description: The Olympic Cascade Financial Company said yesterday that it had acquired the WestAmerica Investment Group unit from the West America Corporation for an undisclosed price as it expands its nationwide network of brokerage firms. The investment group had revenue of $3.6 million in the year ended March 31. Olympic Cascade, with 38 offices in 18 states, was formed as a holding company in January and is based in Seattle. The investment group, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., has 30 brokers. The WestAmerica Corporation, also based in Scottsdale, is an oil and gas company. Shares in Olympic Cascade rose 50 cents yesterday, to $6. WestAmerica rose 12.5 cents, to $1.125.

title: Where to Find It
description: WITH all the talk about spring cleaning, one could easily get the impression that serious cleaning is done only once a year. But with steamy weather and whirring fans, summer invites special rituals.

title: Chief Judge in New York Tells Family Courts to Admit Public
description: New York State's Family Courts, which handle some of the system's most private and wrenching cases, from custody fights to crimes committed by children, should routinely be open to the public, the state's Chief Judge, Judith S. Kaye, said yesterday.

title: Chinese Unit Buys Hong Kong Bank Stake
description: China Resources Enterprises Ltd., the investment arm of China's Foreign Trade Ministry, plans to buy the 50 percent stake in the Hong Kong Chinese Bank owned by its parent company, the China Resources Holdings Company, for $2 billion (Hong Kong), or $258 million (United States). It will rename it China Resources Bank. The other 50 percent is owned by the Lippo Group.

title: House G.O.P., Under Fire, Flip-Flops on Ethics Report
description: Following a script their worst enemies might have written, House Republican leaders today killed and then resuscitated a set of modest changes that had taken a bipartisan task force on ethics procedures four months to draft.

title: Rent Law Extension Stays Unofficial as Albany Legislators Argue
description: For the third consecutive day, the Legislature adjourned today without passing a bill to extend state rent laws, as negotiators fought over a provision intended to make it easier for landlords to decontrol apartments that rent for more than $2,000 a month.

title: Procreation Isn't the Way to Gain Immortality
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Four Faces of Hong Kong: Daily Life in Heady Times
description: Every day, millions of Hong Kongers head for work, on gleaming subway trains or double-decker buses, by cab and some, even, by chauffeured cars.

title: In Unusual Move, F.C.C. Chief Criticizes a Possible Deal
description: Seeking to scuttle the largest corporate merger in history before it is even formally proposed, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission is expected to declare today that merging the AT&T Corporation with a regional Bell telephone company would be ''unthinkable'' under antitrust laws.

title: Discrimination Settlement
description: A real estate management company agreed yesterday to pay $950,000 in fines and damages to settle a discrimination complaint filed by the United States Justice Department.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Israel's Central Bank Lowers Interest Rate
description: The Bank of Israel said yesterday that it would reduce its benchmark interest rate 1.2 percentage points, after the Israeli Cabinet voted to widen the band the shekel can trade within.

title: Van Gundy's Stock Grows
description: The Knicks have maintained that they plan to extend Jeff Van Gundy's contract, but they have yet to begin negotiations. The longer they wait, the more the coach's negotiating leverage seems to grow.

title: TV Industry Freezes Talks On Revising Rating System
description: Negotiators for the television industry broke off talks yesterday with parent advocacy groups that are seeking changes in the fledgling television program ratings system, after Vice President Al Gore issued a statement supporting the position of the advocacy groups.

title: A Seductive Drug Culture Flourishes on the Internet
description: Even as parents, teachers and government officials urge adolescents to say no to drugs, the Internet is burgeoning as an alluring bazaar where anyone with a computer can find out how to get high on LSD, eavesdrop on what it is like to snort heroin or cocaine, check the going price for marijuana or copy the chemical formula for methamphetamine, the stimulant better known as speed.

title: Whoever Came to Bat, Interleague Play Proved a Big Hit
description: Stan Javier hit three home runs against American League pitchers after not having hit a home run all season against National League pitchers. Rickey Henderson and Tony Phillips each hit a home run playing designated hitter in one of the first games involving the N.L. and the d.h. In a game in which A.L. pitchers had to hit, Matt Stairs batted for a pitcher in the seventh inning, got a hit, stayed in the game and stroked two more hits.

title: A Young Neal Cassady, On the Road and Off
description: You didn't have to dye your hair green, pierce your tongue and wear bizarre eye makeup to stand out as a flaming rebel in the late 1940's. All you had to do was chain-smoke, play pool, listen to be-bop and break girls' hearts. That's the portrait of the 20-year-old Neal Cassady (flashily played by the newcomer Thomas Jane) that emerges in Stephen Kay's snazzy-looking but slight film, ''The Last Time I Committed Suicide.'' At 20, the man who became a guiding light of the Beat Generation, inspiring Jack Kerouac's ''On the Road'' and later joining Ken Kesey's psychedelic troupe the Merry Pranksters, is portrayed as a hunky mixed-up kid with too many hormones roiling around in his body.

title: Willard Hurst, 86, Legal Scholar And Pioneer in History of Law
description: J. Willard Hurst, professor emeritus of the University of Wisconsin Law School and internationally recognized as the dean of American legal historians, died on Wednesday at his home in Madison, Wis. He was 86.

description: Scream

title: Home Video
description: A Fistful of Disks

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on June 8 about Gibraltar referred incorrectly to its 1967 referendum on its future as a colony. The referendum, in which residents voted overhwhelmingly for continued association with Britain, was not conducted under United Nations supervision.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Son of Dr. King Asserts L.B.J. Role in Plot
description: Three months ago, Dexter Scott King declared that he and his family believed that James Earl Ray was not guilty of the murder of his father, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Tonight, in a televised interview, Mr. King asserted that President Lyndon B. Johnson must have been part of a military and governmental conspiracy to kill Dr. King.

title: $25 and Under
description: The hand-written menu at Bel-Air, a little French restaurant that opened just a few weeks ago in the East Village, looks familiar.

title: AIDS-Associated Virus Is Tied to a Common Blood Cancer
description: In a surprising finding that is likely to intensify the hunt for viruses as causes of cancer, scientists in Los Angeles have linked an AIDS-associated virus with a common blood cancer.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Dr. Peter Blos, a child psychoanalyst and an authority on adolescence, misspelled his wife's given name. She is Dr. Betsy Thomas Blos, not Bessy.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL TO REVAMP FOOD BUSINESS
description: CPC International Inc. said yesterday that it would reorganize its consumer food business, resulting in job cuts and a second-quarter charge of $155 million, or $1.08 a share. The maker of Skippy peanut butter, Mazola corn oil and other food products said it would take an additional charge of $65 million, or 45 cents a share, for the cost of spinning off its corn-refining business. CPC will sell some units and close some plants, in addition to the previously announced transfer of Mueller's pasta production to another manufacturer. A company spokeswoman declined to say how many jobs would be cut. The reorganization was announced after the close of trading. Shares of CPC rose $1.375, to $86.50. CPC, which is based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., had been expected to earn $1.08 a share in the second quarter.

title: Baptists' Big Sacrifice
description: To the Editor:

title: Golden Arches Are Victorious, But Bloodied, in a British Court
description: McDonald's has had more than its fair share of grief lately: hamburger sales are down, hackers are spreading nasty tales through the Internet, and the company's 55-cent burger campaign in its native United States fell flat.

title: The Tyranny of Time In Every Detail? Creepy
description: Summertime often produces a rash of grade-B horror films catering to a vacation state of mind. But the creepiest show to hit town so far this season is an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art titled ''Ivan Albright: Magic Realist.''

title: Barney's to Take a Charge of $51.4 Million
description: Barney's Inc. said yesterday that it would take a $51.4 million charge to close four of its 13 stores and dismiss 200 employees.

title: Merrill to Pay $30 Million in Orange County Bankruptcy
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has agreed to pay $30 million to settle a criminal investigation into the firm's role in underwriting bond offerings for Orange County, Calif., before the county filed for bankruptcy in 1994, the Orange County District Attorney announced yesterday.

title: A New Threat to the African Elephant
description: The wanton destruction of the African elephant has been one of the 20th century's grimmer monuments to human stupidity and greed. In the 1980's alone the kill rate, mainly from poaching, reached 200 a day. The number of these majestic creatures dwindled from 1.3 million to less than half that. Then in 1989 the U.N. Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species put the African elephant on its ''most endangered'' list and banned worldwide commercial trade in ivory. The agreement has been a resounding success. The ivory trade dried up, and elephant populations have shown only modest declines ever since.

title: U.S. Loses Redistricting Challenge
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a court-ordered redistricting plan that left Georgia with only one black-majority Congressional district instead of the two that the Justice Department said were required by the Voting Rights Act and the Court's own precedents.

title: Panel Seeks 20-Cent Rise in Cigarette Tax
description: After a long day of horse-trading behind closed doors, the Senate Finance Committee approved a substantially changed tax-cutting bill tonight, dealing out victories and defeats to special interests and making concessions to members of both parties on their priority issues.

title: Time Bent, Love Tested And Illness Faced Down
description: By the time Yvonne Rainer's film ''Murder and Murder'' is over, you will have come to know its main characters about as well as it is possible to know any two personalities projected onto a movie screen. You will, that is, if you've been paying close attention to a film that demands a concentrated intellectual engagement.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Nominated for Prosecutor
description: Governor Whitman nominated two Republicans yesterday to replace county prosecutors from the opposing party. Mrs. Whitman's choice for Hudson County, a Democratic stronghold, is Frederick J. Theemling, of Weehawken, a former assistant prosecutor who practices law in Guttennberg. The incumbent, Carmen Messano, was nominated for a seat on the Superior Court. For Ocean County, Mrs. Whitman named David Millard of Toms River, to the post held by Daniel Carluccio. The nominations are subject to State Senate confirmation.

title: Nation's Trade Deficit Rose 7.8% in April
description: The nation's foreign trade deficit rose 7.8 percent in April, calling new attention to trade tensions with Japan and China as President Clinton and other world leaders gathered yesterday for a summit meeting in Denver.

title: France's Premier Says Shaky Finances Put a Brake on Jobs Plan
description: France's Prime Minister told Parliament today that the country's precarious finances would force him to move cautiously on the job-creation programs he promised during the election campaign last month.

title: British Safeway Venture In Northern Ireland
description: Safeway Food Stores P.L.C., Britain's third-largest supermarket chain, said yesterday that it had set up a joint venture with Fitzwilton P.L.C. to run supermarkets in Northern Ireland.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * KING WORLD PRODUCTIONS INC., New York, named Jules Haimovitz president and chief operating officer. Mr. Haimovitz, who had been president and chief executive at ITC Entertainment Group, succeeds Michael King as president. Mr. King, who remains chief executive, takes the new post of vice chairman.

title: Affordable Apartments Open Way for Financing
description: A 33-story mixed-income apartment tower rising on a plot running from 42d to 43d Street between 10th and 11th Avenues underscores both the city's hearty rental market and continued developer interest in the so-called ''80-20'' method of tax-exempt financing, in which some apartments are leased to low-income tenants.

title: The Traitor Movement
description: Timothy McVeigh awaits execution. The jurors who convicted and sentenced him have done their duty. The rest of American society has not.

title: Detroit's Behemoths Are a Menace on the Roads
description: To the Editor:

title: Legislature Approves Bill to Keep Rent Rules for Six Years
description: The Legislature approved a set of laws tonight to keep the system of rent regulation in place for six years while allowing landlords much larger increases for vacant apartments, ending the Capitol's most wrenching struggle in years.

description: New Rent Laws Approved

title: Decline of Crest Shows How a Brand Can Fade
description: Toothpastes have been promising consumers everything but a visit from the tooth fairy lately, with an onslaught of ads for products that whiten teeth, reduce sensitivity, control tartar, eliminate plaque and generally produce a more kissable mouth. So how is it that Crest, for nearly 40 years the market leader, was so slow to respond?

title: Privacy in Family Court
description: To the Editor:

title: In Ontario, Some Bare Breasts, Some Beat Them
description: Finally, the bony fingers of winter have left central Canada and with the first warm days of summer have come the first encounters with the province's new judicial ruling that allows women to go topless anywhere they please.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APPLE SOUTH INC., Madison, Ga., a restaurant company, said it planned to acquire the closely held Canyon Cafes Inc., Dallas, for $42 million in cash, stock and assumed debt.

title: Waking Up With a Political Hangover
description: ''Underground'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 12. The film opens today at Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village.

title: A Cabby Who Knows How To Keep His Meter Running
description: Have you ever harbored the suspicion that some men are drawn to filmmaking by the opportunity it offers to associate with alluring women? Support for that notion may be found in ''Fall.''

title: Unisys Chief to Step Down From Troubled Computer Maker
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that James A. Unruh, its chairman and chief executive, would step down, paving the way for new management at the struggling computer company.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Blackmon

title: Electric Car to Undergo A Far-Ranging Change
description: EXPENSIVE and limited, just as the first personal computers, the first factory-built electric vehicles are on the market but selling slowly. A change coming this year, though, will make existing models obsolete and new ones more attractive, say advocates, the way MMX chips are supplanting plain old Pentiums, or, to pick a metaphor from the parallel era of computing, as Windows is replacing DOS.

title: Art in Review
description: 'In the Eye of the Tiger'

title: It's a Jungle Out There In the Yard
description: Leslie Nielsen, in straw hat or pith helmet, takes his naked rake into an apparently peaceful garden on Sunday only to find a mayhem of massacre and mating. Through the magnifying magic of the camera lens, this improbable National Geographic explorer meets up with too-large-for-life shrews, snakes, earwigs, fire ants, dragonflies, tiger beetles, acorn weevils and other creatures that, happily for gardeners, thrive largely unseen in the nation's backyards.

title: Diner's Journal
description: When you consider that Manhattan is an island, it's shocking how few waterside restaurants we have.

title: A Missing Cat Unmasks the Hidden Paris
description: ''When the Cat's Away'' was shown in this year's New Directors/ New Films Series. Here are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 21. The film opens today.

title: AT&T Picks Vice Chairman and Stirs Speculation
description: In a move that raises a fresh round of questions about the future leadership of the AT&T Corporation, the company yesterday promoted its top lawyer, John D. Zeglis, to vice chairman.

title: Two Fishermen Arrested in Sale Of Contaminated Striped Bass
description: Two fishermen were arrested yesterday for selling 686 pounds of striped bass, caught in the contaminated waters of Jamaica Bay, to an undercover police officer who told them that he planned to sell the fish to local restaurants, the Queens District Attorney's office said yesterday.

description: In Love and War

description: Two agencies have won Best of Show honors at the 30th annual American Advertising Awards ceremony, sponsored by the American Advertising Federation.

description: 'The Art of the Everyday'

title: Some Gains for Landlords Emerge in the Fine Print
description: Though tenant advocates declared victory earlier this week on the outlines of a rent-regulation agreement, the language that finally emerged in the legislation last night represented significant gains for landlords.

title: In a New York Oz, Even the Glitz Is Artificial
description: ''Auntie Mame, long pants!''

title: Potential Barney's Suitor Has Eye for Bargains
description: It's guys like David Bonderman who have gotten pricey clothiers like Barney's Inc. into such a fix. He may have founded one of the nation's largest, fastest-growing buyout firms, with about $4 billion under management, but around his office, casual Fridays last all week. At age 54, he still usually looks as though he is headed for a rock concert -- and he often is -- in whatever rumpled, mismatched khakis and sport shirts and socks happened to be lying around.

title: Bill McCartney, Away From the Sideline, Brings His Inspirational Message to the Bowery
description: Like many evangelists, Bill McCartney has a passel of stories to tell, stories about individuals who have turned to God and been rewarded. And because he won fame as the successful head football coach at the University of Colorado, he also has football stories, about men bonding in common cause, infusing their team with a power greater than their individual selves and marching to unlikely victory.

title: In Election Year, Debate Rages Over Using Public Money for City Ads
description: As the television camera glides through the picture-perfect streets of New York City, the voice of the actor Tony Roberts makes some very familiar points.

title: New Air Quality Standards Would Save Money
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big Riff Made Small Sounds New And Smart
description: Riffs are usually big, whomping things meant to make dancers dance. In Ned Rothenberg's hands, riffs are small and gentle compositional devices, and at Biblios on Tuesday night, as part of the Knitting Factory's New York Jazz Festival, Mr. Rothenberg led his band through a series of compositions that leaned heavily on them.

title: Murdoch Broadens Horizons
description: Rupert Murdoch now owns 20 percent of the Knicks and the Rangers. He can't control them, but he's got them, as part of his larger plan to broaden the influence of the Fox Sports Net, the cable sports empire of which he owns half.

title: Glamour magazine signs up Diet Coke, NBC and Target.
description: IN a multifaceted promotional marketing campaign, a leading women's magazine is joining forces with a giant advertiser, a big retailer and the No. 1 television network.

title: Justices Back U.S. in Dispute With Alaska on Coastal Areas
description: To the relief of environmentalists, the Federal Government today won a complete victory in the Supreme Court in an 18-year-long boundary dispute with Alaska over control of offshore areas along the state's Arctic coast that are both ecologically fragile and rich in oil and gas deposits.

title: As the Yanks Settle Down, Gooden Takes the Mound
description: The hype and hysteria over the historic meeting between the Yankees and the Mets matched the product for three scintillating games this week, with enough entertainment to make even the purists reconsider their detestation of interleague play.

title: One Indicator Bodes Well For the Bulls
description: When it comes to breadth, Wall Street has not seen anything like the current rally in more than six years. And some analysts think that means that the bull market is nowhere near its end.

title: Adoption Policy Is Contested
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit yesterday in Superior Court contending that the state's adoption policies discriminate against gay couples. Under state regulations, only one member of an unmarried couple may adopt a child. A second parent may petition for adoption afterward, but this is a costly and lengthy process, said Michael Adams, a staff lawyer with the A.C.L.U. Since gay couples cannot legally marry, this policy means they are treated as second-class citizens, he said. Mr. Adams is representing Jon Holden and Michael Galluccio, of Maywood, who are seeking to legally adopt their 21-month-old foster son. The child had been exposed in the womb to H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and was suffering from various ailments when the couple brought him home from the hospital.

title: AIRBUS GETS $2 BILLION ORDER FROM NORTHWEST
description: Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 50 A319 jets, valued at $2 billion, from Airbus Industrie, giving the European consortium a much-needed success in its battle for market share with the Boeing Company. Northwest also took options to buy 100 more of the planes, which seat 125 passengers. If all the options become orders, the sale would be valued at $6 billion. The planes will be delivered from 1999 through 2003. Keeping Northwest was crucial for Airbus, which recently lost some of the biggest United States airlines as potential customers. Since November, Delta Air Lines, Continental Airlines and American Airlines, an AMR unit, have all reached agreements making Boeing their sole supplier of planes for 20 years.

title: Stewart, a Hot Prospect, Hopes Knicks Take Him
description: When he played on the blacktops of the East New York section of Brooklyn, Kebu Stewart would pretend he was Charles Oakley, the Knicks' power forward.

title: For Children
description: 'A Puppet Celebration'

title: A Financial District Tour
description: Heritage Trails of New York, a nonprofit organization that promotes the history and architecture of downtown Manhattan, is offering guided tours of the financial district, from the grave sites of past titans of industry at Trinity Church to the vaults at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, where foreign gold is stored 80 feet below street level.

title: For Megan's Killer, Prosecutor Says, Justice Is Death
description: Just before the jury began deliberations today to decide whether to sentence Jesse K. Timmendequas to death for the murder of 7-year-old Megan Kanka, a prosecutor said Mr. Timmendequas deserved no mercy because he had shown none to Megan.

title: Mexico Reacts Bitterly to Execution of One of Its Citizens in Texas
description: Mexicans and some international groups today harshly criticized the execution in Texas on Wednesday of a Mexican citizen convicted of murdering an American motorist.

title: Price of 30-Year Bond Edges Up as Yield Stays at 6.68%
description: The prices of Treasury securities bounced around yesterday in choppy trading before finishing slightly higher. The market fell early in the day on fears that signs of strength in the economy would lead to inflation, but it later recovered.

title: Divorce Lawyer Switches
description: One of of New York City's premier divorce lawyers, Eleanor B. Alter, is leaving Rosenman & Colin, her law firm of 15 years, and taking a team of family-law attorneys with her.

title: Coffee and Cotton Exchanges May Merge
description: The boards of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange have agreed to explore a possible merger, the exchanges said in a statement late yesterday.

title: U.S., Lauding Its Economy, Finds No Summit Followers
description: It may not be polite to gloat about your good fortune in front of your guests. Nonetheless, as President Clinton and his economic team prepare to open the annual summit meeting of major industrial nations, which starts here on Friday, they just cannot resist.

title: HOUSE IS CRITICAL OF MEDICARE PLAN BY SENATE PANEL
description: The bipartisan shine on Senate efforts to revolutionize Medicare and protect its finances started tarnishing today, as the plan met pained silence from House Republicans and withering attacks from Democrats.

title: Two Exchanges Set Records For Uncovered Short Sales
description: On the smaller American Stock Exchange, short interest rose 7.45 percent, to 171 million shares -- also a record -- for the same period, the exchange said yesterday.

title: Proposal Would Let Insurers Reorganize
description: Responding to appeals from the life insurance industry, Gov. George E. Pataki introduced legislation yesterday that would permit some of the biggest insurance companies in the state to adopt a controversial new corporate structure that critics say shortchanges policyholders.

title: General Bearing and G.M.
description: The General Bearing Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a $54 million agreement with the General Motors Corporation to supply wheel and axle bearings to the No. 1 auto maker over the next three years.

title: Evasive on Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Complaints Against the Police Decline by 21% Through May
description: Civilian complaints against New York City police officers, which rose steadily during the first half of the decade, dropped slightly in 1996 and then by nearly 21 percent during the first five months of this year, according to statistics released yesterday by the Civilian Complaint Review Board.

title: No Change Reported In Shabazz's Condition
description: Doctors at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx reported no change in the extremely critical condition of Dr. Betty Shabazz yesterday as members of her family continued to receive visits at the hospital from friends and dignitaries.

title: No Magic, But Mets Keep It Interesting
description: It seemed the Mets might suffer pixie-dust withdrawal symptoms once they departed the magical Yankee Stadium to return to their same old crowd at Shea Stadium. And yet, not even reality could bring this team down.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Ridicule

title: Political Costs Are Clouding Tobacco Talks
description: As negotiators declared today that a settlement in the tobacco talks appeared imminent, the White House grew increasingly concerned that the costs of signing a deal with the unpopular cigarette industry might far outweigh the political benefits.

title: C. Martin Wilbur, 89, a Scholar Of Nationalists' Rise in China
description: C. Martin Wilbur, an authority on the history and politics of 20th-century China and a former director of Columbia University's East Asian Institute, died on Wednesday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 89.

title: GATEWAY SETS $194 MILLION ACCORD WITH ADVANCED LOGIC
description: Gateway 2000 Inc. signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Advanced Logic Research Inc. for $15.50 a share, or about $194 million, in cash. Gateway, a direct marketer of personal computers based in North Sioux City, S.D., said it expected the acquisition to accelerate Advanced Logic's growth and work force expansion. Directors of Advanced Logic, a maker of microcomputer systems that is based in Irvine, Calif., approved the deal and recommended that stockholders tender their shares pursuant to an offer that will start by June 25. Holders of about 42 percent of Advanced Logic shares have agreed to tender their shares. Gateway shares closed up $1.125, at $33.125, and Advanced Logic shares rose $2.125, to $14.125.

title: Art in Review
description: Peggy Preheim

title: The Men Who Made Pinocchio Come Alive
description: Besides an obvious talent for drawing, what is the secret of creating memorable movie cartoon characters? One astute commentator in ''Frank and Ollie,'' a tantalizing peek into the history of cartoon animation, credits the magic of infusing an image with compelling personality as a matter of ''sincerity.''

title: Publishers Hire Marketing Executive
description: The Magazine Publishers of America has hired Christine Miller as executive vice president for marketing. She assumes duties from James R. Guthrie, executive vice president for marketing development, who resigned in April to become executive vice president for marketing and sales at the Peterson Publishing Company in New York.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Someone Borrowed And Blue
description: Like his first nuptial comedy, ''Muriel's Wedding,'' P. J. Hogan's ''My Best Friend's Wedding'' has a case of the Australian cutes. Its title sequence features a bride and bridesmaids in poufy gowns, all mouthing a Dionne Warwick song with kitschy passion. This turns out to be a significant motif within this otherwise obtuse, prettily decorative comedy. Characters burst gaily into song when, as often happens, they don't have anything better to do.

title: Bond Issue Sent to Governor
description: The State Assembly passed a measure yesterday that would give voters the chance to approve a $20 million bond issue to provide municipalities with grants and low-interest loans for demolishing abandoned buildings. The measure now goes to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who issued a conditional veto of a similar bill in May and asked that the dollar amount be reduced from $35 million. In Newark alone, there are 1,200 abandoned buildings.

title: Budgets Show Less Is Spent For Students In High School
description: At a time when the state is requiring New York City high school students to meet tougher standards for graduation, the city school system spent substantially less on those students this year than on their counterparts in elementary and middle schools, widening a gap that was first documented last year, according to school budgets released yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: A Couple of Guys Teeter on the Edge
description: Finn Taylor's ''Dream With the Fishes'' recalls a peculiarly innocent film genre, the whimsical, try-anything 1970's film with characters who drop out of the mainstream on their journey to enlightenment, be it peaceful or tragic. It's an endearingly eccentric blueprint, especially in these blockbuster-driven times.

title: Woman Plunges to Death As Apartment Is Robbed
description: After two robbers forced their way into a sixth-floor apartment yesterday afternoon, a Queens woman locked herself in a bathroom and then jumped or fell to her death from the bathroom window, the police said.

title: Holy Iceberg! Dynamic Duo Vs. Mr. Freeze
description: AT a gala in Gotham City, the fabulous Poison Ivy makes her entrance in a fluffy magenta gorilla suit made from 450 Santa Claus wigs.
