Then she peels this off slowly as the band plays her theme song. And out comes the most show-stopping character in ''Batman and Robin,'' the fourth and most frenetically gaudy feature in the series. As played by Uma Thurman, Poison Ivy is perfect, flaunting great looks, a mocking attitude and madly flamboyant disguises. Like Mae West, she mixes true femininity with the winking womanliness of a drag queen.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Trade Deficit Grows, But Exports Stay Strong

title: The Two-Week Legislative Year
description: Independence Day is the traditional end of New York's state legislative session. But with two weeks to go, the Senate and Assembly have not even begun to tackle their 1997 agenda. The fight over rent regulation kept business at a standstill. Now the senators and Assembly members may fail to deal with critical problems in their rush to get home for summer vacation. History suggests there is even more danger that they will pass bad legislation in the last-minute confusion.

title: In Denver for Economic Talks, Clinton Calls for Freer Trade
description: On the eve of an economic summit meeting of eight nations in Denver, President Clinton chided critics of his free-trade policies in a speech in this suburb today and called on Congress to give him greater flexibility in negotiating trade agreements with Latin American countries like Argentina, Brazil and Chile.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Corrections
description: The mutual funds tables from Morningstar Inc. in Business Day on Wednesday and yesterday omitted funds that invest primarily in New York municipal bonds. The funds appear in the table today, on page D16.

title: Art in Review
description: Elena Climent

title: BORDEN CHEMICALS TO BUY BASF'S 50% OF JOINT VENTURE
description: Borden Chemicals and Plastics L.P., a polyvinyl chloride resins producer, said yesterday that it planned to acquire the BASF Corporation's 50 percent interest in a jointly owned chemical plant for an undisclosed sum. The plant, which is in Borden's headquarters city of Geismar, La., produces acetylene under a joint venture agreement, and the two companies have shared the plant's output. Borden said it expected to close the deal Dec. 31, 1999. Its shares slipped 12.5 cents, to $10.875. BASF is a unit of Germany's BASF A.G.

title: Don't Raise the Age for Medicare Eligibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Looking for Right Fit For Their Draft Selections
description: The Nets are holding auditions, looking for players with the perfect combination of skill and attitude to select as their seventh and 21st picks in next Wednesday's draft -- if they stay at those positions.

title: Superfund Item Is Defeated
description: The United States Senate voted yesterday to remove a provision of a defense bill that New Jersey lawmakers said would have exempted W.R. Grace & Company, the former operator of a Federal Superfund site, from further liability for cleanup costs at a site in Wayne Township. The company paid the Government $800,000 in 1984 to help remove cancer-causing thorium from the site. Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, said that the government already has spent more than $50 million to clean up the site, and costs are expected to reach $120 million.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: BUDGET DISPARITY -- The school system spent substantially less on high school students this year than on elementary and middle school students, school budgets show. B4.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an enforcement action taken by the Securities and Exchange Commission against an offshore fund, GFL Ultra Fund Ltd., misidentified the rule under which the commission acted, and misstated an allegation against the fund. The rule was Regulation S, not Registration S. The commission contended that the fund had hedged its position by selling stock short in 62 of the 90 instances in which it purchased securities issued under Regulation S. It did not say the fund hedged in almost all of the cases.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What more could any college administration wish for than the gift handed to Wellesley College on Monday by OPRAH WINFREY?

title: Ban on Sale of Ivory Is Eased to Help 3 African Nations
description: A worldwide ban on the sale of ivory was eased today to give three southern African countries, all of which have healthy and growing elephant populations but little money to take care of them, the right to sell their stockpiles of ivory.

title: Inside Art
description: Stars in New York . . .

title: Arthur Cutler, 53, Restaurateur of Eclectic Taste and Unlikely Sites
description: Arthur J. Cutler, whose small empire of popular, conceptually unusual restaurants made a distinctive mark on the New York dining business, died on Wednesday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 53.

title: No Headline
description: ''The best anybody was hoping for was that he would have the grace to resign quietly. But it's as if he is a different human being now. Look around the summit table this week and ask yourself which President is more vigorous, active or successful than Boris Yeltsin. ''

title: GolfWatch Not Exactly The Ultimate
description: TIGER WOODS arrived at the Buick Classic yesterday with another PGA Tour rookie, GolfWatch.

title: VENCOR AND TRANSITIONAL TO MERGE IN $639 MILLION DEAL
description: The Transitional Hospitals Corporation of Nashville agreed yesterday to be acquired by Vencor Inc. for $639 million. Under the deal, Vencor, based in Louisville, Ky., would acquire Transitional's 40 million shares for $16 each. Both companies own long-term acute care hospitals. Vencor began a tender offer for Transitional at $16 a share on May 7, and expects to complete it by June 19. After that, it will buy the Transitional shares not tendered. Also yesterday, Transitional ended its proposed merger with the Select Medical Corporation, which had offered $14.55 a share before Vencor's May 7 offer.

title: LVMH Increases Its Stake in Grand Metropolitan
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods company, spent $1.31 billion today to increase its stake in Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. to 6.3 percent in another attempt to thwart Grand Met's merger with Guinness P.L.C.

title: SBC Planning Charges Up to $2.3 Billion
description: SBC Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would take charges of up to $2.3 billion in 1997 in connection with its purchase of Pacific Telesis Group as the combined company, representing the first merger between two regional Bell operating companies and creating the second-largest United States phone company behind the AT&T Corporation, pares operations to improve profit.

title: Dead Woman Wins Appeal
description: After Ellen Gartland fatally shot her husband, John, in 1993, she contended that she was acting in self-defense, but a jury convicted her of reckless manslaughter. The conviction was upheld on appeal, and Mrs. Garland, of Newark, died shortly afterward at the age of 67.

title: A Syncopated City Swings As Twin Jazz Festivals Ignite
description: FOR the next 10 days, jazz will become part of New York City's pavement and sky. It will be in Harlem and TriBeCa; in Central, Bryant and Prospect Parks. Its past will be curatorially unearthed, its future sniffed out by guesswork and its tributaries examined: sounds from Brazil and Japan and Cuba, Eastern European folk songs and cantorial music, the Southern gospel tradition, black pop, and new, patchwork genres that have as much to do with electronic music as with Louis Armstrong.

title: Pol Pot's Brothers in Crime
description: Pol Pot may not have surrendered to his former Khmer Rouge comrades, but there still has been a sea change in Cambodian politics.

title: Victim of Rape Goes Public After 11 Years of Nightmares
description: Every night for 11 years she has thought about some aspect of what happened to her, whether it was Alex Kelly's powerful grip on her throat, the paralyzing fear she felt during the rape, or Mr. Kelly's flight from justice.

title: Cambodia Prince Gives New Report of Pol Pot's Early Surrender
description: First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh said today that he had received confirmation this morning that the Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, had asked to surrender to former supporters who had surrounded him in the jungle.

title: Banning Arms for Dictators
description: For years, a small band of peace activists pushed the entirely sensible but seemingly hopeless idea that the world should refuse to sell arms to dictatorships. Now it may be coming to pass. For the first time, a Code of Conduct setting out criteria for determining who can buy American arms has passed in the House of Representatives. The British Government has said it will adhere to an even stronger code, and support is growing in the European Union for a code that would apply to all members. Together the United States and the European Union account for 80 percent of the world's arms trade.

title: Poignant Faces of the Soon-to-Be-Dead
description: For four years starting in 1975, the Khmer Rouge, under Pol Pot, rounded up Cambodians at S-21, a converted high school in Tuol Sleng, a district of Phnom Penh, where they were tortured and killed. In all, more than 14,000 people were imprisoned there. Seven survived.

title: Jobless Claims Rise Unexpected 8,000
description: The number of Americans applying for state unemployment insurance rose a surprising 8,000 in the week ending last Saturday to a seasonally adjusted level of 347,000, the Labor Department said today.

title: College Isn't a 'Product'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spoken Word
description: VISUAL ARTISTS' LECTURE SERIES, at two Bronx branches of the New York Public Library. Tomorrow at 1:15 P.M. at the Moshulu Branch Library, 285 East 205th Street, near Perry Avenue, Paula Nadelstern, a quilter, will speak about her craft. Also tomorrow, at 2 P.M. at the Van Nest Branch Library, 2147 Barnes Avenue, near Pelham Parkway South, Ira Mark Merritt, a photographer, will speak about his creative process. Both lectures are free. Information: (212) 221-7676.

title: A Seedy Strip Slowly Gives Way To Assaults of the Squeaky Clean
description: To some, it was the Wild Side, to others, Hell's Bedroom. At a particularly low point in the 1970's, it became the Minnesota Strip, a bleak reference to Midwestern girls who had hoped for careers on the Broadway stage, only to become Eighth Avenue street walkers.

title: Emory Bans Gay Rituals At Its Chapels
description: The board of Emory University today temporarily banned commitment ceremonies between people of the same sex in the nondenominational chapels on university campuses.

title: Corrections
description: A chart caption yesterday with an article about benefits of hormone replacement therapy after menopause misidentified the group of women for whom the risk of death was reduced in a study. It was women currently taking hormones, not those who had taken them for 10 years.

title: CITIBANK BUYING BALANCE OF ARGENTINA PENSION MANAGER
description: Citibank N.A. said yesterday that it would pay $230 million to $250 million to acquire the 51 percent of the Argentine pension fund and insurance group Siembra that it does not already own. Siembra comprises the pension management company Siembra AFJP S.A., the life insurance company Sur Compania de Seguros de Vida S.A. and the retirement insurance company Siembra Compania de Seguros de Retiro S.A., all owned by the Argentine bank Banco Rio de la Plata S.A. Citibank, a subsidiary of Citicorp of New York, has a growing presence in Latin America.

title: Racism's Nine Lives
description: In Fayetteville, N.C., a black man and woman walking down the street are shot and killed by white supremacists on the prowl for ''niggers'' to torment.

title: Accused War Criminal May Appeal Ruling
description: The lawyer for Kazys Ciurinskas, a Lithuanian-American who is accused of taking part in World War II atrocities, said he had not decided whether to appeal the ruling of a Federal judge on Wednesday to strip away his client's citizenship.

title: Stocks Regain Steam as Dow Jumps 58.35
description: The stock market roared back to life yesterday, sending all the major indexes back into record territory.

title: Victim's Tape to Be Shown
description: For the first time in a New Jersey courtroom, a videotape of a victim will be shown today during a sentencing hearing for the man who pleaded guilty to manslaughter in her death, officials said. A Superior Court judge ruled on Monday that the parents of the victim, 14-year-old Shannon Wittkopp, could show a five-minute tape showing birthday parties and other highlights of her childhood. Robert Kinzel, 51, admitted in March that he struck the girl with his pickup truck in May 1995, while he was intoxicated.

title: BAY NETWORKS AGREES TO BUY RAPID CITY COMMUNICATIONS
description: Bay Networks Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Rapid City Communications, a privately held developer of routing switch technologies, for $155 million in stock. Rapid City, based in Mountain View, Calif., makes products that increase the speed of data delivery along computer networks. Bay Networks, based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes computer networking products. Bay Networks said it expected to begin shipping Rapid City's fully integrated routing switch products in the fourth quarter. Shares of Bay Networks rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $25.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A 30-Year Monument To Subject and Scholar
description: THE PAINTINGS OF PAUL CEZANNE

title: About the Mutual Funds
description: The mutual funds tables from Morningstar Inc. on Wednesday and yesterday omitted funds that invest primarily in New York municipal bonds. The funds appear in the table today, page D16.

title: Europeans Have Long Agreed to Disagree
description: To the Editor:

title: In Turkey, President Must Pick With Care
description: With Turkey's experiment in government led by an Islamic hard-liner at least temporarily at an end, the political spotlight shifted today to the country's canny elder statesman, President Suleyman Demirel.

title: MAGELLAN AEROSPACE TO ACQUIRE ROLLS-ROYCE SUBSIDIARY
description: The Magellan Aerospace Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Bristol Aerospace Ltd. from Rolls-Royce Industries Canada Inc. for $44.9 million. Magellan, based in Toronto, is an international aerospace manufacturer. Bristol, an aerospace company, is a subsidiary of Rolls-Royce P.L.C.'s Canadian unit, which is concentrating on gas turbine engines, electrical power transmission, materials handling and nuclear power businesses. Bristol's core business includes aircraft wing repair, space rocket propulsion systems and engine components.

title: Purring Over a New Broadway Record
description: It's official. Just after 9 o'clock last night, when the last notes rang out and the house lights went up at the Winter Garden Theater, ''Cats'' entered the record books, sweeping past ''A Chorus Line'' to become the longest-running show in Broadway history. It opened on Oct. 7, 1982.

title: Century 21 Account in Review
description: The Century 21 Real Estate Corporation unit of HFS Inc. has placed in review the creative part of its account; billings are estimated at $30 million.

title: When Youth Is Wasted on the Young
description: Pity the poor baby in the show of Lauren Greenfield's photographs at the International Center of Photography Midtown, ''Fast Forward: Growing Up in the Shadow of Hollywood.'' There she is, Sophie at 6 weeks, a study in white (jumper, socks, blanket), lying on an ocean of floral carpeting, a frown on her face. All about her is a riot of colors and patterns that is her living room in the Hollywood Hills.

title: Lev Kopelev, Soviet Writer In Prison 10 Years, Dies at 85
description: Lev Z. Kopelev, a scholar, dissident author and revered figure in the human rights movement in the Soviet Union in the 1970's, died in St. Elisabeth Hospital in Cologne on Wednesday. He was 85.

title: Judge Rejects Hinckley Bid for Hospital Leave
description: The man who tried to kill President Ronald Reagan in 1981 cannot leave the mental hospital for unescorted visits with his family because ''he has deceived those treating him in ways to numerous to recount'' and may still be dangerous, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Lukas Is Hoping Sharp Cat Will Wear the Triple Tiara
description: She is a big, beautiful chestnut who stands 17 hands tall, she is one of the swift daughters of the swift Storm Cat and she may be ready to salvage some of the season's honors for D. Wayne Lukas, her trainer.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Japanese stocks traded moderately lower here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 100.01 points, or just under one-half of 1 percent, at 20,407.84. Brokerage stocks were among those down most sharply, stung by charges of illegal activity. On Thursday, the Nikkei was little changed, gaining 10 points.

title: Lucky Switzerland?
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS SELLING 2 CONSUMER PRODUCTS UNITS
description: The American Greetings Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Acme Frame Products and Wilhold subsidiaries, which make picture frames and women's hair care products, respectively, to the Newell Company. Terms were not disclosed. American Greetings, based in Cleveland, had pushed to diversify its offerings in recent years by adding a variety of consumer products. But in January, the company said it was considering quitting some of those businesses. Newell, based in Freeport, Ill., makes hardware and home furnishings. American Greetings shares rose 81.25 cents, to $35.9375, while shares of Newell climbed 37.5 cents, to $39.

title: Els Jumps to a Fast Start in the Buick Classic
description: On Sunday it was a grueling trek down the stretch in the United States Open. Today it was a country walk in Westchester.

title: How Technology Liberates The Animator's Imagination
description: If the Hollywood live-action movie is in danger of turning into an amusement park ride, the health of the animated film has never been more robust. The same computer technology that has undermined the humanity of live-action movies has paradoxically prodded animators to develop new looks, textures and visual rhythms as well as richer characters.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the planned sale of One Times Square referred incorrectly in some editions to the percentage of profit the seller is expected to make. The owner, Lehman Brothers, bought the building for $27.5 million and has a contract to sell it for $110 million, which represents a profit of 300 percent, not 400 percent.

title: New Interpublic And Omnicom Units
description: Two agency companies said yesterday that they had expanded in the interactive marketing and corporate identity fields.

title: Restaurants
description: ''Is it noisy?'' ''Is it expensive?'' ''Do I have to dress up?''

title: Colombia Rebels, Feeling Strong, Offer Peace
description: While guerrilla movements in much of Latin America have been withering or making peace in recent years, the handover on Sunday of 70 soldiers and marines who had been held hostage, on terms that leftist guerrillas first dictated nine months ago, illustrated that the opposite has been happening in Colombia. Here, the rebels' muscle is still growing, to the point that they have become a competing authority operating parallel to the elected Government in much of the countryside.

title: Piecemeal Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shaky Year Over, the Yeltsin of Old Flies to the Summit
description: A year ago President Boris N. Yeltsin was practically a dead man. Desperate to win a second term, and to vanquish Communism in Russia for good, Mr. Yeltsin had a heart attack in the middle of the campaign and promptly disappeared from sight.

title: Push a Show's Buttons and It Pushes Back
description: You can't beat the Anchorage, the space at the base of the Brooklyn Bridge, as a spot for a summer exhibition. Its high arched ceilings, accommodating niches and broad halls make it one of the most interesting showcases in town, and its thick walls assure that it's one of the coolest. These factors don't guarantee the quality of ''Art in the Anchorage,'' the show staged there every summer since 1983, but they do enhance the experience.

title: High Court Upholds Death for a Virginia Man
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a death sentence for a Virginia murderer whose 1988 sentencing proceeding was unconstitutional under the terms of a decision the Court issued six years later.

title: Untested Tory, a Foe of Europe, Is Picked to Lead Party
description: Britain's bedraggled Conservatives today chose as their new leader William Hague, the most untested and inexperienced of the candidates for the post and a declared opponent of Britain's further integration in Europe.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the last few years, LENA HORNE has received all sorts of accolades, but few can match the tribute that will be paid to her on Monday, when the Society of Singers honors her with a sold-out show and black-tie dinner in Avery Fisher Hall. The occasion: her 80th birthday, which will actually be on June 30.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A House to Call Home

title: Doubt Cast on Prime Site As Nuclear Waste Dump
description: For more than a decade, this mountain in the heart of the desolate Nevada desert has been promoted as the best spot to bury the country's mounting pile of nuclear waste.

title: 'You Can't Despair'
description: When Irish Republican Army gunmen killed two Ulster policemen this week, Prime Minister Tony Blair suspended British contacts with the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sinn Fein. ''Their cynicism and hypocrisy are sickening,'' he said. ''Their actions defy normal understanding.''

title: Pakistani Reportedly Confesses to C.I.A. Killings
description: The Pakistani under arrest for the deadly rampage near the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency in 1993 confessed to the attack to Federal agents who captured him, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Tutu, Head of Apartheid Inquiry, Refuses to Apologize to de Klerk
description: The head of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, said today that he had no intention of apologizing for his remarks last month questioning the credibility of former President F. W. de Klerk's testimony before the panel.

title: Leetch and Berard Are Given Awards
description: Brian Leetch, the Rangers' perennial All-Star, was awarded his second Norris Trophy last night as the National Hockey League's best defenseman. Bryan Berard, the young Islanders defenseman many have compared to Leetch, was voted winner of the Calder Trophy as the N.H.L.'s rookie of the year, an honor accorded Leetch in 1989.

title: Pete Pascale, 82, Civic Leader Who Loved East Harlem, Dies
description: Pete Pascale, a social worker, community center official and civic leader who loved East Harlem so much that he made it the focus of his life, his work, his dreams and his memories, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 82 and had been executive director of La Guardia Memorial House, the settlement house on East 116th Street that had been his second home as a boy and his vocation for more than 65 years.

title: Resolving Conflicts by Whirling About
description: Conflicts and attempts to resolve them dominated the dances that Donald Byrd/the Group presented on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Ex-Police Official Cites Parking-Ticket Push
description: A former top police official, testifying at a hearing on a police contract dispute, said that the New York City Police Department was pressured by City Hall to produce millions more in revenue from parking fines and that police officers did their part by writing more tickets, according to transcripts of the hearing.

title: Whitman and Legislators Plan $16.8 Billion Budget
description: After three years of cutting taxes and reining in government spending, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Republican legislative leaders agreed today on a $16.8 billion election-year budget that increases spending for public schools, state colleges, child protection workers and municipalities struggling to pay for school construction projects.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER

title: Naval Academy Faces Inquiry on Past Scandals
description: The Pentagon is investigating the way the United States Naval Academy and its Superintendent handled three highly publicized cases of criminal misconduct, Defense Department officials said today.

title: Senate Passes Intelligence Budget, Still a Secret
description: The Senate today passed a secret spending bill for United States intelligence, but the White House threatened to veto it over a provision that would protect whistleblowers.

title: Official's Aide Funneled Illegal Campaign Funds
description: Michael F. Zinn, finance manager for Representative Maurice D. Hinchey's 1992 Congressional campaign, admitted in Federal court here yesterday that he funneled illegal campaign contributions through the employees of his power plant construction company and then claimed the contributions as a company tax deduction.

title: A Little Brother Grows Up
description: There was a time not so long ago when the new assistant basketball coach at Rutgers University got sick of the game and, well, of himself too. It came to a head in December 1993 when, as a junior starting at point guard, Danny Hurley quit the Seton Hall team.

title: Had Enough? Chance to Fix Albany Mess
description: YOU may not always think so, because numbskulls are hardly in short supply, but there are a lot of very smart people in New York City. Proof of a sort came this week when the 1997 MacArthur Fellowships were announced.

title: Screening Skews Juries in Death Penalty Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Turbulence

title: Rara Avis: An Iron Eagle Returning to City Roost
description: It seems even cast-iron birds migrate home eventually.

title: Sex Offender Is Suing His Neighbors Over Protests
description: When John Becerra, a convicted sex offender, moved into his two-story home here in December 1995, he had hoped to begin a new life with his wife and their 9-year-old son.

title: Big Volume Pushes Stocks To More Highs
description: The stock market drifted into the record books again yesterday, but just barely, in one of the busiest trading sessions ever.

title: Rape Charge Is Rejected
description: An Essex County grand jury declined yesterday to indict a former Newark City councilman on sexual assault charges, officials said. Gary S. Harris, who is serving a 33-month sentence on a 1995 Federal bribery conviction, had been accused of raping a woman at his home in Newark on Aug. 17 after offering her a ride home from a nightclub where they had met earlier that evening. Mr. Harris's lawyer, Cecil Banks, said that his client testified that the sex was consensual.

title: Romania Raps on Door For a NATO Invitation
description: As diplomacy goes, the timing could have been better.

title: Camby Repays Tourney Money
description: Marcus Camby, who accepted money and gifts from a sports agent while playing basketball for the University of Massachusetts, announced today that he would pay the school for its share of lost N.C.A.A. tournament revenue.

title: Dalai Lama's Tutor, Portrayed by Brad Pitt, Wasn't Just Roving Through the Himalayas
description: A forthcoming film starring Brad Pitt as an Austrian mountaineer who treks to Tibet during World War II and befriends the young Dalai Lama has been plunged into controversy over the revelation that the Austrian has a Nazi past.

title: Probation in Corruption Case
description: In the final stage of a corruption case involving 11 public officials, teachers, and poll workers, a former member of the Newark Board of Education was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation for arranging to have hundreds of phony votes cast in his 1992 re-election bid, officials said. John Mavilla, 50, faced up to 18 months in prison after pleading guilty in April to vote tampering, said Ray Weiss, a spokesman for the Essex County Prosecutor's office. Judge Michael Casale of Superior Court in Essex County said that Mr. Mavilla, 50, was spared a prison sentence because he is in ill health.

title: ARCHER DANIELS TO PURCHASE ED&F MAN'S COCOA UNIT
description: The Archer Daniels Midland Company said yesterday that it would buy ED&F Man Group P.L.C.'s cocoa unit for $223 million in cash and debt, vaulting the United States company, already the world's largest corn miller, into first place among cocoa processors. Archer will pay $108 million in cash for the unit, assume $80 million in debt owed to others and write off $35 million owed to it. ED&F Man's cocoa division reported a trading loss of $:4.6 million ($7.5 million) in the year after Man took charges to reorganize its Brazilian unit. The London-based Man said in a statement that it would retain its cocoa sources and sales network.

title: Baptist Rank and File Split on Disney Boycott
description: The resounding vote this week in Dallas by the Southern Baptist Convention to boycott all things Disney seemed to carry the weight of a religious crusade.

title: EMI SHUTTING 2 NEW YORK-BASED RECORD LABELS
description: EMI Group P.L.C. said yesterday it would shut down two New York-based record labels, dismissing 140 people including the chief executives, in the final step in the British music company's shake-up of its North American business. EMI said last month that it would take a $:117.2 million ($191 million) charge to pay severance costs, provide for bad debts from United States retailers and close the head office of EMI Capitol in New York. The latest cuts come at EMI Records and Enclave Records, a smaller start-up label. Enclave will be folded into Virgin Records, while the roster and some of the staff at EMI Records will be consolidated into Virgin and Capitol Records.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Whispers Belie Kinship Of the Yanks
description: THE Yankees, finished with the exhilarating interleague series against the Mets, have returned to American League ball and the realities that daily bombard any club loitering eight games behind a division leader.

title: Modern Luminary Finds A Parable in the Occult
description: To say that the dancer and choreographer Pearl Lang gives young people a chance to shine is an understatement. Over the decades, everyone from Harvey Lichtenstein, now president of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, to Madonna (not to speak of Paul Taylor) has danced in her company.

title: Smells of the Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Orders Detroit Papers to Rehire Strikers
description: A Federal labor judge issued a sweeping ruling in favor of more than 1,000 former Detroit newspaper workers yesterday, finding that The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press had engaged in unfair labor practices in forcing a 19-month strike, and ordering the two dailies to put the strikers back to work, even if that means laying off replacement workers.

title: Dollar Rises Against the Yen As Trade Tension Seems Eased
description: The dollar rose against the yen yesterday as the prospect of trade tensions between the United States and Japan appeared to ease as a summit meeting of world leaders began in Denver.

title: Ex-Tobacco Official Enjoys the Aftermath of the Deal
description: Jeffrey S. Wigand, the highest-ranking executive ever to turn against the tobacco industry, was in high spirits today after antismoking forces and cigarette makers reached a settlement.

title: A Stress Test for Third Graders
description: I thought my 8-year-old son's anxiety over his first set of citywide exams was over. But last night he asked me what happens if he doesn't pass the eye exams. The eye exams? You know, ''the Standard Eye Exams.''

title: Ellis Island's Ruins Are Far From Romantic
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Boeing Order From British Air
description: British Airways P.L.C. exercised options to buy five Boeing 777 jetliners today and placed orders for three of the 767 model in a contract valued at $1 billion.

title: Lawmakers Vow Close Scrutiny of Tobacco Pact
description: News of a settlement between tobacco companies and antismoking forces today stirred cautious reactions from many on Capitol Hill and outright skepticism from others. But members of Congress on both sides of the debate agreed that any deal that eventually wins their approval will require a mountain of legislative and bureaucratic changes.

title: Elements of the Deal: Pros and Cons''
description: The participants in yesterday's tentative tobacco settlement presented it as a compromise that balanced the competing demands of cigarette companies and anti-smoking forces. The parties to the agreement say it is a historic settlement that will save thousands of lives in the long run. But some public health advocates are likely to oppose the deal. Here are summaries of some of the main provisions of the agreement, with arguments for and against them.

title: No Headline
description: ''However, while there are things in this agreement that I would prefer to see changed, and there are things in this agreement that anyone can find to criticize, if you look at the overall, comprehensive scope of this agreement, it represents the single-most fundamental change in the history of tobacco control in any nation in the world.''

title: Lawrence Payton, 59, Singer With the Four Tops, Is Dead
description: Lawrence Payton, who sang with the Four Tops for more than four decades, died yesterday at his home in Southfield, Mich., the town's police department said. He was 59.

title: Yeltsin Basks at Summit; Some Europeans Are Cool to U.S.
description: The newly renamed ''summit of the eight'' opened today with President Clinton, buoyed by an effervescent economy, meeting the revived Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, and trying to soothe European anger over what they see as America's arrogance in NATO and the United Nations.

title: Proud to Lead the Way, A Park Greets 'Carmen'
description: The severe thunderstorm that was predicted for early Wednesday night did not arrive until midnight. But the threat was enough for the Metropolitan Opera to cancel the first of this season's Met in the Parks performances, the popular double-bill of ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' and ''Pagliacci'' in Central Park. Instead, opening night for this season's 11-stop parks tour was on Thursday, when ''Carmen,'' with Denyce Graves in the title role, was performed at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. In welcoming the crowd, William Castro, the Bronx Commissioner of Parks, did not try to conceal his delight that the cancellation made his borough the first stop on this summer's tour.

title: More Than 50 Are Arrested In Drug Raid In the Village
description: New York City detectives joined Federal agents Thursday in Washington Square Park to arrest dozens of marijuana dealers who the authorities say return again and again after serving short sentences.

title: Less and Less of Agassi: He's Out at Wimbledon
description: The odd 1997 disappearing act performed by Andre Agassi had its impact felt at Wimbledon today when he withdrew from this Grand Slam tournament, which starts on Monday. The 27-year-old Agassi has played only a dozen matches this year and has dropped five of his last six on the ATP Tour.

title: Bruno Critical of Strategy Pataki Used in Rent Fight
description: The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, criticized his fellow Republican, Gov. George E. Pataki, today for undercutting him during the battle over rent legislation and said the Governor had strongly urged him during the final hours of negotiations to accept a deal Mr. Bruno strongly disliked.

title: Judge Says State Plan for Con Ed Overhaul Needs Work
description: A state proposal to restructure the Consolidated Edison Company does not do enough to introduce competition into what is now a monopoly market for electric power, an administrative judge said in a report released today.

title: Team Canada Is Interested In Campbell
description: Rangers Coach Colin Campbell is one of the top candidates to coach Team Canada in next winter's Olympic Games. Campbell was scheduled to be interviewed tonight for the position by Bob Clarke, the Flyers' president and general manager.

title: The Fight Thickens: Helmsley Sued by Yet Another Partner
description: Battered by legal challenges and allegations of wrongdoing from Leona Helmsley, Peter L. Malkin, a wealthy real estate investor, has retaliated with his own lawsuit contending that Mrs. Helmsley has ''misappropriated'' $5.35 million that was due the partnership that runs one of New York's most enduring symbols, the Empire State Building.

title: Testimony in South Africa Ties Ex-Leader to Bombing
description: Edging closer to illuminating the role of top government officials in the political violence that pervaded South Africa under apartheid, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission has received testimony that former President P. W. Botha personally ordered the bombing that destroyed the South African Council of Churches headquarters in 1988.

title: Women Take the Court, Playing for Peanuts
description: Remember when girls got to play ball only after the boys were finished with the gym? Those days are back. The Women's National Basketball Association plays its first games tonight in the arenas that the National Basketball Association's players have vacated for the summer.

title: Metro Pacific Controls Big Philippine Project
description: The Metro Pacific Corporation of the Philippines agreed yesterday to pay 5.4 billion pesos ($203 million) for the Filinvest Group's 16 percent stake in the Bonifacio Land Corporation, gaining control of a big real estate project, Filinvest Sky City, outside Manila.

title: Student Passion in Korea: Now What's the Point?
description: Yang Hyun Ju's bedtime ritual has been a bit different these last few days, ending with her chaining herself to a fence outside a cathedral here and lying down to go to sleep for the night.

title: Pension Deal Is Rated
description: A major financial rating service, Moody's Investors Service Inc., assigned an A1 rating yesterday to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's offering of $2.75 billion in bonds to bolster the state pension fund and help balance the budget. The rating is less than Moody's top ratings of Aaa and Aa, and the service warned that the bond deal could leave the state ''less well-prepared'' and less flexible to deal with a slower economy.

title: Brookhaven Lab Shut After Accident Kills Worker
description: United States Energy Secretary Federico F. Pena ordered a shutdown of Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, N.Y., yesterday, after an industrial accident in which a construction worker was killed.

title: Abstinence and AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Views of a Culture
description: ''Three Duets,'' presented on Thursday at Aaron Davis Hall, ought to be required viewing for anyone who doubts the viability of performance art and how much challenging live performances appeal to young audiences. The lineup of artists was impressive in this first program in the four-day African-American Performance Art Festival on Tour. And the material shimmered with intelligence, wit and humanity.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing investments made in recent years by the Texas Pacific Group, a potential suitor for Barney's, included one deal erroneously. Texas Pacific has not acquired Varo and Baird Optical Systems. It reached an agreement to acquire the businesses in October 1994, but the deal collapsed.

title: Platinum and Palladium Soar As Russia Delays Shipments
description: Futures prices for platinum and palladium jumped yesterday after Russia said it would not resume shipping the metals until July or later, keeping stockpiles critically low.

title: A Worrisome Tobacco Deal
description: The tobacco deal announced yesterday is a remarkable development in the decades-long fight to curb smoking. Few would have guessed even a few months ago that the industry would pay out such substantial reparations, totaling $368 billion over 25 years, or accept restrictions on advertising and youth access that in many respects are stronger than the Food and Drug Administration previously proposed. Even so, this is a troubling deal that looks as if it does more to protect the tobacco industry than to protect the public health. It should not be approved by the White House or Congress until it has undergone searching scrutiny and been made significantly stronger.

title: FOUNDATION HEALTH SYSTEMS TO REPURCHASE STOCK
description: Foundation Health Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would repurchase 4.55 million of its shares from a not-for-profit entity for about $111.3 million, or $24.47 a share. The managed-health-care company would buy the class B, nonvoting stock from the California Wellness Foundation, a charitable entity created in 1992 to let the company convert its Health Net unit to for-profit status. Foundation Health shares rose 25 cents, to $32.75. California Wellness owns about 19.6 million class B Foundation Health shares, the company said. Foundation Health Systems, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., was formed in April through the $1.34 billion merger of the Foundation Health Corporation and Health Systems International Inc.

title: Westchester's Drug Treatment Woes
description: Westchester County has been spending some $10 million a year in Medicaid money for short-term treatment of a few hundred drug addicts and alcoholics on public assistance who have been using hospitals as temporary detoxification centers. The cost is exorbitant and the treatment often fails to stick. After returning home, many patients resume drinking or taking drugs, only to check into a different hospital for another temporary bout of relief. The county, adjacent to New York City, has now devised a sensible program to divert such people into long-term treatment with the hope of curing their addiction while reducing costs. A successful experiment could reap benefits statewide.

title: Why Must Concertgoers Pay, Pay, Pay?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kenneth Moser, 68, Developer Of Method to Remove Lung Clots
description: Dr. Kenneth Miles Moser, a lung specialist who devised an intricate procedure for the surgical removal of rare but deadly blood clots from the arteries of the lung, died on Monday at his home in San Diego. He was 68.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Ball Makers Pitch to the Heavy Hitter in Every Hacker
description: Tony M. Pisacano, an eye surgeon, looked up from the small constellation of golf balls that gleamed at him like vexing patients from a practice putting green at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Gooden Pitches His Way Into Starting Forefront
description: Before Dwight Gooden dug his cleats into the mound, before he reached for the resin bag and before he uncorked his first official pitch tonight, he had been given an important comfort zone. The Yankees ripped Charles Nagy for three runs in the top of the first inning, and now to Gooden the Indians looked less daunting and Jacobs Field, which is rarely threatening to New York, looked even less imposing.

title: INSIDE
description: And Russia Makes Eight

title: Lawmakers Ask White House To Revisit Gulf War Illnesses
description: Eighty-six members of the House today urged a special White House panel of experts to reverse itself and conclude that Iraqi chemical weapons were responsible for some of the health problems reported by veterans of the 1991 Persian Gulf war.

title: The Deal: 'Punishment for Their Past Misconduct'
description: Following are excerpts from the news conference held yesterday in Washington by state attorneys general and others to announce a $368.5 billion settlement between anti-smoking forces and tobacco companies, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company in Washington. The excerpts are followed by a statement from President Clinton.

title: Backups Can't Cover for a Substation
description: The electric grid, a vast, interconnected web of power plants, transmission lines and distribution equipment that covers half the continent, is highly reliable, in part because it is highly redundant. Usually it can shrug off the loss of a generating station or a power line without a flicker.

title: Assisted Suicide Can Mask Incompetent Care
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Immigrants Settle For $740,000 in Beating
description: Two illegal immigrants whose beating by Riverside County Sheriff's deputies was videotaped by television news crews have settled a lawsuit against the county for $740,000.

title: Industry Still Has Many Weapons Available
description: The sweeping changes that the nation's tobacco companies have agreed in principle to make in how they sell cigarettes -- from eliminating the Marlboro Man in advertisements to banning bearing brand logos and limiting signs in stores -- will make a significant difference in consumer behavior, a range of experts predicted yesterday.

title: Forgotten Signature Eliminates Azinger
description: Paul Azinger had shot 69 for a two-round total of 136, only four strokes behind the leader, Ernie Els, in the Buick Classic, but now he had the look of a man in shock, the look of a golfer who had been disqualified because he forgot to sign his scorecard.

title: School Helps Students Break Language Barrier
description: Forty students from 20 countries, who two years ago did not even know enough English to be able to spell the names of their new neighborhoods in New York, graduated yesterday from a school that taught them that and much more.

title: Silver Charm Will Run In Haskell at Monmouth
description: Silver Charm, who came within one length of winning the Triple Crown, was booked yesterday into the $1 million Haskell Invitational at Monmouth Park in New Jersey on Aug. 3, possibly delaying his return match against Touch Gold and Free House until the Travers Stakes at Saratoga three weeks later.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Fire Disrupts Newark Airport and Turnpike Traffic
description: Two oil-filled, boxcar-sized transformers that funnel electricity to Newark International Airport and thousands of homes in and around Elizabeth exploded and burned this morning, knocking out power for about five hours, disrupting all of the airport's morning flights and snarling rush-hour traffic.

title: A Brazilian Feast Welcomes Summer
description: ''My song is hemispheric/I am the voice of America'' sang Lenine of the duo Lenine e Suzano, as the five-day Brazilian Music Festival opened on Wednesday night at Central Park Summerstage. It was a sweeping claim, yet if made on behalf of Brazilian music rather than any single performer, it has its merits.

title: Assisted Suicide Can Mask Incompetent Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Unemployment Inches Up
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate rose to 5.3 percent in May, from 5.2 percent, the first increase this year, but State Labor Department officials said the change was statistically insignificant. Because the rate has been below 5.5 percent for the last three months, the economy is still considered very strong, said James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. The nation's jobless rate for May was 4.8 percent.

title: Budget Deficit Narrowed in May
description: The budget deficit narrowed in May from a year earlier, keeping the annual shortfall between revenues and expenses on track to fall to the lowest level in almost two decades.

title: Proposed Deal Doesn't Mean Court Cases Would End
description: Yesterday's tobacco settlement will not shield the industry from all current and future legal threats. But if approved by Congress, it is expected to provide the industry considerable relief from the mounting expense of defending itself in court.

title: Law to Put More Limits On Gifts To Officials
description: The House passed a bill today that would prohibit legislators and other public officials from accepting virtually all gifts from lobbyists, turning Connecticut in the direction of a growing number of states that are tightening such laws.

title: In Rebuff to Turkish Islamists, Secularist Gets a Call to Lead
description: In an effort to push Turkey back toward fully secular rule, President Suleyman Demirel today asked Mesut Yilmaz, a center-rightist with strong secular credentials, to try to form the next government.

title: Family of Pakistani In Killings at C.I.A. Also Seeks a Motive
description: Inside a high-walled compound here, the family of Mir Amal Kansi gathered today to grapple with events that saw American agents swoop into Pakistan this week to seize Mr. Kansi for a 1993 shooting rampage near the Central Intelligence Agency's headquarters at Langley, Va.

title: Critics Say Airport Plan Risks an Expanse of Land
description: As part of his plan to turn the state-owned Stewart International Airport into a private, profitable venture, Gov. George E. Pataki has put up for sale a 7,400-acre expanse of woods, fields and wetlands west of the airport that is dear to hunters, bird-watchers and environmental groups.

title: Stop Bullying Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Shadow of Britten, A Showcase for the New
description: England's Aldeburgh Festival does what ancient Greeks thought festivals ought to do: transport audiences from big places to small ones, replacing urban noise with country quiet, then submerging the ear and eye in nearly continuous performance.

title: Strawberry Agrees To Surgery on Knee: YANKEES NOTEBOOK
description: Darryl Strawberry's agonizing and annoying season essentially ended today when he agreed to undergo exploratory arthroscopic surgery on his injured left knee next week. Manager Joe Torre said the surgery is expected to sideline Strawberry for the rest of the season.

title: Failures of Leadership on Land Mines
description: Never before has the momentum to ban all land mines been so strong, both in the United States and internationally. Yet President Clinton and Vice President Gore, both of whom claim to favor an early ban, have become the main obstacles to American leadership on this issue. Despite ample political cover, they meekly yield to the wrongheaded opposition of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Compromise Included In Senate Panel's Tax Bill
description: When the chief Republican tax writer, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, pushed a tax-cutting bill through the House Ways and Means Committee earlier this month, he did it without a single Democratic vote.

title: Failed Conference Center
description: To the Editor:

title: 30-Year Bond's Yield Drops To 6.66 Percent
description: In the absence of fresh economic news, Government securities traded higher yesterday as investors remained confident that the Federal Reserve would maintain a steady policy and refrain from raising interest rates next month.

title: Dream World Growing Ever Smaller
description: Bill Frisell, the most significant and widely imitated guitarist to emerge in jazz since the beginning of the 1980's, builds a smaller, tighter dream world with each new project. Once he was drawn to vaulting, heavily electrified sounds, with notes rounded into massive bubbles by an application of the volume pedal. But lately he has been making music rich with old-time references and shrunk to tiny proportions, like a back-country funeral band heard through a mouse hole.

title: New Talks on East Timor Problem Open
description: Indonesia and Portugal announced here today that they are opening a new round of talks aimed at finding a solution to the problem of East Timor. There is cautious hope among diplomats that the negotiations, organized by Secretary General Kofi Annan, may make more progress than past discussions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about the closing of beaches in Westchester County because of a sewage spill misidentified one shown. It was Hudson Park in New Rochelle, not the Glen Island Park beach in Pelham Manor.

title: Officer Is Charged Over Courses For Those Seeking Police Jobs
description: The lure of salaries of $70,000 after just a few years on the job guarantees a crush of applicants for Suffolk County's police exam every four years. The competition is stiff.

title: Reacting With Skepticism But Also With Some Hope
description: Joe Santiago only has to listen to his ailing mother to know the harmful effects of cigarettes. She tells him to look at her to see a bad role model. The 57-year-old woman has smoked since age 8 and was diagnosed with lung cancer four months ago.

title: Some Fear That Fine Print Will Limit F.D.A. Authority
description: When a Federal judge in North Carolina declared in April that the Food and Drug Administration could regulate nicotine as a drug, he gave the agency virtually unrestricted authority to alter the design of cigarettes radically, trimming the levels of nicotine to the point where smoking would no longer be addictive.

title: Voting Their Fears in Croatia
description: Her voice trembled. She sounded shattered. My friend, a journalist for Croatia's opposition weekly, The Feral Tribune, told me that a member of the secret police had visited her at home a few weeks ago. He wanted to know how often she traveled abroad, whom she met, what they discussed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Ward Just and his latest novel, ''Echo House,'' misspelled the given name of the chairwoman of The Washington Post Company, who said she could vouch for his skill. She is Katharine Graham, not Katherine.

title: Pol Pot Could Escape Judgment Through Legal Gap
description: If Pol Pot is indeed captured alive and his captors decide that an international tribunal should try him, they will soon discover a gap in the world's justice system.

title: Impact on Health: Hazy
description: The $368 billion pact reached yesterday by tobacco companies, health groups, state attorneys general and lawyers for sick smokers represents the most determined effort in the nation's history to reduce cigarette smoking, which ranks as the leading preventable cause of death in the United States and takes 400,000 lives a year.

title: Marvin Pope, 80, Professor and Authority on Ancient Ugarit
description: Marvin H. Pope, a retired Yale professor who was one of the world's leading authorities on Ugarit, the ancient city in Syria where excavations shed important light on the ancient Scriptures, died on Sunday at First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn. He was 80.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OGLEBAY NORTON INC., Cleveland, said it had bought two vessels from GATX Corp's GATX Capital Corp. unit, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Westchester Opens Last of 26 Beaches Sewage Leak Closed
description: Westchester County reopened the last of its 26 beaches early yesterday, two days after county health officials ordered all beaches closed because of a break in a sewage pipeline near City Island.

title: Germany's Free Democrats Watch Their Popularity Plunge
description: FRANKFURT  - With Germany groaning under the weight of record unemployment, staggering taxes to rebuild eastern Germany, waning industrial competitiveness and a welfare system it can no longer afford, the economic reform zealots in the nation's Free Democratic Party thought their moment had arrived.

title: Leader of Spain's Socialists Will Not Seek to Retain Post
description: Former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, who had a commanding role in leading a democratic Spain into full partnership in Western Europe in the 1980's but lost power in last year's election, stunned his Socialist Workers Party today by announcing that he would not seek re-election as its leader. Nevertheless, he left the door open to run as the party's candidate in the next general elections, due by 2000.

title: Camry Teaches Economics 101: Features Are Nice but Price Sells
description: Auto advertisers love to promote each new model as changing an industry, but only a few actually do so, like the 1986 Ford Taurus, which spawned a fleet of aerodynamic imitators.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 19 about legislation to separate men and women in basic training summarized the Army's experience with such training incompletely. Although the Army did not formally integrate men and women in boot camp until 1993, it conducted integrated training on a trial basis in the late 1970's and early 1980's. A woman who underwent combat training in 1978 reported the error to The Times this week, and an Army spokesman confirmed her account.

title: El Nino Is Back, Scientist Says, With Threat Of Global Havoc
description: The potent weather disrupter known as El Nino is returning, and Government scientists say it is shaping up as one of the strongest climatic events of its kind on record.

title: Jones Keeps It Casual and Wins His 12th Game
description: The news was on the clubhouse television. Bobby Jones was taking it all in as he sank back into a blue leather couch before the game. So laid back, so casual. He blended in with the furniture, just as unassuming as his last name.

title: Olbermann Poised to Join NBC
description: KEITH OLBERMANN, who is leaving ESPN's ''SportsCenter'' on June 29, is expected to join NBC News on Monday in a deal that would most likely place him with MSNBC, the cable network that is half-owned by NBC.

title: Killer in 'Megan' Case Is Sentenced to Death
description: Jesse K. Timmendequas, whose rape and murder of a 7-year-old neighbor girl provoked the passage of ''Megan's Laws'' to protect children from sex offenders, was sentenced to death today by a New Jersey jury.

title: Teen-Agers Indicted In Central Park Killing
description: The two teen-agers accused of killing and dismembering a man in Central Park were indicted for murder and robbery yesterday.

title: BELCO OIL GETS 14.9% STAKE IN HUGOTON ENERGY
description: The Belco Oil and Gas Corporation said yesterday that it had bought a 14.9 percent stake in the Hugoton Energy Corporation for about $31 million and was looking into a merger between the companies. Hugoton, of Wichita, Kan., and Belco, of New York, are both oil and natural gas producers. Belco said it had purchased 2.94 million shares of Hugoton for $10.50 a share from affiliates of the First Reserve Corporation. Belco also said it had signed a joint confidentiality agreement with Hugoton in which each company would exchange information with the other.

title: Jurgen H. Rahe, 57, Space Program Head
description: Dr. Jurgen H. Rahe, a senior manager at NASA, was killed on Wednesday when a tree fell onto his car while he was driving home in a heavy thunderstorm in Potomac, Md. He was 57 and lived in Potomac.

title: Pilot Also Blamed for Air Force Crash That Killed 23 G.I.'s
description: The Air Force reversed itself today and found that the pilot of an F-16 jet fighter shared the blame for a 1994 midair collision that killed 23 soldiers and injured more than 100 others in one of the military's worst peacetime accidents.

title: French Report Shows A Stronger Economy
description: French manufacturing output rose a higher-than-expected 1.1 percent in April, the third monthly gain, indicating an acceleration of economic growth, The Government said yesterday.

title: Companies' Cost Would Be Great, But So Is Their Outlook for Profit
description: In reaching an agreement that would cost them billions of dollars a year and poses the potential to chase away customers, cigarette companies calculated that they would still be left with sufficiently lucrative business that would not continue to be haunted by lawsuits that have depressed their stock prices, consumed ever more of their resources and given their industry an image as America's corporate rogue.

title: Enterprise Director Is Named
description: A man whom state officials are counting on to jump-start Camden's sluggish empowerment zone program began work yesterday. Bryan K. Finnie, the director of community and small business lending for the state Economic Development Authority, was appointed earlier this week as interim managing director of the program, which is designed to spur economic development in the impoverished city.

title: CIGARETTE MAKERS IN A $368 BILLION ACCORD TO CURB LAWSUITS AND CURTAIL MARKETING
description: Tobacco negotiators announced a historic settlement proposal today that, if ratified, promises to change forever the way cigarettes are marketed in the United States, to provide billions of dollars in compensation to states and to permanently alter the nation's legal, regulatory and public health landscape.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: DRUG ARRESTS IN PARK -- New York City detectives and Federal agents joined forces in arresting dozens of suspected drug dealers in Washington Square Park. Page 25.

title: Casino Boat Stirs Up North Fork Traffic, and Residents
description: Lined by Victorian barns, picket fences, scarecrows and potato fields, the 15-mile stretch of Route 25 between Greenport and Orient Point is still a century, or at least a state of mind, away from the jams of the Long Island Expressway.

title: Internet Laws Overturned In Two States
description: In separate but related cases that could shape the future of the Internet, Federal judges in Manhattan and Atlanta ruled yesterday that the States of New York and Georgia could not enforce new laws intended to protect children from computer-network pedophiles and to bar anonymous communications in cyberspace.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Historic Pact Proposed With Tobacco Industry

title: When the Engine Dies
description: There came a time when all the money had been made. Many committed suicide. The notes they left were all much alike.

title: Where Imaginations Run Wild
description: There are no swings, slides, seesaws or any of the other pieces of equipment that combine to make most playgrounds. Instead, there are masks for children to hide behind, a dragon gushing water, a child-size stage, angled, multilevel, cleverly painted platforms to run along and, most compelling, a bronze sculpture of a child reading a book while reaching down to pet his dog.

title: Former Stockbroker Admits To Illegal Trading Scheme
description: A former stockbroker pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges of masterminding an illegal trading conspiracy that cost eight of Wall Street's largest brokerage houses more than $13.4 million in losses during the summer of 1994.

title: Subpoena Power Granted as Democrats Cry 'Witch Hunt'
description: The House today gave its chief investigator of campaign-finance abuses the power to summon witnesses and take sworn testimony, despite objections from Democrats that the inquiry was ''a political witch hunt.''

title: Japan Insurance Society Helps Insurer Bailout
description: The Japanese Life Insurance Association said yesterday that it planned to contribute 200 billion yen ($1.8 billion) to bail out the Nissan Mutual Life Insurance Company, Japan's first life insurance company to fail in the postwar period. It collapsed in April with about 300 billion yen in debt.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6

title: Religious Left Draws Strength From Grass Roots
description: Why is it that the religious right seems much more prominent -- equipped as it is with television programming and political action organizations -- than liberals within various faith groups?

title: Another Scoreless Show As Irabu Climbs a Notch
description: Moving closer to Yankee Stadium, both figuratively and literally, Hideki Irabu continued his minor league warm-up tonight with another impressive performance, this one for the Yankees' Class AA Norwich Navigators.

title: WHEELABRATOR'S PARENT SEEKS REST OF SHARES
description: Wheelabrator Technologies Inc. confirmed yesterday that its parent company, Waste Management Inc., had offered to acquire the 33 percent of Wheelabrator that it does not already own for $15 a share, or about $780 million. Wheelabrator said it expected its board to appoint a special committee of independent directors to which the proposal would be referred. Wheelabrator, based in Hampton, N.H., provides municipalities and industry with water treatment and trash-energy projects. Waste Management, of Oak Brook, Ill., offers waste collection and disposal services. Waste Management shares fell $1.125, to $32.625, while Wheelabrator closed at $15.75, up $2.75.

title: Sentencing in Robbery
description: A Franklin Township dentist was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in prison for his part in a botched jewelry store robbery that resulted in the death of a co-owner of the shop. Harry Insabella, who did not take part directly in the robbery, pleaded guilty in April to conspiracy, receiving stolen property and perjury, after the authorities agreed to drop felony murder charges against him, an assistant Somerset County prosecutor said.

title: Icahn-Led Bondholders Take Control of Marvel From Perelman
description: Bondholders led by Carl C. Icahn took control of Marvel Entertainment Inc. yesterday, seven months after they erupted in anger over a proposal that would have frozen them out while leaving control with Ronald O. Perelman, the financier who had overseen the comic book and trading card company while it first prospered and then fell into bankruptcy.

title: Girl, Caught in Tide, Missing From Rockaway
description: A 14-year-old girl who had been swimming with friends at Rockaway Beach was pulled out into the ocean by a strong tide yesterday and was lost, the police said.

title: Head of Foxwoods Casino Quits Suddenly
description: G. Michael Brown, chief executive of the Foxwoods Resort Casino, a gambling mecca in eastern Connecticut that claims to be the world's most profitable casino, abruptly resigned today, two months after the chief of the Indian tribe that owns the casino called him ''the finest chief executive officer in the gaming business.''

title: Antiseptic Renovation
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Two star-studded teams clashed here today in the final of the Women's International Team Trials, which will determine two teams to represent the United States in the World Championships in Tunisia in October.

title: Try a Medical Museum

title: NICHE TALK

''Idiom Savant'' is one of four new books that suggest the latter -- it says barbers feel dejected when confronted with a ''cul-de-sac'' (mostly bald head). *''Buzzwords: L.A. Fresh Speak'' catalogues slang from ''kili cali'' (Southern California), where ''wammies'' (aspiring actresses) long to live in ''the Boo'' (Malibu). *According to the forthcoming ''How to Talk American,'' crack is called ''Scotty'' -- as in, ''Beam me up.'' *''Jargon Watch'' focuses on ''mouse potatoes'' (computer addicts) who spend too much time with their ''square-headed girlfriends'' (computers). *One question: Does anybody ever really talk this way? There's room for doubt. Gareth Branwyn, author of ''Jargon Watch,'' says his work is ''more about entertainment and humor than rigor and lexicographical correctness.''

title: City Sues S.R.O. Landlord, Citing 'Dingy, Airless Cubicles'
description: In 1984, Jay Podolsky was indicted on charges accusing him of trying to force tenants from a single-room-occupancy building on West 77th Street. Prosecutors said Mr. Podolsky, his father, Zenek, and a brother, Stuart, were responsible for a ''routine of terror'' that included installing as tenants drug addicts, prostitutes and thieves to assault and rob other tenants and harass them into leaving so they could sell the building, in one of the city's hottest residential neighborhoods. Jay Podolsky pleaded guilty to grand larceny, coercion and conspiracy, among other charges, and was sentenced to five years' probation. He was forced to give the building to the city, but he remained a landlord.

title: Brilliance And Bardot, All in One
description: THIRTY-FOUR YEARS AFTER ITS PREMIERE, one of the masterworks of modern cinema, Jean-Luc Godard's ''Contempt,'' is back in town. Long unavailable, it has been ravishingly restored and, starting on Friday, will play at both Film Forum and the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. The film has inspired passionate praise: the Sight and Sound critic Colin McCabe called ''Contempt'' ''the greatest work of art produced in postwar Europe.'' And it has influenced a generation of filmmakers, including Rainer Werner Fassbinder and Quentin Tarantino in addition to Martin Scorsese, who sponsored this rerelease, calling it ''brilliant, romantic and genuinely tragic.''

title: County to Put Into Use Hazardous Waste Law
description: THE average person relies on a variety of products to speed tasks like cleaning ovens, getting rid of pesky insects, growing lawns and waxing cars. But what many consumers might not realize is that such commonly used products often contain chemicals harmful to their health and the environment.

title: Hong Kong Escape Network Is Driven Into Shadows

It is a tiny crescent of sand peeping just above the sea, two beaches with almost nothing in between, looking as if any large wave could wash away Bikini for good.

title: The Fat-Free Family
description: Summer has come again to the Hamptons, and I wonder, as I wander the tree-lined lanes clogged with the tight-faced and socially prominent, what has become of the Fat-Free Family. I'll never forget them. In the cold, cruel gulag that is Long Island's East End, they were a vision of friendliness, the only strangers, in fact, ever to have acknowledged my existence there. They appeared to me last June, as if from nowhere, in the Sag Harbor ice-cream parlor. It was closing time, and I was contemplating my options when the daughter turned her gaze upon me.

After all, he had set a limit of 55 on how old a woman could be to receive an egg from a younger woman to become pregnant. It was a limit based, as most such limits are, not so much on medical concerns as on what the doctor considered to be appropriate.

They're nervous, making their way up flights of wooden steps to the top of a swaying tower where they crouch in line, double a rope around their waists, heave themselves out at a 90-degree angle and bounce 50 feet down the tower's sheer wooden face. The process, familiar to rock climbers, is called rappelling. It's an unnatural act.

The cast and crew, working on the final episodes of the season, had serious concerns about whether their ensemble series, about the quirky workaday lives of the staff of a struggling radio station, would survive past the season's end. Then Paul Simms talked to Rolling Stone magazine.

They lost their horses and supplies, and were outwitted by the local Indian tribes. The place brought them nothing but misfortune.

title: Weighty Matters
description: When is a paperweight not just a paperweight? When it's made by Paul J. Stankard, a studio-glass artist in Mantua, Gloucester County. Mr. Stankard creates botanical works of art by making lifelike flowers and roots, insects and ''root people'' -- tiny humanoid figures that look delicate enough to be the stamens of flowers themselves -- from spun filaments and suspending them in molten crystal, which cools to clear perfection. Mr. Stankard's paperweights usually sell for $2,000 to $10,000, but you can buy nearly 200 of them for $39.95 in ''Paul J. Stankard: Homage to Nature'' (Harry N. Abrams), with text by Ulysses Grant Dietz and photographs by John Bigelow Taylor. Mr. Dietz is curator of decorative arts at the Newark Museum and has bought three Stankard paperweights for the museum's collection.

description: On the day that Abe Hirschfeld, the eccentric New York millionaire, was set to announce his candidacy for the office of Manhattan borough president, he was handcuffed by authorities who indicted him on 123 counts of tax fraud. Hirsch-feld, a 78-year-old Republican who made a fortune developing inexpensive open-air parking garages (''Cars don't catch cold,'' he likes to say), shrugs that off as a minor setback. Flanked by white-shirted lieutenants and clutching his trademark cigar, he dismisses his legal woes as the work of jealous political enemies.
