title: What You See Is What You See
description: ''In a small town like ours,'' says the high school biology teacher who narrates THE CHURCH OF DEAD GIRLS (Metropolitan Books, $23), Stephen Dobyns's novel about a series of child abductions in a quiet college town in upstate New York, ''something that has happened and something that has not happened but is gossiped about are equivalent.'' In Aurelius, 40 miles from Utica, population 7,000, three young girls have disappeared. The grief and suffering of their families is made real enough, but Dobyns's unnamed narrator focuses his story on the town's increasing anger and suspicion. In this climate of fear, a number of local people find their secrets bared, their smallest differences marking them out for accusations and retaliation. ''The Church of Dead Girls'' is named for its grim opening and closing scenes, depicting the discovery in an attic of the three dead girls in three straight chairs, each missing her left hand. This is a scene born from the demonology of genre fiction, but Dobyns's complex parable of social disintegration (''I see fragility where I had imagined resilience, the fleeting where I'd seen permanence'') fits more into the naturalist mode -- as if Theodore Dreiser had written ''The Lodger'' or a closet serial killer had turned up in Thornton Wilder's Grover's Corners. Dobyns's sad and disquieting novel carries a contemporary moral, true in even the smallest American towns: ''Just as we are only aware of the surface parts of one another's minds, so are we only aware of the surface parts of one another's behavior.'' David Walton

title: Shakespeare for the Season: An Aptly Timed Romantic Comedy
description: FEARS about the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's season of transition and transiency have now been quashed. While its old theater is reconstructed on the festival's home site in Madison (first show: this time next year), ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' has opened at the less-than-ideal Community Theater of Morristown, one of three performance spaces the festival is renting this summer. But anyplace theater artists hang their lights is home, and Bonnie J. Monte's enchanting production of Shakespeare's comedy about love and marriage among mortals and other fools is the very model of making magic while making do.

title: The Looks of Rock
description: Pop-music stardom in Britain changed in the mid-1960's. As chronicled in THE END OF INNOCENCE. Photographs From the Decades That Defined Pop: The 1950s to the 1970s (Scalo, $39.95), groups in the early days obligingly did whatever their recording studios told them to; for example, the Beatles are shown cavorting like children in a chorus line on the steps of Abbey Road Studios in 1963, and the Supremes are depicted perching on a rail with furled umbrellas for a foggy London theme. This was assembly-line production, when almost every group from the Hollies to Freddie and the Dreamers seemed to consist of four or five neat lads in skinny ties and dark suits. David Bowie was one of the first performers to break the mold, appearing in street clothes and sneering at the camera. The look caught on; as the book's editor, Liz Jobey, an editor at Scalo, points out, later photos resemble self-portraiture more than they depict the studio's point of view. By 1969 nobody is smiling, and motley groups from Pink Floyd to Deep Purple and Steppenwolf seem to be merely tolerating the camera, rather than performing for it. The reproductions of album covers at the end show a similar shift, from Hollywood-style head shots to covers that didn't even picture the group. The photos are handsomely printed on heavy stock, but leave the reader longing for a bit more text, if only liner notes. Eric Nash

title: In One Somali Town, Clan Rule Has Brought Peace
description: Like many people in this town on the northeastern Somali coast, Halima Farah Jibril knows what it means to lose everything and start all over in a barren place with no friends.

title: First New Works, Then the Brahms
description: THE Norfolk Chamber Music Festival ushers in its summer season this week, but it will be another two weeks before the sounds of Schubert, Mozart and Brahms echo through the Music Shed. This week and next, performers of contemporary music are at hand.

title: Politics in Israel
description: You think Yasir Arafat and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu don't trust each other? You think Ehud Barak, the opposition Labor Party's new top man, and ''Bibi'' don't trust each other?

title: On Intimations Of Mortality
description: John Salustri's concerns about his vulnerability $(''He's Gone at 38. What About Me,'' June 15$) could be somewhat relieved if he remembered Edna St. Vincent Millay's poem:

title: 65 Summers in the Berkshires
description: THE STORY OF THE JACOB'S Pillow Dance Festival, which celebrates its 65th anniversary this year, began famously with the purchase in 1931 of a rambling farm in Becket, Mass., in the rural Berkshires. The buyer was Ted Shawn, the patriarch of American modern dance, who immediately set about building dance studios and cabins for his Men Dancers company and the school they were to run. Fifty-seven people showed up for the first performance, held in 1933 in the garden. Shawn had expected 25. ''If this attendance keeps up,'' he wrote to a friend, ''it will contribute considerably to the grocery bill.''

title: Alison Landsberg, Matthew Karush
description: Prof. Alison Landsberg, the daughter of Jill Warren Landsberg and Dr. Lewis Landsberg of Chicago, is to be married today to Prof. Matthew B. Karush, the son of Dr. Ruth K. Karush and Dr. Nathaniel P. Karush of New York. Rabbi Steven S. Lowenstein is to perform the ceremony at the Three Arts Club in Chicago.

title: Rogers Is Relegated to a Long Relief Role
description: Kenny Rogers sat in the bullpen talking with the pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, after the Yankees finished their pre-game warm-ups today. It was an appropriate place for them to chat because it is Rogers's new home.

title: Managed Care Is Manageable for This Drugstore Chain
description: MANAGED care is old hat to Arbor Drugs, a Midwest drugstore chain, and that fact may be one of its attractions.

title: Leslie Kahn, Cameron Logan
description: Leslie Meredith Kahn, a daughter of Greta E. Kahn and Dr. Frederick H. Kahn of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Cameron Fay Logan, the son of Helen M. Logan and Fay W. Logan, also of Tenafly. Rabbi Nathaniel Benjamin performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: Mortgage Recording Taxes
description: IT'S frustrating paying income tax on money you earn. It's even worse paying sales tax on money you spend. But what could be worse than paying a mortgage tax on money you borrow?

title: Lori Storch and Rodger Smith Jr.
description: Dr. Lori Michele Storch, a pediatric resident, and Rodger Field Smith Jr., a lawyer, were married last evening at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Jeannette Bassinger-Ishii, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony, in which Rabbi Edward Schlaeger took part.

title: Putting A Mixer In A Museum And Asking, What Is Art?
description: WHEN A BROODING black-on-black painting of an electric chair by Andy Warhol shares space with a framed pair of Levis, does the juxtaposition reveal the jeans' subliminal cultural agenda or reduce the Warhol to just another consumer product?

title: Dishes Made Exotic With Asian Touches
description: THE anticipation is over. The trendsetter of the season has opened. Pacific East, a sibling of Pacific Time, an award-winning restaurant in Miami,has the makings of an instant hot spot: stunning good looks, creative pan-Asian cuisine and a prestigious pedigree. Inside Pacific East, on Montauk Highway in Amagansett, the look is spare and airy: pale-wood floors, slowly turning fans, green plants, Balinese carvings and a dramatic, balconied, two-storied space softened by billowy, diaphanous draperies.

title: On the Coast, a Cabin With a View
description: WHEN I asked friends if they knew a quiet, unspoiled spot on the Oregon coast, several recommended Yachats (population 635, according to the sign), where the air is soft and the sound of surf never far away.

title: Margaritaville It's Not
description: MEXICALI Blues Cafe is just odd enough to pique your interest. It offers milk with meat in a neighborhood of kosher restaurants, and jazz in a former Pathmark. The crowd is old enough to appreciate the Grateful Dead memorabilia on the walls, and settled enough to eat in the presence of only a book or a laptop. The restaurant, named for one of the band's lesser known songs, is a Southwestern-style gathering place for grown-ups.

title: The Joy of Theft
description: THE BACON FANCIER

title: Getting Student (and Faculty) Wallflowers Out on the Floor
description: IT is the time of year when high school students dress up like Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, then can't waltz or fox trot once they get to the prom.

title: Big-Town America
description: To the Editor:

title: Waaay Out
description: Courtney Brown, a political scientist at Emory University in Atlanta, has been denounced as a scam artist, ''definitely deluded'' and a virtual accomplice to suicide. The last barb came about because Brown helped spread the idea that the Hale-Bopp comet was accompanied by a mysterious spaceship, a notion that may have inspired 39 members of the Heaven's Gate group to kill themselves in March. Brown became convinced of this thanks to the controversial practice of ''remote viewing'' -- mental imaging practiced at great distances, which the Federal Government once researched in a defunct program called Stargate. Brown was told by his own team of remote viewers that a ship lurked behind the comet, and he spread this news on the airwaves and the Internet.

title: Imagining The Future Of Downtown
description: IN the early 1980's, the people of this Union County township became concerned about a rising vacancy rate in stores and other signs of deterioration and began plans to make their downtown more attractive, and robust.

title: Patient's Quest for Normal Life, at a Price
description: In time, it would come to be known as ''the famous dinner.'' But on that Saturday of Labor Day weekend in 1994, it was just Fredda Rosen and two friends getting together at the Boathouse restaurant in Central Park to compare lives and bat around issues in the social-services field.

title: Jody Goldberg And Ed Seibert
description: Jody Beth Goldberg, a daughter of Veronica and Arthur Goldberg of New Vernon, N.J., and Henry Edward Seibert, a son of Dorothy and Henry Edward Seibert 4th of Solon, Ohio, were married last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Margo Manhattan and Edi Arjang
description: Margo Manhattan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Gewirtz of New York, is to be married today at her parents' house in Southampton, N.Y., to Edi Arjang, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Arjang of Teheran, Iran. Rabbi Yidel Stein is to officiate.

title: Susan Antilla, Dennis Leibowitz
description: Susan Antilla, a financial columnist for Bloomberg News and Bloomberg Television in New York, was married yesterday to Dennis H. Leibowitz, a senior vice president and securities analyst for the broadcasting, cable television and wireless industries at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the New York investment bank. Sydney Greenberg, a justice of the peace, officiated at the couple's house in New Canaan, Conn.

title: In Piles of Human Ashes, a Grim Fraud
description: A little more than two weeks ago, sheriff's deputies were called to this small Northern California town to investigate a seemingly mundane complaint. The wall of a storage shed was collapsing, and the manager of the storage company was concerned by what appeared to be small puffs of ash billowing out of the unit.

title: Life or Death? Stay Tuned
description: ''NEWS RADIO'' ISN'T THE ONLY

title: Devils Take a Goalie With Their Top Pick
description: Already employing one of the National Hockey League's best goalies, the Devils today used their first-round draft pick to choose another player for the same position. Choosing 24th in the draft, they selected Jean-Francois Damphousse of the Moncton Wildcats of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League.

title: Francophile Sniffs, Sips And Assays L.I. Wines
description: IN self-conscious wine circles, clasping a long-stemmed glass by the base -- thumb on top, index finger on the bottom -- is common. To the everyday eye, the grip seems pretentious. But when Peter Mayle of Amagansett canted his chardonnay that way while visiting four East End wineries, it seemed natural, even artistic.

title: Gabrielle Galanter, Luis Camara Silva
description: Gabrielle Galanter, a daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Eugene H. Galanter of New York, was married yesterday at her family's farm in Herrick Township, Pa., to Luis Gerardo Camara Silva, the son of Dr. Maria Teresa Silva de Camara and Dr. Luis Felipe Camara of Queretaro, Mexico. The Rev. Dorsey McConnell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: A Noble Attempt, But Few Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: As Drugs for Depression Multiply, So Do the Hard Questions
description: CHERYL F. is a 37-year-old therapist in Rhode Island who has spent the last few years struggling to tame her own emotional dybbuks. In the early 1990's, she received a diagnosis of dysthymia, a chronic, low-grade depression that lingers for two years or longer. Unlike full-blown clinical depression, which can knock you into an agonized state of catatonia, dysthymia (pronounced dis-THIGH-mee-a) steals life in day-size pieces.

title: Creating On-Line Guide to Gay Activities
description: RICHARD LAERMER leaves Manhattan at a dead run, the pace at which he has traditionally done everything. He hops into his customized green Jeep, replete with fog lights, compact disk player and de rigueur cell phone. He talks a mile a minute, interrupting himself to comment on the latest celebrity gaff or news bite on Fidel Castro. ''I get a lot done in my commute,'' he says, whizzing through the tunnel on his way home to Southampton. ''They even have car modems now.''

title: A Lesson for Residents: They're Not Like Men
description: MUCH has changed in medical training since the days when anatomy professors ordered students to discard the breasts from female cadavers.

title: How Much Did Della Femina Win in Suit?
description: IN the end, the only way East Hampton Village could shut Jerry Della Femina up was to give him a check -- and even that barely did the trick.

title: Some Like It Cold
description: The summer of cold soup was the summer our 7-year-old collie, Herschel, spent most of his days chewing up the carpet and fertilizing the furniture. He was not happy about Betty Lou's puppies, even if Betty Lou's puppies were his. (Betty Lou didn't seem too happy herself, and she and her brood permanently attached themselves to my left leg.) Our two cats were not exactly thrilled, either, and they spent their summer shredding every plant on the terrace. This, while my 5-year-old stepdaughter was obsessed with making life-size mermaids out of papier-mache (she did this at the kitchen table, every afternoon), and I was slogging through a midlife crisis.

title: Even for Talkies, They Worked Silently
description: FRANCES MARION WAS America's highest-paid screenwriter -- man or woman -- from 1916 through the mid-1930's. She wrote 200 films, covering every genre, and won two Academy Awards. Irving Thalberg of MGM said he ''adored her and trusted her completely.'' Her fellow writer Adela Rogers St. Johns called her ''the senior all of us sophomores wanted to be.'' Yet over the years Marion and her once powerful female colleagues have been lost in the footnotes of Hollywood history. Now the Museum of Modern Art is trying to set the record straight by honoring them with a retrospective of their films.

title: Patricia Arledge, Robert Loonie Jr.
description: Patricia Lu Arledge, a producer in New York for ''Dateline NBC'' and a daughter of Roone Arledge, was married yesterday to Robert John Loonie Jr., a senior Treasury bond options broker for the GFI Group in New York. The Rev. Sue K. Arledge, a Presbyterian minister who is the bride's aunt, performed the ecumenical ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: In the Gender Game, New Rules to Play By
description: ''I grew up in the weight room trying to prove my manhood,'' said Don Sabo, who was the defensive captain in 1968 when SUNY-Buffalo's football team was in Division I. ''Build my biceps, lose my neck, bench-press a ridiculous amount of weight. It was about ego and domination, not about health. One of many things I like about Title IX is that the old weight room is usually called a fitness center now.''

title: Breaking Out Of the Box
description: Until I read David Gelernter's article ''Breaking Out of the Box'' (June 1), I thought my computer-space problems were a result of my own disorganization. I hope all those computer designers take note.

title: Dressed for Diagnosis
description: It may be a stereotype about stereotypes, but there is widespread belief that doctors tend to discount the health complaints of women whom they regard as hysterical.

title: U.S. Persuades Nations to Join Plan for Tighter Iraq Sanctions
description: The United States, France and Russia have reached agreement to toughen sanctions against Iraq unless United Nations inspectors can certify that Baghdad is fully cooperating in efforts to destroy its weapons of mass destruction, officials meeting here said today.

title: Mormons Step Into the Past in Footsteps of Their Ancestors
description: One summer day in 1847, P. G. Sessions, a Yankee farmer following the Mormon leader Brigham Young to Utah, inscribed his name on Independence Rock, a gray dome rising from the Wyoming prairie.

title: Elaine Ryan Hedges, 69, Author
description: Elaine Ryan Hedges, an author, educator and expert on the contributions of American women to literature and the arts, died on June 5 at Sinai Hospital in Baltimore. She was 69 and lived in Roland Park in suburban Baltimore.

title: New Buyers, and a New Wave of Stately Makeovers
description: IN 1921, The New York Times said the gay colors and picturesque stucco rowhouse alterations made 64th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues a ''fairy-book street,'' an informal counterpoint to the buttoned-up limestone mansions off Fifth Avenue.

title: Patients View H.M.O.'s With Hope and Suspicion
description: WHICH is your picture of managed care for women: free annual mammograms or ''drive through'' mastectomies?

title: Garynn Rodner, Kenneth Cutroneo
description: Garynn Stacey Rodner, a daughter of Janice and Jeffrey Rodner of Bedford, N.Y., and Kenneth Robert Cutroneo, a son of Dr. Kenneth R. Cutroneo of Burlington, Vt., and the late Carol F. Cutroneo, are to be married this evening in New York. Rabbi David E. Greenberg is to perform the ceremony in the Pegasus Suite of the Rainbow Room.

title: Makeshift Defense Makes Game-Saving Play
description: The names in the lineup change, the positions change, and the Mets win. Somebody gets hurt, somebody named Jason Hardtke steps in, and the Mets win. Manager Bobby Valentine juggles the healthy bodies on his team, and somehow they end up in the right place at the right time, doing the right thing.

title: London, From the Outskirts In
description: EARLY one morning in May, I saw a red fox in Holland Park in London. It scurried across the lawn in the Kyoto Garden before vanishing into a rhododendron bush. Amazed, I sank down onto a bench, wondering whether the Mad Hatter would turn up next.

title: Leftist Poses A Challenge To Top Party In Mexico
description: Two weeks before Mexico City's first mayoral election in 70 years, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, a leftist candidate, is so far ahead that he is acting -- and being treated -- not just like the mayor-elect but like a potential president.

title: Defining Fast Food: Between 55 Seconds and 30 Minutes
description: AMERICANS may be loath to admit that saving a few seconds makes a difference to them when they decide where to eat, but restaurateurs know better. Especially at the fast-food end of the business, shift managers of the low-paid, ever-changing work force are schooled to be nearly as attentive to quick service as pit crews at the Indy 500.

title: County General's E.R., Where Real-Life Stuff Goes Prime Time
description: A YOUNG woman from a local college visits an emergency room one morning. She is visibly upset and needs to speak to someone confidentially, someone she can trust.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Angel and Me Stories. By Sara Maitland. Morehouse, paper, $12.95.

title: Miranda Brooks, Edward Meyer 3d
description: Miranda Elizabeth Brooks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Brooks of Glen Head, N.Y., was married yesterday to Edward Bailey Meyer 3d, the son of Jean Thompson of Oyster Bay, N.Y., and the late Mr. Meyer Jr. The Rev. Paul E. Gilbert performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, N.Y.

title: After Glare of Victory, Galindo Is at Peace With Himself
description: Here he was, a Mexican-American skater who belied his sport's all-American image. A gay athlete who refused to play it straight. A skater who had been dumped by Kristi Yamaguchi as a pairs partner, who had lost a brother and two coaches to AIDS and a father to a heart attack, who had ridden a bike to practice because he could not afford a car.

title: David Brainerd and Wendy Burger
description: Wendy Ellen Burger, an architectural designer, and David Carter Brainerd, an investment banker, were married last evening at Christ Church in Warwick, Bermuda. The Rev. Henry A. Shepherd, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: So, You're Thinking of Becoming a Priest . . .
description: Bishop John M. Smith, who is about to take over as the leader of the Trenton Diocese, has said that recruiting new priests will be a priority and that the diocese ''will be very dynamic in its approach.'' Questions and answers about the priesthood can be found on the diocese's Internet site. The address is: http://www.priestlyvocations.org. What follows are excerpts from the site.

title: Talk to Me
description: Unplugging my answering machine was not an easy decision. When I first broached the idea, friends ominously warned against it, telling me, as one put it, that such a move would be ''isolating and regressive.'' Nevertheless, I had reason to proceed with the experiment.

title: DIARY
description: TOBACCO SETTLEMENT

title: 'Sexual Ecology'
description: To the Editor:

title: They Also Serve Who Only Queue
description: AFTER watching all those televised breakfasts at Wimbledon, imagine actually being there, in person, at the All England Lawn Tennis Championships, rubbing shoulders with Brooke Shields, breathing in freshly mowed lawns, nodding to the Duke and Duchess of Kent. We had moved to London and a day at Wimbledon seemed a reasonable fantasy -- until we tried to get tickets.

title: For a Real Page-Turner, Check Out the Joy of Soy
description: A DECADE ago, the health section of any good-size bookstore featured a shelf of titles for women on pregnancy, premenstrual syndrome and dieting. Today, that shelf is groaning with books on menopause, the mind-body duality -- and dieting.

title: Talking to the Next Governor
description: People said they would use a chat over dinner with Governor Whitman or James E. McGreevey to steer the campaign to issues affecting daily life.

title: A Comforting Thought
description: ''We don't worry much about breast cancer in women under 30,'' said Dr. Nancy Lee, a researcher at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Although young women report worrying more about breast cancer than other diseases that are more likely to kill, the incidence of breast cancer among women in their 20's is so minuscule that a man in his 60's is more likely to get a diagnosis of breast cancer than a woman under 30.

title: Classical Brief
description: JOHN THOW: 'SONGS FOR THE EARTH,' 'TRILCE,' 'REMEMBERING OPUS 109,' OTHER WORKS

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Complete Fiction

title: Lois Kaznicki and Timur Yontar
description: Lois Wanda Kaznicki and Timur Kaya Yontar were married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Colin Leitch, a Unitarian minister, officiated in the Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: The New Blood in Chinatown
description: ON the gray, chilly morning of June 3, before Chinatown even opened for business, the incense-filled room of the Hong Kong Funeral Home was already packed. An assortment of Chinatown movers and shakers and city officials had come to pay their last respects to Wu Quin-Rong, the 11-year-old girl who disappeared in mid-May on her way to school. Her body was found floating in the East River. The police said she had been strangled.

title: Fiber Artisanship Also Blooms on the Guilford Green
description: WHEN the flowers have finally burst into bloom, Guilford's village green and surrounding galleries are more welcoming than ever. And the cooperative known as Gallery 12, in a yellow Victorian house facing the green (between a bistro and the church rectory) has chosen this compelling season to show the works of 11 fiber artists, from large quilted wall hangings to woven rugs, from wearable art to paper sculptures to baskets.

title: In Dobbs Ferry, Art Displays Enhance Window Shopping
description: LOOK up and you might glimpse the Palisades here, or a beam of sunlight glancing off the Hudson River. Sudden, unexpected views have always rewarded strollers in this village, and a recent exhibition provided an even greater feast for the eye.

title: When Progress Means Back to Horse and Wagon
description: The idea of hauling trash with a team of horses came from an old issue of the magazine Draft Horse Journal. Patrick Palmer was intrigued. He and his wife, Cathy, had a pair of Percherons and they had the wagon. All they needed was a customer.

title: Alison McLean, C. F. Fitzmaurice
description: Alison Jeanne McLean, a daughter of Nancy Lennon McLean of Warwick, N.Y., and John D. McLean of Middletown, N.Y., was married on Friday to Christopher Francis Fitzmaurice, a son of Diana and Robert Fitzmaurice of Pittstown, N.J. The Rev. David I. Fulton performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: Shore Town's Bars Fight an Earlier Last Call
description: The resolution of a bitter four-month dispute over closing Wildwood's bars and nightclubs in summer at 3 A.M. instead of 5 has been put off -- for now.

title: From First Violin to Artistic Director
description: PETER OUNDJIAN felt the finale coming about 10 years ago. ''I had the sense that there was a strain going on in my fingers that was causing an abnormality in my finger reaction,'' said the former first violinist of the Tokyo String Quartet.

title: A Rare Jig Lures the Striper Other Anglers Only Dream About
description: During the first 15 minutes of casting from my brother Dan's boat, which was drifting on the incoming tide in the channel between Menemsha jetties and Menemsha Pond, he hooked, landed and released four striped bass while I went hitless, a victim of my own stubbornness.

title: After Graduation, Heading for the State Line
description: WHEN Connecticut's recent high school graduates pack their bags for college this summer and fall, more than 40 percent will be heading for schools -- and probably future jobs -- across the state's borders.

title: Correction
description: An article on June 8 about films based on theatrical works misstated the title of Thomas Rothman, a movie-company executive who played a part in the production of the movie ''The Crucible.'' He is president for film production at 20th Century Fox, not president of its division Fox Searchlight Pictures, which released ''The Crucible'' last year.

title: Where It's Always Time for Tea (And the Goodies That Go With It)
description: Angie Lockard is happy to brew my cup of tea. And yours.

title: Disconnections
description: THE LIFEGUARD

title: Zurich
description: Switzerland's biggest city is about to launch the first Zurich Festival, a 23-day celebration of the arts that it hopes will become an annual summer highlight in this metropolis of banking, technology and high-priced shopping.

title: One for Lady Macbeth
description: Here is a recipe for a spot on the best clothes: Take one trip, don one good shirt, enter a restaurant, take one sip. The makers of liquid Shout stain remover have developed a packaging for such travel emergencies. Towelettes moistened with Shout liquid, sealed in small packets, are now sold as Shout Wipes. The maker, SC Johnson Wax, says the price is $1.99 for a box of 12 packets. BETSY WADE

title: THE EAST SOLUTION TO THE SOCIAL SECURITY CRISIS
description: THE BUDGET RESolution passed last month by Congress is supposed to eliminate deficits by the year 2002. That's nice. But Congress ignored the proverbial 800-pound gorilla smoking a cigar in our living room. The beast has several aliases: ''Social Security Crisis,'' ''Entitlement Crisis'' and ''Third Rail of American Politics'' are the most common.

title: At Wimbledon, a Royal Flourish to Tennis
description: IN one sense, Wimbledon isn't that different from the United States Open at the National Tennis Center in Flushing, Queens. You can get to either tournament by subway. At the Southfield stop on the London underground, signs alert you to ''Alight Here for Wimbledon.'' But after you alight, it's much different.

title: June Peoples, Bill Lichtenstein
description: June Eileen Peoples and Bill Lichtenstein, documentary film producers in New York, were married last evening in Lenox, Mass. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated with the Rev. Puja Thomson, a minister of the Healing Light Center Church, at the Seven Hills Country Inn.

title: Fizzy Water Everywhere
description: I traveled to Germany last summer and discovered that when ordering bottled water in a restaurant, one is asked, ''mit Gas?'' I'm sure the staff had no idea why we were so amused.

title: 58 Years in a Cave, Who Wouldn't Need a Change of Clothes?
description: Bob Kane created the brooking, poker-faced moralist known as the Bat-man 58 years ago in Detective Comics No. 27, a copy of which, by the way, sold this month at Sotheby's for $68,500. But over the ensuing decades, as the times have changed, so has the Caped Crusader. His sartorial style today is far removed from yesteryear's avenger in gray tights and briefs-as-outerwear. In the latest reinvention - Joel Schumacher's campy costume party, ''Batman and Robin,'' released on Friday by Warner Brothers - the superhero is resplendent in a cybersuit of black and silver rubber. Below, some highlights on the bat continuum.

title: CONDOM KNOWLEDGE
description: ''Royal has a positive feeling. The wrapper is black with a gold crown -- it connotes quality,'' explains Dr. Deborah Cohen, who spearheaded the state of Louisiana's recent introduction of low-cost condoms as a public-health measure. Like anyone moving a product, state officials commissioned marketing research to produce an appealing package; royal imagery won out, says Cohen, because Louisianans just seem to like royalty. And the also-rans? ''Well, there was Yellowjacket,'' says Jamey Crump, whose firm, X Design, did the research. Connoting what? ''That was a spoof. Bees having stingers and all that.''

title: Get Me Out of Here!
description: A colleague quits his job with a flourish, perhaps exacting a little revenge in the process. But you can only watch in awe, perhaps wishing you had the chutzpah, or the financial independence, to do the same. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Raving My Religion
description: It's often said that religion could benefit from being a lot more fun. That's part of the idea behind the Techno Cosmic Masses, created by Matthew Fox, a radical theologian. A former Dominican priest from California, Fox was kicked out of the order after a decadelong battle over his various unorthodoxies, and hooked up with British deejays who were reinventing the Anglican Mass to entice young hipsters. Back in California, Fox started holding his own rave-inspired services, drawing young and old alike. ''With multimedia technology,'' he explains, ''we can turn an ordinary room into Chartres Cathedral.'' Really? Recently, nearly 500 people lined up outside a loft in an industrial section of Oakland for a Mass called ''Gaia Our Mother.'' Here's what they experienced.

title: For Elegant Watch Hill, New Faces on the Scene
description: FOR more than a century, the elegant seaside community of Watch Hill beckoned a select group of wealthy families, who traveled by steamer and train to their Victorian-style cottages from New York, Philadelphia, Cincinnati and other bases of industry.

title: Passports to Adventure?
description: Because of the strong run-up in the United States stock market, investors may be eager to add to their stakes in overseas markets, expecting more value abroad. But they won't achieve the diversification benefits promised by advisers if they buy shares in the typical foreign fund, warns Tricia O. Rothschild in a recent edition of Morningstar Mutual Funds.

title: A Dozen Who Have Risen to Prominence
description: Here are some leaders in the field of women's health and their answers to the question, ''What do you think a woman's chief health concern should be?''

title: Vote Ends Board Official's Chances to Fight Dismissal
description: The Board of Education has upheld Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's decision to suspend a Queens community school board president who he said had flouted his authority in selecting a district superintendent.

title: Newark Arts Center Signs Rock and Pop Promoters
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center has signed John Scher, one of the East Coast's biggest rock promoters, and Ernest Booker, a prominent rhythm-and-blues promoter in the area, to book music shows. The hall is to open in Newark on Oct. 18.

title: Life: Start Here . . .
description: A woman's life cycle can sometimes seem like an obstacle course in which she must dodge an increasing number of health threats. In reality, as medical experts point out, every stage in a woman's life has its health benefits. Indeed, women typically pass through long periods of essentially good health. Risks can be reduced if good habits are nurtured early on. And eve late in the game, women can undertake preventive measures that improve the quality of life.

title: Anomaly in a Rape Case: Freedom for Alex Kelly
description: When Alex Kelly strode out of the courthouse here and rode off in the family Jeep, free just two hours after a jury convicted him of rape, he seemed to many to be an unlikely candidate for bail.

title: Where Dim Sum's King
description: DINERS who think of the new Hong Kong Seafood House, in Plainview, as just another suburban Chinese spot are missing the point. Saturdays and Sundays from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. this little restaurant, with the decor, spirit and style of humble Manhattan and Flushing Chinatown eateries, serves a dim sum, or Chinese tea luncheon.

title: Rent: Not the Musical
description: Rent regulation can seem one of those arcane and faintly archaic things that New Yorkers enjoy obsessing over, but for more than a million tenants, living in a rent-regulated apartment doesn't just prove mastery at the art of getting a good deal; it enables people with modest incomes to stay in the city.

title: Second Look: A Holdout On the Farm Finally Sells
description: ''It had to come,'' said Alvina Frey, surrounded by the late-Saturday morning crush of the Union Square Greenmarket in Manhattan, where she has been selling her beans and geraniums for more than 20 years. ''But I don't know what I'm going to do with myself. I really don't know what I'm going to do with myself.''

title: Women Vie for Seats in Bridge Tournament
description: Two women's bridge teams that will represent the United States in world championship play in Tunisia in October are being determined here this weekend by the American Contract Bridge League's International Women's Team Trials.

title: Pilgrims
description: To the Editor: Just a few lines to say how much I have enjoyed the articles about Spain by Robert Packard these past many years. Being an octogenarian, I only wish I were 50 years younger, to travel the pilgrim's way on foot.

title: Teen-Agers Learning The Ways Of Offices
description: Chris Paparo is a banker, but for a few minutes last week he was a secretary, a bad one. He arrived 35 minutes late for his first day of work, relaxed and unconcerned. Wearing headphones, he met his boss, a frazzled doctor. After a testy confrontation, he excused himself to get a cup of coffee and go to the bathroom.

title: Preamble To Text Of Accord
description: Following are excerpts from the preamble to the 68-page tobacco settlement document, which has not yet been publicly released and was provided to The New York Times by advisers to negotiators of the settlement. It is stamped ''draft'' and marked ''for settlement discussion purposes only, 6/20/97 3 P.M.''

title: A Newborn Baby Is Left Home to Die, Police Say
description: A 20-year-old woman taken by ambulance to a Bronx hospital yesterday morning because she appeared to be having a miscarriage did not tell paramedics that she had given birth in her home and had left her newborn son to die, the police said.

title: Safety First: Screening Test
description: While experts may argue heatedly about the who's and when's of screening tests for various ailments, they agree that regular screenings are vital in the battle against disease. The recommendations below were gleaned from the United States Preventive Service Task Force'sGuide to Clinical Preventive Services and from the guidelines of medical associations. They apply only to the average adult, not to pregnant women or those who are ill. SANDY M. FERNANDEZ

title: A Long-Suppressed Urge to Be Noisy
description: THIN ICE Coming of Age in Canada. By Bruce McCall. 249 pp. New York: Random House. $24.

title: Islam and Liberty: Struggles in 2 Lands
description: TRAVELING between Turkey and Iran these days produces an odd sensation of dissonance. In militantly secular Turkey, a Muslim-oriented political movement is thriving despite intense efforts by generals and others to suppress it. In orthodox Iran, a relatively moderate cleric who preaches tolerance and studies Kant and de Tocqueville has been elected President.

title: Schools Scramble For Funds
description: IN a successful budget season for most of the county's school districts, the repeated rejections of budgets in Greenburgh, Harrison and Peekskill have left those districts scrambling for ways to support their programs. And the reasons for the rejections, in some communities, highlight tensions that go beyond the budget votes.

title: Community Work Eases Senior Slump
description: THE college acceptances are in hand, Advanced Placement exams are over, and, traditionally, this is the time for high school seniors to spend their last few weeks in school enjoying the proverbial senior slump before graduation..

title: Frequent-Flier Miles, Earned Without Flying
description: Several frequent-flier programs are offering members new ways to accumulate mileage without ever buying an airline ticket. Westin Hotels and Resorts, (800) 228-3000, is now a participant in Sky Miles, Delta Airlines' frequent-flier program. Members collect 500 miles for each stay at any Westin anywhere in the world.

title: In Sentencing, 'Megan' Jury Sought Middle
description: The fight over whether Jesse K. Timmendequas should die for the murder of Megan Kanka was a battle of caricatures drawn by the prosecution and the defense.

title: Kenneth Starr, Trapped
description: In ''Kenneth Starr, Trapped'' (June 1), Jeffrey Rosen assures readers, with virtually no elaboration, that Starr's outside activities do not ''present actual conflicts of interest.''

title: Dog Day Care (Hydrant Too)
description: On her first day at camp, Layla hunched in a corner of the sunny playroom, watching Amelia romp with a red ball. In seconds, Amelia dropped the ball and pounced on Kelsey, who had bounded into the room as Riley, gregarious as always, approached Layla and wrapped himself around her from behind. Layla grumbled and threw him off.

title: Revival of the 'Crown Jewel' Of Brooklyn Is Stalled Again
description: The Loews Kings closed in 1978, and the city and businesses in Flatbush have struggled for years to revive the ornate movie palace.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about a dry cleaner in TriBeCa that was criticized by neighbors on environmental grounds misstated its address at one point. The business, White Glove Cleaners, is at 39 North Moore Street, not 29.

title: The Growing Lure Of Wakeboarding
description: ON a recent quiet weekday evening, Chris O'Neill stands on a small board while a boat pulls him calmly across Cold Spring Harbor. Holding firmly to the tow rope handle, he suddenly turns towards the wake, flies 15 feet into the air and flips head over heels slamming hard into the water, as those on the boat erupt into loud hoots and hollers. Welcome to the world of wakeboarding.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about William Steiner, a shareholder activist who founded the Investors' Rights Association of America, omitted a byline. The writer was Sana Siwolop.

title: Three-Fifths Clause Didn't Define Humanness
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Lannan, Mr. Korybut-Daszkiewicz
description: Sharron Killan Lannan, a daughter of Anne Lannan of Los Angeles and J. Patrick Lannan of Santa Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to Alexis Korybut-Daszkiewicz, a son of Katherine Maffitt O'Connor of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Kasimir Korybut-Daszkiewicz of Naples, Fla.

title: Falling Pigeons Stir Calls for New Controls
description: For the last few weeks, residents of East 86th Street have been shocked by what they say are pigeons falling from the sky, seemingly in convulsions, then dying a lingering death. The residents blame the deaths on the Channel Club, a 45-story condominium at 455 East 86th Street whose managers, they say, have arranged to poison the pigeons.

title: Amy Schwartz, John Tanenbaum
description: Amy Ilene Schwartz, the daughter of Susan and Robert Schwartz of Riverdale, the Bronx, is to be married today to John Michael Tanenbaum, the son of Winifred J. Tanenbaum of Woodmere, N.Y., and J. Jay Tanenbaum of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Shlomo Balter is to officiate at the Pierre in New York.

title: A Wider Road, With New Curves, for Robertson, Stephens
description: MERGERS of fund families tend to make investors nervous. Will managers stay? Will expenses, fees and other key attributes of the funds change?

title: Many Grandparents Find Themselves Parenting Again
description: LIKE most adults raising children today, Zelma Tompson of Yonkers could do without rap music. She worries that her 14-year-old will succumb to peer pressure in a world where drugs and AIDS are rampant. She worries about choosing the right school for her 8-year-old.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article last Sunday about Latitudes, a travel agency, described the location of its Manhattan office imprecisely. The office, at 457 Madison Avenue, is in the New York Palace Hotel. The hotel is no longer known as the Helmsley Palace. Because of a production error, the company's logo appeared with the final ''s'' omitted.

title: Students at Jefferson Should Know of Its History
description: To the Editor:

title: Street Crime Plagues Papua New Guinea
description: DON'T go onto the golf course alone. Don't go out to eat on Fridays, when people are getting drunk on their government salaries. Don't walk around too much. For goodness' sake, don't drive alone at night.

title: Pampering for a Price
description: Last month, Virgin Atlantic Airways opened the Virgin Touch salon in its Clubhouse Lounge in Logan Airport in Boston. The salon has two beauty therapists for aromatherapy and massages for necks, shoulders and hands as well as manicures. The free service is for Upper Class passengers only, going to or from London (round-trip fare: $5,206). Information: (800) 862-8621.

title: Waterbury Revives Its Baseball Heritage
description: UNTIL a few years ago, a sign on the outfield fence at Cubeta Stadium in Stamford proclaimed the city the ''Baseball Capitol of the World.'' Even though Stamford had indeed turned out national championship youth teams, that seemed to be a spurious statement since the city has produced only one career major leaguer -- Bobby Valentine, currently the manager of the New York Mets.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Doll Houses for Adults

title: How a Dream Apartment Turned Into a Nightmare
description: THIS is the story of my life,'' said Margeau Dyer with a grimace, gesturing toward the new down-filled paisley-covered armchair in the middle of her still-unfinished living room -- which arrived with a broken leg, and is now propped up by a pile of books.

title: I'm Sure of It: A Conspiracy's Afoot Against Island Commuters
description: COMMUTERS never agree which season they hate most. Some maintain that commuting through the heat and humidity of summer is worse than a vacation in Europe during the Black Plague. Others firmly believe no human beings in history ever suffered as much as Long Island commuters in winter.

title: Renaissance of a Restaurant in Brewster
description: IF outstanding renovation of restaurant interiors has taken up space in recent reviews -- of Mona's and the Eastchester Fish Gourmet -- chalk it up to coincidence, and in the romantic category, the Arch now joins that number. Stunning refurbishment here includes sponge-painted walls -- crimson in one room, golden in another -- sparkling mirrors and table appointments and lighting that glows more than illuminates.

title: The Foreign Aid Gamble in Africa
description: IT was a high-powered team that President Clinton sent to meet with the new Government here: the United States representative to the United Nations, Bill Richardson; an assistant secretary of State; an admiral; a senior member of the National Security Council; a senior spy, a member of Congress.

title: An Icon Goes to Washington
description: The new congresswoman was in a ford explorer, bound for a place far from Washington, and she could not wait. Soon she would be in the Hamptons, breathing ocean air that clears the mind like smelling salts. Finally, she would have time to reflect.

title: On Breast Cancer, the Vote Favors Aggressive Screening
description: WOMEN are more afraid of cancer than any other disease and are most anxious about breast cancer. Even though heart disease kills more women, this fear is not surprising: almost 40 percent of women say that a close female relative has received a diagnosis of breast cancer, and three-quarters say they have been following the recent controversy over how often women of different ages should have mammograms, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: The Reputation Is Legendary, The Playing Unpredictable
description: OF THE SOVIET VIRTUOSOS who broke onto the international scene after World War II, Emil Gilels was the first to come to the United States. He made his debut playing the Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto in B flat minor with the Philadelphia Orchestra in 1955.

title: Making America Safe for Electronic Commerce
description: NOT too long ago in America, the chief threats to personal privacy were the snoopy neighbor and the party-line eavesdropper.

title: Acorn Fund
description: RALPH WANGER, an elfish money manager with a mischievous streak, says he is nuts about small-company stocks -- always has been, always will be.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-9

title: Unlikely Allies in Fight for Hemp
description: Fred A. Maslack made the long drive down from southern Vermont in the oldest car with Vermont legislative plates, his rusting 1982 Dodge Diplomat.

title: From Home Renovation to Empire Building
description: MEET Bob Vila Inc., or what he affectionately calls his ''little media empire.''

title: Personal Health
description: WHAT do women want to know about their health, the possibilities of losing it and the ways of preserving it?

title: The Writer Is Dead. But His Ghost Is Thriving.
description: Jack Hitt's article ''The Writer Is Dead. But His Ghost Is Thriving'' (May 25) sent me straight to the local bookstore. It turns out that Dannion Brinkley's ''Saved by the Light,'' Melvin Morse's ''Closer to the Light'' and Raymond Moody's ''Light Beyond'' -- all firsthand accounts of near-death experiences -- were co-authored by one Paul Perry. Now there's a ghostwriter.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Top talent from the ranks of directors and actors shines out of television screens this week in enduring comedies and dramas.

title: Letting It Fly
description: How nice that Joyce Maynard recognized the error of her rage and made a special trip to retrieve the screw gun she'd tossed into the bushes in her ex-husband's yard (Lives: ''Letting It Fly,'' June 1). How sad that she makes only passing reference to her greater cause for shame -- moving her sons to the West Coast and denying them those weekend visits with their father. No, Ms. Maynard, the worst thing about divorce isn't ''what it makes you do to yourself'' -- it's what you let yourself do to your children.

title: Rebecca Jones, Christian Urciuoli
description: Rebecca Crane Jones, a daughter of Sarah and Landon Y. Jones Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Christian Joseph Arthur Urciuoli, the son of Margaret and J. Arthur Urciuoli of Riverside, Conn., were married yesterday in Princeton. The Rev. Dr. Joseph C. Williamson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Moves Behind the Scenes Could Affect Rangers Most
description: Certainly it was important for the Rangers to select Stefan Cherneski in the first round of the National Hockey League draft here today. He is a right wing, a position where the Rangers have lacked depth in recent seasons.

title: Miriam Wine And Zev Kaplan
description: Miriam Frances Wine, a daughter of Ann and David Wine of Westcliff-on-Sea, England, is to be married today to Zev Kaplan, a son of Judy and Stanley Kaplan of Brooklyn. Rabbi Levi Yitzchak Horowitz is to perform the ceremony at Maxim's, a catering hall in Jerusalem.

title: The Silence
description: THE STORY OF THE NIGHT By Colm Toibin. 324 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $23.

title: Amy Adelson, Dean Valentine
description: Amy Adelson, an independent film and television producer, is to be married today to Dean Valentine, the president of network television and television animation at the Walt Disney Company in Burbank, Calif. Rabbi Ari Fridkis is to perform the ceremony at the Americas Society in New York.

title: The Logic of Losing at All-News TV
description: IF a television network starts a 24-hour news channel and nobody watches, does it exist?

title: They Talked and Talked, and Then Wrote a Classic
description: JANE PINCUS is again writing the childbirth chapter. Nancy Miriam Hawley is working on the one about psychotherapy. Wendy Sanford is rewriting the section on AIDS. Norma Swenson is taking on the politics of women and medical care. Judy Norsigian is writing about contraceptives. And Paula Doress-Worters is handling the topic of women and aging.

title: Hilary Weiss, William Cooper
description: Hilary Nelson Weiss, a daughter of Nancy S. Nelson and Ronald W. Weiss, both of New York, was married last evening to William Harris Cooper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Cooper of Mount Vernon, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: The Reluctant Bridesmaids
description: KAREN OWENS unzipped the plastic dress bag, and a spray of lilac and fuchsia satin and Champagne raw silk fanned out over her bed. She spread the varied assortment of bridesmaids' gowns and, with a disgusted look, fiddled with netting, sashes and ruffles.

title: A Life Spent Asking, 'What Is Art?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Her Majesty's Court Has Ruled: McDonald's Burgers Are Not Poison
description: AFTER nearly three years in court, the ''McLibel'' trial finally ended in Britain last week. The judge in the case ruled that Helen Steel, a part-time bartender, and Dave Morris, an unemployed postman, were guilty of defaming McDonald's in a pamphlet distributed in the late 1980's. But while awarding the burger giant $96,000 in damages, the court also said the chain was responsible for cruelty to animals, exploiting children through its advertising and depressing wages in the British fast-food industry.

title: N.B.A. Teams Are Playing It Cautiously in Their Planning for the Draft
description: The Chicago Bulls tried a novel approach with their first-round draft choice last year. They waived the rights to the rookie center Travis Knight. Their thinking seemed to backfire as Knight developed into a solid role player for the Los Angeles Lakers, but there was logic behind the transaction.

title: The I.R.A. Shuts the Door On Itself Again
description: When two police officers were killed in Northern Ireland and a caller to a Belfast radio station said the attack was the work of the Irish Republican Army, the British Government retaliated by calling off all further contact with Sinn Fein, the I.R.A.'s political arm.

title: As Conversation Stopper, It Has Few Equals
description: WHEN I was a girl, there was an enigmatic quality to all things gynecologic. While today most sixth graders learn the word ''period'' at school as both punctuation and physiology, the mechanics of menstruation in the early 1960's were so oblique as to constitute a series of riddles:

title: What Can He Do If Banks Never Say No?
description: For millions of Americans, the kind and encouraging face and voice of Joseph P. Goryeb represent the lure of easy credit.

title: Books vs. Computers: What About the Index?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rickshaw in Tiergarten: New Way to See Berlin
description: The newest way to see the sights in Berlin is by rickshaw. Velotaxi, a Berlin rickshaw service, recently started operating 30 three-wheeled bicycles attached to passenger wagons, which can carry one or two people past landmarks like the Brandenburg Gate, the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church or along the grand Unter den Linden Avenue. Most of these 10-foot-long high-tech tricycles, which have five gears, are pedaled by students.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Gearing Up for P.G.A.

title: Newfoundland Marks John Cabot's Landing
description: Five hundred years ago, King Henry VII of England commissioned John Cabot, an explorer, to find a new trade route to Asia. Instead, Cabot's ship, the Matthew, brought him to the east coast of North America. In May, a copy of the Matthew left Bristol, England, and is due to arrive on Tuesday at Bonavista, Newfoundland, marking the day of the original landing.

title: College Entry Shouldn't Depend on Test Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: No Hot Air on Global Warming
description: Five years ago, more than 100 world leaders came together for the first international Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, leaving a diaphanous trail of promises to clean the earth's atmosphere, save its rain forests and otherwise collaborate on common environmental challenges. Many of these leaders or their successors will convene at the United Nations this week to review their work. There is little to celebrate. The oceans are as polluted as ever, and deforestation proceeds at a ruinous pace. Perhaps the most conspicuous failure, however, involves the hugely contentious subject of global warming.

title: Making Do in a Year When Money Abounds
description: As they put the finishing touches on a new election-year budget, state lawmakers and Governor Whitman found themselves in a political quandary: there was too much money to spend.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Italian Gardens In Green and Gray
description: CLASSIC Italian gardens are paradoxical places, celebrating sun and shade, earth and sky, the green of hedge, the crunch of gravel, the play of moving water -- just about anything but a profusion of flowers. In a country as dry and hot as Italy in summer, blooms and blossoms turned out to be far too complicated and expensive to maintain. So although Italy was the first European country to be dazzled by bulbs from the East and West Indies, the Americas and South Africa -- tulips, daffodils, narcissus -- in the 17th century, flowers gradually disappeared from the classic Italian garden. Increasingly, architects focused on perennial greens, cool stonework and the sound of water to soothe eyes and minds burning from the fierce sunlight that bakes the peninsula much of the year.

title: Restoring a Fine Khmer Craft Rent by Revolution
description: IN 1995, KIKUO MORIMOTO, a Japanese weaver and textile expert, traveled by motorcycle, by boat and on foot through the forests and jungles of Cambodia in search of master weavers. Everywhere he went, he showed pieces of boldly patterned Khmer silks taken from 19th-century costumes and temple hangings to shopkeepers in hopes of finding weavers who were still producing such work.

title: Vietnam Tours
description: To the Editor: Just back from Vietnam, I enjoyed Orville Schell's article, based on a trip last spring. Bone-chilling itineraries such as ''Cu Chi tunnels in the morning, shopping in Ho Chi Minh City in the afternoon'' illustrate the desire of Vietnam to join the market economy.

title: Limits on Lawsuits and Damage Claims Could Bring Years of Legal Fights
description: A day after cigarette makers and the attorneys general of seven states proposed a historic agreement to settle claims against the tobacco industry, legal experts predicted that even if the proposal overcame hurdles in Congress, it was certain to be tied up in years of litigation.

title: Classical Performance With a Hispanic Edge
description: A 'safe' or 'standard' repertoire of classical music doesn't entice a young audience,'' says Lisa Hansen, executive director of the Northern Manhattan Community Artists organization and flutist for the Hudson Sinfonietta.

title: Susan Meyer And Charles Ross
description: Susan Lynn Meyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Meyer of Wellesley, Mass., was married last evening to Charles Nicholson Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Ross 3d of Claremont, Calif. The Rev. Dean Wolf, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Trinity Church in Boston.

title: Hong Kong and False Alarms
description: Back in 1984, when Britain agreed to return Hong Kong to China in 1997 and China agreed to keep it as it was for ''50 years at least,'' Deng Xiaoping remarked that Hong Kong would not change much over that period but China would. Eventually, China would become so much like Hong Kong, he implied, that there would be no significant difference between the two.

title: Top of the Health List
description: When it comes to staying healthy, what you don't do -- like smoke, drink or overeat -- seems to be more important than how often you undergo screening tests, if the experience of Asian-American women is an indication. In 1991 and 1992, according to the National Cancer Institute, Asian women had lower rates of Pap test, mammography and clinical breast exam than any other racial or ethnic group in the United States.

title: Karen Rosen And Seth Harris
description: Karen Beth Rosen, a social worker, and Seth David Harris, the acting assistant secretary for policy at the Labor Department in Washington, are to be married today. Rabbi Irwin N. Goldenberg is to perform the ceremony at the Strong Mansion, a historic house in Dickerson, Md.

description: FREE CHOICES

title: Revenge and the Sixth Commandment
description: IN Cape May, in a Presbyterian church whose stained-glass windows glow with the seashore sun, the argument against capital punishment was being defended last Sunday, the day after the headlines announced the jury's verdict that Timothy McVeigh must die.

title: What's Bad For the Goose Is Unpopular
description: ''The Unthinkable Has Happened! Canada Geese Kidnapped From Parks and Sent to Secret Death at 6 A.M.''

title: Water Rationing Ordered Again in San Juan
description: The Government of Puerto Rico ordered water rationing in San Juan and nearby areas this week because of low rainfall, heavy use of water and limited reservoir space. It is the second time that rationing has been ordered in three years.

title: Manager Still Has Detractors, but Not Among the Mets
description: Bobby Valentine stood in the middle of the clubhouse at Shea Stadium on Aug. 26, 1996, his first day as Mets manager, and assured the players he had an open mind about each of them. Then he asked them to keep an open mind about him.

title: Jam Sessions
description: THE INVENTION THAT CHANGED THE WORLD

title: Pamela Brainard, Brian Greenho
description: Pamela Hall Brainard, a publicist at Globe Pequot Press in Old Saybrook, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Douglas Greenho, the president of Stencil Ease International, a manufacturer of decorative stenciling materials in Old Saybrook. The Rev. David W. Good performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Conn.

title: On Atlantic Avenue, Another Boom, at Least in Optimism
description: In 1972, when Nancy Cogen opened the Melting Pot, a tie-dye clothing store on Atlantic Avenue, great expectations were in the air. A group of young entrepreneurs was renovating storefronts, with the idea of creating a pleasant shopping district.

title: Increasing Evidence Of Pol Pot's Capture
description: Appearing together, Cambodia's two Prime Ministers said that the Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, had been captured and that they would ask the United Nations to help put him on trial for the bloodletting that took at least one million lives. The announcement carried more credibility than reports last week, experts said. A trial would be an extraordinary demonstration of the long reach of justice, across 18 years.

description: Meaning as a Second Language

title: Capturing 'The Souls of New York' on Film
description: IT was three years ago, while chatting with a horse-and-carriage driver in Central Park in Manhattan, that Brent Nemetz came up with the idea for his documentary.

title: From Welfare to a Job and a New Attitude
description: CHRISTINE AVILA'S attitude about life changed, she said, when she got a job. On and off of welfare for 22 years, Mrs. Avila, 43 and the mother of four, also has a home of her own, in Mount Vernon -- something that seemed impossible a short time ago.

title: Takeover, Handover or Reversion
description: ''Where you stand depends on where you sit'' is a political adage. In the same way, where you stand often determines the word you choose. Take the impending transfer of Hong Kong on July 1, after the British lease on the island territory runs out.

title: Grand Hotels
description: In the late 19th century, before there was a Miami Beach, the White Mountains of New Hampshire could make as good a claim as anyplace else to being the hotel capital of the United States. The Museum of New Hampshire History is bringing back that era with the exhibit ''Popular Resorts: Grand Hotels of the White Mountains,'' through Jan. 4. The museum, at 6 Eagle Square in Concord, is using hotel furnishings and other memorabilia to recreate the atmosphere in the big resorts of that era, many of which have since burned down. Photographs and advertising materials are also on view. Take Exit 14 of I-93; open daily except Monday. Call (603) 226-3189. JOSEPH SIANO

title: Kentucky Exile
description: The Good Brother By Chris Offutt. 317 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: After 3 Years, Challenges Gain Momentum
description: So unthinkable, so fantastic were the allegations that the apple-country town of Wenatchee, Wash., suddenly became infamous, indelibly associated with claims of ritual orgies on a church stage, of pedophile parents swapping their children, of adults lining up to take turns at child rape.

description: Painted along the topsides of Chessie Racing, a new round-the-world sailboat docked here, is a green sea monster. Judging by its impish grin and Blues Brothers sunglasses over serpentine eyes, almost anyone would agree that it is friendly.

title: Marc J. Gerson and Emily Porter
description: Emily Lowe Porter, the daughter of Susan and Stephen Porter of Washington, was married last evening to Marc Jay Gerson, the son of Robin and David Gerson of Marlboro, N.J. Rabbi Joseph P. Weinberg performed the ceremony at the Willard Hotel in Washington.

title: Three Mile Island Vents Radioactive Steam
description: The Three Mile Island nuclear plant vented steam with a trace of radioactivity today after a brief power failure shut down the reactor, said its operator, GPU Nuclear.

description: Hours after Attorney General Michael Moore of Mississippi declared victory in the war on tobacco, Dr. David A. Kessler, the former Commissioner of Food and Drugs, sat down to study the fine print of the 68-page peace proposal.

title: Waging the Rent Wars on the Far West Side
description: A tenant was ranting into the microphone at a public hearing. ''Rent control is for the lawyers, by the lawyers and of the lawyers,'' she yelled, jabbing a finger at the officials on the dais, who were rolling their eyes and chatting with each other. ''You don't listen to the people, you keep control by keeping people off balance and creating problems. You whales.''

title: No Clanking Dinner Plates In the Wings for This Candide
description: IN ODD MOMENTS, WHEN Jason Danieley is standing at the edge of the stage at the Gershwin Theater, belting forth one of Leonard Bernstein's high-octane numbers in the latest incarnation of ''Candide,'' the actor half expects to hear the clink of cutlery from the black void before him.

title: A Global Manhunt Ends
description: More than four years after their manhunt began, agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation hauled Mir Amal Kansi out of a no-star hotel in Afghanistan last week and brought him to the United States to face murder charges in a Virginia court.

title: Conceptualist Comments on the Soviet Union
description: IN Moscow, as in New York and elsewhere, the late 1960's and the 70's brought the emergence of what became known as Conceptual Art -- an art that gave language equality with or even predominance over purely visual elements. But what happened simultaneously in the Soviet Union and in the West did not happen for the same reasons, as is shown by ''Sequences: As You Can See,'' a selection of multi-part works by two generations of Moscow Conceptualists at the Zimmerli Art Museum here. The works have been selected by Marek Bartelik from the vast holdings of the Norton and Nancy Dodge Collection of Nonconformist Art From the Soviet Union, donated to the Zimmerli six years ago.
