title: Paired Up for Summer: Boats and Gardens
description: BOATS and gardens are a natural pair of opposites, both associated with summer, one signifying travel to distant places, the other meaning stay home and, well, tend one's own garden. They're currently together in the form of two exhibitions at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich.

title: Word May Be Out, but Schoolgirls Need to Get Message
description: The benefits of running track were obvious years before Benita Fitzgerald Mosley won a gold medal in the 100-meter hurdles in the 1984 Olympic Games. They were visible long before she ran well enough to earn a full scholarship to the University of Tennessee. Sports helped her, as it does many young women and men, to develop a sense of self and find her way through the inevitable trials and challenges of adolescence.

title: Moscow On the Make
description: Michael Specter's vivid portrayal of five people in Moscow touched me deeply (''Moscow on the Make,'' June 1). Life in Moscow is tenuous at best. Yet, they have such a will to survive. And they live with gusto and bravado!

title: Biker Bar Owner's Legacy Is Revelry
description: It is a weekday evening two weeks after the unexpected death of Allan Dell, the 31-year-old owner of Hogs and Heifers, the meat packing district bar. Bras -- 3,000 of them, said the manager, Mick McGee -- still hang from stuffed deer heads and the 480-pound mako shark mounted over the bar. Ceiling fans still churn dust slowly over the heads of bikers, meat market workers and celebrity would-bes as they crowd, elbow to elbow, into the dark, dingy, 900-square-foot space and spill onto the sidewalk. And there is still no dancing.

title: After 7 Years Of Delays, Gigante Trial Is Set to Begin
description: After seven years of court battles over whether he is crazy or crazy like a fox, Vincent Gigante is to go on trial tomorrow on charges that he ordered murders and led rackets as a powerful Mafia boss.

title: Three Cheers for the Rockies' Walker (He Prefers It That Way)
description: The Colorado Rockies were clobbering the Expos in Montreal on the first Saturday of the season, and Larry Walker had already hit two home runs against the team that raised him to be the star he is today. But Don Baylor, his manager, didn't want Walker to stop there.

title: Double Exposure
description: TO glimpse the hunger of aspiring short-story writers for publication, recognition and a little pay, you need look no farther than the offices of Zoetrope, a new fiction magazine that is the brainchild of the director Francis Ford Coppola. The quarterly publication started a few months ago with some fanfare, thanks to the fame of its founder.

title: For Sale by City: 39 of Its Walk-Ups
description: Thirty-nine vacant, city-owned walk-ups, many with ''mom and pop'' shops downstairs, are to be gut rehabilitated and sold to homeowners and investors for $90,000 to $385,000, according to Lori Holland, spokeswoman for Neighborhood Housing Services, which is renovating and selling them.

title: Trouble-Shooting in the Summer Rose Garden
description: It was the most unusual rose garden I'd ever seen. Every bush had at least one aluminum pie plate suspended over it. Under the plates were perfect roses, securely wrapped in white netting. I was awed by the engineering created to guard each specimen from chewing and sucking predators like Japanese beetles, thrips and midges. But I wondered at the racket this garden must make when it rains.

title: A Jockey in a League of His Own
description: OFFICIALS of Muttontown may want to check the zoning laws. One resident keeps a horse in his basement.

title: How to Succeed in Politics Without Really Working
description: IMAGINE. The French Socialists want to shrink the work week by four hours, but without shrinking anyone's pay, which is wonderful politics, no doubt, but iffy economics. French industrialists must be itching to relocate to southeast Asia -- or the United States, for that matter -- where the natives will work more hours, not fewer, for no extra money.

title: That's Show Biz
description: ON Tuesday, shortly before the evening show of ''Five Guys Named Moe'' at the Claridge Hotel, the director, Chapman Roberts, was informed that the musical revue, which had been playing since March 24, wasn't selling enough tickets and that today would be its last performance.

title: Betsy Hart And Dennis Gray
description: Betsy Maria Hart and Dennis Joseph Gray, the owners of an architectural firm in Salem, Mass., were married yesterday at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Salem. Msgr. James G. Hart, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony, in which Joseph T. Ryan, a former Archbishop of Anchorage, took part.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Detective

title: Look Ma: No Holes!
description: WHAT -- Trendiness without commitment. Magnetic studs from the Gravity Free Factory eliminate the need to pierce ears, lips, noses or tongues, so that when the fad has passed, there are no unsightly holes. For $6 at the factory, 59 Franklin Street (near Lafayette Street); (212) 965-1265.

title: Beer and Ale Plus Casual, Hearty Menu
description: JOHN HARVARD'S Brew House in Westport is the second to open in Connecticut in just a few months, the first being in Manchester. Both are branches of a Boston-based company.

title: Joseph Johnson 3d, Dana Roberson
description: Dana Marie Roberson, the daughter of Edith L. Roberson and Dr. William J. Roberson of Flint, Mich., was married yesterday to Joseph Jerome Johnson 3d, the son of Imogene P. Johnson and Joseph J. Johnson Jr. of Columbus, Ga. The Rev. Katharine Henderson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Laura Samponaro, Kurt Steltenpohl
description: Laura Marie Samponaro, a daughter of Philip G. Samponaro of Litchfield, Conn., and the late Laura I. Samponaro, was married yesterday to Kurt Maus Steltenpohl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Steltenpohl of Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. Robert F. Tucker, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Anthony of Padua Church in Litchfield.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: GIVING AWAY SIMONE: A Memoir

title: Moscow On the Make
description: I am a 21-year-old college student, just returned from eight months of study in Moscow. During my stay, I lived with a wonderful and highly educated family that was struggling to subsist on a few hundred dollars a month. The mother (with a master's degree in geology) teaches English at a grade school for $1 an hour. There is a nightclub in Moscow where the cover charge on the weekend is $425. It is these kinds of discrepancies and this kind of excess that marks today's Moscow.

title: The Many Splendors of Hanging Baskets
description: HANGING plants have become great assets for decor, either indoors or out. Choices of what plants to grow are almost anything your heart desires. Or, to be more practical, what the garden center happens to be offering for sale this season.

title: Corrections
description: A credit was omitted from four photographs of subway musicians last Sunday with the continuation of the front-page article. The photographer was Jack Manning of The New York Times.

title: Tracks
description: POINT LAST SEEN A Woman Tracker's Story. By Hannah Nyala. 168 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $21.

title: It's Love at First Roar
description: WHAT -- The Ducati 916 Superbike, a fantasy toy for proud owners like the chef David Bouley, the supermodel Tyson Beckford, the singers Lyle Lovett and Billy Joel, and the actors Jason Priestley and Stephen Baldwin. At around $16,000, this motorcycle is a lot less expensive than a flashy sports car.

title: The Sunny Side Of the Cascades
description: IT never rains in Bend. Any Oregonian will tell you that. The clouds and drizzle that envelop Portland, Salem and Eugene leave a snowy topping on the Cascades, some of the best skiing mountains in the West, then magically evaporate, leaving nothing but glorious blue skies over the eastern two-thirds of the state.

title: Islanders Draft With Trades in Mind
description: With the fourth and fifth picks from what is thought to be a talented crop of 18-year-old prospects, the Islanders picked goalie Roberto Luongo and defenseman Eric Brewer today in the first round of the National Hockey League entry draft in Civic Arena.

title: In Principle, a Case For More 'Sweatshops'
description: Now some of the nation's leading economists, with solid liberal and academic credentials, are offering a much broader, more principled rationale. Economists like Jeffrey D. Sachs of Harvard and Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology say that low-wage plants making clothing and shoes for foreign markets are an essential first step toward modern prosperity in developing countries.

title: Perfectionist Of Pizza Expands
description: Before there was Al Yeganeh, the obsessed soup purveyor parodied on ''Seinfeld,'' there was Jerry Pero, the perfectionist heir to Totonno's Pizzeria Napolitano, the storied Coney Island landmark that his father, Antonio (Totonno) Pero, founded in 1924.

title: Annus Horribilis
description: The Year

title: Air Hercules Joins Disney's Pantheon Of Pitchmen
description: ACCORDING TO LEGEND, Zeus, married to Hera, misbehaved one night with the mortal wife of Amphitryon, king of Thebes. Result: Hercules.

title: Just When You Thought Air Was Free
description: DRESSED in a deep-green bodysuit and wraparound sunglasses, blond hair pulled up like a pineapple on her head, Ann Marie Murphy was not the least bit self-conscious about sitting at a bar with a hose up her nose.

title: Bronx Decision to Come in '97
description: A decision on the future home of the Yankees will be made later this year, George Steinbrenner, the team owner, said today.

title: Transportation News: Cars, Boats, Buses, Bikes
description: New Jersey Transit has ordered 50 buses powered by natural gas for use on its commuter runs along Route 9. The buses will be part of a demonstration program using alternative fuels to cut pollution. One of the buses, ordered from Motor Coach Industries of Winnipeg, Manitoba, is to be delivered next summer and the other 49 by March 1999.

title: Arts in Education: An Experiment Graduates
description: WHEN Fred Luks was first confronted with Arts Excel in his third-grade classes in the Greenburgh 7 School District, he scoffed at the program. ''No one could convince me that what they wanted to do could be served any better than what I was already doing,'' the Highview School teacher said. ''I had no desire to participate in a program I viewed as a frill.''

title: Melissa Katz, Stephen Silver
description: Melissa Wendy Katz, the daughter of Marjorie and Lewis Katz of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Stephen Gregg Silver, a son of Roberta Strugats of Garden City, N.Y., and Joel Silver of Woodmere, N.Y. Rabbi Joel Zion performed the ceremony at a private residence in Sagaponack, N.Y.

title: INSIDE
description: Court Saves Best for Last

title: Bradley's Real Growth Is in Air Cargo
description: PEOPLE who fly out of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks were not surprised to hear passenger traffic there increased last year by 5 percent, a faster pace than most airports in the Northeast. But even stronger growth is taking place in an area most people never see as they rush to the ticket counters for passage to Washington, D.C., or West Palm Beach: Cargo shipping was up 13.5 percent in 1996, to more than 261 million pounds. And it is cargo that gives the strength to Bradley's international designation, with regular shipments to Europe, Mexico and Africa. The growth shows no signs of slowing; in January alone, shippers reported moving 27.6 million pounds of cargo through Bradley, up 43 percent from the same month a year earlier.

title: Hot News: Latin Lives. Rock Rules.
description: THE FINNISH BROADCASTING COMPANY wrote recently, reminding us of its regular ''News in Latin'' programs sent around the world. ''Nuntii Latini Radiophoniae Finnicae Generalis'' (to those of us who know our ablatives from our datives) runs from world news to science, culture and sports. This is classical Latin. Given the unlikelihood that Suetonius bandied words like ''doo-wop'' or ''megaton,'' our Finnish Latinists must be busy neologists as well as stalwart grammarians.

title: A Younger Audience
description: To the Editor:

title: Women of Letters
description: OLD BOOKS, RARE FRIENDS Two Literary Sleuths and their Shared Passion. By Leona Rostenberg and Madeleine Stern. Illustrated. 275 pp. New York: Doubleday. $21.95.

title: Breaking Out Of the Box
description: In 1961 or '62, my parents went down to their favorite furniture store and bought a ''stereo'' that was built into a buffet-size console. I guess that it was a pretty decent piece of equipment for the day, but its electronic components soon became obsolete, and it spent the next 20 years holding up a lamp and a couple of framed family photos. It was, however, the direct descendant of the elaborate console radios that Gelernter thinks should serve as models for computer design. He should know better.

title: For Muted Bronxville, a Spurt of Construction
description: THIS one-square-mile village, known for its turn-of-the-century housing and quaint Tudor downtown, will soon be adding 188 new apartments in two separate projects, the most construction the village has seen in 25 years.

title: R. A. Sherman 3d, Andrea Gregorich
description: Andrea Barbara Gregorich, the daughter of Barbara B. Gregorich of Buck Hill Falls, Pa., and Gregor F. Gregorich of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Arnold Sherman 3d, a son of Betty A. Sherman of Washington and the late Peter G. Sherman. The Rev. Alfred J. Vito performed the ceremony at St. Bernadette's Roman Catholic Church in Canadensis, Pa.

title: Lacking Luster, U.S. Global Still Pans for Gold
description: WHEN Bre-X Minerals collapsed last month, mutual fund companies across the country raced to distance themselves from their suddenly worthless investments in one of the century's biggest gold mining frauds.

title: Forget the Charts. At the Festivals, Polka Is Forever.
description: The polka, experts agree, came out of Bohemia in the early 19th century, became the rage in Prague, Paris and London, and was even danced at a ball in Calcutta, India, in 1845.

title: Term Limits at Issue For County Officials
description: IT has been debated on the Federal level, but not enacted; it has been discussed at the state level, but not enacted; and now term limits for some elected officials are being seriously debated, and may in fact soon be enacted, on the Westchester County level.

title: Vote on Lilco Plan Fails to Silence Critics' Attacks
description: WHEN trustees of the Long Island Power Authority voted last week to approve a $7.3 billion partial public takeover of Lilco, their widely expected endorsement advanced a plan by Gov. George E. Pataki to lower electric rates.

title: Program Gives Coach Experience
description: Sam Clancy took a winding road to the National Football League, but once he arrived he spent 11 years as a defensive end for Cleveland and Indianapolis. Now, he is taking an equally circuitous path to becoming an N.F.L. coach.

title: A Collective Madness
description: THE SERBS History, Myth and the Destruction of Yugoslavia. By Tim Judah. Illustrated. 350 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $30.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 4 of the Television section today about the Wimbledon tennis tournament includes an outdated reference to Steffi Graf. She has undergone knee surgery, which will keep her from seeking her eighth title in the tournament.

title: Only the Screen Will Change
description: Re: ''Should You Roll Out the Welcome Mat for HDTV?'' (Spending It, April 27), which offered various questions and answers about the technical aspects of digital, high-definition television -- in other words, the new order forced upon the public by the industry and our willing Government.

title: Hal DeWindt, 63, a Producer And an Advocate for Integration
description: Hal DeWindt, a director, producer and actor who was a leader in integrating the performing arts, died on Monday at University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. He was 63 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Robin Winn And C. J. Winfree
description: Robin Joy Winn, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen G. Winn of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Christopher Jules Winfree, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jules P. Winfree of Jupiter, Fla. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Cold Spring Country Club in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y.

title: Growing Pains
description: Dreading marriage to the king of Sicily, the princess prayed all night that she would be ugly on her wedding day. When the groom went to lift the veil, he discovered a bride with full mustache and beard. The wedding was off, the princess crucified. Later beatified as St. Uncumber, the bearded virgin received the prayers of women wishing to be disencumbered from their husbands.

title: At Some Co-ops, Investors Succeed Banks as Lender
description: WHAT led Irene Ryan King to move to Washington Heights from the West 90's in Manhattan 12 years ago was the reality of the Manhattan housing market at the time. ''Washington Heights was one of the few places where I could find a reasonable amount of space for what I could pay,'' said Ms. King, an opera singer and instructor.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: PROSPECT PARK

title: Mr. Moto Does Sophocles
description: PANDAEMONIUM

title: Honoring African Heritage
description: Ignoring the creaking of rusting amusement rides behind him, Ahsana Adae kept his gaze focused ahead, toward the horizon, where the gray expanse of overcast sky met the brackish waves.

title: The French Still Love a Succes de Scandale
description: Women won the lion's share of the prestigious Parisian literary prizes this past season. After the usual editorial politicking, followed by the usual compromises and controversies, the sacrosanct Goncourt, Femina and Medicis prizes were awarded to Pascale Roze, Genevieve Brisac and Jacqueline Harpman for their mildly compelling texts. More interesting, perhaps, are the books by women that have made this year's French best-seller lists.

title: Thomas Coleman, 86, Dies; Killed Rights Worker in '65
description: Thomas L. Coleman, who killed an unarmed civil rights worker then won a jury acquittal by claiming self-defense, died on June 13 at his home in Hayneville, Ala., the scene of the infamous 1965 killing. He was 86.

title: Scout Leader Held in Killing After a Woman's Body Is Found
description: A Scout leader from Corona, Queens, has been arrested in the slaying of a woman whose decomposed body was found Friday afternoon wrapped in plastic garbage bags in the basement of an apartment building near Lefrak City, officials said.

title: Monica Salamon, Gavin Abrams
description: Monica Salamon, the daughter of Eva Salamon and Dr. George Salamon of Dallas, is to be married there today to Gavin Mark Abrams, the son of Cathy Abrams and Dr. Denis Abrams of New York. Rabbi Stefan Weinberg is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Shearith Israel.

title: New Jersey Justice
description: A New Jersey jury decided Friday that Jesse K. Timmendequas deserves to die. In sentencing him to death, the jurors accepted some of Mr. Timmendequas's account of a depraved and abusive childhood. But they agreed that nothing justified his 1994 rape and murder of Megan Kanka, a 7-year-old girl who lived across the street. The killing inspired laws requiring authorities to notify neighbors when sex offenders move into the community. The jurors hadn't been told of Mr. Timmendequas's other assaults against little girls.

title: Northwest Passage
description: OUR group of 38 had been hiking uphill on a warm, sunny day for more than an hour. When the dusty path led us to a rickety bench perched on the hillside, I plopped down onto it, grateful for a rest. Next to me sat Nancy Russell, a woman known in some circles as Godmother of the Gorge for having founded Friends of the Gorge. It was this 17-year-old organization that was instrumental in the creation, by an act of Congress in 1986, of the Columbia River Gorge National Scenic Area. -- one of eight national scenic areas under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Forest Service. Ms. Russell and I gazed out onto a verdant valley sprinkled with colorful wildflowers. To the south, the snowy peak of Mount Hood jutted above the forested hills that rose from the Oregon side of the Columbia River. Directly to the north, on the Washington side, was Mount Adams.

title: Elvis Lives
description: TRADITIONALLY, CROWDS ARE THIN AT the Minnesota State Fair on weekdays. So a couple of years ago, it decided to liven things up with an Elvis lip-sync contest -- a little harmless goofiness, the managers thought. Nobody expected much to come of it, except some free publicity on a slow news day. On the appointed Wednesday morning, however, thousands turned up at the fairgrounds, in St. Paul. And a goodly number of those stolid Minnesotans had dressed up as Elvis (the thin-as-a-rake-and-handsome-as-10-movie-stars young Elvi were significantly outnumbered by the fat old Las Vegas versions) or his consort, Priscilla. There were Elvis babies, too: strange, hairless space creatures with diapers stuffed into tiny Day-Glo jumpsuits and sideburns drawn on with eyebrow pencil.

title: In Research, the Sincerest Form of Concern Is Money
description: ANYONE looking for proof of the political clout attached to women's health issues can find it in the place that provides the truest test of such importance: the fine print of the Federal budget process.

title: Letting It Fly
description: It would be helpful to know if Maynard's former spouse has a second wife now inhabiting her previous home. The rage exhibited could well be nothing but good old jealousy.

title: Gain Without Pain: Fitness a Dose at a Time
description: AT THE Y.M.C.A. where we live in central New Jersey, the pool is busy every day with women swimming laps and taking water-aerobics classes, an all-in-one, moderate exercise package. Wearing buoyancy belts, the women -- of all ages and body types -- participate in a 30-minute-or-more workout that offers safe and easy movement supported by the water, but also the chance to socialize. With 1960's music playing in the background, the class could be called ''Cooling Off With the Oldies.''

title: Frances Blynn, Richard Baxter
description: Frances Adams Blynn, a daughter of Nancy A. Mackenzie of Fairfield, Conn., and Henry Reid Blynn of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard Brian Baxter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Baxter of Grand Rapids, Mich. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: 6 Dead in a Flurry Of Unrelated Killings
description: Six men were killed in separate incidents during a 12-hour period that began on Friday afternoon in the Bronx with the slaying of a man during a dispute, and ended early yesterday on Staten Island when the police found a man shot to death in his car.

title: Elizabeth Kavetas, Lowell Paddock
description: Elizabeth Ann Kavetas and Lowell Clucas Paddock were married yesterday at St. Thomas Church in New York. The Rev. David Sellerie, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Science Fiction
description: There was a time when arbiters of literary taste dismissed science fiction as escapist junk for adolescent boys. Though this judgment did an injustice to the Asimovs, Heinleins and Clarkes who were inventing the modern genre, it held a germ of truth. Science fiction through the 1960's was largely a male enterprise. Stories with female protagonists were few and far between, as were female readers. One of the writers who changed all that was Anne McCaffrey. Her Dragonriders series, begun in 1967, has proved to be abidingly popular with adolescent girls.

title: Joys and Lessons Of Sleep-Away Camp
description: Day camps $(''At Day Camps, Skills Venture Beyond Socializing,'' June 8$) are one venue for Long Island youngsters to learn skills and values. Long Island sleepaway camps offer another.

title: New Museum in Santa Fe Honors O'Keeffe
description: Santa Fe means sun, Southwestern cuisine, contemporary art, opera, Indian crafts and, of course, Georgia O'Keeffe. But visitors to the city who come away sated by most of these attractions are often disappointed by its slim pickings in O'Keeffe artworks. This summer, that deficiency will be corrected when a new museum dedicated to the artist opens downtown, just off the historic central plaza.

title: Better Never Than Late
description: Not content to deliberate endlessly over how to stamp out the national epidemic of flag desecration, Congress has come up with another bright idea: a bill officially apologizing for slavery. Though opposition to this gesture has made strange bedfellows out of Jesse Jackson (who called it ''meaningless'') and Newt Gingrich (''a dead end''), Bill Clinton is already hedging about it, a few Congressmen are calling for reparations, and the debate could easily eat up the full year of the President's promised race initiative.

title: Jennifer Laird, Richard White
description: Jennifer B. Laird, a daughter of Nancy M. Laird and James D. Laird of Westport, Mass., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Richard A. White, a son of Roberta M. White of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, and the late Richard J. White. The Rev. Richard DenUyl Jr., a Congregational minister, officiated.

title: Correction
description: A picture on this page last Sunday showing Russian religious pilgrims was published upside down. Their images are reflected in a puddle and should have appeared at the top.

title: The Tempest
description: THE PERFECT STORM

title: Is There a Doctor in the House? Whatever Kind You Need
description: SURE, there are magazines in the waiting room of the Columbia-Presbyterian Center for Women's Health: Metropolitan Home, Vanity Fair and the like. But the patients would rather yak -- strangers turned friends as they exchange remedies for hot flashes, brittle bones, depression or obesity in what is fast becoming the medical version of the kaffeeklatsch, Tupperware party or consciousness-raising group of old.

title: Strengthening 'Rules of Society' For Violent Youths
description: SPURRED by a sharp increase in the number of crimes committed by teen-agers and the demands of an alarmed populace, legislators in Albany are struggling to revamp the state's juvenile justice system. A sense of urgency has taken hold in the state's capitol in the aftermath of several recent cases that have focused attention on whether to punish young offenders who commit violent crimes or attempt to rehabilitate them. It is a question that divides not only lawmakers and criminal justice officials but the public as well.

title: SoHo-Style 'BID' Moves South
description: When he moved the Knitting Factory from the East Village to TriBeCa in late 1994, the owner, Michael Dorf, wanted to make sure that his performance space would become a welcome member of its new community. Having left Houston Street in part because of his inability to make a dent in the disorder there -- ''No matter what I did, the dirt always came back,'' he said -- Mr. Dorf was determined to keep things clean in his new neighborhood, where he now also lives.

title: Army Must Explain Closing of Sex-Case Hearing
description: In an unusual step, the military's highest court has ordered the Army to explain its refusal to open to the public a hearing involving sexual misconduct charges against the Army's most senior enlisted soldier.

title: Cristina Vidal and John McLaughlin
description: Cristina Clara Vidal, the vice president for operations of Oliver Productions Inc. in Washington, the company that produces ''The McLaughlin Group,'' and John Joseph McLaughlin, the host of the NBC and PBS program, are to be married this afternoon. The Rev. James L. Connor is to perform the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BEFORE THEIR TIME

title: New Transit Links Needed To Serve Riverside South
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Look, Listen, Read

title: Mock Airport Rescue Marks Flag Day Show
description: SEVERAL hundred people were on hand to watch the Navy's special forces stage a dramatic rescue of the Westchester County Airport manager, Joel Russell, in a mock kidnapping by so-called drug smugglers last Saturday. The demonstration at the north end of the County Airport was part of the Sound of Freedom Flag Day ceremonies, sponsored by Westchester County and American Legion Post 29 in Greenwich.

title: Correction
description: Because of a production error, an obituary of Marvin H. Pope yesterday omitted several survivors. Mr. Pope, an authority on ancient Scripture, is survived by his wife, Ingrid Bloomquist Pope; a son, Marvin Jr., and a daughter, Berverly, both of New Haven, Conn.; three stepchildren, Dennis Bloomquist of Great Falls, Va., Diane B. Connelly of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Laurel B. Shields of Austin, Tex.; a sister, Mary Gladys Hodges of Durham, N.C., and eight grandchildren.

title: Prague Puppets
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Prague'' (May 25) did not mention the open-air puppet theater. It was the most delightful thing we did in Prague last year.

title: From One Who Loved His Corvair
description: I was delighted to see the article on the Chevrolet Corvair $(''The Poor Man's Classic Car,'' April 6$). In 1963, I purchased a beautiful Monza convertible -- white with a black top and black interior. It was a classically handsome sports car. Beyond the looks, it performed as well or better than any car I've ever had. It handled wonderfully well. I never had to worry about having enough antifreeze, and in snow that intrepid little scat-back scooted up slippery hills, weaving around wheel-spinning behemoths like a snowmobile.

title: The Subversive
description: Try to explain to a young person why the President of the United States is in the news more for his scandals than for his accomplishments and it becomes apparent that honor and integrity are not issues this country considers when voting. At a time when elected officials are abandoning the public trust to serve as television-show hosts, John McCain is a breath of fresh air.

title: Sibelius a la Russe, Times 3
description: BY ALMOST ANY RECKONING, Jean Sibelius's Violin Concerto in D minor would fall under the rubric of Romanticism. Grand, lyrical, sweeping, virtuosic and, not least, dark, it bears all the markings of a Romantic essay. Were it a painting, it might be signed by Delacroix.

title: Is the Longer Life The Healthier One?
description: TO EMPHASIZE the differences in the health of the sexes, Dr. Eugenia Eng tells students at the University of North Carolina, ''Women are sicker; men die quicker.'' That women in the United States live about seven years longer than men is hardly disputed, though the reason for the gap is a mystery.

title: An Ode to Fitz
description: On first encounter, it is not easy to appreciate New York's consummate man of letters. His genius is not obvious when you come across him in Central Park, on a stretch of the Mall around 67th Street that is named Literary Walk. As you head north on the wide promenade leading to Bethesda Terrace and the Lake, you pass statues of William Shakespeare, Walter Scott, Robert Burns and then one final bronze titan . . . Fitz-Greene Halleck.

title: Bookshelf
description: TREEHOUSE TALES. By Anne Isaacs. Illustrated by Lloyd Bloom. Dutton. $14.99. (Ages 8 to 11) Three short stories from the author of ''Swamp Angel,'' evoking the world of Pennsylvania farm children in the 1880's and combining imaginative fantasy with historical figures.

title: Amory Downes And Kirby Files
description: Elizabeth Amory Downes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Downes of Milton, Mass., was married yesterday to Kirby Scott Files, a son of Mrs. Ralph Epstein of Sonora, Calif., and Wilfred Colison Files Jr. of Homer, Alaska. The Rev. Samuel Sewall Rodman 3d performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Milton.

title: After a Death, Brookhaven Studies Safety
description: The Brookhaven National Laboratory remained open yesterday, but the research center's huge reactors were not operating and no scientific work was going on. Instead, workers and scientists at the Long Island laboratory were meeting, talking and thinking about safety, after a construction worker died in an accident on Friday morning while installing a new sewer line.

title: A 2-Door for Buyers At the Entry Level
description: ABOUT a year ago, the clerk at a service station was admiring the handsome European sedan I was driving, the brand of which I no longer recall.

title: Shelter Is Not a Place Where Pets Are Doomed
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''Release a guy who's jumped bond and fled the country? Never. A violent felon, even if he's been behaving himself on bond, is scooped off the floor and put in his coveralls to await the next bus to Joliet.''

title: Rewiring
description: The Talking Cure The Science Behind Psychotherapy. By Susan C. Vaughan. A Grosset/Putnam Book. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95.

title: How the War Goes On (And On) in Cambodia
description: AS Cambodia wobbles yet again on the edge of a violent implosion, barely five years (and billions of dollars) after the United Nations mounted the largest national recovery mission in its history, the rest of the world might justifiably wonder, as an anonymous diplomat asked last week, whether Cambodians are simply bent on killing each other. ''Let them be,'' seems to be the common sentiment. ''We have done all we can for them.''

description: TALL SHIPS

description: A picture on page 32 of the Arts and Leisure section today with an article about a cappella pop music is published in error in some copies. Corrected versions, showing the House Jacks, portray a small all-male group. The large mixed group in erroneous copies is Talisman.

description: 'TOPPER,' THE MUSICAL

title: Donna Ziegler, Sean O'Sullivan
description: Donna Marie Ziegler, a daughter of Mrs. Helmuth Ziegler of Syosset, N.Y., and the late Mr. Ziegler, was married yesterday to Sean Christopher O'Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick O'Sullivan of Mitchelstown, County Cork, Ireland. The Rev. John Denniston performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Fidel Velazquez, Mexico Titan, Dies at 97
description: Fidel Velazquez Sanchez, a former milkman who helped create Mexico's modern labor movement and then ran it with an iron fist for over half a century, died yesterday in Mexico City of cardiac and respiratory failure. He was 97.

title: Supreme Court Saving Weighty Cases for Last
description: It has been clear for months, as case after major case piled up in the Justices' in-baskets, that the current Supreme Court term is potentially one of the most significant in years. But it became clear only this week that nearly every one of the most important cases would be decided in the term's last few days.

title: Alison Giske, Anthony Pratt
description: Alison Hope Giske, a daughter of Blanche Giske of New York and the late Martin Giske, was married on Thursday evening to Anthony Joseph Pratt, the son of Jeanne and Richard Pratt of Melbourne, Australia. Rabbi Arthur Schneier officiated at the Sherry Netherland in New York.

title: Pilgrims
description: To the Editor: All I can say about Robert Packard's car trip along the pilgrim's route ''On the Road to Santiago'' (April 27) is that one person's decaying and decrepit town can be someone else's romantic and historic vision of another time and place.

title: Giuliani Defends Parks On Monitoring of Beach
description: Mayor Giuliani defended the New York City Parks Department yesterday after a 14-year-old girl apparently drowned off a closed section of Rockaway Beach in Queens.

title: Celebrating Life After a Dance With Death
description: THE CHOREOGRAPHER Anna Halprin says she remembers the day some 25 years ago when, as she lay stricken with cancer, she had a vision of a black bird, which she interpreted as a messenger of death. When she told the bird that she hadn't finished her work on earth, she says, the bird relented, promising that she could remain here, provided that she used dance in the service of peace and love.

title: New York May Use Money to Aid Children
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of New York said on Friday night that he would urge legislative leaders to dedicate half the money the state would receive under the legal settlement with the tobacco industry to establish a program providing medical coverage to hundreds of thousands of uninsured children each year.

title: Lael A. Iozzo, Peter S. Brodsky
description: Lael Alexandria Iozzo, a daughter of Karen Aberle of New York and Patric M. Iozzo of Dallas, was married last evening to Peter Samuel Brodsky, the son of David M. Brodsky of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Barbara B. Brodsky. Rabbi Richard Jacobs performed the ceremony at the Dallas Museum of Art.

title: Christine Stelben and Sean Connolly
description: Christine Alyce Stelben, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Stelben of Darien, Conn., was married there last evening to Sean Timothy Connolly, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Connolly of Waccabuc, N.Y. The Rev. Terence Attridge performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: Software Helps Cut Patient Costs
description: CONSIDER the advantages of this scenario: a visit to your primary-care doctor indicated that the medication you had been using to control hypertension is no longer working. The doctor considers all the factors and looks to other pharmaceuticals to control the condition.

title: Joanna Lawrence, Dean Schwartz
description: Joanna Lawrence, the daughter of Sherry and Lawrence S. Lawrence of Locust Valley, N.Y., was married last evening to Dean Adam Schwartz, a son of Linda and Harold Schwartz of Wayland, Mass. Rabbi Laurence A. Kotok officiated at Harrison House in Glen Cove, N.Y.

title: Environmental Groups Say Gore Has Not Measured Up to the Job
description: Vice President Al Gore, one of the environmental movement's steadiest allies, is under attack from major conservation groups in an unlikely turn that carries important implications for environmental policy as well as Presidential politics.

title: New Bishop of Trenton Frets Over the Poor and His Priests
description: Just because Bishop John M. Smith will soon be appointed head of the Trenton diocese -- with 700,000 Roman Catholics in 126 parishes -- doesn't mean he intends to be unapproachable. If poking fun at himself charms and disarms people, making them receptive to his spiritual advice, he'll willingly tell them, for instance, of his first day at the Trenton diocese headquarters.

title: Girls Light Up, While Women Struggle to Quit
description: Debbie Sanders is wavering. She has already confessed to the eight other women gathered on this dreary May evening for the weekly meeting of a smoking cessation group at the Hines Veterans Administration Hospital in suburban Chicago. After a stretch with no cigarettes, she says she has been smoking three or four a day and telling herself she might revise her goal from quitting smoking to limiting it.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Three-Week Festival At Sarah Lawrence
description: FOR 15 years, Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers offered a distinguished cycle called Summer Evenings, but when Kenneth Wentworth stepped down as director a few years ago, the series faltered, then disappeared. Next Sunday at 8 P.M., summer music returns to the campus with the opening of a three-week festival in Reisinger Hall under the direction of Sung-Rai Sohn, first violinist of the college's resident Laurentian String Quartet and conductor of its student-community orchestra.

title: WOMEN'S HEALTH
description: From women's clinics to breast cancer treatments to medical experts for the teen-age set, women have become the focus of medical care and health care marketing as never before. Today in Section 14, a national New York Times-CBS News survey on women's attitudes toward health, an essay by Anna Quindlen on (shhh!) menopause, Jane Brody on what women want to know about their own well-being, and a resource guide for those who want more.

description: Appearing together to mark what they said was an important moment, Cambodia's rival Prime Ministers announced today that the Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, had been captured and that they would ask the United Nations to help put him on trial.

description: In a red floral, ribboned shirt, Brian Standing Bear Wilkes waves a turkey feather over a bowl of burning sage, fanning its incense toward a woman whose arms are outstretched like eagle wings. When Mr. Wilkes nears her left arm, the herb crackles wildly, telling him of pain in that area.

title: Jordan Most, Laura Ruttenberg
description: Laura Amy Ruttenberg, the daughter of Suzanne W. Ruttenberg and David A. Ruttenberg, both of New York, is to be married today to Jordan Fredric Most, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert S. Most of Barrington, R.I. Rabbi John Haddon is to perform the ceremony at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: The ''Your Home'' column on June 8, about ways in which title to real estate can be held, misstated the availability of the form known as ''tenancy by the entirety.'' That form of ownership, available to married couples only, can be used in New York and New Jersey for any real estate; it is not confined to a principal residence. (''Tenancy by the entirety'' is not recognized in Connecticut.)

title: Making Sense of Breast Cancer Treatments
description: In the moment when a woman is told that she has breast cancer, two simultaneous and contradictory impulses arise: She has an immediate need for more information and a mental block against seeking it. Thirty-eight-year-old Lori Plager described that moment of truth when she learned her diagnosis as the beginning of Mr. Toad's wild ride.

title: Seeing Upswing For U.S.
description: MICHAEL ELLIOTT and his wife, Emma Oxford, are at home here this morning -- hospitable and at ease. Mr. Elliott, from Liverpool, England, is on a roll these days. Last year, he became editor of Newsweek's three international magazines, and before that, he had been Washington bureau chief for The Economist.

title: The Smithsonian Celebrates Barbicide, A Barbershop Germ Killer Born in Brooklyn
description: Fifty years ago, a wizard with bushy eyebrows hunched over the bathtub in his Brooklyn apartment, intensely mixing poisonous chemicals. Gradually, a deep blue emerged. It stained the bathtub, but it would also come to revolutionize barber shops across America and, ultimately, the globe. Barbicide had been born.

title: Estrogens au Naturel
description: No medicine is prescribed more often in the United States than Premarin, the most common form of hormone replacement therapy. But some women, concerned about links between extended use of drugs like Premarin and some forms of cancer, have been trying something else: foods like soy, flax, yams and herbs that contain estrogenic substances.

title: A Low Price for Better Health Care
description: THE explosive growth of Medicare and Medicaid continues to take its toll in the struggle to balance the Federal budget -- and one big victim is investment in basic medical research. That is unfortunate because an increase of just a few billion dollars in research could drastically reduce the cost of Americans' health care.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Lobby Light Show

title: A Dream Grows in Brooklyn
description: WHEN the Regional Plan Association published a study in 1983 arguing that the way to reverse the deterioration of downtown Brooklyn was to turn it into the city's third central business district, after downtown and midtown Manhattan, the outcome was anything but certain. The uncertainties continued over the years even as the cluster of buildings known as Metrotech Center rose and filled with offices; one developer, after years of frustration, pulled down a billboard promising a hotel's imminent arrival.

title: Jennifer Wallace, Billy Dobbs Jr.
description: Jennifer Anne Wallace, the daughter of Anne M. Wallace of Brookline, Mass., and Caleb E. Wallace of Sanibel Island, Fla., was married yesterday to Billy Dean Dobbs Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dobbs Sr. of Madera, Calif. The Rev. David D. Holroyd, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's-by-the-Sea Chapel in York, Me.

title: As Barnes & Noble Looms, Two Bookstores Consolidate
description: Three months before it is scheduled to open, the first Barnes & Noble superstore in Brooklyn has claimed a victim. In anticipation of stiff competition from the retail juggernaut, the owners of Booklink Too in Park Slope have decided to consolidate their operations and close one of their two small bookstores.

title: Deindustrializing the Nazis
description: THE DOG KING By Christoph Ransmayr. Translated by John E. Woods. 355 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.

title: Pap Smears, Once a Reassuring Routine, Now Create Anxiety
description: ONE of the most disquieting trends in women's medicine has been the sharp rise in the number of inconclusive Pap smears. The increase does not mean that cervical cancer is becoming more prevalent. Rather, doctors and insurers say, it is a direct result of a huge increase in the number of malpractice suits brought against pathologists for missing cervical cancer.

title: Answering the Phone as an Act of Revenge
description: IT'S seven o'clock, and Nicole is on the phone demanding to know how you are this evening. Of course, Nicole doesn't really care, so long as you are breathing and willing to listen to her scripted pitch for a home equity loan from some bank with a name that sounds like a greeting-card imprint.

title: At UConn, Winning Does Not Add Up
description: The vivid images were carried from coast to coast. An undefeated women's basketball team, the 1995 national champions, with ''Connecticut'' on their jerseys. Sellout crowds in Gampel Pavilion, an adoring following that demonstrated the potential of a well-marketed team of college women.

title: Correction
description: An opera listing and a picture caption on page 41 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Opera Manhattan's production of ''Cleopatre'' on Thursday include an outdated reference to the title role. Florence Quivar has withdrawn because of an injury and will be replaced by the mezzo-soprano Jane Gilbert.

title: The Contraception Conundrum: It's Not Just Birth Control Anymore
description: CONTRACEPTION is no problem -- if you happen to be a camel. Some pebbles in the uterus will do it. So why is human contraception so complicated? The quick answer is that camels are not worried about sexually transmitted diseases.

title: When DeMille Was More Auteur Than Showman
description: SMELLING POTENTIAL TROUBLE, Cecil B. DeMille took no chances when the cameras rolled for his epic ''The King of Kings.'' To keep scandal at bay, all the players, from the stately H. B. Warner as Jesus to Sally Rand (in her pre-fan days) as a handmaiden to Mary Magdalene, were required to sign agreements that they would behave in an exemplary fashion on and off the set. That also went for the director, who, it is said, kept his mistress away by creating a role for her in another film.

description: Buoyed by New York's growing reputation as a safe and welcoming city, Manhattan hotels continued their strong performance in the first quarter of 1997.

description: In describing the David-versus-Goliath nature of her job, Anne Compoccia, the chairwoman of Community Board 1, likes to talk about the TriBeCa bridge. That is the bridge that appears on the opening credits of ''The David Letterman Show,'' brightly arcing across the former West Side Highway linking Stuyvesant High School in Battery Park City to rest of Manhattan at Chambers Street. To Ms. Compoccia, it was almost the bridge that wasn't.

description: FOR even its most dedicated American practitioners, poetry is all too often more than a hobby but less than a job.

description: President Clinton and the leaders of Russia, Japan and Western Europe plunged into the messy business of defining their new roles in the global economy today, with Russia pressing for quick entry into the World Trade Organization and Europe struggling to save its effort to unify under a single currency.

title: A Daydream About Elvis Inspires a Ballet
description: THERE ARE THOSE WHO will swear that they saw Elvis at the supermarket. Dennis Nahat, the artistic director and choreographer for the Cleveland-San Jose Ballet, says he saw him at a ballet board meeting in 1994. Daydreaming, Mr. Nahat looked out a window and there was Elvis, on stage at the Fox Theater in Detroit.

title: Fan Friendly
description: Major League Baseball's first attempt at interleague play was hailed as a success last week, certainly as far as attendance was concerned. Each of the 24 games drew an an average of 34,992 fans -- 35 percent more than the average for all previous games this season.

title: Men and Women, by the Numbers
description: The difference in the health of the sexes are not straightforward. The gap in life expectancy continues to grow, even as the difference in death rates from some killers like heart disease, lung cancer and AIDS declines. Here are some measures of the health status of each sex:

description: YOU'RE a 16-year-old girl, and you've done something dumb. You've had impetuous, unprotected sex with a boy you don't know well, and now you're suffering symptoms that fill you with fear and dread -- fear that you have caught something and dread of the doctor's visit you know you have to make.

description: In the tax legislation he submitted early this month, Representative Bill Archer, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, proposed raising more than $4 billion in the next decade by trimming and eventually abolishing the Federal tax subsidy for ethanol.

title: Dolls Made by Homeless on Display
description: THERE is a rag doll on display at the White Plains Public Library that has the word ''Better'' stitched on one arm and the word ''Lately'' on the other. The woman who made the doll is homeless. When she was asked what she would like to name her new creation, she answered '' 'B.L.' -- this doll had some problems but she's doing better lately.''

title: Suzanne Proujan, Stephane Weber
description: Suzanne Jeanette Proujan, the director of research in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's office of communications, was married yesterday to Stephane Andre Weber, the pastry chef at Tropica Bar and Seafood House in New York. The Mayor performed the ceremony at City Hall.

Shorten of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The Rev. Dr. John Turner Ames performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: The Day My Modem Called 911
description: MANY people need tremendous self-discipline to work in a home office. But I can't stay out of mine. So it was not unusual that I was on line one Sunday morning last year, working on a project while getting ready to attend a brunch.

The Rev. Bob Stevenson, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the Ehrman mansion at Sugar Point State Park.

title: For Hot Flashes, See Chapter 7
description: In the last decade, there has beem explosion of information about women's health. Here is a selective list of resources recommended by staff writers of The New York Times and by experts in the field. Information from these sources should not be considered a substitute for consultation with a health professional. An expanded version is available on the Inernet. The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com.

title: Low Taxes in a Town With 60% Parkland
description: THERE was a time before the strip malls were built in Stony Point, the northernmost town in Rockland County, when the roads were dirt and Main Street bustled with businesses like Malloy's Pharmacy and Vic & Lou's Barbershop.

title: Strasbourg
description: To the Editor: As one who has spent many happy hours lingering in the great cathedral of Strasbourg and wandering the varied streets of that charming city, I enjoyed Anne Roston's article on its delights (''What's Doing in Strasbourg,'' May 16).

title: The Subversive
description: Your fine article on John McCain had one error -- your reporter did not interview me but said I thought negatively of Senator Fritz Hollings. In fact, I think very highly of Senator Hollings, and we worked together closely.

title: Els Hits His Stride as Woods Hits a Rough Patch
description: It just might be true these days that it is better to be Ernie Els than Tiger Woods.

title: Moscow On the Make
description: Your article fails to cite the percentage of Russians working for the ''free enterprise'' dreams of others -- namely, wage laborers. If the five people you portrayed represent a cross section of the new Russia, the implication is that four-fifths of the people there are entrepreneurs of one sort or another.

title: Seeking a Public Health Solution for a Problem That Starts at Home
description: IN THE 1970's, the criminal justice system in the United States woke up to the problem of domestic violence. Since then, women's advocates and policy makers nationwide have been pushing the health care system to focus on domestic violence as a public health problem that sends thousands of women to hospital emergency rooms each year.

title: The American Way of Dying Is Increasingly in a Hospice
description: The term hospice, which comes from the same Latin root as hospitality, has been used for centuries to describe a place of shelter and rest for weary or sick travelers. According to the National Hospice Organization, the term was first applied to specialized care for dying patients in 1967 at St. Christopher's Hospice in a suburb of London.

title: Despite Warnings, the Sales of Diet Drugs Soar
description: WEIGHT-LOSS experts have yet to create a silver bullet for fighting fat, but consumers are searching harder than ever for one. From 1995 to 1996, sales of anti-obesity drugs nearly tripled to $526 million from $179 million.

title: Pettitte Is Unsure, And It Shows
description: Just when the Yankees were feeling a bit calmer in their topsy-turvy world, they received a jolt today after the usually reliable Andy Pettitte had trouble against the Cleveland Indians. Pettitte added to an already depressing scene, after the 13-4 loss, by saying that he is sometimes so indecisive about pitch selection that it has become a mental burden.

title: Swiss Join NATO Plan, Easing a Long Isolation
description: In a first step away from its traditional isolationism, Switzerland has joined NATO's security cooperation pact, called the Partnership for Peace. But Swiss officials emphasize that their country's participation will be limited.

title: After Schulman, Two Are Running In White Plains
description: THE regulars at P&P; Delicatessen do not hesitate when asked who should be the next mayor of White Plains. The answer comes as easily as their morning coffee orders: Joseph M. Delfino.

title: The Secret Joy of Oceanside Preserve
description: LAST summer when my husband and I walked through the Rachel Carson Wetlands Preserve near Kennebunk, Me., we saw one blue heron and felt dozens of mosquitoes.

title: Another Center Aids the Childless
description: I am writing to call your attention to an inaccuracy in the article ''Childless Couples Give Nature a Push'' $(April 20$), which states that the Fertility and Hormone Center in Dobbs Ferry is ''the only such hospital-affiliated institution currently serving Westchester County.''

title: Black and White in the Jury Room
description: IS it reasonable to expect a juror to put aside (by command of the court) a conscious bias, a persistent memory or the emotional fallout of an anguished time in order to look at a case unencumbered by the weight of such things?

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negoitiations began that ended in a sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Tripling the Flavor of Cherries in Cake, Ice Cream and Sauce
description: FRESH ripe cherries, one of the glories of early summer, should be selected with care. At their best, they are firm, glossy and have pliant green stems. They burst with juice and rich winey flavor.

description: A WINDFALL for the contact lens wearers of America is becoming distinctly visible on the consumer horizon.

title: Forgotten Cemetery to Be Restored
description: A five-year battle over a playground in Flushing and the all-but-forgotten remains of more than 1,000 blacks and Indians buried beneath it has ended.

title: Early Bird
description: When the early bird sings at 4 A.M., the only other sound is the dogs running out their dreams at the foot of the bed. Somewhere on the Atlantic the sun is already rising, but in the Berkshires the sky at that hour is no brighter than tarnished silver, a superior dullness in the eastern windows. The early bird is extremely early, and it seems to have perched on the bedside lamp, so piercing is its call. In the phonetic language birders use to represent birdsong, the early bird says: ''Why don't -- you get -- up? Why don't -- you get -- up?'' But at 4 A.M. it is all too easy to drift back to sleep. Soon the early bird seems to be saying, in dreamlike fashion: ''Guess what -- you've just -- won! Guess what -- you've just -- won!'' It is worth putting on some clothes and going to find out.

title: Getting V.A.T. Back, at a Price
description: FOR travelers, the value-added tax is a pain, pure and simple. Those who shop while traveling are usually paying extra, often without knowing it, for the Irish sweater or the scarf from Paris.

description: To the Editor:

title: For the Disabled: Money for Housing, No Place to Call Home
description: Alicia Garrity's name has been on the waiting list for a spot in one of the state's residences for people with developmental disabilities for eight years. But it is unclear who needs help more: Alicia, the 26-year-old whose cerebral palsy has left her no more capable than a six-month-old infant, or her 48-year-old mother, Judy.

title: What 'Prom Mom' Can Teach Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Sampras Aims to Begin New Wimbledon Reign
description: The more things change, the more they stay the same. This year, for the first time since 1993, Pete Sampras came to Wimbledon as a challenger, not its defending champion. For the first time in six years, he came to Wimbledon without his constant companion, Delaina Mulcahy, from whom he initiated a split just before a seven-year itch, or marriage, set in. For the first time in nine years at Wimbledon, he elected to skip his luxurious hotel suite in bustling London and hunkered down instead on a dead-end lane in suburbia.

title: The Casually Well Dressed On the March
description: Since Armani's baggy suits have become the uniform of nightclub security guards, a look has evolved, often described as ''the Gucci clone.'' In the last year, many designers have been involved in the evolution of this fashion for young men, which combines dressing up and dressing down at the same time: jackets are slightly shaped; shirts are predominantly black with open collars; dress shoes and sandals have blunt, square toes, and gold chains and neckties are banished. The 1950's rat pack silhouette is gone, except the narrow trousers, as jackets are longer and shoulders less padded.

title: Randi Silber And Jeffrey Schor
description: Randi Silber, the daughter of Joyce and Louis Silber of Port Washington, N.Y., was married last evening to Jeffrey Darin Schor, a son of Hope and Robert Schor of Tiburon, Calif. Rabbi Beth Davidson performed the ceremony at the Roslyn Claremont Hotel in Roslyn, N.Y.

title: TOKE ME, ELMO
description: The holiday toy craze of 1996 has sparked a trend in marijuana circles: Tickle Me Elmo pipes. ''It started right after Christmas,'' says a craftsman in Manhattan who makes Elmo pipes. ''Everybody started asking me could I make Elmo.'' Elmo as totem makes some sense, since potheads can probably sympathize with the ''Sesame Street'' regular's nonstop laughter. Not laughing is the Children's Television Workshop, which has already forced one store in Northfield, N.J., to stop selling Elmo-themed merchandise. We hope that's the end of it, says Lisa Sherman-Cohen, a senior publicist at C.T.W. It probably isn't. Elmo is my biggest seller, says the pipe maker gleefully. I really don't think it'll die down at all.

title: Baptists Boycott The Magic Kingdom
description: As a transmitter of moral values, even the Southern Baptists, the nation's largest Protestant denomination, may be no match for communications conglomerates like the Walt Disney Company.

title: Alexis Wolf and Philip Nykamp
description: Alexis Ambler Wolf, the daughter of Sandra Cantey of Fort Worth and Peter Wolf of New York, was married yesterday to Philip Dean Nykamp, a son of Reva Nykamp of Holland, Mich., and the late Roger Nykamp. The Rev. Samuel Edleman performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: A Bright Job Outlook for the Class of '97
description: TIMING is everything. Only a few short years ago, employment prospects for college graduates were bleak. This year, with the economy booming and unemployment at its lowest point since the late 1980's, the job outlook for the class of '97 is the brightest it has been in years.

description: RUN-FLAT tires -- now on a handful of sports cars -- are finally making an appearance in the mass market.

description: THERE has never been a business lobby quite like Big Tobacco. For decades, its clout in Washington and state capitals was legendary, its prowess acknowledged by friend and foe.

title: Albany Impasse May Delay $1.4 Billion Subway Project

title: Top-Seeded at Wimbledon: Sampras, Hingis and Torrential Downpours

title: Neglected Yank Gets In Lineup
description: The Yankees' starting left fielder mocked himself before the game for barely playing in three weeks, causing his teammates to laugh. He grabbed the first ball hit to him and threw out a runner at second base, causing his manager to smile. He singled in his second at-bat, causing his manager to grin.

title: Man Held After Bodies Of Family Are Found
description: North Carolina police arrested a Connecticut man yesterday after the bodies of his wife and two children were found in their home here.

title: A Hot Blast Heralds Summer's First Weekend
description: By noon yesterday in Manhattan, the heat and humidity of the first weekend of summer was enough to send the horses pulling carriages of tourists through Central Park back to their barns.

title: Left Out of Succession Fight, A Rising Star Defects to Upstart
description: What's the market value of being an AT&T alumnus?

title: Off to See the Wizard, for One, in Bryant Park
description: For Jim Roderick, who arrived in Bryant Park at 5 P.M., there was space on the grass for 20 friends, wine, cheese and bread, and a four-hour wait for Dorothy and Toto to light up the screen.

title: Rocky Mountain Cram Session
description: President Clinton and the leaders of Russia, Japan and Western Europe emerged from their marathon meetings in Denver over the weekend like tired college students who had endured a grueling round of final exams. Their joint declarations covered such a bewildering array of subjects, from Bosnia to global warming to trade barriers, that it was hard to imagine that they did justice to any of them. The blurred focus obscured a couple of significant accomplishments, however. One was the further integration of Russia's President, Boris Yeltsin, into the West's concerns, and the other was a new economic agenda for the world's richest countries.

title: Songs of a Golden Age Wrapped in Maturity
description: The two most anticipated concerts of the opening weekend of the JVC Jazz Festival, one by Aretha Franklin and the other by the Brazilian singer Caetano Veloso, hinted at what jazz festivals now mean internationally: They are an excuse to program more or less anything mildly related to the African diaspora.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks were trading moderately higher here today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 74.81 points, or three-eigths of 1 percent, at 20,460.35. On Friday, the Nikkei index lost 122.31 points.

title: It Tolls For Thee
description: The reported capture of Pol Pot in the Cambodian jungle is a dramatic reminder of how little the world has done to prevent political mass murder or punish its perpetrators. But it also points to something else. Notwithstanding that failure of leadership, the ideal of human rights and a regime of law has a deeper hold on the human imagination today, everywhere, than it has ever had.

title: Ernest Pascucci, 29, Architectural Critic
description: Ernest Charles Pascucci, an architectural theorist, editor and critic, died on June 12 in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. He was 29 and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: The Tango Travels a Bit But Settles For Lust
description: ''Forever Tango,'' which opened on Thursday night at the Walter Kerr Theater, will probably be considered a must-see show by fans of that popular, sexy Argentine dance. Ordinary mortals may find the evening an enjoyable summer entertainment with terrific music and considerably cruder dances. But the superficiality of ''Forever Tango'' suggests a touring show designed to cash in on the international tango craze.

title: Correction
description: The Things column in the Styles pages yesterday, about magnetic studs as a replacement for body piercing, described possible uses of the devices incorrectly. The company, Gravity Free Factory, recommends that the studs be used only on noses, lips and ears, not on the tongue.

title: Bridge
description: One women's team has already claimed the right to represent the United States in the World Championships in Tunisia in October, but a second spot remains in doubt here today. Marinesa Letizia, Lisa Berkowitz, Jill Meyers, Randi Montin, Tobi Sokolow and Mildred Breed won the final of the Women's International Team Trials on Saturday.

title: Scandals Mar Last Leg of Korean Leader's Term
description: As President Kim Young Sam approaches the last stretch of his term, the biggest problem he faces has nothing to do with his policies or his politics.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Accounts
description: * Reynolds Metals Co. consumer products division, Richmond, consolidated its account at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., by shifting the duties for Cut-Rite wax paper, Paper Maid parchment paper and Reynolds Oven Bags to that agency from West Wayne, Atlanta. Billings for the reassigned brands were estimated at more than $5 million and for those for the consolidated account were put at $25 million to $30 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: Anthony Maltese, Pastor, 68
description: The Rev. Msgr. Anthony Louis Maltese, pastor of the combined parishes of Immaculate Conception and Assumption Roman Catholic Churches in Tuckahoe, N.Y., died on June 15 at his home in Tuckahoe. He was 68.

title: Pol Pot Reported Seen
description: A senior Cambodian Army general said he saw the Khmer Rouge leader yesterday in northern Cambodia, the first reported sighting of Pol Pot by someone outside the Khmer Rouge since 1981. Page A6.

title: Reassessing the Role of Modern Acting, at Its Birthplace
description: It was one of those urgent, endless conversations that have always been the province of the young and the idealistic. Exactly 100 years ago two Russian men, their eyes aflame with passion for a new idea, met at a Moscow restaurant called the Slavyansky Bazaar.

title: Road Project Rated Wasteful
description: A plan to complete the final link of State Route 29 just south of Trenton has been rated one of the nation's 37 most wasteful road projects, a coalition of taxpayer and environmental groups said Thursday. Construction is scheduled to start next year on the 1.7-mile, four-lane connector, which has a price tag of $90 million. On average, one lane of interstate highway costs about $2.4 million a mile, according to a 1995 Federal report.

title: Loving to Hate Yankees
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cruelly Efficient Act
description: Bloomsday, 5:15 P.M., June 16, 1997; a new edition of ''Ulysses'' was about to be launched. I was in a pub at the corner of North Great George's Street. The publisher was buying drinks, the place was crowded, the noise deafening, the TV in the far corner vainly on at full volume. The editor, Danis Rose, was standing behind me at the bar. As we edged out, I heard fragments of TV news: I.R.A. . . . Lurgan . . . two policemen dead. I thought it must be a program that was replaying old footage, although as I walked up the street, it nagged at me that I could not remember any Royal Ulster Constabulary men being killed in Lurgan. It was only at dinner afterward that I heard the details and that full realization dawned.

title: Hospitals Face A U.S. Inquiry In Newark
description: A nonprofit hospital network owned by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark is the subject of a Federal investigation into whether it made illegal political contributions and violated Federal law by paying doctors for referring Medicaid and Medicare patients, court documents show.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JACKIE CAIN, 69, and ROY KRAL, 75, are celebrating more than one milestone of togetherness this month. Last week they marked their 48th wedding anniversary, and tonight they are to be honored for their 50 years as Jackie and Roy, singers of a variety of jazz, Latin and pop genres, always with a tinge of jazz.

title: Barneys: Good Riddance
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Names Italian Expert on the Mafia to Its Top Anti-Crime Post
description: One of Italy's top experts on the Mafia has been appointed the United Nations' leading official on international crime.

title: Kenneth Mott, 58, Tropical Disease Expert
description: Dr. Kenneth Eugene Mott, who led a campaign against tropical diseases for the World Health Organization, died June 14 in George Washington University Hospital in Washington, where he was undergoing treatment. He was 58.

title: Treasury's Calendar of Auctions Offers Sales of Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.

title: Tiger's Best and Worst On Display on No. 10
description: ON the green of the 314-yard 10th hole, a short par 4, at the Buick Classic yesterday, Neal Lancaster was lining up a 15-foot putt when Fulton Allem warned, ''Watch out, Tiger's tee shot is coming.''

title: A New Edition Purges What May Have Been Joyce's Errors and Enrages Critics
description: Even James Joyce didn't always know the precise words he intended to use in ''Ulysses,'' his masterpiece and a book that was as challenging in the writing as it is in the reading.

description: FOR the first time in a long while, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has some good news for its riders.

title: The Runner-Up Is Familiar: Maggert
description: In 10 seasons of professional golf, Jeff Maggert has earned $3,995,933 in 185 tournaments with only 1 victory, the 1993 Walt Disney World/Oldsmobile Classic. And today in the Buick Classic, he finished second. Again.

title: Pulsipher to Pitch in Relief
description: If Bill Pulsipher is recalled from Class AAA Norfolk, he will almost certainly be used in relief, Mets Manager Bobby Valentine said yesterday.

title: Clinton Calls Tobacco Deal A Beginning, Even if Flawed
description: President Clinton today encouraged critics of the historic tobacco agreement announced on Friday to regard it as a starting point, rather than as a finished product, and said he himself feared that it might hobble the Government's regulation of nicotine.

title: Any Omens? Colony's Soothsayers Won't Say
description: In the shadow of an old Buddhist temple, a curving alleyway known as Soothsayer's Arcade is full of tiny stalls where fortunetellers routinely predict the future and, for a few dollars extra, unlock some of life's deepest mysteries.

title: Playing With Guns
description: There is a bill in the State Legislature in Albany that was designed to prevent the violent and utterly senseless deaths of youngsters like Levar McGriff, 10, Jonathan Fitzgerald, 10, Amir Smith, 12, and James Carl Baisley, 13.

title: Real Choices on the Budget
description: The House and Senate will vote this week on tax and spending bills. Both versions will drive up the deficit shortly after 2002 and shower tax cuts on the nation's wealthiest families. Nevertheless, there are important differences between the bills and important battles to be won on the floor this week and in conference later on.

title: Call It the Penance Chase, And Everett Saves the Mets
description: The Mets have three teams to vault in the National League East before they are legitimate contenders, but they absolutely lead the league in penance. In one corner of the clubhouse yesterday, first baseman John Olerud confessed that he should have been holding a runner in a critical situation, and in the other corner John Franco admitted he pitched badly. The manager, Bobby Valentine, confessed that if he had told Olerud to hold the runner, Franco might not have been in jeopardy.

title: CHRONICLE
description: More than 50 years ago, JACK HAUSMAN, a retired textile company executive, and his wife, Ethel, tried to find help for their son Peter, who was born with cerebral palsy after a difficult delivery.

title: Frances Foster, 73, Actress And Director in the Theater
description: Frances Foster, a character actress, a stage director and a founding member of the Negro Ensemble Company, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Fairfax, Va. She was 73 and had homes in Manhattan and in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Ex-Counselor Accused of Abusing Teen-Agers
description: A former guidance counselor at a Brooklyn junior high school has been arrested and charged with the rape and sexual abuse of three teen-age sisters he met at the school and who later moved into his Bay Ridge apartment with their mother, the police said yesterday.

title: For Some Women, Estrogen Has Only Benefits

title: Dependable Partisans Celebrate 15 Years of Sparring
description: The ''Crossfire'' gang spent last week celebrating the program's birthday. ''Thank you for 15 wonderful years,'' rejoiced Patrick J. Buchanan, joining his dependable sidekick, John H. Sununu, and his loyal opposition, Geraldine A. Ferraro and Bill Press, in a chorus-line demonstration that opposites attract audiences.

title: Wells Feels the Pain After Staying in Game
description: David Wells chugged after Manny Ramirez's innocent trickler between the mound and third base in the fourth inning today, not knowing his afternoon would soon be shaped by one clumsy misstep. Wells's left shoe got stuck in the grass as he tried to pivot and field the ball, forcing him to land awkwardly. He felt pain in his lower back.

title: Arson Case Turned Into an Offer He Couldn't Refuse
description: For Detective Richard Cowan, a nine-year police veteran, it began as a routine arson investigation.

title: Study Says Megan Slaying Fits Pattern for Such Cases
description: Megan Kanka's fatal encounter with Jesse K. Timmendequas in the shadow of her own home three summers ago is typical of the abduction and murder of children over the last 20 years, according to an extensive analysis of such homicides by Washington State's Attorney General.

title: Correction
description: The Inside Art column on Friday misstated the price paid by the National Gallery of Art in Washington for a Winslow Homer painting, ''Home Sweet Home,'' and misidentified the auction house where it was bought. The work sold for $2.64 million (not $24,150) at Christie's (not Sotheby's).

title: Proposed Tax Cuts Would Give Break to Wealthiest, New Study Shows
description: The changes in Federal tax and benefit policies now working their way through Congress would eventually be worth thousands of dollars a year to the 5 million wealthiest families in America, while the 40 million families with the lowest incomes would actually lose money, a new study shows.

title: Land's End Without Leaving Home
description: How could anyone looking for a relaxing vacation spot possibly resist a pitch like this:

title: Swing-Time Harmony, With a Punch
description: Because the Manhattan Transfer has refused to stick to one genre, recording everything from Brazilian sambas to jazz vocalese and rock-and-roll, some view the group as detached musical dilettantes corrupting whatever they touch. And indeed the popular vocal quartet has taken some ill-advised tangents in its 25-year career. But even the Transfer's more foolish ventures have been carried off with a polished joie de vivre. And at Carnegie Hall, where it performed with a pop-jazz sextet, augmented by a 12-piece horn section on Friday as part of the JVC Jazz Festival, the group was in excellent form.

title: For Some Women, Estrogen Has Only Benefits
