title: Chronic-Care Unit for Prison
description: As the number of inmates who die of terminal diseases mostly AIDS -- continues to grow, the state is planning to open its first chronic-care unit at a prison, officials said Friday. The 60-bed unit at the new South Woods State Prison, staffed with doctors hired from outside the prison system, is to open next year. ''This is sort of a logical evolution, given our inmate population,'' Bob McHugh, a State Department of Corrections spokesman, said. Each year, Mr. McHugh said, 100 to 120 inmates die from long-term illnesses.

title: Record Legal Fees Loom as Major Issue in Tobacco Deal
description: The proposed $368.5 billion tobacco settlement is likely to provide plaintiffs' lawyers -- both those representing smokers in lawsuits and those acting for states in Medicaid-related claims -- with the biggest fees in legal history.

title: Effects of Pact's Costs on Industry and Smokers Are Unclear
description: For years, the tobacco industry and its critics have disagreed, in public at least, about why people smoke. Are they heavily swayed by marketing promotions and advertising? By where smoking is allowed? By the relatively low cost of cigarettes and smokeless tobacco in the United States, compared with other wealthy countries?

title: East Harlem's Needs Conflict: A Place to Play Versus a Place to Live
description: In New York City, dealing with certain facts of life, every day of your life, is a given. Where to put all the people. How to assure a certain quality of life. Preserving the child in childhood.

title: 6 Grand Winners In Ad Competition
description: The New York Festivals has named six grand Best of Show winners at its 39th annual international print and radio competition. Bozell Worldwide in Southfield, Mich., part of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, won for best magazine campaign, for the Chrysler Corporation's Jeep line of vehicles. Jupiter Drawing Room in Cape Town, South Africa, won for best newspaper advertisement, for Sabre, a business trade publication. Lewis Moberly in London won for best design, for a brochure for TBWA International, the agency network owned by Omnicom Group.

title: Dropping a Sure Path to the Top To Follow a Technological Dream
description: Alex J. Mandl was once in line to run the nation's largest telephone company, but you would hardly know it from a visit to his suburban Washington office.

title: Correction
description: An obituary on Friday about Lev Kopelev, a Soviet human rights activist and writer, referred incorrectly to one of his daughters. Svetlana Ivanova was born to Mr. Kopelev's second wife, Raissa Orlova, not to his first wife.

title: Girl Games on Computers, Where Shoot 'em Up Simply Won't Do
description: Laura Groppe sat in front of a computer as several male programmers looked on, demonstrating to a visitor the difference between boy games and girl games.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: UNDERCOVER CARTER -- A detective went on an undercover odyssey through New York City's garbage-hauling industry -- dining with mobsters, loading garbage trucks, evading thugs -- and ended up helping to overhaul it. B3.

description: The tobacco farmer lunged forward, his face red with anger at the latest provocation from Washington.

title: A Musician Who Revels In Finding A New Way
description: Greg Osby's concert on Friday night at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, part of the Texaco New York Jazz Festival, showed a musician reveling in a new, fluorescent chapter of his career.

title: C-Net Promotes a Novel Idea: The Internet Should Be Easy
description: Despite its youth, the Internet industry is already littered with the remains of consumer on-line services that failed. But C-Net Inc., a source of on-line information, thinks it has found a winning formula.

title: Army Renews Pact With Y.& R.
description: The United States Army has renewed its advertising and marketing contract with Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York for another five-year term.

description: American consumers are buying far fewer televisions this year than manufacturers had expected because of fears that those sets may soon be obsolete.

title: James H. Wall, 94, Innovator in Psychiatry
description: Dr. James Hardin Wall, who improved the diagnosis and treatment of mental disorders and alcoholism in Westchester County, died on June 13 at his retirement home in Freeport, Me. He was 94 and formerly lived in White Plains.

title: Sue Sumii, Writer, 95, Dies; Ally of Japan's Untouchables
description: Sue Sumii, a fiery human rights campaigner whose landmark novel sold 8.3 million copies and helped change attitudes toward Japan's ''untouchables,'' died last Monday. She was 95.

description: To the Editor:

title: Replacing steel wheels with rubber tires may be the road to making high-speed railways a reality.
description: ABE HIRSCHFELD, the parking magnate and real estate developer, is known for his quixotic political campaigns and for his brief, eccentric reign as the publisher of The New York Post. But now Mr. Hirschfeld has distinguished himself in yet another way. He has received a patent at the age of 77.

title: U.S. SPEARHEADING EFFORT TO BRING POL POT TO TRIAL
description: The United States and other countries have asked Canada to be the key partner in an extraordinary effort to take the Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, out of Cambodia to face an international tribunal for crimes against humanity, American and foreign officials said today.

title: Editors Urge Limits on Input By Advertisers
description: Demonstrating how blurred the once-solid line between advertising and editorial content in magazines has become, the American Society of Magazine Editors is now urging editors to resist influence from advertisers over what appears in their publications.

title: FAULTY OVERSIGHT PROFITED OWNERS OF PUBLIC HOUSING
description: James H. Johnson has lived in the same small apartment here at Edgehill Village for 19 years. The ceilings are cracked. Water from the leaky roof has warped the walls. Heaters barely function, and the unit has not been painted since he moved in.

title: Women Over 40 Discovering Competitive Athlete Within
description: Ten years ago, at the age of 37, Mari Jalbing's athletic history amounted to a few games of halfcourt basketball in the eighth grade, when she was more focused on her hair than the hoop. She thought she did not have a competitive bone in her body. Then she joined the masters women's rowing team at the Seattle Yacht Club and discovered the truth.

title: Tobacco Growers Wince
description: In eastern North Carolina, tobacco farmers saw the recently negotiated settlement with cigarette companies as yet another blow. Page B9.

title: Rural Suit for More School Aid
description: For more than 20 years, the court battle about how to pay for the education of the state's poor schoolchildren has focused on the cities. But places like Commercial Township, a struggling farming and fishing community of 4,700 people along Delaware Bay, have more than their share of poverty and decaying schools. So after the State Supreme Court ordered last month that 28 urban districts receive an extra $248 million in state aid, Commercial and about 50 other rural districts decided to sue the state to get a bigger piece of the pie. $(Page A1.$)

title: Els Wins Buick Classic And Ranking as No. 1 in the World
description: Ernie Els might not be the No. 1 golfer in the world in terms of income or adulation or recognition. No, Tiger Woods still leads in those categories. Els simply rules where it counts: on the golf course.

title: Few Paintings or Sculptures, But an Ambitious Concept
description: In a dingy passageway here, a French artist, Suzanne Lafont, has plastered a series of posters tracing the immigrants' route from Turkey to Germany, through Belgrade, Budapest and Vienna. The posters show photographs of anonymous buildings, interchangeable modern boxes on city margins, where poor immigrants live. Elsewhere, an Austrian artist, Martin Walde, is displaying pictures with texts, like film storyboards, skittishly drawn, of the sort of brief, freakish encounters that punctuate city life: one of them involved the sudden appearance of a naked man on a subway car, mop in hand, scrubbing the floor.

title: Songs To Unite Heaven And Earth
description: Aretha Franklin, a preacher's daughter, was in her element and in her glory when she sang at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, the opening night of the JVC Jazz Festival. She was singing gospel music, promising the solace and exaltation of faith in Jesus with one of the greatest voices in American music. She called for healing power; she gently urged listeners to ''give yourself to Jesus,'' she exhorted us to reach for higher ground in a voice that radiated joyful conviction.

title: Dow Jones Markets Names New Officers
description: Dow Jones & Company has filled two crucial jobs in an effort to remake Dow Jones Markets, its troubled electronic markets information service. But the position of technology director, who will lead the service onto the Internet, has not yet been filled.

title: Rural Schools Feel Ignored by Trenton Aid to Poor
description: On its face, this remote township on Delaware Bay has nothing in common with cities like Trenton and Newark. It has no supermarket, no police department, no high school. Only 4,700 people call it home.

title: Caramoor's Pleasure Principle
description: I can't imagine that things often go wrong at Caramoor. The conditions of the place -- the Venetian colonnade around the outdoor stage, the proximity of gardens, the night air, the almost startling presence of the sound inside the tented auditorium -- would all conspire to bring out the best in musicians and audiences. But surely things can rarely go so right as they did tonight at the opening concert of this year's festival.

title: 'Hoop House' Plastic Deal

When the weather warms, the plastic sheeting can be pulled off the frame of a hoop house and the plants grown to market size without being transplanted.

title: A Death In the Minors Leads Mets To Dismiss 3
description: On April 19, the Mets organization was stunned to learn that Tim Bishop, a 20-year-old outfielder on its Class A team in Columbia, S.C., had been killed late the previous night in a car accident. Now, two months later, the Mets have dismissed the manager and two coaches of the Columbia team because, according to a high-ranking official in the Mets' front office, the three men did not appropriately address whether players had been drinking on the team bus before the accident occurred.

title: Selling 'By the Numbers'

title: Credit Report Bill on Agenda
description: Under Federal law, consumers in New Jersey, as in all states, are entitled to a free copy of their credit report if they are unemployed, on welfare or have been refused credit. A bill that the State Assembly is to consider today, however, would entitle consumers to one free credit report a year without any conditions.

title: Farmers' Markets Crop Up
description: Farmers' markets are spreading across the state's cities and towns like zucchini after a hot spell. In 1994, there were three weekly markets outside farm country that exclusively sold New Jersey produce. This year, there are 31. The newest market, next to the PATH station in Hoboken, is to open tomorrow with fruits and vegetables from Denville, Cream Ridge, Wyckoff and Oldwick, among other places. Five other markets are opening this year, according to the North Jersey Farmers' Market Council, including one in Englewood that is to open Friday and others in Newark, River Vale, Roselle Park and Teaneck.

title: At N.A.A.C.P., Talk of a Shift On Integration
description: Facing continued white resistance to busing to achieve school desegregation, an increasingly conservative judiciary and now criticism from inside and outside its ranks, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is rethinking one of its fundamental principles: advocacy of public school integration.

title: Onward, Christian Whippersnappers
description: So Randy Tate is the new executive director of the Christian Coalition. With his receding hairline, he might not look younger than the outgoing leader, Ralph Reed, and he might not be able to discern the Foo Fighters from Chinese food (Mr. Tate's sobriquet, ''Rockin' Randy,'' was coined by a fellow Congressman to poke fun at his lack of musical hipness). But the coalition is putting its faith in numbers. At 31, Mr. Tate is younger than Mr. Reed. In a move similar to the Sierra Club's appointment of a 23-year-old as president last year, the Christian Coalition is expressly hoping that the former Representative from Washington State will expand its appeal to young people.

title: Mexican Leaders Honor a Union Giant, and an Era
description: Government officials and labor leaders turned out today to pay their last respects to Fidel Velazquez Sanchez, the 97-year-old labor patriarch whose death on Saturday marked the end of six decades of unbending top-down control of the Mexican union movement.

title: Tinted Windows
description: Sure, America's G-7 allies were grumbling a bit in Denver over what they considered excessive bragging by President Clinton about how ''America's economy is the healthiest in a generation and the strongest in the world.'' But I say let him brag a little. The fact is he deserves credit for a five-year program of deficit reduction and trade expansion that has lowered inflation and interest rates -- without a recession -- and left enough steam in the economy to finance America's transformation into a much more efficient global competitor.

title: Young Athletes Put Their Spin on What Sport Should Be
description: On Saturday, the first day of summer, blue skies, sparkling water and 30,000 wild and crazy fans formed the backdrop of a production here that is on the verge of becoming this generation's Olympics. It is called the X Games, ESPN's three-year-old invention for those twenty-somethings known as Generation X.

title: Suspect Says He Killed Woman In Fight About Theft From Wife
description: A Scout leader from Corona, Queens, who was arrested in the murder of a woman whose decomposed body was found in a basement near Lefrak City told police that she was his mistress and that he killed her during an argument when he accused her of stealing some of his wife's jewelry, an investigator close to the case said yesterday.

title: Properly Girlish, as Teen-Age Aurora
description: It is a sluggish ''Sleeping Beauty'' that American Ballet Theater has put on the boards this season.

title: Church Groups Use Pressure Tactics in Drug Fight
description: Singing spirituals and chanting against the sale of illegal drugs in their neighborhood, about 80 members of the Mount Zion Baptist Church here took their anti-drug message this afternoon to an area they suspected of being a source of the problem.

title: Major Debuts Add Zest to 'Sleeping Beauty'
description: ''The Sleeping Beauty'' came awake twice on Wednesday when American Ballet Theater presented matinee and evening performances of the Tchaikovsky classic at the Metropolitan Opera House. Each featured different dancers as the spellbound Princess Aurora and in several other leading roles.

title: G.M. and Sony join forces to market cars to moviegoers at a Michigan theater complex.
description: THE next wave in marketing may be coming soon to a theater near you.

title: Computing Giants Join Electronic Games Show
description: Two years ago, Nintendo, Sega, Sony and hundreds of other video game companies abandoned the cluttered floors of huge computer trade shows, setting up the Electronic Entertainment Expo so they could train the spotlight on their own products.

title: On a Cultural Battlefield: Women in the Military
description: GROUND ZERO

title: Jacor a Rising Star Among Radio Networks
description: In just over 18 months, Jacor Communications Inc. has gone from being a bit player in the radio business to one of its rising stars.

title: For Congo's Elmer Gantrys, Flocks to Be Fleeced
description: With the pastor shouting and the choir chanting loudly, all eyes were fixed on the woman with the heavy limp and pained grimace as she stood before the altar in the sweltering church.

title: Jubilation In Sounds Of Bahia
description: One of the bywords of Brazilian culture is anthropophagy, or cannibalism; the culture swallows and transforms anything tasty that arrives from outside. The process continues in Bahia, the state in eastern Brazil that has galvanized the country's music for decades. Two Bahian acts, the group Ara Ketu and the singer Daude, provided a jubilant finale for the Summerstage's Brazilian Music Festival on Sunday afternoon in Central Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSON, WALTER
description: CASSON-Walter. Our deepest condolences are extended to the family of Walter Casson. Walter was a very special person to all of us. title: Paxson Selling Its Radio and Other Assets
description: To help finance its effort to start a national broadcast TV network, Paxson Communications said yesterday that it was selling its radio holdings and other assets for $693 million.

title: Whitman and Lawmakers Back Auto Insurance Bill
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and top Republican legislators agreed today on an automobile insurance bill that ends automatic annual rate increases, prevents insurance companies from dropping policyholders for no reason and cracks down on fraud.

description: In percent

description: To the Editor:

title: Ethicists Struggle Against the Tyranny of the Anecdote
description: FOR those who like their ethics up close and personal, the debate over assisted suicide is encapsulated in a single question: What is your worst nightmare?

title: Student Math Scores' Gain Is the Smallest in Recent Years
description: Elementary and middle school students in the city continued a five-year trend by improving their scores on standardized math tests this year, but the gain of less than one percentage point was considerably less than in previous years.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: WORKFARE CONCERNS -- A workfare participant with heart problems died on the job, prompting concerns over whether New York City can determine whether some laborers are too sick to work. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAINSON, ETHEL C.T.
description: BRAINSON-Ethel C.T. On June 22, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Hyman L. , loving mother of Arthur and Linda. Proud grandmother of Mitchell, David and Daphna, great-grandmother of Gabriel. Dear sister of the late Oscar and cherished sister-in-law of Hannah Tannenbaum. Donations in her memory to United Hebrew Geriatric Center, New Rochelle, NY.

title: Summer's Earrings
description: As fashion retreats gradually from its emphasis on minimalism, jewelry is coming back into focus. For summer, that may mean a strand of beads or just a pair of small earrings.

title: French Child-Porn Dragnet Is Criticized After Suicides
description: Did French gendarmes go too far in a highly publicized sweep across the country last week that picked up 800 people suspected of pedophilia? Justice Minister Elisabeth Guigou wondered today whether they had, after four of the people arrested apparently committed suicide.

title: O.K., So How Many Alabamians Does It Take . . .
description: Alabama's image, often a leaky vessel, is taking on water and wallowing in the swells as the captains of its fate stand defiantly on deck and refuse to steer any course except straight to the reefs.

title: Supreme Court Rules Against Rail Workers
description: The Supreme Court ruled yesterday that 140 pipe fitters and underground workers from Grand Central Terminal exposed to cancer-causing asbestos dust are not entitled to seek damages from the Metro-North Commuter Railroad for emotional distress before the onset of actual disease.

title: The Shape of the Draft? Better Ask Philadelphia
description: They might take Keith Van Horn and then trade him. Or they may select Chauncey Billups and move Allen Iverson to his more natural position of gunner. There is even an outside chance that they will swap the No. 2 pick and acquire an impact player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSING, MIRIAM S.
description: LESSING-Miriam S. of Islip, L.I. on June 23, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence A. Lessing, Jr. Devoted mother of Lawrence A. Lessing III, John S. Lessing, Miriam L. Donohue, Ann L. Benedict, Virginia L. Lucas and Stephen M. Lessing. Dear sister of Mona Cavanaugh and the late Joan S. Coleman. Proud and cherished grandmother of 30 and great grandmother of 26. Reposing at The Frederick J. Chapey and Sons East Islip Funeral Home, 200 East Main Street (1/2 Mile West of S.S. Pkwy. Exit 45 W.) Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial St. Mary's R.C. Church, East Islip, Wednesday 10:45 AM, Interment St. John Nepomucene Cemetery, Bohemia, L.I. Visiting Tuesday 24:30 & 7-9:30 PM. Donations may be made in Miriam's memory to St. Mary's School, 20 Harrison Avenue, East Islip, New York 11730.

title: Park Where You Will, Mother Teresa
description: Mother Teresa met with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday to ask for help in expanding her convent and her AIDS mission, and could not resist adding a very New York request: a few extra parking permits for her nuns.

title: Wendy's Signs Hockey Deal
description: Wendy's International Inc. said yesterday that it had signed its first national sports sponsorship agreement, with the National Hockey League. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBEL, HENRY K.
description: LOBEL-Henry K. The National Board of The ALYN Hospital for Handicapped Children in Israel mourns the passing of our esteemed board member and great benefactor, Henry K. Lobel. As Chairman of the Board of SmithEdwards-Dunlap, he, his beloved wife, Edith and his family gave without reservation to ensure the well-being of the handicapped children of ALYN Hospital. Our heartfelt condolences to Edith and his family. Simone P. Blum, Chairman of the Board

title: From Digital Frustration to Small Claims Court
description: THE software started as a Hanukkah present to an 11-year-old girl in Washington State. It ended up as a lawsuit in Texas.

title: Prosecutor Faces Complaint
description: The Attorney General has referred an employment discrimination judgment against the Monmouth County Prosecutor, John Kaye, to an attorney ethics committee. If the committee decides to investigate and finds the complaint warranted, Mr. Kaye could face disciplinary charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKENSON, HARRIET FORD
description: DICKENSON-Harriet Ford. Peter Martins, Eugene P. Grisanti, Chairman, Howard Solomon, President, the Board of Directors, dancers, and staff of New York City Ballet wish to express their deepest condolences to the family of Harriet Ford Dickenson. Her contributions to the Company touched our lives in more ways than we can count. She was a special member of the NYCB family and we shall long recall her many gifts to us.

title: Broadening the Appeal of Resort Wear
description: The woman who spends her winter lolling around a tropical beach is a vanishing breed. That fact of life has gradually dawned on American designers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHABAZZ, DR. BETTY
description: SHABAZZ-Dr. Betty. The Professional Staff Congress of The City University of New York extends its profound sympathy to the family of our beloved colleague at Medgar Evers College, Dr. Betty Shabazz. Dr. Shabazz was a unique personality who brought the instructional staff together in a committed spirit of service to students and to their scholarly and professional contributions. Dr. Shabazz recently made a masterful presentation at the union's annual conference on women. Her passing removes a great and esteemed colleague from the City University community. Irwin H. Polishook, President Professional Staff Congress, City University of New York Joyce Siler, Medgar Evers College PSC/CUNY Chapter Chair

title: Amend Voting Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Light Brazilian Country
description: Some of the music of the state of Pernambuco, in northeastern Brazil, has a light, spare quality to it. It's country music and street music, and the instruments are portable -- flutes, snare drums, triangles, violins and scrapers. Dancers like it, and its African side delivers percussive joy.

title: Deafening Is Not 'Fun'
description: To the Editor:

title: Parties Team Up to Protect Their Turf
description: State legislators have fled the green-tile-domed Capitol here, and just in time. They were gone before anyone discovered what they had wrought in the wee hours: an amendment that showcases Pennsylvania as one of the last redoubts of party control in the country.

title: Likely Repeaters May Stay Confined
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may confine violent sex offenders in mental hospitals after they have served their criminal sentences, even if the offenders are not so mentally ill as to meet a state's ordinary criteria for civil commitment against their will.

title: Hollywood Is Bitten By the Bugs
description: Blame it on the millennium. Blame it on fears about cloning. Blame it on an overload of studio alien films or just plain creative exhaustion among executives and screenwriters. But bugs -- teeny ones and monsters, happy little critters who sing and fearsome ones who kill -- are overrunning Hollywood studios. At least a half-dozen scripts involving insects are in various stages of development and production, turning the creatures into formidable screen competitors of dinosaurs and aliens.

title: On Gay Nature vs. Nurture
description: ''Anatomy of Desire'' is an attack on scientific, medical and mental health establishments in the United States and elsewhere that treat homosexuality as a disease. This history from a gay-rights perspective maintains persuasively that greater understanding and acceptance of homosexual impulses and behavior have come not from changes in psychological theories but from united action by homosexuals beginning with the 1969 Stonewall confrontations. Whether forcing changes in medical diagnoses by political means is healthy for science is not discussed.

title: The Chilliest of Stars
description: WITH the help of a large radiotelescope at the European Southern Observatory in Chile, two scientists have taken the temperature of a blast of wind from a dying star some 5,000 light-years from Earth and concluded that it is one of the coldest places in the universe.

title: SUIZA FOODS IN $400 MILLION DAIRIES AND FACTORIES DEAL
description: The Suiza Foods Corporation of Dallas said yesterday that it had agreed to buy four dairies and other businesses for about $400 million in cash and stock. Suiza, which operates dairies and packaged-ice makers, said it would buy Dairy Fresh L.P. of Winston-Salem, N.C., which processes milk and makes ice cream and had $125 million in annual sales last year. Suiza will also buy the stock of Garelick Farms in Franklin, Mass.; Fairdale Farms in Bennington, Vt.; Grant's Dairy in Bangor, Me.; a water bottling company, and 16 plastic bottle factories. Together, those businesses had about $370 million in sales.

title: Drag and Gags at a Family Reunion
description: When members of the Goldman family of Chicago want to express a thought or feeling of extreme delicacy, they reach into -- what else? -- their bottomless sack of one-liners.

title: For Hong Hong Pranksters, a Quick Retreat
description: The People's Liberation Army gives many people the jitters in Hong Kong, and with Chinese rule -- and military presence -- just a week away, even minor incidents involving the army quickly attract lots of attention.

title: India and Pakistan Plan Kashmir Talks
description: India and Pakistan pledged today to make a new effort to reconcile their differences over the disputed territory of Kashmir, the issue that more than any other has made enemies of the two countries for much of the last 50 years.

title: After Years of Classes in Vans, It's Back to School
description: It was on the afternoon of July 1, 1985, that Edward I. Koch, then the Mayor of New York City, telephoned Msgr. Vincent D. Breen, the Vicar for Education of the Archdiocese of Brooklyn, with an urgent question.

title: Congress Must Be the Judge and Jury
description: Last week's announcement of the proposed settlement by cigarette companies was, appropriately, breathtaking: a ban on most cigarette advertising, regulation by the Food and Drug Administration and a $368.5 billion fund for those hurt by smoking. The details of the deal will continue to be negotiated, but the significance of the settlement is that it shifts responsibility for this social problem to where it belongs: Congress.

title: Treasury Securities Take Tumble
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped yesterday, with most of the late selling attributed to what traders took as a warning from Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan that exchange rate instability could encourage Japan to sell some United States Treasury holdings in order to buy gold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAZES, EVELYN
description: CAZES-Evelyn. On June 22,1997. Loving mother of LLoyd and Lois. Dear sister of Louise. Adoring grandmother of Marc, Daniel, Robin, Laura, Nicole and Clifton. Greatgrandmother of three. Services today, June 24th at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam, NYC.

title: G.M. Unit to Pay $550 Million for Insurer
description: The General Motors Corporation's financing unit said today that it had agreed to buy the Integon Corporation for $550 million in cash to increase its presence in the auto insurance market.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a detective's work in a racketeering case in Manhattan involving garbage carting misspelled the surname of a defendant who has pleaded guilty in the case. He is Angelo Ponte, not Aponte.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, MILTON
description: KRAMER-Milton. Of Boston. Beloved brother of Daisy Wynn and Pearl Bernstein and the late George Kramer and uncle. Mourned his passing. He fought passionately against discrimination and in his own way strove to improve the human condition.

title: Faring Well With Labor, Giuliani Gets Fire Union Nod
description: The city's largest firefighters union plans to endorse the re-election of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who so far is faring better in the battle for union support than Republicans typically do in New York City.

title: Europe Faults U.S. at Talks On Ecology
description: With Tony Blair, the new British Prime Minister, in the rhetorical vanguard, European heads of state came before a gloom-and-doom conference of the world's nations today and demanded ever more forceful actions by the United States to confront environmental trends like global warming.

title: Publicis Wins 2 New Accounts
description: Publicis S.A. in Paris and the New York office of its American unit, Publicis/Bloom, have been awarded accounts with combined billings estimated at $50 million to $75 million.

title: With Round-the Clock Help, Young Man Joins the World
description: In the dappled morning light, a small young man walked out of the back entrance of Building 2 of the Brooklyn Developmental Center, a loose-muscled swing to his shoulders. The act itself was unremarkable, and he was attended by only a handful of familiar faces. For him, though, it was like the earth shifting. His shoes rasping on the macadam, he scuffed toward his mother's van.

title: INSIDE
description: Gene Flaw Causes Obesity

title: House Votes to Overturn a Plan By Clinton to Save Military Jobs
description: Defying a veto threat from President Clinton, the House voted tonight to overturn the Administration's plan to keep thousands of jobs at two large Air Force maintenance bases in Texas and California that were ordered closed two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWKEY, SR. EILEEN, S.C.
description: HAWKEY-Sr. Eileen, S.C. The Board of Trustees, Sisters of Charity, Medical Staff, Hospital Auxiliary, Administration and the entire family of St. Vincents Hospital and Medical Center mourn the loss of our beloved friend and colleague, Sr. Eileen, a cherished member of the Hospital staff for over 40 years. Sr. Eileen formerly had been Director of Nursing and Director of Purchasing at St. Vincents and continued to manage the purchasing department until her death. In 1995 she was honored with the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Award. She was known for her extraordinary warmth, her lively wit, and her unending devotion to her family, the Sisters of Charity and St. Vincents. Her enthusiasm and vitality inspired us all. She will long and most affectionately be remembered. With great sadness we extend our prayers and condolences to her family. Thomas A. Coleman, Chairman of the Board Karl P. Adler, M.D. President, Chief Executive Officer Eduardo M. Gonzalez, M.D. President of the Medical Staff

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AYDELOTTE, WILLIAM
description: AYDELOTTE-William. On June 8 in Naples, Florida. Founder, Chairman Ayco Corporation. National indoor singles and doubles tennis champion, 1928. Survived by three children: Margaret A. Mills, New York City; William H. Aydelotte, Naples, Florida; G. Thomas Aydelotte, Greenwich, Connecticut; three grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Reception to celebrate his life June 25, 12:00 noon, Mohawk Golf Club, Schenectady, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory should be made to the charity or organization of choice.

title: Union Pacific Resources Turns Hostile in Pennzoil Bid
description: Union Pacific Resources began a hostile $4 billion offer for the Pennzoil Company today, seeking to capture rich petroleum reserves and a venerable brand name. And Pennzoil shares took flight, as analysts called the bid generous and its prospects of success strong but not certain.

title: A 60's Vision, With Jazz For Today
description: In 1969, the bassist Charlie Haden unveiled his Liberation Music Orchestra. A musical response to turbulent times, the all-star jazz band's first album consisted of pieces about socialism, revolution, Che Guevara and the 1968 Democratic National Convention. Since then, the Communist bloc has collapsed, Che Guevara has turned into a pop icon and the optimism and cohesion that fueled the 60's counterculture have given way to cynicism and fragmentation. Yet the Liberation Music Orchestra continues, and tonight it will give its first New York concert in five years, at TriBeCa Hall as part of the Texaco New York Jazz Festival.

title: Four Agencies Are Joining Forces
description: Four agencies that specialize in advertising, public relations and lobbying have combined to form Winning Strategies Communications. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Remember L.A.'s Riots
description: To the Editor:

title: Sixteenths Come To Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange today will become the last of the major American markets to begin quoting stocks in increments of one-sixteenth of a dollar, or 6.25 cents.

title: One More Bad Pitch Betrays Smoltz
description: A dejected John Smoltz propped himself up against a locker, lamenting one pitch after the Atlanta Braves' 3-2 loss to the Mets last night at Shea Stadium.

title: Movements Reflecting Mood
description: The score by Samuel Barber to which Peter Martins choreographed ''Barber Violin Concerto'' has many changes of mood, and Mr. Martins has responded to them with a gently comic ballet about ways of feeling and behaving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, GRACE M.
description: HART-Grace M. on June 21, 1997 of Forest Hills, NY. Survived by nieces and nephews and many good friends. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc. Forest Hills, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church Wednesday, June 25 at 9:30 AM. Interment St. Charles' Cemetery.

title: New York Bound Bookshop Is Closing at End of Summer
description: The New York Bound Bookshop, a bookstore in Rockefeller Center that for the last 20 years has specialized in books about New York, offering out-of-print books, quirky maps and vintage photographs, is closing at the end of the summer.

title: Woman's Death Prompts Concerns Over Workfare
description: A 50-year-old workfare participant with heart problems died on the job last week, prompting questions about the city's ability to determine whether some of its workfare laborers might be too sick to work.

title: Clinton, in Talk to Mayors, Sketches a Vision for Cities
description: As he hopscotched among California fund-raising events, President Clinton alighted today at an elementary school to promote his ideas for children's health care and at the annual gathering of the United States Conference of Mayors to unveil some modest initiatives -- and some grand dreams -- for cities.

title: In Sex, It's He and Hermaphrodite
description: ''Male and female created He them'' - the biblical formula is true for mammals and other familiar animals, but in nematode worms the two flavors of sex are male and hermaphrodite.

title: 'Master Class' to Close
description: ''Master Class,'' a drama by Terrence McNally, is to close after the evening performance on Saturday at the John Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, Manhattan. It will be the 601st regular performance of the play, directed by Leonard Foglia and currently starring Dixie Carter; it had 12 previews.

title: Senate Finance Panel Adjusts A 'Means Test' for Medicare
description: Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee said today that they had agreed to revise their proposal to make affluent elderly people pay more for Medicare.

title: Opera Sends Free Samples
description: Hoping to reverse a trend of declining membership, the New York City Opera has decided to try something different this year: mailing out free CD's featuring selections from works that will be heard in future productions.

title: Europe Rivals Set TV Venture
description: The Kirch Group of Germany and CLT-UFA of Luxembourg said today that they planned to form a German pay-TV joint venture and agreed to use a single decoder box to decode transmissions, ending a long-running dispute between the two companies.

title: Timeout Called To See Ewing
description: In the middle of his draft activities, Knicks General Manager Ernie Grunfeld made a trip to Washington yesterday to meet with Patrick Ewing.

title: NORWEST TO BUY FIDELITY ACCEPTANCE FROM BANKBOSTON
description: The Norwest Corporation agreed to buy the Fidelity Acceptance Corporation, the BankBoston Corporation's auto finance company, for $340 million. Norwest, based in Minneapolis, will repay BankBoston $800 million in outstanding debt obligations. BankBoston expects an after-tax gain of about $40 million. The bank had a previous deal to sell Fidelity to the Mercury Finance Company for $392 million in Mercury stock, until accounting irregularities pushed Mercury close to bankruptcy. A bank spokeswoman said the purchase price was lower this time because the transaction with Mercury was a stock transfer. She also said the auto finance market had changed as a result of Mercury's problems.

title: Suits Aren't Emblematic of Their Salaries, Drivers Say
description: It is 1:25 P.M., and Zahid Syed, a 32-year-old Pakistani immigrant dressed in a double-breasted charcoal suit and Italian silk tie, kisses his pregnant wife goodbye, opens the door to his gleaming Lincoln Town Car and, for a moment, seems the embodiment of the American dream.

title: Tobacco Company Lawyer Says Pact Might Lead to Bankruptcy
description: A lawyer for the Liggett Group Inc., the first cigarette maker to negotiate a deal with government officials, said yesterday that the historic $368.5 billion product liability settlement reached with other leading tobacco companies last week could force it into bankruptcy.

title: Whimsy in Wooden Shoes
description: When Hermeto Pascoal announced he was going to play something ''really crazy'' for the Summerstage audience in Central Park on Saturday afternoon, he was only escalating slightly. Mr. Pascoal, a renowned Brazilian composer and keyboardist who turned 61 on Sunday, had already delivered one solo by scat-singing into a plastic cup of water (sounding like a trombone) and another through a scrap-metal horn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTLER, ARTHUR J.
description: CUTLER-Arthur J. It is with profound sorrow that the partners of Jeff Gural mourn the untimely passing of his close, personal friend and soul-mate ''Artie'', a compassionate and devoted friend, restauranteur extraordinaire, avid horse player and all around great guy. Our hearts ache with sympathy for his wife Alice and his daughters Jody and Danielle. He will live on in our hearts forever. Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. William Cohen Ronald Goldberger Barry Gosin Aaron Gural Jeffrey Gural Ira Fishman James Kuhn Arthur Lerner Marlene Post and Arthur Rosenbloom.

title: Excerpts From Opinions On Status of Sex Offenders
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court opinion allowing states to confine violent sex offenders in mental hospitals after they have served their criminal sentences. The vote in the case, Kansas v. Leroy Hendricks, No. 95-1649, was 5 to 4. Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the opinion.

title: Other Decisions
description: The Supreme Court also issued these rulings yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHREDERS, MARVIN P.
description: SHREDERS-Marvin P. on 6/22/97. The employees of the Bliss Exterminator Company mourn the loss of Marv Shreders, a caring and dedicated technician and supervisor for 33 years. Marv made friends with his customers, with his warm heart and kind manner. He will be missed by all of us. Wake tonight, 4-7pm at Honan's Funeral Home, 58 Main St, Newtown, CT. Donations can be made to Hospice of Orange County, 800 Stony Brook Ct, Newburgh NY 12550

title: Budget Clears Committees
description: A $16.8 billion state budget for the next fiscal year cleared the budget and appropriations committees of the State Senate and Assembly yesterday and is now expected to be voted on by both houses on Thursday. The spending plan, which Gov. Christine Todd Whitman must sign before July 1, would increase spending by more than half a billion dollars, an increase that is $260 million higher than the Governor proposed in January. Much of the extra money would go to urban schools, state social workers and higher education.

title: When Hip-Hop, Now 20, Was Young
description: It was a night of oldies on Friday at Tramps. But the music wasn't rock, jazz or soul. It was hip-hop, a 20-year-old style that is beginning to establish its own oldies circuit. On the bill was the Sugarhill Gang, the group responsible for the genre's first big hit; Run-D.M.C., the group that completed the music's crossover to a mainstream audience, and a later rap act, the Jungle Brothers, whose biggest hit was a house song.

title: Gigante Trial Judge Sorts Out the Prejudicial Gore
description: The jury that is about to try Vincent Gigante, the reputed Mafia boss, will hear that a mobster whose murder Mr. Gigante is accused of ordering was found with unexploded fireworks in his mouth -- a message that the killing was in retaliation for the victim's role in blowing up another gangster.

title: Louisiana Approves Measure To Tighten Marriage Bonds
description: Louisiana's Legislature today became the first in the nation to approve a law allowing a new and more binding form of marriage contract, one that would permit divorce only in narrow circumstances such as adultery, abuse, abandonment, a lengthy marital separation or imprisonment on a felony.

title: New Chairman Is Reportedly Chosen for Accounting Board
description: Edmund L. Jenkins, a former managing director at Arthur Andersen, has been chosen as the new chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, according to people who were briefed on the decision last night.

title: A Guilty Plea In Fraud Case
description: Edward A. McKay, the president of two small brokerage firms called Buttonwood Securities Inc. and Securities Planners Inc., pleaded guilty last week to stealing money from a client and agreed to cooperate with an investigation of the brokerage industry.

title: Report Says Barclays May Bid For NatWest
description: The shares of National Westminster Bank P.L.C. rose yesterday after it was reported that Barclays P.L.C. was considering a bid to take over NatWest and form Britain's largest bank. NatWest declined to comment on the speculation, although it did say yesterday that its chairman, Lord Alexander, had invited 12 institutional shareholders to meet with him about the bank's strategy.

title: Chess
description: The St. Petersburg Grandmasters Tournament in May was a homecoming for illustrious alumni. Only those who grew up in the city were invited to enter the round-robin event of a dozen grandmasters. Of the three who shared first place, Viktor Korchnoi has been a Swiss citizen for many years, Valery Salov has been residing in Spain while retaining his Russian citizenship, and Aleksandr Khalifman lives in St. Petersburg, after a sojourn in Germany. They each tallied 7-4 in a salute to the place -- it was then Leningrad -- where they received their excellent training.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODSON, ANNA MARIE ''PAT'' DWYER
description: HODSON-Anna Marie ''Pat'' Dwyer, 73, of Basin Harbor, VT and Delray Beach, FL died at her home in Basin Harbor on Monday, June 23, 1997. She was born in New York City on April 19, 1924 the daughter of Gerald P. and Anna Marie (Haubrech) Dwyer. On July 23, 1949 she was married in Port Washington, NY to Robert G. Hodson. She was a member of St. Peter's Parish in Vergennes, VT and a member of St. Vincent Ferrer in Delray Beach, FL. She is survived by her husband Robert G. Hodson of Basin Harbor, VT and Delray Beach, FL; four sons and their spouses, Robert P. and Patricia O. Hodson of Port Washington, NY Thomas F.X. and Marybeth S. Hodson of New Canaan, CT, William J. and Karen F. Hodson of Burlington, NC and Timothy J. and his fiancee Amanda E. Daly of Charlotte, VT; two daughters, Mary Patricia Strobel of Eliot, ME and Catherine H. and her husband William S. Bristow, Jr. of Rollinsford, NH; twelve grandchildren, Shawn, Megan, Michael, Ryan, Kelly, Carlie, Nicholas, Caitlin, Christina, Molly, Claire and Libby. She was predeceased by a brother Gerald Dwyer. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Wednesday, June 25, 1997 at 10:00 am at the Chapel of St. Michael the Archangel on the campus of St. Michael's College in Colchester, VT. Burial will follow in Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Edmundite Trust Fund, c/o St. Michael's College, College Parkway, Colchester, VT 05446 or to the St. Peter's Building Fund, St. Peters Church, 85 South Maple St., Vergennes, VT 05491. Visiting hours will be held at the family home at Basin Harbor on Tuesday from 4 to 7 PM. For more information contact Ready Funeral Home South Chapel, 261 Shelburne Rd., Burlington, VT.

title: Mets Thinking Big, But Gate Still Is Small
description: Before every game these days, just after the national anthem has been played, someone in the Mets' dugout -- it's usually a different person each day, Bobby Valentine said -- yells, ''Hey, this is a really big game, guys.''

title: Dainty Worm Tells Secrets Of the Human Genetic Code
description: EARLY this month, nearly a thousand biologists met here to discuss the affairs of a speck of protoplasm with a grandiloquent name, a barely visible, almost transparent worm called Caenorhabditis elegans. The worm holds the same secrets of life as other animals, but may be the first to yield them, an event that would deeply influence biology and medicine.

title: A Madcap Search for Bio-Mom
description: LEAVE IT TO ME

title: Williams on the Outside As Nets Throw a Party
description: No matter what ill will exists between him and Coach John Calipari, or how often his name is cast out as trade bait, Jayson Williams thought five years of dedication to the Nets and the community would bring a peace offering -- if only for one night.

title: Unlikely Warrior Leads the Charge For Simpler PC
description: DR. MICHAEL L. DERTOUZOS, head of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's computer laboratory, is railing against personal computers. ''You want to use them as boat anchors,'' he says. ''People should really revolt. I think we should take up arms.''

title: Recipe For Terrorism
description: The mixture of armed groups and the preaching of hatred is a recipe for disaster.

title: Disputes and Legalisms Are Put Aside as Friends and Family Grieve
description: As the descendants of Malcolm X retreated into mourning again and questions about the prosecution of her grandson were raised, the death of Betty Shabazz was met yesterday with an outpouring of grief and solemnity from political and civil rights leaders, colleagues, friends and hosts of ordinary people whose lives she had touched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, EDWARD M. JR.
description: STRAUSS-Edward M. Jr. Of New York and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., died on June 21, 1997, at home in New York, after a long illness at age 79. Survived by his wife of fifty years, Dorothy R. Strauss; his son, Edward M. Strauss III, of New York his daughter, Cynthia L. Strauss, of Dallas, Texas, his brother, Willis A. Strauss, of Omaha, Ne., and his granddaughters Louisa Ryder Strauss and Eleanor Kirtland Strauss, of New York. Born in Omaha, Mr. Strauss was a 1940 engineering graduate of Iowa State University. After a forty year career with the Aluminium Company of America (Alcoa) in Baltimore, Fairfield, Connecticut, Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, and Lausanne, Switzerland, he was President of the Business Committee for the Arts, New York, from 1979 to 1982. He was President of the Swiss-American Chamber of Commerce in 1978-1979, and was a founder of the American Council for Jean Monnet Studies. Services are at All Saints Episcopal Church, 230 East 60th Street, on Friday, June 27 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to All Saints Church would be appreciated.

title: Thanks to Marvel, Toy Biz Faces a Battle of the Boards
description: Toy Biz Inc., the company that has the right to sell toys based on characters created by the bankrupt Marvel Entertainment Group, has seen its stock price and revenues plunge since the fight for control of Marvel began. And now it has two boards of directors, each claiming to be the only rightful one.

title: Ancient Art Show For Getty Opening
description: The Getty Center, a $1 billion arts complex in the foothills of the Santa Monica Mountains in Los Angeles, is to open on Dec. 16 with an exhibition of ancient artworks. The six-building center, designed by Richard Meier, will feature a new J. Paul Getty Museum along with institutes for conservation, research, education, information and grants. Plans were conceived more than 13 years ago.

title: 'Daughter' to Close
description: ''An American Daughter,'' a drama by Wendy Wasserstein, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Cort Theater, 138 West 48th Street, Manhattan. The play, a Lincoln Center Theater production directed by Daniel Sullivan and starring Kate Burton, Lynne Thigpen, John Procaccino and Ralph Waite, will have run for 88 regular performances and 27 previews.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Former Andersen Director To Head Accounting Board

title: Army Hearing in Sex Case Must Be Open, Court Says
description: In a surprise move, the military's highest court today ordered the Army to open to the public a hearing involving sexual misconduct charges against the Army's senior enlisted soldier.

title: Abortion Foe Seeks G.O.P. Nod for Congress
description: Randall Terry, the founder of the militant anti-abortion group Operation Rescue, announced yesterday that he hoped to run for Congress in 1998 as a Republican to unseat Representative Maurice Hinchey, a three-term Ulster County Democrat who supports abortion rights.

title: New Court Rekindles Old Hopes
description: TIM HENMAN could hear the sirens singing, and he knew they sang for him. He could probably even hear Tina and Helena, screaming his praises from a green hillside outside the new Court 1.

title: Canadians Surprised by Proposal to Extradite Pol Pot
description: Canadian officials said today that they were taken by surprise when the United States suggested that their country seek the extradition of the former Cambodian dictator, Pol Pot, and expressed doubt that their genocide law could be used as Washington requested.

title: Public Teachers in Parochial Schools
description: In a 5-to-4 decision yesterday, the Supreme Court discarded its own 1985 precedent barring public-school teachers from entering parochial schools to offer federally financed remedial classes and counseling. That is a salutary result, particularly for New York City. But in the process of reaching it, the Court eroded the integrity of its deliberative process, and added fresh confusion to the continuing skirmishes along the church-state border.

title: Police Officer Wounds Man
description: A Newark police officer shot and wounded a 26-year-old man yesterday, the 25th shooting by an officer this year, the police said. The officer, Nicholas Popolizio, shot Jonathan Adams in the shoulder after pulling over the car Mr. Adams was riding in for a traffic violation and Mr. Adams pulled a gun from the glove compartment, Lieut. Anthony Ambrose said. Mr. Adams was in stable condition yesterday.

title: Fenced In at Home, Marlboro Man Looks Abroad
description: On the wall of Andre Calantzopoulos's office in Warsaw hangs a glass cabinet displaying dozens of the more than 300 brands of foreign cigarettes, including seductively packaged ''his'' and ''hers'' brands, that the tobacco giants are churning out to entice Polish smokers.

title: McIlvaine Says Coaches Showed Poor Judgment
description: Mets General Manager Joe McIlvaine, speaking for the first time since the organization fired the coaching staff of its Class A affiliate in Columbia, S.C., said yesterday that the manager and two coaches made ''a mistake in judgment'' in how they handled their players after the death of outfielder Tim Bishop on April 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ISADORE (IRVING)
description: COHEN-Isadore (Irving). Beloved husband of Lillian, loving father of Melvyn and Robert, devoted brother of Anna Schifter, devoted grandfather and loving uncle. Services today, 10:00 A.M., at Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue (Ave. M), Brooklyn.

title: The Big Boys in Denver
description: All slimmed down after his illness, Boris Yeltsin told President Clinton that his suits were now too big. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's giant van was too big for the driveway at dinner on Friday. Everyone at the summit meeting of the heads of major industrial nations thought the agenda was, well, too big.

title: After Some Suspense, Jersey City Gets to Choose a Mayor
description: As he strode down Newark Avenue today, poking his head into the modest shops, bending over to bestow kisses on most of the women who crossed his path and beseeching everyone to vote on Tuesday, Mayor Bret D. Schundler was greeted with good wishes, beaming faces and only a smattering of complaints.

title: Bill to Limit Fund-Raising
description: A bill to limit campaign contributions to the political action committees of the four legislative leaders was passed yesterday by the Senate Judiciary Committee. Now, individuals or corporations can give up to $25,000 a year to the committees set up by the Senate President and minority leader and the Assembly Speaker and minority leader. The leaders then pass the money on to candidates in their parties. The bill would decrease the limit to $10,000. The bill, which now goes before the Senate Appropriations Committee, also cuts maximum contributions to state or county political parties from $25,000 to $15,000.

title: Utility Plans 2d Buyback
description: The Peco Energy Company said today that it would buy back as many as 20 million of its shares. The electric and gas utility, which is based here, said the buyback plan would be in addition to a repurchase program begun in April for as many as 5 million shares. As of March 31, Peco Energy had 222.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Gates to Help Libraries Acquire Gear To Go on Line
description: William H. Gates, the software entrepreneur sometimes criticized for being too slow to give away his billions, is creating a foundation that intends to spend $200 million over five years to bring new computers and the Internet into the nation's public libraries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UMANSKY, SUSAN
description: UMANSKY-Susan. On June 23, 1997. Beloved daughter of the late Clara and Maurice Umansky. Loving sister of Richard. Cherished aunt of Ilana. Service Wednesday, 11:00 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, GRACE A.
description: SCHMIDT-Grace A., on June 22, 1997. Beloved mother of Mel and Richard. Cherished grandmother of Eric and Scott. Loving sister of George Silverton and Bernice Bucalos. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Tuesday 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Service in chapel 7:30 PM, Tuesday. Interment Wednesday Evergreen Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUSHLIN, SIDNEY
description: MUSHLIN-Sidney. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of its esteemed member. We extend deepest sympathy to his wife, Muriel, his children, Marilyn and Miles and to the entire family. Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Linda P. Goldberg, President Julian Bernstein, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITCHIN, ESTELLE
description: RITCHIN-Estelle. East Midwood Jewish Center mourns the passing of our former trustee and wife of our former vice president, Dr. Hy Ritchin. Estelle was a brilliant and talented woman who loved education and found her greatest pleasure in meeting the needs of others. She will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Dr. Alvin Kass, Rabbi Marsha Shlefstein, President

title: 2 Chains Sold by Restaurant Associates
description: The Restaurant Associates Corporation, which has been a trailblazer in the metropolitan area's restaurant industry and has managed some of Manhattan's most popular restaurants, sold its Charlie Brown's Steakhouse and the Office chains yesterday to Castle, Harlan Partners III L.P., a New York City investment firm.

title: Gore Failed to Stop Harmful Oil Pipeline Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Tory Chief Turns to Right, and to Past, to Pick His Team
description: William Hague, whose political views have gone largely unstated during his short time in Britain's public life, has in his opening act as Conservative Party leader assembled an opposition team leaning toward the Thatcherite and Euroskeptic right.

title: Gore Failed to Stop Harmful Oil Pipeline Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Bill Is Vetoed By Whitman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman vetoed a bill tonight that would ban a type of late-term abortion, saying she would sign the proposal only if it included an exception allowing the procedure to protect a woman's health.

title: Report Says Hubbell Defrauded Los Angeles by Taking Fees for Work He Never Did
description: Webster L. Hubbell, the former Associate Attorney General, greatly overstated the amount of work he performed as a lobbyist for the Los Angeles Department of Airports in 1994, and the city should seek to recover $24,750 in fees that Mr. Hubbell received under false pretenses, an inquiry by the city controller's office concluded today.

title: Icon Epidemic Rages
description: Disaster! That's what my campaign against icons has ended in. The defeat is not as catastrophic as Custer's at the Little Big Horn, but it is just as total.

title: Accounts
description: * Helzberg Diamonds, North Kansas City, Mo., a unit of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., to Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia, to handle the creative and strategic duties for its Jewelry 3 and Helzberg chains of retail stores, which had been handled by Barkley & Evergreen, Kansas City, Mo. The Media Edge, New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc., continues handling media; duties like direct marketing remain in house. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: A potential arthritis drug could help Immunex rise even higher.
description: SHARES in the Immunex Corporation have tripled in the last year, but some analysts say considerable upside potential remains. They believe a potential new drug for rheumatoid arthritis, a crippling disease that afflicts 2.5 million Americans and as much as 1.5 percent of the world's population, could transform the company from one of biotechnology's laggards to a rising star.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There was a touch of royal news as well in Beacon, N.Y., yesterday, when Prime Minister ANTONIO GUTERRES of Portugal, who was in New York to address the United Nations, took time out to pay tribute to a Queen from his country -- or at least half a Queen.

title: Atlanta Finds No Relief From Reed
description: As pitchers go, Rick Reed is a sprinter. Runs to the mound, pitches quickly, runs off, does not take time to change his sweaty T-shirt between innings, usually does not last much longer than six innings.

title: Corrections
description: A film festival review on Oct. 12, 1996, about Emir Kusturica's ''Underground'' misidentified the leading female character, a beautiful actress fought over by two men. Her name is Natalija and she is played by Mirjana Jokovic; Vera, correctly identified as having been played by Mirjana Karanovic, is a supporting role. The error was repeated on Friday in excerpts from the review that were published for the film's commercial release. A reader pointed out the error yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AWN, JOHN J., JR.
description: AWN-John J., Jr. Died suddenly on June 21, 1997 at 41. His untimely passing is mourned by his fiancee Joann Sweeney, his brother Christopher and his sister Linda. Dear son of the late John J., Sr. and Louise (nee Alouf). He was a graduate of Xaverian High School and Fordham University Summa Cum Laude 1978. He was a mortgage-backed securities broker with Chapdelaine Corp. Securities. We are all richer in having known John. He will be remembered by his family and friends for his high-spirited intelligence, his sense of humor and the extraordinary manner in which he shared his life with all those he touched. A true New Yorker, who loved the Yankees, the Dead, Cohibas, and politics. He will always be remembered. Visiting on Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial on Wednesday at 10 AM, St. Anselms Church. In lieu of flowers, you may remember John through NARSAD, National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression, Great Neck, New York, 516-829-0091 or AMI/FAMI, Friends and Advocates of the Mentally Ill at 432 Park Avenue South, New York.

title: CBS Defends Exit From Rainy Buick
description: CBS's decision to cut off the rain-delayed final round of the Buick Classic at 6 P.M. Sunday was based on its belief that it would not finish by 7 P.M. The tournament did not end until about 7:30 P.M., with Ernie Els winning.

title: Excerpts From Ruling Allowing Aid to Church Schools for Remedial Classes
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that overturned a precedent to declare that the Constitution permits public schools to send teachers into parochial schools to teach remedial classes. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the majority opinion, Justice David H. Souter the dissent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PREISS, EDMUND
description: PREISS-Edmund. Forever loved, forever remembered. Pearl, Byron, Sandi, Karah and Blaire Preiss

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRODSKY, JUDITH
description: BRODSKY-Judith. In our minds, precious memories; in our hearts, love forever. Grace and Ruth

title: Genome Project Partners Go Their Separate Ways
description: A long expected divorce between the oddest couple in genome sequencing, the decoding of an organism's full DNA and a field of growing importance in both science and the pharmaceuticals, took place on Friday and was announced late yesterday by both parties. The split is another step toward insuring that research on human and other genomes takes place openly and not behind company doors.

title: Fox Rooting for Home Teams
description: If you are the ESPN monolith, do you tremble at the potential threat posed by Fox Sports Net, the entity built by Rupert Murdoch's Fox Sports, Liberty Media, the programming arm of mighty Tele-Communications Inc., and Cablevision Systems?

title: Navy Supplier Admits Fraud
description: A military contractor, Med-Atlantic Petroleum of New York, was able to bilk the Navy out of $20 million from 1990 to 1992 by overcharging for transport and supply ship fuel, said Alain Leibman, an Assistant United States Attorney. Yesterday, Med-Atlantic's president, Jacqueline Plecas, 44, pleaded guilty to the fraud in Federal court. She faces up to five years in prison and must pay restitution. The case against Ms. Plecas grew out of cases against other contractors who admitted overcharging a naval support fleet based in Bayonne by $2 million.

title: UNITED NATURAL IN $100 MILLION DEAL FOR STOW MILLS
description: United Natural Foods Inc., a natural food distributor aiming to broaden its geographic reach, agreed yesterday to buy Stow Mills Inc. for nearly $100 million in stock. Together, the companies will distribute in 46 states. United Natural Foods, of Dayville, Conn., will issue five million new shares to buy Stow Mills, a privately held company that is based in Chesterfield, N.H., and had annual sales of $208 million last year. United Natural shares rose $1.375, to $19.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEGER, HILDA MULLER
description: RIEGER-Hilda Muller, of Brooklyn Heights, NY. Peacefully on June 21, 1997, age 89. Beloved wife of the late Frederick E. Rieger. Loving mother of Frederick Ernest Rieger, Jr. Thomas Muller Rieger and D.O. Christian Rieger. Devoted grandmother of Frederick III, James, David, Christina, Andrew, Elizabeth, and Margaret, and great grandmother of Rachel and Nicholas. Memorial service 11 AM, Saturday, June 28, Trinity Episcopal Church, 651 Pequot Rd., Southport, CT. Contributions may be made to Salvation Army, 120 West 14th St., NY, NY 10011

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Excerpts from Decision on Private Prison Guards
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today affirming lower court rulings that guards working for privately run prisons did not enjoy the same legal protection against inmates' lawsuits as prison guards who are state employees. The vote in the case, Richardson v. McKnight, No. 96-318, was 5 to 4. Justice Stephen G. Breyer wrote the majority opinion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMBLE, SAMUEL R.
description: TRIMBLE-Samuel R. of Landing, NJ passed away at home surrounded by his loving family. His survivors include his wife Iris, children Kellie and Bill Hamburger, Michael and Lori Trimble, Samuel T. Trimble, and Ralph Aiello, mother Ethel Trimble and siblings Kathy and Earl Mikoloski. Six grandchildren also survive. Funeral service will be held today at 11:30AM at Leber-Lakeside Funeral Home, Main Road, Landing, NJ. Entombment at the sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Emerson, NJ. Donations will be accepted to Make A Wish Foundation.

title: Black Communities Remain Separate and Unequal
description: To the Editor:

title: KIA GROUP HOPES TO RAISE $893 MILLION IN LAND SALES
description: The Kia Group of South Korea said today that it hoped to raise about $893 million through real estate sales as part of its efforts to tide over cash flow problems. Kia, which owns the third-largest auto maker in South Korea, said that nonbanking institutions have been calling on its units to make debt payments following reports that the company was encountering financial problems. Kia said the reports were unsubstantiated and urged the Government to help it minimize damage from such speculation. Among the properties that Kia plans to sell is an auto plant in Kwangju, 500 kilometers south of Seoul.

title: CHS ELECTRONICS TO BUY SWISS CONCERN FOR $160 MILLION
description: CHS Electronics Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Karma International S.A., a Swiss distributor of personal computer components, for $160 million in cash and stock. CHS, based in Miami, said it would pay $74 million in cash and $86 million worth of stock. CHS shares gained 75 cents yesterday, to $26.50. CHS, a microcomputer products distributor, said the acquisition was subject to the completion of CHS's recent offering of up to 10 million common shares. Part of the proceeds from the offering would finance the acquisition. Last year, Karma earned $15.1 million on revenue of $700 million.

title: Patterns
description: Lagerfeld's Poetic License

title: Master Persuader Will Run the Leading Business Lobby
description: The half-dozen top lobbyists sipping cocktails in the dimly lighted library of the City Club suspended their talk of golf and dieting (without giving up red wine or red meat) to raise a glass to Thomas J. Donohue, head persuader for the trucking industry, who had just been named president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.

title: Compass of Britain Buying Food Concern
description: Compass Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would acquire a 93 percent stake in the French food company SHRM for $:227.1 million, or $376 million. Compass, a British food services company, said it expected the acquisition, which should close next Monday, to increase earnings in the first full year of operation. Compass said it would soon acquire the remaining shares, which are held by SHRM management.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLORFEIN, INA
description: KLORFEIN-Ina. On June 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Larry and Carole. Dear sister of Gertrude. Services private.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was Cinderella in reverse on Saturday, when PRINCESS ZAHRA, the daughter of the AGA KHAN, spiritual leader of the world's 20 million Ismaili Muslims, was married in two ceremonies in France to MARK BOYDEN, whose father is a farmer in Dorset, England.

title: Betty Shabazz, A Rights Voice, Dies of Burns
description: Betty Shabazz, who saw her husband, Malcolm X, assassinated 32 years ago and sought to preserve his memory and teachings in a life that became a symbol of perseverance to black America, died yesterday at a Bronx hospital, three weeks after suffering extensive burns in a fire apparently set by her troubled 12-year-old grandson. She was 61.

title: It All Started With Ragtime
description: Ragtime is now 100 years old, counting from the appearance of the music's first published song, William H. Krell's ''Mississippi Rag.'' And the debate still continues about its importance to jazz. Its showoffy sequential melodies lapsed into formulaic kitsch 20 years on and had to be largely abandoned before jazz, and its ethos of the improvised variation, could come into its own. Yet some of the renowned musicians who worked in this Midwestern style were later among the first to play the thing called jazz.

title: Townships Embrace a Stranger: Ailey
description: ''Our dancers don't usually wear sneakers, but this floor rolls up and down so much, they could injure themselves,'' said Judith Jamison, watching her hip-swinging company slink through ''Night Creature'' for an enthusiastic crowd of primary school students the other day in a small community center in the mixed-race township of Eldorado Park.

title: REPUBLIC TO ACQUIRE VALUE RENT-A-CAR FOR $77.5 MILLION
description: Republic Industries agreed yesterday to buy Value Rent-a-Car from the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation for $77.5 million in cash or stock. Republic also agreed that Mitsubishi, a Japanese auto maker, would supply it with as many as 27,000 vehicles a year for Value and three other car-rental companies that Republic has acquired -- Alamo Rent-a-Car, National Car Rental System and Spirit Rent-a-Car. Republic's chairman, H. Wayne Huizenga, has been acquiring car-rental companies partly as a way to supply Republic's Autonation USA chain of used-car mega-stores.

title: Clintons Lose Before Justices On Notes Fight
description: The Supreme Court dealt a major setback to President Clinton in the Whitewater investigation today by refusing to review a subpoena that orders White House lawyers to surrender notes they had taken of conversations with Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Miller is seeking to create buzz with its new sweepstakes.
description: SUMMER is the peak selling season for beer marketers, the most competitive time for an industry in which sales have remained essentially flat for years. As such, the war for market share is never more intense.

title: Operators Are Not Worried by Ruling
description: From their prisons to their lotteries to their welfare offices, state and local governments across the nation have been looking more and more to private companies to do the job for less money. And while a major Supreme Court ruling today might appear to threaten the privatization vogue by increasing these companies' costs, several executives and industry analysts said the effect would be much more limited.

title: Majoli Tastes Her First Success at Wimbledon
description: There was a quartet of rain delays and a slew of incomplete matches. There was dew on the grass and trepidation among the opening-day combatants, such as last year's out-of-the-woodwork champion, Richard Krajicek, and two players who had not won a match here, the French Open champion, Iva Majoli of Croatia, and the Australian Open runner-up, Carlos Moya.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, IRMA
description: ADLER-Irma. On June 21, 1997, widow of the late Dr. Martin Adler. Memorial services today at 10:30AM at ''The Riverside'' West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. NYC

title: Genetic Cause Found for Some Cases of Human Obesity
description: HUMAN obesity, a condition affecting a third of Americans, has for the first time been found to have a genetic cause, at least in some cases.

title: Yes, That's Duncan at Second Base
description: Mariano Duncan became the prodigal Yankee tonight after the forgotten second baseman continued his return from the abyss and started at the position for the first time since May 30. George Steinbrenner's pronouncement that Duncan would never play second again for the Yankees because of his erratic defense lasted almost three weeks, a brief time in Yankeeland since it originally seemed as if it would last forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, DAVID MICHAEL
description: MOSKOWITZ-David Michael, age 38 of Short Hills, NJ and Quogue, NY, suddenly while bicycling on June 21, 1997. Devoted husband of Jacqueline (nee Stevens), adoring father of Alexander and Matthew, loving son of Reba and Ted Moskowitz, beloved brother of Robert Moskowitz and Alice Freidus, cherished son-in-law of Edward and Lillian Stevens, treasured brother-in-law of Susan and Robert Tanne, Jeanette Moskowitz and Gene Freidus, adored uncle of Erica, Marc, Jill, Claire, Rachel and Joshua. Vice-President of Computer Systems at J.P. Morgan. A great friend and terrific athlete with a sharp mind and a wonderful sense of humor, he will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ, Tuesday at 10:15 A.M. The family will be observing shiva at the home of Susan and Robert Tanne.

title: New Respect For Estrogen's Influence
description: IF Shakespeare had been a chemist, he would have loved estrogen, a hormone fit for comedy, tragedy and a sonnet or two.

title: Reed Elsevier Is Purchasing Disney Unit for $447 Million
description: Reed Elsevier P.L.C., the British-Dutch business publisher, announced yesterday that it would buy the Chilton trade magazine group from the Walt Disney Company for $447 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONTOW, MARY
description: JONTOW-Mary. She leaves behind a son, Bernhard L., a daughter-in-law, Eleanor J., and daughter-in-law, Sylvia; five grandchildren and nine great grandchildren.

title: FRESH GUIDELINES REDEFINE DIABETES IN BROADER TERMS
description: Levels of blood sugar that have long been accepted as normal are actually too high and should be considered a sign of diabetes, according to new guidelines issued yesterday by the American Diabetes Association and endorsed by Federal health authorities.

title: Little Progress Since 60's
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGOL, LAURA
description: EGOL-Laura, age 83, died peacefully in Miami, FL on June 7, 1997. She will be missed and always remembered by her children Lewis (Gail), Andrew (Nancy) and Mandy; her brother Hy (Ruth); her grandchildren Erik, Jessica and Jared; her cousins, nieces, nephews and countless friends from the Bronx, NY and Hallandale and Miami, FL. She gave tirelessly to her family and to many others through her volunteer work with the blind, the homeless, the aged and infirm. A funeral was held for the family at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont where she was buried next to her husband Albert. The family asks that those who wish to remember her do so through service to others.

title: A Gleaming New Guggenheim for Grimy Bilbao
description: Just months from its inauguration, with one work of art in place, several interior walls unfinished and the entrance plaza slippery with mud, the spectacular new Guggenheim Bilbao Museum designed by Frank O. Gehry is still something of a work-in-progress. Yet already, it seems, the $100 million building has won the hearts of many inhabitants of this industrial port city in Spain's northern Basque region.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OSTRAU, IRENE
description: OSTRAU-Irene. Love you and miss you these long ten years. Stanley and Bert

title: Green, Too, Chooses Sides in Race to Succeed Messinger
description: Abandoning an earlier pledge to remain neutral, Mark J. Green, the city's Public Advocate, will endorse C. Virginia Fields for Manhattan borough president, becoming the latest Democratic official to choose sides in what has become one of the most contested races of the year, his aides said yesterday.

title: Ex-Deputy Mayor Nominated to SUNY Board
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today nominated Randy Daniels, a former deputy mayor of New York City who resigned in 1992 amid charges of sexual harassment that were never substantiated, to serve on the State University of New York's Board of Trustees.

title: Bronx Athlete Has Learned His Father's Lesson: 'Books Are the True Security'
description: In the dark before dawn -- it is about 5:30 A.M. -- the solitary figure of a 17-year-old boy in cap, jacket and sneakers emerges from the red-brick building where he shares a first-floor apartment with his parents, his grandfather and a younger brother. He moves along tree-lined, working-class 41st Street in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Pataki's Leadership Ended Rent Control Saga
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Critics Begin Heavy Attack on Settlement, Calling It Soft on Cigarette Makers
