description: Critics began a concerted attack on the proposed tobacco settlement today, citing numerous provisions they consider too favorable to cigarette makers and demanding that major portions of the agreement be rewritten.

title: Q&A
description: Wolverine Power

title: DIME TO BUY A MORTGAGE LEADER FOR $374 MILLION
description: Dime Bancorp Inc., New York's biggest savings and loan company, said yesterday it had agreed to buy the North American Mortgage Company for about $374 million in stock. North American Mortgage, based in Santa Rosa, Calif., was the 12th-largest originator of mortgages last year, financing nearly $10 billion in new mortgage loans. Under the agreement, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, each share of North American Mortgage will be exchanged for 1.37 shares of Dime. Shares of North American Mortgage rose 62.5 cents, to $23.875, and Dime's fell $1.125, to $17.875. North American Mortgage has the right to end the agreement if the price of Dime's shares falls 20 percent or more.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, ANNA C.
description: WALTER-Anna C. Of Princeton, NJ and NYC, died June 20 in her 90th year after a short illness. Born in NYC, she was a founding partner with her late husband Fred of Thermo Electric Co. in Saddle Brook, NJ. Long active in church and civic affairs in Fairlawn and Allendale, NJ, she was for many years chairman of the annual fundraising event for the Cerebral Palsy Center in Ridgewood, NJ, and still served as an honorary trustee. She was a benefactor of the Los Angeles County Museum and a life member of the J. Pierpont Morgan Library. Long an active member of St. Peter's Lutheran Church in NYC, she was the third generation of her family to worship there. She is survived by her daughter Marilyn Grounds, her son Paul, her granddaughters Christine and Rebecca Grounds, and her son-in-law Peter Grounds. Funeral service on Tuesday, June 24, 11:30 AM, St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Ave. at 54th Street. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions to the Music Fund, St. Peter's Church.

title: Ivory and the Elephant
description: To the Editor:

title: Cone Throws 16 Strikeouts At the Tigers
description: The pictures David Cone provided with a supply of mighty pitches tonight were familiar to those who had watched him master hitters with the Mets. The perfect delivery. The big fastball. The nasty split-finger fastball. The batters mumbling and muttering as they flailed and missed. Cone strolling to the dugout with his head down after another strikeout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINBERG, ROSALYN
description: KLEINBERG-Rosalyn. Temple Beth Torah, Westbury, NY mourns the loss of our beloved member. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Jonah, and children, Neila and Mitchell and the entire family. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Michael Katz Ivan Ziegler, President

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on Saturday about the purchase by the Metro Pacific Corporation of a stake in a project in the Philippines misidentified the builder of a second project, halfway between Manila and a belt of industrial parks to the south. That project, Filinvest Corporate City, is being built by the Filinvest Group, not by Metro Pacific.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILLIANT, RITA DIMITRI
description: BRILLIANT-Rita Dimitri. On June 21. Cherished wife of Stanley. Actress, singer for 22 years. Performer and owner of La Chansonnette Supper Club in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations to National Kidney Cancer Association, 1234 Sherman Avenue, Evanston, Illinois 60202. Funeral services private.

title: Anquished Debate: Should Doctors Help Their Patients Die?
description: By the end of the month, the Supreme Court will rule on a wrenching social issue -- whether terminally ill Americans have the right to a doctor's help in killing themselves. Earlier this year, in The New England Journal of Medicine, Marcia Angell, executive editor, discussed reasons to legalize physician-assisted suicide. This month, in The Journal of the American Medical Association, Herbert Hendin of the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention and his co-authors described problems they found with physician-assisted suicide in the Netherlands. Following are excerpts.

title: Mayor Gets Newark Ads Out of His Face
description: Last week, Continental Airlines began a new ad campaign to promote its service out of Newark International Airport, with in-your-face slogans like: ''If you fly Continental out of Newark, raise your hand. The rest of you, raise your standards.''

title: Wei-Sender Team Wins in Bridge Trials
description: The final playoff in the American Contract Bridge League's Women's International Team Trials ended here Sunday in a victory for kathie Wei-Sender, Sue Sachs, Juanita Chambers, Kerri Sanborn, Lynn Deas and Beth Palmer.

title: Official Says Pol Pot's Foes, Fearing Trial, May Kill Him
description: The enemies of Pol Pot are likely to kill him rather than let him testify at a trial where he could implicate them, First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh said today.

title: Giant Squid Keeps Its Secrets
description: Slimy and huge, a living nightmare of the sea with unblinking eyes the size of hubcaps and tentacles as long as buses, the giant squid has once again eluded scientists intent on tracking it into the ocean depths.

title: The Real Bias In Higher Education
description: Those of us committed to racial justice might try this thought experiment: Cheryl Hopwood, the white woman who successfully challenged the University of Texas Law School's affirmative action plan last year in Federal court, is our ally.

title: Lilly Cuts Distribution Unit's Book Value by $2.4 Billion
description: Acknowledging that it paid far too much when it bought a drug distribution and managed care business from the McKesson Corporation in 1994, Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday it was reducing the book value of the unit by $2.4 billion, or more than half the $4.1 billion purchase price.

title: A Trial for Pol Pot
description: A rare chance now exists to hold Pol Pot, one of this century's most notorious mass murderers, accountable for his crimes against humanity and the Cambodian people. Many hurdles must still be overcome before he can be brought before an international tribunal. But current realities of Cambodian politics and international diplomacy make this an opportune moment to try. America and other countries committed to upholding international law against wholesale murder must do their utmost to see that he comes to trial.

title: Trinet Buys 3 Buildings
description: Trinet Corporate Realty Trust Inc. said today that it had acquired three office buildings in Silicon Valley for $52.3 million from an undisclosed seller. The San Francisco-based real estate investment trust said the buildings totaled 187,380 square feet on about 12.5 acres. Two of the buildings are leased to the 3Com Corporation and the other to Sun Microsystems Inc., all through October 2006.

title: Decorators on Call At Design Center
description: For the last 20 years, the New York Design Center, at Lexington Avenue and 32d Street, has functioned as a private shopping salon for interior designers and architects. The dozens of showrooms display fine furnishings that in many cases are not available anywhere else in the country, whether a reproduction of an 18th-century walnut armoire or a sleek chrome and leather chair.

title: Gates's Gift to Libraries
description: William H. Gates, the software entrepreneur sometimes criticized for being slow to give away his billions, is creating a foundation to spend $200 million to bring computers and the Internet into public libraries. It is the largest charitable effort by Mr. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft.

title: CUNY Chancellor Responds To Accusations on Tests
description: Defending herself against accustions by university trustees that she had misled them, the Chancellor of the City University of New York, W. Ann Reynolds, said yesterday that she had been told repeatedly that students at Hostos Community College were taking and passing a university writing test to earn diplomas.

title: Man Is Guilty in Internet Case
description: A 47-year-old man from Ohio pleaded guilty in Federal court yesterday to enticing a 13-year-old New Jersey girl he met on the Internet to send him pornographic videos and photos of herself. The man, Paul Brown Jr. of Cleveland, posed as a 15-year-old boy, prosecutors said, and gained the girl's confidence over more than a year of E-mail messages and phone calls. He faces up to five years in prison.

title: Leaks Aplenty in Capitol Dome; Repairs Fall Prey to Politics
description: Yikes! The dome of the United States Capitol has sprung a leak. Make that more than 200 leaks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REETH, GEORGE P.
description: REETH-George P., suddenly on June 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Marie Mark, George Jr. and Mark. Cherished grandfather of seven. Dear son of Catherine. Loved by all who knew him. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Avenue at 12th St., Garden City. Tuesday 2-4 & 7-9. Religious service 8 P.M. Tuesday. Contributions to Pace University Alumni Association appreciated.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: Immunity From Suits Is Withheld For Guards in Privately Run Jails
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that employees of companies that run prisons under contract with a state or local government are not entitled to the immunity from prisoner lawsuits that shields prison guards who are on the public payroll.

title: Fall of 192.25 Is Worst Day Of '97 for Dow
description: The stock market plunged yesterday in a late wave of selling that turned what seemed to be a routine session into the worst of the year.

title: In Death Penalty Case, Court Rewards Stalling
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRAVELERS PROPERTY CASUALTY CORP., Hartford, a unit of Travelers Group Inc., agreed to buy back 6.6 million shares from four private investors for a total of $240.8 million.

title: Or You Could Just Read a Book
description: The television industry, politicians and family advocacy groups are wrestling over expanding the ratings system for television programs, with designations for violence (''V'') and sexual content (''S'') proposed. But why not some truly useful ratings? Like these:

title: Tyson Eyes A Bigger Picture
description: Champion of nothing now, other than the rumor mill, Mike Tyson has only one thing left to defend: himself.

title: Compaq to Acquire Tandem, Big-Systems Maker
description: Broadening its reach in large systems, the Compaq Computer Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Tandem Computers Inc. in a stock swap valued around $3 billion. Tandem's shares gained 38 percent on the news.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: COURT EASES CURB ON PROVIDING AID IN CHURCH SCHOOLS
description: In a dramatic and potentially far-reaching ruling, the Supreme Court overturned one of its own precedents today to declare that the Constitution permits public school systems to send teachers into parochial schools to teach remedial and supplemental classes to needy children.

title: Cisco Forms Technology Alliance With Alcatel of France
description: Paris tangoed with Silicon Valley yesterday at the Plaza Hotel, and Wall Street applauded.

title: No Headline
description: ''This is Bill Gates becoming the 21st century's Andrew Carnegie.''

title: Brian Keith, Hardy Actor, 75; Played Dads and Desperadoes
description: Brian Keith, the gruff, sturdy character actor whose roles in films and on television ranged from Western gunslingers and small-town police chiefs to private eyes and the Manhattan bachelor uncle raising three children in ''Family Affair,'' was found dead yesterday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ANNE PHILLIPS
description: SCHWARTZ-Anne Phillips. Died peacefully of natural causes in her 98th year. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Roberta Ackerman, Harold Schwartz and Dr. Stuart Schwartz. Loving mother-in-law of the late Sy Ackerman, Doris Cadoux, Judy Rosley & Dr. Roberta Huberman. Darling Nana of the late Michael, Susan & James, Jill and Jonathan, Maryam, Juliet and Zachary. Adoring great grandmother of Meghan, Wyatt, Sam and Cooper. Services will be held on Friday, June 27 at 11 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Memorial contributions to the City of Hope Hospital, Duarte, CA. 91010.

title: City Confident of New Plan for Notorious Building
description: For exactly $1, Frank J. Sciame Jr. has bought one of Manhattan's oldest structures, a brick house at 273 Water Street that was built in the 1780's by a seafaring mahogany trader and then became an infamous tavern where bloody rat-and-dog fights were the chief diversion.

title: Innovative Mentor Wins Dance Award
description: Anna Halprin received the 1997 Samuel H. Scripps/American Dance Festival Award in ceremonies on Monday night at Page Auditorium on the campus of Duke University here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOVERN, H. KENNETH
description: MCGOVERN-H. Kenneth. Died of cancer on June 20, 1997 at the age of 80 years old. Formerly of Scarsdale, NY, he resided in Jupiter, FL and died in West Palm Beach. He is survived by 4 children: Kenneth, Jane, Ann Noble and Elizabeth. Kenneth was married to the late Elizabeth Hoyt McGovern. Services will be held 11:00 AM Saturday, June 28, at Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Pelham, New York. In liew of flowers, the family requests that donations are sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: Who Needs the N.E.A.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTAUER, SUE
description: LITTAUER-Sue. Beloved mother of Beverly and Roberta. Cherished grandmother of Ian, Terence, Jocelyn and Daniel. Adored great grandmother of Miriam. Dear aunt of Bernard, Mickey, Jackie, Josh and Laura. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, Wednesday 9:30AM.

title: The Big Mayoral Issue: Can Johnny Read Now?
description: The New York City third graders who picked up their pencils earlier this year for yet another reading test probably had no idea how many grown-up politicians were anxiously looking over their shoulders. But the results of that test, released two weeks ago, have become the single hot issue in a mayoral campaign so far bereft of serious policy debates.

title: Do as We Do
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PACIFIC GAS AND ELECTRIC CO., San Francisco, said it planned to sell four more power plants in California, as part of the state's plan to deregulate its electricity industry.

title: Suddenly, Out of Obscurity, She's the New Voice in Brazil
description: Virginia Rodrigues's journey began in the hillside slums outside Salvador. She was too poor for formal training, but her love for music drew her to choirs at Roman Catholic and Protestant churches. Even so, she never abandoned Candomble, the religion of her ancestors, with its pantheon of deities and powerful percussion music.

title: Again From the Box Tops, Antics and Blue-Eyed Soul
description: There were two kinds of people at the Box Tops concert on Saturday night at Tramps. Some were there for nostalgia, because it was the first reunion in 29 years featuring the original lineup of the Memphis band, which recorded the hit ''The Letter'' in 1967. Almost everybody else was there because the band's singer is Alex Chilton, who went on to amass a cult following after leaving the Box Tops, first as a member of the seminal but obscure 70's band Big Star and later with a singularly eclectic solo career.

title: Israeli Premier Survives Vote Of Confidence In Parliament
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu survived a no-confidence vote in the Parliament today, though only through some last-minute deals and with several damaging defections.

title: Tyson a Not So Raging Bull
description: The post-penitentiary years:

title: AIDS Policy Coordinator Is Stepping Down
description: New York City's first official AIDS policy coordinator, Ronald S. Johnson, is stepping down after five years to join Gay Men's Health Crisis, the nation's largest AIDS services organization, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: 2 Diplomats Who Clashed With Officers Leave Country
description: Two diplomats from Russia and Belarus who scuffled with New York City police officers last December, setting off a season of testy relations between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the United Nations diplomatic corps, have quietly left the country.

title: Mayors Are Opposed To Air Quality Plan
description: Mayors voted today at their national conference to oppose a plan by the Environmental Protection Agency to set strict new limits on smog and soot, saying such standards could jeopardize local economies.

title: Jobless Rate for City Fell Slightly in May
description: The unemployment rate in New York City inched down last month, falling to 9.6 percent, from 9.7 percent in April, the New York State Department of Labor said yesterday. The statewide jobless rate was unchanged, at 6.3 percent, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations.

title: Postal Worker Admits Scheme
description: Sergio Hernandez needed help paying his mortgage and other bills, he told a Federal judge yesterday. But unlike most people with a similar problem, Mr. Hernandez had ready access to cash. He was the postmaster of Sayreville.

title: TRIARC EXPANDING WITH ADDITION OF CABLE CAR BEVERAGE
description: The Triarc Companies agreed yesterday to buy the Cable Car Beverage Corporation for about $31 million in stock as Triarc, the maker of Snapple and Mistic beverages, seeks to expand its high-end beverage business. The Denver-based Cable Car markets the Stewart's Root Beer and Orange N' Cream sodas. Triarc expects to issue 1.5 million new shares to Cable Car holders. Each Cable Car share will be exchanged for 0.1722 share of Triarc class A stock in the transaction. Triarc's shares fell 37.5 cents, to $20.375, and Cable Car shares were down 78.1 cents, to $3.25. Cable Car, which hires other companies to make its beverages and sells the drinks to distributors, had 1996 sales of $18.8 million.

title: On Beijing's Leash, the News In Hong Kong May Lose Bite
description: For all his amiable veneer, Fong So spends his days in a small office here tormenting a group of old men.

title: Nasdaq Reports Marginal Rise In Uncovered Short Positions
description: Short-selling on the Nasdaq stock market rose slightly in June, according to figures released yesterday.

title: On to Round 2, Whiskers and All
description: Justin Gimelstob said he did not bother to shave before his opening-round singles match with Gustavo Kuerten at Wimbledon today because he did not expect to be in the limelight after it.

title: Exxon Settles F.T.C. Suit on Gas Ads
description: The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest oil company, has reached a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission in which it must run television advertisements acknowledging that more expensive, high-octane fuels are not better for most cars than other grades of gasoline.

title: William Metcalf, 68, a City Opera Baritone
description: William Metcalf, a baritone who sang with the New York City Opera for more than a decade, died on June 5 at the Terence Cardinal Cook Health Center in East Harlem. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The robust number of passengers on United States airlines this year shows no signs of easing.
description: AIRLINE passenger loads show no signs of easing, and in fact carriers have already boarded millions more passengers this year than last, when a record 581.2 million passengers flew.

title: Beijing Says It Won't Go Along With Creation of Pol Pot Tribunal
description: As a Cambodian Government request for help in bringing Khmer Rouge leaders to justice formally reached the United Nations today, China indicated that it would not support the creation of an international tribunal.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: OVERHEARD by Nidia Besso at a Central Park playground, between two girls about 6 or 7, the day after a heavy rainfall.

title: The Dow Regains 153.80 Points As Stocks Rebound From Selloff
description: Remember that big selloff Monday? Forget it.

title: Lobbyists for TV Angle to Elude Rules to Return Free Channels
description: In April, Federal regulators lent each of the nation's 1,600 television stations a second channel for the coming transition to digital broadcasting, despite complaints that the extra channels represented a multibillion-dollar gift of public property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRISCHMAN, DORIS
description: FRISCHMAN-Doris. Beloved wife of Bernard (Ben); Beautiful mother of Judy and Laura and cherished sister of Bernard; Devoted grandmother of Irene, Randi, Mindi and Steven. Great grandmother of Tyler, Hanna, Ilana, Noah, Brittany; Services at Sherman's Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY, 10:00 AM, Friday, June 27.

title: John Akii-Bua, 47, Is Dead; Ugandan Won Olympic Gold
description: John Akii-Bua, a slender hurdler who surprisingly won an Olympic gold medal in 1972 and almost paid for it with his life, died last Friday in Mulago Hospital in Kampala, Uganda. He was 47 years old.

title: The Nervous Season: Beijing and a U.S. Prisoner
description: With less than a week before Hong Kong's legal system starts answering to a Chinese master, the authorities quietly released a senior United States immigration official from custody today.

title: Fruits of Integration
description: To the Editor:

title: Milk Fat as Cancer Fighter
description: Just when people are finally learning to tolerate, if not enjoy, skim milk, nonfat yogurt, fat-free cream cheese, cottage cheese and sour cream, comes this finding from an Australian nutrition researcher: cows' milk fat contains a number of cancer inhibitors. Just maybe, in efforts to cut dietary fat to save hearts and figures and prevent some cancers, people are eliminating some fats that may be beneficial.

title: Simply a Better Machine
description: To the Editor:

title: Murder Charged in Prom Case
description: The New Jersey teen-ager who gave birth in a bathroom stall at her senior prom and left the newborn baby in a knotted plastic bag was formally accused of murder yesterday.

title: No Time for Meddling
description: ''A secret meeting?'' roared Israel's Arik Sharon at his Jordanian counterpart as negotiations about water rights reached the critical point. ''I am not a mistress!''

title: Home-Services Alliance Forms
description: Utilicorp United Inc. and the Peco Energy Corporation said today that they had formed an alliance with the AT&T Corporation and ADT Ltd. to sell electricity, natural gas, Internet access and home security services in a single package to customers.

title: U.S. Seeks Delay of Loan To Croatia
description: Signaling mounting frustration with President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, the Clinton Administration said today that the United States would try to block the World Bank from considering a $30 million loan for Croatia.

title: Canada Honors Its Birthplace, but Where Is It, Eh?
description: Precisely 500 years ago today, a flimsy, 70-foot English caravel called the Matthew plowed through the heavy fog of the icy sea and dropped anchor at this rocky spit of land.

title: Gleeful Drag Queens and That Poor Raven
description: Lenore Usher is not a well woman. (She is not, well, a woman, either.) But as played by Sherry Vine (known to friends and family as Keith Levy), Lenore is a blond goddess of gore, the author of a gruesome best seller about body parts and a penthouse-bound agoraphobe who plots murderously with her overdressed housekeeper, Cora Tripetta.

title: Three Herbs That Are Hard to Find but Easy to Appreciate
description: FOR the avid cook or gardener, almost all herbs are worth growing. Limited space or time may call for pruning one's ambitions. With most common herbs readily available in the market, it makes sense to grow those that are hard to find.

title: The Nets Are Thinking Big, Bigger and Biggest
description: A Nets staffer or two had eyes fixed on the workout of the 6-foot-11-inch center Tony Battie yesterday morning, but team officials were thinking big all day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAY, DOROTHY KEYES
description: DAY-Dorothy Keyes, 80, of Southbury, CT., on June 23, 1997. Retired English teacher. Widow of Allen F. Day. Loving mother of Allen. Sister of William, Robert, Marion and Leonore. Grandmother of E. Spencer, Evan and Ashton.

title: A Citrus Olive Oil Finds Favor
description: AMONG the 40,000 products that will be competing for attention at the Fancy Food Show in Manhattan this weekend, one is already a standout: an unusual citrus olive oil called O, which has been nominated for best new product and best package design at the show.

title: Accounts
description: * Avery Dennison Worldwide Office Products, Los Angeles, to Saatchi & Saatchi San Francisco, owned by Cordiant P.L.C., to handle consumer advertising for a new line of greeting cards for ink-jet printers. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million.

title: Toy Biz Fills Four Vacancies on Its Board
description: Toy Biz Inc. said yesterday that it had filled four of the vacancies caused by the resignations of five directors connected with a change of management at Marvel Entertainment Group.

title: A Festival Aims to Stimulate Outsiders' Art and Commerce
description: Every few years something ignites the issue of blacks in Hollywood. Back in 1915, it was D. W. Griffith's ''Birth of a Nation.'' The N.A.A.C.P. tried to have it banned because of its stereotyping of blacks and sympathetic treatment of the Ku Klux Klan. Last year, it was a cover story in a national magazine, ''Hollywood Blackout.'' Warrington Hudlin, the black filmmaker, and his friend Byron Lewis, chairman of Uniworld, a Manhattan-based black advertising agency, were among those troubled by the article, which concluded that exclusion of blacks had become a ''way of life in Hollywood.'' It noted that only one of the 166 nominees for that year's Academy Awards was an African-American. ''It's time for us to do something,'' Mr. Lewis told Mr. Hudlin.

title: CUNY Board's Leader Says Chancellor Is Under Review and Suggests She Resign
description: Escalating their attacks on the performance of W. Ann Reynolds, the Chancellor of the City University of New York, the new chairwoman and vice chairman of the university's board said yesterday that they would assess her performance in coming months to see whether she should continue in her job.

title: Unanimity of Budget Deal Quickly Falls by the Wayside
description: On May 2, the drums rolled, the champagne corks popped and President Clinton and the Republican Congress announced that they had reached a historic agreement to cut taxes, increase spending on several programs and balance the budget in five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODY, CARLOTA
description: GODY-Carlota. Beloved wife of John Gody. Devoted mother of Lilian Vardy and Catalina Meyer. Grandmother of Eric Wald, David Vardy, Ilana Vardy and Risa Meyer. Memorial services will be held at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, New York City, at 2:45 P.M. today.

title: Air Force Details a New Theory in U.F.O. Case
description: No bodies. No bulbous heads. No secret autopsies. No spaceship. No crash. No extraterrestrials or alien artifacts of any sort. And most emphatically of all, no Government cover-up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIN, MAURICE M.
description: DUBIN-Maurice M. Died peacefully in his 101st year on June 23, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Leah. Loving father of Marjorie and Alfred Faeder and Sydelle and Mac Carter. Devoted grandfather of six and great grandfather of ten. Dear brother of Harry. Service private.

title: A Serenade for the Ultimate Sophisticated Lady
description: Two of the many film clips of Lena Horne shown during her 80th birthday celebration at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening spoke volumes about the woman whom the Society of Singers presented with the Ella Award for Lifetime Achievement in Vocal Artistry. In her late-career performances of Jim Croce's ''I Got a Name'' and of ''Believe in Yourself,'' from ''The Wiz,'' the singer animated lyrics exhorting self-determination with a transforming ferocity. All the messy emotions of life swirled together into a defiant assertion of willpower that made you sense every wound suffered as well as every triumph.

title: Pataki's Plan On Welfare Faces Defeat
description: Seven months after Gov. George E. Pataki proposed the most sweeping overhaul ever of the state's welfare system, the plan faces almost certain rejection in the Legislature, with opposition building not only among Democrats in the Assembly but also among many of his Republican allies who control the Senate.

title: Montana Bank Merger
description: The United Financial Corporation and Heritage Bancorporation, two banking companies based in Great Falls, said today that they had agreed to merge. United Financial, a savings institution with $108 million in assets, and Heritage, with $69 million in assets, will have a market value of about $33 million when combined, the companies said. United Financial shareholders will own 72 percent of the merged entity. Other terms were not disclosed.

title: H.M.O.'s Fight Plan to Pay For Some Emergency Care
description: For six months, as Congress has considered far-reaching proposals to regulate managed health care, the industry has waged a public relations offensive under the slogan ''putting patients first.''

title: Right Result on Whitewater
description: Thanks to the Supreme Court, Whitewater investigators now have the notes they were seeking from conversations in 1995 and 1996 between White House lawyers and the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton. In refusing to review a subpoena ordering the White House to turn over the notes, the Court left standing a lower court ruling that rebuffed the White House's overreaching claim that the notes were protected by attorney-client privilege. The lower court correctly found that such privilege did not extend to Mrs. Clinton's conversations with Government lawyers about Whitewater matters, which are of a personal nature.

title: Ace of Mets' Coaching Staff
description: ONE day in 1994, after having served 13 years in the Mets' organization as a pitching coach -- from Little Falls in the Class A New York-Penn League to Jackson in the Class AA Texas League to Norfolk in the AAA International League, among a bunch of other places -- Bob Apodaca was called in to talk to Dallas Green, then the Mets' manager. There was an opening for a pitching coach with the Mets.

title: PREMIER BANCSHARES IS PURCHASING GEORGIA BANK
description: Premier Bancshares Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Citizens Gwinnett Bankshares Inc. for about $35 million in stock. Premier, an Atlanta-based bank and savings and loan holding company, said it would issue between 2,072,378 and 2,311,633 common shares in exchange for all of Citizens Gwinnett's outstanding shares. The specific number of shares would be set prior to the regulatory filing of the acquisition, which is expected to close before the end of the year. Citizens Gwinnett, of Georgia's Gwinnett County, has about $155 million in assets and four branches. Premier has more than $700 million in assets and a total of 25 branches. Shares of Premier Bancshares were unchanged yesterday at $16.

title: Correction
description: The diagram accompanying the chess column yesterday, about a game between Viktor Korchnoi and Peter Svidler, was garbled in some editions. Below is a corrected version. It was here, after 31 h5, that Svidler resigned, seeing that 31 . . . gh 32 Be7 Be7 33 R1c6 b4 34 Rh6 Kg7 35 Re6 would win easily.

title: From Left Side or From Right Side, Everett Is Hot
description: Despite carrying the hottest bat on the team, Carl Everett still stopped to take a look at the bulletin board as he entered the Mets' clubhouse yesterday. On the board, which is just outside Manager Bobby Valentine's office, the names of the day's starters are posted.

title: Camden Finance Bill Stalled
description: A bill to give the state greater control of Camden's finances has been stalled by the legislators who represent the city and will not be taken up until after the summer recess, officials said yesterday.

title: ABC, Ratings Falling, Elevates an Executive
description: ABC named a longtime program executive, Stu Bloomberg, chairman of its entertainment division yesterday, in a move widely interpreted as a response to continuing problems with the network's prime-time programming.

title: Automatic Deportation Law Isn't Retroactive, Judge Says
description: The Government cannot use the 1996 antiterrorism law to automatically deport legal immigrants who were convicted of some crimes before it was enacted, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Company Draws Rich Eco-Tourists to Africa
description: The most famous employee of the Conservation Corporation of Africa is not Dave Varty or Alan Bernstein, the founders. Nor is it a member of the Getty family, a major investor. It is Zibane Mazibuko, a poacher caught with a dead antelope on the company's Phinda Game Reserve. He has been featured in environmental magazines as an example of Conscorp's enlightened attitude toward the African communities in which it operates game lodges.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Cold and Narrow Fit
description: To The Living Section:

title: James S. Todd, 65, Surgeon Who Led Medical Association
description: Dr. James S. Todd, a New Jersey surgeon who was the executive vice president and chief executive officer of the American Medical Association from 1990 until he retired last year, died yesterday in Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 65 and lived in Ridgewood.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wachovia to Buy Bank In Virginia for $2.3 Billion

title: Safir Is a No-Show At Council Hearing
description: A City Council hearing on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposal to give the Police Commissioner more power to discipline officers turned into a test of wills yesterday when Police Commissioner Howard Safir refused to testify after learning that former Mayor David N. Dinkins was also scheduled to appear.

title: Conference Follows Shooting
description: Mayor Sharpe James of Newark will lead a ''unity conference'' today in an attempt to ease tensions arising from a recent fatal shooting by the police. Municipal officials, representatives of local colleges, clergy members and law enforcement officers will meet with residents at City Hall. The Mayor's office would not release the invitation list, but members of the City Council, the Newark Police Department and Ras Baraka, a community organizer, have said they may attend. The event will be closed to news organizations.

title: Another Broadcast Giveaway
description: Congress begins voting as early as today on proposals that could turn last year's giveaway to broadcasters into a perpetual gift.

title: If It Is Fielder's Choice, Detroit Feels Like Home
description: Cecil Fielder stood behind the batting cage this afternoon at Tiger Stadium, puffing on a huge cigar and laughing with his former Detroit teammates. He pointed to the right-field upper deck repeatedly, obviously discussing homers he had hit during his seven seasons as an icon here.

title: In Favor of Computers Without Complications
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Sharp in Schools
description: If teachers in the Lower Camden County Region look a little spiffier next fall, it will not be because they got a raise. On Monday night, the Board of Education voted to impose a dress code on its entire staff, requiring men to wear jackets, ties or sweaters, and women to wear skirts, dresses or pants suits.

title: UNION PLANTERS IN $59 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR BANK
description: The Union Planters Corporation, a banking company with $15 billion in assets and 433 offices in Missouri, Tennessee, Mississippi, Arkansas, Louisiana, Alabama and Kentucky, agreed yesterday to acquire the Sho-Me Financial Corporation for $39.34 a share, or $59 million, in stock. Union Planters of Memphis would exchange 0.7694 share of its common stock for each common share of Sho-Me, which operates eight banking units. Sho-Me, based in Mount Vernon, Mo., has assets of $305 million and about $29 million in shareholders' equity. Shares of Sho-Me fell $2.25, to $37.50, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Union Planters were up 12.5 cents, to $51.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Rally in 9th Gives Mets Another Reason to Believe
description: The Mets had every right to be heady entering last night's game with the Atlanta Braves, having won five straight, including their first encounter of the season with the mighty two-time defending National League champions on Monday.

title: A Few Rules for Drawing Legislative Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: Nike's Asian Factories Pass Young's Muster
description: Andrew Young, the civil rights leader called upon by Nike Inc. to look into its overseas labor practices, said yesterday that a months-long investigation had turned up no evidence of widespread or systematic mistreatment of workers.

title: Iraqis Still Defying Arms Ban, Departing U.N. Official Says
description: Six years after the Security Council imposed its extraordinarily intrusive inspections on Iraq, that country's scientists are still under orders to keep the nation ready to make lethal chemical weapons at short notice, even if existing stocks are destroyed, according to a United Nations official.

title: D'Amato Vows to Fight for E.P.A.'s Tightened Air Standards
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York threw his support today behind the embattled Environmental Protection Agency and its proposals to toughen air quality standards, promising that he would lead a fight in Congress against any lawmakers who opposed them.

title: Tarango Loses Without a Tantrum
description: This time there was no hubbub as Jeff Tarango left the court. He was forced to walk in place on the cramped corridor alongside Court 4 because the jammed spectators could not create a space for his departure.

title: A.M.A. Ratifies Leaders' Call for a Late-Term Abortion Ban
description: After some dissent, the American Medical Association today ratified its leaders' earlier endorsement of Federal legislation that would ban a type of late-term abortion, a ban that would impose criminal penalties on doctors who performed the procedure.

title: Philip Morris To Pay Most Of First Bill
description: The Philip Morris Companies, the giant of the cigarette industry, will provide the majority of an initial $10 billion payment under the $368.5 billion tobacco settlement proposal reached last week, industry officials said yesterday.

title: A Sauce With Lamb Is Nice With Rice (or Even Pasta)
description: Lamb and rice with olives and dried cherries is a long description for a dish that is very quick to make. The lamb serves simply as part of a thick sauce that is served over the rice, though it would surely go nicely over small pasta, as well. The spinach dish, with its slight spiciness, plays nicely off the lamb and rice.

title: First Homer Doesn't Clinch It, So Martinez Blasts Another
description: Tino Martinez's prodigious three-run homer in the sixth inning, which hit off the third deck in right field, should have catapulted the Yankees to an easy victory tonight. It almost soared out of Tiger Stadium, and it gave the Yankees a comfortable 9-3 lead. They should have been yawning in the ninth.

title: What Ever Happened To the Stars of the 80's?
description: THE heady days of New York in the 1980's, when restaurants were theater and chefs achieved the celebrity status of movie stars, are gone, and with them some of the brightest lights at the stove.

title: Wachovia to Acquire Central Fidelity, in 2d Virginia Deal
description: The Wachovia Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Central Fidelity Banks Inc. of Richmond, the second time in less than a month that Wachovia has moved to acquire a Virginia banking company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATRELLE, ELVIRA R.
description: PATRELLE-Elvira R. Beloved wife of the late Joseph G. Devoted mother of Jospeh A. and wife Barbara and Francis. Loving sister of Alfred Recupido. Also survived by four cherished grandchildren and 8 great-grandchildren. Reposing Scotto Funeral Home, 106 1st Pl. (near Court Street), Bklyn, until Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Mary Star of the Sea R.C. Church, 9:15 A.M. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers all donations to Dances...Patrelle, in memory of Elvira Patrelle. For any additional information call 718-875-2515.

title: Corrections
description: A review on June 16 about the Venice Biennale, the art exhibition, misstated the closing date. It is Nov. 9, not Oct. 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, ELAINE ASHER
description: ROSE-Elaine Asher. The members of the New York Wellesley College Friends of Art mourn the untimely passing of their longtime associate Elaine Asher Rose. The Friends of Art and the Davis Museum and Cultural Center at Wellesley have benefitted immeasurably from her vision, energy, and sound advice over many years. She will be sorely missed. To honor her, a memorial fund has been established at the College for the purchase of a work of art in her name.

title: Pataki Plan for Increases In Tuition Is Seen Failing
description: Top state lawmakers in Albany indicated yesterday that the State University and City University tuition increases that Gov. George E. Pataki proposed in January were unlikely to be enacted, thanks to a healthy economy and better-than-expected state tax revenue.

title: Pippen in Celtics' Green?
description: A frantic night of trade talks throughout the National Basketball Association led to one very interesting possibility involving the Bulls' Scottie Pippen. Those close to the situation said Boston Coach Rick Pitino was mulling a deal in which he would send his team's third and sixth picks in tonight's draft to Chicago for Pippen and center Luc Longley.

title: The Use and Injection of Heroin Are Rising in Cities, a Study Says
description: More snorters of heroin in Chicago and New York, among other cities, have taken to injecting the drug for a more efficient high, according to a report on national trends in illicit drug use released yesterday.

title: Summertime for the Unions
description: One of the great warm-weather traditions in New York's State Legislature -- along with baseball, late budgets and fund-raising parties where the only paying guests are lobbyists -- is passing special-interest bills for public-employee unions.

title: 7 Are Accused of Fraud In Hormone Purchases
description: Federal authorities have charged seven people in a scheme to fraudulently obtain a human growth hormone that has become popular among athletes because it enhances performance but is not detected by drug tests.

title: Wine Talk
description: REAL men don't drink rose. What guy is going to belly up to the bar and demand, ''A glass of rose''? Real connoisseurs don't drink it, either. They like to show off, to order by region, by vintage, even by the name of the winemaker if they can. With rose, that's not easy to do.

title: Special School District Has Worst Math Scores
description: While math scores across the city inched up this spring, students in 12 school districts performed worse than last year, with the poorest showing in a special district that New York City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew established to lift up the city's lowest performing schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCHISIO, ROSINA LAWRENCE
description: MARCHISIO-Rosina Lawrence, June 23, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Judge Juvenal Marchisio and caring wife of Dr. John McCabe. Loving mother of Juvenal L., Rosina and Margaret. Adoring grandmother of Giulia, Francesco, Juvenal, Christina, and Arianna. Her grace and sensitivity have left an indelible imprint upon us all and her courage and strength during her final days will be an inspiration to her family and all who loved her. Family will receive friends Thursday, June 26th, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, 7-9:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her name may be made to Mount Sinai Medical Center, Dept. of Surgery, Box 1049, One Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, New York 10029-6574, Attention: Zmira Goodman.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT DE NIRO is renowned for his ability to avoid publicity, and he certainly kept private his marriage last week to GRACE HIGHTOWER, a former flight attendant.

title: Big Tobacco's Big Mistake
description: First, some disclosures. I have never puffed a cigarette in my life. And I have advised Philip Morris on its defense strategy for nearly 13 years. I see no contradiction there. Smoking is not a habit I wish to acquire. Nor is it a practice for which tobacco companies should be held liable. The controversial $368.5 billion settlement to which the tobacco industry has agreed (in which I played no role) represents the misguided substitution of political muscle for sound legal principle.

description: Edmund L. Jenkins, a retired managing partner for Arthur Andersen, was named yesterday as chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the seven-member group responsible for establishing the nation's accounting rules.

description: CUTLER-Arthur J. Our hearts ache with sympathy for his wife Alice and his daughters Jody and Danielle. He will live on in our hearts forever. Newmark & Company Real Estate Inc. William Cohen Ronald Goldberger Barry Gosin Aaron Gural Jeffrey Gural Ira Fishman James Kuhn Arthur Lerner Marlene Post and Arthur Rosenbloom.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies yesterday about a bill to impose new limits on contributions to the political action committees set up by state legislative leaders misstated the current limit. The amount is $30,000, not $25,000.

title: Excerpts From Agreement Between States and Tobacco Industry
description: Following are excerpts from the proposal for a settlement reached last Friday by tobacco industry representatives, a group of state attorneys general and plaintiffs' lawyers. The agreement is expected to alter the nation's legal, regulatory and public health landscape permanently. Among other changes, the proposed settlement would require cigarette companies to pay $368.5 billion over the next 25 years to compensate states for the costs of treating smoking-related illness, to finance nationwide anti- smoking programs and to underwrite health care for millions of uninsured children. The text was downloaded from the Web site at http://stic.neu.edu run by the State Tobacco Information Center, an information clearing house created to provide information for the public and attorneys general involved in the case.

title: DASSAULT SYSTEMES IS ACQUIRING SOLIDWORKS
description: Dassault Systemes S.A., a leading maker of computer-aided design software based in Suresnes, France, agreed yesterday to acquire the Solidworks Corporation of Concord, Mass., for stock valued at about $300 million. Solidworks, which is privately held, also produces software for mechanical design. The deal was announced after Dassault's American depository receipts gained $1.25, to $65.25, in Nasdaq trading. Dassault produces primarily mainframe-based software for industrial customers and suppliers. Solidworks has developed mechanical design software products primarily for use with Microsoft's Windows operating system software for personal computers.

title: Hummus Maker's Recall Widened
description: Cedar's Mediterranean Foods, whose hummus was ordered recalled this month by the Food and Drug Administration, has now been directed by the F.D.A. to remove all its salads and dips from store shelves nationwide. The products could contain a bacteria that could sicken healthy people and also cause serious and sometimes fatal illness in infants, the elderly and those with weakened immune systems, said an F.D.A. spokesman, Bradford Stone.

title: Tracing Threads of Meaning Through Time
description: Long before the current rage for thematic programming, often of a heavy-handed and superficial kind, subtler strains flourished. Good programming depends at least as much on intuition as on planning, and it stems as often as not from seeming inadvertence.

title: Odd-Couple Salads in the Summer Kitchen (Hold the Heat)
description: THERE was always something oddly appealing about the Waldorf salad, that mad amalgam of apples, walnuts, celery and mayonnaise. But that last ingredient sealed its fate. These days, we prefer our salads sharp and lean, not smooth and, well, gunky.

title: Panel to Call Former Wife Of Mandela
description: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, established to investigate the atrocities in this country's past, will subpoena Winnie Mandela, President Nelson Mandela's former wife, to a closed session of the panel, officials of the commission said today.

title: House Defeats Effort to Punish China by Curbing Trade
description: In a 259-to-173 vote, the House today easily rejected the annual attempt to punish China by ending its normal trading status with the United States.

title: Attorneys General Defend Landmark Tobacco Pact
description: With a landmark tobacco settlement coming under increasing criticism as too lenient on cigarette companies, state attorneys general today offered a spirited defense of the pact they reached after nearly three months of negotiations, describing it as an unprecedented leap forward on a vital public health issue.

title: Thyssen to Sell 2 Units To Ispat of Britain
description: Thyssen A.G. said yesterday that it planned to sell two steel units to Ispat International Ltd. of Britain for an undisclosed price as Thyssen, Germany's largest diversified steelmaker, redoubles efforts to focus on its most profitable businesses.

title: Focus on Tobacco Pact
description: Details of the settlement between the tobacco companies and several state attorneys general are coming under intense scrutiny. While many praise the deal, others say the companies should be more strictly supervised and not allowed tax deductions for payments to ill smokers. The Philip Morris Companies will pay most of the initial $10 billion of the $368.5 billion settlement

title: Parochial Schools Ruling Heartens Voucher Backers
description: A dramatic Supreme Court ruling allowing public school systems to send teachers into parochial schools for remedial programs has given new optimism to backers of voucher plans in three states, Wisconsin, Ohio and Vermont, now fighting in court to revive programs providing public funds to families to pay parochial school tuition.

title: Wrong on Sex Offenders
description: Everyone can agree that society has a a duty to protect children from violent sex offenders, but the Supreme Court has gone down a potentially dangerous road for civil liberties in upholding a 1994 Kansas law that waters down the ordinary criteria for involuntary civil commitment as a way to keep sex offenders confined in mental hospitals after they complete their prison sentences.

Just in time for Independence Day and the big U.F.O. bash in Roswell, the Air Force has finally coughed up an explanation of what happened in the New Mexico desert that caused untold numbers of Americans to believe that the military covered up a 1947 spaceship crash.

title: South Korea to Keep Bank Ownership System
description: South Korea will retain its bank ownership limits, blocking attempts by the country's powerful conglomerates to exert more control over their finances. The Finance and Economy Minister, Kang Kyung Shik, said yesterday that the maximum holding in a commercial bank would remain at 4 percent, scotching speculation that the limit would be raised to 10 percent to encourage conglomerates to play a management role at banks.

title: Ex-Lawyer for Police Union Is Accused of Tax Evasion
description: For a brief moment in 1988, Richard Hartman seemed like a broken man. The fortune he had earned as a lawyer for city police unions and his reputation for shrewd negotiating were threatened by an investigation into charges that he had used clients' money to pay off his gambling debts. Mr. Hartman forfeited his law license, and charges were never filed.

title: Communists Are Coming, And Stocks Are Soaring
description: Just like its older cousin in New York, the Hong Kong stock market is benefiting from a robust economy and stable interest rates, and last week it hit highs and saw record volume.

title: TV Ratings Are Mired In Demand By Industry
description: On the brink of completing negotiations on revising the six-month-old television ratings system, the television industry and a coalition of parent-advocacy groups reached an impasse yesterday over the industry's position that the groups and Congressional leaders must pledge to keep the issues of violence and sex on television out of the political arena for at least two years.

title: Passion Among the Nomads
description: ''Gabbeh'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Lawrence Van Gelder's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 10, 1996. The film opens today at theaters in the New York area.

title: Fear of Mob Wrath Is No Excuse for Jury
description: Two prospective jurors in the trial of Vincent Gigante, the reputed Mafia boss, said they were afraid of retribution if they convicted him, but the judge yesterday refused to excuse them.

title: How to sell Amstel beer? One idea: Fill Times Square with billboards opposing its consumption.
description: AS this serious?'' asked John Handy as he walked down 42d Street near Times Square. ''I don't understand; is this a joke?''

title: Saving the N.A.A.C.P.'s Soul
description: Twenty-five years ago, when the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was at its influential peak, its leaders looked forward to the day when the United States would no longer need an N.A.A.C.P. The nation's endemic racism clearly shows that that day is far away. Yet the organization is now talking of abandoning the fight for integration of public schools that had defined its very soul.

title: Social Ties Reduce Risk of a Cold
description: BUILDING on a dozen studies correlating friendship and fellowship with health, a new study has found that people with a broad array of social ties are significantly less likely to catch colds than those with sparse social networks.

title: About the Man of Expressive Circles and Cubes
description: ''Always Isamu brought to me his idea of space, the intimacy of an object onstage,'' Martha Graham wrote of the set designs that the sculptor Isamu Noguchi made for her for decades. Noguchi himself, bemoaning the second-hand quality of photography, wrote that ''sculpture is the art which can only be appreciated in the raw.'' What chance is there that a television documentary can capture the tactile quality and sense of space so essential to Noguchi's art, those giant stones and landscape gardens that are his best-known legacy? His circles, cubes and abstract forms seem to rise out of the earth, with an enigmatic, evocative quality that owes something to Stonehenge.

title: APOLLO MANAGEMENT IN DEAL FOR SMT HEALTH SERVICES
description: Apollo Management L.P. agreed yesterday to acquire SMT Health Services Inc., a provider of diagnostic imaging services, for about $100 million, which includes the assumption of $24 million in debt. Apollo, an investment firm headed by the financier Leon Black, said it would offer $11.75 a share directly to SMT's shareholders. SMT stock rose 28 cents, to $11.531 a share, in Nasdaq trading. SMT's board had unanimously approved the agreement, and SMT's managers, who own about 15 percent of the company, have agreed to sell their shares to Apollo. SMT, which is based in Wexford, Pa., operates 19 mobile Magnetic Resonance Imaging units.

title: Coffin Company Acquired
description: The Service Corporation International, the world's largest funeral chain, said today that it had acquired the Marsellus Casket Company of Syracuse. Terms were not disclosed. The Houston-based Service Corporation operates 2,882 funeral homes, 345 cemeteries and 150 crematories in North America, Europe and the Pacific Rim. Marsellus, based in Syracuse, is considered the nation's leading manufacturer of wooden coffins.

description: In a move intended to speed up the growth of international electronic commerce, the Commerce Department granted permission today to the Netscape Communications Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation to export more secure versions of their software to banking customers.

description: The chorus girl in overalls was peculiar -- most peculiar -- to the Soviet bloc. She epitomized the Marxist movie musical in which there were no pennies from heaven, only the fair rewards of maniacally cheerful work.

description: Sears P.L.C., a British retailer, said yesterday that sales growth in recent weeks had slowed because of poor demand for children's clothing and footwear. The retailer, which owns Selfridges, the London department store, said sales in the 19-week period through June 14 had risen 2.5 percent from a year earlier, compared with a 5.3 percent rise in the first 11 weeks of the period.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHABAZZ, DR. BETTY
description: SHABAZZ-Dr. Betty. Columbia University mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Betty Shabazz. Dr. Shabazz devoted her life to promoting the values of education, community, and family. She was herself a leading example of those principles, educating herself in college and graduate school while working and raising a family following the death of her husband, Malcolm X. All educators everywhere owe a deep debt to her leadership and the inspiration she gave to young people by her teaching, her dedication, and the example of her own life. Columbia is proud to have worked with her for more than a decade in establishing the Malcolm X Memorial Scholarship for minority students at Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons. She was proud of the program, and proud of the more than 20 students who have been Malcolm X Scholars and who practice in fields as diverse as anesthesiology, obstetrics and gynecology, orthopedic surgery, pediatrics, and medicine. Betty asked these recipients to give something back, in the spirit of her husband, to the less fortunate, medically underserved people of the inner city. In the Malcolm X scholarship program, Columbia commits itself to helping instill the values Dr. Shabazz stood for not only through the work of the Malcolm X Scholarship, but to all students who study medicine and the health professions at Columbia. Dr. Shabazz was an inspiration in life and in deed. She will be deeply missed. George Rupp, Ph.D. President Columbia University Herbert Pardes, M.D. Vice President and Dean, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons

title: Church's Faith In the Bronx Survives Fire
description: A DEFIANT majesty clings to St. Philip Neri Roman Catholic Church, even though its bells are silent and its empty sanctuary is exposed to heat and rain. Although an electrical fire reduced its roof to ashes two Sundays ago, its stone walls are ever steady. Not bad for a 99-year-old church built by Italian immigrants who -- in their spare time, no less -- hauled rocks to the site after carving out the basin for the Jerome Park Reservoir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORMER, GUNNEL JERREBO
description: DORMER-Gunnel Jerrebo, 58, of Palm Harbor, Florida, died Sunday June 22 at Helen Alice Memorial Hospital in Tarpon Springs, Florida. She was born in Helsingborg, Sweden, and came to the United States in 1965. Before moving to Florida in 1994 she was a member of the staff of The College Board in New York City. Survivors include her husband Robert, one stepdaughter and three stepsons, six grandchildren, and 2 brothers Bertil and Claes Jerrebo and their families in Sweden. Burial will be in Helsingborg, Sweden.

title: A Market Grows, Not by Fish Alone
description: CITARELLA, 2135 Broadway (75th Street), was once a modest fish market. But like Zabar's, another Upper West Side institution that was once just a deli, it keeps expanding. Citarella has transformed its second-floor office and storage space into a bazaar of coffees, pickles, smoked fish, charcuterie, cheeses, chocolates and pastries. The new pastry chef is Giovanni Strassi, who worked at Peck, Milan's best-known prepared-food company.

It's not a boondoggle but a trip to promote jams and spreads at the summer Fancy Food Show, a trade show for the kinds of products that line the shelves of high-end food markets.
