title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GAVIN, HELEN, M.D.
description: GAVIN-Helen, M.D. Esteemed and dearly loved physician, cousin, friend, who died on June 25, 1972. Never forgotten.

title: 2 Children Are Abandoned in Central Park
description: Two girls -- a toddler and an infant -- were abandoned in a playground in Central Park yesterday afternoon by a woman who was overheard telling the children that she was going to get them ice cream, the police said.

title: Courville Wins the Ike Championship
description: Jerry Courville Jr. justified his reputation as one of the top amateur golfers in the area again yesterday.

title: From the Welfare Rolls To the Starring Roles
description: The afternoon got off to a slow start at the Academy of Excellence, a training program for welfare recipients on the north side of Milwaukee. A dapper instructor in a double-breasted suit was praising the power of positive attitudes, and for a while the crowded classroom's only visitor was a lone newspaper reporter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELDRIDGE, FLORENCE
description: ELDRIDGE-Florence. Beloved wife of Harry S. Devoted mother of Stephen and Hindee. Loving grandmother of Jolie, Nicole and Michael. Teacher for all times. Services Thurs, 11AM, Westchester Hills Cemetery. For information call Weinstein Memorial Chapels, Yonkers, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday about new guidelines for diagnosing diabetes described incorrectly a group of people without symptoms who should be tested more frequently than once every three years for the disease if they are 45 or older, and should at least consider being tested if younger. It is those whose levels of HDL cholesterol are low -- 35 milligrams per deciliter or lower -- not people whose levels are high.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about labor union support for New York City mayoral candidates misidentified the unit of the Communications Workers of America that has endorsed Sal F. Albanese in the Democratic primary. While District 1 of the Communications Workers, representing more than 30,000 workers in the city, has endorsed Mr. Albanese, Local 1180, representing 7,500 middle managers working for New York City, has not yet made an endorsement.

title: Violence on a Delayed Honeymoon
description: Near the beginning of ''Head Above Water,'' a pitch-black comedy whose plodding screenplay fails to animate its fiendishly misanthropic humor, the central character, Nathalie (Cameron Diaz), explains in a voice-over narration why she married George (Harvey Keitel), a superior court judge more than 20 years her senior. ''He helped me with my little addictions, calmed my nerves and sentenced me to only two years' probation,'' she chirps with an airheaded flippancy that immediately establishes her as a spoiled brat begging for a comeuppance.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia Is Seeking Trustco in a $900 Million Deal
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia said today that it had agreed to buy National Trustco Inc., one of Canada's largest trust companies, for $1.25 billion (Canadian), or $900 million (United States), to increase its business in Ontario.

title: Noah of City's Parks Defends His Choices
description: Henry J. Stern has been caught up in a whimsical mission since becoming Parks Commissioner three years ago: he is determined that every new or restored park and playground include a piece of animal art, if only footprints stamped in concrete.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''Rise!'' a painting by CHRISTOPHER ANSELMO PRIORE, will not be seen in any of the city's major museums. But it will, well, travel past the Guggenheim, the Metropolitan, the Frick, the Whitney and downtown art galleries at least several times a day. That's because starting Friday the painting will be on view in Transit Authority bus No. 9137 on the M1 route, from Harlem to Battery Park and back again.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARC NEIKRUG, a composer and a pianist who has also been Pinchas Zukerman's accompanist for 22 years, has been named artistic director of the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival starting Sept. 1. He will succeed Heiichiro Ohyama, who is stepping down as artistic director after seven years in the post.

title: Treasuries Rise on Fed Governor's Comments
description: Overcoming a strong consumer confidence report, Treasury securities rallied yesterday after Robert Parry, head of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said he foresaw the economy slowing to a moderate pace.

title: Decades After Kidnapping, Victim Vents His Anger in a Courtroom
description: The kidnapping was a front-page horror when it happened 23 years ago: a white businessman was abducted from the driveway of his Long Island home by black men who kept him chained in a dark closet for a week, peppering him with anti-Semitic and racial slurs, until his family paid $750,000 in ransom.

title: Casino Beats Union Vote
description: Final figures show that the Tropicana Casino and Resort succeeded in heading off a union organizing drive of its dealers, officials said yesterday. In December, the dealers voted against the union, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, 417 to 415. The union challenged the results, saying that 18 votes were cast illegally by casino workers who are not dealers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THUNHORST, HENRY J., JR.
description: THUNHORST-Henry J., Jr. June 23, 1997. Hank was a gentleman of great integrity, style and charm. He was fiercely loyal to country, family and friends, devoted and loving to Marsha, Nancy, Tripper, James, Chip, and Remy. Courageously he battled physical challenges to live a full and rich life. His great enthusiasm and wonderful work ethic allowed him to make many lifelong friends at the Christian Science Monitor, Dow Jones, American Way and Inc. Magazine. Hank will be greatly missed by all whom he inspired. Burial services will be held at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York at 2:00 PM today, Wednesday, June 25. In lieu of flowers contributions would be greatly appreciated by St. Edmond's Academy, 2120 Veale Road, Wilmington, Delaware 19810.

title: SENATE BACKS RISE IN MEDICARE COSTS FOR WEALTHY AGED
description: The Senate voted today to increase Medicare premiums for affluent elderly people and to raise the age of eligibility by two years, to 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, PETER LEWIS
description: RATNER-Peter Lewis, suddenly on June 22 in Chicago, IL. Beloved son of the late Marguerite & Oscar Ratner. Loving brother of Dr. Richard (Linda) Ratner. Cherished uncle of Carolyn and Lauren Ratner. Services Thursday 12:30 P.M. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NY, N.Y. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery Paramus, New Jersey. Remembrances may be made to the charity of your choice. For more information, contact Lloyd Mandel Levayah Funerals 1-888-L-E-V-A-Y-A-H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMANN, MALCOLM ARTHUR
description: HOFFMANN-Malcolm Arthur. On June 24, 1997, beloved husband of the late Anna F. Hoffmann, dear friend of Miriam T. Miller, adored father of Gertrude Bolter and her husband William and Jessica Davis and her husband Will. Cherished grandfather of Daisy & Flora Bolter and Joshua Malcolm Davis & his wife Susan, Alexander Hoffmann Davis and Benjamin Byron Davis. Cherished greatgrandfather of Emerson Jacob Davis. Service is on Thursday, June 26, 1997, at 11:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In his memory, contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Judge Bars Expulsion of Immigrants in 3 States
description: A Federal judge in Miami today barred the Immigration and Naturalization Service from deporting tens of thousands of Nicaraguans and other immigrants who have challenged the agency's interpretation of a provision of the 1996 immigration law until their case can be heard.

title: Off to Timbuktu With Few Illusions
description: TO TIMBUKTU

title: Pacifier Thermometers
description: For as long as rectal thermometers have been the gold standard for taking a child's temperature, parents have been seeking alternatives that are easier to use. But the alternatives, like underarm readings, forehead tapes and ear scans have proved controversial or unreliable, especially for infants and toddlers.

title: TRILON IN TALKS WITH ROYAL BANK OF CANADA
description: The Trilon Financial Corporation said yesterday that it was negotiating with the Royal Bank of Canada to sell its insurance unit, which is valued at $1.39 billion. The London Insurance Group, which is 57 percent owned by Trilon, a division of Trilon Holdings Inc., is the largest provider of individual life insurance in Canada through its 98 percent owned London Life Insurance Company subsidiary. If completed, the sale would be the first major foray into life and automobile insurance by the Canadian banking industry. Officials of the Royal Bank, based in Toronto, declined to comment.

title: Food Notes
description: Takeout Passes Sit-Down

title: A Muscular Nigeria Proves a Flawed Peacekeeper
description: Almost every day, huge Russian-built helicopters fly out of James Spriggs Payne Airport here, raising a deafening din as they ferry troops and artillery to Nigerian positions in neighboring Sierra Leone.

title: Roger C. Bone, 56, Advocate for the Terminally Ill
description: Dr. Roger C. Bone, a lung specialist and former president of the Medical College of Ohio who spent his final year reminding his fellow physicians about their obligations toward the terminally ill, like himself, died on June 8 at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. He was 56 and lived in Chicago.

title: Pol Pot's Crimes Are Punishable Under Global Genocide Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: A Devotee's Portrait of an Iconoclast
description: The tap-dancing actress Ann Miller once opined that it's a star's duty to look like an 8-by-10 studio glossy all the time. Not a dictum that one associates with Patsy Cline, the great, iconoclastically gutsy country music singer known for her warmth, wildness and vast emotional reservoir of a voice.

title: American Topics : $7,000 Fun in the Backyard Luxury Barbecue Grills
description: Barbecue madness, Part 2: Americans, as we were saying, love their barbecues. They are, it seems, willing to spare almost no expense to get the latest in incredibly high-tech models.

title: Separate Tips for Poker
description: The State Casino Control Commission gave preliminary approval yesterday to a rule authorizing certain casinos to segregate tips for poker dealers from the tips given to other dealers.

title: Settlement Set In Futures Case
description: Merrill Lynch Futures Inc. of New York, the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan, a St. Paul brokerage firm and a floor broker have been fined a total of $415,000 to settle Government charges that they engaged in illegal ''wash'' sales on wheat futures contracts.

title: HICKS, MUSE AGREES TO BUY PLY-GEM INDUSTRIES
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Ply-Gem Industries, a building products maker, for $18.75 a share in cash, or $300 million. Hicks, Muse, an investment firm based in Dallas, will also assume $182 million of Ply-Gem debt and costs associated with the transaction. Ply-Gem's shares rose $1.75, to $18, on the New York Stock Exchange, an increase of 10 percent. Ply-Gem will be combined with Hicks, Muse's Atrium unit. Together, they will be the second-largest maker of windows and doors in the United States, with annual sales of $1 billion. Dana Snyder, Ply-Gem's president and chief operating officer, will become president and chief executive of the new company, which will have 5,700 employees in 25 states.

title: Indian Point Nuclear Plant Removed From List of Worst in Nation
description: For the first time since 1993, the Indian Point 3 nuclear power plant in Westchester County is off the Federal list of the nation's worst nuclear power plants.

title: Pol Pot's Crimes Are Punishable Under Global Genocide Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Rita Dimitri, a Club Singer And Actress, Is Dead at 67
description: Rita Dimitri, a multilingual singer who was the ebullient spirit of the Manhattan supper club La Chansonette for more than 20 years, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.

title: U.S. Officials Divided Over Mexican Governor Who's Reportedly Linked to Drug Trade
description: United States diplomats in Mexico City have rejected a proposal to revoke the visa of a powerful state governor in Mexico, despite what officials described as a widespread judgment among law enforcement and intelligence analysts in Washington that he is linked to major drug traffickers.

title: For Holyfield, Pounding Out All the Fear
description: Earth to Evander, earth to Evander.

title: DUTCH COMPANY BUYS PUBLISHING CONCERN FROM DISNEY
description: Wolters Kluwer N.V., the Dutch publishing company, said yesterday that it had acquired the United States company NILS Publishing in Chatsworth, Calif., from the Walt Disney Company, which has been selling publishing assets. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Wolters said NILS had annual sales of $25 million and 135 employees. The Dutch company said that the acquisition was part of its strategy to strengthen global legal publishing activities and that NILS would become part of CCH Inc., its United States business and finance unit that specializes in tax and business law publishing.

title: Break for a Rich Few Sneaks Into Bill
description: Buried in the estate tax section of the big tax-cut bill the House of Representatives plans to approve on Thursday is an obscure provision that would cost the Government $9 million a year in lost revenue and give a bonanza worth thousands of dollars to about 1,000 wealthy taxpayers.

title: Walter F. Weiker, 65, Educator
description: Walter F. Weiker, a specialist in Turkish politics and history at Rutgers University who was long active in Jewish causes, died on June 8 at his home in Livingston, N.J. He was 65.

title: Bill on AIDS Services Is Passed by Council
description: The City Council passed a bill yesterday that would strengthen the city's Division of AIDS Services, requiring that it provide a menu of benefits, including transportation and nutrition subsidies, to New York City residents with AIDS or H.I.V. who request assistance.

title: Ready for Enchantment: Lovers and Some Cute Bugs
description: ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' in George Balanchine's magical if bug-infested version for the New York City Ballet, began a weeklong run on Tuesday night.

title: Cost of Center in Queens Now Put at $254 Million
description: When first suggested in 1991, the cost was to be $150 million. Since then, the price for building the new United States Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park has increased. By 1992, the cost had risen to $210 million. Three years later, when construction started, the expense was up to $227 million.

title: Fund-Raising Softly
description: Roberta Flack is to appear tonight in a concert to raise money for black Republican candidates in the November elections. Nearly all 400 of the $250 tickets to the event at the Newark Airport Marriott Hotel have been sold, Rocco Iossa, the executive director of the Republican State Committee, said yesterday.

title: Egyptian Court Overturns Ban On Cutting of Girls' Genitals
description: An Egyptian court has overturned a year-old ban on the ritual cutting of female genitals in a decision that has been celebrated by Islamic leaders but has outraged human rights advocates.

title: German Inflation Rate Shows an Increase
description: The annual inflation rate in four western states in Germany picked up in the month ended mid-June from the previous monthly period. Consumer prices rose two-tenths of a percent in the period and were up 1.6 percent from a year earlier, the Government said in a preliminary report. The monthly rate was higher than the rise of one-tenth of 1 percent forecast by economists.

title: Under the Big Top, Design Stretches The Imagination
description: IF people embraced modern technology in home construction as enthusiastically as they do advancements in airplanes, computers and fabric for clothing, houses would look like tents. At least, that is the opinion of Todd Dalland, an architect in Manhattan.

title: A Lakeside Villa in Berlin Tells Its Long, Bittersweet Story
description: If buildings could tell stories, the 40-room lakeside villa at Sandwerder 17-19 on Berlin's Wannsee would have a tale to recount.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIERNEY, ALICE M.
description: TIERNEY-Alice M. June 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Michael J. Loving mother of Kevin M, devoted sister of Catherine Hodges, Andrew Brogan, James Miller & the late Thomas and Michael Brogan. Cherished grandmother of Lisa Throneberry, Michael and Patrick Tierney. Great-grandmother of Ryan and Danielle Throneberry. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends at Williams Funeral Home Inc, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx, New York, on Friday from 2-4, 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial at Saint Gabriel's Church, on Saturday, 11 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, PETER LEWIS
description: RATNER-Peter Lewis. We mourn the untimely passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, and offer our deepest sympathy to the Ratner family. M.D. SASS Investors Services, Inc. and its affiliate, Corporate Capital Consultants, Inc.

title: Van and Boy Missing
description: A man who stopped his van to use a public telephone in the Bronx yesterday morning said the van was stolen with his five-year-old son in the back seat, the police said.

title: Bond Prices Drop; 30-Year Yield 6.73%
description: Prices of Treasury securities slid yesterday, affected by a number of factors including the dollar's decline and the sale of a large municipal issue, as well as an unsubstantiated rumor of a large sale of 10-year maturities by a foreign central bank.

title: MONTGOMERY WARD TO DISMISS 400 AT HEADQUARTERS
description: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation is dismissing 400 people at its corporate headquarters, a spokeswoman said yesterday. Montgomery Ward, the struggling retailer, said the dismissals, which represent 20 percent of its headquarters staff, were part of its plan to turn the company around after a string of quarterly losses. It said the move would cut costs and improve efficiency by eliminating layers of management. Montgomery Ward is also considering closing or disposing of some poorly performing stores among its 340 units. Montgomery Ward, which is based in Chicago, told suppliers in April that it expected losses to continue through the second quarter.

title: Inevitable Surgery on Medicare
description: The Senate's votes to raise Medicare premiums for wealthy retirees and to raise the age of eligibility were a sensible start down a road that has to be taken. If Congress does not reduce soaring Medicare costs in ways that protect the needy, it will eventually be forced to cut wantonly. But the policy implications are less remarkable than the fact that 70 senators had the guts to take necessary action despite the opposition of the elderly, a powerful constituency. When Congress voted in 1988 to raise Medicare premiums on wealthier retirees, the elderly forced it to repeal the decision. Something has changed for the better on Capitol Hill, in ways that will color future debates on Medicare and other privileged sanctuaries of the Federal budget.

title: When Gambling Threatens a Nest Egg
description: ''ALL those years I worked, I wanted to make sure of one thing,'' said Al, a 75-year-old retired New Jersey businessman who declined to give his last name. ''I wanted to have financial security in my old age. I almost lost it all at the craps table.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHABAZZ, BETTY DR.
description: SHABAZZ-Betty Dr. The faculty of CUNY is deeply saddened by the passing of its colleague Dr. Betty Shabazz, whose life is a testament to courage, strength, and the triumph over adversity. Sandi E. Cooper, Chair University Faculty Senate.

title: No Rights for Deceived
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Decision Voiding Congressional Act on Religious Freedom
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in City of Boerne v. Flores, declaring unconstitutional the Religious Freedom Restoration Act. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote the majority opinion, joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices John Paul Stevens, Clarence Thomas, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Antonin Scalia. Justices Stevens and Scalia also filed concurring opinions. Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, David H. Souter and Stephen G. Breyer filed dissenting opinions.

title: Supreme Court Upholds S.E.C.'s Theory of Insider Trading
description: The Supreme Court provided a major victory to Federal prosecutors and securities regulators yesterday by ruling that insider trading laws apply to people who have confidential information even if they do not have any connection to the company whose shares are being bought.

title: North Korea Again Plans Preliminary Negotiations
description: North Korea has agreed once again to send a senior delegation to New York to discuss the possibility of negotiating a formal end to the Korean War, officials here and in Seoul said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIDUS, HAROLD
description: FREIDUS-Harold. June 24, 1997. Beloved husband of Cora. Devoted father of Jeffrey, Elleri and Marshall. Cherished grandfather of Wayne, Tara, Vanessa, Greg, Mandi, Stephanie and Justin. One will always remember his unique strength of character. Service Thursday, June 26th, 9:30 A.M., Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC.

title: ELCOM TO HIRE BANK TO EVALUATE WAYS TO LIFT SHARE PRICE
description: Elcom International Inc. said yesterday that it would hire an investment bank to explore ways to increase its share price. Elcom, which produces electronic commerce software, said the options could include putting itself up for sale, forming a partnership with another company or seeking financing. Elcom will take up to a month to pick a bank and could take five or six months to decide what to do, said Robert Crowell, its chairman and chief executive. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Elcom, based in Norwood, Mass., rose $2, or 40 percent, to $7, giving the company a market capitalization of $188 million.

title: Decisive Days for Congo
description: The coming days will show what kind of ruler Congo's new President, Laurent Kabila, is likely to be. A United Nations team has arrived in the country, formerly called Zaire, to investigate reported massacres by Mr. Kabila's troops earlier this year. If Congolese officials cooperate with the investigation, as Mr. Kabila has assured the Clinton Administration they will, Washington can put some faith in the new leader's other promises. These include an end to corruption, respect for human rights and eventual democratic elections.

title: A Victory for Cleaner Air
description: After a few nervous weeks in which it seemed that the Clinton Administration would retreat on an important environmental issue, the White House agreed yesterday to tighten pollution standards on smog and soot. The decision was a defeat for industry, many Midwestern governors and Administration economists who had argued that the costs of the new standards far outweighed their benefits. It was a victory for Carol Browner, the boss of the Environmental Protection Agency, who insisted that the new rules would prevent 15,000 premature deaths a year and improve the lives of millions of Americans who suffer respiratory diseases.

title: On-Line Company Grows
description: Agency.com, one of New York City's largest on-line marketing companies, has acquired a stake in Online Magic, an interactive media company based in London.

title: Executive Changes
description: BROOKS BROTHERS, New York, a subsidiary of Marks & Spencer P.L.C., named Paul Andrew Gitter to the newly created position of director of advertising and loyalty marketing.

title: One Farm's Stock Plan Gives Its Migrant Workers a Stake
description: Like most farms reliant on seasonal field workers, the McKay Nursery Company long ago gave up the notion that it could afford wages high enough to make such dirty, wearying labor attractive to unemployed Americans.

title: Citing Flaws, Health Panel Rejects Deal On Tobacco
description: A panel of the nation's leading public health experts set up to advise Congress on the proposed $368.5 billion tobacco settlement today called the agreement unacceptable, saying it would undermine the Government's ability to regulate nicotine in cigarettes.

title: Currents
description: AS the Fourth of July approaches, dining rooms move outdoors. The good news is that perennial problems of serving food and drink al fresco have been solved, thanks to helpful new accessories.

title: Calendar: Of Dance And Art
description: Forms by Toshiko Takaezu

title: Gift of Gab
description: Microsoftphobes who want to flame Bill Gates can still find valid reasons to do so, but miserliness is no longer one of them. The new Gates Library Foundation, which will pour $400 million of cash and software into needy public libraries for computer access and training, is rightly being acclaimed by the American Library Association and its peers as the greatest gift to libraries since Andrew Carnegie's. And it's only a start: Mr. Gates and his wife, Melinda French Gates, are planning other major, non-library largess, says Patty Stonesifer, the Gates Library Foundation president -- and ''not just digital projects.''

title: Herbert Beckwith, Architect, 94, Dies
description: Herbert Beckwith, an architect and longtime professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, died on June 3 at his home in Kingston, Mass. He was 94.

title: The offbeat film maker David Lynch directs a campaign for Unilever's home pregnancy test.
description: AS if pregnancy were not a surreal enough topic on its own, Unilever has enrolled the notoriously offbeat film maker David Lynch to direct a television campaign for a new home pregnancy test.

title: High-Achieving Readers Bask in Mayoral Spotlight
description: The hundreds of schoolchildren packed into the City Hall parking lot yesterday did not care about the political overtones, the questionable statistics or even the 93-degree heat that had perspiring teachers tossing iced water bottles right and left. They were there to be recognized for their reading achievements, and to them, the squabbles of the adult world seemed petty by comparison.

title: Bridge
description: Most people would be unhappy if their departure caused pleasure, but Laura Brill and Rick Goldstein of White Plains were flattered. It happened at the regional championships in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., in May. In the first three days they had won the Open Pairs, the Swiss Teams and another Open Pairs. This sentiment appeared in the daily bulletin on the fourth morning: ''Thank heaven they are leaving today. Now maybe somebody else can win something.''

title: Clinton Raises Money for Senator in Illinois
description: On a day devoted to political and family values, President Clinton came here this evening to raise money for Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois and other Senate Democrats after spending the afternoon in Nashville swapping ideas with educators and businessmen about how to improve schools for children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLE CESE, ALEXANDER A.
description: DELLE CESE-Alexander A. (Honorable, Retired New York State Civil Court Judge). Beloved husband of the late Frances (Trader). Devoted father of Michael, Paul, Barbara Battista, and the late Stephen. Dear brother of Marie Corelli. Cherished grandfather of 2 grandsons and 2 granddaughters. Reposing at A. Ribustello & Son Funeral Home, Inc. at 811 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, NY. Mass of Christian Burial in Saint Francis Xavier Church Saturday, 10 AM. Emtombment St. Raymond's Cemetery. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday, 2-5, 7-9:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, RUTH L.
description: SAMUELS-Ruth L. On June 23, 1997. Beloved mother of Virginia Kovner and Michael Samuels. Cherished grandmother of Melissa (Joseph) Smouha, Jason Samuels, Chloe, Emily, Noah and Jacob Kovner. Devoted great grandmother of Marc, Jonathan, Nina, and Lauren Smouha. Dear Sister of Philip Lowy and sister-in-law of Janet. Loving companion of Jack B. Feigin. Services Friday 10:45 AM at Temple Israel of the City of New York, 112 E. 75th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Temple Israel City of NY.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TED TURNER, 58, has had harsh words for RUPERT MURDOCH, 66, for so long that he must have felt the time was right to lace on 12-pound gloves and take on his archenemy in a ring in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: U.S. Exports Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Space Station Damaged In Collision With a Cargo Vessel
description: An unmanned cargo vessel smashed into the Russian Mir space station today during a practice docking in the most serious collision ever involving a manned spacecraft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, HERBERT
description: PARKER-Herbert. Esquire. 84. Beloved brother of Emanuel and the late Jerome, Annette, Louis and Renee. Loving uncle and brother-in-law.

title: Big Sky, Big City
description: AH, wilderness. The trees, the stars. The taxicabs and helicopters.

title: Gould as a Pianist Playing Physician
description: GLENN GOULD

title: Knicks Add Strength To an Aging Frontcourt
description: It's not that Charles Oakley and Buck Williams are old, graying players who can barely get up and down the court anymore. But as the Knicks examined the list of National Basketball Association draft prospects, they wanted to lighten the loads of their veteran power forwards.

title: Excerpts From Ruling Clarifying Insider Trading Definition
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that insider trading laws apply to people who have confidential information even if they do not have any connection to the company whose shares are being bought. The ruling reinstated the conviction of James H. O'Hagan, a lawyer who made $4.3 million trading the securities of the Pillsbury Company after his law firm was retained to represent Grand Metropolitan, which was planning a hostile takeover of Pillsbury. Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg wrote the majority opinion. Justice Clarence Thomas wrote the dissent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIPOLI DAVI, JOSEPHINE
description: TRIPOLI DAVI-Josephine. May 21, 1906-June 9, 1997. Service St. Anthony's Shrine, Nanuet, NY, 9:45AM, Sat., June 28th. God bless.

title: The Economy and Markets Frail, Thais Breed Skeptics
description: Thailand's new finance minister has moved to repair the country's troubled financial system, but analysts see little evidence so far that the Government has found the resolve to rejuvenate the faltering economy.

title: Appeals Court Backs Lesbian Asylum Bid
description: The Federal appeals court here has unanimously ruled that a Russian lesbian living in the United States can seek political asylum in this country because of efforts by the Russian Government to forcibly ''cure'' her of homosexuality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINTERO, JOHN
description: QUINTERO-John, age 34, of Brooklyn, NY, on March 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Laura (nee Bue). Survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Reynold Quintero, and sisters, Cecilia and Alicia. John was employed by the Xerox Corp. Mass was celebrated at St. Finbar's R.C. Church on April 12, 1997.

title: Only Where It's Due: Producers Want Credit
description: In the golden days of Hollywood, producers dominated the movie business. Top producers in the 1930's and 40's not only played creative roles that rivaled those of directors and writers but received sole credit for their movies as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORSI, POMPEO L.
description: ORSI-Pompeo L. On June 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Lavinia (nee Savino), loving father of the Rev. Michael P., Marie A Shammas, Peter G. and Paul A. Dear brother of Carmela Corrado, cherished grandfather of 5. Funeral Friday, 8:45 A.M., the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, NY. Mass 9:45 AM, St. Thomas Aquinas RC Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting hours Thursday 2-5 P.M., 7-10 P.M.

title: After 7 Years, Gigante Trial Finally Begins
description: Seven years after he was first charged in a broad murder and racketeering case, a wan and wheelchair-bound Vincent Gigante was rolled into a Brooklyn courtroom yesterday and heard himself described by a prosecutor as a vicious mob boss and by his lawyer as a mentally ill victim of Government-spawned ''myths'' about the Mafia.

title: AT&T Plan to Cut Fraud
description: The AT&T Corporation is putting into practice a plan approved by the New York State Public Service Commission to reduce complaints that the largest long-distance carrier has been ''slamming'' customers.

title: Lost Jazz Treasures, Just for the Asking
description: Sometimes all one has to do is ask. When George Avakian, the legendary jazz producer, began hearing rumors of a cache of lost compositions by the trumpeter Louis Armstrong, he did the logical thing. He went to the Library of Congress.

title: The Sauna Scandal: Steamy Stuff in High Places
description: Corruption in high places is hardly new in Russia, but political sex scandals are almost unknown. So a popular tabloid newspaper created a sensation when it published pictures of what it described as Russia's Minister of Justice cavorting nude with three naked women in a sauna frequented by gangsters.

title: New Assignments For 2 Agencies
description: Two companies have chosen agencies for new assignments.

title: Garden Q.& A.

title: ITT CONSIDERING SALE OF STAKE IN ITALIAN HOTEL CONCERN
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it was considering offers to sell part of its 70 percent stake in Ciga S.p.A., an Italian luxury hotel company. In a statement, ITT said it was also considering the sale of individual Ciga hotels, which include some prestigious landmark hotels in Italy and Spain. ITT's statement came after Ciga's chairman said that as far as he knew Ciga was not for sale as part of ITT's defense against a hostile takeover offer from the Hilton Hotels Corporation. ITT bought Ciga in 1994. ITT is the subject of a $10.5 billion takeover bid from Hilton and has been seeking to thwart the offer by selling many of the 72 hotels it owns and which Hilton wants.

title: COPPER PRODUCER TO CUT JOBS AND CLOSE MINE IN ARIZONA
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company said yesterday that it would cut as many as 500 jobs, about 16 percent of the work force, at its San Manuel copper mine and smelter in Arizona. Broken Hill, the world's second-largest copper producer, based in Melbourne, Australia, will proceed with plans to close its Pinto Valley mine, about 70 miles away, by 2002, eliminating 630 jobs. The company said the reduction in the 3,160-employee work force at San Manuel would allow it to decrease production costs substantially. Most of the job cuts will be through early retirement, the company said. It bought the mines as part of its takeover of the Magma Copper Company last year.

title: Jacques Cousteau, Oceans' Impresario, Dies
description: Jacques-Yves Cousteau, the French oceanographer who opened more of the Earth's surface to human endeavor than any other explorer, died yesterday at his home in Paris. He was 87.

description: A state appeals court upheld an age discrimination verdict against the Schering-Plough Corporation yesterday but reversed an $8 million punitive damage award, saying there was no evidence implicating the top executives of the drug company in the 1991 dismissal of a salesman.

title: French Stocks Soar As Inflation Fears Fade
description: French stocks soared yesterday to a high, posting the biggest rise in nearly two years amid optimism that inflation and interest rates would remain low. France's CAC 40 index rose 82.68 points, or almost 3 percent, to 2,867.44 points. The previous high of 2,825.18 was set on June 13. Yesterday's gain was the biggest since Oct. 30, 1995, when the CAC rose 3.04 percent. Nearly 20.5 billion shares changed hands, twice the average for the last three months.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS TO ACQUIRE OFFICE COMPLEX FROM MOBIL
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it would acquire a research and office park in New Jersey from the Mobil Corporation for $41.7 million. The company, a drug and personal care products maker based in New York, also said it would add 2,000 people to its research staff during the next five years. Bristol-Myers has 4,000 employees in its Pharmaceutical Research Institute in Princeton. The 433-acre complex in Hopewell Township, N.J., near Princeton, has largely been vacant since last year, when Mobil moved research operations elsewhere. The company's shares, which jumped more than $8 on Tuesday, closed yesterday at $82.625, down $2.125.

He managed the fraud and risk prevention area for the Carte Blanche division of Citibank from 1979 to 1981.

title: Chile, First and Forever
description: With only two weeks to go before the Madrid NATO summit meeting, the U.S. and its NATO allies are still arguing over which countries to add to NATO. The reason they're still arguing is because there are no clear criteria over who should be let in, because there is no clear strategy for how to expand NATO, because the Clinton team has no clear idea what it wants NATO to become. When you don't know where you are going, any road (or new member) will get you there. So the U.S. favors Poland, Hungary and the Czechs, while the Europeans also want Romania and Slovenia. Since everyone is pushing his favorite country, as if NATO were a book club, I would like to propose mine: Chile. You laugh, but here are 10 reasons Chile is the best candidate for an expanded NATO.

description: The City Council passed a bill yesterday requiring casino boats that sail from New York City to have city licenses and submit their workers to background checks for possible organized-crime links.

title: Liposome Shares Take 61% Nose Dive
description: The shares of the Liposome Company plunged 61 percent today after the company said a study showed no significant difference between patients receiving its experimental Ventus respiratory drug or a placebo.

title: Sexual-Harassment Hearing for Top Enlisted Man
description: In riveting testimony, a 25-year-old sergeant described in detail today how Gene C. McKinney, the Army's senior enlisted soldier, befriended her, won her trust and then betrayed her by having unwanted sexual intercourse with her when she was seven-and-a-half months pregnant.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Down 68 Points In Day of Wild Gyrations

title: Court Date Is Set In Helmsley Fight
description: Both sides claimed victory in the latest legal skirmish between Peter L. Malkin and Leona Helmsley over the Helmsley real estate empire, after a lawyer for Mrs. Helmsley flourished a $5.3 million check in court to pay the July tax bill on the Empire State Building.

title: Stocks Dive In 3d Straight Volatile Day
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday in the third consecutive session of volatile trading.

title: Of Dignity, Struggle And Sadness
description: Charlie Haden and his Liberation Orchestra moved into TriBeCa Hall on Tuesday night for two sets of languid, melancholic music, part of the Knitting Factory's New York Jazz Festival. The band's compositions and orchestrations owe a debt to Hispanic music of both the Old and New Worlds, and its minor strains and dignity evoked eras in Spain and Latin America when music and politics mingled overtly. It is sad music, and though there are elements of hope to it, with a little historical knowledge it can sound like the music of defeat.

title: Children Place Low in Adults' Esteem, a Study Finds
description: Adults' negative views of the nation's teen-agers and younger children are so widespread that only 37 percent believe that today's youngsters will eventually make this country a better place, according to a new national study by a public-policy research organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROPHY, SHIRLEY LAMM
description: BROPHY-Shirley Lamm. On June 25, 1997 of Bay Shore, N.Y. Loving mother of Bernard, Eric, Moira Snover and Steven. Fond grandmother of Emma. Also survived by her sister, Lillian Kaplan and her brothers Charles and Kermit Lamm. The family will receive friends today 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at the George C. White Funeral Home, 364 E. Main St., Bay Shore, NY. Funeral Service 10AM, Friday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Bay Shore, New York. Interment Oakwood Cemetery, Bay Shore. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 500 S. Country Road, Bay Shore, New York, would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN FELIX, FLORENCE
description: VAN FELIX-Florence, June 21, 1997 in her 82nd year. Longterm Greenwich Village resident and activist. Survived by husband William, daughters Norma and Martha, son Andrew, grandchildren David, Michelle and Katie.

title: N.H.L. Adds Four Franchises
description: Thirty years ago, the National Hockey League was a six-team circuit. Chicago represented its western frontier and no franchise was farther south than New York. Three years from now, the N.H.L. will be a 30-team league, with franchises scattered from sea to shining sea and everywhere in between.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOWLING, JAMES C.
description: BOWLING-James C. June 24, 1997. The directors and staff of the Laymen's National Bible Association mourn the loss of our longtime director, friend and colleague.

title: Thwarting a Van Driver
description: Vincent Cummins has been struggling for almost five years to license a badly needed commuter van service in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Mr. Cummins has done everything the law requires to get the license. But faced with threats from the Transport Workers Union, New York's City Council has left him in the lurch, with his license unapproved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMINGUEZ, NICHOLAS
description: DOMINGUEZ - Nicholas. Died June 18, 1997. Age 87. Joined the United Nations at end of World War II, retired 1970. Born Caracas, Venezuela 1910, arrived New York City 1920. Played semi-pro baseball. During World War II, served under General Douglas MacArthur as a Corporal in U.S. Army 307th Infantry 77th Division, awarded Purple Heart. In 1994, returned to Guam at invitation of its government, where his Army Division was honored during 50th Anniversary of the U.S. Army's liberation of Guam from the Japanese. An avid sports fan, Mr. Dominguez played on New York Mets Dream Team at age 75. Remains oldest participant to have played on the fantasy baseball team of World Champion Mets players and civilians. In 1990, Lou Carnesecca, then coach of St. John's University NCAA Champion basketball team, named Mr. Dominguez, at age 80, Fan of the Year, for never missing a game. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Maria; two sons, Francisco and Nicholas; two daughters, Josette and Angela, both of New York City and three grandchildren. At his request, his ashes wil be scattered on a ball field in Queens where he played as a child.

title: Diana Cleans Out Her Closet, And Charities Just Clean Up
description: The clothes trace her metamorphosis from frilly princess through the ''Dynasty Di'' years to the woman on her own in the sleek column dresses of the 1990's. They were also, it turns out, an excellent investment.

title: Continental Drops Ads That Mayor Criticized
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani rounded up a posse of civic, business and labor leaders yesterday to do battle with the latest interloper to besmirch the reputation of New York City. They met at City Hall, all itching to stride before the microphone to announce that they were boycotting Continental Air Lines for running a waggish advertising campaign that seeks to entice New Yorkers to cross the border to Newark International Airport.

title: Pataki and Legislative Leaders Are Close to a Budget Deal, Aides Say
description: With the long battle over rent laws ended, lawmakers, working toward a state budget with surprising speed, have settled the crucial question of how much money is available to spend, and could enact a budget within a few weeks, top aides said today.

title: For Athletic Pilobolus, Even the Statues Move
description: Fans of the Pilobolus Dance Theater have wondered in recent years how the group, known for its impudent athleticism and wild physical imagination, could retain its original nature with each new generation of dancers. For a fascinating and mostly heartening answer, a visit is in order to the Joyce Theater, where Pilobolus opened a three-week season on Tuesday night.

title: Church Fire Called Accident
description: Two boys accidentally set fire to a historic church with a predominantly black congregation on Tuesday, the authorities said yesterday.

title: The Voice In Tyson's Corner
description: THE second time around, the plot for Evander Holyfield and Mike Tyson isn't that much different than it was the first time except for one formidable factor: Tyson has a respected trainer now in Richie Giachetti.

title: For Children
description: 'Art Safari'

title: Suitable Tumult for Cyclone's 70th
description: In a party at Coney Island that amounted to a glorious efflorescence of publicity stunts, a human perversity long held sacred at the amusement park, hundreds gathered in the shimmering heat to celebrate the 70th birthday of the Cyclone Roller Coaster.

title: $25 and Under
description: As the blocks south of Houston Street between Lafayette Street and the Bowery began to orient themselves toward SoHo rather than Little Italy or the Lower East Side, Joe Perrotta, who owns a wine shop on Elizabeth Street, sensed a growing demand in his neighborhood for sushi. So he and a partner, Vincent Stravato, decided to do something about it. Five weeks ago, they opened their own restaurant, called Mottsu, in the spirit of Mr. Perrotta's wine shop, Elizabeth and Vine.

title: Investor to Pay $80.4 Million To Buy Starrett Corporation
description: Jacob A. Frydman, a 39-year-old New York real estate investor and developer, has agreed to buy the Starrett Corporation, the company that built the Empire State Building, Stuyvesant Town and Trump Tower, for $80.4 million, the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDRING, CHARLES
description: GOLDRING-Charles. The officers and members of the National Commission and staff of the AntiDefamation League mourn the passing of Charles Goldring, 90, of Los Angeles, a great national leader and longtime devoted supporter. It was his foresight and determination that inspired, initiated and built ADL's Planned Giving program. Charlie was a man of warmth, wit and wisdom and he will be sorely missed. We extend out heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Leona, and the entire family. David H. Strassler National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHURCHILL, W. PHILIP
description: CHURCHILL-W. Philip. We mourn the passing of our elder partner, Phil Churchill. He served this law firm and its clients faithfully for 44 years, from 1935 to 1979, interrupted by military service in World War II. Phil provided friendship, wise counsel and guidance to many, including his partners. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Polly and to his sons Bill, John and Jim. FISH & NEAVE

title: Sotheby's Buys in Chicago
description: Seeking to expand its business in the Midwest, Sotheby's has announced that it is buying Leslie Hindman of Chicago, the region's biggest auction house. It did not disclose the price.

title: Fidelity Index Funds Hire Outside Manager
description: Fidelity Investments hired Bankers Trust yesterday to manage its index mutual funds, the first time Fidelity has ever sought an outside group to manage its fund assets.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: PORTRAIT OF GIGANTE -- Prosecutors introduced evidence that they said showed that Vincent Gigante was not mentally ill. B3.

description: There may be no election district in New York City more densely packed with Rudy Giuliani voters than Building 1 of the North Shore Towers in Floral Park, Queens, with the possible exceptions of Building 2 or Building 3.

description: The people who brought the ''. . . for Dummies'' books to the computer illiterate have unveiled their latest attempt to help: a line of free, daily electronic mail newsletters called Dummies Daily.

title: Some Hail a 'Victory,' but Others Have Reservations
description: Reaction to the Supreme Court ruling on assisted suicide was at once emotional and intellectual. It ranged from unalloyed joy to cautious, almost noncommittal comment. It was based on secular thinking and religious feeling.

title: Mets Now Outstanding in Their Field
description: There are many sound, logical, quantifiable reasons for the Mets to fail: they have had too many injuries, their bullpen is too thin, the production of the star left fielder Bernard Gilkey has plummeted. But they win, even if what they do well is not borne out in Rotisserie standings, with home runs and runs batted in.

description: LEFKOWITZ-Joseph, 77, of Long Beach, on Thursday June 26, 1997 after a long illness. title: COURT, 9-0, UPHOLDS STATE LAWS PROHIBITING ASSISTED SUICIDE; PROTECTS SPEECH ON INTERNET
description: Stepping for the first time into the wrenching political and moral debate over doctor-assisted suicide, the Supreme Court ruled today that states may continue to ban the practice but at the same time suggested that the door remained open to constitutional claims for assistance by dying patients in the future.

title: Graduation Rates Rising For Athletes
description: For the fifth consecutive year, athletes at major colleges have done better than the student body as a whole in the classroom.

title: Second Bombing Trial Will Begin on Sept. 29
description: Federal Judge Richard P. Matsch today set Sept. 29 as the opening date for jury selection in the second Oklahoma City bombing trial, of Terry L. Nichols, 42 years old, charged with murder and conspiracy in the 1995 attack that took 168 lives.

title: Bonds Drop For a 2d Day; Job Data Cited
description: The prices of Treasury securities, with the exception of the shorter maturities, fell yesterday for a second day.

title: 4 at Syracuse Finance Firm Indicted in Pyramid Scheme
description: The Federal Government indicted the former chief financial officer of the Bennett Funding Group and three other men yesterday in what the Government called one of biggest securities fraud cases in American history and a large-scale attempt to cover it up.

title: Rivera Adjusting To Role As Closer
description: Mariano Rivera purposely places himself in a time warp every time he pitches for the Yankees. It is not 1997, it is still 1996. It is not the ninth inning that Manager Joe Torre is summoning him for, it is the seventh or eighth. It is not a potentially game-ending spot, it is another situation as a setup man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYAMS, GEORGE, M.D.
description: HYAMS-George, M.D. The Board of Trustees and the Board of Directors of the New York County Medical Society mourns the passing of this esteemed colleague. Dr. Hyams' many positions included former chairman of the Board of Trustees and longtime delegate to the Medical Society of the State of New York. He was a compassionate and caring physician who will be greatly missed by all. Milton Haynes, M.D., Secretary

title: TriBeCa Lofts Are Growing, and Growing Larger
description: Manhattan's heated housing market continues to fuel the conversion of old manufacturing buildings into loft condominiums in TriBeCa, where developers are trying to meet a demand they say still outstrips the supply.

title: Zurich Group Said to Offer $867 Million For Scudder
description: Zurich Group, the big Swiss insurer, will announce today that it is acquiring majority control of Scudder Stevens & Clark Inc., the money management giant, for about $867 million in cash and a significant minority stake in the combined company, according to people familiar with the deal.

title: Talks on Shopping Center
description: Home Depot and Price/Costco are among several retailers involved in discussions to develop a three-block-long shopping center in East Harlem, a lawyer for the property owner said yesterday.

title: Yankees to Start Irabu July 10
description: Although Hideki Irabu hit his first speed bump in Binghamton, N.Y., on Wednesday night, the way has been cleared for the Japanese right-hander to make his first appearance with the Yankees in a home game against the Detroit Tigers on July 10, the Yankees' first game after the All-Star Game break.

title: CATALYTICA TO PAY $247 MILLION FOR GLAXO DRUG PLANT
description: Catalytica Inc. said yesterday that it would pay $247 million in cash plus a package of shares, share options and business contracts for Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C.'s drug manufacturing plant in Greenville, N.C., and inventory. It signed a preliminary sale agreement in February, but no price was given then. In addition to the cash, Glaxo would receive 250,000 preferred shares in Catalytica, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., and options to buy 2 million more over six years at $12 a share. Glaxo also agreed to buy products from the Greenville site valued at about $800 million over the next five years. Catalytica's shares fell $2 yesterday, or 14 percent, to $11.625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALVADORI, MARIO G.
description: SALVADORI-Mario G. Died June 25, 1997, aged 90. Beloved husband of Carol; father of Vieri and Michael; grandfather of Niccolo, Daniel, and Maia; and father-in-law of Rebecca and Beth. Mario was a master teacher, a brilliant engineer, and a clear and imaginative writer. He lives in the hearts of his thousands of students as well as in the soul of his family. Funeral services private. A memorial gathering will be announced later.

title: Last Moments Of Levin Are Described By a Suspect
description: In the final moments of his life, Jonathan M. Levin desperately tried to reason with Corey Arthur, a former student who had bound him and was holding a gun to his head, according to court papers filed yesterday.

description: ADLER-Kurt Alfred. May 28, 1997. A Memorial Service will be held Sun, June 29, 1 PM at Community Church, 40 East 35 Street, NYC.

title: Rhone-Poulenc May Buy Rest of Drug Subsidiary
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A. said today that it might buy the 31.7 percent of Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. that it does not already own as part of a possible plan to shed its nonpharmaceutical operations.

title: Fireworks Are Seized From Long Island Home
description: More than 500 cases of fireworks with an estimated street value of $400,000 were seized late Wednesday from a home in Seaford on Long Island, the authorities said.

title: A Winner at Marbles
description: Black seemed to be a lucky color for 12-year-old Megan Winkelman this week at the National Marbles Tournament.

description: STEIN-Sidney. On June 25, 1997. description: DELLE CESE-Alexander A. (Honorable), The Officers, Directors, members and staff of the Bronx County Bar Association mourn the passing of our beloved Past President and distingushed member of the Bench and Bar and extend our deepest sympathy to his bereaved family.

title: Teen Pregnancy Programs
description: Although she did not refer specifically to any of the recent well publicized cases of young women abandoning their newborns, Governor Whitman announced a new $1.1 million program yesterday that was clearly a response to them.

title: Excerpts From High Court's Decisions Affirming Laws on Suicide Aid
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's unanimous decisions today in two cases, finding that bans on assisting suicide enacted by the States of Washington and New York do not violate the 14th Amendment. In both cases -- Washington v. Glucksberg, No. 96-110, and Vacco v. Quill, No. 95-1858 -- Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion. There were several concurring opinions, including ones by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Stephen G. Breyer and David H. Souter.

title: Open Road and Open Mind: A Bike Tour of New Jersey
description: TRAVELING by bicycle is a demystifying enterprise. You see a place up close, slowly, sweat your way through it from end to end -- not to mention eat its fast food and sleep in its motels -- and, well, it doesn't seem so exotic any more.

title: With Priorities in Check, Pepper Set to Defend Title
description: This is the time of year when Dottie Pepper raises her game. She did it in 1996 by winning two consecutive tournaments, and this year she is playing her best golf of the season heading into the ShopRite Classic that begins Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the reaction of smokers and others to the agreement between the tobacco industry and state attorneys general misattributed quotations from two young men who defended smoking, and a picture caption misidentified one of them. The youths gave their names as Spencer Wolfe and John Fireman, and said that they attended Trinity School in New York City. In fact, they were Richard Russell and Dylan Stein. They do not attend Trinity. The picture was of Mr. Russell.

title: Restaurants
description: For 15 minutes we have been waving our hands in a futile attempt to get the attention of a waiter. Any waiter. We'd like a little wine and a bit of bread, but the waiters go dashing past, eyes straight ahead, unseeing. They seem so horribly harried that it's hard to be angry. Still, we're hungry, and when a busboy arrives with plates of foie gras, we are sorely tempted to take them. Only the sight of a woman at the far end of the dining room, beckoning frantically for her food, forces us to admit that we haven't even ordered. As we sadly watch the plates being borne off, the man at the table behind ours mutters, ''Hang around; it'll get worse.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENSER, SALLY
description: GENSER-Sally, nee Reiner. On June 26, 1997. Beloved wife the late Irving. Devoted mother of Beverly and Marvin Rauch, Phyllis and Stephen Genkin. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Loving sister of Mae Flamm. Services today, 11:45AM at ''Boulevard/Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: An Issue That Won't Die
description: The Supreme Court may have been unanimous in ruling yesterday that terminally ill patients have no accepted right to medical help in committing suicide, but the decision does little to resolve the myriad, murky, practical concerns that many Americans have about exactly how they will die.

title: INSIDE
description: Crew Exercises Veto Power

title: Dissident Badly Beaten In China Jail, Family Says
description: Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent pro-democracy dissident, was severely beaten earlier this month by other inmates at a prison camp 100 miles east of here, family members said today.

title: At Hearing, Voices From a Cigarette Maker
description: The dozens of hecklers wearing ''Save Our Store'' stickers in the balcony of the City Council Chambers yesterday appeared to be store owners protesting a bill that would ban tobacco advertisements on billboards, store windows and other sites within 1,000 feet of schools. But as officials later learned, they were sales representatives from the tobacco company Philip Morris U.S.A.

title: Microsoft in On-Line Billing Venture
description: The Microsoft Corporation and the First Data Corporation said yesterday that they had formed a company that would allow consumers to pay bills over the Internet, a move aimed at speeding up the use of the global computer network for business.

title: Scrutiny in Abuse Cases
description: Less than two weeks after it was introduced, a bill to allow greater public scrutiny of the State Division of Youth and Family Services was approved yesterday by the Legislature.

title: Fuel Shortage Has Nigerians Fuming in Line
description: A severe fuel shortage here in one of the world's major oil-producing nations is crippling economic activity in many parts of the country and raising political and social tensions.

title: Window at Waldorf Is Found Broken by Bullet
description: A chambermaid discovered a window broken by a small-caliber bullet in an unoccupied suite on the 35th floor of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday morning, according to the Secret Service, which was investigating because heads of state and other dignitaries have been staying at the hotel this week during a United Nations environmental conference.

Fox, Esq., Dilworth Law Firm, 3200 Mellon Bank Center, 1735 Market Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19103.

title: Good and Evil Trade Places, Body and Soul
description: WANTED: summer action heroes. Must be able to dodge fireballs and type on cutting-edge computer toys. Must have cool way with no-brainer one-liners. Must stride naturally in heavyweight metal or rubber. Creative input helpful. Should be able to spin whole character out of minimal description, as in: ''Him? Been in the slammer since he burned down the barn and let that brontosaurus stomp Grandma. It was all a misunderstanding. Now he's itching for a second chance.''

title: In Hollywood Gold Cup, It's the Mandella Show
description: Richard Mandella, racing's master of multiple entries, used two horses to end Cigar's winning streak last August at Del Mar in California. He entered three in the $1 million Santa Anita Handicap in March, and they ran 1-2-3. For an encore, with $1 million on the line and $3 million more in bonuses, he entered five starters yesterday in a six-horse field for the Hollywood Gold Cup on Sunday, and said: ''It'll sort itself out.''

title: A 13-Year Transition Has Made Hong Kong China's Money Capital
description: The level of marketing expertise in China is summed up by the clothing company that tried to export a new line of men's underwear and thought it would be nice to name it for a flower that suggested fragrance and cleanliness. So it tried to find buyers for its Pansy brand underwear.

title: Spectrum Settles A Fraud Case
description: Spectrum Information Technologies Inc., a wireless communications company, settled a securities fraud case today that was brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: For the mutual fund industry, this seems like the best of times.
description: MORE than six years into a roaring bull market, the growth of the largest portion of the mutual fund industry appears to still be accelerating, indicating that investors are not yet close to satisfying their hunger for funds that invest in stocks.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Fierce Creatures

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PG&E CORP., San Francisco, a utility holding company, agreed to buy the 50 percent interest of U.S. Generating Co. it does not already own from Bechtel Enterprises Group Inc., San Francisco, for undisclosed terms.

title: APRIA HEALTHCARE LOOKS FOR WAYS TO RAISE STOCK PRICE
description: Apria Healthcare Group Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help it explore alternatives for increasing the value of its shares, including the possible sale of the company. Apria, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., also said it would phase out its low-margin home-health nursing and medical equipment sales businesses. It will focus instead on its main businesses of respiratory services, home infusion therapy and home medical equipment. Shares of Apria closed unchanged at $18 each, giving the company a current market value of $925 million.

title: How a Third Grade Reads (With a Teacher's Help)
description: With his third-graders off at their last gym class, Ted Kesler sat down at a tiny wooden desk yesterday morning to stuff report cards and standardized test scores into the manila envelopes that the children would soon carry home.

title: Union Square Cafe Owner To Open Two Restaurants
description: The pool of restaurants that has made the Flatiron district a chic dining destination is about to flow north, into the Madison Square Park area. Danny Meyer, co-owner of Gramercy Tavern and Union Square Cafe, signed a 20-year lease yesterday for 21,057 square feet of space at 11 Madison Avenue, from 24th Street to 25th Street.

title: Plight of the Poor Post-Feminist Man
description: ''Slouching Toward the Millennium'' is Murray Schisgal's meditation on the exacting social standards for middle-aged men in the post-feminist age. In three one-act plays, presented by the 42d Street Workshop, he explores with varying degrees of success the pressures imposed on men by society's evolving notions of sexuality and more specifically, masculinity.

title: No Pajamas Is Not Enough
description: Vincent Gigante, best known to the public for a sartorial standard that runs to bathrobes and pajamas in the street, has upgraded his style for his appearances at his trial, but he still has a way to go to satisfy the judge.

title: Congolese Troops Detain Top Opposition Leader
description: In a move that appeared to signal a new hard line against dissent, Government soldiers here burst into the home of the leading opposition politician today, arresting him and his wife, and carrying them off to an undisclosed destination.

title: Kelly Stays Free on Bond, Judge Again Rules
description: For the second time since Alex Kelly's rape conviction on June 12, a judge has ruled that Mr. Kelly may remain free on $1 million bond.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRDSALL, BLAIR
description: BIRDSALL-Blair, of Allendale, N.J. formerly of Glen Rock, N.J. on June 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Elizabeth (nee Figueroa). Loving father of Elizabeth J. Evans of Fl., William B. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTLEDGE, FELIX NOAH, M.D.
description: RUTLEDGE-Felix Noah, M.D., an internationally known gynecologic surgeon who developed innovative treatments for women with cancer, died on Saturday, June 21, 1997, in Houston, Texas. He was seventy-nine. During his 38-year association with The University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Dr. Rutledge helped improve the outlook for thousands of women with gynecologic cancers. He was at the forefront in designing conservative, individualized cancer therapy that extended survival and reduced post-surgical complications. He was born in Anniston, Alabama, on November 20, 1917, the only son of Josie and Felix Noah Rutledge, Sr. He began planning to study medicine as a youth. He received an undergraduate degree at the University of Alabama in 1939 and earned his medical degree at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in 1943. He completed an internship and residence training in three specialty areas at Johns Hopkins Hospital before moving to Houston. Dr. Rutledge joined the M.D. Anderson staff in 1948 on a part-time basis. At that time, patients were seen in temporary quarters on an old family estate while the first hospital facility was being planned and built in the then-new Texas Medical Center. He became the first chairman of the Department of Gynecology when M.D. Anderson opened in 1954 and continued in that post until he retired in 1986. Dr. Rutledge was instrumental in developing the Department of Gynecology at M.D. Anderson into one of the nation's most productive academic training centers. He was widely acclaimed for his work in pelvic exenteration, as well as poineering less radical methods to remove cancers and preserve patient function and body image. In addition to his surgical and teaching skills, Dr. Rutledge designed clinical trials that demonstrated conclusively the superior results of applying multidisciplinary therapy to treat many forms of gynecologic cancer. His research led to extensive publications in leading professional journals and contributions to several textbooks. As a teacher, he personally trained over 100 post-graduate fellows in gynecologic oncology, many of whom have gone on to hold senior academic positions in medical institutions around the world. In 1970, the physicians he trained honored him by establishing the Felix Rutledge Society. The Society's purpose, to share new developments in gynecologic oncology and to stimulate original investigation in gynecologic oncology and to related fields, mirrors Dr. Rutledge's philosophy and values in the practice and art of medicine. A member of all societies of his specialties as well as many other medical societies, Dr. Rutledge served as President of the Society of Gynecologic Oncologists in 1975, President of the American Radium Society in 1976, and President of the Society of Pelvic Surgeons in 1979. He was one of five physicians who created the Subspecialty of Gynecologic Oncology for the American Board of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Dr. Rutledge received many honors and awards throughout his life including the Janeway Medal, American Radium Society (1982); the Distinguished Service Award, American Cancer Society (1985); the Heath Memorial Award (1985); Fellow of the Society of Scholars, Johns Hopkins University (1994); Honoris Causa in Medicine, University of Bologna, Bologna, Italy (1994); Honoris Causa, University of Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain (1997); Honorary Fellow, Royal College of Obstetrics & Gynecology of Great Britain; and Honorary Fellow, Royal College of Obstetrics and Gynecology of South Africa. He is survived by his wife, Dorothy Wood Rutledge of Geneva, Texas, his son and daughter-inlaw, Don and Melanie Rutledge of Sugar Land, Texas, and two grandsons, Kevin Scott Rutledge and Travis Matthew Rutledge also of Sugar Land. Services and interment will be held on Saturday, June 28, at 11:00 A.M. at McMahan Chapel near San Augustine, Texas, under the direction of the Starr Funeral Home of Hemphill. Memorial contributions may be sent to The Felix Rutledge Society Foundation, in care of Dr. J. Taylor Wharton, Chairman, Gynecologic Oncology, M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe, Houston, Texas 77030.

title: It's Virtually Pop Art

As a result, Ms. Wilson has successfully cultivated jazz and pop audiences, and she played to both of them at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, headlining a JVC Jazz Festival bill given over to musicians from the Blue Note records roster.

The acquisition will end Cater Allen's 180-year independence. Cater Allen is a diversified financial company that specializes in stock lending, which is lending shares to institutions for a fee so the stock can be sold short, and British Government repurchase agreements.

The 114-store chain, based in Grand Island, Neb., has about $300 million in annual sales. The purchase will make Central Tractor, with 116 stores and also about $300 million in sales, the largest specialty farming-goods retailer in the United States. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. Central Tractor, based in Des Moines, operates farm and garden stores. It is controlled by J. W. Childs Associates, a Boston-based investment firm. As part of the Country General sale, Fenway Partners Inc. of New York will become a co-investor in Central Tractor.

title: HACH TO REPURCHASE SHARES FROM LAWTER INTERNATIONAL
description: The Hach Company is buying back 3.16 million shares, or 28 percent of its shares outstanding, from Lawter International Inc. for about $60 million. Hach, a maker of water analysis kits, said late on Thursday that it would pay $19 a share to buy Lawter's entire stake. Hach intends to hold onto the shares and not use them for other purposes, said Mary McCray, assistant to the vice president. Shares of Hach, which is based in Loveland, Colo., rose 68.75 cents, to $18.9375. Shares of Lawter, based in Northbrook, Ill., which makes specialty chemicals, rose 18.75 cents, to $12.125.

Modelo, Mexico's largest brewer, makes Corona and other beers. Seeking growth markets outside the United States, Anheuser, based in St. Louis, paid $477 million for its initial stake of roughly 18 percent in 1993. Anheuser said the purchase, expected to close later this year, would increase its investment in the company to $1.6 billion.

title: Hong Kong's Colonial Ghosts
description: These pictures, on display at the Asia Society in Manhattan as part of the exhibition ''Picturing Hong Kong: Photographs 1855-1910,'' are artifacts from the peak era of European colonialism. We can agree that they are beautiful, some perversely so. Their meaning, however, is in flux. The group portrait of W. C. & Company, with Chinese employees in Western dress, probably looked unusual in 1860, while the disjunction of the Chinese street with the Western plague inspectors in white may appear even stranger to later, more culturally homogenous generations than to us. Which is odder, native servants in traditional garb, or Asian streets that look like Rome or Madrid? That Europeans presumed to remake the world in their image, or that there were once cultures that owed nothing to Western ideas or aesthetics? As colonialism comes to a ritual end, even as its momentum persists, these images haunt us twice over, with the ghosts of the past and of the future. LUC SANTE

title: Escaping All Boundaries With Noise and Delicacy
description: Whether or not electronica turns into the next big thing, it is already stirring ideas among musicians. Rickie Lee Jones has spent her career mixing pop, jazz, beat poetry and folky simplicity in songs that drift wherever she wants, eluding the strictures of verse-chorus-verse. Now, on her new album, ''Ghostyhead'' (Reprise), she has discovered the open-ended soundscapes of trip-hop, giving her new ways to blend the worldly and the ethereal. On the album, her new songs are reveries, quiet and mysterious. But on stage at Irving Plaza on Tuesday night, she transformed them into amalgams of lowdown noise and eerie delicacy.

title: The Business Behind Those Nights of Music

Not only does the JVC Jazz Festival have a handful of nights given over to record companies, but at the Knitting Factory, several record labels have become sponsors as well. There is no free lunch, and with the corporate support come corporate shows. At the Knitting Factory last week, the guitarist Bill Frisell was featured for a whole night. His record label, Nonesuch, is a festival sponsor. JVC Jazz has several nights linked to record companies. George Wein, who runs the show at JVC, calls them what they are, with titles like ''Blue Note Sings and Swings'' and ''Verve Records Presents.''

title: Nuclear Plant Can Reopen
description: Federal inspectors gave the Salem II nuclear power plant a clean bill of health yesterday, saying they would allow the reactor to reopen. A team from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission spent about 1,500 hours over two weeks examining machinery and questioning staff at the plant, which has been plagued by equipment and management problems, Curtis Cowgill, the team's leader, said. The plant was closed in 1995.

title: NUGAS AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED BY TARRAGON OIL
description: Nugas Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Tarragon Oil and Gas Ltd. for about $75 million (Canadian), or about $54 million (United States). Nugas, based in Calgary, Alberta, said its shareholders would receive $3.60 (Canadian)in cash and about 40 cents in stock of a new exploration company to be managed by Nugas senior personnel. The stock rose 48 cents, to $3.68, on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The new company will retain Nugas's exploratory lands in Canada and the United States, together with certain producing properties and will have initial production of about 100 barrels of oil equivalent a day. Tarragon will also assume $18.4 million (Canadian) of Nugas debt.

title: The Opium War's Secret History
description: Losers rarely name wars, an exception being the conflict between Britain and China from 1839 to 1842, known bluntly ever since as the Opium War. To most Chinese, a century of humiliation began with this war, in which Westerners sought to force a deadly drug on an Asian people, and then imposed an unequal treaty that pried open their country and annexed the island that became Hong Kong.

title: CHAIRMAN SAYS THERE ARE NO TALKS WITH POSSIBLE BUYERS
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., whose shares have surged 73 percent this year amid speculation the firm is a takeover target, is not talking to potential acquirers, the company's chairman has told employees. ''Let's say just one more time -- DLJ is an important and highly profitable part of the Equitable family, DLJ is not for sale, and no discussions are under way with any imagined potential acquirers,'' DLJ's chairman and chief executive, John Chalsty, said in a memo to employees. The memo was also signed by the president of the Equitable Companies, Joseph Melone. Equitable owns 73 percent of Donaldson, Lufkin, whose shares fell $3.375, to $60.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: What Education Really Needs
description: Barry Edelson's tenure article $(''Is Tenure Fair? You Bet It Is!'' June 15$) is a prescription for greater ossification and not more flexibility so necessary to meet the needs of students. What is required is a clear and articulate aim and objective of public education, which would include the working conditions, free of the obfuscations of vested interests and local censorships along with a reporting system to evaluate students, teachers, methods, principles and administrators, would obviate the need for tenure. The failure to be flexible and meet student needs causes an increase in the number of dropouts. Continuing this failure is another form of systemic child abuse.

A scrambly, international marathon of early-1900 autos, it carries the likes of Tony Curtis, Natalie Wood and Dorothy Provine, under Blake Edwards's blithe direction. The show-stealer is a sneering and villainous Jack Lemmon (above with Peter Falk). Expect a few lulls but not many. For the record, a song called ''The Sweetheart Tree'' copped an Oscar as the year's best ballad and then disappeared -- SATURDAY at 11 A.M. on FAM. Howard Thompson

title: CUSTER BLUSTER
description: ''This is just a new way of disrespecting him,'' says Bill Wells, a California-based devotee of George Armstrong Custer. Wells is ticked off because the National Park Service, which supervises the Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument in Montana, is pushing ahead with a plan to build a monument to the Indians who carried the day 121 years ago this month. The design looks sensitive enough -- it's a simple earthen mound incorporating bronze ''tracings'' of three warriors -- but Wells says that the proposed placement, about 20 yards from a monument to the slain 7th Cavalry, is ''right out of hell.'' Gerard Baker, who is part Mandan and part Hidatsa Indian and the park's superintendent, replies that it is also the will of Congress, which mandated a privately financed monument in 1991. As for the unsolicited art criticism, he shrugs it off. ''Bill Wells does not accept change,'' he says, ''but it's coming.''

title: Circling Lake Erie by Bike
