I was enamored of the water that stretched all the way to Canada, of the sunsets flaming across an open sky. Later the lake lost some of its glow as pollution levels rose, and we found other places to go. Now that Lake Erie is clean once more, I decided to explore it again -- the whole thing -- in the most intimate way I could think of: by bicycle.

title: A Movable Farce
description: Delightful and decidedly goofy, Jean Echenoz's novel BIG BLONDES (New Press, $22) has one at its center -- the fleetingly famous chanteuse Gloria Stella (nee Gloire Abgrall), who fled from the public eye upon the suspicious demise of her agent-lover. Her seclusion is complete until a trash television producer named Paul Salvador picks up the trail while in pursuit of his two abiding interests: ''What ever happened to?'' celebrity stories and the blondes of the book's title. When Salvador's private detectives begin closing in, Gloire reacts with feral rage, hurling one of her pursuers off a cliff and leading the rest on a chase from Paris to Sydney to Bombay. In Mark Polizzotti's translation from the original French, Echenoz's modus operandi is parody played so broadly it occasionally borders on farce; he delights in savaging mass media cliches like television docudramas or action-adventure movies. Though these are not new or difficult targets, Echenoz dispatches them with gleeful silliness. He doesn't spare his own work in the process, using sporadic asides to treat his novel as cavalierly as any of his other subjects. ''We already know the deal,'' he writes at one point, ''so let's get this over with quickly and move on.'' What's not to like about such a considerate author? Liam Callanan

title: SALLYING FOURTH
description: *The Fourth of July can be a long haul for Congressmen from sprawling districts -- Scott McInnis, a Colorado representative whose home district is larger than Florida, rides tiny charter planes between several far-flung stops, nibbling on dry cereal to curb his appetite for hot dogs. *South Dakota's only Congressman, John Thune, slogs hundreds of miles on two-lane roads. *''It's like a marathon,'' says John Baldacci, whose Maine district is the largest east of the Mississippi. *There are, of course, limits: Don Young, an Alaska Republican, represents all 570,374 square miles of the state but confines himself to a couple towns in the southeast. Couldn't he go all the way? ''Impossible,'' says a spokeswoman. ''and everyone knows it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROACH, CONSTANCE
description: ROACH-Constance, 93, died on June 23, 1997, in Orinda, California. From 1942 until retirement in 1963, Miss Roach enjoyed a successful career in government service, beginning during World War II in the Office of War Information, Washington, DC. In 1947, she became a member of the UNESCO Relations Staff in the Department of State. She joined the Foreign Service in 1955 and served as a Political Officer in the U.S. Mission to NATO in Paris from 1956-1963. She helped organize many chapters of the League of Women Voters, 1928-1942. Born in Carthage, MO, on October 23, 1903, Miss Roach is survived by one sister, Mrs. Emily White of Redding, CA, and by many other relatives and friends. Funeral services were held in Orinda, CA. Burial will take place at Forest Hill-Calvary Cemetery in Kansas City, MO. Memorial donations: The Natural Resources Defense Council, 40 W. 20th St., New York, NY 10011 or the Women's League, First Congregational Church of Oakland, 2501 Harrison St., Oakland, CA 94612.

title: Boston
description: FORGET stuffy dioramas and dimly lighted, pedantic exhibits. Children these days will grow up thinking of museums as lively, colorful places where they do as much as they see, and where learning is approached with more levity than gravity. The concept of a museum expressly designed for children emerged in 1899, with the founding of the Brooklyn Children's Museum. And since the mid-1980's, with the onset of the baby boomlet, institutions with waterworks and climbing structures, bubble-blowing equipment and gigantic insects have sprung up around the country, designed both as attractions for the youngest tourists and as sites for educational programs in their communities. There are now more than 200 in the United States, according to Janet Rice Elman, executive director of the Association of Youth Museums in Washington. Five contributors visited major children's museums in cities across the country. Here's what they found:

title: Tropics Below Canal
description: When Karen Nason opened a tropical plant store in TriBeCa last month, she noticed that the neighborhood lacked trees. So she installed seven 30-foot trees in concrete pots on the northwest corner of Franklin Street and West Broadway. These are palm trees, grown on the Florida farm owned by Ms. Nason and her husband, Chris Krstic, brought north by truck and lifted into the pots by crane. They will be returned to Florida in October, when the weather turns cold. ''I wanted people to walk around and think they were in South Beach,'' the hip section of Miami Beach, Ms. Nason said. She also figures the palms' size will deter thieves. Judy Duffy, who lives on West Broadway, said she had considered asking the city to plant trees. ''Now I can wait,'' she said, ''at least until fall.'' BERNARD STAMLER

''There were big 'danger' signs posted all over the place, and I was petrified,'' he says. ''And it was driving me crazy to have to stand there and be afraid of this cliff. It was like doing the first episode of 'Fresh Prince of Bel Air,' '' the NBC sitcom in which he starred for six seasons. ''But my reaction to being scared is to attack what I am afraid of. So I jumped off the cliff.''

title: The End of Tenure?
description: Tenured professors are held in such contempt that just about everyone feels free to demonize them. But while the country fixates on the cloistered academic with the cushy job for life, tenure is actually withering of its own accord. Data from the United States Department of Education and the American Association of University Professors show that only about 25 percent of America's 1.2 million college teachers are tenured -- a proportion that is surprisingly small and decreasing. In addition, of current full-time faculty who do not have tenure, only about 40 percent are eligible to apply, down from about 60 percent two decades ago. Most college teachers can look forward to part-time work at best. Almost half of four-year faculty and 65 percent of two-year faculty are part-timers.

title: Clip-Clopping to the 19th Century
description: MACKINAC ISLAND has never been an ordinary sort of place. The local Indians, mostly Ojibwa and Huron, considered it sacred, using it only for ceremonies and summer fishing. French Jesuits perched briefly in the 17th century at the tiny island where Lake Huron meets Lake Michigan, but French fur traders were more persistent. Mackinac (pronounced Mackinaw) was first a French trading post, then an English trading post and fort. After the War of 1812, John Jacob Astor made the strategic island (now American) the western headquarters of the American Fur Company, and over $3 million in pelts left the Market Street warehouse in 1822 alone. When the fur trade dried up, the island became an important Great Lakes fishing port.

title: Cooperstown
description: More than two centuries after it was founded by a New Jersey transplant named William Cooper, Cooperstown still seems to rise out of an unspoiled wilderness to greet the traveler like a snug village stuck in time. Nestled on the south shore of placid Otsego Lake -- dubbed Glimmerglass by the novelist James Fenimore Cooper, William's son -- the village is rimmed by verdant hills, beyond which are rolling cornfields and a brown creek called the Susquehanna, just beginning its journey to the Chesapeake Bay.

title: The Buss About Firefly
description: ''Feeding the lion'' is how Max Metral describes his visits to Microsoft headquarters. Metral is the 24-year-old chief of technology at Firefly Network, a small Internet software company based in Cambridge, Mass., and one evening in February, he and his partners flew to Seattle to spend the next day showing off Firefly's software, which has aroused a good deal of investor interest. One of the Microsoft engineers, who have elevated the techno-put-down to high art, glanced at Firefly's software and concluded, ''We could do that in a week.'' But they did seem interested in Firefly's business plan, Metral recalls. When the meetings were over and the Firefly team drove back to Sea-Tac International Airport, they had not only fed the lion but also felt the fear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKER, ALFRED B.
description: HECKER-Alfred B., 90, of Danbury, CT, formerly of Manhattan, on June 24, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Tatiana (Brajnikov) Hecker. Mr. Hecker was born in Alton, MO on July 15, 1906. He attended Harvard University and graduated college in England, where he became a Chartered Accountant. He served in the U.S. Army during World War II and held the rank of Captain. As a young man, Mr. Hecker worked for the accounting firm of Price-Waterhouse. He later worked as Chief Auditor for Standard Oil Company (Exxon), retiring in 1968. Mr. and Mrs. Hecker had a vacation home in Bridgewater, CT, where they lived after his retirement, moving to Danbury about ten years ago. Mr. Hecker was a patron of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in NYC. He is survived by a niece, Eugenia McCoy, and a grand niece, Valerie McCoy, both of Sarasota, FL. Funeral services were held at St. Tikhon Monastery, South Canaan, PA. Burial was in St. Tikhon Cemetery. Green Funeral Home, 57 Main St., Danbury, CT., 203-748-2131.

title: Looking for Summer Magic in London

title: Blending Shakespeare With the Community

The idea was to get everyone in tune with the bittersweet, classic comedy to be performed in Pinkney Park in Rowayton starting next Wednesday.

title: New Visions of the Cosmos Now That It's Close at Hand
description: FROM THE PLUCKY COMET that upstaged the ''Adoration of the Magi'' in Giotto's Scrovengi Chapel frescoes in Padua to the fiery swirls of van Gogh's ''Starry Night,'' celestial objects have long fascinated artists. Whistler, Goya and Paul Klee also studied the heavens after dark. During the last 50 years, however, breakthroughs in astronomy and space exploration have changed how artists portray the cosmos. Where once it glittered with remote objects onto which romantic longing could be projected, it now beckons with reachable destinations, whose topographical details -- craters, ice fields, volcanic ridges -- have been revealed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, ELIAS A.

In the spirit of ''Noblesse Oblige,'' his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquility Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that our 79th camp season will begin on July 2, 1997. Tranquility Camp Inc. Earlton, New York Pearl C. Miller, President

title: A Crash in Space Heard Around the World
description: For 11 years, Russia's Mir space station has whirled around the earth. But after a violent collision between the Mir and a cargo spacecraft last week, experts have begun to wonder if the Mir's glory days have ended.

title: The Other Abstract Expressionist
description: Joan Mitchell, one of the major artists of the Abstract Expressionist movement, is not as well known as she deserves to be, in part because she spent the later decades of her life in France, but also, as Klaus Kertess makes clear in JOAN MITCHELL (Abrams, $60), because she was a woman. Kertess, an adjunct curator for drawings at the Whitney Museum of American Art, does a wonderful job of re-creating the context in which Mitchell (1926-92) first made her mark -- the heavily male-dominated New York art world of the 1950's, when Pollock and de Kooning and heavy drinking reigned supreme. Both artists had an impact on her, as did van Gogh, Cezanne and Matisse. The poet Frank O'Hara was among her friends, as was Samuel Beckett later in Paris. Poetry and nature inspired her work, which Kertess describes by calling the ''precarious balance between vastness and containment, storminess and order'' a ''hallmark of Mitchell's paintings.'' A passionate, sometimes irascible woman, Mitchell in her will directed Kertess to write the text for this volume, which includes 120 color plates; it is the most complete study of her work to date. Robin Lippincott

title: Bettman Gets Involved in Sale of Islanders

title: SEE MYANMAR'S VIRGINS!
description: Apparently, Myanmar (formerly Burma) uses only pure ingredients as tourist bait. An article in Today -- an English-language tourism magazine published in the Asian nation -- calls Myanmar ''The Land of Virgins and Restful Nights'' and boasts about ''trademark'' virgins with ''clear skin.'' Sounds lewd, but in fact the magazine is controlled by Myanmar's strict military regime, and the wording is meant to contrast the country's squeaky-clean women with the decadence of, say, Thailand's. ''We want to convey how much we value virginity,'' says Thet Lwin, Today's executive editor. Well ... nice try. ''Most visitors go away highly satisfied with their visit to the Land of Pagodas,'' Today clumsily sums up. ''and -- now that you know -- of virgins, too.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARVEY, RITA MORLEY
description: HARVEY-Rita Morley, whose career as an actress embraced television, radio and theatre and who, in the 1950's, while serving as a spokeswoman for The Coty Company, was dubbed ''America's Most Televised Girl,'' died Saturday, June 28, 1997, at the McLean Home in Simsbury, CT, after a long battle with cancer. She was 69. During the 1950's and 60's, Ms. Harvey, whose professional name was Rita Morley, was featured in continuing roles on many of television's leading soap operas, including ''As The World Turns,'' ''Edge of Night,'' ''Secret Storm'' and ''Brighter Day.'' She was also featured in numerous productions of ''Studio One,'' a mainstay of live televsion drama during television's ''Golden Age'' of the 50's. As The Coty Girl, Ms. Harvey made as many as twelve live and televised appearances daily. She also appeared on Broadway in ''The Seven Year Itch'' and ''The Impossible Years.'' Long a member of the Board of Directors of the American Federation of Televsion and Radio Artists (AFTRA), Ms. Harvey was the author of ''Those Wonderful, Terribble Years,'' the story of the union's early history as it coped with the notorious 1950s blacklist. The hardcover editon was published last year by the Southern Illinois University Press. At one time, Ms. Harvey also wrote a gardening column for the Westport News, where she alternated as a columnist with the now famous Martha Stewart. The widow of the late Kenneth Harvey, a popular actor and former AFTRA National President, Ms. Harvey also served on the Board of the Screen Actors Guild. Ms. Harvey, who live in Stamford, CT, is survived by a sister, Ellen Chorches and by a brother, Morley Gann, both of whom live in West Hartford, CT, where Ms. Harvey was born. Funeral services will be held Monday, June 30, 1997, at 1 PM, in the chapel of the Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Ave., Hartford, CT. Memorial donations may be made in Rita Harvey's memory to the McLean Home, 75 Great Pond Rd., Simsbury, CT 06070.

He served as a major in the US Army during World War II in England. title: What's a Nice Jewish Lawyer Like John Rosenberg Doing in Appalachia?
description: The first time John Rosenberg drove into David, Ky., in the early 1970's, fresh from Washington and eager to fight the War on Poverty, he was struck by how little there was there. What once had been a thriving coal camp of a hundred homes, a company store, a swimming pool and ballfields had become an Appalachian shantytown of boarded-up shacks. When the coal was mined out, the company abandoned David, Ky., selling the town to an absentee landlord. On the day that Rosenberg appeared out of the East, 30 tenant families remained. Untreated sewage flushed into the creeks. Residents had to cart in their drinking water. People giving directions to David joked, ''It's right on 404 -- you can't miss it, unless you get lucky.''

''Then it hit us,'' said Donald Bussolini, the BID's manager of capital projects, ''we need benches.''

title: Once Upon a Time, a Princess Married a Prince . . .

At $25 for a photo session, the Conservatory Garden may well have the best bargain in the wedding budget (the Botanic Garden is $200). Opulent white bridal dresses and veils are the most popular, many drawing on earlier periods, like the 1870 silhouette with parasol, top left, and the slim 1910 Edwardian silhouette, bottom left, with its voluminous veil and cascading flower bouquet. Below center, the wedding party is a tea-rose-color take on 18th-century style, including parasols and fans, while the embroidered white sari-style dress, top right, draws on an even older tradition.

title: Martial Bliss Comes to Madame Bovary
description: LIEUt. Col. Emma (Bo) Bovary brushed the hair from her brow with a hand both delicate and strong. Her face was smooth and unscarred, but the fine lines of care were beginning to etch the limpid ivory of her complexion. On the lot outside her office, frost limned the dull metal of the idle tanks and armored vehicles with the pale, chill light of loss. Colonel Bovary sighed. How had it happened that she, a woman of passion and subtlety, a woman who had dreamed of Thermopylae and Agincourt, had found herself in such an unhappy union, mercilessly yoked, at least until retirement with a full pension, to an institution so lacking in romance as the United States Army?

Some evenings she declines invitations from friends so as not to lose a jealously guarded space, which often takes up to an hour to find. On Sundays, Ms. Bodner's parents, who live in Douglaston, pick her up for family functions so she won't have to move her light blue Cutlass Ciera. ''We can't live under these conditions,'' Ms. Bodner said. ''You want to move.''

title: Rethinking Diabetes
description: New guidelines issued last week for diagnosing diabetes reflect an urgent goal: to spur early detection and treatment and so prevent devastating complications like blindness, amputations, kidney failure and heart disease. An estimated 16 million Americans have diabetes, but only half have been diagnosed with the disease.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

description: MOST homeowners are familiar with the common three-hole electrical receptacle. Two slots accept the flat prongs of a standard plug. These, the hot and neutral, allow the current to flow through an appliance and return to the ground, making an electrical circuit. The third hole accepts a half-round prong. This is for the ground circuit. It provides a safe escape for stray electricity that may leak through loose connections or frayed wires in the appliance.

title: Natasha Kablaoui, A. S. Brodsky

Kablaoui of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alexander Simon Brodsky, the son of Vivian Brodsky and Dr. Marc Brodsky of Washington. The Rev. Lisa Ward, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the West Park (N.Y.) Winery.

title: A Purveyor of Rarities Is Back in Business
description: HE is the archetype of the ''ugly American'' -- and a cad, or so it appears. B. F. Pinkerton, a Navy lieutenant stationed in Nagasaki, Japan, loves and leaves his geisha bride, Cho-Cho-San, his ''pretty little plaything,'' his ''moon maid,'' with child (whose name is Trouble). He promises to return one fine day, and does, with his American wife, Kate.

title: Gilkey's Bat Wakes Up to Spark the Mets' Victory
description: Pirates Manager Gene Lamont is a nice man who would never intentionally humiliate anyone in everyday life. But he demonstrated utter disdain for slump-ridden Bernard Gilkey tonight and, of course, Lamont was entirely justified.

title: New Jersey Is Betting The Future On Wall St.
description: In the summer of 1982, with the stock market 22 percent below where it had been in 1966, stocks were understandably unpopular. In the 15 years since, the Dow Jones industrial average has risen 895 percent. Now, stocks are so popular that a state government has opened a margin account.

title: A Chancellor's Fate
description: For seven years, W. Ann Reynolds has served as Chancellor of the City University of New York. How much longer she will continue is anyone's guess.

title: Helen F. Ladd, Edward B. Fiske
description: Helen F. Ladd, a professor of public policy studies and economics at Duke University in Durham, N.C., is to be married there this afternoon to Edward B. Fiske, the author of The Fiske Guide to Colleges (Times Books/Random House). The Rev. Dennis Campbell, the dean of Duke's Divinity School, is to perform the ceremony at the University Chapel.

title: Ann Smith and David Peipers
description: Ann Emily Smith, a dancer, and David Harald Peipers, an investment manager, were married yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Thomas K. Tewell performed the ceremony.

title: Regulating Financial Advisers: Are States Up to It?
description: COME July 8, there will be a huge shift in responsibility for monitoring investment advisers. And while many investors are barely aware of the change, it may subject some of them to a worrisome gap in regulatory protection.

title: From an Effervescent Era of Tipplers in Top Hats
description: TWENTY-ODD YEARS AGO, Stephen Visakay went to a garage sale and came home with his first cocktail shaker. Chrome-plated and shaped like a tall, thin teapot, the shaker, a 1930's relic, cost him just 50 cents. It was also twin to one that his mother had won as a trophy during a youthful turn with the Top Hats, a roller-skating club.

title: Shackles of Addiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of the Rocker, Ready to Roll
description: MY grandmother was a loyal Buick owner. A mechanical draftsman, she appreciated the refined engineering and solid structure that had long been Buick attributes. A widow who often traveled to visit her grandchildren, she felt secure and comfortable in the cavernous interiors. I recall Christmas Days when I helped her unload gifts and tins of homemade goodies from the immense trunk of her 60's-era Electra. And for years before she died last year, she drove a LeSabre from the early 80's; though it was full-sized, she considered it small compared with Buicks she had previously owned.

title: U.S. Faces Acid Test in El Salvador
description: The young forwards Jovan Kirovski and David Wagner will get no warnings about the perils of soccer in El Salvador. No cautions about the hail of coins that shower players on corner kicks. No reminders of the State Department's advisory on possible fan violence. No speeches about the solid wall of sound created by the 35,000 spectators shoehorned into Cuscatlan Stadium and the 10,000 more cheering from an adjoining hill.

title: Ado Over Plenty o' Nuttin'
description: THE ''RHAPSODY IN BLUE'' of George Gershwin is the most familiar, most performed and, as they say in the entertainment world, highest-grossing piece of 20th-century music. It is also the most protean. Since its premiere, in 1924, it has taken ever-changing forms, from multiple concert versions of varied lengths and orchestrations to 15-second commercial sound bites.

title: Classical Briefs

title: Style Standard for Early Steel-Framed Skyscraper
description: OLD-LINE preservationists still mourn the demolition of the elegant 47-story Singer Tower, built in 1908 at Broadway and Liberty Street, one of the big architectural losses of the 1960's. But an earlier and perhaps more important Singer building survives, at Broadway and Prince Street, and a $1 million restoration campaign has workers disassembling and repairing the unusual iron and terra cotta facade.

title: Seeking a Modern Co-op, Finding a Victorian Ideal
description: THEY thought they'd go on renting forever. Then, they thought maybe they'd look for a co-op. Then, their real estate agent insisted they look at a small house in Cobble Hill in Brooklyn.

title: For the Plane to Everest
description: IT'S not your father's National Geographic.

title: Dr. Forest Dodrill, 95, Pioneer In Use of Heart Pump Machine
description: Dr. Forest D. Dodrill, a pioneer in the use of mechanical heart pumps to assist in heart surgery, died on Monday in Baltimore, where he lived. He was 95.

description: Amid hundreds of children and a pile of luggage at the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Friday, Da-Nisha Banton sat quietly reading her book, ''Buck-Buck the Chicken,'' eagerly awaiting her first Fresh Air Fund vacation.

title: Finally! Federal Law For Boxing
description: IN other boxing eras, the names on the fight posters were enough to sell tickets: Ali-Frazier, Marciano-Walcott, Louis-Schmeling, Dempsey-Tunney. Now the big fights, like movies and plays, have marquee titles befitting their show-biz market.

title: Casual Dining by the Brook, Beneath the Boughs. And Don't Forget Napkins
description: Summer arrived a week ago, and with it came the heat and humidity that springtime had managed to keep at bay. Air-conditioning is fine as an antidote, of course, but nature has its own cooling rewards: woods, streams, cliffs, ponds, meadows and sky.

title: After Marine on Patrol Kills a Teen-Ager, a Texas Border Village Wonders Why
description: It was an encounter between four camouflage-clad United States marines and a young man herding his family's goats on a rocky, desolate bluff of desert above the Rio Grande. It ended when one marine fired his M-16 rifle and hit the teen-ager, Esequiel Hernandez Jr., who bled to death on a windswept hill overlooking his adobe home and the cemetery where he was buried a few days later.

title: On Top of Pop, But Not With One Voice
description: PAULA COLE STANDS ON THE lip of the stage of the Vogue, a trendy club in downtown Indianapolis. With her angelic face and innocent demeanor, she looks just like the prom queen she was a decade ago in the little seaside town of Rockport, Mass. ''I will do the laundry if you pay all the bills,'' she sings in a sweet soprano from her current hit single, ''Where Have All the Cowboys Gone?'' ''Where is my John Wayne? Where is my prairie son? Where is my happy ending? Where have all the cowboys gone?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, ELIZABETH, PH.D.
description: MINTZ-Elizabeth, Ph.D. Died after after a long illness on June 23rd, at the age of 83. A psychotherapist in private practice in New York City, she was a leader in the human potential movement. She authored numerous articles in professional publications and two books. She was the widow of Alexander Mintz, Ph.D., Professor of Psychology at City College of The CUNY and is survived by her son Harvey Mintz of Hastings on Hudson, NY and her daughter Ann Mintz Wagner of Harrisburg, PA. She will be mourned by her family and her many friends. Memorial service Thurs., July 16, 7PM NPAP Meeting Rm 150 West 13th st. NYC

title: Residents Go Indoors For Some Sunday Fun

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILHORAT, ADE T. M.D.
description: MILHORAT-Ade T. M.D. We deeply mourn the passing of our longtime friend, whose pioneering research conducted at New York Hospital in the 1940s and great concern for the patients he served sparked the creation of MDA, the world's foremost agency dedicated to the defeat of neuromuscular diseases. He guided development of MDA's research program for more than two decades. His scientific acumen made possible many significant achievements that have brought us to the treshold of delivering treatments and cures for a host of diseases, many of them catastrophic. With profound admiration and gratitude for Dr. Milhorat's unparalleled contributions to MDA's lifesaving mission, our heartfelt condolences go to his two sons, daughter, and their families. Jerry Lewis, National Chairman Robert M. Bennett, President Robert Ross, Senior V.P. & Executive Director Board of Directors Muscular Dystrophy Association

A willful 12-year-old boy, having stowed away on his older brothers' cross-country trip, calls home to beg his mother's permission to travel with them as they shoot their first nature documentary. Without her support, the boy will have to spend a boring summer down on the family farm.

title: In This Old House, a Jewel

He and a friend bought a vintage 1890 brownstone on West 121st Street for $20,000. Over the next few years Mr. Jackson painstakingly restored the interior, stripping and refinishing the mahogany and other wood trim and plastering, painting and furnishing the house with items from secondhand stores and trash bins. In 1994, he sold the house for $225,000. Today it is on the market for $599,000.

title: How the World Sees Us

Yeah, yeah, we Americans are youth obsessed, materialistic, politically naive, culturally insensitive, sexually adolescent, yada, yada, yada. Tell me something I don't know. And don't get me started on the rest of the planet.

title: Right Pitch, Wrong Pitchmen
description: It is not often that New York City residents experience a big improvement in services overnight. But that will happen on July 4, when the city's mass-transit system becomes one big single-fare zone. Guaranteeing that everyone's trip to work will cost only $1.50, even if it involves both a subway and a bus ride, is an unarguably good thing.

title: Irwin Rosen, 93, Harvard Square Bookshop Owner
description: Irwin Rosen, a Harvard Square bookseller who sold esoteric works to two generations of academics and weathered the rise of superstores, died on Thursday at Youville Hospital in Cambridge. He was 93 and lived in Cambridge.

description: THERE is a standard format to political fund-raisers these days, and in most ways the $500-a-plate event that New York City Public Advocate Mark Green held the other night at the Sheraton Hotel in Manhattan stuck to it.

title: The Federal Government will allow a group of companies to unify administration of 27 patents.
description: THE Justice Department has given a consortium of eight companies and Columbia University a green light to combine 27 patents into a single portfolio and license the inventions under the direction of one administrator. A spokesman for the Justice Department said the decision on Thursday appeared to be the first time its antitrust division had approved such a patent clearinghouse.

title: Charles O'Neill, 87, TV and History Writer
description: Charles Kendall O'Neill, a writer of history, radio and television scripts and short stories, died on June 19 at his home in Green Farms, Conn. He was 87.

title: Treasury's Auction Schedule
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

description: REGAN-James P. On June 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Florence. Loving father of Brian and Maureen Regan Clark. Dear grandfather of James, Erin and Brianna. Fond brother of Helen Regan. Lifetime resident of NYC, veteran of World War II, retired Battalion Chief, FDNY, founder of James P. Regan and AssociatesInstitutional Fire Safety Consultants. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILHORAT, ADE T. M.D.
description: MILHORAT-Ade T. M.D. We deeply mourn the passing of our longtime friend, whose pioneering research conducted at New York Hospital in the 1940s and great concern for the patients he served sparked the creation of MDA, the world's foremost agency dedicated to the defeat of neuromuscular diseases. He guided development of MDA's research program for more than two decades. His scientific acumen made possible many significant achievements that have brought us to the treshold of delivering treatments and cures for a host of diseases, many of them catastrophic. With profound admiration and gratitude for Dr. Milhorat's unparalleled contributions to MDA's lifesaving mission, our heartfelt condolences go to his two sons, daughter, and their families. Jerry Lewis, National Chairman Robert M. Bennett, President Robert Ross, Senior V.P. & Executive Director Board of Directors Muscular Dystrophy Association

title: Mr. Clinton and the Cities
description: The urban initiatives recently announced by President Clinton look dismayingly timid. They will prove important only if they signal a strong effort by the Administration to win Congressional approval for more than $10 billion worth of urban initiatives proposed earlier. But even if Mr. Clinton gets every dime of the money, it will not be nearly enough to mend urban blight.

title: Cries of the Dying Awaken Doctors to a New Approach
description: In a Baltimore neighborhood of simple brick houses, where geraniums edge the lawns in cheery bursts of pink and red, an old woman is dying. On a sweltering summer afternoon, she is in bed, frail and frightened, waiting for her doctor to arrive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANE, WINTHROP MURRAY III
description: CRANE-Winthrop Murray III. Age 86, of 101 Main St, Dalton, MA. Retired vice president of Crane & Co, died at his home on Saturday, June 28, 1997. A memorial service will be held in the First Congregational Church of Dalton on September 6, 1997, at 11 AM, with Rev. Robert R. Kyte, pastor of the church, officiating. Private burial in the Main Street Cemetery, Dalton, will be at the convenience of the family. Memorial donations are suggested to the Berkshire County Chapter of the American Red Cross, or the Berkshire Museum of Pittsfield, MA, in Mr. Crane's memory. Among survivors are a daughter-in-law, Mrs. Nancy Stroebel of Andover, CT, a granddaughter, Katherine Ann Crane Francis of Tolland, CT, and two great-grandchildren, Kevin Andrew Francis and Rachel Ann Francis. Reposing at the BartlettWellington Funeral Home, Dalton.

description: The voting in Albania's parliamentary elections, which many feared would be marred by extensive violence, proceeded more smoothly than expected today. But from scattered results, the party of President Sali Berisha appeared to be losing, and it remains unclear whether he will accept the results.

But John Woo, Hong Kong's most celebrated filmmaker, whose movies are almost operatic in their excess, insisted that the flamboyant violence stamping his work resembles a ballet, almost ethereal, even otherworldly.

The second one, yesterday, had the feeling of V-E Day at Piccadilly Circus in 1945 and England's World Cup victory at Wembley in 1966.

description: The Nationsbank Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., will announce this morning that it is acquiring Montgomery Securities of San Francisco for about $1.2 billion in cash and stock, people familiar with the transaction said yesterday.

description: HONG KONG  Call it karaoke diplomacy. The lights are dimmed. A bottle of Scotch is passed around the table. The karaoke machine whirls into action and Chinese and other Asian diplomats settle in for an evening of diplomacy away from the glare of the world's news media.

description: William L. Turnbull Jr., an architect whose early collaboration with Charles Moore led to a career of buildings that earnestly and profoundly expressed a sense of place, died Thursday at his home in Sausalito, Calif. He was 62.

description: Nationsbank Acquisition Of Montgomery Seen Today

title: For a New World, a New NATO
description: It was raining hard on April 22, 1993. Hundreds of guests sat in a soggy tent on the South Lawn of the White House, waiting for the President to begin a moving ceremony marking the opening of the Holocaust Museum. The dramatic weather reinforced a moment that was filled not only with moral imperative, but also with strategic possibility. For it marked the origin of the American policy to expand NATO.

title: McGann Surges to Victory With a Torrid Final Round
description: After birdies, an eagle and a double-bogey in the first two rounds, par was the word for Annika Sorenstam today on the first 15 holes in the final day of the $900,000 ShopRite L.P.G.A. Classic, and it cost her the title.

description: The nation's 62-year-old welfare system, condemned last year by Federal law, will formally die on Tuesday, and a season of state legislative debate has brought new clarity to the decentralized system rising in its place.

description: VULTAGGIO - Marion. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Loving mother of RoseAnn Rochford and Don. Loving grandmother of Christopher, Diana, Wesley and Spencer. description: With all but a few sections of the upper tier filled, the New York Liberty was welcomed home to Madison Square Garden yesterday by a hugely enthusiastic crowd that generated the energy customary at a big Knicks game.

description: The event Hong Kong has so long expected is just about here, and local newspapers are covering almost every angle, down to the details of the handover ceremony and the logistics of how the Chinese Army will march in.

title: G.O.P. Freshmen Agree to Stop Push for Fund-Raising Curbs
description: The prospects for any campaign spending legislation have suffered another blow as House Republican leaders have persuaded their freshmen to stop cooperating with Democrats on a bill to prohibit ''soft'' money, donations to political parties outside of Federal limits on amounts and sources.

title: Body Is Identified As That of Drowned Girl
description: A body found on Rockaway Beach in Queens has been identified as that of a 14-year-old girl who disappeared a week and a half ago while swimming, the New York City police said yesterday.

description: A gas station attendant in Chelsea died early yesterday after he was shot at least six times at close range, the police said.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Yankees Emerge On Top In Slugfest
description: Joe Girardi, a survivor of the war of attrition that the Yankees won, 11-10, against the Indians yesterday, likened it to a heavyweight fight. Cleveland's Kevin Seitzer, for one, did not know just how right Girardi was.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMOROFF, SAMUEL
description: KOMOROFF-Samuel, age 92, died June 28. Lawyer and entertainer. He is survived by his daughter Ellen Reiss, son Brooks, grandchildren Steven, Robert, Michael and Eric, and great-grandchildren James and Joshua. Services Monday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Mexican Conglomerate Abandons Cuban Phone Venture
description: Hamstrung by American economic sanctions and its own financial problems, Grupo Domos, the Mexican conglomerate that has been the largest foreign investor in Cuba, has relinquished its stake in the Cuban telephone company and withdrawn from the island.

title: New Leader of Military Will Need Right Answer
description: When the military's senior field commanders convened behind closed doors at the Pentagon last week, the hottest topic of discussion was not the budget, gulf war syndrome or protecting troops overseas from terrorist attacks.

title: New Treasurer to Take Reins
description: Twenty-six years after he began his career as an auditor trainee in the tax division of the State Department of the Treasury, James A. DiEleuterio Jr. is to assume command of the agency tomorrow as State Treasurer.

title: CLINTON TAX PLAN BACKS G.O.P. IDEAS
description: President Clinton will announce on Monday a revised tax-cutting proposal that his aides describe as an effort to give middle-class taxpayers somewhat deeper reductions than those passed overwhelmingly by the Senate on Friday, but one that accepts a number of the main concepts pressed by Republicans.

title: Cameras In the Courts
description: New York's valuable but still supposedly experimental law that allows television cameras in courtrooms expires at midnight tonight. The Assembly plans to consider an extension today for the fifth time in 10 years, and the State Senate may take it up tomorrow. But passage is not guaranteed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBMAN, ESTHER
description: LIBMAN-Esther. Most cherished and beloved wife of the late Max. Most wonderful, precious mother of the late Florence, Shelley Israel, Norman and Edwin. Much loved mother-in-law of the late Lester Israel, Barbara and Phyllis. Adored and irreplaceable grandmother to the late David, Peter Libman, Mark Israel (Jennifer), Dr. Michele Libman, Marlene Zekser (Michael), and Jonathan Libman. Loved great-grandmother of Glenn Zekser. Beloved sister Ethel Altman and Aaron Gottfried. A true woman of valor. We love you, and will remember and love you always and forever. Services today, 11:30 AM, at ''Boulevard Riverside Chapels,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Romeos and Juliets Galore
description: Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet'' has almost everything. There is the thundering Prokofiev score, along with Nicholas Georgiadis's richly detailed costumes and imposing sets through which all of Verona seems to sweep, repeatedly. The ballet also offers career-making dramatic opportunities. Unfortunately, it is undersupplied with dance.

title: For Lieberman-Cline, Game's Past Meets Its Future
description: This was unlike any women's basketball crowd Nancy Lieberman-Cline remembered from the dead old days. For not only was it significantly larger -- a professional record of 17,780 -- but the treble was much higher, an ear-splitting sound straight out of Nickelodeon's Kids Choice Awards.

title: Singer Who Reaches Out and Connects
description: In Patti LaBelle's Carnegie Hall concert on Saturday night, 80 minutes and 3 outfits long, the power points arrived when she touched her fans. Ms. LaBelle continually accepted flowers and cards from the audience throughout the show, and she knows how to say thank you.

title: Swipes Gain on Plunks as Metrocard Takes Off
description: After more than two years of being largely shunned by New York City commuters, the Metrocard is finally replacing the token as the currency of choice for many mass transit riders, with its use doubling in the last six months.

title: New Service Skims 150 Newspapers for Its Users
description: In the spring of 1995, a partnership of large newspaper companies formed the New Century Network to bring the country's dailies into the age of the Internet. Then they sat down to figure out what that meant.

title: INSIDE
description: Top Military Officer Search

title: A Rock at First Base, Martinez Keeps Focus
description: If Joe Torre gained anything from the 1996 season, aside from a championship ring, it was the satisfaction derived from a low-maintenance, veteran club that did little else but concentrate on playing ball.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Homosexual imagery is spreading from print campaigns to general-interest TV programming.
description: AS more mainstream companies aim sales pitches at homosexuals as part of efforts to reach segments of the general consumer market, images associated with gay men and lesbians have become increasingly prevalent in print advertisements for products as disparate as Absolut vodka, American Express travelers checks, Subaru automobiles and Gardenburger vegetable patties.

title: Asia Times Stops Printing
description: Sondhi Limthongkul, a Thai entrepreneur, said last week that he would halt publication of The Asia Times because of a cash-flow crisis at his flagship daily newspaper. Mr. Sondhi said he wanted ''to re-evaluate the business side of Asia Times'' before restarting it in two to three months. But analysts said the newspaper -- the centerpiece of Mr. Sondhi's plan to build an Asian media empire -- would probably not reappear on newsstands.

title: At Home in Roswell, and on the TV Screen
description: In a documentary with the provocatively slanted title ''Roswell: Cover-Ups and Close Encounters,'' Jonathan Frakes explains, ''Over the past few years, various film clips and photographs have surfaced that were purported to be actual images of alien life forms.'' Mr. Frakes, best known as Commander Riker on ''Star Trek: The Next Generation,'' is the narrator of this surprisingly rational Sci-Fi Channel program about the New Mexico city where something fell out of the sky 50 years ago this week. (Maybe it was balsa wood, maybe a spy satellite, maybe a little gray uncle of E.T. Those things are so easy to confuse with each other.) ''So far no pictures have been verified as being genuine,'' Mr. Frakes concludes.

title: Penguin Sues Ex-Credit Aide As Embezzler
description: With an accounting-scandal investigation drawing to a close, the Penguin Group has concluded that a $163 million black hole in its balance sheet began with an elaborate scheme that subsidized a credit director's eclectic taste for diamonds and Louis Vuitton leather, Home Depot hardware and cruises aboard the Monarch of the Sea.

title: Mayor Says Cash Needed For Workfare Union Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he was willing to begin talks with a New York City union about its efforts to organize the city's 35,000 workfare participants, but said the union leaders would have to lobby the Federal Government to cover the increased costs.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about a statue of the Indian leader Crazy Horse referred incorrectly in some copies to the rank that George Armstrong Custer held at his death. Custer attained the rank of major general of volunteers in the Civil War. When the Army was reorganized after the war, he was given the rank of lieutenant colonel in the Seventh Cavalry.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A week ago, a chance remark at a Foreign Policy Association luncheon sent the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting.

title: Marsh Takes Senior Open By Keeping His Composure
description: The man from Down Under finally reached the top today.

title: Lowell Paxson has a dream: to start yet another television network.
description: WHEN Lowell Paxson, the ebullient founder of Paxson Communications, bought his 50th television station, Channel 31 in New York, he began publicly promoting his plan to start yet another television network. ''I want to be the United States Post Office of eyeballs,'' exclaimed Mr. Paxson, the king of infomercials, who invented the interactive home shopping business back in 1977.

title: Digital 'Watermarks' Assert Internet Copyright
description: Playboy magazine, which has been plagued by on-line piracy of its pictures of scantily clad and nude women, is planning to announce today that it will place a digital ''watermark'' on its images in its most aggressive move yet to stop copyright infringement.

title: Suspect in Japan Beheading Is Linked to 2 Other Attacks
description: As people throughout Japan pondered the shocking news that a 14-year-old boy had been arrested for the slaying and beheading of an even younger boy, reports today linked the teen-ager to two previous attacks against children.

title: Literary World, and Joyce, Don't Need Dumbed-Down 'Ulysses'
description: To the Editor:

description: Carlos Baerga cannot play second base, or at least that was what Mets Manager Bobby Valentine was told in the off season, when the team strongly considered shifting Baerga to third. Luis Lopez cannot play short, or at least that was what Valentine was told before Lopez joined the Mets.

title: Protect Children on Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Unrepentant Iraq
description: Six years after the Persian Gulf war, Saddam Hussein remains determined to manufacture chemical and biological weapons and the means to deliver them. The United States must rally a wavering United Nations Security Council to make sure that the Iraqi dictator does not succeed.

title: Bill Seeks to Make Sure Immigrants Get Paid
description: With immigrants pouring into the New York area and vying for the humblest jobs, many are facing a growing and particularly painful form of exploitation: unscrupulous employers who fail to pay some or all of their relatively low wages.

title: U.S. Team Mad at Itself After Settling for a Tie
description: After a 1-1 soccer match that featured a heavy police presence and none of the feared spectator violence, players from the United States left the field at Cuscatlan Stadium today to applause from Salvadoran fans. Alexi Lalas showed his thanks with a thumbs-up salute.

title: Topsy-Turvy Tax Cut
description: Marie McCumbers and her husband, Rickey, have played by the so-called rules for years. They live in Frametown, a little hole-in-the-wall between Clarksburg and Charleston in West Virginia. Mrs. McCumbers is a secretary-receptionist for an organization that supplies food to soup kitchens. Rickey McCumbers is a greenhouse worker. Their combined income this year will be a shade over $20,000.
